html:
‘As Jesus was on his way, the crowds almost crushed him. And a woman was there who had been subject to bleeding for twelve years, but no one could heal her. She came up behind him and touched the edge of his cloak and immediately her bleeding stopped. “Who touched me?” Jesus asked. When they all denied it, Peter said, “Master, the people are crowding and pressing against you.” But Jesus said, “Someone touched me; I know that power has gone out from me.”Then the woman, seeing that she could not go unnoticed, came trembling and fell at his feet. In the presence of all the people, she told why she had touched him and how she had been instantly healed. Then he said to her “Daughter, your faith has healed you, Go in peace.”

I would like to start by sharing with you a letter I came across. It is very relevant to the story we are looking at.

And, it is a type of letter we all might need to write.

Dear Fear-Of-What-Others-Think,‘I am sick of you, and it's time we broke up. I know we've broken up and gotten back together many times, but seriously, Fear-Of-What-Others-Think, this is it! We're breaking up! I'm tired of overthinking my status updates on Social media, trying to sound more clever, funny, and important. I'm sick of feeling anxious about what I say or do in public, especially around people I don't know that well. Because of you, I go through my day with a cloud of shame hanging over my head, I can never live up to the expectations of my imaginary audience, the one that lives only in my head but whose collective voice is louder than any other voice in the universe. And all of this is especially evil because if I really stop and think about it, and let things go quiet and listen patiently for the voice of the God who made me, and the Saviour who died for me, in his eyes, it turns out I'm actually—profoundly—precious, lovable, worthy, valuable. Fear-Of-What-Others-Think. You and I are done. And no, I'm not interested in "talking it through." I'm running, jumping, laughing you out of my life, once and for all. Or at least, that's what I really, really want, God help me!’‘I go through my day with a cloud of shame hanging over my head,’ adapted from https://wonderfullymade.org/2012/04/25/dear-fear-of-what-others-think/ accessed 20/03/2025

Can you relate to this?

Many of us have or are living under the dominate power of shame.

‘Shame affects us in some interesting and destructive ways. That’s because we relate it to who we are and not just what we felt, thought, or did. It eats away at self-image, gradually destroying a healthy sense of identity. Intellectually, we know our identity is secure in Christ, but emotionally, we can see ourselves as uniquely and unforgivably flawed.’ Doug Robinette https://www.healingcare.org/post/shame-a-crisis-of-identity#:~:text=The%20effects%20of%20shame%3A&text=That's%20because%20we%20relate%20it,as%20uniquely%20and%20unforgivably%20flawed. Accessed 20/03/2025

Shame is the prominent form of identity theft, it robs a person of their true selves, causing them to live out of a false and destructive narrative about themselves. When Jesus spoke the name ‘daughter’ over this lady, her heart began to heal, and her identity was restored.

Prayer: Father help me not to live under a cloud of shame, help me to realise

Bible in a year: Genesis 1-3
study_refs: Luke 8:42b-48a

html:
Let me put the story in context.

Jairus, a prominent member of the community and the ruler of the Synagogue, had one daughter who was 12 years old and was dying. He came before Jesus, fell at his feet pleading that Jesus would come and heal her. Jesus went with him along with a crowd who surrounded Jesus. The idea behind the Greek word for surround is to crush or press against. It comes from the Greek word for choke/strangle, so this a very intense moment. Jairus and the crowd are making their way to his home. Lots of people are pressing against Jesus, invading his personal space. Suddenly this woman touches the fringe of Jesus’ robe, and everything stops. Before we pick up the story let’s take a look at this woman.

1. We know that she had an ‘issue of blood’ for 12 years. We can only speculate as to the reason why she was bleeding. This may most likely refers to a chronic vaginal or uterine haemorrhage. We also know from Mark’s account that ‘She had suffered a great deal from many doctors and over the years she had spent everything she had to pay them, but she had got no better. In fact, she had gotten worse.’ Mark 5:26. These doctors would have given her ‘Contemporary remedies which included wine mixed with rubber, alum, and crocuses.’ (D. Bock, Luke [BECNT], 1:793).We also know that because of her condition she would have been constantly living with acute shame, as she would have been viewed as unclean.

a. The Levitical law stated that during a women’s menstrual period she was not permitted to go to the place of worship. See Leviticus 15:19-28. The law in Leviticus was very straight forward setting out what was required. It is not easy to understand why God gave this law. However, by the time of Jesus, the Rabbi's had introduced a whole new set of laws that would make life impossible for any woman with this chronic condition.

b. If a new mother haemorrhaged for more than seven days after giving birth she was put into isolation. If the haemorrhaging continued for a further seven days, her baby was taken from her. A nurse chosen by the priest would look after the baby until the mother was pronounced clean.

c. If the haemorrhaging continued for more than 14 days, she was put into isolation for 40 days, if the problem continued after that she was isolated 120 days. If the problem continued, she was put into permanent isolation reporting to the priest once a year.

This poor woman had been bleeding for 12 years, so she would’ve been considered cursed by God and unworthy of healing. At this point she was officially pronounced dead. Her name would have been removed from the rolls of the living.

d. This meant that she would have had to beg for food, and anyone she touched would have been declared unclean for 21 days. If she touched a religious leader, she could had been flogged on the spot [Roman authorities permitting.] Or she would have been banished to live at Gehenna, a rubbish dump outside Jerusalem. The rabbi’s taught, that if a religious leader did not punish a woman who touched him while she was haemorrhaging, he would inherit her curse.

e. Because she was considered dead this meant that she would have been disowned and despised by all of society. This dear lady was living a terrible life. She was the ‘walking dead.’

Prayer: Father

Bible in a year: Genesis 4-7
title: THE WOMAN WITH THE ISSUE OF BLOOD Part 2
study_refs: ‘ As Jesus was on his way, the crowds almost crushed him. And a woman was there who had been subject to bleeding for twelve years, but no one could heal her. She came up behind him and touched the edge of his cloak and immediately her bleeding stopped. “Who touched me?” Jesus asked. When they all denied it, Peter said, “Master the people are crowding and pressing against you.” But Jesus said, “Someone touched me; I know that power has gone out from me.” Then the woman, seeing that she could not go unnoticed, came trembling and fell at his feet. In the presence of all the people, she told why she had touched him and how she had been instantly healed. Then he said to her “Daughter, your faith has healed you. Go in peace.”

html:
It was into this broken, lonely life shrouded in shame, that the power of Jesus brought about glorious transformation. It’s important to notice that the power of Jesus healed her physical problem, it took away her haemorrhaging, but it did not take away her shame. The instant she was physically healed she was still perceived by others as the same haemorrhaging women. Jesus could have just walked on and said nothing, and the woman could have gone away ‘healed,’ but this dear lady needed a much deeper work done in her life than just physical healing. She needed a work done in her life that could only happen with an honest encounter with Jesus.

Let’s look at how Jesus dealt with this woman.

1. Jesus stopped. As he was on his way to heal the dying daughter of a prominent member of society, Jairus, a somebody, Jesus stopped. Mark tells us that ‘he turned around in the crowd.’ Then he goes on to say, ‘He kept on looking around him.’ Mark 5:30,32. Jesus was intent on engaging with this lady. He wanted to give her something nobody had given her, time.

This amazes me. At this critical point, a time when another desperately needy person was asking Jesus for help, Jesus made space and opportunity for someone who was not even on the social ladder, never mind being at the bottom of the social ladder.

The shame this lady carried, drove her into isolation and acute loneliness and she needed to know that she was valued.

2. Jesus gave her back her voice. Luke tells us, ‘The whole crowd heard her explain...’ then Luke says ‘While he was still speaking to her…’ we have no idea how long this conversation went on for, but it was ended with the news of the death of Jairus’ daughter.

Jesus was ‘present,’ so he was able to listen to this lady’s story.

When the crowd saw Jesus looking around him, they understood that his focus was being redirected and his attention was now on her. Jesus’ actions were saying ‘You are too precious and important to be defined by a chronic illness. You matter and your story is important.

I love the fact that Jesus did not take her aside so she could tell him about her story and healing. Others needed to hear it also, so they were able to see her in a new light and not define her by her past.

3. Jesus redefined her identity.

Daughter’ he said, ‘your faith has made you well,’ Being healed from her haemorrhaging would not be sufficient to remove her shame, she needed to realise who she was. This lady is the only individual that Jesus calls ‘daughter.’ The word for daughter is “thygatēr’’ and it means: “a daughter of God, acceptable to God, rejoicing in God’s peculiar care and protection. In calling her ‘Daughter’ Jesus was changing her status in society. Prior to her encounter with Jesus, she was a nobody, an outcast. Jesus restored her to her rightful position, she was acceptable, a lady of dignity, a daughter of God.

Prayer: Father,

title: THE WOMAN WITH THE ISSUE OF BLOOD Part 3

html:
I would like us to consider one of the best-known stories in the bible. The story of how Peter and Jesus walked on the water.

For many, this well-known story has come to mean something like this. ‘Peter had the right idea, getting out of the boat and quite literally stepping out in faith. Indeed, in all our lives we can see Jesus standing out on the stormy waters of life bidding us to “come unto him.” Like Peter we need this invitation, find the courage of faith needed to swing our legs over the boat’s side and then step out onto the waters. If we do, then we too will walk with Jesus, trusting him alone to help us do great things for God. But beware of doubts and fears! Don’t pay any attention to the winds that howl or the waves that lap against your shins. Keep your eyes fixed on the Master, for if you do, then in his loving confident gaze you will find the strength and courage you need to stay upright. Peter failed to have enough faith, he sank, but you can do better!’

Question: Is this a legitimate and helpful application of this story? Are we being encouraged to be like Peter, to step out of the security of our boats and join Jesus on the stormy waters?

Could it be that this way of applying this story is very dangerous for a number of reasons? [If you would like to know how I think this story could be applied to our lives keep reading over the next few days.]

The dangers of this popular application.

a. It could produce an ego-centric life and ministry.

To be like Peter, to walk on water, to do great things for God, sounds wonderful. However, often the way this story is taught and applied, all it does is appeals to our ego. We all want a theology that strokes our ego.

We think, if I could walk on water. If I could show the world how wonderful and special I am. If God were to really use me in obvious and significant ways then I would feel a lot better about myself. My ego always wants to walk on water.

b. It could produce a performance based mindset.

To apply the story of Peter walking on water as an example of courageous faith, is to make ourselves the centre of our story. We become the focus, and the life of faith, or any ministry we may have becomes about meeting our needs, not the needs of others.

An ego-centric philosophy of life or ministry is not consistent with how Jesus viewed life or ministry. Jesus often told people, ‘don’t tell anyone about this.’ for example See Mark 1:44. 7:36.

When we look at the life and ministry of Jesus you will notice that for Jesus the healing of the individual was more important than his reputation. His ministry was never ego-centric.

Prayer: Father,

Bible in a year: Genesis 11:10-14:13.
title: Have you enough faith to stay on the boat? Part 1
study_refs: “ Immediately Jesus made the disciples get into the boat and go on ahead of him to the other side, while he dismissed the crowd. After he had dismissed them, he went up on a mountainside by himself to pray. Later that night, he was there alone, and the boat was already a considerable distance from land, buffeted by the waves because the wind was against it. Shortly before dawn Jesus went out to them, walking on the lake. When the disciples saw him walking on the lake, they were terrified. “It’s a ghost,”they said, and cried out in fear. But Jesus immediately said to them: “Take courage! It is I. Don’t be afraid.” “Lord, if it’s you,” Peter replied, “tell me to come to you on the water.” “Come,” he said. Then Peter got down out of the boat, walked on the water and came toward Jesus. But when he saw the wind, he was afraid and, beginning to sink, cried out, “Lord, save me!” Immediately Jesus reached out his hand and caught him. “You of little faith,” he said, “why did you doubt?” And when they climbed into the boat, the wind died down. Then those who were in the boat worshipped him, saying, “Truly you are the Son of God.”

html:
Wanting to walk on water is rooted in a need to impress. It is expressing a desire to be seen. It is living out of a belief that, what I can do is more important than who I am. Any desire we have to walk on water, to be impressive is to value achievement above character.

There is a common misconception that God’s will for our lives is primarily about us. Look at what Peter says. “Lord, if it’s you,” Peter replied, “tell me to come to you on the water.” this is a very emphatic, exclusive statement, ‘tell me’ We are inclined to over individualise God’s will. When we are seeking to know and do the will of God we should always be concerned for the needs and blessing of others. Knowing and doing the will of God should be an expression of our love for God and for others. The will of God for our lives will always challenge and undermine our ego and potency for seflish living.

It is important to note that through Peter’s attempt to walk on water, at that time Peter appears not to be thinking about anyone else.

What may have been going on in Peter’s heart?

It may be that Peter’s decision to step out of the boat was motivated by internal conflict and turmoil. Was his choice to step out of the boat his way of trying to manage his insecurities and fears? In this boat, in the middle of a storm. This familiar place was the last place Peter wanted to be.’ A place where he felt filled with uncertainty, fear and confusion. This did not feel like the will of God, but it was!

Prayer: Father

Bible in a year: Genesis 14:14-18
title: Have you enough faith to stay on the boat? Part 2.
study_refs: “ Immediately Jesus made the disciples get into the boat and go on ahead of him to the other side, while he dismissed the crowd. After he had dismissed them, he went up on a mountainside by himself to pray. Later that night, he was there alone, and the boat was already a considerable distance from land, buffeted by the waves because the wind was against it. Shortly before dawn Jesus went out to them, walking on the lake. When the disciples saw him walking on the lake, they were terrified. “It’s a ghost,”they said, and cried out in fear. But Jesus immediately said to them: “Take courage! It is I. Don’t be afraid.” “Lord, if it’s you,” Peter replied, “tell me to come to you on the water.” “Come,” he said. Then Peter got down out of the boat, walked on the water and came toward Jesus. But when he saw the wind, he was afraid and, beginning to sink, cried out, “Lord, save me!” Immediately Jesus reached out his hand and caught him. “You of little faith,” he said, “why did you doubt?” And when they climbed into the boat, the wind died down. Then those who were in the boat worshipped him, saying, “Truly you are the Son of God.”

html:
Peters request to Jesus was an expression of doubt not faith.

“Lord if it is You, tell me to come to you on the water.’’

[a] The very word ‘if’ smacks of doubt, of needing to test something out. There are only a couple of other times in Matthew when someone addresses Jesus through the word ‘if.’ It happens three times in Matthew 4 when in the wilderness the devil repeatedly says to Jesus, ‘If you are the Son of God.’? And in Matthew 27:40, ‘Come down from the cross, if you are the Son of God.”?

[b] The particular Greek word for doubt Matthew uses in verse 31 ‘distazo’ occurs only twice in the whole bible, here and Matthew 28:17. It means ‘to stand in two ways.’ (dis, “double,” stasis, “a standing”) implying uncertainty as which way to take. The kind of doubt that Matthew refers to in this chapter is not a doubt that comes from fear. Rather this is more a rational or logical doubt that says. “Is Jesus who he says he is? Is he what he appears to be?

So before Peter got out of the boat there was a lot going on in his mind.

[c] Nowhere in this passage does Jesus commend Peter for his faith. When people suggest that Peter’s stepping out of the boat was a step of faith, what do they base this claim on? Believing that Peter stepping out of the boat was an act of faith, actually trivialises faith, it turns faith into some magical power that is not related to our everyday living.

[d] His doubt was not the reason why he sank. Matthew says, “When he saw the wind, he was afraid and beginning to sink.” Fear made him sink not doubt.

Peter’s request was a wrong response to a divine revelation.

The NIV reads “But Jesus immediately said to them. ‘Take courage it is I don’t be afraid.” The original Greek does not say ‘It is I’, but ‘I AM”

Here and elsewhere in the gospels, this simple designation powerfully connects Jesus to the God of Israel. When Moses asks God at the burning bush for his name, God says that his name is ‘I AM’ Yahweh is the great ‘I AM.’ At this time these disciples needed to know that Jesus was much more than an earthly king, he was God. Jesus wanted to do for Peter, and the rest of the disciples the same thing that Yahweh did for Moses at the burning bush. He wanted to give them a new revelation of himself, but because of what was going on in Peter’s heart he was unable to grasp who Jesus really was. For Peter, walking on water, doing the spectacular became more important than responding in worship to a new revelation of Jesus.

When our hearts and minds are dominated by our fears and insecurities, we will find it difficult to receive and respond to divine revelation because our focus will be on ourselves.

Ask yourself, what did Peter achieve by stepping out of the boat?

It is true that Jesus invited him to come. But the reason why Jesus invited Peter was very different to the reason why Peter wanted to step out in the first place.

Prayer: . Father,

html:
Peter could not understand why Jesus refused to be King. The crowds wanted to make Jesus king after he had fed them, but Jesus totally refused. Instead he “Made the disciples get into the boat” He compelled them. The word ‘made’ the NIV uses in Matthew 14:22 is sometimes translated ‘compelled.’ The Greek word is anagkazo. The word means to drive or force. This word was used in surgery to describe the force required to repair dislocations.

Sometimes God has to force us into places that make no sense to us. We need to experience the pain of having our dislocated hearts and wills realigned.

Sometimes God’s will for our lives can feel like a dislocation. There seems to be no alignment between our expectations and experience. Our theology and circumstances can be at logger heads. What we expect from Jesus does not tally with the Jesus of our every day lives and we stoically endure the discomfort of dislocations. Finding ourselves in a boat, heading into a storm seems awful timing, and yet being forced into the boat was an expression of the painful faithfulness of God.

Prayer: . Father

The backstory of Peter walking on the water ls fascinating and important. Jesus had just fed over 5000 people. In response to this, the crowd wanted to take Jesus by force and make him king. See J0hn 6:15.

html:
Reasons for Peters insecurity.

Regret or Failure of the past.

This is the second time we find Peter and the disciples in a storm. During the first storm the disciples did not respond very well. ‘Do you not care if we perish?’ In response to their panic Jesus said, “Why are you so afraid, do you still not believe?” See Mark 4:40, Matthew 8:26. Jesus is calling these men cowards and cowardliness is morally wrong, it is not a personality trait (See Revelation 21:8.) I think Peter may have remembered this and how Jesus spoke to them during the first storm.

The word for fearful in this story is only found three times in the New Testament, Matthew 8:26, Mark 4:40 and Revelation 21:8 the word deilos carries the idea of the lack of moral resolve.

It is so easy for anyone of us to be controlled or become reactive to our failure of the past. We can develop an all-consuming desire to prove ourselves. We will take risks in the hope that past failures will be eradicated. We fall for the lie that says that ‘what I do, or achieve, adds value or status to me as a person.’

If I walk on water I will become worthy of respect, people will take notice of me. Being defined by past failure, distorts and destroys the present.

html:
The reason I tell this, is that Peter may have been feeling a bit put out by the success of his brother Andrew.

Being overlooked in the present.

Before Jesus fed the 5000, he asked Philip and Andrew “Where shall we buy bread for these people to eat?” (Perhaps Jesus saw in them a willingness to serve.) We’re really not sure why Andrew was asked, but he was the one who brought the young boy with the loaves and fish to Jesus and so it’s possible that Peter felt out shone by Andrew. Maybe he felt that he needed to do something that made him look just as great and full of faith as his brother. Surely Jesus would be impressed if he walked on water?

Sibling rivalry can become something that poisons life and relationships, and can lead to impulsive actions like stepping out of a boat in the middle of the storm.

History has been touched by sibling rivalry, as has the church [the family of God] where we compare ourselves to others, making life a competition. We begin to endorse envy by default, becoming upset or mad if God uses someone else more than he uses us, when really we should rejoice when God chooses to use others.

Can I suggest that the reason why Peter stepped out of the boat was more likely to do with self-doubt than doubt in Jesus; it was a desperate attempt to compensate for his own vulnerability and insecurity. Peter’s attempt to walk on water did not happen in an emotional vacuum; rather it was an outworking of a man dominated by his insecurity. Motivated by insecurity is akin to throwing away your ministry and making yourself the centre of your world.

Everybody knows that Puma and Adidas are massive global brands reigning the arena of footwear and accessories. However, not everyone knows that both companies that compete for the same audience were founded by brothers Rudolf (“Rudi”) and Adolf (“Adi”) Dassler aka the Dassler brothers. Unfortunately, the relationship between the two brothers strained over the years making them ultimate rivals in business. Both brands started as the brainchild of the Dassler brothers living in Weimar, Germany in the 1920’s, initially working together to create the Dassler Brothers Shoe Factory. For a while, they were the only ones in Germany who manufactured sports shoes. World War II and certain personal disagreements led to hatred between the two brothers. Their feud led to the origin of Adidas and Puma in the year 1947, two giant shoe manufacturing companies, and started a long-lasting rivalry between the two companies. https://www.indiaretailing.com/2023/02/21/puma-and-adidas-were-founded-by-brothers/ accessed 20/03/2025

html:
Trouble in his present.

We read that the disciples were in trouble far away from land. The older versions use the word tossed for trouble. The Greek word basanizo originally means to test, to investigate, to examine and to put to the test. These disciples were in a storm, but also there was a storm inside them. They were in a boat, in a storm, but they were filled with uncertainty and confusion. What they were going through did not make any kind of sense. As most of them were fishermen, they knew that the last place you wanted to be was in a boat in a storm, and yet this is where Jesus told them to go. What was Jesus thinking?

In Mark 6:48 We read, ‘He [Jesus] saw the disciples straining at the oars, because the wind was against them. The Greek word used for straining is the Greek word ‘enantios’ which is used to describe the environment Peter and the other disciples found themselves in. The word ‘enantios’ carries the idea of hostility, or something being against you.

Maybe you are finding that your familiar place is a struggle right now? Perhaps home, or your workplace, or church has become a place of ‘enantios,’ a place of struggle and hostility. And everything in you wants to step over the side and escape the ‘enantios’ the difficult situation that you’re facing.

What should you do? Jump? Or stay and trust God in the storm?

Prayer: . Father,

Shortly before dawn Jesus went out to them, walking on the lake. When the disciples saw him walking on the lake, they were terrified. “It’s a ghost,”they said, and cried out in fear. But Jesus immediately said to them: “Take courage! It is I. Don’t be afraid.” “Lord, if it’s you,” Peter replied, “tell me to come to you on the water.” “Come,” he said. Then Peter got down out of the boat, walked on the water and came toward Jesus. But when he saw the wind, he was afraid and, beginning to sink, cried out, “Lord, save me!” Immediately Jesus reached out his hand and caught him. “You of little faith,” he said, “why did you doubt?” And when they climbed into the boat, the wind died down. Then those who were in the boat worshipped him, saying, “Truly you are the Son of God.”

html:
Physical exhaustion.

Peter, along with the other disciples was very tired. When we are tired, we loose perspective. Before the feeding of the 5000, Jesus tried to find a place to rest with his disciples, see Mark 6:30-31. When we become emotionally and physically drained our ability to make wise choices is often diminished.

When I was a young Christian I was often taught that busyness can lead to barrenness. I fully understand this sentiment and it is very true that people can be so busy serving God that they never take a day of rest, or relax.

But maybe the real problem is that barrenness leads to busyness. In Christian circles people can live with constant fatigue, they live with an addiction to ministry and a loss sense of being dispensable. They end up as driven people who always feel they have something to prove. The loss of any sense off being dispensable is rooted in pride, and can cause people to mistakenly think that God needs them. The good news is that God wants us, but he never has or never will need us.

How does the fact that you are not indispensable or even necessary for the plans of God to be fulfilled make you feel?

Peter’s request for Jesus to tell him to come, he uses a strong word, keleuō which means to command or order, Matthew 14:28. The same word is found in verse 9 when Herod ordered the murder of John the Baptist, this was a word used for a military command. Peter had almost a demanding attitude. He was looking for some kind of authority to justify him getting out of the boat. He did not understand what he was going through, confusion, and doubt filled his heart. So he uses the ‘call’ of Jesus, a call initiated by Peter, to avoid dealing with the stuff going on in his heart.

Of course we would never do that; we would never hide behind the call of God!

Hiding behind the call of God has become a popular occurrence amongst Christians, we say say things like ‘God told me to ….’ we utilize spiritual language or spiritual practices to justify our unspiritual egotistical behaviour.

If we use what we perceive to be a call of God to avoid sorting out the stuff that is going on in our hearts, we will need to eventually sink. Sinking will be a necessity so we can discover the grace of God.

God was going to really use Peter in the future, therefore, it was important for him to learn that being gifted, even gifted to do supernatural things can never bring value, significance or security to a person.

We live in a generation that love the Marvel Movies. Movies that portray people with super human abilities. Being super human is a step towards de-humanisation. There is something in all of us that is tempted to think, that if we process a special ability or power, life would be a lot better or easier.

If Peter was to turn a God given power into a source of security, then he would be in great danger of turning his ministry into a god, and an essential for life. Peter walked on water, but did this make him more whole or secure?

Maybe the best part of Peter’s experience at this time was that he he began to sink.

html:
I am inclined to think that for Jesus this may have been one of the few times he suspended his humanity when he walked on water.

I wonder what would have happened if Peter hadn’t began to sink? Would he have become proud? This was a hard lesson for Peter to learn, he was self confident, he liked to be in control, here he was learning that he did not have to do anything to earn Jesus’ love or acceptance.

Sometimes as Christians we hold unto a subliminal belief that we must prove ourselves in order to be accepted by God. we develop a nostalgic relationship with grace. We tie our experience of grace to some past experience like conversion, or some past service or trial.

We need revelation more than we need ability. Like Peter we will never conquer our insecurities with ability and achievement, we need a continual revelation and a growing understanding of who Jesus is. Revelation and understanding of Jesus is the bedrock of our security. Without these, we will become tired, exhausted people who continually strive for acceptance.

They worshipped Jesus.

Matthew tells us ‘Then those who were in the boat worshipped him, saying, “Truly you are the Son of God.”

The problem is, circumstances and the demands of life are not often conducive to worship, they may even make worship feel inappropriate.

As they worshipped Jesus, their insecurities melted, and their prospectives changed. ‘Truly you are the Son of God.’ This was the first time they worshipped Jesus This was worship in response to revelation. As Christians we need more revelation so the difficult places in life can become places of worship.

Sometimes the last place we want to be is in the boat where we feel fearful, confused and uncertain of what is going on around us. We cannot join all the dots and make sense of our circumstances.

However like Peter, we are on a journey that has been ordained by Jesus. He wants us to stay in the boat until it becomes a place of revelation and worship. That is the purpose of the journey, to discover who Jesus really is.

html:
These verses are completely mind blowing, because for Jewish men to worship God in the form of a man, would have been culturally and theologically shocking. When you think about it these circumstances were not conducive for a time of worship. Here were a group of disciples on the middle of a storm, they had no music, no ecstatic spiritual experience, just fear and insecurity.

Often our circumstances and the demands of life are not conducive to worship, they may even make worship feel inappropriate. However the purpose of the journey, is to discover who Jesus really is. We need to develop a mindset that includes worship in every opportunity. We need eyes that see and recognise Jesus when we’re in difficult situations. This was one of the greatest lessons for these first disciples. We are told, ‘Then those who were in the boat worshipped him, saying, “Truly you are the Son of God. For these conservative Jews to worship Jesus as God would have been thought of as being blasphemous. This was a big moment in the lives of these disciples. The ordinary difficult circumstances of life became a place of worship and revelation. This is the first time we are told that the disciples worshipped Jesus, how exciting that must had been.

html:
I want us to think about the importance of having spiritual ambition. Let us think about this for a moment. When you think about the future, do you ever think about what kind of Christian you would like to be? Do you ever sit and daydream about the kind of relationship you would love to have with God? Do you ever get excited about the possibility of really knowing God? Some of you may be thinking, what is he on? does he not live in the real world, with all it’s rough and tumble, all it’s pain and loss, all it’s demands and expectations, and he is dreaming about really knowing God!

title: The Parable of the Persistent Widow part 2
study_refs: Then Jesus told his disciples a parable to show them that they should always pray and not give up. The fall of the Berlin wall is believed to be the result of prayer. For 28 years the Berlin Wall separated East from West; tearing apart families, friends and neighbours, and denying freedom to millions. The Soviet Union seemed invincible, threatening nuclear destruction, oppressing the innocent and persecuting Christians. Pastor Christian Fuehrer of Leipzig’s 800-year-old Nikolai Church had begun Monday prayer vigils which grew, until a month before the wall fell 8,000 people crammed into city centre churches with 70,000 more outside; carrying candles symbolising non-violence. One witness wrote, “They laid their candles at the feet of the armed soldiers and police. The steps of the STASI building –the organisation that spied on, abused and sold people out – now awash with candles looked like a river of peace and light.” The authorities didn’t know what to do. “We had everything planned. We were ready for anything − except candles and prayers,” one official said.

html:
The history of prayer should create in us all, a good desire to become men and women of prayer. However as I thought about having a desire to have a life that is shaped and defined by prayer, on the surface this appeared to be a good and noble desire although, I realised in some ways that it is not really recognising what Jesus is hoping for when he tells this parable.

When Jesus says that his disciples should always pray and never give up, he is not speaking about his hopes and aspirations of a few highly dedicated people who take prayer very seriously. Rather he is addressing an intrinsic need of every Christian. In other words, you and I have a God given need to become people whose lives are being shaped by the ongoing practice of prayer.

Redefining the practice of prayer.

When Jesus told this parable, He was saying that we ‘should always pray.’ When these disciples heard this they would have been surprised. According to Leon Morris ‘Jesus’ teaching goes beyond that of the Jews, who tended to limit the times of prayer lest they weary God. Three times a day (on the model of Daniel 6:10) was accepted as the maximum’.https://www.preceptaustin.org/luke-18-commentary. Accessed 23/04/2025

Like the ancient Jews, we have developed a ‘cookie cutter,’ approach to prayer. What do I mean by that? We can develop a prayer life that takes on a formalised shape. So we pray at a certain time in a certain place and in a certain way. Now this is a great practice which should be encouraged, however, the problem is we can reduce our prayer lives to this practice and not be fulfilling what Jesus said when he said, ‘we ought always to pray.’ Is Jesus being unrealistic? Is he asking too much? No, what he is saying is that prayer and praying with others should be a natural spontaneous reflection of our everyday lives.

Let me give you a few simple examples:-

You’re in the car and your in conversation with your spouse or a friend, and as you talk, it may be a good thing to say, let us pray about that issue. Our you get a round church prayer text about someone in the church, why not send them a prayer by text. Or you having a family discussion around the meal table, why not pray about the issue you are talking about. Or if someone comes into your mind, just pray for them. Or if you facing a difficulty a work, just stop and ask God for wisdom and help. The point is that prayer needs to be part of the fabric of life, of all of life, not just a ‘cookie cutting’ experience.

Father, help me see all of life as an opportunity for prayer.

study_refs: Then Jesus told his disciples a parable to show them that they should always pray and not give up. But finally he said to himself, ‘Even though I don’t fear God or care what people think, yet because this widow keeps bothering me, I will see that she gets justice, so that she won’t eventually come and attack me!’ And the Lord said, “Listen to what the unjust judge says. And will not God bring about justice for his chosen ones, who cry out to him day and night? Will he keep putting them off? I tell you, he will see that they get justice, and quickly. However, when the Son of Man comes will he find faith on the earth?”

html:
”Understanding the reason for prayer.

If I were to ask you why we should be a praying people, we would all come up with very different answers. But I don’t think many of us would have come up with the same answer as Jesus. When you read the NLT translation of 18:1 you could think Jesus is saying something like, ‘you should always pray and never give up praying.,’ I am sure Jesus’ words may infer that, but that is not what he is saying. He is saying ‘incorporate prayer into every area of your life so you won’t grow weary, grow faint, loose heart and become overwhelmed with discouragement. Or to put it another way. Through prayer let your relationship with God be an integral part of every area of your life so you won’t be overwhelmed by the challenges of life.

We need to keep in mind the context of the parable. Jesus had just taught about the coming kingdom. We do not know when Jesus will return to bring justice to his world. How long will it be? So how do we handle all the injustice we see all around us? How do we keep going and not give up?

The word used for give up is the Greek word egkakeo, which means to not grow weary or lose heart, which in essence is really a "positive" admonition to keep on keeping on, to endure, to persevere despite obstacles, setbacks and adversaries. But the word has a second meaning. It was used to describe the act of committing culpable neglect, or doing ill. Perhaps there can be a strong correlation between these two meanings, we give up and others suffer.

Martin Luther said, ‘Prayer is the most important thing in my life. If I should neglect prayer for a single day, I should lose a great deal of the fire of faith.’

The greatest motivation for prayer, is God himself.

Often when you read the parables of Jesus it can be difficult to grasp what he is saying. We know that the purpose of this parable was to redefine our understanding of prayer. But the question, is how does it do that? We can be sure that Jesus is not telling us that if we pray to God in the same way this widow, who wore this judge down with repeatedly pestering him, then God will answer us. That doesn’t mean that we should not be persistent in prayer. But the point of this parable is to show us how unlike God is to this unjust judge. Jesus is showing us a contrast between God and the unjust judge. This unjust judge answered this widows cry for justice, merely to shut her up, to get her off his back, he did it to get a quiet life. If a godless uncaring judge was prepared to give this widow what she needed, how much more will a loving God do. A God who cares for his chosen people who cry to him day and night.

It can be very easy for anyone of us to become like this poor widow. She was destitute with no one to fight her corner. Her lack of confidence in the unjust judge fuelled her desperation. The more he resisted her cry for help the more desperate she became, Like the widow we to can allow a lack of confidence in God to produce in us an exhausting feeling of despair. Sometimes that despair is expressed in an unhealthy anger which feels like resentment towards God. At other times we can develop a silent desperation. Our confidence in God has gone and we stop praying, resigning ourself to the belief that nothing will change. The writer of Hebrews tells us that we can come with confidence to God, (Hebrews 4:13). Having confidence in God is having a settled belief that God’s response to our prayers is always appropriate.

What Jesus is saying in this parable is very profound. The only way we can develop into people whose lives are defined by prayer is to know Gods character. The glorious goodness of God’s unchanging character will always stimulate prayer. Maybe one of the reasons why we struggle so much with prayer is because our distorted views of Him prevent us from really knowing him. As we gaze upon his beauty and are distracted by his glory we will find ourselves wanting to pray. God is nothing like this unjust judge, he is kind and compassionate, he cares and understands, and his heart is for us. That is why we can pray at all times.

Jesus gives us a better understanding of the life of faith.

In Luke 17, Jesus had been teaching on his second coming, and the parable of the widow and the unjust judge was given to help us to live faithful lives until Jesus returns. So in verse 8 Jesus says ’When the Son of man returns, how many will he find on earth who have faith.’ The scary thing about this verse is its context. Is Jesus using this parable as a means of gauging faithfulness? Is the faith he longs to see expressed through those who always pray and never give up? When Jesus returns, we all want to hear the words ‘Well done my good and faithful servant. In some ways this parable gives us all an opportunity to hear these words. Jesus could have defined faithfulness in lots of different ways, but He chose to use something that everyone of us can do no matter who we are, that to pray always without giving up.

Let me close with this question. ‘Would you like to become a man/woman of prayer, or do you need to become a man/woman of prayer?’ Let us not give up. Let us make prayer part of every area of our lives.

Prayer: . Father,

html:
John 10 is one of the best-loved chapters of the bible, for many Christians it has been a chapter that has brought much comfort and encouragement. Verses like, ‘I have come that they may have life, and have it to the full, 10:10 or I give them eternal life, and they shall never perish; no one can snatch them out of my hand.’ 10:28

The problem is because it is so well known we are inclined to come to it with our assumptions. When Jesus first spoke these words they were not intended to be a source of comfort or encouragement, rather they were a challenge against the bad shepherding practices of the Pharisees and the religious leaders of His day.

To help us understand the context we need to go back and just take a quick look at the last few verse of chapter 9;40,41 Some Pharisees who were with him heard him say this and asked, “What? Are we blind too?”Jesus said, “If you were blind, you would not be guilty of sin; but now that you claim you can see, your guilt remains. In those verses we are given a moral infantry of the Pharisees who were bad shepherds of Gods people. The interesting thing about these verses is that Jesus does not talk about the ‘activities’ of the bad shepherds or their theology, but their characters.

A bad shepherd is someone who refuses to be honest with themselves. Look at the question they asked Jesus. ‘What? Are we blind too?’ John 9:40. This is a very interesting question that reveals a lot about the Pharisees. They were unable to evaluate their own lives; they lived in denial, and could not cope with reality. They were blind to their blindness. They were unable to correctly evaluate their own spiritual condition. They found comfort in lying to themselves about themselves Often people find it easier to deal with other peoples problems than deal with their own, this is a common form of denial and self-deception.

A bad shepherd is some one who has a confused morality. Jesus said in response to the Pharisees question, “If you were blind you would not be guilty of sin.” In other words your claim not to be blind makes you more calculable for your sin. Because you think you have spiritual insight and understanding, you are more more guilty of sin. Any refusal on our part to make honest and spiritual evaluations about ourselves will result in us having wrong perceptions and making wrong judgements about others.

A bad shepherd is one that lives under guilt. Jesus concludes in verse 41 with saying ‘but now that you claim you can see, your guilt remains.’ Jesus is not speaking here about being motivated by guilt; rather he is speaking about living under the condemnation of God. To live under condemnation in essence means that a person has no freedom, they are condemned, and they are slaves to something or some one. Without freedom we will not be able to serve others.

The bad shepherd is someone who lacks honesty, morality and freedom. These people may not have set out with the intention of being bad in the sense that they are unable to implement good pastoral care for others, rather their bad shepherding is the symptomatic and spontaneous result of their character. They were unable to do the good things that a good shepherd should do, not because they were uninformed about the responsibilities of a shepherd. Rather, because of a flaw in their characters they were unwilling or unable to fulfil the role of a ‘good shepherd.’

Father,’help me to develop the character of a good Shephard.’

Bible in a year: Exodus 5:10–8:15
title: Laying down your life for the sheep Part 1
study_refs: “ I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd lays down his life for the sheep. The hired hand is not the shepherd and does not own the sheep. So when he sees the wolf coming, he abandons the sheep and runs away. Then the wolf attacks the flock and scatters it. The man runs away because he is a hired hand and cares nothing for the sheep. “I am the good shepherd; know my sheep and my sheep know me—just as the Father knows me and I know the Father—and I lay down my life for the sheep. have other sheep that are not of this sheep pen. I must bring them also. They too will listen to my voice, and there shall be one flock and one shepherd The reason my Father loves me is that I lay down my life—only to take it up again. No one takes it from me, but I lay it down of my own accord. I have authority to lay it down and authority to take it up again. This command I received from my Father.”

html:
I am the Good Shepherd

When Jesus says ‘I am the Good shepherd and the Good Shepherd lays down his life for His sheep,’ what is He saying? It is very easy to put a post-Calvary interpretation on what Jesus is saying here, and assume that Jesus is speaking about his death on the cross, but in doing this we are taking the verses out of context, and missing the point. Although there may be an allusion to the death of Jesus, this is not its main point.

In making this passage about the death of Jesus, we will subconsciously detach or distance ourselves from it. This will cause us to turn ministry into more of a convenience than a calling, because we will never believe that God would expect us to ‘lay down our lives for the sheep.’ and yet this is precisely what God expects. Irrespective the ministry we may have been called to, it will require us to live a ‘laid down’ life. Irrespective the gifts we may or may not have, we will need to live a laid down life, if we are gong to authentically reflect Jesus and meet the needs of others.

The people who originally heard Jesus speak these words would not have associated them with His redeeming death on a cross.

A good shepherd will risk his life to protect the sheep, but that is different from laying down one's life. The shepherd, who risks his life for the sheep does not expect to die, but expects to live. Occasionally, a shepherd will die in an encounter with animals or thieves, but most will not. They plan, not to lay down their lives through death, but to lay down their lives through a selfless live.

A wise shepherd would not plan on loosing his life, for he knows that this would be of no benefit to his sheep; he may have an accident, or he might be attacked by thieves and robbers, but to deliberately plan to loose his life would be very serious for his flock. A shepherd who dies leaves the sheep defenceless, so the only good shepherd is one who is alive.

Jesus did not lay down his life on the cross. The cross was only possible because he had already laid down his life.

So what does it mean to ‘Lay down your life?’

The word Jesus uses four times in this passage for lay down is the Greek word tithemi which means to set in place, to establish, to ordain. In Acts 20 v28 Paul has summoned the elders from Ephesus together and to them he says, "Take heed therefore to yourselves and to the flock over which the Holy Spirit has made you overseers . . ." The word "made" is a translation of the Greek word tithemi. 1 Tim 2:7: Paul was ordained a preacher and an apostle. The word "ordained" is the Greek word tithemi.

So to ‘lay down’ your life is to have your life in the right place, to find God’s ordained purpose for it.

Father, thank you that it has been ordained that we all lay down our lives

title: Laying down your life for the sheep Part 2

html:
To ‘lay down’ your life is to live as a sacrifice so you can spontaneously minister unto the needs of others.

To lay down your life is to cultivate a mindset that refuses to allow your life to function on the basis of selfishness.

Laying down your life is more about character than heroism; it is more about the simple, apparently incidental life choices we make every day, than some gallant grand gesture we might make in the face of some crisis or calamity.

Laying down your life is to see every day as an opportunity to serve and encourage others.

I think if we make it into some kind of supper heroic act then it robs us of honour of exercising everyday mundane servant-hood.

The only way we can avoid laying down our lives is to resist the purposes of God and live outside his will.

Laying down your life will look very different for different people, and how it looks in practical terms is up to every individual to work out. A guiding principle in working the practical implications of living a ‘Laid down life,’ is that your paramount concern is the welfare and needs of others.

How do we lay down our lives?

As we unpack this passage we will discover that we will never lay down our lives if we are motivated with shame or guilt. Nor will we be able to lay down our lives simply by determination or effort; rather the life that is laid down for the sake of others is first and foremost an expression of character. Laying down our lives for others is more about an expression of our natures than it is about responding to the needs of others. Jesus gives four reasons why he lay down his life for the sheep. It is more about the people we are than the spiritual gifts we may have.

[a] The Good shepherd lays down his life because he is good.

‘I am the good shepherd, and the good shepherd lays down his life for the sheep.’ The word good (Greek: kalos) shepherd. Barclay notes that there are two Greek words for good. The first is agathos, which "simply describes the moral quality of a thing." The second is kalos, "which means that a thing or a person is not only good; but in the goodness there is a quality of winsomeness, loveliness, attractiveness which makes it a lovely thing." It refers to someone who was more than just a good person. https://www.trinitycoatesville.org/sermons/whats-good-about-a-shepherd-2/

They would also be someone that we could count on to be there for us in a time of crisis. Someone who would offer us support, prays for us, or brings meals by for us. They would be the person that we could call in the middle of the night without reservation if we needed them.

In Classical literature the word kalos was a picture word that was used to describe

A Suitable Harbour.

A Healthy Body.

Pure genuine gold.

An unblemished sacrifice.

[b] The good shepherd lays down his life for the sheep because of the relationship he has with them.

‘I am the good shepherd; I know my sheep and my sheep know me- Just as the Father knows me and I know the Father- and I lay down my life for the sheep.’

I think this is one of the most profound verses in the New Testament.,,

Jesus models his relationships with people on his relationship with his father, ‘I know my sheep and my sheep know me- Just as the Father knows me and I know the father.’ The implications of these words are very scary. If we were to have the same kind of relationships with people that we have with God, what kind of community would we be? The heart attitudes that a person needs to know and love God, are the same heart attitudes we need to know and love people.

We cannot say that we love God and hate our brother. The only way we can lay down our lives for God is to lay it down for people

Because Jesus knew his sheep he laid down his life. It is easier to live a sacrificial life in order to help a friend than it is to help a stranger.

Many people in positions of leadership struggle with fulfilling their God given responsibilities because they are emotionally disengaged from those they are trying to serve and lead. Knowing the sheep will help the shepherd to lay down his life. If you understand and care for the people God has made you responsible for, you are going to want to lay down your life in order to show your love for them.

Father, help me to be mature enough to lay down my life.

Bible in a year: Exodus 12:1-14:20
title: Laying down your life for the sheep Part 3
study_refs: “ I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd lays down his life for the sheep. The hired hand is not the shepherd and does not own the sheep. So when he sees the wolf coming, he abandons the sheep and runs away.Then the wolf attacks the flock and scatters it. The man runs away because he is a hired hand and cares nothing for the sheep. “I am the good shepherd; know my sheep and my sheep know me—just as the Father knows me and I know the Father—and I lay down my life for the sheep. have other sheep that are not of this sheep pen. I must bring them also. They too will listen to my voice, and there shall be one flock and one shepherd The reason my Father loves me is that I lay down my life—only to take it up again. No one takes it from me, but I lay it down of my own accord. I have authority to lay it down and authority to take it up again. This command I received from my Father.”

html:
We have been thinking about how Jesus laid down his life for the sheep. He did it because his sheep know him. Jesus said ‘I know my sheep and my sheep know me.’ Part of the process of laying down your life is to become known. It is to open yourself up, becoming vulnerable, sharing your pain, weaknesses, and sin. The laid down life is one were there are no masks, pretences or performances, but honest openness. Knowing and being known are essential if we are going to find God’s appointed place for our lives.

‘The reason why my Father loves me is that I lay down my life.’ It would be very easy to conclude from this verse that Jesus was saying that he needed to earn his father’s love by laying down his life. We know from the scriptures that God’s love cannot be bought or earned, so how are we to understand these words?

Could it be that Jesus’ willing sacrifice elicited the Father’s eternal love in a fresh way? For example, I have loved Caroline for over 25 years. Now if she does something that reflects her love for me, which would cause my love for her to well up in a fresh way so that I say, “I love you for doing that for me.” The love was there before her deed, but her deed called forth my love once more

I think Jesus is saying that when he laid down his life it did not cause God to love his Son. But it caused the love God had for his Son to to well up inside him. Maybe this is Jesus’ way of saying that the lad down life brings great joy and pleasure to God. The laying down of Jesus' life for the sheep is an act that expresses to the world that Jesus felt secure in his father’s love. Because Jesus felt secure in his father’s love he was prepared to lay down his life and eventually die on the cross.

The kind of ‘laid down life’ that God is looking for is only possible when we are feeling secure in the love of God. Feelings of insecurity will prevent a person from living a sacrificial and laid down life, because insecurity encourages and develops selfishness within a person. The more we receive and enjoy God’s love the more secure we will be, and the more secure we are the more equipped we will be to lay down our lives.

The security Jesus felt meant that he had the authority to lay down his life. ‘No one takes it from me but I lay it down of my own accord. I have authority to lay it down and authority to take it up again.’ This is alluding to Jesus’ death, but in this context it is primarily referring to how Jesus lived. The word that John uses for authority literally means ‘unrestricted possibility or freedom of action.’ In other words Jesus was free enough to lay down his life.

When a person is free because they feel secure in the love of God, then they will be prepared to meet the demands and sacrifices that the Christian life demands. We cannot live the life of a Christian without a conscious knowledge of God’s love. Knowledge of God’s love is the most effective sanctifying and freeing influence a person can experience.

In laying down his life for others Jesus was outworking the natural consequences of obeying his Father’s commandments. ‘I have authority to lay it down and authority to take it up again. This commandment I have received from my father.’ In our western culture we have over individualised obedience, but every time we obey the word of God, it is not solely for our own individual and personal benefit, but it is also for the enrichment and encouragement of others. Obedience to the commandments will equip a person for his ordination, it will make a laid down life a reality.

With that in mind, let me mention our understanding of abundant that Jesus refers to in verse 10. . Abundant life is not an individualistic experience; rather it is the result of feeling secure within the flock. . Abundant life is a relational quality that is discovered in the midst of community. Abundant life is an impossible individual experience.

Father, may my love for you be seen in me laying down my life for others

The man runs away because he is a hired hand and cares nothing for the sheep. “I am the good shepherd; know my sheep and my sheep know me—just as the Father knows me and I know the Father—and I lay down my life for the sheep. have other sheep that are not of this sheep pen. I must bring them also. They too will listen to my voice, and there shall be one flock and one shepherd The reason my Father loves me is that I lay down my life—only to take it up again. No one takes it from me, but I lay it down of my own accord. I have authority to lay it down and authority to take it up again. This command I received from my Father.”

html:
Understanding the hired hand.

It is important that we look at the role of the hired hand as described in verses 12-13. The description Jesus gives us of the hired hand is the antithesis of a lay down life. The life that is laid down is the opposite in attitude and actions of the hired hand.

Many people, when they read what Jesus says about the hired hand think that he was someone who set out with the premeditated intention to harm the sheep and cause havoc in the flock. Jesus says. ‘The hired hand is not the shepherd who owns the sheep. So when he sees a wolf coming he abandons the sheep and runs away. Then the wolf attacks the flock and scatters it. The man runs because he is a hired hand and cares nothing about the sheep.’

There is nothing bad or wrong about being a hired hand. The word John uses is misthotos was used to refer to day labourers working for a wage of normally one drachma per day. It is unlikely a shepherd would hire a hand for the day, if he knew that the hired hand was intending to harm his flock and destroy his livelihood.

Although this hired hand did not set out with the intended purpose of harming the sheep, the pressures and demands of the job exposed flaws in his character, which made him a threat to the sheep. So what kind of person was this?

He had more fear than courage. Because of his lack of courage he was controlled by fear, making him unable to fulfil his responsibilities and deal with the realities of the job, ‘when he sees a wolf coming he abandons the sheep and runs away.’ Our level of commitment to people is reflected in the amount of courage we show.

Often people can begin a ministry with every intention of being faithful and committed to the work God has called them to, often they start with every intention of showing care, however, when problems arise they can often abandon their responsibilities because of a lack of care and courage..

He is more concerned with the protection of self than the protection of the sheep. Jesus said ‘when he sees a wolf coming he abandons the sheep and runs away.’ Notice that this hired hand had no contact with the wolf; he didn’t abandon the sheep after he had some physical contact with the wolf, but when he saw the wolf he ran away.

The word thaat John uses for ‘see’ in this passage is the Greek word theoreo. Theoreo denotes ‘deliberate contemplation.’ The perceptions we hold are never accidental or enforced upon us, rather they are the result of deliberate and considered thinking, be that right or wrong. So when this hireling saw the wolf his understanding and considered conclusion was, ‘I’m scared I need to get out of here.’ His running and abandoning the sheep may have the appearance of being spontaneous and not thought through, but it wasn’t. It was the result of deliberately formed perceptions that governed his life.

The hired hand in Jesus’ story was more concerned about himself than he was about the sheep; it was natural for him to avoid difficulties and confrontation in order to save his own skin. A bad shepherd will avoid confrontation, and refuse to deal with problems that may arise in case he damages his reputation, for him pleasing people is more important than facing and tackling difficult issues.

This hired hand had unrealistic expectations. Was he surprised that a wolf would attack the flock? Was he not hired with the expressed purpose of protecting the sheep from possible predators like wolves? This hired hand was not prepared for something that was likely to happen ‘The hired hand will run away.’ Twice Jesus tells us that the hired hand will run. ‘He abandons the sheep and runs away.’ The word for run is the Greek word pheugo where we get our English word fugitive from; it literally means ‘to seek safety in flight’ or ‘to escape from danger.’

In Christian ministry people often run away, sometimes this literally means running away, leaving work or moving geographically. But more often the running away can be a more subtle and less obvious. People become emotionally detached, they build walls, they loose their passion, doing the very least they can get away with doing, for in their hearts they have run away.

Running away is never a benign or an exclusively individual experience, Jesus tells us. ‘Then the wolf attacks the flock and scatters it.’ In other words, when we run others suffer. Running away may feel totally personal, but it never is and never can be. When we are trying to avoid truth, responsibilities or circumstances, others will suffer because of our avoidance of reality.

The word used for scatter is the Greek word "skorpizo." The root of the verb means, ‘to pierce!’ It gives us the English word "scorpion." Having a lack of courage, pursuing self-protection and running away from responsibilities, circumstances and truth will be a sting in the tail to others.

How should we handle the wolves when they come?

The only way we will have the courage and the spiritual resources to face the wolves, i.e. the demanding challenges that will confronts us, is to live a ‘laid down’ life. If we have already laid down our lives, then we will not fear what any predator may do to us.

Being a good shepherd is very difficult, demanding and challenging. However, to be like this hired hand and run because of a lack of courage, (although may appear the easier option), will cause us to do untold harm to God’s flock. So if we want to live the life that Jesus did, we need to be willing to ‘lay down’ our lives.

Father. I recognise that my insecurities have the ability to turn me into a hired hand.

html:
I wonder how you feel about miracles? You may have a positive response to that question, and rightly so. However, if we were to delve a little deeper into Jesus miracles we would discover that they are subversive in nature. Jesus did not only bless, heal and set people free through his miracles, but he challenged the status-quo. Some of his miracles were like exploding grenades that brought down the walls established theological structures that had kept the Jewish belief system in place for hundred’s of years. In our day people use the phrase ‘politically correct,’ well you could say that sometimes the miracles of Jesus were perceived as not being ‘theologically correct,’ They caused offence and disquiet. We have sanitised some of the miracle stories of Jesus, making them into nice, wee, twee stories that make us feel good about ourselves. Somehow, by default we manage to ignore their subversive, disturbing side, maybe that suits us?

Jesus has not changed, through his kingdom he continues to subvert everything this world stands for. Through the lives and ministry of people like us, Jesus wants to be a threat to the oppressive unjust systems that control and destroy people. As Christians we ought to be the biggest threat to sinful systems, and organised religion that are dominate our society.

Journalist Peter Hitchens the brother of famous atheist Christphour Hitchens. was a part of a panel discussion at a large conference. An audience member asked, “What so called dangerous idea would have the potential to change the world for the better if implemented?” After another contributor responded saying his dangerous idea would be population control with mandatory abortions for pregnant women. When Peter was asked this is what he said

“The most dangerous idea in human history and philosophy remains the belief that Jesus Christ was the Son of God and rose from the dead. And that is the most dangerous idea you will ever encounter,” he said. When asked a follow up question, Peter responded, “[the resurrection of Jesus] alters the whole of human behaviour and all our responsibility. It turns the universe from a meaningless chaos into a designed place in which there is justice and there is hope. Therefore, we all have a duty to discover the nature of that justice and work towards that hope. It alters us all. If we reject it, it alters us all as well. It is incredibly dangerous. That is why so many people turn against it.” https://www.theolatte.com/2021/03/three-reasons-i-believe-in-the-resurrection-of-jesus/ Accessed 21/03/2025

Father, may the miracles of Jesus have a subversive effect upon my life

title: Jesus Forgives and Heals a Paralysed Man. Part 1

They gathered in such large number that there was no room left, not even outside the door, and he preached the word to then some men came, bringing to him a paralysed man, carried by four of them. Since they could not get him to Jesus because of the crowd, they made an opening in the roof above Jesus by digging through it and then lowered the mat the man was lying on. When Jesus saw their faith, he said to the paralysed man, “Son, your sins are forgiven.” Now some teachers of the law were sitting there, thinking to themselves, “Why does this fellow talk like that? He’s blaspheming! Who can forgive sins but God alone?”Immediately Jesus knew in his spirit that this was what they were thinking in their hearts, and he said to them, “Why are you thinking these things? Which is easier: to say to this paralysed man, ‘Your sins are forgiven,’ or to say, ‘Get up, take your mat and walk’? But I want you to know that the Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive sins. ”So he said to the man, “I tell you, get up, take your mat and go home .” full view of them all. This amazed everyone and they praised God saying, “We have never seen anything like this!”

html:
Another thing about the miracles of Jesus, they demonstrated who he was, they were a revelation of his love and power, they showed what was important to him. However, I think that we believe that it must had been easy for Jesus to do miracles, sure he was God and he possessed all power. But we need to recognise that for Jesus to do miracles it was an expression of courage, I don’t know if you have thought of this before, a lot of Jesus miracles required great courage. His power and love to do miracles was rooted in the courage of a cruciform life. Jesus understood that the subversive nature of his ministry would cause a kick back, it would lead to a negative and sometimes death threatening reaction. The only way he could accept and respond to such reactions was to have a life that was cruciform, a cross shaped life that had already been laid down. Maybe in our lives there is a like between a lack of love and power and a lack of courage? Jesus’ life and ministry teach us that the love and power of God was never intended to sustain the status-quo.

If you attended Sunday school as a child, or if you have been around church for a while you will be familiar with the story of the paralytic being brought to Jesus by four ‘friends’ and how they were resourceful and creative. Unable to get to Jesus, they carried the man unto the roof, dug through the clay roof and lowered the man down so Jesus could heal him. This is a very dramatic story and it is often used to encourage people to evangelise. The four men who brought the paralytic are portrayed as an example and an encouragement for us to follow, and do what we can to bring others to Jesus,. Their is no doubt that we all need to be continually encouraged to be passionately involved in evangelism, doing what we can to bring people to Jesus. However, that is not the point of this story, of course in can be used in this way, as a secondary application. But it is so easy focus on the activity of the actions of the four stretcher carriers and miss how radical this story really is.

This story is about Jesus and how he has come to redefine us and how we see our selves and how we see the world we live in.

This is the first in a series of five controversy stories that are told, in these very early chapters of Mark, how Jesus’ authority is superior to that of the Jewish authorities—and how they reject Jesus’ authority. Of the nineteen references to scribes in Mark, all but one (12 28-34) place them in opposition to Jesus and his teaching, or in a negative light. It is unlikely that these five stories happened in exactly the sequence that Mark reports them. It is more likely that he gathered these stories from various places and grouped them together at the beginning of his account of Jesus’ ministry. In fact, Mark’s first chapter is the only one in the Gospel that doesn’t reflect some form of conflict or controversy arising from Jesus’ activity The five stories are arranged in a chiastic structure as follows:

1. Jesus he heals the Paralytic 2:1-12

2. He calls Levi the tax collector,2:13-17

3 Jesus discourages fasting while he is on earth. Joy 2:18-22

4. Jesus’ disciples pick wheat on the Sabbath liberty Mark 2:23-28

5. Jesus heals on the Sabbath rest Mark 3:1-6.

These five “controversy” stories which highlight this emerging opposition.

Jesus forgives sin (thereby committing blasphemy). Jesus eats with sinners (and thus defiles himself). Jesus feasts rather than fast’s (contrary to the traditions of the elders). Jesus works on the Sabbath (violating the traditions). Jesus heals on the Sabbath (violating the traditions). In each case Jesus crosses boundaries that mark him as an agent of change.,

As you read these stories you will notice an increasing level of hostility and opposition Jesus engenders from the scribes and Pharisees: first they question in their hearts (Mark 2:6); then they question his disciples (Mark 2:16); and then they confront Jesus himself (Mark 2:24). By the end they are so incensed that they immediately begin to plan to “destroy him” (Mark 3:6) — and this resolve hangs like a chill over the story from here on out.’John Mark Hicks https://johnmarkhicks.com/2011/10/06/mark-223-36-son-of-man-sabbath-and-opposition/accessd 24/04/2025.

Father give me the courage to let the subversive power of God to be revealed through my life.

title: Jesus Forgives and Heals a Paralysed Man. Part 2
