They gathered in such large number that there was no room left, not even outside the door, and he preached the word to then some men came, bringing to him a paralysed man, carried by four of them. Since they could not get him to Jesus because of the crowd, they made an opening in the roof above Jesus by digging through it and then lowered the mat the man was lying on. When Jesus saw their faith, he said to the paralysed man, “Son, your sins are forgiven.” Now some teachers of the law were sitting there, thinking to themselves, “Why does this fellow talk like that? He’s blaspheming! Who can forgive sins but God alone?”Immediately Jesus knew in his spirit that this was what they were thinking in their hearts, and he said to them, “Why are you thinking these things? Which is easier: to say to this paralysed man, ‘Your sins are forgiven,’ or to say, ‘Get up, take your mat and walk’? But I want you to know that the Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive sins.” So he said to the man, “I tell you, get up, take your mat and go home He got up, took his mat and walked out in full view of them all. This amazed everyone and they praised God saying, “We have never seen anything like this!”

html:
Just at a surface level this story teaches us about living with an unfixed agenda. Imagine, here was the Son of God, teaching the word of God, and suddenly he is interrupted. Surely these men could have waited, a few more minutes was not going to make a huge difference. Jesus did not allow his own agenda from robbing him of opportunities to show mercy. Sometimes the interruptions in life reveal what is in our hearts. It is good to have objectives and goals, it is good to know where you are heading. However, if we are given an opportunity to show love or minister to a person in need, then we must not be afraid to stop what we are doing, put our agenda on hold so we can respond to a need that has been brought before us.

This story redefines how we understand our needs.

Here we have a man who is in great physical need If you were to asses this man’s need. You would say yes his greatest need is physical. This man can do nothing for himself, he is totally dependant on others. So these men go to a lot of trouble to bring this poor man to Jesus so he can be healed. We live in a world that puts a premium on having our physical needs met. Health and fitness is a big business. The health service is the biggest employer in the UK with 1.3 Million staff the 8th biggest employer in the world. Their is a growing demand for a law to passed that permits ‘assisted dying,’ for those who live in pain. We all know at at personal level what it like to be sick or live with pain.

So we can understand why these men brought the paralytic to Jesus with the expectation of being healed. But listen to what Jesus says. ‘Son you sins are forgiven.’ No one expected this. Was Jesus being insensitive or cruel. No Jesus was dealing with this man greatest need.

Jesus will never belittle your physical pain, he will never play down a persons suffering or difficult circumstances, but he may not agree with how we may assess our priorities our own needs

‘If you're convinced something is a need, you think you're entitled to it; you think it's your right to demand it; and you will judge the love of others by that. When it comes to need, the Gospel is counter-intuitive. The Gospel is countercultural; it confronts our sense of need.’ Paul Trip source unknown

Here is a very important point if Jesus had only ministered to this man at the point of his perceived need the man would have not been really changed. Jesus could have just healed the man physical, but this would not have really changed the man. Their is something in all of us that doesn’t really want to get too close to Jesus, for if we do he will ignore our priorities, our wants, our understanding of our needs, and go to the issue of our hearts. We would rather Jesus sort out all the external stuff, heal our bodies, change our circumstances. Jesus can do that, but there are other things that are much more important. In redefining our needs Jesus helps us understand who we really are.

In making immediate reference to the paralytics sin and his need of forgiveness Jesus was refusing to allow this man to hide behind his terrible circumstances, he refused to allow him to be victim, or play the ‘disable card.’ He was holding him accountable, for his sin, [not his disability.] that is why he needed to be forgiven.

I don’t think we are comfortable with this kind of Jesus, a Jesus who is more concerned about the effect of our sin than our physical health, we don’t want to be held accountable or take responsibility, we want to pass the blame, we want to be considered as ‘irresponsible,’ nothing is ever our fault. However, Jesus loves us too much to allow us to remain living in denial and pretence. on the surface it appeared to be a ‘not so good bedside manner.’ Only Jesus as the right to treat us in this way, for he alone know our hearts.

One of the things that stops a person from having a close relationship with Jesus is they don’t want to face the real issues of their hearts. I don’t think it is possible to accept Jesus for who he is and remain the same. This man comes to Jesus for healing, and he discovers that Jesus has a different agenda, ‘son your sin is forgive.’

Father thank you that you know what I really need. I don’t always know what I need.

html:
This story is about Jesus helping to understand forgiveness.

We need to think as these Jews would have thought. The physical healing signified the spiritual healing. In general, Jewish thinking was that sickness and misfortune were the result of sin. Perhaps Jewish teachers did not link all ailments to specific sins, but they did understand that in some way such misfortunes were related to God’s favour being removed. The Healing's that took place, even the miraculous Healing’s of Jesus, indicated that the offences of the persons had been removed and God’s favour restored.

So, it would not have been shocking if after Jesus had healed the paralytic, he then said, “Your sins are forgiven.” Everyone would have understood that he was simply making an observation or giving assurance of what God had evidently done. What threw everyone off was pronouncing forgiveness before the healing. Why did he do that? To make the point that he wasn’t simply pronouncing what he believed God had done for the man or was about to do. He himself was forgiving the man’s sins.

By reversing the order of healing and forgiving, he demonstrated that he was more than a prophet given a word of insight by God, but that he possessed the very divine prerogative to forgive. The authority to heal signified the authority to forgive. As Jesus said in verse 10: But that you may know that the Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive sins....”

The words, ‘your sins are forgiven,’ were more than a pronouncement; they were an act performed by one with divine authority to do so.

When Jesus sees the paralytic man he says ‘Son you sins are forgiven.’ At this time their was a strong belief that sickness and disability was either the result of the persons sin or their parents sin. The Rabbi's taught a person could sin in the womb before birth, see John 9:1-2. The Scribes had created categories of people for whom they know God doesn’t like – Gentiles, prostitutes, tax collectors, tanners, lepers, shepherds, women who are barren, and people with disabilities and deformities. So when the people saw this Paralytic man, they had him categorised, they saw him as someone who was condemned, someone who deserved to be disabled, someone who was being punished for his sin and that may be one of the reasons why the crowd would not let him in. So Jesus says in front of all the religious leaders, ‘Son your sins are forgiven.’ In saying this Jesus was confronting the stereotypical perceptions of illness and disability

These professional theologians knew the hidden implication to which the rest of the crowd were oblivious to. By claiming the ability to forgive sins Jesus was claiming to be equal to God himself. According to Jewish belief, no man not even a messiah—would have the authority to forgive sins. In the teaching of the Pharisees, blasphemy was the most evil sin to which any human being could stoop to. No wonder they were both outraged and secretly delighted at the same time. This dangerous new rabbi was trapped by his own words, public words that had been uttered in front of many witnesses. Judaism had determined that even the promised, Messiah could not forgive sins. So, these scribes took Jesus’ assertion as an affront to God’s majesty, if not an implied claim to be God. In the Torah, insulting God’s dignity was the primary basis of blasphemy.

The word forgiveness is one of those words that is used a lot in Christian circles. But I don’t think we fully grasp it meaning or implications.

‘The word "forgive" is the Greek word aphiemi. It means to set free; to let go; to release; to discharge; or to liberate completely. It was used in a secular sense in New Testament times in reference to cancelling a debt or releasing someone from the obligation of a contract, a commitment, or promise. Thus, it means to forfeit any right to hold a person captive to a previous commitment or wrong he has committed. In essence, it is the picture of totally freeing and releasing someone. A modern paraphrase of this Greek word would simply be to let it go! This means you and I don't have the privilege of holding people hostage to their past actions if they repent and ask us to forgive them.’ Rick Rener. https://renner.org/article/confront-forgive-and-forget/ access 21/03/2025

In the ancient world when a slave was set free after the death of his master sometimes the word aphiemi was used. Here is the important thing in using this word for forgiveness the focus is not preparing us for heaven but transforming how we live now. Forgiveness is about whether or not we live in bondage and enslavement to sin here and now in this life.

Father help me embrace the glories of being forgiven.

Bible in a year: Exodus 30-32
title: Jesus Forgives and Heals a Paralysed Man. Part 4
study_refs: A f ew days later, when Jesus again entered Capernaum, the people heard that he had come home. They gathered in such large number that there was no room left, not even outside the door, and he preached the word to then some men came, bringing to him a paralysed man, carried by four of them. Since they could not get him to Jesus because of the crowd, they made an opening in the roof above Jesus by digging through it and then lowered the mat the man was lying on. When Jesus saw their faith, he said to the paralysed man, “Son, your sins are forgiven.” Now some teachers of the law were sitting there, thinking to themselves, “Why does this fellow talk like that? He’s blaspheming! Who can forgive sins but God alone?”Immediately Jesus knew in his spirit that this was what they were thinking in their hearts, and he said to them, “Why are you thinking these things? Which is easier: to say to this paralysed man, ‘Your sins are forgiven,’ or to say, ‘Get up, take your mat and walk’? But I want you to know that the Son of Man has authority on earth to forgive sins.” So he said to the man, “I tell you, get up, take your mat and go home. He got up, took his mat and walked out in full view of them all. This amazed everyone and they praised God saying, “We have never seen anything like this!”

html:
So the title had two meanings at a surface level it simply referred to Jesus’ humanity, but it also was a title of exaltation and victory. So when these Scribes hear Jesus calling himself ‘The Son of Man,’ they knew he was taking on a divine title. So Mark tells us ‘the Son of man has authority on earth to forgive sin.’ The word authority literately means ‘The right to act.’ When we hear the word ‘authority,’ most of us have negative feelings, we don’t like being told what to do, we want to be our own bosses. However, have you every thought that the forgiveness sins is one of the ways Jesus expresses his authority over our lives.

I am not too sure if we can call Jesus saviour and not bring all of our lives under his authority. Being forgiven means that Jesus has exercises his authority in your life, but it also means that you have submitted you life to his authority.

This story teaches us about the scandal of grace.

When Jesus said to the paralytic man ‘Son your sins are forgiven’ the many scribes who were their thought Jesus was guilty of blaspheming. In the teaching of the Pharisees, blasphemy was the most evil sin to which any human being could stoop, and was punishable by death. Being so familiar with story we think the most shocking part is the men vandalising the roof, but it wasn’t. When Jesus said ‘Son your sins are forgiven,’ a theological and social ‘bomb,’ exploded that threatened everything the Scribes believed and taught.

a. The Scribes taught only God could forgive sin,

‘In the Old Testament a priest in the sanctuary could communicate God’s forgiveness when the atoning sacrifice was made. But Leviticus simply says that when the worshipper confessed the sin and made the sacrifice, the sin was forgiven (4:26). It was God who forgave (see also Psalm 32); the priest could only communicate that good word to the genuine penitent after he saw the contrition, the sacrifice, or the restoration to health.’ Allen Ross https://bible.org/seriespage/12-authority-forgive-sins-matthew-91-8 accessed 24/04/2025

b. To be receive forgiveness in first-century Judaism, it was necessary to 1) exercise scrupulous behaviour – never do anything “wrong,” 2) go to the ritual purification baths when ceremonially unclean, and 3) participate in the required Temple offerings and sacrifices. Doing these three things made one “right with God” by definition. According to first century Judaism, “forgiveness” is imputed to a person by the religious “system.” Thus to the Pharisees, there could be no real “forgiveness” without the mandated Temple sacrifices and offerings.

So when Jesus said ‘Son your sins are forgiven’ he was undermining the whole religious system of the time. He was saying, ‘don’t go to the temple, don’t make a sacrifice for your sins. ’ Just go home. Your sins are forgiven. Can you grasp how big this is and it is still the same. Jesus’ authority to forgive makes the religious activities we use to get our value and security, become completely irrelevant. Being forgiven helps you recognise that religion cannot change or transform you.

To be “righteous” in first-century Judaism, it was necessary to 1) exercise scrupulous behaviour – never do anything “wrong,” 2) go to the ritual purification baths when ceremonially unclean, and 3) participate in the required Temple offerings and sacrifices. Doing these three things made one “right with God” by definition. According to first century Judaism, “forgiveness” is imputed to a person by the religious “system.” Thus to the Pharisees, there could be no real “forgiveness” without the mandated Temple sacrifices and offerings. But Jesus had just declared this paralytic “forgiven,” even though there was no animal sacrifice rendered on his behalf and they were obviously not in the Temple.

I love that in Mark’s account Jesus address the paralysed man as son/child. Think of the tenderness and acceptance behind that word. As we have mentioned to be in such poor physical condition would had been perceived as the consequence of sin This tender acceptance was very public and a prerequisite to his forgiveness and healing.

Luke records that seeing their faith, He [esus] said, “Friend, I forgive your sins.” 5:20 NIV. The use of the word “friend” is particularly striking and should have immediately communicated to this foursome of friends – so far so good! Not only did Jesus not dismiss or chide them, He called their paralytic a “friend.” Don’t miss the significance of this salutation – a greeting of good will. Jesus’ first priority was to give this unnamed person a new identity. Up to now this paralysed man may have been known around Capernaum as “the cripple.’

Here the important point, The forgiveness that Jesus brings into our lives is so radical that it transforms our identity. Forgiveness from sin is not just about having your ‘slate wiped clean.’ Rather, it is God dealing with the real issues of the heart so we can be people who really reflect and know Jesus.

When Miami native Chris Carrier was ten, a former family employee abducted him, assaulted him, shot him in the head, and left him to die in the Everglades. But Chris survived. In the years that followed, he struggled daily with the insecurity of knowing that his abductor was still at large. Recognizing that staying angry would never change anything, Chris found the strength to move on. Then, some twenty years later, he received a telephone call that changed his life again. It was the police calling to notify him that an elderly man at a local nursing home, David McAllister, had confessed to being his abductor.

Chris visited him the following day. He saw how David’s body was ruined by alcoholism and that he was now facing death with only his regrets to keep him company. At the end of their time together, and unable to see, David clasped Chris’s hand and told him he was sorry. As he spoke, something came over Chris like a wave: “Why should anyone have to face death without family, friends, the joy of life – without hope? I couldn’t do anything but offer him my forgiveness and friendship.”

And friendship indeed. In the days that followed Chris visited David as often as he could, usually bringing along his wife and their two daughters. They spent hours talking, reading, and even praying together, and as they did, the old man’s hardness gradually melted away. https://www.plough.com/en/topics/culture/holidays/easter-readings/can-we-forgive-like-jesus accessed 26/03/2025

Prayer: .

Bible in a year: Exodus 33:1-35:29
title: Jesus Forgives and Heals a Paralysed Man. Part 5
study_refs: This Story teaches us about how Jesus understood himself.

One of the titles Jesus used for himself was the title ‘Son of man’ 80 times in the gospels Jesus calls himself this title. We know from Luke 5:17 Their was a lot of Scribes listening to Jesus, Jesus was teaching, and Pharisees and teachers of the law were sitting there. They had come from every village of Galilee and from Judea and Jerusalem To the Scribes listing to Jesus they would have understood this as a reference to Daniel 7:13-14.

In my vision at night I looked, and there before me was one like a son of man, coming with the clouds of heaven. He approached the Ancient of Days and was led into his presence. 14 He was given authority, glory and sovereign power; all nations and peoples of every language worshipped him. His dominion is an everlasting dominion that will not pass away, and his kingdom is one that will never be destroyed.

html:
This again is a very well known story that has been dumbed down by familiarity, we make a mistake of reducing this to an other miraculous event in the life of Jesus, but this was far more than a story about Jesus’ power to heal. This was a conflict or a collision between two ‘world views,’ between two opposing ways of understanding and doing life. It was a conflict between authentic spirituality and religion, between life and death. This is a passage that is a huge confrontation that challenges much of how modern day evangelical Christians think. We are going to learn through this conflict that Jesus will never accept or tolerate a religion that is devoid of mercy.

As these conflicts unfold they become more intense and more personal to the point that the Pharisees seek out the Herodians, who they had nothing in common with, to plot how they might kill Jesus.

In order to help us understand what is going on here let me try set the context.

1. Jesus had just claimed to be Lord of the Sabbath. ‘So the Son of man is Lord even of the Sabbath.’ Mark 2:28.

To call himself Lord of the Sabbath Jesus was saying to these Pharisees  ‘I am the interpreter of the will of God for this day. You do not rule the Sabbath. You do not set the standards of behaviour for the Sabbath, I do. I interpret God’s will and God’s Word. ‘ John McArthur. https://www.gty.org/library/sermons-library/41-11/jesus-is-lord-of-the-sabbath-part-1 accessed 26/03/2025

The Pharisees loved the Sabbath. The Jewish Talmud had 24 chapters and about 1500 rules that had to be kept in order to keep the Sabbath holy. McArthur again says:-

‘Now, when Jesus called Himself Lord of the Sabbath, He struck the severest blow at the Pharisaic system. Because the Pharisaic system, the system of works, merit, self-righteousness, achievement, attainment, of spiritual relationship with God through ceremony and ritual and external law-keeping, found its focal point in the Sabbath.’ https://www.gty.org/library/sermons-library/41-11/jesus-is-lord-of-the-sabbath-part-1 accessed 26/03/2025

2. Many people think that this incident of the man with the withered hand was a set up, a trap which the Pharisees engineered in order to catch Jesus. It is possible that the disabled man was brought to the Synagogue with the hope that Jesus would heal him on the Sabbath and so be accused of ‘breaking the law.’

Father, thank you that sometimes Jesus expressed his anger through his miracles power Bible in a year reading plan Exodus 35:30-37:29
title: Jesus’ anger expressed through a miracle part 1
study_refs: ‘ Another time Jesus went into the synagogue, and a man with a shrivelled hand was there. Some of them were looking for a reason to accuse Jesus, so they watched him closely to see if he would heal him on the Sabbath. Jesus said to the man with the shrivelled hand, “Stand up in front of everyone .” Then Jesus asked them “Which is lawful on the Sabbath: to do good or to do evil, to save life or to kill?” But they remained silent. He looked around at them in anger and, deeply distressed at their stubborn hearts, said to the man, “Stretch out your hand.” He stretched it out, and his hand was completely restore Then the Pharisees went out and began to plot with the Herodians how they might kill Jesus.

html:
We know from how this story is written in the Greek that the man’s disability happened later in life maybe as an accident. There was a legend in the early church that he was a stonemason. We will come back to this

We know from Luke’s account that it was the man’s right hand Luke 6:6. This is important because, the right hand in scripture is often a symbol of ability, power or strength. So because of this man disability he was probably denied employment, and therefore financial security; he would have been denied access to the temple in Jerusalem because it would have been believed that his physical condition was a consequence of his sin. The right hand was also considered the clean hand. The left hand was always used to keep the body clean, and to shake hands with your left hand was considered offensive.

This is a very unusual miracle for Jesus. In that, usually when Jesus did some miraculous work he did it away from public gaze, but on this occasion he asked the man to stand up in front of every one, he wanted everyone to see what he was about to do.

Writing about this incident Dr Ron Charles says

According to historical records, Herod the great, initiated many building projects during his time, including one to enhance the Jewish temple. The temple was a magnificent piece of work. In order to build the temple, Herod hired a project manager called Jeshu Bensee and also 217 of the finest stonemasons that the region had to offer. While the substructure work was still underway, Herod feared that he would die and hence he decided to speed up the building work. The stonemasons were ordered to work round the clock, seven days a week, including the Sabbath. Jeshu Bensee convinced the high priest and religious leaders that this was necessary and would benefit the temple. They gave their approval and all 217 stonemasons worked round the clock to finish their work on the temple. Once that was completed, the Romans wanted to build the Tower of Antonio, the administrative headquarters of the Roman governor in Jerusalem. The Romans also demanded that the stonemasons work around the clock to complete this work in record time. Once again, Jeshu Bensee convinced the high priest to issue a proclamation called the Sabbath of Weeks, which allowed the stonemasons to work on Sabbaths until the work was completed. At long last, the work was done. Jeshu Bensee organized a celebration in honour of the stonemasons who had worked so hard, along with their families. It was a gala time, but at some point in the celebration Jeshu Bensee stood up and spoke to the stonemasons. He told them that they had broken Jewish law by agreeing to work on the Sabbath. They would be forgiven for working on the Sabbath on account of the temple but not for the extra work they did on the Tower. He said that it would have been better for them to refuse and face death, then to break the law. The punishment meted out to the stonemasons and their families was barbaric in order to make an example of them. Their punishment included the crushing of the right hand of all the 217 stonemasons, thereby taking away their livelihood. The eyes of the children and their wives were gorged out. The stonemasons were separated from their families for ever, and they were forced to wear sackcloth and beg at the synagogue. No one spoke to them and they were not allowed to speak to anyone. The high priest told them that God hated them and had rejected and abandoned them forever.’

If these facts are true, then Jesus was making a huge statement. He was bringing people like this stonemason out from the edges of society, back into the centre .

Father thank you for Jesus’ power to expose people’s hearts.

Bible on a year Exodus 38:1-31
title: Jesus’ anger expressed through a miracle part 2
study_refs: ‘ Another time Jesus went into the synagogue, and a man with a shrivelled hand was there. Some of them were looking for a reason to accuse Jesus, so they watched him closely to see if he would heal him on the Sabbath. Jesus said to the man with the shrivelled hand, “Stand up in front of everyone .” Then Jesus asked them “Which is lawful on the Sabbath: to do good or to do evil, to save life or to kill?” But they remained silent. He looked around at them in anger and, deeply distressed at their stubborn hearts, said to the man, “Stretch out your hand.” He stretched it out, and his hand was completely restore Then the Pharisees went out and began to plot with the Herodians how they might kill Jesus.

html:
What can this story teach us?

It teaches us that some things make Jesus angry. There are a number of times in the gospels where we see Jesus expressing anger, for example when he turned the tables over in the temple, or when he was at the grave side of Lazarus. But this is the only time that we are explicitly told that Jesus was angry.

An ‘angry Jesus,’ is a Jesus we are not too happy with. I read recently about a toy manufacturer who made a ‘Jesus doll’ It was a ‘hug able, washable, talking,’ doll sporting fuzzy dread locks and satiny beard. When you pulled out the string it said things like. ‘I love you.’ ‘I have great plans for you life.’ ‘Be good to your mother and father.’ That is the kind of Jesus we want. We don’t want a ‘Jesus,’ who gets angry, and we certainly don’t want a Jesus who confronts us and shatters how we see and do life. The incident of the healing of the man with the withered hand was a ‘divine wrecking ball,’ that was going to shatter how these religious people understood life.

The life of Jesus will cause us to rethink our understanding of anger. For Jesus anger was an expression of perfect humanity, it was a necessary virtue that was required to ensure the fulfilment of the loving purposes of God. It was an expression of holy living, an excellent manifestation of morality. For Jesus, expressed anger was consistent with his love and grace. It was a refusal to accept the reign of evil, It was a choice to make a difference in situations where cruelty and injustice appeared to have control.

Did Jesus not clearly condemn anger?

“You have heard that it was said to the people long ago, ‘Do not murder, and anyone who murders will be subject to judgment.’  But I tell you that anyone who is angry with his brother will be subject to judgment. Again, anyone who says to his brother, ‘Raca,’ is answerable to the Sanhedrin. But anyone who says, ‘You fool!’ will be in danger of the fire of hell. (Matt 5:21-22) .

Notice that Jesus gives two examples of the kind of anger he means. The first example is to use the term of contempt: Raca. This term is hard to translate so it is simply rendered in the Aramaic. Essentially what it means is to strip a person of any dignity and to regard them with utter contempt. The term fool; has a similar, though less egregious, purpose. Hence, it would seem that the Lord is not condemning all anger her but rather the anger of contempt and depersonalization..

The problem is we have taken the virtue of anger and turned it into a vice. Our sin has deformed and distorted the virtue of anger so much, that it has become the means by which we express resentment, revenge and control. We have made it into manifestation of acute selfishness, instead of it being a motivating influence against injustice and the suffering of others.

Selfishness has the ability to intoxicate and weaponise anger. When anger ceases to a virtue that causes us to react to the abuse of others.. then it will become toxic selfishness that will poison us, and a weapon that we will use to destroy others for our own benefit.

Sadly the selfless anger that Jesus displayed is rarely seen in the church. I think there are two reasons for this. Firstly their seems to be a tsunami of apathy, the church does not care enough to demonstrate the virtue of selfless anger. It is interesting that the words for disobedience and unbelief in the New Testament come from the Greek word from which we get our English word apathy.

Secondly, because we are so accustomed to selfish, toxic anger, we can assume that all anger is wrong.

‘Holy anger is not driven by a desire to judge or get even but by a desire to love people and set them free. Holy anger does not involve screaming for your rights but advocating for the rights of others. Holy anger is not about proving a point but about proving that everyone has value. Holy anger is not about personal gain but about restoring personal dignity to others. Holy anger comes in many forms and is expressed in multiple ways, but the result is always the same: action is taken in the name of Jesus to loosen chains of injustice, restore dignity and rescue people.’ Jamie Snyder

I wonder what causes us to be angry?

Tim Keller wrote ‘There’s nothing wrong with being ticked — getting angry to a degree — if somebody slights your reputation, but why are you ten times — a hundred times — more angry about it than some horrible violent injustice being done to people in another part of the world? Do you know why? Because if what you’re really looking to for your significance and security is people’s approval or a good reputation or status or something like that, then when anything gets between you and the thing you have to have, you become implacably angry. You have to have it. You’re over the top. You can’t shrug it off. ’https://dkevinbrown.wordpress.com/2014/05/29/handling-anger-in-our-homes/ Accessed 26/03/2025

Father teach me how t0 be angry for the right reasons

Bible in a year: Exodus 39:1-40:16
title: Jesus’ anger expressed through a miracle part 3
study_refs: Another time Jesus went into the synagogue, and a man with a shrivelled hand was there. Some of them were looking for a reason to accuse Jesus, so they watched him closely to see if he would heal him on the Sabbath. Jesus said to the man with the shrivelled hand, “Stand up in front of everyone .” Then Jesus asked them “Which is lawful on the Sabbath: to do good or to do evil, to save life or to kill?” But they remained silent. He looked around at them in anger and, deeply distressed at their stubborn hearts, said to the man, “Stretch out your hand.” He stretched it out, and his hand was completely restore Then the Pharisees went out and began to plot with the Herodians how they might kill Jesus.

html:
a. The attitudes of the Scribes and Pharisees.

Mark tells us a number of important things things about the attitudes of these religious people. As does Luke. Luke 6:8 tells us that ‘Jesus knew what they were thinking’ What was upsetting Jesus at this time is that they were looking great, they were ticking all the boxes, they were sitting on their usual seats in the Synagogue, but their attitudes was a cause of offence and anger to Jesus. The religious people were highly respected members of society. They had a deep love for the word of God, they could quote whole books of the Old Testament, they were trying to live ‘holy lives,’ but they made Jesus angry.

Mark tells us ‘they wanted some reason to accuse Jesus.’ The word accuse is a technical legal term which means to mount a legal case against someone in order to collect evidence against them. It comes from two Greek words ‘Agora,’ a place of public speaking, prefixed by ‘kata’ meaning against. Hence it means speaking against a person before a public tribunal. It wasn’t that they stumbled on an issue that proved problematical to their understanding, but they were determined to find a reason to publicly accuse, humiliate and embarrass Jesus, so they could control him. They were sitting in judgement, they were hoping that Jesus would incriminate himself. This same word kategoreo is the same word that our English word category from. They wanted to accuse Jesus so they could put him into a category that suited them. When Jesus did not act in ways they thought he should act, they attempt to put Jesus in a box that suited their theology and belief system. We would never do that!

They watched Jesus.

When we are told that they ‘watched’ Jesus a very rare word is used which is found only six times in the New Testament. The word carries the idea of watching with evil intent, with hostility, and suspicion. Outside the bible this same word was used to describe the process of of observing that the legal demands of the law be fulfilled.

How they watched Jesus was an amazing revelation of their hearts, they were critical and judgemental, hoping that they would have an opportunity to humiliate and correct Jesus.

They had hard/stubborn hearts

In response to the question  “Which is lawful on the Sabbath: to do good or to do evil, to save life or to kill?” the religious leaders remained silent. Their silence was really a revelation of their hearts. This was not a difficult question. Who would want to do evil or kill, especially on the Sabbath. God intended the Sabbath to be a day of rest, a day for blessing a day of doing good. But the malicious silence of these religious people was really a loud declaration about the evil of their hearts.

When reading this story, it would be very easy to read the phrase stubborn/hard heart as a throw away statement. But it needs to be understood as a defining or an identifying status of these religious people. The word for Stubborn/hard is porosis.

William Barclay writes that. Porosis comes from poros, which originally meant a stone that was harder than marble. It came to have certain medical uses. It was used for the chalk stone which can form in the joints and completely paralyse action. It was used of the callus that forms where a bone has been broken and re-set, a callus which is harder than the bone itself. Finally the word came to mean the loss of all power of sensation; it described something which had become so hardened, so petrified that it had no power to feel at all.’ https://www.sermonindex.net/modules/articles/index.php?view=article&aid=34196. Accessed 17/06/25

The word also suggests a dull mind someone who had chosen to close their mind and refuse to think differently or see things from a different perspective

I think this is probably one of the greatest tragedy's of the human heart, to be incapable of feeling sympathy or compassion. Being hard in the inside, unmoved by the pain of others. Hardened by bitterness and sin and loosing what it means to be truly human.

These religious leaders were so hard and indifferent to the needs of others. They had developed dispassionate hearts that were unable to engage compassionately or sympathetically with others.

You could sum up these Scribes and Pharisees as

a. They like rules.

b. They see themselves as the guardians of right and wrong.

c. They are quick to criticise and slow to compliment.

d. They see the bad in people, not the good enough, never reconsigning the beauty and good in others.

e. They wish every one else was more like them.

f. They don’t like it when others don’t see the bible as they do.

g. Keeping the rule is more important than meeting needs of others

h. They are issue driven not compassionate.

Jesus’ anger was mixed with deep sorrow. This is the only time the word ’syllypeo’ deep sorrow is used in the bible. It carries the idea  “to feel sympathy, be deeply distressed for someone, to feel sorry for someone, to be moved with grief”. The attitude of the Scribes and Pharisees caused Jesus not only anger but pain.

If I had been in Jesus’ position, and was able to silence my critics I would have felt satisfied. Not Grieved. But Jesus was grieved by the consequences caused by these peoples hard hearts. His heart was full of sorrow because they did not care for the needy. This distress that Jesus was feeling is the key to understanding this passage. The Sabbath was given as an expression of God’s mercy. God wanted the Sabbath to be all about doing good not evil, about saving life not killing it. These people had moved so far from authentic humanity, and God’s purposes that they caused Jesus great distress.

For these religious leaders, programmes were more important than people. sustaining the status-quo was more important than mercy, and this caused great pain to Jesus.

What Mark is doing here is showing us the contrast between the hard hearted attitude of the Pharisees, and the grieving heart of Jesus.

Father help me to rightly access and evaluate the circumstances I find myself.

Some of them were looking for a reason to accuse Jesus, so they watched him closely to see if he would heal him on the Sabbath. Jesus said to the man with the shrivelled hand, “Stand up in front of everyone .” Then Jesus asked them “Which is lawful on the Sabbath: to do good or to do evil, to save life or to kill?” But they remained silent. He looked around at them in anger and, deeply distressed at their stubborn hearts, said to the man, “Stretch out your hand.” He stretched it out, and his hand was completely restore Then the Pharisees went out and began to plot with the Herodians how they might kill Jesus.

html:
‘These religious leaders in this story became defined by their inability to show mercy. In the context of Matthew telling the story about Jesus in the corn field and the healing of this man with the withered had, he records Jesus saying.

‘If you had known what these words mean, I desire mercy, not sacrifice, you would not have condemned the innocent.’ Matthew 12:7. In other words these religious people did not understand the nature or purposes of the heart of God, and the kind of hearts we need to have.

Mercy could be defined as an emotional response that leads to practical help. Larry Richards says - ‘Originally eleos, (Greek for mercy) expressed only the emotion that was aroused by contact with a person who was suffering. By NT times, however, the concept incorporated compassionate response. A person who felt for and with a sufferer would be moved to help. This concept of mercy as a concern for the afflicted that prompts giving help is prominent in both the Gospels and the Epistles.’ https://www.preceptaustin.org/2-john-commentary accessed 26/04/2025

Mercy should be the thing that sets the church apart.

Listen to this testimony of a German Christian who lived during the second world war.

“I lived in Germany during the Nazi Holocaust. I considered myself a Christian. I attended church since I was a small boy. We had heard the stories of what was happening to the Jews, but like most people today in this country, we tried to distance ourselves from the reality of what was really taking place. What could anyone do to stop it?

“A railroad track ran behind our small church, and each Sunday morning we would hear the whistle from a distance and then the clacking of the wheels moving over the track. We became disturbed when one Sunday we noticed cries coming from the train as it passed by. We grimly realized that the train was carrying Jews. They were like cattle in those cars!

“Week after week, that train whistle would blow. We would dread to hear the sound of those old wheels because we knew that the Jews would begin to cry out to us as they passed our church. It was so terribly disturbing! We could do nothing to help these poor miserable people, yet their screams tormented us. We knew exactly at what time that whistle would blow, and we decided the only way to keep from being so disturbed by the cries was to start singing our hymns. By the time that train came rumbling past the churchyard, we were singing at the top of our voices. If some of the screams reached our ears, we’d just sing a little louder until we could hear them no more. Years have passed, and no one talks about it much any more, but I still hear that train whistle in my sleep. I can still hear them crying out for help. God forgive all of us who called ourselves Christians, yet did nothing to intervene.”

Sometimes we choose to be oblivious to the backing tract to our lives, we can sing at the top of our voices to drown out the desperate cries of the needy

There is just one more thing I want you to notice. Did the man seek Jesus out? Did he cry out for relief – fall at Jesus’ feet and beg for mercy? Did he even ask to be healed? No. This is the only miracle in Matthew, Mark and Luke that Jesus initiates, without being approached or asked. That is what mercy does, it initiates relevant acts of mercy. Mercy will sacrifice religious traditions for the sake of others. Any life or ministry that is not continually expressing acts of mercy is not really of God, and it breaks the heart of Jesus.

Father may the back ground noise in my life produce a response of mercy

The seventy-two returned with joy and said, “Lord, even the demons submit to us in your name.” He replied, I saw Satan fall like lightning from heaven I have given you authority to trample on snakes and scorpions and to overcome all the power of the enemy; nothing will harm you. However, do not rejoice that the spirits submit to you, but rejoice that your names are written in heaven.”

If we are going to develop a bibicial and healthy philosophy of ministry I think this is one of the best, if not the best passages to help us do that. When I speak of a philosophy of ministry I am referring to how we think about ministry and how we understand ourselves in the context of that ministry. Or put it an other way. If my understanding of the ministry is not rooted in how Jesus understood ministry, then I will find myself struggling with a host of spiritual, emotional and psychological problems.

This passage contains one of the most challenging and penetrating incidents recorded in all the gospels. This is a passage that goes way beyond the surface and deals with dominate issues of the heart. This is a passage that pulls off the covers we hide under, and exposes our real priorities and insecurities As the seventy two return to Jesus and begin to tell Jesus about their successful mission, Jesus uses this as an opportunity to deal with a crucial issue that will prepare them for life and ministry in the future

The seventy two have just returned from the mission Jesus had sent them on, and to their surprise they were able to exercise power over demons. This was surprising for two reasons

The context.

In the previous chapter (9:40), a number of the 12 disciples have failed to exorcise a demon. They were unable to do something that the seventy/seventy two were able to do. These seventy/seventy two were powerful and effective. Jesus had not mentioned casting out demons in his commissioning (10:5-11), of the seventy two but they gained power over demons. Exorcism was not something Jesus told them to do in this commission, but "eat," "heal," and "tell" (v. 8b-9). The Twelve were given "power and authority over all demons" in 9:1 not the seventy two. So think of the surprise and joy they must have felt when they returned to Jesus and began to critique their experience in ministry. Before we look at the passage let me say a word about the importance of critiquing our ministry. As we have said, this passage as a lot to say about having a right perspective on ministry and the importance of critiquing it.

Father give me the wisdom to wisely critique the ministry you have given me.

Bible in a year: Leviticus 8:1-11:8
title: Jesus’ anger expressed through a miracle part 5
study_refs: Another time Jesus went into the synagogue, and a man with a shrivelled hand was there. Some of them were looking for a reason to accuse Jesus, so they watched him closely to see if he would heal him on the Sabbath. Jesus said to the man with the shrivelled hand, “Stand up in front of everyone .” Then Jesus asked them “Which is lawful on the Sabbath: to do good or to do evil, to save life or to kill?” But they remained silent. He looked around at them in anger and, deeply distressed at their stubborn hearts, said to the man, “Stretch out your hand.” He stretched it out, and his hand was completely restore Then the Pharisees went out and began to plot with the Herodians how they might kill Jesus.

html:
The importance of a formal or intentional critique of a ministry

Every day of our lives we are being critiqued to a greater or lesser degree. People look at our lives and they come to conclusions, right or wrong. They evaluate us and make value judgements about us. This informal everyday critiquing is not something we go looking for, nor will it cause us to make helpful change in our lives. However, their must be times in our lives when we sit down with people who we love and trust, and they love and trust us. and will objectivity and honestly help us see were we are at.

This is not an easy thing to do and will require vulnerability and courage. But it will ensure an accountability. Some people who are involved in ministry believing that they are only accountable to God and to nobody else. This almost sound spiritual, however if a person is not humble enough to be held accountable to others, it is unlikely they will have the right heart attitude that is required so they can be accountable to God. Being accountable does not mean that others have the right to control or manipulate you

Often we think that a ministry should be critiqued if it has failed or is in the process of failing. But no matter where a ministry is at, periodically it requires an in depth scrutiny and examination.

The process of critiquing a ministry must take place in the presence of Jesus. It is interesting that we often say more to Jesus before we do ministry while the diciples said more to Jesus after they had finished their ministry. We need to develop the habit of bringing our ministry to Jesus when they appear to be concluded, in order to get his perspective.

To critique is not a licence to criticise or condemn, Christian counsellor Henry Cloud says that in healthy relationships a minimum of five meaningful encouragements should be shared for every one criticism. Nor is the critiquing an opportunity for someone to manipulate their agenda into a specific situation. Rather it is an opportunity to help others grow, mature and become more like Jesus and better equipped to do what God has called them to do .

Father help see what I can do better and how I can do it better.

Bible in a year: Leviticus 11:9-13:39
title: THE ILLUSION OF SUCCESS Part 2
study_refs: The seventy-two returned with joy and said, “Lord, even the demons submit to us in your name.” He replied, I saw Satan fall like lightning from heaven I have given you authority to trample on snakes and scorpions and to overcome all the power of the enemy; nothing will harm you. However, do not rejoice that the spirits submit to you, but rejoice that your names are written in heaven.”

html:
In critiquing the ministry of the seventy/seventy two Jesus helped them see a wider perspective. They had power over demons, but Jesus saw Satan fall like lightning from heaven. In other words, what they experienced and saw was not the whole picture, there were things that were related to their victory over demons that they had no knowledge or understanding of.

Successful ministry was never meant to become a source of Joy. Listen to what

our text says.

The seventy/seventy-two returned with joy and said, ‘Lord even the demons submit to us in your name.’ He replied ‘I saw Satan fall like lighting from heaven; I gave you authority to trample on snakes and scorpions and to overcome all the power of the enemy. However do not rejoice that the spirits submit to you, but rejoice that your name is written in heaven.’ Luke 19:18-20.

1. Jesus’ perspective

The first thing Jesus says to these returning disciples is ‘I saw Satan fall like lighting from heaven’’ When did this happen? Interpreters are divided. Was it the moment Satan rebelled and God cast him out of heaven? Was it the moment Jesus was conceived with the express purpose of conquering Satan? Was it when Jesus defeated Satan in the wilderness? Or maybe Jesus was looking to the future, to the cross where he would crush Satan once and for all. Any and all of those may be true. But the point is not when it happened, but how. The disciples were overjoyed that they were able to drive out demons in Jesus’ name. That’s the key in this context. Jesus is telling disciples of all times that wherever and whenever His name is proclaimed, Satan falls from power, he loses his control, he is defeated.

Father help me never overestimate the importance of my ministry/

Bible in a year: Leviticus 13:40-14:57
title: THE ILLUSION OF SUCCESS Part 3
study_refs: In critiquing the ministry of the seventy/seventy two, Jesus dealt with how the outcome of the ministry affected them, not the people they were ministering to. It is important to look at the nuts and bolt of a particular ministry, but the crucial issue as far as Jesus is concerned, is how do our hearts respond to the success/failure of that ministry.

html:
Success in ministry will not produce lasting joy.

We all want to be successful in our ministry; we all want to be effective for God. And that is not a bad thing. However, sometimes we fall for the lie that says I would be happier if I was more effective for God. We convince ourselves that our happiness depends on us being successful in ministry. We all have this driving desire to be noticed, to be seen, we have a built-in fear of not achieving.

Tim Keller wrote

‘Today there is far more pressure than ever before on ministers to be “successful.” The very idea of success is something of a new way to judge ministers. The older criteria for evaluation had more to do with doctrinal accuracy, loyalty, and consistency of discharging duties. But no one can deny that these measurements have been eclipsed by the criteria of success. Today’s churches and congregations seek successful ministers and dismiss less successful ones. It is also true that ministers hold themselves to the standards of success of increasing numbers and expanding budgets. Source unknown

Some of us are perfectionists, we put so much pressure on ourselves to get everything right, and we have a fear of failure that is really a subtle expression of selfish self protection. Did you know that although Jesus was perfect he was secure enough not to be a perfectionists. One of the most difficult lessons to learn in Christian ministry is to learn how not to turn your ministry into a necessity for life. In our warped way of thinking we often relate success in ministry or life with the approval of God. We think, ‘God must really love me, look how he is blessing what I am doing!’

There is nothing wrong in wanting to be successful in what God has called you to do. But it becomes wrong when the ministry becomes the source of our identity, significance and joy.

Sometimes our Christian service can become an idol, or a trap, and we end up with ‘ministry addiction,’ it can become something we selfishly pursue in order to medicate the ache in our hearts that we dare not acknowledge or speak about. We have been created for something that is much greater than success.

Those who link their joy with being successful in ministry are skating on thin ice. What Jesus is saying here is so radical, he is saying, do not look to success, or to ministry to give you joy in this life. He is saying successful ministry will never make you happy. It is very easy for any of us to get our ministry out of perspective; it is easy to fall into the trap where your ministry becomes too important. The real battle we all face is to hold our ministry lightly, not taking it too seriously, refusing to be defined by what we do. Sometimes ministry can become too important because we have lost our passion for God.

All ministry is not successful. Joshua Wilson pastor of Vankleek Hill Baptist Church wrote.

‘Failure in ministry is generally spoken of in terms of moral failure. We read of the addictions, the affairs, the plagiarism, the misuse of money, and the spiritual abuse in leadership, and we are rightly shaken. However, there are pastors and leaders who commit no moral failure, but perceive that their ministry has failed. This is a different category altogether. What happens when you put your hand to the plough, but the visible outcome of what you do is meagre or non-existent? What does it mean when you pursue your calling, minister with all the strength Jesus supplies, preach the gospel, love people, and it just doesn’t work out? Where did it all go wrong? More precisely, you may ask. What did I do wrong? Wrestling with these questions, my own thoughts grew increasingly dark, leading to the crippling and overwhelming sense of total failure.’ https://www.thegospelcoalition.org/article/the-haunting-of-ministry-failure/.

accessed 26/04/2025

Often we see this in the bible. When God called Isaiah he was told that he will be ignored (Isaiah 6). Ezekiel was prophesying in exile, God tells him not to be afraid of the people he will speak to, and warns him that failure is distinctly possible, because, ‘The people to whom I am sending you are obstinate and stubborn.’ (Ezekiel 2:4) Jeremiah suffered intense emotional, and physical, distress. ‘Whenever I speak, I cry out proclaiming violence and destruction. So the word of the Lord has brought me insult and reproach all day long. But if I say, “I will not mention his word or speak any more in his name,” his word is in my heart like a fire, a fire shut up in my bones. I am weary of holding it in; indeed, I cannot.’ (Jeremiah 20:8-9) It is a bit ironic that Jonah the disobedient prophet was one of the most successful prophets. He reluctantly preached an eight word sermon and the great city of Nineveh repented.

Their seems to be little reignition that often in Christian ministry despite a persons faithfulness and devotion that there is no guarantee of having a ‘successful’ outcome. That is why we need to find our joy in our relationship with God.

This does not mean that we cannot rejoice when or if God chooses to use us. We should be grateful for those occasions. However, if the fear of failure dominates our thinking and drives our emotions then the success we desperately seek indicates that our ministry has become all about us.

Father help find my life and joy in my relationship with you

Bible in a year: Leviticus 15:1-18:18
title: THE ILLUSION OF SUCCESS Part 4
study_refs: The seventy-two returned with joy and said, “Lord, even the demons submit to us in your name.” He replied, I saw Satan fall like lightning from heaven I have given you authority to trample on snakes and scorpions and to overcome all the power of the enemy; nothing will harm you. However, do not rejoice that the spirits submit to you, but rejoice that your names are written in heaven.”

html:
The second lie that Jesus confronts is the lie that says ‘if I have power or authority. I will be happy. I need to be in control.’

Having power and authority cannot produce authentic joy in your heart. “I have given you authority to trample on snakes and scorpions and to overcome all the power of the enemy.”

Even overcoming Satan is not the basis for real Joy. People who can trample on snakes and scorpions and overcome all the power of the enemy are very impressive; they grab the attention of others. There are some people in ministry, who because of their insecurities must always be in charge, they have a finger in every pie, they need to know about every decision, they find it hard to delegate. They give the impression of being strong, they can cope however, these people are seldom happy. They rarely experience real joy, and any joy they do experience is usually superficial and is related to something that is external, something that makes them looks good.

Jesus learned these lessons as he was being tempted in the wilderness. Satan wanted to give him authority over all the kingdoms of the world. But Jesus refused, for He realized that real Joy is not found in the authority a person has, but in their relationship with their Father God, and their ability to submit to the will of God.

In some ways Jesus turns our whole understanding of joy upside down. We are incline to think ‘if we are strong, fearless, macho Christians who have everything sorted and having everything sorted, then we will experience joy. You could interpret what Jesus is saying this way, ‘I give you the authority or the freedom to be vulnerable,’ You ability to demonstrate God’s power over God’s enemies may be impressive, but it will never meet the deepest needs of our hearts, it will never produce lasting joy.

.

It is important that we don’t confuse feelings of vulnerability with being insecure in our relationship with God. No matter what we have to face, or how difficult and challenging our circumstances may be, we need to realise that our relationship with God is secure, and we are completely loved by Him. Deep, lasting joy is not found in having the ability to cope with the difficulties of life. “I have given you authority to trample on snakes and scorpions and to overcome all the power of the enemy.”

There are others who believe that if they can go through life trampling on snakes and scorpions, then they will be happy. Giving the impression of being strong and seeming to have the ability to cope will not produce joy in your heart. Often I hear my own heart say these words ‘If only,’ If only I was someone else without a disability,’ or ‘if only I had a job,’ or it could be a million other things, The if only of life is an illusion, a mirage of pseudo joy

The basis of real Joy.

Jesus said, “Do not rejoice that the spirits submit to you, but rejoice that your name is written in heaven.”

It would be very easy to see this as a throw away statement. We think yes we need to rejoice because we are saved and going to heaven. But that is not what Jesus is saying here. In the context Jesus is talking about our attitude to service. He is saying that our service must flow from our awareness of belonging; in the Hebrew mind a person’s name was far more than a title, it was his identity, it was who he was. So when Jesus says ‘rejoice that your name is written in heaven’, he is saying the thing that brings you security and joy is not the fact that you can deliver people from demons, nor is it found in having authority, nor is it found in you having the ability to cope with the pressures of life, rather your identity and joy is found in the fact that your names are written in heaven.

In ancient times cities kept a register of their faithful citizens; so when a man died, his name was removed from the register. Those whose names were written in the register knew that they belonged. This is the bottom line, having a deep sense of belonging to God.

I have met so many Christians who are full of feelings of guilt, who are driven and exhausted as they desperately try to win Gods approval and love. They have a subliminal theology that says, ‘ If I do all the right things, and cast out demons, stand on scorpions, serve God well, be the best, then God will love me that little bit more.’ That is not how God works.

Too many corpses of faith are buried on the mission field. Many good people left to serve God without really grasping the absolute centrality of the grace of God for everyday living. Many have ended up confused, angry, lonely and deeply scarred by years of performance. They end up sharing the message of the gospel without understanding the meaning of the gospel. This was never how it was meant to be.

According to William D. Taylor, Too Valuable to Lose (Pasadena: William Carey Library, 1997) Unfortunately, about 5.1% of missionaries leave the field every year. He goes on to say . Moreover, of the 5.1% of missionaries who leave the field every year, about 71% of those leave for preventable reasons.

“What kills a soul? Exhaustion, secret keeping, image management. And what brings a soul back from the dead? Honesty, connection, grace.,” wrote Shauna Niequist, author of “Present Over Perfect.”

It there is one lesson we should learn from this passage it is we should learn to belong, we should be less eager for success and become more eager to grasp the truth that we belong. We should minister to other from a posture of joy because we have a defining conviction that we belong to God

There is nothing that makes a person more alive and more whole than the joy of knowing that they really do belong to God; this sense of belonging animates a person and fills them with infectious joy. I believe that this joy is the pinnacle of human experience, and can be defined as a transforming revelation of divine love.

Father is my ministry an idol

Bible in a year reading plan Leviticus 18:19-21:24
title: THE ILLUSION OF SUCCESS Part 5
study_refs: The seventy-two returned with joy and said, “Lord, even the demons submit to us in your name.” He replied, I saw Satan fall like lightning from heaven I have given you authority to trample on snakes and scorpions and to overcome all the power of the enemy; nothing will harm you. However, do not rejoice that the spirits submit to you, but rejoice that your names are written in heaven.”

html:
As Christians we believe that Jesus was both God and man, both human and divine. It is not easy for any of us to reconcile these two truths. How can Jesus be both God and man? In some ways we often feel more comfortable with the deity of Jesus than we do with his humanity. We worship and obey Jesus as Lord and King, but do we also admire him deep down as someone who set an example that believers can really follow? Do we believe that Jesus genuinely struggled against the challenges of life just like us?

Or did Jesus have access to something extra not readily available to all believers?

Was Jesus truly human?

Or did he have some kind of Clark Kent kind of power that gave him a supernatural power to cope with the struggles of life?

Someone has said.’ “If Jesus is superhuman, then I can admire him, but I do not have to take seriously his call to emulate him. I can never be a superhuman being.

we are going to discover that Jesus was the most human person that ever lived. He came to earth to show us His father’s original intention for humanity. In bringing us salvation God wants to restore mankind to the life he had before the fall in the Garden of Eden. Jesus came to earth as the second Adam to shows us what it ‘really’ means to be human. You could say that to become like Jesus is to become ‘more’ or a ‘better’ human, it is to discover God’s original intention for us. Through his humanity and by his redeeming grace Jesus came to transform our understanding of what it means to be human.

He wants us to have a correct and more God centred appreciation of our humanity. He wants us to embrace the glory of being human, of being what God created us to be.

Let me start by suggesting a number of reasons why we struggle with the humanity of Jesus.

1. We feel that if we think of Jesus as being ‘too’ human, then we are being irreverent, we feel that we are being disrespectful. As a human being Jesus had the same needs as you and me. Yes he was absolutely sinless, but that does not mean that he never made mistakes, or had accidents. All sins are mistakes but all mistakes are not sin

Let me quote you something from a book called The Shack:-

‘Mack stood in the bathroom, looking into the mirror while wiping his face dry with a towel. He was searching for some sign of insanity in those eyes staring back at him. Was this real? Of course not, it was impossible. But then . . . He reached out his hand and slowly touched the mirror. Maybe this was a hallucination being brought on by all his grief and despair. Maybe it was a dream, and he was asleep somewhere, maybe in the shack freezing to death? Maybe . . . Suddenly, a terrible crash broke into his reverie. It came from the direction of the kitchen, and Mack froze. For a moment there was dead silence, and then unexpectedly, he heard uproarious laughter. Curious, he exited the bathroom and poked his head through the doorway of the kitchen. Mack was shocked at the scene in front of him. It appeared that Jesus had dropped a large bowl of some sort of batter or sauce on the floor, and it was everywhere. It must have landed close to Papa because the lower portion of her skirt and bare feet were covered in the gooey mess. All three were laughing so hard that Mack didn’t think they were breathing. Sarayu said something about humans being clumsy and all three started roaring again. Finally, Jesus brushed past Mack and returned a minute later with a large basin of water and towels.’

I realise that the Shack is a fictional story, but it makes a very important point; the humanness of Jesus did not mean that for him life was free from mishaps or accidents. Jesus was completely sinless, but because he lived in a sinful world, everything he did was not ‘perfect’ or ‘successful.’ I realise many will struggle with what is being said here because we equate ‘mistakes’ with ‘sin,’ when they very different. Jesus knew what it was like to be disappointed, frustrated and angry. He did things that did not always turn out in the way he hoped for. Often in the gospels you hear his frustration and disappointment. Jesus’ humanity teaches us that doing everything with perfect motives and in a perfect way does not guarantee perfect success or results.

Jesus had to learn to do things; on his first day in Joseph’s carpenter shop, Jesus did not make a perfect wooden joint or a perfect table or chair, he had to learn his craft, learn from his mistakes because that is what it means to be human. This is the Jesus that God wants us to know and love, as a fellow human being who has shared in our frustrations and disappointments, someone who understands what it’s like to live in an imperfect world

.

Could I suggest that Jesus was too secure in his relationship with his father to be a perfectionist. Perfectionism is rooted in pride. Because Jesus had a perfect relationship with his Father, and loved his Father with a perfect love, and lived a life of complete submission to his Father’s will, Jesus had no need to be a perfectionist. What do I mean by that?

Some of us want to do everything perfectly, and when we don’t we begin to come down on ourselves and beat ourselves up. Sometimes we do things with pure motives, for the right reasons, as best as we know how, and they end up in failure and disappointment. Sometimes we are overwhelmed with feelings of failure or even self loathing because our best efforts amount to nothing. We may have done something, even something for God, and it did not turn out the way we had hoped or expected, we may live in fear of letting others down, or fear of failure, or fear of being thought little of, so we develop a perfectionist attitude that drives us. The modern day psychological term ‘perfectionism,’ is not something that affected Jesus. As our perfect example of humanity, Jesus teaches us that being secure in our relationship with the father keeps us safe from the cruel bondage of perfectionism. Perfectionism is really an expression of inverted pride.

We live in a day were their seems to be a ‘pandemic of perfectionism.’ were there is constant pressure ‘on people to always be the best, to always achieve excellence. Social media has helped create a world of unrealistic expectations that have dehumanised people to a glossy two dimensional fictional character that has nothing to do with their true selves. Perfectionism is rooted in pride, it develops a fear of failure and prevents essential vulnerability.

Father help me not confuses mistakes and sins, Bible reading plan Leviticus 22-23
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 1

html:
The Humanity of Jesus. Part 2

We need to stop here and just think about the importance of vulnerability. For Jesus vulnerability was the ‘doorway’ by which he entered our humanity, vulnerability made the incarnation possible. He took on the weakness and fragility of a baby, becoming dependant and needy. For God to reveal himself in the complete vulnerability of a baby would have been seen as a blasphemous shock, a scandal to both the Jews and gentiles. They both wanted a strong militaristic gods who would come and deliver them, a god who was strong and fierce.

We struggle with the humanity of Jesus because we struggle with our own humanity. We don’t feel comfortable with Jesus being human because we don’t really like being human. A lot of people I know don’t really like themselves; they would rather be someone different. And the thought that Jesus is just as human as they are does not sit well with them. So we put Jesus into a different ‘category of humanness.’ We wrongly think, Yes Jesus was human, but he was also God, so to compare the humanity of Jesus with our humanity seems wrong. At its essence the humanity of Jesus is no different to our humanity. As the second Adam, Jesus lived a sinless life, but his sinlessness did not make him less human. The truth is, our sinfulness makes us less human while Jesus’ sinlessness made him more of a human being. Jesus never experienced the ‘dehumanising’ effects of sin.

A third reason why we struggle with the humanity of Jesus is that we make the mistake of comparing the humanity of Jesus with our humanity; instead it should be the other way round. We should be redefining our humanness in the light of his humanity. We should be looking at the life of Jesus and in doing so come to a new understanding of what it means for us to be human. If through salvation God wants to restore us to his original intent, then we are going to have to rethink what it really means to be human, and that is what the life of Jesus wants to show us.

We are going to start our study of the humanity of Jesus by looking at His birth, and what it meant for Jesus to become human.

a. Jesus’ humanity was the result of Him choosing to make himself nothing. Paul tells us ‘Who being in the very nature God, did not consider equality with God something to be grasped, but made himself nothing, taking the very form of a servant being made in human likeness.’ Philippians 2:6-7. These words of Paul express what Jesus did when he became a baby, and how he chose to live his life as a human.

He did not consider equality with God something to be grasped. ‘Christ being fully God, possessing the very nature of God and being fully equal to God in every respect, did not thereby insist on holding onto all the privileges and benefits of his position of equality with God [the Father]. He did not clutch or grasp his place of equality with the father and all that this brought to him in such a way that He choose the condescension and humiliation of the servant role he was being called to accept. He did not think of his status as something to be clung to or grasped.

As a man, Jesus was divested of all self interest; He refused to use his power or glory to gain a reputation. Often when Jesus healed someone he would say something like, “Don’t tell anyone.” He had no interest in making a name for himself. He did not care about his reputation. Because of our sinful habits we have formed over the years, it is our natural inclination to be self protective, to avoid being vulnerable, but in Jesus we see that in emptying himself he became extremely vulnerable. The vulnerability in his humanity was never inconsistent with God’s original intention for mankind. If fact, the vulnerability that Jesus displayed was a natural expression of perfect humanity. For it is through our vulnerabilities we discover our ability to love and care for others.

In his birth, Jesus let go of all the power, prestige and position, and became a vulnerable weak dependent baby.

The birth narrative of the gospels are stories that exalt vulnerability, they teach us that being human is tied to our ability to embrace a God ordained vulnerability, that will make dependence upon him essential and natural. Let me give you some facts about the vulnerabilities around Jesus’ birth.

a. Mary was a teenager who conceived outside marriage. Think of the shame and stigma there must have been for Jesus’ mother, and for Jesus.

b. Registering for the census must have been a very painful act, not only because doing so was inconvenient, but because it was a reminder that while God's people, Israel, were in the land of promise, they were not free; they were under the rule of a pagan power. A Roman law, made by a pagan potentate, compelled the Israelites to comply.

Also physically this was bound to be painful for Mary. She was heavily pregnant an arduous journey of 70 miles!!! The Saviour of the world travelling in his mothers womb. The King of Kings travelling in his mothers womb. How safe was that journey? Did you know there is no mention of a donkey in the Christmas story

The birth of Jesus was welcomed into the world by a group of shepherds, basically ignorant and uneducated. They were unskilled. The work of a shepherd was generally given to children to do because it was so simple. It didn't take any particular talent. They had no trade and were the lowest paid. By virtue of the necessity of caring for sheep seven days a week, they lived in some level of violation of Mosaic Law. Many commentators believe. They couldn't maintain the Sabbath the way the Sabbath should have been maintained. So not only were these shepherds looked on as the "lowest of the low" they were also seen as outcasts because they violated the Jewish Laws. If you read Jewish literature written from the birth of Jesus over the next hundred years or so they shepherds were seen as more and more despised. In fact, it wasn't long after this that they were began to be seen as unreliable, untrustworthy, unsavoury characters who were largely suspected of stealing sheep and doing all kinds of illegal things. Yet these were the first to hear about the birth of the saviour of the world

Father help me to be more human and vulnerable . Bible in a year reading plan Leviticus 24:1-26:13
title: STUDY THEME,

html:
The story of the Birth of Jesus is not only about how He began His life on earth but it contains an important principle that should mark all our lives. God wants us to live in the real world, as it is not what we think it should be. This will require great vulnerability and often we will feel out of our depth and misunderstood. The vulnerability of Jesus caused great suspicion but it also drew people like the shepherds to him.

The steps Jesus took to become human are the same steps we all need to take in order to become truly human. The manner, in which Jesus embraced his humanity, is how he redefined our humanity. He refused to hold onto his privileges as God, but rather he made himself of ‘no reputation.’ Humility and the refusal to be self seeking are totally consistent with how God originally intended mankind to live. Condescension, as we shall see is an expression of being secure in the real knowledge of the love of God.

Although Jesus refused to hold onto his privileges and position as God, he never ceased to be God, He never depended on his Divinity to cope with the pressures and demands of his humanity.

The implications of having this mindset are enormous.

Every time we feel a need to hold onto a position of power or every time we feel a need to be seen to be in control in order to feel secure and fulfilled, we are violating the attitudes that brought Jesus to earth and to the cross. Jesus did not feel the need to hold on to his position, power, or prestige. He did not get his security from being in place of prominence or authority, but from his submission to his father. Security through submission is the way to go.

Father help me embrace my humanity by letting go of prestige power and position

Bible in a year: Leviticus 26:14-27:34 Numbers 1:1-41
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 3

html:
The second thing that Paul says is that Jesus made himself nothing. Jesus was prepared to empty himself. "Emptied himself" (NRSV) is the Greek verb kenaō, literally, "to make empty,” This phrase has caused much debate, as to what Jesus emptied himself of. I don’t think that is the right question to ask. I think the best way to understand the phrase is to see it as a summation of Jesus’ way of living. The point Paul wants to make is that Jesus lived a poured-out life. Paul is not saying that Jesus poured something out of himself, no, rather he poured out himself.

If we feel that we need to be the centre of our worlds, if we think that life is all about having our needs being met, then we are becoming less than human. There is something built in all of us that requires us to embrace insignificance, we have been created to live humble lives that do not find significance or value in reputation, position or power,

Humility could be defined as, ‘freedom from any need to impress or to have your needs/wants met because you are living a life of contentment and complete self acceptance because of the grace of God.’ There is real freedom in not being the centre of the universe. In coming to earth and making himself of no reputation, Jesus was teaching us a new way to think, he was bringing a new world view, a different way to live. He was teaching us that having a humble attitude that is not in pursuit of reputation, power or position rather it is to discover what it really means to be human. We all struggle with pride; we all want to be thought of better than we really are. But pride is the root of all sin, and has the power to dehumanise us.
