To become more like Jesus is to become truly human. Our humanity is the highest expression of God’s creative power because He made man in his own image. Being human is a wonderful thing, and as we fully grasp this we will not say ‘we are only human’ again. It will be something that we will delight in rather than get annoyed at. Our humanity is something to be celebrated.

Father, teach me how to live a poured out life

Bible in a year: Numbers 1:42-3:32
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 4

html:
The growth of Jesus. Luke 2:40-52

I don’t know if you have thought much about the growth of Jesus?. As a human being, Jesus needed to grow in every area of his life. He needed to grow physically, emotionally, spiritually, intellectually and socially. Jesus did not come to earth being complete or mature. He had things to learn, he had to mature and grow, like us all, he was a person in process. We are told in the book of Hebrews, ‘He learned obedience by what he suffered.’ Hebrews 5:8 The problem we have regarding the growth of Jesus is that in our minds we equate sinlessness with perfection. We think, ‘if Jesus was sinless, [and he was,] then surely he did not need to grow emotionally, spiritually, intellectually and socially, because he was perfect, However, in order for him to totally identify with our humanity he needed to become a ‘person of process,’ He needed to know what it was like to develop and change.

The growth of Jesus teaches us a lot about our growth, His growth is a template for our growth.

We need to ask ourselves important questions.

Am I growing as a person?

Am I growing in my relationship with God?

I think it would be fair to say that the answer to these two questions are connected. You cannot grow in your relationship with God and not grow as a person

These are not always easy questions to answer.

Sometimes it can be difficult to evaluate the condition of our own hearts and our relationship with God.

Sometimes it can be difficult to define what spiritual growth looks like, because it can look different at different times of our lives.

At other times we wish there was a formula, three easy steps to grow in you relationship with God, something like ‘read your bible and pray every day. Like ‘an apple a day keeps the doctor away spirituality.’ We want our relationship with God to be easy, be formulaic, but often it is the complete opposite.

Father,, Do you see growth in my relationship with you?

Bible in a year: Numbers 3:33-5:22
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 5

html:
So if we look at the life of Jesus we can discover some principles that will help us in our own growth.

The Incarnation was a huge learning curve for Jesus.

In Luke’s gospel 2:40-52 we read the familiar passage of Jesus visiting the temple of Jerusalem as a boy. This passage has caused a lot of debate, but it is unique because it is the only passage that addresses the growth of Jesus. Being fully human, meant that Jesus needed to grow, to mature and to learn. In some sense this incident from Jesus' boyhood helps us see how Jesus became the type of man he was. As a boy he sowed seeds that grew up into manly godliness and maturity.

We often rob Jesus of his humanity, we think that he always knew everything, or because he was God manifested in the flesh then he had everything on tap. However, that is not the case. He had to learn how to walk, talk, go to the bathroom, he had to learn how to read and write, he may have got his spellings or maths wrong at times. He had to learn how to build relationships, to read social cues and customs. As a man he needed to learn how to relate to God as his father.

We are told by Luke, "Every year his parents went to Jerusalem for the feast of the Passover." All male Jews were required to attend at the Temple three times in the year, at Passover, Pentecost and the Feast of Tabernacles (Ex. 23:14-17). The Mishnah expressly exempts women from the obligation (Haggai 1:1), but some rabbis appear to have thought they should go up and some, of course, did. Attendance at all three festivals was difficult with Jews scattered all over the Roman world and beyond, but many made the effort once a year. It was the custom of Joseph and Mary to go up at Passover, the feast that commemorated the deliverance of the nation from Egypt (Ex. 12)." This was an extremely joyous and exciting time in the life of a Jew; it was the highlight of their religious festivals.

Jerusalem would have been crowded. How large the number of worshippers was, may be gathered from Josephus, who records that, when Cestius requested the high-priest to make a census, in order to convince Nero of the importance of Jerusalem and of the Jewish nation, the number of lambs slain was found to be 256,500, which, at the lowest calculation of ten persons to every sacrificial lamb, would give a population of 2,565,000.

The 12th year was the final year of preparation for a lad before he entered full participation into the religious life of the synagogue. Up until that time his parents, especially his father, taught him the commandments of the law. However, at the end of the 12th year the child goes through a ceremony by which he formally takes on the yoke of the law and becomes a barmitzvah or "son of the commandment.’’ He would then assume all the responsibilities implied in his circumcision. The Mishnah encourages to take a boy to the observance a year or two before he turned thirteen so that he might be prepared (Yoma 8:4), and this may have been what happened when Mary, Joseph and Jesus travelled to Jerusalem at this time.

Father may the times of spiritual celebrations be a contributing factor to my growth

Bible in a year: Numbers 5:23-7:59 Understanding
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 6

html:
In Luke 2:41-52 there are two references to the growth of Jesus. In verse 40 we read ‘And the child grew and became strong; he was filled with wisdom, and the grace of God was on him.’ Then in verse 52 we read ‘And Jesus grew in wisdom and stature, and in favour with God and man.’ These two verses look very similar, but they are communicating two very different things. They use two completely different words for ’grow.’

In verse 40 the word Luke uses is auxáno which means natural growth, like a baby growing or a plant growing. The word means movement towards a destination, to go up, mount up, to climb a mountain or a platform. Luke uses the same word in Acts 2:34 where he says, "For David did not ascend to heaven.’ In verse 52 the word Luke uses an other word for ‘growth’ the word is prokopto which was used of an army of pioneer wood cutters which preceded the regular army, cutting a road through an impenetrable forest, thus making possible the advance of the latter into regions where otherwise it could not have gone, the word was also used to describe the lengthening of a bit of metal out by hammering (as a smith forges metals) this is not natural growth but intentional growth.

Let’s just say that:-

a. We all need these two types of growth in our lives.

b. Natural growth is the basis for intentional growth

c. We will never mature and become the people God wants us to be without intentional growth.

d. Intentional growth is much more difficult than natural growth

e. Natural growth is for those who are young, [in their faith,] while intentional growth is for those who are older.

When it comes to our relationship with God we need to exercise the ‘discipline of prokopto’ we need to embark on the painful process of removing things from our lives so we can enter into a new place in our relationship with God. For Jesus, growth was a demanding painful process which ensured that he was able to cut his way to the cross.

It is very easy for any of us to be intentionally unintentional when it comes to us working on our growth and our relationship with God, especially as we get older. We can become complacent, choosing to live out of auto-pilot. We can become fatigued by the stress of life, that we do not have the energy or inclination to ‘prokopto.’and our relationship with God suffers. We can stop cutting things from our lives that threaten spiritual growth.

The context of growth.

For the next 18 years and beyond, Jesus went through the ‘prokopto’ process as he completely embraced his humanity. He was continually cutting away things out of his life so he could reach the cross. He was continually making hard choices so he could grow, and fulfil the will of his father.

Father I pray that prokopto be an ongoing part of my life.

Bible in a year: Numbers 7:60-10:10
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 7

html:
So how do we get the resources and resolve to embrace the process of growth?

We need to recognise our need of grace.

Twice Luke tells us that Jesus grew in favour with God. Luke 2:41,52 Have you ever thought that Jesus needed grace? We may struggle with the concept that Jesus needed grace just as much as we need grace. Often we fall into the trap of thinking that the only reason why we need grace is because we are sinners, and there is nothing we can do to earn God's love. Grace is more an attribute of God than a response to our sin. It is the essence of the fatherhood of God. Grace is the unconditional, and expressed acceptance of someone else despite their national identity, ethnic grouping, cultural traditions, family background, religious preference, social standing, personality, eccentricity or sinful behaviour. We must remember that Jesus was sinless, but being sinless did not make his Father love him any more. His father accepted his sinless life as a substitute for our sinful lives. Jesus always did the things that pleased his father, but his love for His son was unconditional. Experiencing the grace of God led to real growth. Because Jesus had no pride in his heart he was responsive to the grace of his Father. Jesus grew because he knew that his father loved him unconditionally. Being secure in his Father’s love made his growth possible. The courage to grow is rooted in knowing we are completely loved. As Jesus enjoyed the love of his father he found the security to ‘prokopto.’

2 Peter 3:18 ‘But grow in the grace and knowledge of our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ.’

We need to prize wisdom above knowledge.

When we are told that Jesus grew in wisdom, we must not think that it is referring soley to knowledge or understanding. Wisdom includes knowledge and understanding, but it is a lot more. Wisdom is allowing the understanding of biblical principles to dominate and govern every area of our lives. It is understanding what God would require in every circumstance. Wisdom is having a spiritual understanding about every area of life. It is about truly knowing God and rightly responding to God in love and dependence and obedience! Wisdom is about making the things of the Father your things. It is the knowledge of how to do the right thing at the right time in the right way, in all circumstances.

It can’t be assumed that Jesus brought all his wisdom and knowledge with him simply because he was God. It is also a mistake to assume that wisdom and knowledge was poured into him because of God’s favour upon him. That’s just not the way wisdom works, and it’s not the way it worked in Jesus’ life. One is not simply filled with wisdom. Wisdom is something acquired through effort and experience. I don’t think it is possible to live a God glorifying life without growing in wisdom.

Jesus grew in stature.

This word for stature can either mean physical height or to grow in age, either way, the idea is that at times in our lives growth needs to be evident, visible, easy to recognise. Think of it in this way, sometimes we find it difficult to discern growth in ourselves, so why not sit down with those who love you and know and ask them, ‘Do you see spiritual growth in me?’ ‘Am I Changing?’ Authentic growth doesn’t remain invisible.

Jesus grew in favour with men.

This does not mean that Jesus was a people pleaser. Rather it means Jesus had the growth and maturity to relate to others in ways that were meaningful and helpful. His growth in his relationship with his father determined how others related to him and he related to them.

Father help me be like Jesus and grow in grace

Bible in a year: Numbers 10:11-13:16
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 8

html:
How can we grow in these ways? Our text gives us some clues. Luke2:41-52

Jesus was overtly teachable.

Here he was sitting among the religious teachers, listening and asking questions. I understand that here Jesus was only 12 years old and had lots to learn, however, all through his life on earth Jesus was teachable. How do I know that? Because being teachable is a posture of the heart that come from humility. Read John 7:16 NIV “My teaching is not my own. It comes from the one who sent me.’ You could say, ‘Being unteachable is like trying to play catch with your hands in your pocket.’

Jesus was focused on his Father.

When Mary and Joseph found him in the temple Jesus was surprised. ‘Why were you searching for me” he asked. “Didn’t you know I had to be in my Father’s house?’ [or about my Father’s business.]’ The way Luke describes how Mary and Joseph searched is referring to their mental attitude. The search was full of doubt and mental agony. It must have been particularly distressing for them to realise that Jesus was missing. It is understandable that they were so wrapped up in their own pain that they could not see that there was nothing wrong with what the boy did in staying at the temple. Their rationale is irrational: because they suffered, they assumed him wrong.

It is not that they did not understand Christ's statement in an academic sense; it is just that they are so out of fellowship with him that they will not accept his conclusion. To accept his conclusion is to admit they are wrong, and that is just something that they will not do. One or the other of them had to be wrong; it was not Christ. One of the greatest surrenders of pride is to admit that you have caused your own pain; that is what Joseph and Mary are struggling with. Make no mistake the accusation of Joseph and Mary is completely unfair. At this time they didn’t get him or understand him. Despite that, he maintained his focus. Parents will not always get or understand their children and that has to be okay. Sometimes to maintain a spiritual focus can be very difficult and stressful.

When Jesus was growing up as a boy, the people of Israel had developed a wrong concept of God. God was someone who was far away, someone who did not care, someone who hadn't spoken to the nation for 400 years. Peoples' perception of God was that He imposed rules and regulations on them. Judaism had become a legalistic religion with no love or compassion and people where used to living at a distance from Him. Here we have a 12 year old boy calling this God his father, someone close, someone who cared, someone whom he could trust, someone he could relate to, someone who loved him and whom he could love back. Jesus' view of God as his father was the antithesis to how everyone else saw God. This would have really challenged the Jewish mind-set.

Growth is linked to a person's experience of God as their father. When we are feeling insecure, and are hounded with a bad self-image we will not grow or mature as people. It is only when we are feeling secure and accepted that we will have the potential for real growth. That is why in the 'Lord's Prayer' Jesus begins by expressing our need to experience God as father.

Jesus was deliberately submissive.

The NIV tells us in verse 51 ‘Then he went down to Nazareth with them and was obedient to them.’

The problem is that the word obedient can miss what the text is saying. Someone can be ‘obedient,’ but in their hearts not be submissive, however, it is more difficult to be submissive and not be obedient. The word that Luke uses carries the idea of having an attitude of deep respect and humility. Jesus was free and secure enough that he had no problem with submission. Even though they didn’t understand Him, Jesus was submissive. Jesus was submissive even though he wasn’t understood

As we have seen, growing in our relationship with God requires intentionality on our part, it is not achieved by default. Like Jesus we need to ‘prokopto’ continually cut from our lives the things that threaten us from growing in our relationship with God.

Father, help me enjoy your fatherhood so I can grow.

Bible in a year: Numbers 13:17-15:21.
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 9

html:
Jesus and the Holy Spirit. Luke 3:21-22, 4:1, 10, 18-19.

As we look at the humanity of Jesus we want to look at Jesus’ relationship with the Holy Spirit. The humanity of Jesus not only teaches us what it means to be human, but it also teaches us about the person and work of the Holy Spirit. Before we start, let’s set down some things that will help us in our thinking.

1. Jesus lived normally within the confines of his human limitations, relying predominantly on the divine resources of the Father and the Holy Spirit, while using his own divine power infrequently, if at all, and never for his own benefit.

As a man Jesus lived the life he lived, not because he had a divine nature but because he was predominantly dependant on the Holy Spirit. As a man he chose to live a life that required the empowering of the Holy Spirit. In a sermon to the Gentile Cornelius and his household, the apostle Peter offered a summary statement of the ministry of Jesus: “how God anointed Jesus of Nazareth with the Holy Spirit and with power; how he went about doing good and healing all who were oppressed by the devil, for God was with him” (Acts 10:38). On occasions Jesus did display aspects of his divine nature, for example when he was transfigured, or when walked on water, or when he forgave sin, for only God can forgive sin; but for the most part, Jesus lived as an ordinary man who had a life that was empowered by the Holy Spirit.

The humanity of Jesus teaches us how the Holy Spirit wants to relate to us.

In the Old Testament the Holy Spirit came upon people for a specific period of time with a specific purpose. For example when Saul became King he was anointed by the Spirit. We are told, ‘When they came there to the hill, there was a group of prophets to meet him; then the Spirit of God came upon him, and he prophesied among them.’ 1 Samuel 10:10. Then because of Saul's’ disobedience we are told. ‘But the Spirit of the Lord departed from Saul, and a distressing Spirit from the Lord troubled him!’ 1 Samuel 16:14. That is why in Psalm 51 David prayed ‘Take not your Holy Spirit from me.’

But in the humanity of Jesus we see that we were created to live a life of dependence on the Father and empowered by the Spirit; a life of continual dependence on the Holy Spirit. We are told in John 3:34 that Jesus had the Spirit in his life without limit, and athough Jesus’ experience of the Spirit was greater than ours, but that does not mean that Jesus ceases to be our example or prototype of what it means to live as Spirit filled people.

Father thank you that my humanity was created for the life and work of the Spirit.

Bible in a year: Numbers 15:22-16:50.
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 10

html:
Do you realise we have all been uniquely designed by God, and given unique lives that are created to require and accommodate the Holy Spirit. We have all been given lives that have been purposed built by God to be suitable ‘accommodation’ for his Spirit. If Jesus is our example of authentic humanity, then we are meant to follow and imitate him, then if he needed to live a life of continual dependence on the Holy Spirit, so do we. If Jesus had chosen to make his deity the predominate source of his life and ministry, he would have ceased to be truly human and we would not be able to imitate him. The Holy Spirit wants to be to us everything that he was to Jesus. Or you could say, as a man Jesus needed to learn to relate to the Holy Spirit in order to be authentically human.

In Luke chapters 3-4 we read a lot about Jesus’ relationship with the Holy Spirit. So we want to briefly look at 5 things that these chapters teach us about Jesus his relationship with the Spirit, and the kind of relationship we need to have with the Holy Spirit.

At his baptism the Holy Spirit affirmed the Father’s love for Jesus.

Luke 3:22 reads ‘And the Holy Spirit descended on Him in bodily form like a dove, and a voice came from heaven; You are my Son whom I love; with you I am well pleased.’ I don’t think that this was Jesus’ first experience of the Holy Spirit, We are not ‘explicitly’ told if Jesus had previous experiences of the Spirit, but there are some implied indications that the Holy Spirit was active in his early life, For example when Luke describes Jesus’ growth he does so in spiritual terms see Luke 2:52. However, at His baptism, Jesus had an experience of the Spirit that prepared him for the next stage of his life. The Spirit descended upon him and affirmed the Love of his father.

There is a lot about the baptism of Jesus that is unique to him, and mysterious to us. However, we can be sure that what we learn from it that one of the functions of the Holy Spirit is to assure us of the love of God.

Did Jesus always know that he was loved by his father? Absolutely yes; however at his baptism he got a new, or fresh experience of His father’s love. In his humanity Jesus needed an increasing, ongoing understanding and experience of his father’s love.

‘Christians are fond of presenting a fully formed Jesus, a man-shaped God who knew from his birth what he had to do and how he had to do it, who wondered around in a divine certainty, complete with a halo. Like those icons; the baby with a halo, the piercing eyes and the imperial upraised hand. Of course, before this he must have had some awareness: the stories of his mother, the events of his birth, his experience in the temple would have shown that he was marked out. But that is not the same saying that he understood right from the start how it would go. Jesus was not working to a script; he was coming to a realisation.’ Nick Page. Source unknown

Father may the work Spirit in my life make me more human.

Bible in a year: Numbers 17-20
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 11

html:
Self acceptance is rooted in God’s acceptance of us. Accepting who we are requires us to accept God’s love. If Jesus was going to come through the ordeal of the temptation, the demands of ministry and the horror of the cross then he would need to know deep within his heart that he was loved by his father. The love of the father, gave Jesus the security and wisdom he needed to discern and display the self sacrificing way of life that he had been called to.

Most of the personal issues we face as people are rooted in our lack of understanding our identity as children of God. Often our hearts are flooded with insecurities, fears and anxieties. We struggle to accept who we are, longing to be someone else. For many Christians ‘Child of God’ is more a title than an experience, it is more of a theological concept than a dynamic reality. The most important and significant thing about any Christian is that they are a Child of God, this status is more important than their marriage, ministry, vocation, achievements, or any other thing they may value highly.

As an authentic human, Jesus teaches us than our humanity has been created to live in God’s love. It is through the work of the Holy Spirit in our lives that we realise the reality of God’s love. Knowing the love of God in our heart brings assurance of our salvation.

When Jesus heard his father declaring his love for him from heaven, what was his father communicating? The word used for love is agapetos which means to be ultimately concerned for the welfare of the one who is loved. It carries the idea of being loved deeply. Often we have a superficial response to the deep love of God. We don’t let it penetrate our lives or marinate our hearts. At this point in Jesus’ life, Jesus had done no teaching, nor any miracles; he just lived a quiet life with his family in Nazareth. Yet he was completely loved by his father in heaven.

When it comes to the love of God most of us have a difficulty receiving it. We think it is too good to be true. As we consider Jesus’ baptism we discover that Jesus was in a place where he was open to his father love, and willing to receive his father’s love. Jesus made a deliberate choice to humble himself, and his humility enabled him to engage with and accept his father love. As a man Jesus never had to earn his Father’s love, but as a man he needed to learn how to receive it and live in it through humility.

Knowledge of God's love for us should be our motivation for ministry.

We should be reaching out to others because we know that God loves us, our ministry should not be us trying to earn Gods love.

The motive and nature of our ministry will depend on how sensitive we are of Gods love for us. As Jesus faced the future with all the pain and problems, he knew that his father loved him. That love would give him enduring strength and perseverance. If we are not continually open and sensitive to the fathers love then there is no way we will survive the demands of Christian life or ministry.

Father teach me how to live In your love.

Bible in a year: Numbers 21-23.
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 12

html:
2. Jesus was full of the Holy Spirit. Luke 4:1a

We often think of being filled with the Spirit as something like filling a cup with water, or pouring liquid into a container. But a better way to look at it is to understand the word to mean fulfil or to make complete. Because Jesus was God, the Holy Spirit was unable to add anything to Him. As God, Jesus was complete, but as a man Jesus needed to be filled or ‘fulfilled,’ by the Spirit. Authentic humanity is made complete by the fulfilling of the Spirit. I love that, maturity and Spiritual growth are the result of being made complete by the Spirit. Up to this point in Jesus’ life, he had done no kind of ministry, he hadn’t done any miracles or taught, yet he was full of the Holy Spirit. It was as if the Father was using the activity of the Spirit to develop Jesus in his humanity. I like the thought that our development, maturity and growth as people is related to us being fulfilled or being made content by the inward work of the Holy Spirit in our lives. All the purposes of God are fulfilled in our lives by us being fulfilled by the Spirit.

Jesus was led by the Spirit. Luke 4:1b.

Here we are told that the Holy Spirit led Jesus into the wilderness. We are going to look at this in detail the another time. But just let me say that the word Luke uses for led is very different and the complete opposite of the word Mark uses in his account of the temptation of Jesus. We will compare the two words another time. However, the word Luke uses is a very gentle word which means to take someone by the hand and lead them gently forward. It was also used to describe the leading of an animal by a rope.

There is one thing we can learn from Jesus about our humanity from this word; that is, we need to embrace and joyfully accept the fact that we have been created for a life of submission. This is so exciting and liberating; the realisation that our lives are not about us, or our agendas, but about God.

Let me put this way, lack of submission is so curtailing for it drives a person into the dead-end cul- de- sac of their own horizons, robbing them of the glorious and the unexpected that is found in having a life that is defined by our relationship with God through his Spirit.

It is good to know that the leading of the Spirit in anyone’s life is initiated by the Spirit which means that God decides when we need special guidance or leading.

It is sad that many Christians get very anxious about God’s guidance. I often tell people that guidance is God’s initiative. And as far as I know the only prayer for guidance in the New Testament is “lead us not into temptation.”

Often in Christian circles when people talk or think about being led by the Spirit they are usually thinking about ministry, or being led to serve or help others. Now that often happens, however, the primary purpose of the Spirit’s leading is character transformation and making us more like Jesus. For example there might be a circumstances or a situation you feel threatened by, and you have a strong desire to take control, but you hear God saying through His Spirit ‘Stand back; let me deal with this, let me sort this out.’ The standing back that God may ask of us is so he can develop his work of transformation within us.

Father help me discover the glorious joy of submission and the transforming leading of the Spirit

Bible in a year: Numbers 24:1-26:34
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 13

html:
Jesus returned to Galilee in the power of the Spirit.

Many commentators point out the fact that the Greek word for power dunamis is the word from which we get our English word dynamite. This may be true, but is not very helpful, for dynamite is usually a destructive power, but the power of the Holy Spirit is a positive, life giving power, it carries the idea of a dynamic or a break-through power. It also is a creative power, This is the word that was used in Luke1:35 where the angel told Mary that the power of the most High will over shadow her, so that the Holy one to be born will be called the Son of God.

For Christians there must be a dependence on the power and strength of the Spirit. Jesus needed to depend on the Spirit if his humanity and ministry was going to be authentic, helpful and glorifying to his father.

The lives God wants us to live, the people God wants us to be, the things God wants us do, and the battles God wants us to fight, will always require the empowerment of the Holy Spirit. In tying the temptation in the wilderness to Jesus’ return to Galilee in the power of the Spirit. Luke is making a very helpful point. When we are involved in spiritual warfare we are really fighting to maintain our submission to the Spirit. If Jesus had given into any of the temptations that he faced in the wilderness he would have been taking things into his own hands and putting himself outside the influence and power of the Holy Spirit.

Jesus was anointed by the Spirit.

The word anointed means to sanctify or set something or someone apart for exclusive use. Luke 4:28-19. We read about Jesus’ anointing by the Spirit.

‘The Spirit of the Lord is on me, because he has anointed me to proclaim good news to the poor. He has sent me to proclaim freedom for the prisoners and recovery of sight for the blind, to set the oppressed free, to proclaim the years of the Lord’s favour.’

These are amazing verses, which have a lot to teach us about Jesus’ relationship with the Holy Spirit and his mission. But there are two general principles which we can pick up from these verses.

a. The Holy Spirit prevents someone from being exclusive in their relationships. When you look at the people these verses talk about, many of them would not fit in our middle class church structures.

Clarence Jordan translated the passage:

"The Lord's spirit is on me;

He has ordained me to break the good news to the poor people.

He has sent me to proclaim freedom for the oppressed,

And sight for the blind,

To help those who have been grievously insulted to find dignity;

To proclaim the Lord's new era." Source unknown

As a perfect human, Jesus was empowered by the Holy Spirit to express his authentic humanity by pursuing and embracing the marginalized and the needy.

Authentic humanity that is empowered by the Spirit is extremely relevant. Good news to the poor, freedom for the oppressed, sight for the blind, dignity for the insulted.

The life and ministry of Jesus was really a demonstration of God’s original intention for humanity, where the people would live selfless lives, being sensitive and caring about the needs of others. The work of the Holy Spirit in someone life will cause them to be other-centred never self -centred.

From the life of Jesus we learn that to be really human means that we need to live a life that is continually dependent on the Holy Spirit and be empowered by the Holy Spirit. This means that submission to God and his Spirit needs to become a joyful, ongoing, natural expression of our redeemed humanity.

Farther, I have a desperate need of a Spirit filled life.

Bible in a year: Numbers 26:35-28:31.
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 14

html:
Jesus’ humanity and temptation. Luke 4:1-13

We want to take a look at the temptation of Jesus and how it relates to his humanity and our humanity. Sometimes we mistakenly think that it must have been easier for Jesus to resist temptation than it is for us. Jesus was God, he was sinless therefore he must have had more power than we do to resist the temptation of Satan! The problem with this kind of thinking is that Jesus was tempted as a man not as God. James 1:3 tells us that God cannot be tempted. So as a human being Jesus had to face these temptations.

So we want to draw out some principles from the temptation of Jesus that will help us understand his humanity and ours. But before we do that let me say a couple of things about the context of this incident, the nature of spiritual warfare, the importance of discipline and address our understanding of temptation.

THE CONTEXT.

In his book ‘Adopted for Life’, Dr Russell Moore tells the story of how he and his wife adopted two orphans from Russia and brought them to live with him and his family in the USA. The interesting thing about their story is this; these two boys had to relearn everything. They had to learn a new language, a new culture, a new education system, they had to get used to different food. They had to learn how to be members of a family; they needed to learn how to receive love and care. This was a total culture shock for them, moving from the known to the unknown, almost as radical as becoming a child of God.

Becoming child of God is the, most necessary, most radical and the most exciting experience that a person can ever know. But like Russian orphans in a strange land, we do not know how to cope, we don’t really understand the differences, the changes, the newness, so we spend a lot of energy trying to hold on to our old way of living. We become addicted to our past, afraid to embrace a new way of living in Jesus. Sometimes who we were dominates who we are now. We cannot live the lives that God wants us to live unless we are consciously living as children of God. So over the next few days, we want to look at Matthew 4:1-11 and try to grasp Jesus’ understanding of son-ship and how being a Son governed His attitudes and mindset. We want to try to learn some things that may help us to live as children of God.

Father help me understand that the intention of temptation is to threaten my humanity and my identity as your child. Bible in a year reading plan Numbers 29:1-31:47
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 15

html:
Temptation of Jesus.

In some ways the temptation of Jesus in the wilderness is a revelation of the attitudes and mindset of a son of God.

What does it mean for us to be Children of God?

What does son-ship look like?

How should we as Children of God think and act?

What kind of relationship does God as our father want with us?

The temptation of Jesus is a blue print for son-ship.

Most of the personal issues we face as people are rooted in our lack of understanding our identity as children of God. Often our hearts are flooded with insecurities, fears and anxieties. As we have said before, we struggle to accept who we are, longing to be someone else. For many Christians ‘Child of God’ is more a title than an experience, it is more of a theological concept than a dynamic reality. The most important and significant thing about any Christian is that they are a Child of God, this status is more important than their marriage, ministry, vocation, achievements or any other thing they may value highly.

The basis of son-ship is knowing that you are truly loved. His father prepared Jesus for this ordeal, and planned it. When Jesus was being baptised, a voice spoke from Heaven saying “This is my Son, whom I love; with him I am well pleased.” If Jesus was going to come through the ordeal of the temptation then he would need to know deep within his heart that he was loved by his father. The love of the father gave Jesus the security and wisdom he needed to discern and refuse the temptations that Satan would put before him. As Jesus endured the hunger and desolation of the wilderness he was acutely aware that he was loved.

, Mark says “At once the Spirit sent him out into the desert.” Notice that Jesus was loved then he was led. That is the way it needs to be. It is very easy for any of us to become stressed or anxious about God’s leading in our lives. We wonder what God wants us to do with our lives, we want some divine plan written out in the sky, but it never happens. I think it is far more important to know God’s love than to know God’s plans. And maybe all the stress and anxiety around the whole area of Gods will for our lives is the result of us not having a deep enough experience of His love.

God led his son into the wilderness so that he would learn that being a Son was much more important than being a servant. We can only be true servants when we learn to live as Sons. This has always been God’s way. When a person has been called and commissioned by God to be involved in his service, it is very tempting to allow that call to redefine a person. So everything we do, or everything we become is filtered through a grid of service.

A requirement of son-ship is that you are continually under the influence and direction of the Holy Spirit.

Father help me to life in the real knowledge of your love.

Bible in a year: Numbers 31:48-33:56.
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 16

html:
As a man and as a son, meant that Jesus needed a continual, developing need of the presence and work of the Spirit in his life. We fall into a trap of thinking that the work of the Spirit in my life is for those times when I am ‘serving God,’ or helping others. But no matter who or where we are, our need of the developing work of the Spirit in our hearts will never diminish or decrease. It is the work and ways of the Holy Spirit in us that distinguishes us as children of God.

We are told that the Spirit led Jesus into the wilderness. The word translated ‘sent’ in Mark 1:12 is a very weak translation. The word he uses for “Sent” is an extremely strong word, it literally means to drive out your enemies. In the LXX [the Greek translation of the Old Testament] the word is used in the context where an enemy who is frustrating or standing in the way of God fulfilling his purpose for his chosen people, is ‘cast out’ by God, so that God’s purposes may be fulfilled. See Exodus 23:30 Deuteronomy 33:27ff.

The word was mostly used in the New Testament in relation to casting out demons. The word expresses passion of God’s Ekballo, or God’s resistance to evil. God was sending his son into the wilderness with a strong passion so he could confront and unmask the evil one.

It is interesting to note that the word Luke uses to describe the Spirit leading Jesus into the wilderness. The word almost means the complete opposite to Ekballo, it has the idea to carry, to bring, and to keep.

Protected by passion

On the one hand we have the Spirit driving Jesus into the wilderness, as an expression of God passion against evil; and on the other had we have the keeping power of the Spirit leading Jesus. This is not a contradiction, nor is it even two opposites. God’s passion and God’s protection always go together.

Father help me recognise that your leading on my life is not always the same

Bible in a year: Numbers 34-36 Deuteronomy 1:1-15
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 17

html:
SPIRITUAL WARFARE.

Spiritual warfare was God Initiative. Jesus was about to enter into a ministry which would be marked with confrontation with the powers of darkness. When he would feel under pressure with his back against the wall he would know that Spiritual warfare would be initiated not by Satan but by his Father. (It is interesting to note that in the four exorcisms that Mark covers in detail Jesus always goes to where the demon is, the demon doesn’t go to Him.)

We need to make a comment about how some people understand the temptation of Jesus in light of his Baptism. Many people see the Temptation of Jesus as a reaction of Satan to what Jesus’ Father said to him when he was baptized. This in turn has lead to some people creating a “cause and effect theology” which says something like. “I must be doing something right because Satan is attacking me.” They believe that the blessing of God makes them more open to Satan’s attacks. This is both dangerous and inconsistent with scripture.

Maybe in our thinking we assume that if some experience has been initiated by God then it is going to feel right, we are going to have a peace about it. However sometimes, real life feels like death. Jesus was never a victim but was always the subliminal conqueror who marched into enemy territory to destroy the works of the evil one. By that I mean, that for Jesus victory did not come through triumphalism but through absolute submission.

To say “I must be doing something right because Satan is attacking me.”is to get your affirmation from Satan not from God.

For the most part the bible teaches that Spiritual warfare is not Satan reacting to God, but God pursuing Satan.

Sometimes it is only through Spiritual warfare and wrestling with temptations that important spiritual principles come into focus. It seems that God sometimes uses spiritual warfare to heighten our spiritual awareness and to underpin important spiritual truths. For the Christian the battlefield is often the classroom of God. As Jesus wrestled with Satan in the wilderness there appears to be a deepening in His trust and dependence upon his Father. In the intensity of the battle, Jesus revisited the core spiritual principles that had shaped his life. In order to overcome this evil one Jesus needed to reaffirm what his life was about and how he wanted to live, and what he lived for

The discipline of Jesus

Jesus had to experience the discipline of a son so he could affirm his humanity and fulfil His fathers’ purposes for his life. During this period in the wilderness Jesus had experience his father’s discipline. Deuteronomy 8 was in his mind, Verses 2-5 read.

‘Remember how the LORD your God led you all the way in the desert these forty years; to humble you and to test you in order to know what was in your heart, whether or not you would keep his commands. He humbled you, causing you to hunger and then feeding you with manna, which neither you nor your fathers had known, to teach you that man does not live on bread alone but on every word that comes from the mouth of the LORD. Your clothes did not wear out and your feet did not swell during these forty years. Know then in your heart that as a man disciplines his son, so the LORD your God disciplines you.’ Deuteronomy 8:2-3. Where the People of Israel failed in the wilderness, Jesus succeeded.

Often when it comes to the whole area of discipline we have muddled thinking. We are inclined to see discipline as a kind of punishment for sin. However in the mind of God, discipline is not a divine reaction to sin, but an aid to growth and maturity. As a son Jesus never sinned, but as a son he required discipline. The word discipline simply means to educate, to teach. The Greek word for discipline paideia was used to describe "the process of educating man into his true form, the real and genuine human nature."

Jesus had a divinely appointed encounter in the wilderness. Jesus was learning that cost and suffering were part of the life he was called to. His wilderness hunger, loneliness and temptation were consistent with the love and will of his Father.

Temptation.

The word Luke uses for Temptations in 4:13 is the Greek word peirasmos which is also often translated test or trial. It is important that we grasp the relationship between these two words.

A. Sometimes it is difficult to distinguish the difference between a temptation and a trial. It is not always easy to know if the unpleasant circumstances of our lives are being orchestrated by Satan, or sent by God, or is God using the activity of Satan to fulfil his purposes?

B. The intentions of Satan behind temptation and the intention of God behind testing are the complete opposite. Satan tempts to destroy while God tests to develop, grow and mature us.

C. Sometimes the temptation and the testing come together. The thing Satan wants to use to destroy us is the very same thing God wants to use to develop us. This is what happened to Jesus in the wilderness. It is also how Paul understood his thorn in the flesh. Look at what Paul says.

‘Therefore, in order to keep me from becoming conceited, I was given a thorn in my flesh, a messenger of Satan, to torment me. Three times I pleaded with the Lord to take it away from me. But he said to me my grace is sufficient for you, for my power is made perfect in weakness.’Therefore I will boast all the more gladly about my weaknesses, so that Christ’s power may rest on me.’

D. The outcome of the temptation/trial depends on how we respond to the temptation/trial. The attitudes and responses we need to overcome the seductive nature of temptation are similar to the attitudes and responses we need to cope with trials. Both temptation and trials require us to have a growing dependence upon God and an increasing submission to his will.

Let me conclude with a quote.

“When the world did not end as Jesus himself had said it would, his followers stopped expecting so much from God or from themselves. They hung a wooden cross on the wall and settled back into their more or less comfortable routines, remembering their once passionate devotion to God the way they remembered the other enthusiasms of their youth. Little by little, Christians became devoted to their comforts instead: the soft couch, the flannel sheets, the leg of lamb roasted with rosemary. These things made them feel safe and cared for, if not by God, then by themselves. They decided there was no contradiction between being comfortable and being Christian, and before long it was very hard to pick them out from the population at large. They no longer distinguished themselves by their bold love for one another. They did not get arrested for championing the poor. They blended in. They avoided extremes. They decided to be nice instead of holy, and God moaned out loud.” Barbara Brown Taylor.

https://www.redeemerwhitebear.org/pastors-blog/what-is-lent accessed 30/04/2025

Are we willing to go to the desert and stay as long as it takes for the Spirit to shape our heart, understanding and mission? The desert needs to be part of our Christian life you are trying to avoid or ignore? The desert is a place where we become vulnerable and thus reliant on God. As Children of God we will all have times and experiences were we will feel totally vulnerable and exposed. In these times it is easy to feel abandoned by God, you may feel that your faith is fragile, but be assured God is with you and he will use the difficult times to win your heart.

Father thank you that you are the one who initiates spiritual warfare,

Bible in a year: Deuteronomy 1:16 -3:29.
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Par18

html:
Journey through Gathsemane Mark 14:32-42.

We want to consider what it meant for Jesus as a man to take up his cross. It is so important that we grapple with this issue because like Jesus we are human and like Jesus we need to take up our cross. I fully understand that For Jesus the cross he carried was of much more horrible, horrendous, significance and important than the ‘cross,’ we will have ever have to carry, however, like Jesus, our truest humanity is most clearly displayed through a ’cruciform, life, that is a life that is shaped by a cross..

We are going too learn that to take up your cross is certainly about obedience, devotion and sacrifice, but I think the most important aspect for us about taking up our cross, is it is God way of revealing his heart to the world.

We are going to begin by thinking about Jesus in the garden of Gathsemane. I want to make three introductory remarks which will help us.

a. Gathsemane is ‘holy grounds. These are probable the most intimate and most intense moments in Jesus’ life.

b. Gathsemane is where we need to engage in a battle to maintain our humanity. Here was an other opportunity for Jesus to turn ‘stone into bread,’ to take things into his own hands, to become king without a cross, to allow his deity to overshadow his humanity. But instead he entered into an intense battle to maintain his humanity. In Matthew 26:53 Jesus said. ‘Don’t you realise that I could ask my Father for thousands of angels to protect us, and he would send them instantly.’

c. Gathsemane is the gateway to a cruciform life. That is a life shaped by a cross

At some stage in the life of every Christian there needs to be a Gethsemane moment, a significant crisis of commitment where they decide what kind of relationship they want to have with God. How would you feel if God took your cross from you? If God asked you not to carry your cross any more? These may be a strange questions, however, if it happened we would be unable to follow Jesus

At some stage in the life of every Christian, there needs to be a Gethsemane moment where the decision to enter into deeper devotion and absolute surrender to God is made.

At some stage in the life of every Christian there needs to be a Gethsemane moment where the most important questions of life are answered. It is in the crisis of Gethsemane that the essence of our lives is revealed. As Jesus suffered in the garden of Gethsemane his humanity was threatened, would he remain a man who needed to live in submission and surrender to his Father? Or would he choose to be more than human, and refuse submission and surrender? Gethsemane is where we fight to preserve our humanity and integrity. The crossroads of Gethsemane is where our past can be wasted, our priorities are challenged and our destiny is threatened.

Gethsemane is a place of choice.

We know from Luke 22:39 that Jesus had visited Gethsemane before, he was familiar with it, but on this occasion Gethsemane was much more than a geographical location. It was a place of massive spiritual significance, a symbol of Jesus’ spiritual choice. It would have been very easy for Jesus to walk away from this garden conflict. He was God, he had the power to protect and defend himself, but as a human he needed to go through the pain of completely surrendering his life to his father, in the knowledge that he would have give up the control over the consequences of his surrender. Mark tells us that he would be ‘betrayed into the hand of sinners.’

There is something in all of us that wants to avoid Gethsemane, we are happy with a ‘functional’ faith, we love God and we are willing to serve, but go to Gethsemane? Where God might ask more than we are willing to give, that scares us, it unsettles us, and like the disciples we sleep, not realising that sleeping in a place of commitment like Gethsemane could lead to denial or betrayal. Our Gethsemane will never be as difficult or painful as Jesus’. However, it is essential. There are times in all our lives when we need to visit and revisit Gethsemane, where we decide how we want to live for God, and decide if we are prepared to lay down our lives to fulfil the purposes of God. Gethsemane is the difference between a mediocre religion and whole-hearted following. Gethsemane is the difference between maintenance and maturity.

Let just say that for us Gethsemane is not a regular experience, but it will happen at times of crisis and challenge.

Father thank you for the cross you want me to carry

Bible in a year: Deuteronomy 4:1-6:15
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 19

html:
Gethsemane is more about wrestling with God than it is wrestling with Satan.

When Jesus was in the garden, as a human he was struggling with the will of his father. He said, ‘Abba, Father, everything is possible for you. Take this cup from me. Yet not what I will, but what you will.’ Wrestling with God is an important part of Christian maturity. God would rather us be honest strugglers who are finding it difficult to accept his will, than unemotional robots that simply go through the motions. God wants our honesty, he wants us to be passionate before him, and tell him our struggles.

So how did Jesus in his humanity get through his Gethsemane experience? As a man how was he able to cope? Let me say again, we will never experience what Jesus did, but we can learn from him how we can mature in our devotion and commitment to the Father.

We must not allow our emotions to dictate our understanding of the will of God. As you read Mark’s account of Jesus in the garden you will notice that Mark goes to great lengths to describe how Jesus was feeling, he was deeply distressed, troubled and overwhelmed with sorrow to the point of death. This was an extremely emotional time for Jesus.

The word used for distress is the Greek word ekthambeisthai, which means to be moved to an “intense emotional state because of something causing great surprise or perplex.’ Did Jesus know he was going to die? Yes he did, he had predicted it three times, so why was he so shocked?

Tim Keller says, ‘As he is on his way to pray, a darkness and a horror come down on him beyond anything he could have anticipated and the pain of it makes him feel he is disintegrating on the spot. https://thewearychristian.com/keller-jesus-was-shocked-by-the-pain-he-felt-in-the-garden/#:~:text=But%20he%20is.,is%20disintegrating%20on%20the%20spot Accessed 30/04/2025 It is as if Jesus was finding it difficult to grasp the enormity of what he was going to suffer until this time.’

In his humanity Jesus had to learn when it was not appropriate to use his emotions as a filter to discern the will of his father. Sometimes our emotions and God’s will do not sit well together; sometimes we need to acknowledge our emotions by not allowing them to control us. As Jesus talked honestly about how he was feeling he was taking his emotions in hand by refusing to bury them or pretend.

Again Keller says, ‘The Greeks and Romans have left us many stories of leaders and heroes as they faced death, and without exception these people were calm and dispassionate in their final hours. By contrast, in Jewish literature when Jews wrote accounts of the deaths of major figures and heroes they did not make them cool and removed like the Greeks; rather, they are shown as hot-blooded and fearless, and they praise God as they are being sliced to pieces by their persecutors. Nothing in either of these traditions—indeed nothing in ancient literature—resembles the portrayal that Mark gives us of Jesus‘ final hours as he faced his death.’ https://podscripts.co/podcasts/timothy-keller-sermons-podcast-by-gospel-in-life/the-heart-of-jesus accessed 0/04/2025

For Jesus, Gethsemane was a place where he went through the processes of dealing with his emotions and anxiety so he could submit to his father. When God asks something from us that is painful and difficult, we need to go to the garden; we need to go to the place where we wrestle with ourselves and with God. Sometimes we can assume that because something is the will of God then their will be a subjective peace about it, it will sit well with us emotionally. Sometimes that is the case, but not always. Sometimes the will of God for our lives will cause us great emotional distress. In order to maintain our integrity as children of God by refusing to take things into our own hands we must subject our emotions to his will.

The cross God wants us to carry is often sacrificed on the alter of our emotions, we allow fear and anxiety to determine the measure of our devotion and obedience. We don’t really believe or understand that the way to gain life is to loose it.

Father thank you the we have been made emotional creature help us to control our emotions as we don’t allow them to control us.’

Bible in a year: Deuteronomy 6:16-9:21
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 20

html:
We must create a sacred space of isolation.

Th The further Jesus went into the garden, the more isolated he became. He had left the crowded city and come to a remote area outside its walls. Eight of his disciples stayed at the entrance of the Garden while Jesus took Peter, James, and John with him further. Finally, even these three were left behind, about a stone’s throw away and Jesus was alone. [being ‘a stone throw away’ is very telling because often ‘sinners’ were stoned to death, was Jesus taking our place.] Jesus needed to create a sacred space, a place of intense isolation, a place where he could pour out his crushed soul before his Father. In his aloneness he pierced the darkness with ‘loud cries.’ See Hebrews 5:7. The weight he was carrying in his heart was so heavy that he was unable to remain standing.

There are times in all our lives that we are only able to deal honestly with God and with ourselves in deliberate isolation. There are times when we need to choose to withdraw from everything and everyone so we can engage in the painful act of being absolutely real and honest before God. There are times when we need to create a ‘sacred space,’ a place where all other voices are quiet, were all external distractions are removed, and we feel free to bring to God our hearts. For some this is a scary place to be, alone with God, dealing with the content of our hearts. It is this kind of brutal honesty strips us and enables us to take up our cross.

Jesus dealt with the issues that threatened God’s purposes for his life through prayer. The more I have thought about this passage, the more I am beginning to realize that prayer is much more than making requests to God, it may include that, even here in the Garden Jesus was making requests. However, prayer is engaging in a process that will bring about change in us. It is the act of realigning our will with God’s will. It is through prayer that we come to a measure of acceptance. As Jesus prayed he became more accepting of the will of His father and his death.

Father help me find a place of isolation so I can align my will with yours

Bible in a year: Deuteronomy 9:22-12:32
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 21

html:
Let us take a look at what Jesus prayed

He prayed out of relationship. He begins with the word Abba. This is the only time the word Abba is found in the gospels. And it is the only time we find it used in a prayer by Jesus. Many of us have been brought up being taught that Abba was an Aramaic meaning daddy. However, Abba was not merely a word used by young children. It was also the word that Jewish children used for their parents after they were fully grown. Abba was a mature, yet affectionate way for adults to speak to their fathers.” Abba is profoundly respectful; the deferential language of the Servant reporting to His God, yet at the same time is deeply intimate in a way that no other mortal could have used the word. Respect and familiarity seem to come together in Abba. In the patriarchal societies of antiquity, the father figure is endowed with two particular characteristics. On the one hand, the father rules as head of the household and the person to whom most respect is due, having absolute authority over his family. On the other hand, he has the responsibility of guarding, supporting and helping the other members.

Jesus’ use of the word Abba is extremely significant, for it communicates Jesus’ perception of his Father. He refused to allow this heart-breaking experience to alter his perception of his Father. In the agony of his heart he still had a deep love and respect for his father. So the ‘Abba’ word tells us how Jesus is approaching this time of prayer.

In this prayer Jesus was honest. As a man Jesus did not want to die a death which was the result of the wrath of God upon the sin of the world. Jesus referred to the Cross as the "hour" and the "cup." The first expression includes everything involved in the Cross. The "cup" figuratively spoke of God's judgment in the Cross. Yet His desire to obey his father was greater than his desire to avoid the cross.

It was a prayer of submission. Submission is not about gritting your teeth and clinching your fists. It is not about determination, and being strong minded. Rather, submission is the consequences of allowing God to change your heart; it is the natural result of authentic fellowship with God. The word the bible uses for submit/submission was a military term; to arrange in order file/rank, to get in order under someone else.

One of the fascinating that comes out of this incident, is unanswered prayer made the cross possible. The God who answers prayer because of his great love, is the same God who sometimes does not answer prayer because of his great love.

Father thank you that the heart you express through answering prayer is the same heart you express through unanswered prayer, thank you that unanswered prayer made the cross possible. Bible in a year reading plan Deuteronomy 13:1-16:8
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 22

html:
Leaving Gethsemane.

Jesus left the garden of Gethsemane very different than when he arrived. His circumstance

hadn’t improved, in fact they were going to get a whole lot worse, but Jesus’ resolve was back.

Jesus advanced rather than retreated and accepted the cup from his Father’s hands and from the hand of sinners. Mark’s account of Jesus’ words and actions demonstrates that Jesus was not forced into suffering and death but actively and obediently laid down his life. It is Jesus who affirms and initiates this final confrontation. His command to His disciples to “Rise, let us be going” is similar to a military commander ordering his troops forward into battle. It is a long journey through the garden of Gethsemane. It is an emotional roller coaster. It is a place where real spiritual work is done, where priorities are established, where we wrestle to accept the will of God. It is a place where we find the courage and strength to keep going; it is a place where we have an opportunity to show God the full extent of our love for him. It is the place where we hold on to our humanity, and choose to take up our cross so we can live a cruciform life that reveals the essence of the heart of God. It is from this place we ‘take up’ our cross.

When Jesus said 'Take up your cross and follow me,' what did he mean? For many the phrase ‘Take up your cross,’ has become a cliché which has been robed of understanding and power So we want to try and explore what Jesus meant when he said ‘ whoever does not carry their cross and follow me cannot be my disciple.’ Luke 14:27. Jesus was very emphatic here, he did not give any wriggle room.

Let me make a few observations

Depending on what version of the bible you read, the phrase 'take up your cross' is either found five or six times. Matthew 10:38, 16:24, Mark 8:34, Luke 9:23, and Luke 14:27. Many of the older translations include the phrase in Mark 10:21 as part of Jesus response to the Rich Young Ruler, while the more modern translations don't.

There is an intrinsic between the cross of Christ and the cross we are told we must carry. On a number of occasions when Jesus predicted his death he went on to speak about the cross we must carry. Matthew 16:21 From then on Jesus began to tell his disciples plainly that it was necessary for him to go to Jerusalem, and that he would suffer many terrible things at the hands of the elders, the leading priests, and the teachers of religious law. He would be killed, but on the third day he would be raised from the dead. Then in verse 24 we read ‘Then Jesus said to his disciples, “If any of you wants to be my follower, you must give up your own way, take up your cross, and follow me.’ see also Mark 8:31-3 and Luke 9:21-23.

The importance of this cannot be overstated. In the thinking of Jesus the link between the cross he died on and the cross we have to carry is essential for our understanding of who Jesus is. The cross we have to carry enable us to identify with Jesus and understand how he viewed life and how it should be lived. We need to remember that Jesus did ‘not’ lay down his life on the cross, but that he took up hiss cross because he had always lived a ‘laid down,’ life. In taking up our cross we are entering into the fellowship of his suffering If you look carefully at every context in which Jesus uses the phrase, ‘take up your cross,’ it is in the context of difficult relationships.

In Matthew 10:34-37 Jesus is speaking about difficult relationships, and how the demands of the Kingdom can put great strain on family relationships. Then he says in 10:38 'And anyone who does not take up his cross and follow me is not worthy of me.' This is similar to the context in Luke 14:27 'And whosoever does not carry his cross, and come after me, cannot be my disciple.' The main difference being between Matthew’s and Luke’s quote, is that in Matthew 10 Jesus was speaking to the twelve, while in Luke 14 He is speaking to the crowds. The references to ‘take up your cross’ in Matthew 16:24, Mark 8:34 and Luke 9:23 are all in the context of Peter's confession and rebuke of Jesus, although Luke does not mention that Peter rebuked Jesus. However this was a time of personal tension between the two. If we include Mark 10:21, that too was in the context of a strained relationship between the Rich Young Ruler and Jesus.

When we think of Jesus taking up his own cross, that was to mend broken relationships between God and man, so as we try to understand what 'taking up your cross really means, we need to keep in mind the contexts in which Jesus spoke this command. Taking up our cross has no redemptive power as far as sin is concerned, however, those who take up their cross will be more equipped to build, sustain and heal relationships. That does not mean that relationships will be easy or that they will always be repaired, but we will have the ability and capacity to pay the cost that healthy relationships require.

Taking up you cross is how we overcome the powers of darkness. Matthew 16 places the command to ‘take up your cross’ in the context of rebuking Satan and his influence on Peter. Jesus turned and said to Peter, “Get behind me, Satan! You are a stumbling block to me; you do not have in mind the concerns of God, but merely human concerns.’ Taking up our cross means that we are choosing to life a life that is diametrically opposed to all that Satan thinks and does.

In taking up our cross is how God reveals the essence of His heart to a needy world.. The crosses we are to carry should be tangible symbols of God love for the world. Or to put it an other way, it is not possible to carry your cross and not be loving, forgiving and gracious.

We read some fascinating verses in Matthew 27:39-42 39 Those who passed by hurled insults at him, shaking their heads and saying, “You who are going to destroy the temple and build it in three days, save yourself! Come down from the cross, if you are the Son of God!” In the same way the chief priests, the teachers of the law and the elders mocked him. “He saved others,” they said, “but he can’t save himself! He’s the king of Israel! Let him come down now from the cross, and we will believe in him. Those who where passing by wanted Jesus to take things into his own hands, defend himself, save himself by coming down of the cross. It is so easy for any of us to become separated from our crosses by wanting to defend ourselves from others. Sometimes we need to ask God for the courage to have ‘a staying on the cross’ attitude. Sometimes holding onto your cross can be more difficult than taking it up.

So what is the cross we have to carry?

As we have previously said we must not tum the cross that Jesus was speaking of here into something it isn't. Many people think that a cross is any trial or hardship you are going through, such as, a health problem, a disability, bereavement, or being single. 'That's my cross,' we say, but this is not what Jesus meant. The problem with this understanding is that most of the pain we go through in life is not of our own choosing. I didn't wake up one morning and think Cerebral Palsy is the cross for me, so l chose my disability. No! When it comes to most of the trials and difficulties in life, we don't have a choice, but when it comes to taking up our cross we do have a choice. The cross in Jesus' day was an instrument of torture and execution, pure and simple. There wasn't any figurative use of 'cross' as a 'burden' or 'trial' in those days.

Taking up our cross is us choosing to live the way Jesus died
The cross that Jesus is speaking about may not lead to physical death, in fact there may not be anything physical to it. What Jesus is referring to is the heart attitude of a cross bearer. Or to put it in the form of a question;

What kind of heart attitudes did Jesus display as he carried His cross? Jesus was expressing an attitude of love, forgiveness humility and submission as he bowed to, and suffered in the will of God. The attitudes and motives Jesus needed to die on the cross, are the same attitudes and motives we need for life.

Father help me to show through life the same attitudes Jesus showed through his death,

Bible in a year: Deuteronomy 16:9-19:21
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 23

html:
So how do we become cross bearers?

We must deny ourselves

What does it men to deny yourself? Many people think that to deny yourself means that we must feel bad about ourselves, we must loathe ourselves, we suffer from a poor self image. However, those who think this way are unable to deny themselves. Denying yourself is an expression of security not insecurity, it is a volitional choice of our wills, not an emotional response to the world around us. When we fall into the trap of equating a low self-image with self-denial we are doing the complete opposite to what we think we are doing. People who suffer from chronic self-image problems can become self-obsessed and very selfish, this in turns prevents self-denial.

The Greek word for deny is arneomai means, disown, renounce, refuse, not to accept, to reject, to refuse something offered, it carries the idea of making a volitional choice. It is best illustrated in the words of Philippians 2:6-8

'Who being in very nature God, did not consider equality with God something to be grasped. But made himself nothing, taking the very nature of a servant, being made in human likeness. And being found in the appearance of a man he humbled himself, and became obedient to death even death on a cross.'

To deny yourself is to choose being a servant over having position of authority. To deny yourself is to choose humility over pride. To deny yourself is to choose to obey the will of God irrespective of the personal cost and pain. To deny yourself is an expression of self acceptance and contentment.

We must understand the true source of life.

Look at what Jesus said. ‘For whoever wants to save their life will lose it, but whoever loses their life for me will find it. What good will it be for someone to gain the whole world, yet forfeit their soul? Or what can anyone give in exchange for their soul?

Jesus says four things about life, (Greek psyche) in these verses.

1 Whoever desires to save his psyche will lose it.

2 Whoever loses his psyche for Christ's sake will find it.

3 What profit is it to a man if he gains the whole world, and loses his own psyche

4 What will a man give in exchange for his psyche? The scary thing is that the words of Jesus infer that someone can loose their life/soul before they die. Those who are lost continue to perish after death in the same way those who have eternal life have it before death

It is quite amazing to me that some evangelical commentators understand the word saved in this context as referring to obtaining eternal salvation.

'There is no salvation apart from cross-bearing.' (Boice, Christ's Call To Discipleship, p 36).

I think to interpret the word save in this context, as referring to salvation from sin in this context is wrong for a number of reasons.

Eternal salvation is not conditioned elsewhere in the Bible upon self-denial and cross bearing.

Eternal salvation is not something which we buy or earn, it is a free gift.

Those being addressed here are believers, not unbelievers.

Recompense according to one's deeds is a not a salvation concept. Rather, it is a reward concept.

So what does it mean to loose your life and save your life?

All believers have eternal life. However, only self-denying believers will realise the full potential of eternal life (John 10:10). A 'saved life' is the glory of a life lived for God.

To loose one's life is to play it safe; it is to decide against the way of the cross and its confrontation with the status quo. It is to decide for what is safe, it is a deep concern for self-interest. "Survival at all costs," is a flawed philosophy by which to live. 'Be faithful to Christ no matter what the cost,' is the philosophy Jesus' disciples came to live by. We are made in such away, that when we live a self-obsessed fife, something with in us dies. We have been made to live life for the benefit of others, and that is only possible when we live a cross shaped life.

"Jesus is not anti-our-life; he is anti-preoccupation-with-our-life" (Bruner, 593

You will have right priorities

After speaking about loosing your life in order to find it Jesus goes on to say, 'What good will it be for a man if he gains the whole world, yet forfeits his soul.' Every time I have heard this verse spoken on, it has always been applied to people who are non-Christians. As we have said, Jesus is primarily addressing his disciples. So how are we to understand what Jesus is saying here?

I think Jesus is using what I would call 'ironic hyperbole.' What do I mean? Jesus is saying something like this. 'If you were to gain the whole world, and everything that is in the world, and forfeit your life, your soul, and avoid your cross and the purposes of God for your life, then you will gain nothing.'

In Matthew 16:26 the word "Forfeit" Greek zemioo, to affect with damage or to do damage to, to suffer injury, to suffer loss, to sustain damage, to forfeit or to fine. It means to experience the loss of something, with implication of undergoing hardship or suffering. The word is found 339 other times in the New Testament, and never refers to eternal destruction. So when Jesus speaks about 'forfeiting our lives in this context. He is not speaking about eternal judgement, but rather the self-harm we inflict upon ourselves when we refuse the way of the cross, for an easier option.

Why is it essential that we find life by loosing it? If our mindset is the antithesis to the way of the cross, then we will never be ourselves. We will become caricatures of our true selves who have reduced life to an expression of egocentric selfish living. The crosses we need to carry showcase the glories of humanity as God intended it to be. The attitudes needed to carry our cross conform us into the image of Jesus and display God’s original intention for human kind.

Jesus concludes his teaching on taking up your cross with the words 'For the Son of Man is going to come in his Father's glory with his angels and then he will reward each person according to what he has done.' I find this very challenging. It is as if Jesus. Says My death on the cross will remove all you sin. Your death on the cross will determine the quality of the life you live. The word used to describe ‘what he has done is ‘praxis’ which has the basic meaning of a doing of something, i.e., a deed. It could refer to a habitual or established practice. It later came to connote something that was ordinarily done or practices, a normal function. Our ever day practices and habits need to be motivated and defined by the cross we need to carry.

Father help me to value the cross you want me to take up.

Bible in a year: Deuteronomy 20:1-23:14
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 24

html:
The humanity of Jesus after his resurrection, John 20 11-29

I would like to consider Jesus’ humanity after his resurrection. Jesus’ death, burial, and resurrection did not in any why take away from his humanity, Jesus died as a man, and he rose from the dead as a man. Nor did his death, burial and resurrection make him more human, or less human. From his birth, to this present day Jesus was and is completely human. However, in his humanity, Jesus, through his experience of death, burial and resurrection is able to teach us things about our humanity that he was unable to teach us before his death and resurrection. Or to put it another way, one of the lessons the resurrection of Jesus teaches us is what it means to live as healthy human being, in the victory of God. in a sinful fallen world. What does it mean to live in the ‘power of the resurrection? How does God want to display his power and glory through our humanity? What does the power that raised Jesus from the dead look like in everyday life? The resurrected life of Jesus as it is portrayed in the gospels, explains and demonstrate the purpose and power of the cross. You could say that the record of Jesus life between his resurrection and ascension is an example for those who lives have been transformed by his death on the cross.

We want to look at Jesus’ appearances after his resurrection as it is recorded by John in his gospel. John records more resurrection appearances than any other gospel. When John speaks about Jesus ‘appearing’ to his disciples he uses the word phaneroo ‘appeared, this term conveys the showing of one’s character, motivations or intentions, and it comes from the verb phainō, which means “to shine.”

Jesus’ resurrection teaches us that mankind has a new way to relate to God.

When Jesus was raised from the dead the whole belief system of the disciples was challenged, and made completely obsolete. The followers of Jesus had been brought up good Jews who went to the temple in Jerusalem at least three times a year to make sacrifices for sin. For the early followers of Jesus the temple and the sacrificial system was the centre of their lives. Now Jesus had risen from the dead, he had become the sacrifice for sin; he was the Lamb of God that took away the sin of the world. Can you imagine how difficult this must have been for the first disciples? The beliefs that their nation had held for thousands of years had now been done away with. And the only way mankind could relate to God was by receiving God’s mercy and grace.

Unintentionally for many people today, their Christian experience has become an expression of bloodless sacrificing where they attempt to appease God and win his approval. We all understand the dangers of a ‘prosperity gospel,’ were people are deceived into making sacrifices in order to get something back.
