If you were to boil the tenants of the prosperity gospel down to their basic components you will discover that any one of us can live our lives and relate to God on the same premise.

Let me illustrate. Someone lives for God the best they know how, they cross all the t’s and dot all the i’s. That person may be tempted to think, ‘I have done my best to live for God, God owes me, I deserve God’s blessing.’ We may never actually say those words out loud, but at times we can think or feel that way.

To experience the power of the resurrection is to understand that I can never appease God, and I need to accept the fact that God will only deal with me on the basis of grace. The resurrection of Jesus shouts to the world that the sacrificial system is over and no matter how good I am or how much I sacrifice; God will still owe me nothing, but he has chooses to show me grace.

Father thank you that the resurrection of Jesus shows us that you have accepted the price Jesus paid

Bible in a year: Deuteronomy 23:15-27:10
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 25

html:
To be truly human is not to allow the inevitable injustice of life to define us.

No matter who we are we have all got baggage, we have all felt pain, rejection and disappointment to a greater or lesser degree. It is very easy for anyone of us to cultivate and develop a victim mindset; we can allow the experiences of injustices of the past to shape us.

The injustices and cruelty Jesus experienced through his death on the cross did not turn him into an angry bitter person, but through resurrection he experienced freedom and victory that only God could give. Often emotionally, we remain in the grave, we have been badly hurt, abused, disappointed, and part of us dies. We try our best to live with the pain, keeping it buried, keeping it under control, allowing its nagging influence to insidiously and slowly poison our hearts and warp our thinking. What I am trying to say is that the power of the resurrection can deliver us from the self-destructive attitudes that can be concealed in the baggage of our past. All of us have come through times of difficulty, we have all known times of suffering and tragedy, but the pain of the past does not have to define us in the present.

3. In his humanity Jesus chose to have the mindset that was free from the entrapment of victimhood. Let me just pause here for a moment and ask the question, do you live as a victim? People with a victim mentality do not have ability to build real relationships. Jesus was victimized, but he refused to be a victim. He rose from the dead, and as evidence of the power of God in his life he refused to live as a victim.

What are the evidences of living out of a victim mentality?

a. We don’t want to accept responsibility – This person will do anything to absolve him/herself from personal responsibility for any aspect of their lives. This results in the following symptoms.

b. You become withdrawn. If you weren’t someone who liked staying away from others and you find yourself suddenly wanting to be by yourself, then you may be a victim.

c. You see yourself as a failure. When you start seeing yourself as a failure then you may be a victim.

d. You are not able to forgive. If you are not able to forgive all those who have hurt or harmed you including yourself, then you may be a victim.

e. You have become angry and bitter. If you find that you are becoming angry and bitter, it means you may be a victim

Father thank you I don’t need to live as a victim..

Bible in a year: Deuteronomy 27:11-28:68
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 26

html:
4. Jesus’ resurrection teaches us that the power of God in our lives will restore and rebuild broken relationships.

Relationships are rescued when our lives are touched with the power of Jesus’ new life. Between his resurrection and ascension the main focus of Jesus was one of restoring and reassuring. His disciples were in disarray, fear and confusion; they were not able to understand what was going on. So Jesus patiently took the time to gently rescue them from their fear and misunderstanding. The life of Jesus clearly demonstrates that the power of the resurrection is completely free from any kind of abusive or controlling tendencies, and will empower someone with the humility to bow and help those who hearts have been crushed with guilt and shame. In John 20:17 we see that this is the first time that Jesus refers to the disciples as ‘brothers,’ in this gospel. After his resurrection Jesus inaugurated a new level of intimacy between himself and his disciples.

It is important to notice that every encounter Jesus had with people after his resurrection was initiated by him. Jesus went to those who were broken, fearful and doubting, he went to people where they were. He pursued those who disowned and forsook him. I know that in my own life, to my shame, I have often gone out of my way to avoid someone who had caused me pain. Sometimes it is right to do that, but not always. There is something in all of us that wants to keep our distance from those who have hurt us. When in our humanity we experience the power of his resurrection we will be secure enough to reach out to those who have caused us pain. This is the real demonstration of the power of God. This is how God reveals his glory, when we initiate the process of restoring relationships. It is amazing that Jesus did not go and see those who sentence Him to death.

5. In our humanity we need the power of God to sanctify our scars.

When Jesus appeared to his disciples on two occasions he showed them his wounds, see. John 20:20, 27. Jesus displayed his scars with confidence, not disgrace or shame, The power of the resurrection did not remove Jesus’ scars, it did something much better, it sanctify them. To have our wounds ‘sanctified’ could be seen as the deepest kind of healing. In some senses the removal of our scars would be the removal of an integral part of who we are and what we are becoming. That does not mean that we should be define by our scars. However, the way in which we carry them will either mature us and bring glory to God, our dehumanise us by making us bitter and angry. Your scars tell part of your story

The wounds of Jesus will always remain an integral part of who he is and what he did. The attitude that Jesus carried in his heart, ‘sanctified his scars,’ what do we mean by that? We have all got scars, and usually we are ashamed of our scars, we keep them hidden and concealed, they are often ugly and unattractive.

Scars and wounds that were caused by cruelty were transformed by the resurrection into symbols life and hope. Jesus’ scars brought healing to others. They brought assurance to his disciples; they helped to heal their doubt. We have all got scars, they may be physical or emotional, but perhaps if we have the same loving, forgiving, relationship healing attitudes as Jesus, then maybe the scars we have received will be used by God to bring healing to others. Can you grasp how open and vulnerable Jesus must have felt? It would have been very understandable if Jesus had wanted to protect himself, if he chose to be cautious, but he didn’t. He allowed himself to become vulnerable so he could restore his relationship with his disciples. Jesus is teaching us a very important lesson; when we live in the power of his resurrection, free from the mindset of a victim, we will be secure enough to be vulnerable, we will allow our wounds to bring healing to others.

We have no control what wounds we will receive in life, but we have a choice how we carry them.

Father give me the grace to carry my wounds well

Bible in a year: Deuteronomy 29:1-32:14
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 27

html:
6. We learn from the resurrection of Jesus that to be truly human we need to be compassionate more than we need glory. Try and imagine for a moment, if you were Jesus, and you rose from the dead, after such an unjust trial and heinous death. Surely you would want your enemies to know, surely you would want to make a significant point, Go to Jerusalem, and appear in great glory.

What did Jesus do? He appeared to a woman who would have been considered insignificant by the world. A woman whose heart was breaking, whose world had fallen apart. This is the last time we read about Mary Magdalene in the bible. We never read of her doing any great exploits for God, she seemed to disappear. Yet in great compassion Jesus appeared to her first. She was the first person in history to encounter the resurrected Jesus.

Let us be honest, we would rather experience glory than show compassion. There is something in all of us that wants to be vindicated, we want to be proven right, and we want to prove ourselves to the world. We want to go to our Jerusalem and make a name for ourselves and humiliate our enemies. The purpose of the power of the resurrection is to explain and demonstrate God’s intention behind the cross. The power of the resurrection displays God’s love, grace and forgiveness.

Jesus in all his risen power and glory, goes to a broken hearted insignificant woman, and says ‘Mary.’ We need to grasp the truth that compassion is an expression of power and freedom and will always be necessary. Vindication and reputation may be desirable, but unlike compassion they are not a necessity for life. Compassion is feeling disturbed and distressed because of the needs of others. It is the complete opposite of living in the entrapped selfishness of a victim mentality. I love the fact that after his Resurrection Jesus did not try and restore his relationships with his disciples by trying to impress them with displays of glory and power. Instead he came close to them, gave them time, showed them patience, understood their doubts, recognised their fears, answered their questions, challenged their love and spoke peace into their hearts. Jesus allowed his disciples to experience the restoring gentleness of resurrection power.

There is a lot about the resurrection of Jesus that is unique; there are many things that we do not understand. But we can learn from the resurrection of Jesus that our new life in God will make us other-centred. The resurrection power of Jesus will cause a person to reach out to others; it will empower you to restore broken relationships. To live in the power of the resurrection is to live a life that is defined by love, it is to live a life that over flowing with grace. Maybe a lack of love is really an indication we have no power in our lives? Maybe the lives we have chosen to live don’t really the power of the resurrection?

I think that living in the power of the resurrection will affirm our humanity, but it will also play havoc with our lives. We will be forgiving and restoring those who have hurt us. We will be assuring those who doubt us. We will be encouraging and envisioning those who failed us. We will be living lives that are empowered by the resurrection we are living lives that are counterculture. We are saying that true humanity is about love not position, about forgiveness not revenge, about relationships not displays of glory.

Father may my life be a clear reflection of loving resurrected power.

Bible in a year: Deuteronomy 32:12-34;15 Joshua 1:1-9
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 27

html:
The Ascension of Jesus and his humanity. Acts 1

My first car was a bit strange, it didn’t have a steering wheel and it only had three wheels. It was very light and because it only had three wheels it meant that it was not very safe. Having said that, it served a purpose, it got me from A to B, but it was not very safe. [It was known as a disabled carriage.] The reason why I say this, is because often we preach a three wheeled gospel instead of a ‘four wheeled.’gospel. What do I mean? Often when we think of the life and work of Jesus, we think of his incarnation, how he came to earth and took on humanity, becoming like us. We think of his death on the cross for our sin, and we think of his resurrection, and how he defeated Satan, sin and death. However, this is an incomplete presentation of Jesus’ life and work and the message of the gospel. There is a ‘wheel’ missing and without this forth ‘wheel’ we are creating an ‘unsteady’ gospel. The Ascension of Jesus gives us a complete understanding of the gospel.

There may be a number of reasons why we are less inclined to engage with the ascension of Jesus.

a. The record of the actual ascension of Jesus is very limited. Only Luke gives us two short records of Jesus’ ascension, in Luke 24:50-53, Acts 1:6-11. There are other scriptures that make reference to the ascension, Ephesians 4:7-14

b. The story of the ascension feels a bit weird! A bit ‘star trekie’. Jesus taken up into the sky and then disappearing. In some way it’s ‘strangeness,’ makes it difficult to relate to.

c. Perhaps the main reason why we find it difficult to engage with it is that it is easier to live with an un-ascended Jesus. We will come back to this at the end.

The incarnation, death and resurrection are only complete and effective because of the ascension of Jesus. The ascension of Jesus is something we don’t often we think about or talk about. Someone has called it ‘The forgotten act of Christ.’ We can focus on what Jesus did do while he was here on earth, or we can get excited and exorcised about His return. [Both of these things are important.] However, between these two points we have the ascension of Jesus, which can be overlooked or ignored. It is essential that we take some time to think through the ascension of Jesus and the implications for our lives. The ascension had a profound impact on the disciples.

Up to the moment that Jesus ascended to heaven, the disciples seemed to be puzzled, trying to figure it all out. Luke 24:50-53 tells us. ‘When he had led them out to the vicinity of Bethany, he lifted up his hands and blessed them. While he was blessing them, he left them and was taken up into heaven. Then they worshipped him and returned to Jerusalem with great joy. And they stayed continually at the temple, praising God.’

Look at how Luke describes the affects of the ascension. ‘They worshipped him’, they experienced ‘great joy,’ and they ’continually stayed at the temple, praising God.’ A proper understanding of the ascension will produce great joy in our hearts. This may seem to be a strange response because Jesus is leaving them, he is going away. However, these early Christians had grasped the full meaning of the ascension, and great joy was their appropriate response.

2. The ascension of Jesus is the catalyst for the church.

It would be difficult to overstate the significance of the fact that the book of Acts begins with the ascension. The ascension made the church possible. The ascension is a statement that says Jesus is ready to do something new and different on the earth. The ascension is a universal declaration of Jesus’ intention to redefine His world through the life of his church.

We are often inclined to reduce the ascension of Jesus as him leaving the earth and going into heaven. But it is a lot more than that. Ascension is really coronation language, it carries the idea on enthronement, Queen Elisabeth ascended her throne.

Luke tells us that ‘He was taken up into a cloud.’ This is very important because to people, like the first disciples, who had an understanding of the Old Testament, the cloud would have be a symbol of God’s presence and glory.

Daniel 7:13-14,“I saw in the night visions, and behold, with the clouds of heaven there came one like a son of man, and he came to the Ancient of Days and was presented before him. And to him was given dominion and glory and a KINGDOM, that all peoples, nations, and language should serve him; his dominion is an everlasting dominion, which shall not pass away, and his KINGDOM one that shall not be destroyed.”

In Acts 2:32-35, Peter says these words:-

‘God has raised this Jesus to life, and we are all witnesses of it. Exalted to the right hand of God, he has received from the Father the promised Holy Spirit and has poured out what you now see and hear. For David did not ascend to heaven, and yet he said,“‘The Lord said to my Lord: “Sit at my right hand until I make your enemies a footstool for your feet.”

This truth should produce in us a great confidence. We can look at the church and become discouraged, but we need to remember that Jesus has ascended, he sits on a throne and his reign is everlasting, and his victory is eternal. No wonder these first disciples were filled with great joy.

Father thank you that the accession of Jesus is a cause of great joy

Bible in a year: Joshua 1:10-4:24
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 28

html:
3. The Ascension dignifies our humanity.

Would you be surprised if I told you that a human being is the ruler of the universe? When Jesus sat on the throne of heaven he lost nothing of his humanity. He could of discarded his humanity, but maybe Jesus likes being human. He is God, and he has all the attributes of The Devine, but he is as human as he was on earth. In His humanity he still identifies with our humanity. Some imagine that Christ shed himself of his humanity and returned to being a completely spiritual being when he went back to Heaven. But this is false. The ascension creates a paradigm shift. The truth is not that Jesus became a baby at Christmas, and then 33 years later came the resurrection and ascension and then he stopped being a man. Jesus is still as human today as he was on earth. He still has a male body with all it distinctive parts. The resurrection demonstrates the incarnation is permanent not temporary. See 1 Timothy 2:5. Philippians 2:5-8.

Jesus retains a human body and we will be like him. And that means that like him, we will have bodies for eternity. We will be transformed, we will be different, but we will still have bodies. Our eternal future will be a physical, bodily future. It is very common for Christians to pit the ‘spiritual’ against the ‘physical’, as if the spiritual were somehow more holy than the physical. We think of redemption in terms of escaping from our bodies. Some Christians are Gnostic in their thinking, they believe that our bodies are contemptible or to be despised. A lot of psychological issues people have regarding their bodies are rooted in |Gnostic theology which says that we are just people trapped in a body, and that someday we will be body free. You will always have a body, now you will get a body that is like his body. To dismiss our bodies is to think umbilically. Listen to these word Hebrews 10:5 Therefore, when Christ came into the world, he said: "Sacrifice and offering you did not desire, but a body you prepared for me; In other words the bodies we have been given have been bespokely designed to complement God’s will for our lives

4. The ascension ensures that we have the authority to be the people God wants us to be.

In the day of Jesus a victorious king would give gifts to his people to celebrate his victory and enthronement. Acts 1:8 says:-

‘But you will receive power when the Holy Spirit comes on you; and you will be my witnesses in Jerusalem, and in all Judea and Samaria, and to the ends of the earth.” The gift of the Holy Spirit given to the church by King Jesus is to empower them to be his ‘witnesses.’

The word ’witness,’ is a title given by God, to his servant in the book of Isaiah. If you look at how Isaiah describes a ‘witness’ it has more to do with the quality of the persons relationship with God, than what he does.

Isaiah 43:10

“You are my witnesses,” declares the Lord, “and my servant whom I have chosen, that you may know and believe me and understand that I am he. Before me no god was formed, nor shall there be any after me.’

Isaiah 44:8

Fear not, nor be afraid; have I not told you from of old and declared it? And you are my witnesses! Is there a God besides me? There is no Rock; I know not any.”

The transforming power of the Spirit in our lives give us the godly character needed in order to be authentic witnesses for Jesus. Any witness for Jesus that does not flow from a character that is growing in holiness, because of the ongoing transformation of the Holy Spirit is a false witness.

5. The ascension means we have the security and authority to bring the kingdom of God anywhere and everywhere.

Look at what Jesus said:- ‘In Jerusalem, and in all Judea and Samaria, and to the ends of the earth.”

A lot of commentators understand this phrase as a geographical outline of the book. The church started in Jerusalem, spread to Judea, Samaria and then to Rome, or the end of the earth. However, when the first disciples heard Jesus saying these words ‘in Jerusalem, and in all Judea and Samaria, and to the ends of the earth.” they would have probably have been shocked if not terrified.

Jerusalem, a place where Jesus lost his life, a place were the combined religious and political authorities had set themselves against Jesus and his cause.

Judea, the place where the disciples had blown it. It was in Judea that they had ran away, deserting Jesus. How could they begin a ministry proclaiming the name of Jesus in a place where they were known as those who had ran away?

Samaria, that’s where the ‘they’ lived!! You know? Like ‘them and us’; the despised enemies of the Jews, those who lived on the ‘other side of the tracks.’ This is where those you have absolutely nothing in common with, those who challenge your beliefs, your heritage, your world-view and values come from.

The ends of the earth.

For the Jewish people of Jesus’ day this would have been the last place they would have wanted to go. The common attitude towards Gentiles is seen in the teaching of the Talmud, For example

God is displeased when Jews show hospitality to gentiles.

For executing a gentile, only one person’s testimony is necessary. (To kill a Jew, two witnesses are necessary.)

Jews may steal from Non-Jews

If a Jew finds an object lost by a gentile it does not have to be returned.

Maybe, Jesus is saying that the sphere of your witnessing will for the most part will be way outside your comfort zone, and in some way that is the way it needs to be. For it is outside our comfort zones that we are more vulnerable and dependant on the life of the Spirit. What Jesus was asking of these first disciples was not just to simply gather and ‘rub each others backs’ but was asking to be authentic, transformed witnesses in the most precarious of places. They could do this, not because they were strong and brave, and had dynamic personalities. But because Jesus had ascended, he was the conquering King, who gifted his church with the power of his Sprit.

Do you remember when Jesus appeared to Mary after his resurrection? Mary tried to hold onto Jesus, and Jesus said, ‘Jesus said, “Do not hold on to me, for I have not yet ascended to the Father. Go instead to my brothers and tell them, ‘I am ascending to my Father and your Father, to my God and your God.’ It was as if Mary was trying to communicate, Jesus I want to hold you here with me, you don’t need to ascend to your throne. There is something in all of us that wants a ‘cuddly’ Jesus. A Jesus we can hold on to. A Jesus who will bring emotional well-being and security into our lives. Most of the time this is not the kind of Jesus we need. We more often need a Jesus who sits on his throne, a Jesus we need to be submitted to no matter what circumstances we are going through.

Father may all of my life be influenced by your accession, Bible in a year reading plan Joshua 5:1-8:23
title: STUDY THEME, The Humanity of Jesus. Part 29

html:
I would like to explore this passage of Jesus calling his disciples and designating twelve of them to become Apostles. Like many of the stories in the gospels this is very familiar and because it is familiar it has been reduced to a very familiar application. Let me explain what I mean.

Many apply this passage something like this.

1. Jesus prayed all night before he made an important decision.

2. After he prayed all night he came to his disciples and chose twelve disciples to become apostles.

3.Before any of us make any important decisions in life we should spend time praying about it.

This application of this passage is completely legitimate and helpful, prayer should be a constant in our lives as it was in Jesus’ life. Luke mentions prayer more than any other gospel, 21 times, 25 times in Acts he refers to prayer. As people whose lives depend on God we should pray when we have to make important decisions; we should be seeking God’s wisdom and strength as we seek to make the right choices in life.

Having said that, I am not too sure if this is the main lesson of this passage. Yes Jesus prayed then He called the twelve, but if we set the passage in it’s context we will discover that this may have been far more than Jesus praying about the calling of the twelve.

As 21 century Christians we are inclined to read the bible, especially the gospel in a dislocated way, which can make it more difficult to place stories in their context. This is not our fault. Our bibles have chapter numbers, verse numbers and many modern versions have headings that tell us what the proceeding verses are about. All these things are helpful and allow us to navigate ourselves around the bible. However, if we were to remove the chapter and verse numbers, and remove the introductory heading, I think this and many other passage would read very differently.

The context of the passage:-

Luke 6:12 begins with the words ‘One day soon after,’ NLT. The NIV reads ‘One of those days.’ These words tie Jesus going up the mountain to pray, with events that had taken place before he spent the night in prayer. So there was something going on in the life of Jesus that motivated Him to withdraw to a mountain and spend the night in prayer.

In Luke 5:17-6:11 there are five stories, in all which, there is a common theme i.e. Jesus was attacked, undermined and questioned.

a. He was accused of blasphemy, we are told in Luke 5:21 ‘But the Pharisees and teachers of religious law said to themselves. ‘Who does he think he is? This is blasphemy. Only God can forgive sins.’


John MacArthur says:- ‘Blasphemy was the most heinous crime in Jewish thought, since it was a direct affront to the person of God. They defined three levels of blasphemy. First, one blasphemed God by speaking evil of His law, as Stephen (Acts 6:13) and Paul (Acts 21:27–28) were falsely accused of doing. A more serious form of blasphemy was to slander, speak evil of, or curse God Himself (Lev. 24:10–16; cf. Ex. 20:7). But the ultimate form of blasphemy was to assume the rights and prerogatives of God; to usurp the role of God and act as if one were God. It was this third and most severe type of blasphemy that the scribes and Pharisees accused Jesus of.’ https://www.preceptaustin.org/matthew-9-commentary. Accessed 25/06/2025

2. The religious leaders complained bitterly to Jesus’ disciples. Luke 5:30.The word Luke uses is gogguzo, which simply means was that they were whispering in low tones about him behind his back and expressing discontentment with him.

3. He was challenged from an unexpected source.

Look at Luke 5:33. ‘One day some people said to Jesus ‘John the Baptist disciples fast and pray regularly, and so do the disciples of the Pharisees. Why are your disciples always eating and drinking?’

Marks version read like this:- ‘John’s disciples and the Pharisees were fasting; and they came and said to Him, “Why do John’s disciples and the disciples of the Pharisees fast, but Your disciples do not fast? Mark 2:18.

This is strange because John the Baptist and the Pharisees never sang from the same hymn sheet. Yet here they were collaborating in their criticism of Jesus and his disciples.

4. The religious were watching his every move and began to nit-pick. Luke tells us that  ‘One Sabbath day as Jesus was walking through some grain fields, his disciples broke off heads of grain, rubbed off the husks in their hands, and ate the grain.’ The only way they were able to find fault was to nit-pick, to make something important that wasn’t important. They turned a ‘pin head.’ into a point of theological debate, they intensely scrutinised his every move hoping to catch him out.

5. The religious leaders were full of murderous intent. ‘The enemies of Jesus were wild with rage and began to discuss what to do with him.’ Luke 6:11. We know from Mark 3:6 that they began to plot how they could kill him. The word for rage (anoia) denotes an almost "insane: or mindless fury, to the point that these Pharisees were beside themselves.

So it is with this background that we are told that ‘Jesus went up the mountain to pray and he prayed to God all night.’

Father help me see the oppositions and trials of life as an opportunity to pray.

study_refs: One of those days Jesus went out to a mountainside to pray, and spent the night praying to God. When morning came, he called his disciples to him and chose twelve of them, whom he also designated apostles: Simon (whom he named Peter), his brother Andrew, James, John, Philip, Bartholomew, Matthew, Thomas, James son of Alphaeus, Simon who was called the Zealot, Judas son of James, and Judas Iscariot, who became a traitor

html:
There are a number of lessons this can teach us.

1. This story is about Jesus embracing his humanity. Luke tells us that he prayed to God all night. As a man in the midst of the storm, Jesus probably felt the need to bring the pain of his heart to God. Jesus was not some kind of superhuman who was impervious to criticism, ridicule or threat. He was not a dispassionate ‘Tin man,’ who could remain unmoved or untouched by the mistreatment of others. So as a man, in all his human vulnerability he prayed to God and in humility and submission he yielded himself to the purposes of God, despite great opposition.

2. Jesus made time and space to deal with his circumstances before God. This is the only occasion in the bible were we read of an individual spending the whole night in prayer. Jesus was very intentional in how he responded to the growing opposition and criticism he was facing. I love the fact that Jesus allowed his mistreatment by others to matter, he didn’t pretend it didn’t matter, or it wasn’t an issue that he could ignore. Rather, it seems that the only way he chose to respond to the increasing opposition was through a prolonged period of prayer.

When Luke speaks about Jesus praying ‘all night’ he uses the word dianyktereuo. This is the only time we find this word in the bible. Outside the bible it was used in the world of medicine to describe a whole nights vigil. It also had a military rather than religious associations. I think this gives us some insight as to how Jesus was praying, was this a Pre-Gethsemane experience? Could it be that on that night as he wrestled in prayer He found the resolve and courage to go forward in his call and ministry?

It was in the context of Jesus dealing spiritually with the threatening issues of his life that he got a clearer understanding about the way forward.

There will be times in all our live when the pressure of life will stop us from moving forward in the direction God may be calling us to, we may feel overwhelmed or paralysed with fear, we can allow the difficulties of the present to prevent us from stepping into the future.

3. This night of prayer may have been more about receiving the courage to lead, than about the wisdom to decide.

When Jesus called these disciples and chose them to be Apostles, we must remember that he had known them for a while. He had been in their homes, he had been at their places of work, their place of worship, he had partied with them, he had journeyed with them. But now it was time for change, a time to develop them from disciples to Apostles.

Before we go on, I think there is a lesson in this for us. As we deal with the conflicts and intimidations of life in a spiritual way, this will produce in us healing courage so we will be more equipped to lead and influence others for their good. We can allow unresolved issues of rejection, intimidation and misunderstanding to cause us to withdraw into cosy self protection from which we have no ability to be a positive influence or encouragement on/to others.

We have become so used to reading about Jesus and the Apostles that we have missed how radical Jesus is being here. Luke tells us at ‘daybreak’ he called together his disciples. I love that Luke refers to ‘daybreak’ it is as if he was saying, ‘this is a new day, Jesus has just spent the night wrestling in prayer and things are never going to be the same.

When Jesus called these disciples to become Apostles, he was making a very strong statement about who he was and how he saw his future. He was saying ‘I am much more than a Rabbi.’ The calling of the apostles was declaration of intent, it was refusal to be intimidated, it was an expression of determination and certainty, it was the decree of a king.

The word for Apostles comes from Apostolos which refers to someone who was officially commissioned to a position or task, such as an envoy. Cargo ships were sometimes called apostolic, because they were dispatched with a specific shipment for a specific destination. In secular Greek, Apostolos was used of an admiral of a fleet sent out by the King on special assignment. In the ancient world, an Apostle was the personal representative of the King, functioning as an ambassador with the King’s authority and provided with credentials to prove he was the King's envoy.

You could say in Jesus’ world, Rabbi's had disciples, Kings had apostles. So when Jesus called them apostles, it would have been very unexpected, it would have began to change their understanding of Jesus. Their lives had now taken on a regal significance, they were now designated as emissaries of a King.

4. God purposes and goals for you life is rooted in discipleship.

We are told,’At daybreak He called together his disciples and chose twelve of them to be his Apostles.’ The disciples became apostles. For these disciples, ‘Apostles’ was what God wanted them to become, and what God wanted them to do. Their call to be ‘Apostles needed to be rooted in discipleship. It is the same for us, we will not be the people God wants us to be, or do the things God wants us to do, without a life of discipleship.

It is very interesting that we would refer to ourselves as Christians before we would see ourselves as disciples. The name Christian, is only found 3 times in the bible, (Acts 11:25-26, Acts 26:28, 1 Peter 4:16). What’s interesting about all three of these occurrences is that the word “Christian” as a title or identifier doesn’t seem to be self-applied. Rather, it is non-Christians, unbelievers, people who do not follow Jesus, who are using the term to describe or identify Jesus’ disciples or followers.

The word disciple is found 261 times in the Gospels and Acts, 297 times in the New Testament. When it come to understanding our part, or role in our spiritual journey and maturity, we need to think and behave like disciples. Dallas Williard said ‘His disciples were with him learning to be like him.’ This truly captures the essence of discipleship. Transformation because of authentic fellowship with Jesus.

have said nothing about the ‘twelve’ that Jesus called to be his apostles. But I wonder what our lives would be like if our names were in that list. Jesus will never call us to be capital A ‘Apostles’ like these disciples, but we can be sure of three things.

1.Jesus will call you to something. You will never be a spectator or a passenger, every disciple has the call of God upon their lives.

2. The call of God grows from a life of discipleship, being with him, being like him.

3. Discipleship equips us for the will of God. We will never be called to be apostles like these first disciples. But everything we have been called to has apostolic significance because we are emissaries of THE GREAT KING.

Father thank you that because Jesus had the courage to deal with his own pain he was able turn disciples into apostles.

Let me give you an example of some of the things he said.

‘Love your enemies. 6:27

‘Do good to those who hate you.’ 6:27.

‘Bless those who curse you.’ 6:28.

‘Pray for those who hurt you.’ 6:28.

‘Do not retaliate.’ 6:29.

‘Be generous and give to anyone.’ 6:30.

‘Don’t be afraid of loosing your possessions or look for payback.’ 6:30.

‘Love those who can’t love you back.’ 6:32-33.

Lend money without caring if you get it back or not.’ 6:34.

If you were to read on in the chapter you would conclude that Jesus is describing a lifestyle that is completely opposite and confrontative to how people live. In this chapter, Jesus is redefining how we should do life.

So, is He being unrealistic? Is he expecting too much? Is it even possible to live such a counter-cultural life? The alternative to us not being countercultural we will help the lost to embrace their lostness.

Father I need to have a counter cultural life.

title: The Faith of the Centurion part 1
study_refs: When Jesus had finished saying all this the people who were listening, he entered Capernaum. There a centurion’s servant, whom his master valued highly, was sick and about to die. The centurion heard of Jesus and sent some elders of the Jews to him, asking him to come and heal his servant. When they came to Jesus, they pleaded earnestly with him, “This man deserves to have you do this, because he loves our nation and has built our synagogue.” So Jesus went with them He was not far from the house when the centurion sent friends to say to him: “Lord, don’t trouble yourself, for I do not deserve to have you come under my roof. That is why I did not even consider myself worthy to come to you. But say the word, and my servant will be healed. For I myself am a man under authority, with soldiers under me. I tell this one, ‘Go,’ and he goes; and that one, ‘Come,’ and he comes. I say to my servant, ‘Do this,’ and he does it.” When Jesus heard this, he was amazed at him, and turning to the crowd following him, he said, “I tell you, I have not found such great faith even in Israel.” Then the men who had been sent returned to the house and found the servant well.

I wonder how we as a Christian community, understand the gospel? What is the gospel? Let me ask, is it appropriate to share the message of the gospel without a gospel lifestyle? This leads to an other question. What is a gospel lifestyle? Or in what ways is our Christian faith counter-cultural to the world around us? If we had a ‘heart grasp’ of what Jesus as taught in Luke 6, we could only conclude that his words were unconventional, counter-intuitive, counter-cultural, and radical.

html:
There have been three broad ways Christians have reacted to society.

Separatism. In the past, some Christians fell into the separatist trap. They responded to culture with condemnation and retreat. Removing themselves far away from the corruption of culture is the name of their game.

Antagonism. Some Christians see little in the current culture worth redeeming and have decided to fight against almost everything that culture promotes. They succeed in stating clearly what they are against, but their Achilles heel is suggesting alternatives that embody what they are for.

Relevance. Others have gone to the opposite extreme by falling into the “relevance trap.” In an effort to appeal to outsiders, some Christians simply copy culture. They become a photocopy of what they perceive as hip, in the hope that people will perceive them — and their organizations, ministries, and churches — as “cool.”

None of these three approaches are helpful, a better way is countercultural Christianity. What is countercultural Christianity? It is the advancement of the common good in society. It is being salt, a preserving agent actively working for restoration in the middle of a decaying culture. Countercultural Christians attach themselves to people and structures that are in danger of rotting while availing themselves to

Christ’s redeeming power to do work through them.

We are going to look at the story of the Roman centurion and the healing of his servant. Luke places this story at the end of the Sermon on the Plain as a tangible, flesh and blood example of what it means to be countercultural, what it means to swim against the tide, what it means to demonstrate the distinctiveness of the Kingdom of God.

1. Countercultural living is an expression of authentic faith. In this passage, Jesus implicitly redefines faith. We often have a one dimensional understanding of faith. We understand faith as a set of beliefs, a set of truths we hold onto, or a person we trust. Now all that is true but incomplete. Faith is how we choose to live because of what we believe. You could put this way, any faith in God that does not determine and define how we live is not authentic faith. Faith is the outworking of our beliefs and trust in God through a distinctive lifestyle that confronts and confounds the norms of a godless society.

Father help me be atypical not odd.

title: The Faith of the Centurion part 2
study_refs: When Jesus had finished saying all this the people who were listening, he entered Capernaum. There a centurion’s servant, whom his master valued highly, was sick and about to die. The centurion heard of Jesus and sent some elders of the Jews to him, asking him to come and heal his servant. When they came to Jesus, they pleaded earnestly with him, “This man deserves to have you do this, because he loves our nation and has built our synagogue.” So Jesus went with them He was not far from the house when the centurion sent friends to say to him: “Lord, don’t trouble yourself, for I do not deserve to have you come under my roof. That is why I did not even consider myself worthy to come to you. But say the word, and my servant will be healed. For I myself am a man under authority, with soldiers under me. I tell this one, ‘Go,’ and he goes; and that one, ‘Come,’ and he comes. I say to my servant, ‘Do this,’ and he does it.” When Jesus heard this, he was amazed at him, and turning to the crowd following him, he said, “I tell you, I have not found such great faith even in Israel.” Then the men who had been sent returned to the house and found the servant well.

html:
2. Counterculture living requires atypical people.

Life of a centurion.

Luke 7 introduces us to a Roman Centurion. As you may know a Roman Centurion was someone who was in charge of 100 plus men. We know a number of facts from history about the life of a Centurion in Israel at this time.

During the New Testament era, a Roman centurion was a professional military officer commanding a platoon of troops called a “century.” This could be anywhere from nearly one hundred to several hundred men. Each Roman legion was composed of 5,000-6,000 men, divided into multiple cohorts, each cohort composed of multiple centuries. As a result, a legion could contain as many as sixty centurions. Their importance was based on seniority, with the senior centurion in a legion being in a position of great prestige.

The rank of centurion was the highest that an ordinary soldier could reach. Those who filled this office were career soldiers who had to be good leaders. 15 years service was required before a solider could become a centurion. The discipline and efficiency of the Roman military machine depended on them. According to one source, centurions “were often the most experienced and best-informed men in the army.”

This particular centurion could not have been part of the Roman army, however, since there were no Roman forces in Galilee at the time; instead, he probably belonged to the royal troops of Herod Antipas. Rulers appointed by Rome and were expected to maintain an army and to provide Rome with military support when necessary. The average lifespan of a Roman Centurion is not well-documented. However, it is believed that it was around 25-30 years. This is due to the harsh conditions of military life, as well as the high mortality rate in battle. The ancient historian Polybius offers a list of qualifications looked for in centurions. They must be not so much "seekers after danger as men who can command, steady in action, and reliable; they ought not to be over anxious to rush into the fight; but when hard pressed they must be ready to hold their ground and die at their posts. This centurion, would have been a highly paid military man. An average soldier was paid 75 denari; a centurion 3,750-7,500 denari.

To the Jew, the centurion had three things against him: he was bitterly hated because he was non-Jewish, a Gentile; he was of the nation that had conquered Palestine, and he was of the armed and occupying force.

Interestingly, every time a centurion is mentioned in the New Testament it is with honour.

So to be a centurion was a tough, dangerous job, which would require a ‘’kill or be killed’ attitude. And yet the centurion we meet in our story did not really fit the status-quo, he did not comply with conventional perceptions and understandings of what a centurion should be.

The world needs people like this centurion, who are atypical because they have a dynamic relationship with God. We need to become people who do not fit into nice, neat tidy boxes. People who are positively distinctive, not odd, strange or awkward, but people who threaten the essence of a godless culture through love and grace. This front line solider had the courage to be different, he had the courage not to be ‘pigeon holed.’ I wonder if we have inadvertently turned the church into a ‘sausage factory’ where we mass produce a ’Christian experience,’ that allows us to feel content with the bland of the status-quo.

Father ,may I be positively distinctive

Bible in a year: Joshua 21:13-23:16
title: The Faith of the Centurion part 3
study_refs: When Jesus had finished saying all this the people who were listening, he entered Capernaum. There a centurion’s servant, whom his master valued highly, was sick and about to die. The centurion heard of Jesus and sent some elders of the Jews to him, asking him to come and heal his servant. When they came to Jesus, they pleaded earnestly with him, “This man deserves to have you do this, because he loves our nation and has built our synagogue.” So Jesus went with them He was not far from the house when the centurion sent friends to say to him: “Lord, don’t trouble yourself, for I do not deserve to have you come under my roof. That is why I did not even consider myself worthy to come to you. But say the word, and my servant will be healed. For I myself am a man under authority, with soldiers under me. I tell this one, ‘Go,’ and he goes; and that one, ‘Come,’ and he comes. I say to my servant, ‘Do this,’ and he does it.” When Jesus heard this, he was amazed at him, and turning to the crowd following him, he said, “I tell you, I have not found such great faith even in Israel.” Then the men who had been sent returned to the house and found the servant well.

html:
Countercultural living requires a life that expresses radical love.

Luke tell us that ‘a highly valued slave of a Roman Centurion was sick and near death.’ This phrase is full of controversy. In Roman law, a slave was defined as a living tool. He had no rights. In fact, a master could abuse him and even kill him if he chose to do so. A Roman writer on estate management recommended the farmer to examine his implements every year and to throw out those which were old and broken, and to do the same with his own slaves. Normally when a slave was past his ability to work, he was thrown out to die. They were bought and sold at slave markets across the ancient world, and were paraded by their owners as a sign of wealth: the more enslaved people a person owned, it was thought, the greater their stature and wealth. They were considered the property of their masters, enslaved Romans were often subjected to vile treatment, including physical and sexual abuse.

This centurion esteemed, respected, and had a high regard for this slave. He didn’t look down on him, or belittle him, or see him as less than. The respect we show or don’t show to others says more about us than it does about them. Does respect need to be earned? Do others need to deserve our respect? Respect cannot be demanded, nor should be tied to someone’s status or position in life. Every person who is made in God’s image has value and worth no matter their status.

4. Countercultural living will require us to have relevant relationships with the community.

Luke tells us, ‘When the officer heard about Jesus, he sent some respected Jewish elders to ask him to come and heal his slave. So they earnestly begged Jesus to help the man. “If anyone deserves your help, he does,” they said, “for he loves the Jewish people and even built a synagogue for us.’ I think these verses are amazing. Here we have a pagan solider enlisted in the Roman army. He is respected by the Jewish religious leaders and he built a synagogue. The incredible thing is not that he was prepared to pay for the building of the synagogue, but that the Jewish leaders let him build it in the first place. In these days the predominate world-view of Judaism was aggressively anti-gentile. The Gentiles were despised and hated by the Jews, and some how this member of an occupying enemy force was able to remove all the barriers between himself and his antagonists so he could show love. Some people think that this centurion may have been a convert to Judaism, but this is unlikely as Jewish men were not allowed to enlist into the Roman army. Can you grasp how counter-cultural this man was? He did not allow the stereotypical norms or expectations of society to dictate his actions. He loved his enemy, he did good to those who hated him. This was authentic faith, living out a set of beliefs that will enable you to touch the very heart of community.

Father help me to be different but not odd.

title: The Faith of the Centurion part 4
study_refs: When Jesus had finished saying all this the people who were listening, he entered Capernaum. There a centurion’s servant, whom his master valued highly, was sick and about to die. The centurion heard of Jesus and sent some elders of the Jews to him, asking him to come and heal his servant. When they came to Jesus, they pleaded earnestly with him, “This man deserves to have you do this, because he loves our nation and has built our synagogue.” So Jesus went with them He was not far from the house when the centurion sent friends to say to him: “Lord, don’t trouble yourself, for I do not deserve to have you come under my roof. That is why I did not even consider myself worthy to come to you. But say the word, and my servant will be healed. For I myself am a man under authority, with soldiers under me. I tell this one, ‘Go,’ and he goes; and that one, ‘Come,’ and he comes. I say to my servant, ‘Do this,’ and he does it.” When Jesus heard this, he was amazed at him, and turning to the crowd following him, he said, “I tell you, I have not found such great faith even in Israel.” Then the men who had been sent returned to the house and found the servant well.

html:
Countercultural living will mean that we have a realistic view of ourselves.

We read in verse 6, ‘So Jesus went with them. But just before they arrived at the house, the officer sent some friends to say, “Lord, don’t trouble yourself by coming to my home, for I am not worthy of such an honour.’

Some think the reason why the centurion did not want Jesus to enter his home was because he was a gentile and Jews were not allowed into their homes in case they become unclean. I think it was more to do with the centurion’s self awareness. Often I have thought how amazing it would be to have Jesus’ physical presence in our home, and it would be, however, the attitude of this centurion was so different than mine. His attitude was one of complete humility, free from any sense of entitlement or any feeling of deserving. His humility was also expressed when he said, ‘Lord don’t trouble yourself.’ Lord don’t put yourself out for me.’ I wonder if we have ever said those words to Jesus?

Countercultural living requires an exclusive hope in the authority of Jesus.

‘Just say the word from where you are and my servant will be healed. There were many things this centurion did not know or understand about Jesus, but he understood that Jesus had authority. In the face of the impending death of his esteemed slave, this centurion found comfort and hope in the fact that Jesus was a person of great authority, and that authority could make all the difference.

In a world full of chaos, fear and confusion we have the freedom to live distinct countercultural lives because all authority in heaven and earth has been given to Jesus. We can live in humble expectation because the word of Jesus is as powerful now as it was then. We don’t have to become moulded or squeezed into some kind of ‘misshapen’ Christian experience by the insidious pressures of the world. Because Jesus has authority we can be atypical. I love the fact that this centurion is the only person in the bible who brought the need of a slave to Jesus.

Countercultural lives touches the heart of Jesus.

Luke tells us that ‘Jesus was amazed by this man’s faith’. The Greek word for amazed thaumazo, means to wonder, marvel, be struck with admiration or astonishment. To be surprised by the unexpected. This may have been one of the sweetest moment of Jesus’ ministry. He had been amazed before at the unbelief of the people of Nazareth see Mark 6:1-7. And he told a Canaanite women that her faith was great, see Matthew 15:28.but this the only time Jesus was amazed by someone’s faith. This man’s faith was not set of dogmas or theological tenets that he subscribed to. It was much more than a sure confidence in the authority and power of Jesus. Rather it was a confident belief in the authority and power of Jesus that directed and shaped how he lived and how he treated others.

I do not think it is a coincidence that the person whose faith amazed Jesus was a centurion, because to live a life of faith requires great courage in the face of threatening circumstances, just like this centurion. I don’t know about you, but I would love to be ‘atypical,’ not odd, or strange, or awkward. But someone who lives a life shaped and directed by authentic faith.

Father help me to have the courage to have more faith

He said: “Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven. Blessed are those who mourn, for they will be comforted. Blessed are the meek for they will inherit the earth. Blessed are those who hunger and thirst for righteousness, for they will be filled. Blessed are the merciful, for they will be shown mercy. Blessed are the pure in heart, for they will see God. Blessed are the peacemakers, for they will be called children of God. Blessed are those who are persecuted because of righteousness, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven. Blessed are you when people insult you, persecute you and falsely say all kinds of evil against you because of me. Rejoice and be glad, because great is your reward in heaven, for in the same way they persecuted the prophets who were before you.’’

If you were in Jesus shoes, what issues would you have address first? What advice would you give to those who were about to embark on full time service?

The main emphasis of the Sermon on the Mount is on our character, what we become not what we do. The way we serve God has more to do with character, than gift or ability so Jesus addresses the whole issue of character at this time because he knows that for them to fulfil the role of Apostles, they would need much more than divine ability, they would require godly characters. A further emphasis of the sermon is the protection and the development of relationships. Being salt and light, and the proper fulfilment of the law are about healthy relationships. In the 'Lord's Prayer' the reference is to forgiving others.

These two emphases, character and relationships, can be summed up in one word, righteousness. The word righteousness is not only a descriptive word that describes the moral conduct of someone, but it is also a relational word, describing how we relate to others. Jesus said "For I tell you unless your righteousness surpasses the righteousness of the Pharisees and teachers of the law, you will certainly not enter the kingdom of heaven." 5:20

So what does it mean to be righteous?

1. Righteousness is being blessed.

When we think of being blessed, we usually suffer from a totally wrong understanding. "In ancient Greek times, makarios, blessed referred to the gods. The blessed ones were the gods. They had achieved a state of happiness and contentment in life that was beyond all cares, labours, and even death. The blessed ones were beings who lived way up there in some other world. To be blessed, you had to be a god. That word took on a second meaning. It referred to the "dead". The blessed ones were humans, who, through death, had reached the other world of the gods. They were now beyond the cares of earthly life. To be blessed, you had to be dead. Finally, in Greek usage, the word came to refer to the elite, the upper crust of society, the wealthy people. It referred to people whose riches and power put them above the normal cares and worries of the lesser folk the peons, who constantly struggle and worry and labour in life. To be blessed, you had to be very rich and powerful. When this word, makarios was used in the Greek translation of the Old Testament, it took on an another meaning. It referred to the results of right living or righteousness. If you lived right, you were blessed. Being blessed meant you received earthly, material things: a good wife, many children, abundant crops, riches, honour, wisdom, beauty, good health, etc.

A blessed person had more things and better things than an ordinary person. To be blessed, you had to have big and beautiful things. In all of these meanings, the "blessed" ones existed on a higher plane than the rest of the people. They were ‘gods.’ They were humans who had gone to that other world of the gods. They were the wealthy, upper crust. They were those with many possessions.

‘Jesus uses this word in a totally different way. It is not the elite who are blessed. It is not the rich and powerful who are blessed. It is not the high and mighty who are blessed. It is not the people living in huge mansions or expensive penthouses who are blessed. Rather, Jesus pronounces God's blessings on the lowly: the poor, the hungry, the crying, and the hated. Throughout the history of this word, it had always been the other people who were considered blessed: the rich, the filled up, the laughing. Jesus turns it all upside-down. The elite in God's kingdom, the blessed ones in God's kingdom, are those who are at the bottom of the heap of humanity." Brian P. Stoffregen

Many people understand the word Blessed to mean the same as being happy, but this is not what it means, the best way to understand the word blessed is to see it from God's perspective. So blessed could be translated, "Those who have God's approval." So the blessing spoken of here, is referring to those who have a character that God approves of. An indication as to how blessed we are is seen in the kind of character we have. Notice when Jesus speaks of being blessed he never mentions material possessions, or worldly achievements.

Father may I be blessed with a godly character Bible in a year reading plan Judges 6-7

He said: “Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven. Blessed are those who mourn, for they will be comforted. Blessed are the meek for they will inherit the earth. Blessed are those who hunger and thirst for righteousness, for they will be filled. Blessed are the merciful, for they will be shown mercy. Blessed are the pure in heart, for they will see God. Blessed are the peacemakers, for they will be called children of God. Blessed are those who are persecuted because of righteousness, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven. Blessed are you when people insult you, persecute you and falsely say all kinds of evil against you because of me. Rejoice and be glad, because great is your reward in heaven, for in the same way they persecuted the prophets who were before you.’’

2.The structure of the Beatitudes.

Jesus begins this sermon with a list of sayings known as the Beatitudes. If you look carefully, you will notice that the first and last beatitude ends with the same promise. "Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven" and "Blessed are those who are persecuted for righteousness' sake, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven." Verse 11 is not considered as one of the beatitudes because it is worded differently, it is viewed more of an explanation of verse 10. The promise given in the first and last beatitude is given in the present tense, "for theirs is the kingdom of heaven." While the promises given in the second through to the seventh are in the future tense, "They will.

" "Now what is the meaning of this pattern? I think there are at least two implications. First, by sandwiching six promises in between two assurances that such people have the kingdom of heaven, I think Jesus means to tell us that these six promises are blessings of the kingdom. In other words, these six things are what you can count on when you are a part of God's kingdom. This is what the kingdom brings: comfort, earth ownership, satisfied righteousness, mercy, a vision of God, and the awesome title, son of God. You don't have to pick and choose among these promises. They all belong to the kingdom. Secondly, I see in the fact that Jesus begins with the assurance, "Theirs is the kingdom of heaven," and ends with the assurance, "Theirs is the kingdom of heaven" with six promises sandwiched in between. I think this is Jesus' way of saying that in some sense the kingdom of heaven is present with the disciples now (Theirs is the kingdom of heaven) but that the full blessings of the kingdom will have to wait for the age to come (They shall inherit the earth)." John Piper. https://www.desiringgod.org/messages/the-beatitudes-and-the-gospel-of-the-kingdom#:~:text=The%20Blessings%20of%20the%20Kingdom,a%20part%20of%20God's%20kingdom. Accessed 26/06/2025

3. Every beatitude is in striking contrast to the character and conduct of the Scribes and Pharisees. When you look at the attitudes portrayed by the scribes and the Pharisees, it was completely opposite to that described by Jesus in the beatitudes. Twice in the sermon Jesus warns his disciples "do not be like them" Matthew 6:5,8. Notice carefully what Jesus says here, He did not say, "Do not do what they do," but "do not be like them." He was referring to their characters.

The Pharisees were proud, not poor in spirit.

As far as I'm aware, there is only one other place in first century Jewish literature where the phrase 'poor in spirit' occurs and that is in the Dead Sea Scrolls. "Among the poor in spirit [there is power] over the hard of heart." These two separate phrases declare opposites, which are being contrasted. What the phrase 'poor in spirit' seems to mean, therefore, is the antithesis of 'hard of heart' The poor in spirit are those who are not self-assertive, self-reliant, self-confident, self-centred, or self-sufficient.

There are two Greek words for poor. PENES describe the person who does not have a lot; they live from day to day, someone like a day labourer, who was paid a daily wage. The second word is the word PTOCHOS means to crouch like a beggar, this describes the person who has nothing, who is completely destitute, and this is the word Jesus uses. Being poor in spirit is a strong realisation of our desperate need of God, not just for salvation, but for every thing in life.

The Pharisees were self satisfied and self-content, because of their self-righteousness they had nothing to mourn over. When Jesus speaks of mourning he uses a very strong word. It was the word used to describe the external evidences of an internal grief. In other words, Jesus is talking about people being real. Often in Christian circles there is a tendency to bury how we really feel in order to protect ourselves from further pain or rejection. But Jesus is saying that mourning is part of a healthy Christian experience.

When we bury stuff we die spiritually, many people believe that if they ignore a problem, or bury a pain it will go away. Living in the kingdom of God is a call to reality. The focus of the Pharisees was always to keep up the appearance of have everything under control, to look cool, but never dealing with reality. Those who mourn will find comfort; the comfort of God brings healing and hope.

This is a very important principle for us to learn, there is great temptation for us to look cool, and in the process bury wounds and hurts that can only be healed when they are brought out in the open.

The Pharisees were hard, quick to condemn others. They were not gentle or meek. The biblical word "meek" comes from the Greek word praos, which means "mild, humble, or gentle." Classical Greek uses it in many ways. Meekness refers to describe a soothing medicine. Meekness refers to a gentle breeze. Meekness refers to a colt that is broken and useful. Meekness refers to person who treats others with respect, dignity, politeness and courtesy. In one of Plato's works, a child asked a physician to be "gentle" with him. The word for meekness was used in much extra-biblical literature to refer to a horse that had been trained. Therefore the idea is "power under control."A horse that is trained is useful and safe. However one that cannot be controlled is useless and dangerous. It was used to describe a medicine that can bring healing.

However a horse that cannot be controlled can kill. A wind that blows with controlled speeds is useful to pump water and provide energy. One without control is destructive. A person who can control his words is encouraging and pleasant. A person who is not meek and gentle is out of control. Living in the kingdom of God is bowing to the control of another..

"The meek will inherit the earth." There is a simple principle here; God will not give those who are out of control any inheritance. God gives those who are gentle, positions of authority.

But how is such meekness produced in a person? This gentleness is the result of the healing comfort of God. In the beatitude before this one we are told that those who mourn shall be comforted. The word for comfort means to draw along beside someone in order to encourage and exhort him or her in times of sorrow. Often people end up hard and bitter as a result of the sorrows of life. This hardness is caused by the refusal to receive the comfort of God.

Father is their any area of my life that is not touched by meekness, where I am out of control?

Bible in a year: Judges 8-9

He said: “Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven. Blessed are those who mourn, for they will be comforted. Blessed are the meek for they will inherit the earth. Blessed are those who hunger and thirst for righteousness, for they will be filled. Blessed are the merciful, for they will be shown mercy. Blessed are the pure in heart, for they will see God. Blessed are the peacemakers, for they will be called children of God. Blessed are those who are persecuted because of righteousness, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven. Blessed are you when people insult you, persecute you and falsely say all kinds of evil against you because of me. Rejoice and be glad, because great is your reward in heaven, for in the same way they persecuted the prophets who were before you.’’

"Blessed are those who hunger and thirst for righteousness, for they will be filled." The Pharisees did not feel a need to seek for righteousness; they viewed themselves as being righteous.

This beatitude describes what should be in the heart of those who are living in the kingdom of God. There should be an overwhelming desire for righteousness. We need to cultivate a love for righteousness. The thirst and hunger mentioned here is an unquenchable one, the result of prolonged deprivation. The Puritan Thomas Watson wrote, "He who has most need of righteousness is he that least wants it." Why is it important that we develop and encourage such a hunger in our own hearts and in the hearts of others? Righteousness brings hope and security to a person. Why? For righteousness brings satisfaction. The Greek word for filled is chortazo, which was often used to describe the feeding of animals until they were so full they could eat no more. When we lack contentment and satisfaction we will turn to sin in order to find fulfilment. If a person has a strong desire and appetite for righteousness, how will that effect how he treats others? Fulfilment in this life can only be experienced as we increase in righteousness.

If we were to divide the beatitudes into two groups of four, the first four speak of those who feel their need of righteousness, while the second four is speaking about those who display righteousness. The first four is speaking about the internal attitudes, while the second four is speaking about external relationships, relationship with God and people.

"Blessed are the merciful for they shall be shown mercy."

The Pharisees were incapable of showing mercy. What is mercy? The Greek word here was originally used to describe the emotion aroused by contact with an undeserved affliction that comes on someone else. We might use the words "sympathy," "pity" or "compassion." Mercy may involve such acts as pardon, forgiveness, or the mitigation of penalties. Mercy is experienced and exercised by a person who has another person in his power, or under his authority, or from whom no kindness can be claimed. Mercy is an essential requirement for healthy relationships. Having a heart full of mercy will help a person respond properly to the pain that comes through difficult relationships, and enables a person to reach out to those who are less fortunate.

A person, who is incapable of showing mercy, is dehumanised, for mercy is one of the noblest expressions of what it means to be human and made in the likeness of God. The person who is poor in spirit, mourning over sin, meek submissive to God in all things, and hungering and thirsting after righteousness is going to be merciful. If a person is not merciful, then the other qualities are also lacking.

Father, may my life display mercy to other

Blessed are you when people insult you, persecute you and falsely say all kinds of evil against you because of me. "Blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God."
The Pharisees were not pure in heart. "Purity of heart" is not mere the avoidance of "impure thoughts" (e.g., sexual fantasies), but refers to the single-minded devotion to God... faith. Having an "undivided heart" (Ps 86:11) requires that there be something big enough and good enough to merit one's whole devotion, rather than the functional polytheism of parcelling oneself out to a number of loyalties." Boring (Matthew, NIB] [p. 1791 ]

The word "pure" also brings out the idea of "cleansing" which is the central idea in the Greek word katharos from which we get our word, "catharsis" - meaning to "cleanse the emotions or spirit. "This 'pure in heart' could be described as being whole-heartedly committed to God and is the consequences of mourning. Refusal to deal with the issues of sin and pain will distract us from being whole hearted in our walk with God. Paul taught this same principle in Philippians 3:1-14. He had to leave behind the past so he could be wholeheartedly devoted to God. When we refuse to be honest with ourselves and deal with the issues that are going on in our hearts, then we will be incapable of being whole-hearted in our commitment to God. When we bury our pain, we bury our commitment to God in the process.

Father, help me be wholehearted in all that I am

Bible in a year: Judges 14-16

"Blessed are the peacemakers, for they will be called sons of God." The Pharisees did not understand the meaning of real peace. For a Pharisee peace meant having the ability to control things or people, so their expectations and needs would be met. Jesus said, "Blessed are the peacemakers for they will be called the sons of God." It is important to notice that Jesus is not talking about peacekeepers, but peacemakers.

So what is a peacemaker?

To help us answer this question, it would be helpful to say what a peacemaker is not. A peacemaker is not someone who tries to keep the peace at all costs; they are not someone who buries issues, hoping that they will go away, they would never sweep things under the carpet. In fact a peacemaker may be viewed as a troublemaker, why? Because they will insist that an issue will be brought out in the open, so it can be dealt with properly.

The ultimate expression of peacemaking is Jesus' death on the cross. "For God was pleased to have all his fullness dwell in him, and through him to reconcile to himself all things, whether things on earth or things in heaven, by making peace through his blood, shed on the cross." Colossians 1:19-20. In other words, peacemaking is a very demanding and painful. This is not a licence for us to go around and always being in people's face or on their cases. To be a peacemaker you must also be poor in spirit, mournful over your own failure, gentle, etc. If we are not pure in heart, then we are in need of the help of a peacemaker for a lack of peace within ourselves, and with others, is an indication that we are not pure in heart.

For some people like myself, this is the most scary and demanding beatitude, because of our dislike of confrontation. But if we are going to be known as sons of God, then we must be willing to be involved in peacemaking, or the "ministry of reconciliation," to use Paul's phrase.

"Blessed are those who are persecuted for righteousness: for theirs is the kingdom of heaven."

The Pharisees were not persecuted for righteousness, rather they persecuted the righteous.

Some see the last two beatitudes as two separate beatitudes, while others see them as one. I don't think it matters. Reading this beatitude is ot very comforting. Twice Jesus says that a person who is persecuted is blessed. So how is persecution a blessing? Before we answer that, we need to point out that often people have misused these verses, those they are in your face, ramming the gospel down your throat. When they are persecuted, they get puffed up with pride, wrongly believing that they are being persecuted for righteousness.

The righteousness that Jesus is referring to here is the result of combined qualities of all the beatitudes expressed through life. It is interesting to note that this beatitude comes after Jesus speaking about peacemaking. Peacemakers will attract persecution because of what they stand for.

So what is Persecution, and how is it a blessing?

Persecution, the word Jesus uses here is dioko, which literally means to be chased, it was used in the LXX to describe being chased by hostile soldiers

To insult, the word means to reproach or complain about, to cast in one's teeth.

To falsely accuse, to deceive by lies, to speak all kinds of evil against. This is the complete opposite of the righteous character of those who display the attributes of the beatitudes. But how is this kind of hassle to be seen as a blessing?

There are three reasons that Jesus gives which explain why this persecution can be perceived as a blessing.

First of all, it is suffering for His sake. It is a distinct privilege to suffer for the sake of Christ.

Secondly, suffering in the present gives promise of future rewards: "Rejoice, and be glad, for your reward in heaven is great."

Thirdly, we can rejoice because persecution for Christ's sake places us in the company of the prophets of old, who, for their testimony, were persecuted as well.

What can we learn from these blessings?

Suffering for Christ is the deepest kind of fellowship we can have with Christ. When we suffer because of our righteousness, we are sharing in his sufferings. To have fellowship in someone's suffering, to suffer along with them, is real intimacy.

Suffering reminds us that we haven't got home yet. Our reward is in heaven. When people believe that all their needs can be met in this world, then they will not be able to cope with persecution. But for beatitude people, their hearts are set on heaven.

Suffering for righteousness, reminds us that this is the way it has always been for those who live close to God, like the prophets. We should not be surprised if righteous living causes an offence to an evil world.

The type of person that the beatitudes describe is the most concise and accurate description we have of a disciple. The goal of discipleship is seen in the beatitudes.

Father may I have then courage to be a peacemaker
