Matthew 11:25-30 At that time Jesus said, “I praise you, Father, Lord of heaven and earth, because you have hidden these things from the wise and learned, and revealed them to little children. Yes, Father, for this is what you were pleased to do. All things have been committed to me by my Father. No one knows the Son except the Father, and no one knows the Father except the Son and those to whom the Son chooses to reveal him. “Come to me all you who are weary and burdened, and I will give you rest. Take my yoke upon you and learn from me, for I am gentle and humble in heart, and you will find rest for your souls. for my yoke is easy and my burden is light.”

This section is introduced by one of the few-recorded prayers of the Lord Jesus. Matthew writes, "At that time Jesus said, 'l praise you, Father, Lord of heaven and earth, because you have hidden these things from the wise and learned, and revealed them to little children."'

If we are going to learn anything from this prayer we must remember the context in which it was prayed. Three things had happen to Jesus that may have caused him to be discouraged.

John was in prison and because of his circumstances he began to doubt if he had made a mistake about Jesus, was He really the promised Messiah? The generation in which Jesus lived was totally inconsistent. They condemned John for fasting, and condemned Jesus for feasting. It was a generation that could never be satisfied.

After months of ministry in the cities of Korazin, Berthsaida and Capernaum, Jesus who must have been weary had no choice than to denounce them for their unreasonable and determined rejection. This was not easy for Jesus, he loved these people, he had made his home with them. These denouncements most have taken their toll on him. So in order to keep his perspective, and to encourage him to reach out in the future, he turns to his Father in prayer

What can we learn from this prayer?

When you consider the prayer life of Jesus as it is recorded in the four Gospels there are two interesting factors. We are only told the contents of Jesus' prayers in the second half of his ministry. We have instances of Jesus praying in the first half of his ministry, but we are never told what he said. The reason for this may be that the Gospels writers are trying to teach us 'How we approach God is more important than what we say.'

The prayers that we do have recorded of Jesus, most of them are said in times of crisis, especially around his passion. Jesus did not allow the pain of life to prevent him from having an intimate relationship with his Father. Often in times of crisis our prayer life becomes more an expression of panic rather than fellowship. How we pray in times of difficulty reveal what we really think of God.

Jesus' relationship with his Father helped him cope with the stress of ministry.

I don't know if you have ever felt like a failure, sometimes feelings of failure are appropriate, you have an exam, or a driving tests, and you know that you have done nothing to prepare for it, and you fail, your not surprised. But what happens, when like Jesus, you give yourself one hundred percent, hoping that people would turn to God and repent, and they don't. The feelings of failure would be far worse. It would have been very easy for Jesus to give up, and think, "what's the point"? To prevent discouragement from eating him up, he turned to his Father.

To call God, Father was a new concept to the Jews. In the Old Testament God is referred to as father, but only sparingly, only twenty-one times. And when he is referred to father it is never as 'father to an individual, but as father to the nation of Israel. However, in the gospels God is referred to as father one hundred and seventy times. This was the title Jesus uses most for God. It was because Jesus felt so secure in his relationship with his Father that he was able to give the wonderful invitation "Come unto me all who are weary."

Jesus prayer was an expression of total submission.

We read "At that time Jesus said, "I praise you Father." When we think of praise, most of us think in terms of our emotions, we think that to praise God is to feel emotionally happy with whatever God brings into our life. This understanding is a perversion as the Greek word used here for praise is exomologeo. It means to acknowledge or agree fully: confess, profess, and promise. To praise God is to submit to him, to acknowledge that he God, and what he does is always right.

This kind of submission is only possible, when we are experiencing God as our Father, and we are living like his Sons. Surrendering our lives to God is not a one off experience, it is something that is ongoing, and is an essential requirement if we are going to cope with the demands of life and ministry. This kind of submission will produce a heart of gratitude, so we yield our lives to our Father as an expression of thanks and gratitude

Jesus prayer expressed the belief that his Father was sovereign. We read

"At that time Jesus said. 'l praise you Father, Lord of heaven and earth."' Despite the rejection by those he loved, Jesus reminded himself that his father was still Lord. When we are under pressure we need to remind ourselves that God is Sovereign.

In prayer Jesus found comfort in the ways of the kingdom.

"l praise you, Father, Lord of heaven and earth, because you have hidden these things from the wise and learned, and revealed them to little children." As Jesus communicated with his Father, he was aware that the ways of the Kingdom are very different to the ways of the world. The wise and the learned in this context were the Pharisees and the religious people who were privileged in many ways, yet they were obstinate and oblivious to the truth.

Jesus knew that his job was not to use intellectual persuasion or reasoned argument to convince people of his message. God resists the proud, and hides truth from them, but reveals truth to children. The word for children nepios literally means, "not speaking," so it refers to infants prior to their learning to speak. There is a very important principle here, the ways of kingdom are only learned, understood and applied properly in the context of a dependant relationship and ongoing communication with the father. The ways of the kingdom, and how God works in his world are not learned like a mathematical formula, but it is only as we open our hearts to God and depend on him, that we will be able to understand his ways. The truth that it was his Fathers pleasure to reveal these things...to little children" helped Jesus understand the rejection of the people in the three cities.

Jesus emphasises the importance of being a Son.

"All things have been committed to me by my Father. No one knows the Son except the Father, and no one knows the Father except the Son and those the son chooses to reveal him." Fulfilling the role as a Son made it possible for Jesus to reach out to others in the future despite the rejection of the past. He remembered that being a Son was the most important thing, not being successful. As Jesus communicated with His father through this prayer, he was encouraged and strengthened, and he was able to make the invitation, not because success was guaranteed, but because he was feeling secure

Father I would love to have Jesus’ attitude to prayer

html:
Jesus said. "Come to me, all you who are weary and burdened, and I will give you rest. Take my yoke upon you and learn from me, for I am gentle and humble in heart, and you will find rest for your souls, for my yoke is easy and my burden is light." Before we can understand what Jesus is saying we need to do some background work. Many people feel that the burden Jesus was speaking of when he said 'Come to me, all you who are weary and burdened', was the burden of the law that the Pharisees had laid upon the people. The law was originally intended as the essentials necessary for the journey of faith by God's people. Unfortunately, over the years the children of Israel added to the list, adding much more than was necessary for the trip. For every "thou shalt" or "thou shalt not" they added many more commandments, so that the backpack grew in size to overpower those who had to carry it. By the time Jesus came along, it was too heavy for the journey. So Jesus wanted to remove the burden of the law from people.

Although this is a legitimate application of what Jesus is saying, I don't think this was his primary thought. In the context of Matthew 11 Jesus is not directly addressing the issue of legalism.

A second thing we need to understand is what Jesus meant by yoke. The yoke mentioned shouldn't be thought of as a wooden object, which was used to join two animals together, so that they might pull a plough or some other such agricultural device. Rather it was a wooden yoke placed over the shoulders of a single human being which was used to balance the weight being carried on two extremes, thus enabling the load to be laid upon the entire frame of the person

A third factor is how the Old Testament uses the symbol of the yoke.

"This is what the Lord said to me; 'Make a yoke out of straps and crossbars and put it on your neck. Then send word to the kings of Edon, Moab, Ammon, Tyre and Sidon through the envoys who have come to Jerusalem to Zedekiah King of Judah. Give them this message for their masters and say. This is what the Lord almighty the God of Israel says. Tell this to your masters: with my great power I made the earth and its people and the animals that are on it, and I give it to anyone I please. Now I will hand all your countries over to my servant Nebuchadnezzar King of Babylon; I will even make the wild animals subject to him. All the nations will serve him and his son and his grandson until the time for his land comes; then many nations and great kings will subjugate him. If, however, any nation will not serve Nebuchadnezzar King of Babylon or bow its neck under his yoke, I will punish that nation with the sword, famine and plague declares the Lord, until I destroy it by his hand. So do not listen to your prophets, your diviners, your interpreters of dreams, your mediums or your sorcerers who tell you. 'You will not serve the King of Babylon,' They prophesy lies to you that will only serve to remove you far from your lands; I will banish you and you will perish. But if any nation will bow its neck under the yoke of the king of Babylon and serve him I will, I will let that nation remain in its own land, till it, and to live there declares the Lord. I gave the same message to Zedekiah King of Judah. Bow your neck under the yoke of the king of Babylon; serve him and his people and you will live." Jeremiah 27:1-12.

When God was judging the nations he placed a yoke on them as a form of punishment, this yoke implies the death of a way of life and the loss of a sense of identity. When Jesus offered people his yoke, he was promising them more than a release from they heavy burdens, he was promising a new way of life and a new identity. So the yoke spoke about a persons identity and value system. The yoke is whatever controls and masters our lives.

With these facts in mind, we can answer two important questions. What was Christ’s yoke? And how did he carry it?

Father help me be controlled and mastered by your yoke

Jesus knew the importance of being a Son. These attitudes make up the yoke that Jesus wore. Imagine what would happen to a man who did not have these attitudes to govern his life. He would have the weight of the world on his shoulders. He would feel responsible for being successful, he could never rest or relax, and his confidence would be in himself, not in God. This is the heavy load Jesus is referring to.

Jesus says two things about how he carries his yoke.

He was gentle. This is the only time in scripture where Jesus speaks about his heart. The word for gentle is the same word that Jesus used in the beatitudes when he said 'Blessed are the meek.' As we have seen before this is a picture word

A gentle spirit describes a soothing medicine.

B. gentle spirit refers to a gentle breeze.

C, gentle spirit refers to a colt that is broken and useful.

D. gentle spirit refers to person who treats others with respect, dignity, politeness and courtesy.

F. gentile spirit was used in much extra-biblical literature to refer to a horse that had been trained. Therefore the idea is "power under control."A horse that is trained is useful and safe. However one that cannot be controlled is useless and dangerous. A medicine that can be controlled can bring healing. However one that cannot be controlled can kill. A wind that blows with controlled speeds is useful to pump water and provide energy. One without control is destructive. A person who can control his words is encouraging and pleasant. A person who is not meek and gentle is out of control. When our hearts are harsh and hard, we will find it impossible to submit to the yoke of Jesus.

Father ‘May I demonstrate the gentleness of Jesus.’

html:
Jesus is saying "Do not fear my yoke for I am not like your previous masters. I am gentle and humble. You do not have to carry the heavy load the worlds expectations has placed upon you."

Look how Jesus describes his yoke, "For my yoke is easy and my burden is light."The word for easy is Chrestos. This word means to be kind. When we allow Jesus to place his yoke upon us, then we are responding appropriately to his kindness. It is kind of Jesus to want to be our Lord and have complete control over our lives. For he knows that we will only discover life to the full if we bow to his rule in our lives, in the same way He bowed to his father The word Chrestos was also used to describe mature wine. (Luke 5:39.) Wine that has no bitterness in it. When we discover the yoke of Jesus, this is not a bitter experience; the effects of Christs yoke will remove all bitterness from our hearts, why? Because we submit to Christ believing that he is sovereign.

Jesus concludes with saying "My burden is light." Bowing to the will of God does not mean that our lives become carefree or careless. Bowing to the yoke of Christ means that we will be equipped to carry the right kind of burdens. The burdens that Jesus was speaking of here could be hooked onto the yoke. Many people go through life "weary and burdened" and are unable to carry the God designed burdens we need to carry if we are going to have a fulfilled life. Only people, who have experienced the rest of Jesus, can bow to his yoke and carry his burden.

Jesus gives this invitation so that those who come to him will find rest. The word for rest is. " Anapausin " it denotes a temporary rest, a respite, e.g. 'of soldiers rested to prepare to go back into battle,' to refresh us for the work that lies ahead. This rest is the result of intimacy when we respond to Jesus' invitation "come unto me." Jesus found rest when he came to his Father. If we do not learn to find rest in God, and be refreshed by being with him, then we will be unable to bow to his yoke and carry his burden, and we will end up weary and tired under our own burden.

Father help me find real rest

html:
Some Historical background about the family of Jesus.


Jesus had at least 6 siblings, two or more were sisters and four brothers -James, Joses, Judas and Simon (Mark 6.3). The former became the head of the Palestinian part of the Movement after the crucifixion. Mary, His mother was probably married at 12 or 13 years of age and would have been in her early 40's at the time of Jesus' violent death outside Jerusalem.

Conflict within his family.

"Then Jesus entered a house, and again a crowd gathered, so that he and his disciples were not even able to eat. When his family heard about this, they went to take charge of him for they said, 'he is out of his mind." Mark 3:20-21. After recording Jesus' confrontation with the Pharisees, Mark writes; "Then Jesus' mother and brothers arrived. Standing outside, they sent someone in to call him. A crowd was sitting around him, and they told him 'Your mother and brothers are outside looking for you.' 'Who are my mother and brothers?' He asked. Then he looked at those seated in a circle around him and said. 'Here are my mother and brothers! Whoever does God's will is my brother and sister and mother." Mark 3:31-35

What Mark says here is very interesting and can teach us many lessons.

Jesus is not only facing opposition from the religious authorities, but he is also facing pressure from his family. His family wanted to control him. 'When his family heard about this, they went to take charge of him for they said, 'he is out of his mind."

Jesus' family thought he was "out of his mind." The idea behind the phrase for 'out of his mind' means to be out of position. They thought that Jesus had lost his way, and they may have felt embarrassed by him. Nazareth was about 30 miles from Capernaum so why did Jesus' family make such a long trip to seek Him out? Because they wanted to control him. The word used for 'Take charge of' is the Greek word Krateo. This is a very strong word, which means to seize or arrest. We are not told precisely why they took this very strong decision. It is possible that when His family heard the things being reported concerning what he was doing, they decided that Jesus must have lost contact with reality and so they rushed out to locate Him to reduce the shame of the both the family and the family name.

The arrival at the house.

When Jesus' family leave their home and arrive at the house where Jesus was staying. They sent someone in to tell him that they, his family wanted him outside. In response Jesus says ' 'Who are my mother and brothers?' He asked. Then he looked at those seated in a circle around him and said. 'Here are my mother and brothers! Whoever does God's will is my brother and sister and mother." In Matthew's gospel we read "He replied to him. Pointing to his disciples, he said, 'Here are my mother and my brothers. For whosoever does the will of my Father in heaven is my Brother and sister and brother."

To help us understand what Jesus meant when he said these words, we must keep in mind the whole context of this incident. Jesus was under great pressure, he had been accused of being demonised, and His family thought he was crazy, so he must have been feeling lonely and vulnerable.

The crowds around Jesus would have believed because of the importance of the family in that culture that family members have priority relationship over others. But instead of dropping everything and going out to see his family, Jesus gives a response that would have shocked all that were listening. There are a number of lessons we need to learn from Jesus' response.

Jesus draws a contrast between his natural family and his Spiritual family. There are two ways we can relate to Jesus, we either relate to him naturally or spiritually. When we relate to Jesus at a natural level, we will be like his family, we will try and control him, we will expect him to come to us, our communication with him will be all about us trying to control and manipulate him. On the other hand, to relate to Jesus spiritually is to have a submissive heart that bows to the will of his Father

Enjoying God as father and doing his will increases a person capacity to relate to Jesus. We cannot live in devotion to the Father and not have intimacy with Jesus.

The family of God is made up of those who live under the same authority as Jesus Christ. We cannot be committed to Jesus until we are as committed as Jesus is.

Jesus finds his fellowship and acceptance with those who do the will of his father. At this vulnerable time in Jesus' life, he needed those who would understand and accept him. Only those who have a heart set on doing the Fathers will can accept Jesus and what he stands for.

As Jesus pointed out to those seated around him, He was expressing his hearts desire for real intimacy with those who are called disciples. The attitude of Jesus' family towards him at this time should causes us to ask some very important questions. Why do people try to control others? What does the controls of others look like? Mark 3:20-21 has a lot to teach us about how as people, we can fall into the trap of trying to control others, or even try to control God

When we set out to control others it is always a deliberate wilful choice we make. It is never a spontaneous thing; it is not the result of a character defect. But the result of deliberate responsible choice. Jesus’ family "went to take charge of him."

father help me understand and accept the members of my family

title: The family of Jesus part 1

And the teachers of the law who came down from Jerusalem said, “He is possessed by Beelzebul! If a kingdom is divided against itself, that kingdom cannot stand. If a house is divided against itself, that house cannot stand. html:
Those who are trying to control others are usually living at a 'distance' from those they are trying to control. As we have said Jesus' family were living in Nazareth, while Jesus was living in Capernaum about thirty mile away, two days walk. But the distance may not be geographical, but it will always be emotional. Sometimes when relationships are not fulfilling their emotional expectations, people can take on the role of a controller in order to medicate the sense of loss they are feeling,

Those who want to control others will avoid meaningful communication. When Jesus family came looking for him it is interesting what they did not do. They did not wait until he was finished before sending someone else in to get him. There was a sense of panic, they needed to act immediately, and they could not wait. They did not ask him questions or give him a chance to explain himself. They made a number of assumptions, and decided how they would deal with him based on these assumptions.

Those who want to control others are often motivated by second hand knowledge not on facts. We are told, "When they heard about this they went to take charge of him." They did not feel a need to go out and gather the facts for themselves. When our hearts are set on controlling others we will not take the time to gather the facts for ourselves; we will use any excuse to justify our need to control.

Our desire to control others means that we perceive the other person as the problem. They came to Jesus with an attitude that said, "we need to change or fix you" You are the problem not us. This same attitude prevents us from seeing our own problems.

When we feel a need to control others we build our relationships on merit rather than on grace. The desire that Jesus' family had to take charge of him indicated that for him to retain their acceptance, then he would have to change the way he was behaving.

Those who have a desire to control others will use others to hide their inability to communicate. When the family of Jesus came to the house where Jesus was we read a very interesting thing. 'Standing outside, they sent someone in to call him. A crowd was sitting around him, and they told him 'Your mother and brothers are outside looking for you.' They refused to go in for themselves, they sent someone else in. Was Jesus so unapproachable? Lepers, tax collectors, broken people wanting to be freed from their sin felt they could approach. But his own family members, who felt a sense of shame about him, had not the freedom to go to him

The person who desires to control others will hide behind other in order to justify their lack of communication. Luke implies that they were unable to get to Jesus because of the crowd. But surely the person they sent in was able to get through the crowd. It is easy to hide behind the crowd, it is easy to hide behind others in an attempt to conceal the desire to control,

Father show me if I am controlling

When Jesus was a boy of 12 years old, his mother and father had to come looking for him; 'When they found Him Jesus said to them "Didn't you know I had to be in my Father's house?" but they did not understand what he was saying to them." Luke 2:49-50

At the wedding in Cana we read "When the wine was gone, Jesus' mother said to him. ‘They have no more wine." "Dear woman, why do you involve me?" Jesus said. "My time has not yet come." John 2:34.

19:26-27

It had been a long time since Mary had prayed "l m the Lord's servant. May it be to me as you have said." Jesus was now thirty years old, she would have been in her mid forties, and Joseph was probably dead. How could she let him go? She needed him. Bible in a year: 1Samuel 14:43-17:25
title: The family of Jesus part 2
study_refs: Those who try to control others are usually trying to hide their own insecurities. When they heard what Jesus was doing they felt threatened and vulnerable, so in an attempt to hide these insecurities they thought if they could bring Jesus under their control then they could prevent him from doing all this stuff that was concerning the religious authorities. The purpose of controlling others is always to make us feel better.

html:
At that time the disciples came to Jesus and asked, “Who, then, is the greatest in the kingdom of heaven?”He called a little child to him, and placed the child among them And he said “Truly I tell you, unless you change and become like little children, you will never enter the kingdom of heaven. Therefore, whoever takes the lowly position of this child is the greatest in the kingdom of heaven And whoever welcomes one such child in my name welcomes me “If anyone causes one of these little ones—those who believe in me—to stumble, it would be better for them to have a large millstone hung around their neck and to be drowned in the depths of the sea Woe to the world because of the things that cause people to stumble! Such things must come, but woe to the person through whom they come! If your hand or your foot causes you to stumble, cut it off and throw it away. It is better for you to enter life maimed or crippled than to have two hands or two feet and be thrown into eternal fire And if your eye causes you to stumble, gouge it out and throw it away. It is better for you to enter life with one eye than to have two eyes and be thrown into the fire of hell. They came to Capernaum. When he was in the house, he asked them “What were you arguing about on the road?” But they kept quiet because on the way they had argued about who was the greatest. Sitting down, Jesus called the Twelve and said“ Anyone who wants to be first must be the very last, and the servant of all.”He took a little child whom he placed among them. Taking the child in his arms, he said to them, Whoever welcomes one of these little children in my name welcomes me; and whoever welcomes me does not welcome me but the one who sent me.”

Jesus and his disciples were sitting in a home in Capernaum. They were probably relaxed and beginning to unwind after walking all day, when Jesus drops a bombshell in the form of a question. 'What were you arguing about on the road?' If we were to compare Marks account with Matthew's there seems to be a slight difference. Matthew says, 'At that time the disciples came to Jesus and asked, Who is the greatest in the kingdom of heaven?' We know from Mark's account that the apostles remained silent when Jesus asked the question. So how do we reconcile these two accounts? This whole incident was initiated by Jesus, the disciples did not want to bring this issue out in the open, and it was after some probing by Jesus that they were prepared to be honest about it. That is why Matthew simply records it as the disciples asking a question

The question Jesus asked


There are a number of lessons we can learn from how Jesus dealt with the disciples at this time. In order to address the problem Jesus asked the question. The word Mark uses for ask is a very strong word eperotao which means either(a) an especially earnest enquiry, (b) an insistent pressing interrogation, or (c) enquiry with a certain legal formality about it. This was more than just an off the cuff question, but a serious interrogation. It was as if Jesus was demanding an answer off them. Sometimes we need to push people in order to get out what is really in their hearts. Jesus knew that this was such an important issue and if he didn't bring it to the surface then the disciples would not be able to do the ministry they had been called to.

Jesus waited until they were 'in the house' before he began to address the problem. He didn't do it in public, but waited until he was alone with them. It was in 'the house' a place where they felt secure and at home. Jesus was very direct in his questioning 'What were you arguing about?' This was more than a friendly chat. Dialogizomai the word for arguing, is from a word that can refer to simple conversation or to argument and dispute among parties. Here all the disciples were party to a dispute. The imperfect tense tells us that they kept on arguing. Over and over again they kept picking at each other. We have recorded three different occasions when the disciples argue about which of them would be the greatest --here in Mark 9:46-48, just before Jesus' final ministry in Jerusalem (Matthew 20:20-28), and, amazingly, at the Last Supper (Luke 22:24). The disciples had an ongoing problem with who was the greatest, so Jesus needed to address

The response of the disciples

Mark tells us 'But they kept quiet.' This response reminds me of a typical teenager, when asked a question simply grunts, or says 'l don't know.' The question Jesus asked made them feel uncomfortable, so instead of being honest and open, they remained silent. The disciples understand the inappropriateness of their conversation. While Jesus was telling them to expect his betrayal and death, they were thinking about their place in the kingdom.


This was a moment of high drama as an awkward silence descended upon the room. I can just imagine the disciples looking at each other, as Jesus patiently waits for an answer. The word Mark uses for 'kept quiet' is the Greek word siopao, which carries the idea of involuntary silence. I think this is important, while the disciples were arguing as they were going along the road they had some sense of control over where the debate was going, they could steer it, each one could manipulate it to their own advantage. But now Jesus had entered the debate, not as a contributor but as a one that would take control, revealing the real issues. This in turn means that the disciples had no more control over where the debate was going, so in their vulnerability they retreat into silence, no longer wishing to express their opinion. The fact that the silence was involuntary indicates that the disciple were no longer in charge.

Father forgive me for the times I have given you the silent treatment

If your hand or your foot causes you to stumble, cut it off and throw it away. It is better for you to enter life with one eye than to have two eyes and be thrown into the fire of hell.

They came to Capernaum. When he was in the house, he asked them “What were you arguing about on the road?” But they kept quiet because on the way they had argued about who was the greatest. Sitting down, Jesus called the Twelve and said “Anyone who wants to be first must be the very last, and the servant of all.”He took a little child whom he placed among them. Taking the child in his arms, he said to them, Whoever welcomes one of these little children in my name welcomes me; and whoever welcomes me does not welcome me but the one who sent me.”

Questions about the question

Mark does not tell us what they were arguing about, but Matthew and Luke do. After some probing by Jesus the disciples eventually ask 'Which of them would be the greatest?' We want to ask two questions about the disciples' request. [al What! does it mean? [b] Why did they ask it?

What does it mean?

When the disciples eventually asked Jesus 'Which of them would be the greatest?' this was much more than a question, it was a window into their hearts and minds. It revealed an identity problem. These men believed that a person's identify, value and worth is evaluated by how 'great' they are. They are looking for significance and importance, they long for position and prestige, and they wanted to know who was 'top dog.' Because of their insecurity they were caught up in the pursuit of status, the acclaim of others, always comparing themselves with others. The insecurity that drove this question would make them a liability to the kingdom of God, it would cause them to abuse positions of power and manipulate others to meet their egotistical desires, so Jesus needed to address Why did they ask it at this time? To help us understand why the question 'Who is the greatest?' became a significant issue in the hearts of the disciples at this time we need to look at some of the background.

They used wrong categories to evaluate each other. The question they asked indicates that they viewed each other in terms of 'failure' or 'success.' Peter, James and John had been up the mountain where they saw Jesus transfigured. The other nine were at the foot of the mountain trying to hide their inability to cast out a demon by arguing with the teachers of the law. Where the three on the mountain more successful or more spiritual than the other nine? Did they start to compare themselves with one another?

Seeing people in terms of 'failure' or 'success' is like using a ruler to measure water, or scales to measure distance, it doesn't work. 'Failure' and 'success' evaluations will encourage shame or pride, two negative and dangerous emotions. The question 'Who is the greatest?' means that we have become judges of others, determining their worth in the light of how we see ourselves. They avoided listening to what Jesus had to say by becoming self obsessed. When we look at the question 'Who is the greatest?' in its immediate context it is very frightening. Look at Mark 9:30-32 'They left that place and passed through Galilee. Jesus did not want anyone to know where they were, because he was teaching his disciples. He said to them. 'The Son of man is going to be betrayed into the hands of men. They will kill him and after three days he will rise again, but they did not understand what he meant and were afraid to ask him about it.'

This is the second and shortest of three passion announcements in this Gospel (see 8:31, 10:33-34). The important thing for us to notice that the disciples 'did not understand what he meant and was afraid to ask him about it.' The refusal to accept and the inability to understand Jesus' teaching about His cross encouraged the disciples to think egotistically. It is possible that the desire for greatness was a reaction to the cross and a diversionary device to prevent them from thinking about it.

Father change my understanding of greatness

html:
At that time the disciples came to Jesus and asked, “Who, then, is the greatest in the kingdom of heaven?”He called a little child to him, and placed the child among them And he said “Truly I tell you, unless you change and become like little children, you will never enter the kingdom of heaven. Therefore, whoever takes the lowly position of this child is the greatest in the kingdom of heaven And whoever welcomes one such child in my name welcomes me “If anyone causes one of these little ones—those who believe in me—to stumble, it would be better for them to have a large millstone hung around their neck and to be drowned in the depths of the sea Woe to the world because of the things that cause people to stumble! Such things must come, but woe to the person through whom they come! If your hand or your foot causes you to stumble, cut it off and throw it away. It is better for you to enter life maimed or crippled than to have two hands or two feet and be thrown into eternal fire And if your eye causes you to stumble, gouge it out and throw it away. It is better for you to enter life with one eye than to have two eyes and be thrown into the fire of hell. They came to Capernaum. When he was in the house, he asked them “What were you arguing about on the road?” But they kept quiet because on the way they had argued about who was the greatest. Sitting down, Jesus called the Twelve and said“ Anyone who wants to be first must be the very last, and the servant of all.”He took a little child whom he placed among them. Taking the child in his arms, he said to them, Whoever welcomes one of these little children in my name welcomes me; and whoever welcomes me does not welcome me but the one who sent me.”

A visible lesson.

To help them understand true greatness; Jesus gave his disciples two examples of greatness.

The Servant

Mark reads, 'Sitting down Jesus called the twelve and said. 'If anyone wants to be first he must be the very last and the servant of all.' The truly great person is a diakonos -- a deacon a servant, a person who spends his/her day taking care of other people. 'diakonos' which refers to one who runs errands and is synonymous with 'attendant' or 'waiter.' Look carefully at what Jesus says here, 'the servant of all.' Think about that, there is nobody unworthy of being served by us. I think that is mind blowing. Diakonos is a humble role, and sometime we wonder whether Jesus is serious when he says that the servant is great, but we have seen evidence that he is. Servant-people like the Mother Theresa, inspire great affection and wield great influence. They not only relieve the suffering of those whom they touch directly, but they also inspire greatness in people whom they have never met. Their witness draws people to Christ and Christian service.


But what kind of person would struggle with taking on the role of a servant? Someone, who is insecure, someone whose focus is getting his or her own needs met, someone who is not free in the inside. Our inability to express the attitude of a servant indicates that we don't really understand what it means to be a Christian. Having the heart of a servant is not a luxury that can be done without, but an essential requirement for life.

The Child

Matthew 18:2-3 tells 'He called a little child and had him stand among them. And he said. ‘Unless you change and become like little children you will never enter the kingdom of heaven. Therefore whoever humbles himself like this child is the greatest in the kingdom of heaven.' Many people read these words and jump to wrong conclusions. Their thinking is something like. 'We need to be as innocent as little children if we are going to be great in the kingdom of heaven.' This understanding is wrong.

The Jewish Scriptures do not support the argument that children were perceived as being innocent. Psalm 51:5 says 'Surely I was sinful at birth sinful from the time my mother conceived me.' The Rabbi's taught that a person could sin even before they were born. On one occasion the disciples asked Jesus 'Rabbi who sinned this man or his parents that he was born blind? They taught that a baby could sin in the womb.

Once innocence is lost, it is lost, and to ask a sinful grown man to become innocent again is asking the impossible.

So in what way do we need to become like little children?

In the first-century Mediterranean culture, children were treated as property; they were possessions belonging to their fathers. 'Parents are right to ignore the child's point of view and to disregard the child's feelings.' (Malina, 55). 'Children owe their lives to the parents, a debt that they can never adequately repay.' (153). Children had no power, no privilege, and no prosperity. They lived only through the good will and care provided to them by others. The New Interpreter's Bible said that the child in this society was a 'non-person' and was 'socially invisible' and, it would be unusual for a child to be regularly in the company of Jesus and his disciples (637)

So when Jesus says to us to become like little children he is saying 'l want you to be vulnerable and dependable so you can grow in your capacity to receive love.' Little children have this natural ability to receive love from others, and give love to others. In Marks account we are told that Jesus took the child in his arms. Intimacy with Jesus is only possible if we are open or humble enough to receive love. But why do we as adults find it so difficult to receive love? Because of our lack of humility. The Greek word Matthew uses in 18:3 for humbles is tapeinoo, which in it's strongest form, means 'to humiliate.' If children were full of pride and weren't willing to humiliate themselves they'd never learn to walk or talk. What makes a child get up and try again after they've had a clumsy fall, is it not the love and encouragement of others? So it is in the Christian life. Humility of heart makes us sensitive and open to the love of God, and that is true greatness.

Father may I have a child like capacity to receive your love.

Such things must come, but woe to the person through whom they come! If your hand or your foot causes you to stumble, cut it off and throw it away. It is better for you to enter life maimed or crippled than to have two hands or two feet and be thrown into eternal fire And if your eye causes you to stumble, gouge it out and throw it away. It is better for you to enter life with one eye than to have two eyes and be thrown into the fire of hell. They came to Capernaum. When he was in the house, he asked them “What were you arguing about on the road?” But they kept quiet because on the way they had argued about who was the greatest. Sitting down, Jesus called the Twelve and said“ Anyone who wants to be first must be the very last, and the servant of all.”He took a little child whom he placed among them. Taking the child in his arms, he said to them, Whoever welcomes one of these little children in my name welcomes me; and whoever welcomes me does not welcome me but the one who sent me.”

'The Little ones.'

Many bible scholars believe that Jesus is referring to children when he speaks of the 'little ones' in Matthew 18:6, so they apply this passage as to how we should treat young children. I think to apply this to young children is a secondary application, not it's primary application. Jesus was not thinking about children's ministry, or children per-say when he spoke these words, rather he was continuing to address the issues of the disciples pursuit for greatness. The ‘little ones’ in this context are anyone who suffers because of the pursuit of greatness by an other. In verses 5-11 Jesus describes the opposite heart attitude to what the disciples expressed when they asked the question. 'Who is the greatest?' With this in mind then


How do we avoid the self-seeking attitudes of the disciples?

We need to receive with the right attitude. What did Jesus have in mind when he was speaking about receiving people? In the New Testament there are two different words for receive. The most common Greek word is lambano, receive, here having the meaning 'take into one's possession, to acquire.' Archelaus went to Rome to receive his appointment as king over the opposition of his subjects who had also appealed to Rome. The word Jesus uses in this context is dechomai. It is used in the Greek as a term for those in love or an intimate embrace. Jesus was speaking of warmth here, an embracing and friendly compassion from the heart.

What kind of person would be unable to embrace another? What kind of person couldn't show this kind a warm authentic welcome? Someone whose heart was set on their own agenda, someone whose focus was on themselves.

How we treat Jesus is seen in how we treat people. 'And whoever welcomes a little child like this in my name welcomes me.' The kind of relationship we have with Jesus is seen in the kind of relationships we have with those around us. If we are loving and kind to people, then that is an indication that we are expressing love to Jesus. If we are cold and distant from people that is an indication that we are cold and distant towards Jesus. We cannot be one way towards people and another way towards God.

We must receive people in Jesus' name. In the bible a person's name was more than a title, it was an expression of their characters, so to receive someone in Jesus' name is to receive someone as an expression of the character of Jesus. So our hearts and arms are open to all as an expression of the reality of Jesus.

Jesus' warning!!

Before we look at this warning, there are a number of things we need to notice.

Jesus is alone with his disciples when he spoke these words. He was still in the house in Capernaum dealing with the sinful attitudes of his disciples. It would be very easy for some to use these verses as a means of not taking responsibility for their own sin. Although Jesus talks about others causing 'little ones to sin' he is not in any way taking responsibility from the 'little one's' for their own sinful behaviour. 'But if anyone causes one of these little ones who believe in me to sin, it would be better for him to have a large millstone hung around his neck and be drowned in the depth of the sea.'

What do we need to learn from this verse.

We are a)) people of influence, irrespective of our personality type, our abilities and our opportunities. We all have some kind of influence on others. The word Jesus uses to describe the process of causing someone to sin is an interesting one in the Greek language skandalon. It actually started out to be a word that describes the part on a trap that you would use to put the bait. In fishing, it would be the fishing hook. In a mousetrap, it would be the little tab that sticks up where you put the cheese on. Some older versions translated the word stumbling block. Jesus is saying that every time someone is wrongly influenced by us leading him or her to sin, it is as if we have set a trap for them. The sin that Jesus is referring to is very specific to this context, however this specific sin is the motive or the source of all other sin. So what specific sin is Jesus alluding to in verse 6? I think Jesus is talking about any sin that robs a person of their childlike vulnerability and dependence. When we become independent, ceasing to appreciate and enjoy the father's love we automatically veer towards sinful habits in order to find life and love. When people begin to look for life and love through pursuing sinful habits, it is because they have been robbed of freedom. The sin that Jesus speak of here always robs people of freedom; they are caught -in a trap; a skandalon.

Every time we encourage some to move away from grace, and begin to teach legalism, we are becoming a stumbling block to others. It is the responsibility of every Christian leader to fight to maintain people's freedom in Christ. Jesus continues in v.6b by saying 'It would be better for him to have a large millstone hung around his neck and to be drowned in the depth of the sea.' The type of 'millstone' to which Jesus referred was the large stone that required a donkey or ox to turn. It usually weighed several hundred pounds. Romans sometimes practised this form of execution. Jesus is implying that we would be better dead, than be the cause of someone loosing their freedom and their intimate relationship with God. Imagine the shock that came over the disciples when they heard this. In their dispute over whom was the 'greatest' they had just caused each other to sin or stumble by inciting envy, jealousy and anger. Jesus is like a good parent that says; 'l don't mind what you do to me, but dear help you if you hurt one of my children.'

We need to take a step back and evaluate our lives and ministry in the light of this verse. We need to ask what kind of influence we are. We will be judged for our influence before we will be judged for our deeds. To be passive, our inactivity does not mean that you are not some kind of influence. Not to be lovingly involved with encouragement and affirmation in the life of others is to be stumbling stone. Do people know and love Jesus more because they have met us.

Father may my life be a continual godly influence

Such things must come, but woe to the person through whom they come! If your hand or your foot causes you to stumble, cut it off and throw it away. It is better for you to enter life maimed or crippled than to have two hands or two feet and be thrown into eternal fire And if your eye causes you to stumble, gouge it out and throw it away. It is better for you to enter life with one eye than to have two eyes and be thrown into the fire of hell. They came to Capernaum. When he was in the house, he asked them “What were you arguing about on the road?” But they kept quiet because on the way they had argued about who was the greatest. Sitting down, Jesus called the Twelve and said“ Anyone who wants to be first must be the very last, and the servant of all.”He took a little child whom he placed among them. Taking the child in his arms, he said to them, Whoever welcomes one of these little children in my name welcomes me; and whoever welcomes me does not welcome me but the one who sent me.”

The expectation of Jesus.

In verses Matthew 18:7-9 Jesus explains how we can avoid becoming a stumbling block or a skandalon to others.

Realise that we live in a fallen world. 'Woe to the world because of the things that cause people to sin. Such things must come but woe to the man through whom they come.' Jesus was a realist and he understood that we living in a fallen world, a world that is opposed to God. Having said that, Jesus goes on to talk to the disciples about how they must act towards their own sin, especially because they live in a fallen world.

Living in a fallen world will not justify the sinful behaviour of the Christian. If we are the wrong kind of influence on people, causing them to be entrapped in some kind of sinful habit, we cannot blame our circumstances, or the world in which we live. Those who are not free themselves will lead others into sin and bondage. Twice in these verses Jesus uses the phrase 'causes you to sin' this is the same word skandalon. In other words, if you are trapped yourself, it won't belong before you will start trapping others. We must treat our own sin more seriously than anyone else's sin. 'If your hand or foot causes you to sin, cut it off and throw it away and if your eye causes you to sin gouge it out and throw it away.' Jesus is saying, be decisive and if need be, be desperate to cut sinful habits out of your life.

Now there is a problem we need to address. Maiming yourself will not make you less sinful, because how we deal with our sin is a matter of our hearts. But if we have a right heart attitude towards our sin, then we will go to desperate steps to be free from it. The words that Jesus spoke here was not only extreme hyperbole but they have some historical background

In 2 Maccabees 6-7 the story is told of the martyrdom of the elderly scribe Eleazar and the Jewish mother and her seven sons. Though facing torture and death, Eleazar refuses to renounce his faith, even to pretend to do so, "lest many of the young should suppose that Eleazar in his 90th year has gone over to an alien religion, and through my pretence, for the sake of living a brief moment longer, they should be led astray because of me" (2 Macc 6:24-25; cf. 4 Macc 6:12-23). In other words, Eleazar refuses to set a poor example and so become a stumbling-block for the Jewish youth of his day. In the vivid expansion of this story found in 4 Maccabees, Eleazar tells his tormentors, "I will not transgress the sacred oaths of my ancestors concerning the keeping of the Law, not even if you gouge out my eyes and burn my entrails" (4 Macc 5:30). So also in the case of the mother and her seven sons. Because they refuse to eat pork, they too face torture and death. The first son has his tongue cut out and his hands and feet cut off (2 Macc7:4). His brother tells the tyrant Antiochus, "Gladly, for the sake of God, we let our bodily members be mutilated" (4 Macc 10:20).

Thus, Jesus' graphic descriptions are not only hyperbolic, they also call to mind the heroes of the faith, who by their devotion to the Law of God set an example for others to follow. They were willing to give up life and limb, rather than lapse into apostasy or lead others into apostasy. As far as Jesus was concerned, his followers could not be any less committed. The fight against our own sin is really a fight for real life. As we deal ruthlessly with our own sin Jesus says ‘we will enter into life.’ As we deal with our own sin, we discover that we enter into the life that God has for us. This does not mean that we become legalistic and self-righteous. Rather we realise that the sin we so often resort to in order to find life, is the biggest threat to real life.

If we are 'entering into life' if we are dealing honestly with our own sin, if we respond with rigour to remove the things that facilitate our sin, then we will be less likely to become a stumbling block to others.

If we are 'entering into life' if we are dealing honestly with our own sin, if we respond with rigour to remove the things that facilitate our sin, then we will be less likely to become a stumbling block to others. We never intend to become stumbling block or a hindrance to others, but we will be by default, if we are not rigorous in confronting our own sin.

Father teach me to hate my sin more than anybody else's sin
