study_refs: Matthew 18v1-9. Mark 9v33-37.

html:
Some of what we will cover in this section we have mentioned before. But is worth repeating.

What does it mean for us to be Children of God?

What does son-ship look like?

How should we as Children of God think and act?

What kind of relationship does God as our father wants to have with us?

The temptation of Jesus is a blue print for son-ship.

Most of the personal issues we face as people are rooted in our lack of understanding our identity as children of God. Often our hearts are flooded with insecurities, fears and anxieties. We struggle to accept who we are, longing to be someone else. For many Christians ‘Child of God’ is more a title than an experience, it is more of a theological concept than a dynamic reality. The most important and significant thing about any Christian is that they are a Child of God, this status is more important than their marriage, ministry, vocation, achievements or any other thing they may value highly.

The basis of son-ship is knowing that you are truly loved.

Before we look in depth at the temptation that Jesus faced in the wilderness we need to look at how His father prepared Jesus for this ordeal, and how the father planned it. When Jesus was being baptised, a voice spoke from Heaven saying “This is my Son, whom I love; with him I am well pleased.” If Jesus was going to come through the ordeal of the temptation then he would need to know deep within his heart that he was loved by his father. The love of the father, gave Jesus the security and wisdom he needed to discern and refuse the temptations that Satan would put before him. When Jesus heard his father declaring his love for him from heaven what was his father communicating? The word used for love is agapetos which means to be ultimately concerned for the welfare of the one who is loved. It carries the idea of being loved deeply. Often we can have a superficial response to the deep love of God. We don’t let it penetrate our lives or marinate our hearts. At this point in Jesus’ life, Jesus had done no teaching, nor done any miracles; he just lived a quiet life with his family in Nazareth. Yet he was completely loved by his father in heaven.

As Jesus endured the hunger and desolation of the wilderness he was acutely aware that he was loved.

God not only prepared Jesus to face the gruelling ordeal of the wilderness. But He led him into it. All three synoptic gospels give us the context of Jesus’ temptation. Matthew says. “Then Jesus was led by the Spirit into the desert.” In Luke we read “Jesus full of the Holy Spirit, returned from the Jordan and was led by the Spirit in the desert.” Mark also gives a shorter account of Jesus’ Temptation, Mark says “At once the Spirit sent him out into the desert.” There is a lot in this which we will look at later, but for now notice that Jesus was loved then he was led. That is the way it needs to be. It is very easy for any of us to become stressed or anxious about God’s leading in our lives. We wonder what God wants us to do with our lives, we want some divine plan written out in the sky, but it will never happen. I think it is far more important to know God’s love than to know God’s plans. And maybe all the stress and anxiety around the whole area of Gods will for our lives is the result of us not having a deep enough experience of His love.

Father thank you that it is the knowledge of your love that enables me to face the difficulties of life

Bible in a year: 2 Samuel 3:1-6:11
title: temptation of Jesus part 1
study_refs: In some ways the temptation of Jesus in the wilderness is a revelation of the attitudes and mindset of a son of God.

html:
Being a child of God means that you have a continual, developing need of the presence and work of the Spirit in your life. We fall into a trap of thinking that the work of the Spirit in my life is for those times when I am ‘serving God,’ or ‘helping others.’ But no matter who or where we are, our need of the developing work of the Spirit in our hearts will never diminish or decrease. It is the work and ways of the Holy Spirit in us that distinguishes us as children of God.

We are told that the Spirit led Jesus into the wilderness. The word translated ‘sent’ in Mark 1:12 is a very weak translation. The word he uses for “Sent” is an extremely strong word, it literally means to drive out your enemies. In the LXX [LXX stands for the Septuagint which is the Greek translation of the Hebrew scriptures.] the word is used in the context where an enemy, frustrating or standing in the way of God’s fulfilling his purpose for his chosen people, is ‘cast out’ by God, so that God’s purposes may be fulfilled. See Exodus 23:30 Deuteronomy 33:27ff.

The word was mostly used in the New Testament in relation to casting out demons. The word expresses passion of God’s Ekballo, or God’s resistance to evil. God was sending his son into the wilderness with a strong passion so he could confront and unmask the evil one.

It is interesting to note that the word Luke uses to describe the Spirit leading Jesus into the wilderness. The word almost means the complete opposite to Ekballo, it has the idea to carry, to bring, and to keep.

Protected by passion

On the one hand we have the Spirit driving Jesus into the wilderness, as an expression of God passion against evil; and on the other had we have the keeping power of the Spirit leading Jesus. This is not a contradiction, nor is it even two opposites. God’s passion and God’s protection always go together.

This was so important for Jesus at this time and so encouraging. Think of the lessons he was learning.

Spiritual warfare was God Initiative. Jesus was about to enter into a ministry which would be marked with confrontation with the powers of darkness. When he would feel under pressure with his back against the wall he would know that Spiritual warfare would be initiated not by Satan but by his Father. (It is interesting to note that in the four exorcisms that Mark covers in detail Jesus always goes to where the demon is, the demon doesn’t go to Him.)

The Father did not lead Jesus into Spiritual warfare until Jesus was assured of His fathers love. Feeling secure in the father’s love is an essential to coping with spiritual warfare. Because Jesus was feeling secure in his father’s love he was able to handle the temptations of Satan.

We need to make a comment about how some people understand the temptation of Jesus in light of his Baptism. Many people see the Temptation of Jesus as a reaction of Satan to what Jesus’ Father said to him when he was baptized. This in turn has lead to some people creating a “cause and effect theology” which says something like. “I must be doing something right because Satan is attacking me.” They believe that the blessing of God makes them more open to Satan’s attacks. This is both dangerous and inconsistent with scripture.

To think in these terms is to get your affirmation from Satan not from God.

The bible teaches that Spiritual warfare is not Satan reacting to God, but God pursuing Satan.

Father thank you that you are the one who initiates spiritual warfare

Bible in a year: 2 Samuel 6:12-10:19
title: Some of what we will cover in this section we have mentioned before. But is worth repeating.
study_refs: A requirement of son-ship is that you are continually under the influence and direction of the Holy Spirit.

html:
What is going on here? Why did the Spirit drag Jesus into this situation? What is the point of the temptations? Let’s see if we can work that one out!

Jesus was weary and weak; and the very first temptation thrown at Him was designed to take advantage of His diminished condition. But what we learn, of course, is that combating temptation is not a physical exercise, it is a spiritual exercise. Jesus gave every indication of being in a weakened state—a circumstance the devil intended to exploit, of course—but in reality, this battle would not be decided by physical endurance, but by spiritual truth and discipline.

Jesus had to learn to be a Son before he could fulfil his role of a servant. When a person has been called and commissioned by God to be involved in his service, it is very tempting to allow that call to redefine a person. So everything we do, or everything we become is filtered through a grid of service. God led his son into the wilderness so that he would learn that being a Son was much more important than being a servant. We can only be true servants when we learn to live as Sons. This has always been God’s way. Often in Christian circles there is a false belief that service is the most important thing about the Christian life, and that God measures our spiritual growth by how much service we do. Although service is an important expression of our love for God, it was never meant to be the purpose of salvation. God longs for the intimacy of his children before their service or ministry.

Father help me be more of a son than a servant.

Bible in a year: 2 Samuel 11-13
title: Some of what we will cover in this section we have mentioned before. But is worth repeating.
study_refs: Sometimes being led by the Spirit is uncomfortable.

The Spirit drove Jesus into the wilderness, into a place of desolation. Often we have romantic ideas as to what life would be like if we were led by the Spirit. But sometimes the Holy Spirit will take us to places where we would never choose for ourselves. This particular desert was known as Jeshimmon or "The Desolation." This stretch of land covers a 35 x 15 mile scarred plot of limestone waste between Jerusalem and the Dead Sea. It remains inhospitable and barren of sustaining human life. Yet, here is where Jesus is sent

html:
Some of what we will cover in this section we have mentioned before. But is worth repeating.

Often when it comes to the whole area of discipline we have muddled thinking. We are inclined to see discipline as a kind of punishment for sin. However in the mind of God, discipline is not a divine reaction to sin, but an aid to growth and maturity. As a son Jesus never sinned, but as a son he required discipline. The word discipline simply means to educate, to teach. The Greek word for discipline paideia was used to describe "the process of educating man into his true form, the real and genuine human nature." We often learn more about ourselves and life in time of testing and trial. The scriptures say,

Remember how the LORD your God led you all the way in the desert these forty years; to humble you and to test you in order to know what was in your heart, whether or not you would keep his commands. He humbled you, causing you to hunger and then feeding you with manna, which neither you nor your fathers had known, to teach you that man does not live on bread alone but on every word that comes from the mouth of the LORD. Your clothes did not wear out and your feet did not swell during these forty years. Know then in your heart that as a man disciplines his son, so the LORD your God disciplines you. Deuteronomy 8:2-5.

This passage must have been on the Lords mind, because twice he quotes from it as he refutes the temptation of Satan. Where the People of Israel failed in the wilderness, Jesus succeeded.

Jesus had a divinely appointed encounter in the wilderness. Jesus was learning that cost and suffering were part of the life he was called to. His wilderness, hunger, loneliness and temptation were consistent with the love and will of his Father.

“When the world did not end as Jesus himself had said it would, his followers stopped expecting so much from God or from themselves. They hung a wooden cross on the wall and settled back into their more or less comfortable routines, remembering their once passionate devotion to God the way they remembered the other enthusiasms of their youth. Little by little, Christians became devoted to their comforts instead: the soft couch, the flannel sheets, the leg of lamb roasted with rosemary. These things made them feel safe and cared for -- if not by God, then by themselves. They decided there was no contradiction between being comfortable and being Christian, and before long it was very hard to pick them out from the population at large. They no longer distinguished themselves by their bold love for one another. They did not get arrested for championing the poor. They blended in. They avoided extremes. They decided to be nice instead of holy, and God moaned out loud.” Barbara Brown Taylor. https://www.religion-online.org/article/settling-for-less-lk-41-13/. Accessed 03/05/25

Are you willing to go to the desert and stay as long as it takes for the Spirit to shape your heart, understanding and mission? Is the desert the part of your Christian life you are trying to avoid or ignore? The desert is a place where we become vulnerable and thus reliant on God. As Children of God we will all have times and experiences were we will feel totally vulnerable and exposed. In these times it is easy to feel abandoned by God, you may feel that your faith is fragile, but be assured God is with you and he will use the difficult times to win your heart.

Father thank you that the reason that you discipline me is because I am your child.

Bible in a year: 12 Samuel 14-16
title: temptation of Jesus part 4
study_refs: Jesus had to experience the discipline of a son so he could fulfil His fathers’ purposes for his life.

html:
Now if we read this passage carefully we will be surprised at the nature of the temptation that Satan put before Jesus. Satan came to Jesus intending to undermine Jesus’ identity. Twice he says to Jesus ‘If you are the Son of God.’ He wasn’t tempting Jesus to do some heinous sin. He wasn’t asking Jesus to steel, or murder, or commit adultery, or tell lies, but he was asking Jesus to deny is true identity by become something less than the Son of God. I think every temptation to sin can be traced back to Satan’s attempting to rob us from embracing our true identities as Children of God.

Irrespective of a person’s background, upbringing or pre-conversion lifestyle, an authentic experience of the gospel of grace will always be radical and transforming. In Jesus we receive a completely new and different identity. Identity leads to character, and character leads to biography, how we perceive and understand ourselves will determine the story our lives will tell. If you see yourself as a victim then you are going to live a selfish self-protecting lifestyle unable to trust others.

If you see yourself as “a sinner saved by grace,” there is no way you are going to live a life which enjoys God as your father. Often in Christian circles we are encouraged to beat ourselves up, to see ourselves as worthless people who God just about tolerates. Yet nothing could be further from the truth. If you see yourself as a sinner saved by grace then you haven’t really understood the gospel.

The ultimate goal of redemption is to mature us into children who have an ongoing enjoyment and experience of the fatherhood of God.

The primary goal of Satan for your life is to undermine the fact that you are a child of God, so he can rob you of your true identity. If he can prevent us from thinking and living as children of God, then all his other immoral and unspiritual desire for our lives have more of a chance of being realised. This strategy is extremely clever, for he knows that if we do not think and live as ‘Children of God’ then our relationship with God is not what it should be, or needs to be.


”This is the enemy’s one central purpose-to separate us from the Father. He uses neglect to whisper, ‘you see-no one cares, you’re not worth caring about.’ He uses a sudden loss of innocence to whisper, ‘This is a dangerous world, and you are alone. You’ve been abandoned.’ And this is why he makes it nearly impossible for us to know what Jesus knew, makes it so very, very hard to come to the father’s heart towards us.” https://islandtimes.org/loved-and-forgiven/#:~:text=This%20is%20the%20enemy's%20one,world%2C%20and%20you%20are%20alone. Accessed 03/05/2025

In some sense it is more difficult to be a Son than a Servant. A son is someone who understands the importance of complete dependence. Sometimes we get involved in the hectic activity of a servant to hide the fact that we are not enjoying our roles as sons.

The first temptation. ‘Turn these stones into bread!’

Matthew saw the sequence of the three temptations as significant in that they move to greater heights, from stones on ground level, to the pinnacle of the temple in Jerusalem, and finally to a mountain top from where all the kingdoms of the earth can be surveyed. The progression is not only in terms of greater physical height but also greater intensity and scope. The first temptation has to do with Jesus’ own need for food. The second temptation involves a wider circle in Jerusalem and the temple. And finally the third temptation takes in the whole world.

The First Temptations of Satan will cause us to believe that ‘my life depends on all my needs being met.’

Now we are never tempted to turn stone into bread because that would be impossible. But we are tempted into thinking that my hungers, my desires must be met. Jesus was in the wilderness for forty days and forty nights and he was hungry. There is nothing wrong with being hungry. Jesus’ hunger was a legitimate need, then he hears from Satan “Tell these stones to become bread.” Satan was saying “Jesus you need to have you physical needs met if you are going to survive. We may never be as hungry as Jesus was at this time, but we have all experienced times of need. It is often at times of need when Satan comes along and says. “If only you had bread to fill the hunger your life would be a whole lot better. Your life will never be complete until that hunger is filled, until that thirst is quenched.”

The mindset of a child of God is ‘It is better to be in need in the will of God than be satisfied outside the will of God.’ Sometimes God chooses not to meet our legitimate needs to see if we love him for himself. For the child of God, having their physical needs met is not essential for life.

So you have a legitimate need that God has chosen not to meet, and it hurts, it is painful, it is as legitimate as Jesus’ hunger. What do we do? Look at these words.

“That hollowness we sometimes feel is not a sign of something gone wrong. It is the holy of holies inside of us, the uncluttered throne room of the Lord our God. Nothing on earth can fill it, but that does not stop us from trying. Whenever we start feeling too empty inside, we stick our pacifiers into our mouths and suck for all we are worth. They do not nourish us, but at least they plug the hole.” Barbara Brown Taylor. https://www.religion-online.org/article/settling-for-less-lk-41-13/ accessed 03/05/2025

God does not show up, God does not come through for you, and you are diminishing in your own personal wilderness, and your hear the tempter saying, ‘Take control; take in charge of the situation. Meet your own needs.’

The first temptation causes us not to accept our humanity or our limitations. Satan was coming to Jesus and saying ‘use your power and authority to meet your own needs. In other words suspend your humanity for a few seconds so you can do a miracle in order to meet your own needs. Use you power in a self seeking way, and stop trusting your father. This was a temptation to rebellion, a temptation to impatience, a temptation to self will. It is a temptation to discontentment.

We have all got limitations, we all live with restrictions, and we have all been given divinely appointed boundaries. Like Jesus we must accept and embrace our humanity. We must try and live comfortably with the confines and inabilities God has placed in our lives. Living with inability, restrictions and limitations is not easy, especially when you are acutely aware of an unmet legitimate need. But the mindset of a Child of God is, “I accept and embrace my humanity with all it weakness and limitations, I can do this because God is my Father.’

There is a strong correlation between accepting who we are and accepting our God given limitations and boundaries. Often the struggle for self-acceptance is rooted in our inability to realize that we have limitations, we don’t have all the answers, we cant fix every problem, we don’t always know what to do in every situation. The mindset of a child of God is one that is able to live with God given restrictions and limitations.

The temptations of Satan will cause us to doubt the goodness of God. Jesus was hungry and his Father did not provide. Satan came along and said, “Does God really care?” Jesus if you father cared for you and loved you then surely he would provide bread for you. Sometimes in his love and great wisdom God decides not to meet our legitimate needs. Or to put it another way, sometimes our greatest need is not to have our most obvious needs met. Once we begin to doubt God’s love we are giving the evil one a foothold in our lives.

So how did Jesus respond to this temptation? Jesus said “Man does not live by bread alone, but on every word that comes from the mouth of God.” Jesus’ answer is incredible; it exposes the faulty thinking of the tempter.

Jesus is saying, man needs more than bread to live. We have been made by God and for God, so having our physical needs and desires met will never make us content. In saying that man does not live by bread alone, Jesus is saying that he really understands our humanity, he knows what makes humankind tick, he knows that mankind is more than a consumer. It is a satanic mindset that thinks that if I have all my physical hungers and desires met then I will be complete. Sometimes as children of God we are asked to carry a hunger, an unfulfilled desire, an unmet need. As children of God there is no guarantee that all our prayers will be answered the way we want them to be. We are not promised a panacea, or a life free from suffering and pain. Why? Because we need to learn to love God as children, we need to learn to love him unconditionally, to learn to love Him no matter what, learn to love Him for Himself, for that is the truest quality of a son, and the thing Satan fears most.

Trusting God is more important than food—more important, in fact, than anything else in life. That is the Saviour’s response. The devil is chiefly concerned with filling His empty stomach, but Jesus is chiefly concerned with trusting His Father who put Him in this spot in the first place. Dependence upon God in times of crisis is only possible if we are dependent when we are not in a crisis. One of the ways the children of God express their love for God is through depending on him. When do we not need God? Many Christians live like functional atheists, they have a rational belief in God, but in practice they are independent and live as if they were self-sufficient.

As children of God we are designed to live in fellowship with God. ‘Man does not live on bread alone, but on every word that comes from the mouth of God.’ Often people use Jesus’ use of the scriptures to encourage people to memorise scripture, memorising scripture is a good thing, and should be encouraged. However, quoting the bible in the face of severe temptation is not a magic formula that will cause the tempter to go away. What Jesus is doing here is expressing his understanding of essential principles that shaped his life and thinking. Many people can quote the bible. But quoting the bible, and being shaped by the bible are very different.

Father thank you that my identity is important to you..

Bible in a year: 2 Samuel 17-19
study_refs: The Nature of the temptations. Matthew 4 v 1-11.

html:
We must remember that when it comes to temptation, things are never as they seem, behind every temptation there is a hidden agenda, a devious subplot, an evil intention. We also need to remember that the goal of the evil one is to rob us of our identity; he wants us to cease to live as children of God.

5 Then the devil took him to the holy city and had him stand on the highest point of the temple. 6 “If you are the Son of God,” he said, “throw yourself down. For it is written: “‘He will command his angels concerning you, and they will lift you up in their hands, so that you will not strike your foot against a stone.’ Jesus answered him, “It is also written: ‘Do not put the Lord your God to the test.’

On the surface this may not appear to be a serious Temptation, I have never been tempted to climb up to the top of a tall building and jump, it has never crossed my mind. However, if we dig a bit deeper we will discover how subtle this temptation is. To help us understand this temptation let me mention a Jewish tradition that said that the Messiah would manifest himself by leaping from the pinnacle of the temple. Satan was tempting Jesus to make a name for himself. ‘Jesus do something spectacular and show the world how wonderful you really are.’ We live in a world were lonely empty people long for fame. Fame is the saddest substitute for genuineness in our society. Fame is adulation: admiration without love and commitment. Fame is achieved by jumping off temple walls while the crowd watches; it is a cheap alternative to the respect that can only be earned by consistently showing up in people's lives with humility, honestly and with compassion. In our culture fame comes with being the most outrageous; because people crave for attention and love they pursue fame and notoriety in order to fulfil the haunting emptiness they feel inside.

God’s work in our lives is more often a process than a spectacular event.

Remember the intention of Satan is to rob a person of their identity. When reputation becomes more important than identity then we will cease to be ourselves, and become the person others expect us to be. When reputation become more important than identity then will feel a greater need to jump off pinnacles, or jump through hoops, or do anything else we can in order to be noticed or appreciated. The security that children of God should be experience will protect them from needing the applause of the public. We have all been here at some stage in our lives, feeling that we must do certain things, or be a certain kind of person; we must prove ourselves in order to be accepted. We can even find spiritual reasons for jumping off our pinnacles. This temptation is anti-grace, because it basis acceptance on performance.

But I think there is an even more serious intention behind this second temptation. Satan wants to change how we relate to God. He wants us to view God as more of a ‘fixer’, than a father. Jesus you jump and God will deal with the consequences. Often as Christians we make unwise decisions, we make foolish choices, and we come to God with a demanding attitude, expecting him to clean up our mess. We don’t engage with God as a child would a loving, caring father, but we see him as someone is to keep our lives sweet and easy, like a genie in the bottle.


God takes His relationship with you far too seriously for you just to use him and view him as a fixer. God is not our lives janitor who is responsible for clearing up after us. Viewing God this way will diminish our ability to relate to him as his Children. Approaching God merely as a ‘fixer,’ or deliverer will prevent any desire or ability to cultivate intimacy with him.

Satan will always encourage us not to take responsibility for our self, and in turn this will cause us to become demanding of God, we will think in terms of God having to do certain things to prove his love. God if you love me you will catch me when I jump. And in getting caught in this temptation Satan has managed to trivialise our relationship with God. Being responsible is one of the ways we protect our identities as the children of God. So instead of blaming others for the mess our lives get in, and expecting God to clean up the mess we take full responsibility for our own lives and the condition of our hearts.

Satan wanted Jesus the seek vindication outside the purposes of God. Satan is saying, ‘Ok Jesus let us see how dependant you really are on your father, jump, take a dive and authenticate your claim.’ There is something in all of us that wants, to be vindicated; we want others to see that we are right. Often our identity and how we see ourselves are so entwined with our needing to be seen as being right.

As children of God, you don’t need to prove yourself; your identity, value or significance has nothing whatsoever to do with how others see you or think about you. “Will Jesus use God's means of ambiguity, obedience, obscurity, weakness to achieve His purposes or will He use unworthy means such as power and public acclaim to accomplish this noble end? E.R. Dalglish. Source unnown

Satan misuses the word of God, he quotes psalm 91:11-12. He uses the bible like a book of magic formula, he takes verses and miss applies them. God has promised to care and protect us as we try to live for him in our normal everyday lives, however, when we become unwise, and begin to misuse the word of God to justify our foolish choices, we will have to live with the consequences.

How did Jesus resist this temptation? Jesus once again quotes from the book of Deuteronomy 6:16. “Do not test the lord your God.” What is Jesus saying here? When Jesus quoted this verse he did not quote the last part of the verse. The whole verse reads “Do not test the Lord your God as you did in Massah. At Massah the people accused Moses and God of impotence and indifference. They said, “If you don’t take care of us as we expect, God, we are not going to follow you any more. You have to prove that you are God and that you care for us!” In other words, they challenged God’s power and His benevolence in spite of ample evidence to the contrary. Why did they do this? Because they believe God should act according to their will. They demonstrated that their faith depended entirely on what God would do for them, not on who God was. The test at Massah is a sign of rebellious disobedience, a refusal to accept the character of God as the basis of obedience.

We have all been to Massah; we have all been in the place where we make demands of God, where we think he owes us something, where we made a contractual agreement with Him. ‘God if you do this for me I will follow you.’ We all are guilty of coming to God with a demanding attitude asking that he prove himself. This kind of thinking is a satanic trap, entered into through our refusal to respond spiritually to temptation.

Father thank you that you don’t need to prove yourself to us.

Bible in a year: 2 Samuel 20:1-22:34
title: temptation of Jesus part 6
study_refs: The second temptation.

html:
Again this third temptation may seem a bit strange or even unrelated to our ever day living. I doubt any of us has ever faced a decision to become a king or not we have never been offered kingdoms in exchange for Satanic worship. However, if we dig beneath the surface we will discover that we are incline to think in ways that are similar to how the evil one thinks. For in his mind position of power and honour equals authority and influence. God the Father brought Jesus into a wilderness and Satan offers him the Kingdoms of the world. What a contrast, Satan is trying to bring Jesus out of the wilderness his Father has chosen for him.

Again, the devil took him to a very high mountain and showed him all the kingdoms of the world and their splendour. ‘All this I will give you’, he said, ‘if you will bow down and worship me.’ 1Jesus said to him, ‘Away from me, Satan!’ For it is written: 'Worship the Lord your God, and serve him only.'

The third temptation did not begin like the first two with the words, “If you are the Son of God ….” As we will see, the devil seems to have conceded for the moment that Jesus wanted to be an obedient son. So the thrust of the third temptation was this: What would Jesus the Son be willing to do to establish the Kingdom of God on earth?

This temptation exposes that the way the evil one thinks is completely opposite to the way of the kingdom of God. Satan believed that position equalled authority and influence. Satan was suggesting ‘Jesus here is a wonderful opportunity for you to make a difference to this evil corrupt world. Think of the changes you could make, the laws you could pass, the evil you could crush if you were king right here right now.’ So often we can fall into the same way of thinking, we believe if we were in a more important position, or a more prominent situation we would make some real and lasting change. If we were ‘king for the day,’ this would be a different world.

Listen to these verses. Matthew 20:25=28

Jesus called them together and said, “You know that the rulers of the Gentiles lord it over them, and their high officials exercise authority over them. Not so with you. Instead, whoever wants to become great among you must be your servant, and whoever wants to be first must be your slave— Just as the Son of Man did not come to be served, but to serve, and to give his life as a ransom for many.”

For Jesus the sphere of greatest influence was found in being a servant, and displaying a redeeming quality. We do not need to be in positions of prestige or authority to be an influence for God. Jesus knew that the way of servant hood would be the most effective way to win peoples hearts and love. That is why he said For it is written: 'Worship the Lord your God, and serve him only.'

The problem with us is we have a wrong understanding of authority. A person can be in a position of power and authority, but not be an influence of change and good. Many people in Christian circles hold positions of recognised authority, but their lives make no difference. In the New Testament the Greek word for authority is exousia which carries the idea of freedom or being free. In other words biblical authority and influence is expression of internal freedom. The greatest hindrance to real authority in a person is their lack of freedom. This causes us to ask the question, What are we slaves to?

Are we slaves to our pride? Do we have a desperate need for recognition? Do we need a kingdom to massage our egos and make us feel good about ourselves? Satan will never offer us all the kingdoms of the world, but he will offer us some kind of kingdom that will appeal to our bondage and pride. Are we slaves to our ministry. Some people in the Christian context suffer from ministry addiction, their value and significance is rooted in their ministry. Their ministry is their kingdom. It is a place where they serve themselves instead of serving God

There are thousands of things we can be slaves to, and our lack of freedom will mean that we will not be free enough to serve. Jesus came to earth to be a servant not a king because he knew that in the kingdom of God a servant is the person who has the most influence. When we are not free, and live in bondage to some negative power, we will be desperate for a position, a kingdom, and a crown.

Like the other temptations that Satan put before Jesus, there was more to this than what he is offering. He is offering Jesus a completely alternative way to live. He is offering Jesus an easier way to fulfil God’s purposes for his life. It was the will of the Father that Jesus would be King. See Psalm 24:7-10. Satan is saying ‘Jesus I am more than happy for you to be king of the whole earth, in fact you wont even have to suffer, all you have to do is stop living a life that is totally Father centred and bow and worship me.’

R.G.V. Tasker writes:

To escape the way of the cross by being disobedient to the vocation of the suffering Servant despised and rejected by men, upon whom was to be laid the iniquity of us all, was Jesus’ greatest and most persistent temptation… . Jesus was in effect tempted to subscribe to the diabolical doctrine that the end justifies the means; that, so long as He obtained universal sovereignty in the end, it mattered not how that sovereignty was reached….The Gospel According to St. Matthew (Grand Rapids, Michigan: Wm. B. Eerdmans p54

None of us like suffering, we go to great lengths theologically and practically to avoid it, so Satan appeals to our aversion to pain and suffering. Suggesting ‘You deserve a crown not a cross, a throne not thorns, a palace not pain, life not death. Surly this is want God wants for you. ’ We want pain free lives. In our thinking we do not have a contingency that will accommodate pain and suffering, we expect that our lives to be more about crowns than crosses.

Jesus would rather suffer and die to win peoples hearts than be a cold distant monarch who had no intimacy with them. Jesus would rather suffer and die so he could bring the power of redeeming love to the world than be a king that was able to control men’s behaviour or beliefs.

The thing that Satan fears most is the cross which symbolises the gospel. The crosses that we should be carrying are the ongoing expression of God’s redeeming work in the world. Our lives are meant to be instruments that God uses to display his redemptive love and grace to a dying world. Any refusal on our part to not take up our cross and cling to a crown of glory, position and prestige,, will have a dreadful effect t on the world in which we live. The evil one will appeal to our pride in order to prevent us from carrying our crosses for he knows that he has no power against the cross.

To carry you cross is to embrace a sacrificial life so you can express the same attitudes through living that Jesus expressed through dying.

Father help me through life displaying the same attitudes Jesus showed n his death

Bible in a year: 2Samuel 22::35-24:17
title: Temptation of Jesus part 7
study_refs: The third temptation

html:
Satan is trying to change the orientation of Jesus’ life by changing what he lived for, or to put it in biblical terms, Satan wanted to change the object of Jesus,’ worship. By bowing down to Satan Jesus would have been coming under his authority. Worship is the foundation on which you build your life. Now, notice we are not saying that worship should be the foundation but worship is the foundation on which you are building your life. We are all worshipping something. Every life here has something or someone at its centre that is worshipped. Now remember, the intention of Satan behind temptations is to rob us of our identity, to cause us to think, feel and live as people who have no life changing experience of God as our Father. So to accomplish this, he offers us an easier life so he can change what we worship. There are many subtle and discrete ways of bowing down to Satan and worshipping him, it is rarely an overt tangible act, and is usually expressed though idolatry.

What we worship is the thing that defines who we are and how we live. We serve what we worship. What we worship is the thing that reveals most about us, what you worship is what you serve. What you worship dictates the terms of your life. To worship is to give yourself to it. If we worship sex, we will run to sexual pleasure for comfort, significance and value, I won’t feel loved, value or complete without sex. If we worship power then we will have a desperate need to be in control, so you gossip or stab people in the back with cruel words so you can hold onto a position and power. If we worship money, then we will relate our significance and value to what we own and possess.

Here is the most crucial thing we are going to say. Our experience and enjoyment as children of God is totally dependant on our worship of God. Our identity as children of God has created within us an unceasing need to be worshippers of God. Satan knows that once we set our hearts on something else, once we cease to have a heart that recognises our need to worship God alone, then we will be open to his suggestions, his purposes and ways.

Jesus was offered all the kingdoms of the world, a crown without a cross, glory without pain, an inheritance without death, but he refused, because he wanted to worship and serve his father alone. Those who worship God from the heart will make a difference in the world in which they live.

Father thank you that to love and worship you is the greatest honour of our lives.

Bible in a year: 2
title: temptation of Jesus part 8
study_refs: Satan wanted Jesus to worship him.

html:
"Not everyone who says to me, 'Lord, Lord,' will enter the kingdom of heaven, but only he who does the will of my Father who is in heaven. Many will say to me on that day, Lord, did we not prophesy in your name, and in your name drive out demons and perform many miracles?' Then I will tell them plainly, 'I never knew you. Away from me, you evildoers!' Matthew 7:21-23.

Hiding behind spiritual language.

Look how these people addressed Jesus. “Lord, Lord.” The use of repetition in scripture usually is to bring forth emphasis. Repetition in addressing an other person is only used about fifteen times in the Bible and it always brings out personal intimacy. When the angel intervened and prevented Abraham from sacrificing Isaac, the Lord said "Abraham, Abraham." When God called Moses at the burning bush, He addressed him, "Moses, Moses." When one of Jesus' dear friends Mary, sat at His feet while her sister, another dear friend, toiled to prepare a meal and complained to the Lord, He responded "Martha, Martha, you are worried and upset about many things."

Before He was crucified, Jesus said to Peter, "Simon, Simon, Satan has asked to sift you (all of you) like wheat. But I have prayed for you.”

The way these people addressed Jesus at this time in Matthew 7 was consistent with how they always used spiritual language. Often people can develop a whole new sub-language in an attempt to hide what is really going on in their hearts. They way these people addressed Jesus had the appearance of intimacy, but in reality is was words without substance. Jesus was able to see past their words.

Father help me think about how I speak to you and not hide behind well worn spiritual language

Bible in a year: 1 Kings 2:19-4:19
title: Standing before Jesus part 1
study_refs: As Jesus concludes, the sermon on the mount he wants to speak to us about the kind of service that he rejects. Remembering that this is probably the first teaching that Jesus gave to his Disciples after he called them to be Apostles, it is important that these first Apostles understood that all service is not acceptable to him.

When Jesus began the Sermon on the Mount, he began by talking about Beatitude people, those who were broken and dependent solely upon him for life. Jesus concludes his sermon by describing those who have moved away from being broken dependant people, to those who are self-assured and self- sufficient. In Christian ministry it is very easy to make this shift and not even notice it. Sometimes our service is a waste of time, it has no value. It may appear to be successful or effective but success or effectiveness is not evidences of acceptance or approval by God.

html:
There is an important dynamic at work in this passage that we need to grasp if we are going to understand what Jesus is teaching here.

Jesus tells us "Many will say to me on that day Lord, did we not prophesy in your name, and in your name drive out demons and perform many miracles?' The reason why these people spoke about their ministry was because that what was in their hearts, and what they lived for. When we stand before Jesus, what we lived for will be revealed.

Many will say Lord, did we not prophesy in your name, and in your name drive out demons and perform many miracles?'

Others will say, ‘did we not raise a family in your name?’

‘Did we not work hard and earn money to provide the best materially for my family in your name?’ ‘Did we not serve the church in your name?’

In other words, what we lived for, and what we did not live for shall be revealed.

As we work through this passage, we need to put our life source into this verse, and realise that if we have the wrong life source, then the response of Jesus to us will be the same, ‘I do not know you.’

Being known by God is more important than serving God.

Being known by God is more important than service, even if we do it in Jesus' name.

Look how these people introduced themselves. They did not talk about their relationship with Jesus, they did not say how pleased they were to see the Lord. No their whole focus was on what they were doing, as if Jesus would be impressed. Their ministry had become their life.

We need to unpack what these people are saying when they say 'Lord, Lord, did we not prophesy in your name, and in your name drive out demons and perform many miracles.’ This was a spontaneous statement, which blows the whistle on where these people were. They could no longer hide. They could no longer hide what was really in their hearts. They were saying to Jesus “ For me life equals ministry.”

How they effected other people's lives was more important than what God was doing in their life.

Power for ministry was more important than intimacy in fellowship with God.

Spiritual maturity was measured by success in ministry rather than fruitful characters.

If we think that life is about what we do, then according to this passage we are false prophets; we are not the real thing. We conveniently associate a false prophet with what they teach. However, Jesus goes a lot deeper, he says that if anyone thinks that their life is more valuable, more useful, more important because of what they are doing, then they are false.

Jesus is very clear in what he says. ‘MANY will say to me on that day, did we not prophesy in your name and in your name drive out demons and perform many miracles.’ Most of us fall into this trap, we congratulate ourselves, and we think how wonderful we are, for we have served the Lord.

However, when we stand before the Lord, our service should be the last thing in our minds. Finding life and value in your service is an indication of being false. Finding life and value in anything, no matter how good or respectable it may be, is an indication of being false, according to this passage.

What kind of person would never say these words? What kind of person would never try and impress Jesus with their ministry? Someone who understands Kingdom life, a Beatitude person.

Often people fall into the trap of confusing ministry with being spiritual. They believe that because they are involved in some kind of ministry then they must be all right. Yet, many people get involved in a ministry to meet needs within them as they may have a hidden agenda. If you were to take their ministry away from them, their whole life would fall apart, for their ministry has taken the place of God in their lives.

Sometimes we need to ask God to take our ministry from us so that we can find Him. Those who have a fear of loosing their ministry, are the people who need to loose it.

Father Am I a false ‘prophet’ because of how I live?

html:
Jesus said "I will tell them plainly, 'I never knew you."

When Jesus said these words, He spoke words that sounded familiar to His Jewish audience – especially to the Rabbis and their students.

The Jewish writings tell us of a time when a student said or did something wrong, a very scholarly Rabbi said to him, "I never knew you." Upon saying that he did not speak to the student for a period of 30 days. He gave his student the silent treatment, the cold shoulder.

Now note what Jesus did not say. He didn’t say “you never knew me” but “I never knew you. Surely Jesus is God, surely he knows all things, so how can he say that He doesn’t know us?

When Jesus says ‘I will tell them plainly’, he uses a very strong word, which means to confess, or give thanks. What Jesus says here is an honest assessment of our relationship with him.

What does it mean for God not to know us?

Surely God is Omniscient, so how can he say to these people, “I never knew you.” He is not saying “I know nothing about you.” We all know certain things about others but we don’t know them in a personal way. Jesus is saying to these people who have found their life in their ministry, “You have never really opened up your heart to me.”

What kind of person finds it difficult to open up and become completely vulnerable? The person who is not broken, who is not poor in spirit. If God does not know us, it is our fault. We must be totally honest and open before him.

Lack of Worship prevents God from knowing us.

It is interesting to notice what these people did not say. There were no expressions of gratitude, joy or worship, and their whole emphasis was on what they were doing. ‘Did we not prophesy in your name and in your name drive out demons and perform many miracles,’

When the emphasis of our lives is on what we do, worship of the one true God becomes unlikely. These people were guilty of sanitised idolatry. When a person struggles with worship, that struggle is always the consequences of idolatry. If we have a heart that is looking for life outside of Jesus, we are going to find some reason to justify our lack of worship.

These people could not worship Jesus when they met him face to face, because they never worshipped him before they met him. If worship is not a priority in this life, then it will not be a priority in the 'next life.'

This passage redefines the will of God for our lives.

"Not everyone who says to me, 'Lord, Lord,' will enter the kingdom of heaven, but only he who does the will of my Father who is in heaven.”

God's will is that he knows us.

God's will is that worship must always take the priority over ministry.

God's will is that we remove all our sheep’s clothing.

God's will is that we be honest open people, with no hidden agenda.

How will Jesus respond to these people? He says that they are evildoers. What makes the deeds (both good and evil ones) "lawless" is not disobedience to some law (the Pharisees worked hard to obey all the laws), but what is in the heart i.e. the motivations for those actions. Ministry that is not a reflection of our fellowship with God is unacceptable, even if it appears to be effective.

Some questions we need to ask

Are we satisfied with our relationship with God in the present?

Are we looking for life in something, rather in having an intimate experience of God?

What idol has robbed us of our passion for God?

Has worship ceased to be a priority in our lives?

Can we identify some of the sheep’s clothing we have been wearing?

Some Practical steps we must take in order to open our lives up more to God.

We need to pray differently about ourselves. Can you identify an attitude or a motive in your heart you have never prayed about? We are inclined to pray about external things. God will only know us when we open our hearts to him.

Is there anything in your life that has become a source of life or identity? Maybe you think if I loose this ministry, or if I loose this job, or family, life for me would be pointless. We need God to change our attitudes to these things. When Jesus becomes our only reason for living, then we have the freedom to enjoy these other things.

We need God to teach us the importance of worship. False prophets cannot take the worship of Jesus seriously. If we do not understand the importance of worship, then we need to ask some serious questions about what is in our hearts

Father help me to do what I can so you can know me better. Bible in a year reading plan 1 Kings 7:40-9:9

html:
Before we look at the story let me give you some background.

1. This was at the time of the Passover. Passover was a very important time for Jerusalem. The population of the city was approximately 40,000, and because Passover was one of the major Jewish pilgrimages, during this festival the population would increase to about 240,000 people, six times its normal amount. There was great anticipation for those celebrating this festival, and the city would have been buzzing. There would have been a carnival feel of celebration in the air. People would have been very excited hoping for a Messiah to come and deliver them, especially at this time of passover when they were remembering how God had delivered their forefathers from Egypt. If ever there was a time that nationalistic fervour would be whipped up and the people tempted to rebel against their Roman masters, it would have been this week.

2. Also at this time there was an other official entry into Jerusalem. At this time Pilate came to town. The coming of a provincial governor often took on the trappings of a stately, if not royal, procession. He would have had an impressive entourage. The largest, most formidable group to travel with a governor would have been the soldiers under his command. It seems probable that both infantry and horsemen would have accompanied Pilate from Caesarea. And because of the massive increase in Jerusalem’s population during the festivals. These troops would have been used to put down previous disturbances, and would try to prevent further disturbances. It is likely that something in the order of one thousand troops would have been with Pilate.

3. Up to this point Jesus had refused to make a public deceleration of his Messiah-ship. Often in Mark’s Gospel when Jesus healed people he would tell them not to say to anyone. In Mark, Jesus never claims publicly to be the Messiah, and when people do recognize him as such, as in Peter’s great confession in Mark 8.29 “You are the Christ” or “You are the Messiah,” Jesus strictly charges them to tell no one about him. But now he wants people to see that he is the promised Messiah so he orchestrates this entry into Jerusalem to show them. This is the first time in Mark’s gospel that Jesus visited Jerusalem.

4. So Jesus sets the stage where he is going to reveal himself to the nation'

‘Jesus sent two of his disciples and saying to them, "Go into the village in front of you, and immediately as you enter it you will find a colt tied, on which no one has ever sat. Untie it and bring it. If anyone says to you, 'Why are you doing this?' say, 'The Lord has need of it and will send it back here immediately.'" And they went away and found a colt tied at a door outside in the street, and they untied it. And some of those standing there said to them, "What are you doing, untying the colt?"And they told them what Jesus had said, and they let them go.’ Mark 11:2-6

This was a very suggestive act, it was an act of great prophetic significance. The prophet Zechariah had prophesied that their king would come riding on the colt of a donkey. No one there would have missed the significance of what was happening. They would have been able to connect the dots between this prophet from Nazareth and the prophecy of Zechariah.

‘Rejoice greatly, O daughter of Zion! Shout aloud, O daughter of Jerusalem! Behold, your king is coming to you; righteous and having salvation is he, humble and mounted on a donkey, on a colt, the foal of a donkey.’ (Zechariah 9:9).

The crowds knew about this prophecy. Jesus is declaring himself to be Israel’s Messianic King. The crowds begin to respond with loud acclamations and the waving of palm branches. They want to welcome and honour their new king; they even take the words of Psalm 118 to their lips to praise and celebrate his coming:-

‘And many spread their cloaks on the road, and others spread leafy branches that they had cut from the fields. And those who went before and those who followed were shouting, “Hosanna! Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord! Blessed is the coming kingdom of our father David! Hosanna in the highest!” Mark 11:8-10.

The word ‘Hosanna’ literally means save us now. They were crying out for salvation.

But that is the Problem with the story of the ‘Triumphal Entry’ We have this picture in our minds of a great crowd celebrating Jesus’ entry into Jerusalem. In our understanding we become part of the crowd. Or put it an other way, it is so easy for us to get caught up in the celebrations of the crowd that we miss what the gospel writers want to teach us.

Father I confess it is so easy to be carried along by the shallowness of others

Untie it and bring it here. If anyone asks you, ‘Why are you doing this?’ say, ‘The Lord needs it and will send it back here shortly. ’”They went and found a colt outside in the street, tied at a doorway. As they untied it, some people standing there asked, “What are you doing, untying that colt?” They answered as Jesus had told them to, and the people let them go. When they brought the colt to Jesus and threw their cloaks over it, he sat on it. Many people spread their cloaks on the road, while others spread branches they had cut in the fields. Those who went ahead and those who followed shouted, “ Hosanna!” Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord!”“Blessed is the coming kingdom of our father David!”’Hosanna in the highest heaven!” Jesus entered Jerusalem and went into the temple courts. He looked around at everything, but since it was already late, he went out to Bethany with the Twelve.

‘ Triumphal Entry.’ This is a very well known story that takes place on ‘Palm Sunday,’ the Sunday before Good Friday. This Sunday which began the last week of Jesus’ life is mentioned in all four Gospels. (Matt 21:1ff.; Mark 11:1ff.; Luke 19:28ff.; John 12:12ff.) so it is obviously very significant.

html:
Palm Sunday is more about sorrow than joy.

I think that this may be one of the most tragic experiences in the life of Jesus, and caused him great pain and distress. Luke 19:41 tells us that as they got nearer to Jerusalem Jesus wept over it. The word wept klaio means to howl with sobbing and wailing. It was a word used to describe a loud expression of pain and sorrow. It was visible distress. This is the same word used in Luke 22:62 where it said, ‘Peter went out and wept bitterly.’

It is interesting that when we read about Jesus weeping at the grave of Lazarus the word used there carries the idea of a more muted expression of grief.

As Jesus looked over Jerusalem he was overwhelmed by the horror of what was going to happen there.

Stop and listen to the howling sobs of the Son of God

Through his tears he is saying,

If you had only recognized this day, and everything that was good for you! But now it’s too late. In the days ahead your enemies are going to bring up their heavy artillery and surround you, pressing in from every side. They’ll smash you and your babies on the pavement. Not one stone will be left intact. All this because you didn’t recognize and welcome God’s personal visit.” Luke 19:42 The Message

When Jesus said ’If you had only recognized this day, and everything that was good for you! But now it’s too late. These were more than Jesus reflecting on how his ministry in Jerusalem was not received, they were also a commentary on what was happening at that moment, he was grieving about an on going rejection, a rejection that looked like acceptance.

What the crowd was doing and what Jesus was saying did not add up. If you had been standing on some roof top in Jerusalem watching the procession you would of concluded that Jesus was loved, accepted and worshipped. This was an Isaiah 29:13 moment for Jesus. ‘The Lord says: “These people come near to me with their mouth
and honour me with their lips but their hearts are far from me. Their worship of me is based on merely human rules they have been taught.

If only the crowd had stopped and listened, if only they allowed their hearts to be touched by his heart, but they were too caught up in the moment. They were crying out ‘Hosanna’ save us NOW. NOW NOW save us NOW, as Jesus cried painful tears they remained oblivious to his heart. We will come back to this, but first let me ask this question.

‘Have you ever seen a man cry, a man break down in howling sobs. A dad, a husband, a leader. I don’t think it is something we can easily cope with. It almost feels inappropriate or even ‘wrong.’ we don’t like it, it make us feel uncomfortable and embarrassed. Like the crowd we would rather be ‘hosanna-ing.’ Save US NOW

2. Palm Sunday is about wrong expectations.

As the crowds of people welcomed Jesus with singing, palm branches and coats spread on the ground, they are pursuing their own agenda. They wanted a military Messiah, someone who would deliver from the oppression of Rome. They saw Jesus as a means to an end. As Jesus sobbed, as he drew near the city they were incapable of sharing his pain or feeling his grief. They were blinded and hardened by their own agenda. SAVE US NOW.

Sometimes we are not too different than is crowd. We can come to Jesus with our agenda, with our wants, with our desires. We may not be oppressed by a foreign occupying army, but more often than not all we want Jesus to do is to come and tidy up our lives, change our circumstances, and if he does, we would be willing to make him ‘King for the day.’

Paul talks in the book of Philippians, about the ‘fellowship of his sufferings.’ Part of what that means is we share the pain of his heart, we embrace his sorrow. We allow the sorrows of his heart to become contributing factors in defining our character’s our lifestyles and our purposes. For Jesus this entry into Jerusalem was entry ‘Into the valley of the shadow of death.’ The dark shadow of the cross could not be eradicated by the joyful cheers of the crowds. Three times Jesus had predicted his death, and this was part of the journey to the cross.

3. Psalm Sunday is about worship without devotion.

As the pilgrims made their way to Jerusalem for the passover, on their way they would sing Hallel psalms which were psalms 113-118. as they entered the gates Jerusalem they would sing:-

“Hosanna!”

“Blessed is he who comes in the name of the Lord!”

“Blessed is the coming kingdom of our father David!”

“Hosanna in the highest heaven!”

quoting Psalm 118:25-26

Psalm 118, a patriotic national hymn which celebrates the ancient victories of Israel over its enemies. The message of the psalm is straightforward. While Israel was surrounded by enemies as by a swarm of angry bees, God has delivered Israel from their wrath. The enemies relied on their own power, but Israel's king relied on God alone. Israel ought therefore to give thanks to God, because he is good and because his mercy has no end. When the choirs chant, "blessed is he that comes in the name of the Lord," they are welcoming a real conqueror, a Nelson or a Churchill not an itinerant preacher whose victories are spiritual and whose kingdom is heavenly.

Here is the point, they were using the language of worship without having a heart for worship. They recited the verses they always recited at this time. They politicized these verses believing that they promised military deliverance from the Roman empire. Look at how they address Jesus, the crowds welcome him as someone coming “in the name of the Lord” from Psalms 118: 25-16. They also praise the coming of the “kingdom of David,” which isn’t quite the same as the coming of the king. No one call him Messiah, Son of God or Son of Man, or any of the titles traditionally attributed to Jesus as Messiah.

At this time their praise of Jesus was an expression of their own agendas through the misuse of scripture. Someone has said, ‘The exuberant crowds are chanting the right psalm even though they are drawing the wrong conclusions from it.’

It is so easy to fall into the same kind of thinking, we often miss-quote scripture, taking it out of context, miss applying it and interpreting it to accommodate our agenda. Then we create a language or a way of speaking that can sound spiritual but is not rooted in truth. As these people quoted well known verse, they were expressing misunderstanding and a wrong view of Jesus rooted in their desire for transformed circumstances rather than transformed hearts.

4. Psalm Sunday was about symbolic submission not real surrender.

Mark tells us Many people spread their cloaks on the road, while others spread branches they had cut in the fields. Why would they spread their coats in the road? That was an old, ancient gesture, a custom that showed submission. “You can walk on me, you can step on me, I’m below your feet.” Kings were always elevated and people were under their feet. And this was a way to symbolize that. You can...you can walk all over me, I am submissive to you. Think about this, this act of ‘submission,’ was done in the heat of moment when an excited crowd was being motivated by a desire for a political revolution. This was not a thought through devotion where the cost had been counted, and a commitment of absolute surrender made no matter the outcome. This was just a symbolic submission that would lead to nothing because it was fake.

You could refer to this as tokenised devotion. It was not the real thing. Mark wants us to see the contrast between these people in the crowd and Bartimaeus in the previous chapter, in verse 50 we read ‘Throwing His cloak aside he jumped up and came to Jesus.’

‘Being a beggar was somewhat of an exclusive profession. Not everyone who wished was allowed to beg, for fear many lazy people would take up the vocation and impose on the truly needy. In order to beg, you had to obtain a license from the authorities. The right to beg publicly required a person to present himself to the authorities and provide documented proof of his or her disability. If the evidence satisfied the requirements to the satisfaction of the council, a begging license was issued. Bartimaeus had no doubt experienced this process. In the 1st century AD, licenses did not come in the form of a paper certificate or a letter delivered by email, which one could carry in a wallet or a pocket and present to authorities upon request. Rather, proof of your begging license was issued in the form of clothing. Specifically, a beggar was given a cloak of a certain style and colour, which distinguished him/her from other professions. These cloaks were every bit as distinctive and identifiable as the high priests’ linen garments and ephod. Whenever a beggar chose to attend to his occupation, he was required to don the beggar’s cloak to validate his legitimacy. When Bartimaeus cast aside his cloak, he gave up more than just his outer garment, he gave up his privilege of begging, which served as his life support system and his sole earning potential.’ Jeff Myers I am Ministries

The word Mark uses for Bartimaeus throwing his cloak in 10:50 is only found twice in the New Testament and —conveys the thought of a reckless rejection of what is valuable. When Bartimaeus threw away his coat he was making a radical statement, he was abandoning his old identity, he was throwing his source of security and life as he knew it away. Bartimaeus had dreamed and longed for a day like this a day when he could leave his old life behind. Unlike the crowds who throw their cloaks on the road he was an individual who was not influenced by others. He was determined to get to Jesus no matter what others thought or said. He grasped the radical nature of following Jesus.

Tokenised devotion lacks individualised expression, it is mass produced and is dependant on others and will never have the courage of throw away their old way of living Bartimaeus.

5. Palm Sunday is about an anticlimax

Look at what Mark says, ‘Jesus entered Jerusalem and went into the temple courts. He looked around at everything, but since it was already late, he went out to Bethany with the Twelve.’ This is one of those verses you could easily skim over. It is completely anticlimactic! Jesus is hailed as king by the crowds, so what does Jesus do? Nothing. He does not confront the Roman oppressors, He does not call people to arms. According to Mark all he does is look around the temple then goes to Bethany. The crowds have gone, the singing of ‘Hosanna’ has stopped, the palm branches lie discarded at the side of the road, and the cloaks have been lifted.

This anticlimactic end to palm Sunday was the most appropriate ending. You see if we are going to respond to Jesus in the way the crowds did, then we too will have an anticlimactic experience of Jesus. Let me ask you is your experience of Jesus an anticlimax? Is your Christian life an anticlimax? Are you the kind of person who does not get too excited about Him? You like the crowd are happy for Jesus to be your king for a day, king on your terms. If my relationship with Jesus is an anticlimax then it his never his fault, it is because I have tried to make him into the kind of king I want.

Stand beside Jesus in the temple as in the silence he looks around him. Remember the harrowing words. ‘If you had only recognized this day, and everything that was good for you! But now it’s too late. Luke19:42 message ‘But now it is too late.

‘He was silent and sad among this excited multitude, the marks of the tears He had wept over Jerusalem still on His cheek. It is not so, that an earthly King enters His City in triumph; not so, that the Messiah of Israel’s expectation would have gone into His Temple. He spake not, but only looked round about upon all things, as if to view the field on which He was to suffer and die. And now the shadows of evening were creeping up; and, weary and sad, He once more returned with the twelve disciples to the shelter and rest of Bethany. Albert Edersheim. "Life and Times of Jesus the Messiah".
Book 2 page 373

What kind of king do you want Jesus to be?

Father please break my heart with what breaks yours.

John 17 is the longest prayer of Jesus in the bible, which can be divided up into three parts. In verses 1-5 Jesus prays for himself, in verses 6-19 he prays for his disciples and in verses 20-26 he prays for the whole church. So we want to look at the first part of this prayer. Before we do that let me say that there are a number of reasons why we should consider these verses.

1. These verses capitulate Jesus’ relationship with his father. If we want to know what it really means to love God, then these verses will help us. As Jesus prays He reveals his heart, He shows us how He lived and what He lived for. Understanding these verses will help us understand Jesus. The things we pray about ourselves, say a lot about who we are and what we are living for.

2. These verses will help us to love the father in the same way Jesus did. I have been thinking a lot recently about how wonderful it would be if we could have the same intense fervent love for God our father that Jesus had.

Why are we so content with having an insipid, cold, predictable love for God? Why are we so conditioned to settle for a mediocre love for God? We should have a desire and an aspiration to love our Father God in the same way Jesus did. You may be thinking, that is impossible, Jesus was different, he was God. You’re right, but it was Jesus’ intense, fervent love for his father that made him human. Let me put this way. The more we love God, the more human we become. Not to love God with all our hearts is to deny who we really are, and a refusal to be who we should be.

3. These verses teach us the intimacy with God is not a luxury but an essential. Sadly so many people start their walk with Jesus well, but end badly, or not at all. They give up, they walk away, they jettison their faith, one of the reasons for this, [maybe the main reason.] is they are trying to live a Christian life devoid of any intimacy with God. Think about this, trying to survive as a Christian, and remaining faithful to God is impossible without intimacy. Take intimacy out of our relationship with God, and you end up reducing Christianity to a set of cerebral dogmas that only require unemotional compliance, not the pursuit of a loving relationship.

4. These verses teach us that Jesus’ life was defined by his relationship with his Father. At some level we choose what defines us. For example, I could choose to live as a disabled person. I could allow my disability to determine how I should view life, and control the choices I make. Or sometimes we can be defined by the hurts of the past, and we view ourselves as victims. Or we can be defined by our success. We may look at what we have achieved and develop a heart full of pride. But Jesus’ life teaches us, that healthy, wholesome humanity can only be defined in the context of the fatherhood of God. What I am trying to say is our relationship with God the Father should be the main thing that explains who we are. As Jesus’ relationship with his father was the explanation for his life, so it should be with us.

5. The relationship Jesus had with Father gives us a practical demonstration of ‘eternal life.’ Many people have a wrong understanding of eternal life, often eternal life is viewed as a life that lasts for eternity, which is just one aspect of it, and in some ways the least important aspect. Eternal life is knowing God in an intimate way. It is a quality of life that is the result of continually growing in your knowledge and experience of God.

Let us look at these verses and try and understand the relationship Jesus had with his Father.

Father give me a capacity to love you like Jesus. Bible in a year reading plan 1 Kings 14-17
