html:
‘Father the hour has come.’ Ten times in John’s gospel Jesus talks about his hour or time of his suffering. Five times he referred to His hour or His time as not having arrived (John 2:4; 7:6, 8, 30; 8:20). But when the cross was immediately ahead, Jesus said that the hour had come (John 12:23, 27; 13:1; 16:32,17:1

The word Jesus uses for hour is the Greek word ‘hora,’ which came from Horae who were the mythological gods of the seasons. So as a Son, Jesus related to his father by accepting and submitting to the seasons that God had ordained for his life. Father the hour has come. Sometimes in life we have difficult seasons, we have ‘hours’ that are painful and difficult, we have times that are confusing, where we think this could never be of God. We have times where we feel afraid, anxious and out of control. Like Jesus we need to say, ‘Father the hour has come,’ I am terrified, but the hour has come. I am anxious, but the hour has come. In raw vulnerability and in total submission Jesus embraces this ordained season of darkness. I love that Jesus viewed his passion event as an ‘hour,’ or a season, he knew that it was not going to last for ever, in viewing it has an ‘hour,’ he was expressing confidence in his father.

2. Jesus wanted his suffering to glorify his father.

In verse 1, we read ‘After Jesus said this, he looked toward heaven and prayed: “Father, the hour has come. Glorify your Son, that your Son may glorify you.’ Look at verses 4-5 ‘I have brought you glory on earth by finishing the work you gave me to do. And now, Father, glorify me in your presence with the glory I had with you before the world began.’’ To our ears this sounds a very strange, Jesus is asking his father to glorify Him. What is Jesus saying?

Jesus teaches us that a big factor in our relationship with the father is how we handle the inevitable sufferings of life.

In John’s gospel often Jesus’ death, burial and resurrection are referred to as his glory. We need to try and understand what Jesus is asking for.

The cross was an unlikely place to find glory. In that day, they didn’t make jewellery to display the cross attractively on a necklace. That would be like wearing a hangman’s noose around your neck in our day! The cross was a place of shame, humiliation, and the most excruciating form of execution known to man. So how could the cross be a place of glory?

When we think of glory our minds usually think in terms of beauty, splendour, brightness and at times glory is displayed that way. However, it literally means, “To be heavy or weighty” and has to do with “reputation, fame and prestige.”

So when Jesus was asking his Father to glorify him he was saying something like, ‘Father I am asking that through my arrest, trial, crucifixion, resurrection, ascension and coronation that people will see my true identify. In other words I am asking that despite the depth of the suffering I am going to face, may I suffer with integrity so that who I am will bring glory to you.

When Jesus prayed ‘‘Glorify your son’’, this was a prayer of resolution and commitment. It was an expression of a deep seated desire to glorify his father irrespective the circumstances. Sometimes God comes and rescues us from difficult circumstances, but most of the time he asks us to go through them so his glory can be seen through us. And this is what happened at the cross.

Father help me to recognise that sometimes to bring you glory can be a painful thing.

Bible in a year: 1 Kings 18:1-20:25
title: Jesus love for his father part 2
study_refs: 1. Jesus lived a life that was submitted to the timing of God.

html:
Let me try to explain the implications of what it means to be sent. Jesus never lived without a sense of direction or purposes, he never lived according to his own agenda, as the Son of God he teaches us that the life of a child of God is a ‘sent,’ life, a life of submission to God appointed commission and purpose.

Sometimes when we make our lives all about us and our agenda, the very act of selfish living robs us of significant purpose. As a Son, Jesus understood that his life was not about him, but his father

In John 20:21 Jesus said, ‘As the father sent me so I send you.’ in other words we have been called into a life that is submissive as Jesus.’ To live life as if we have not been sent is to miss an authentic spiritual vocation, reducing our lives to an economic cog in a commercial system, that only exists to generate income.

Do not misunderstand what is being said, we are not talking about being sent as if it were some big emotional experience where you are called to some ministry or mission location. Rather, being sent is the natural DNA of every child of God, it is living with a continual sense of God’s call upon your life irrespective of the circumstances you may find yourself. So if you are young or old, male or female, employed or retired, married or single, rich or poor, healthy or ill, if you are a child of God, then you have be sent into your world to continue the mission of Jesus.

Father may my life be a continuation of the life and ministry of Jesus. Bible in a year reading plan 1 Kings 20:26-22:36
title: Jesus love for his father part 3
study_refs: 3. Jesus lived with a sense of being sent.

In verse 3 we read ‘’Now this is eternal life: that they know you the only true God, and Jesus Christ, whom you have sent.’’ Six times in this chapter Jesus mentions the fact he has been sent. In fact thirty-eight times in John’s gospel we read about "him who sent me." It is a constant theme. The implications for Jesus are clear. He does not come as an independent agent with his own message. Being sent, meant that Jesus was submissive not independent. Jesus’ identity related to his awareness of being- sent.

html:
Let me try and explain what ‘authority’ means. Imagine I went into your home, I go and put the kettle on, I turn on the television, I sit down with a coffee, put my feet on the table, and as I watch TV I open the post. Then I go online and check your bank balance. The problem is, I don’t have the authority to do any of those things. Jesus was give authority or freedom to exercise his rule over all people, but he chose not to.

Notice that Jesus does not merely say that the Father gave Him authority only over His disciples and those who would later believe. Jesus says that the Father gave Him authority “over all humanity.” Jesus had full authority over Judas, over the high priests, and those Roman officials instrumental in His death. Jesus had complete authority over the hostile mob, who cried out, “Crucify! Crucify!

Do you remember when they came to arrest Him? John tells us 19;2‘Now Judas, who betrayed him, knew the place, because Jesus had often met there with his disciples. 3.So Judas came to the garden, guiding a detachment of soldiers and some officials from the chief priests and the Pharisees. They were carrying torches, lanterns and weapons. 4. Jesus, knowing all that was going to happen to him, went out and asked them, “Who is it you want?” 5. “Jesus of Nazareth,” they replied. “I am he,” Jesus said. (And Judas the traitor was standing there with them.) When Jesus said, “I am he,” they drew back and fell to the ground.’

Jesus had authority to defend himself, he could have destroyed his enemies, but instead he chooses the way of vulnerability, weakness and sacrifice. Father you have given me authority, but I am not going to use my authority to protect myself, but I am going to use it to bring eternal life to those you have given me.

Jesus showed his love for his father by embracing vulnerability and refusing to take control. He would only use his authority for the life giving benefit for others.

As children of God, we need to love our Father God by relinquishing our need to be in control, our need to protect ourselves, so we will have the authority or freedom to minister to others in ways that are effective.

5. As a Son, Jesus recognised the importance of accountability. Look at what Jesus says, ‘I have brought you glory on earth by finishing the work you gave me to do.’ Here Jesus is reporting back to his Father. Try and pick up the heart behind these words. ‘I have brought you glory on earth by finishing the work you gave me to do.’ For Jesus, genuine prayer contained an expression of accountability.

I find this very challenging, we express our love for the father by being conscientious about our accountability. We will never be able to pray these words that Jesus prayed, but we can make ourselves more accountable, we can critique our faithfulness. From time to time we need to come before God and by his grace evaluate where we are, where we have come from and where we are going. Why? That is what a child of God does, that is the kind of spiritual discipline that helps develop our relationship with the father.

6. As a son Jesus recognised that fellowship with the father was the best thing in his life. In verse 5 Jesus says these words. ‘And now, Father, glorify me in your presence with the glory I had with you before the world began.’ There is a lot of mystery in this verse, a lot that is outside our understanding. However, it is also one of the most incredible verses in the bible that can teach us about the essence of son-ship. Jesus was about to go to the cross, he was going to take away the sin of the world, he was going to defeat death and Satan. He was going to ascend on high, be given all authority in heaven and earth, and be crowned king of kings. But what brought him the greatest joy, the greatest glory can be summed up it two words, ‘with you.’ Those two simple words verbalised Jesus’ deepest desire, the longing of his heart.

What he would achieve through his death and resurrection would change heaven and earth, but they would not replace the ‘with you,’ of Jesus heart.

Like Jesus we need a ‘with you,’ desire, a ‘with you,’ motivation, a realisation that ‘with you,’ sums up what life is all about. Jesus died so we could have heart of a child of God, a heart that could continually say Father, the real glory of life is only found in your presence, with you.

Father thank you that two words sum the goal and purpose of all of life ‘with you.’

Bible in a year: 1
title: Jesus love for his father part 4
study_refs: Jesus did not use his authority to protect himself from vulnerability.

We read “Father, the time has come. Glorify your Son, so that your Son may glorify you—just as you have given him authority over all humanity, so that he may give eternal life to everyone you have given him” (verses 1b-2).

html:
Remember the first disciples were fishermen, who would have been able to relate to what Jesus is saying here. So when we read “Be Careful,” Jesus is wanting to get our attention, he is saying that if we do not hear what he is going to say, we are in danger of beaching our faith and shipwrecking our testimonies.

One of the ways we shipwreck our faith is sometimes we forget who we really are, we forget that we are children of the living God. Sometimes the storms of life cause us to hit the rocks and we feel that we have been ‘beached’ or stuck and we can’t move.

It is so easy to react to the storms of life by feeling that I must try harder, I must pray more, and I must read the bible more so I can get through this crisis. Spiritual disciplines are always a good thing. However in times of crisis we need more than spiritual disciplines and self effort, we need a fresh revelation of God.

Every commentary I have read on Matthew 6 believes that Jesus is teaching his disciples how to have healthy wholesome Christian disciplines. So he talks about how they should give to the poor, how they should pray and how they should fast. Jesus is teaching how to cultivate a proper heart attitude so they can participate in the natural spiritual requirements of a follower of Jesus. The more I have looked at the chapter, the more I am inclined to think that the giving, praying and fasting, which are extremely important, are secondary issues as far as Matthew 6 is concerned. There is a much more important issue that is not often picked up.

If you read the whole Sermon on the Mount especially chapter 6 you will find one word that is repeated 17 times, 11 of which are in chapter 6. That word is Father. The word father is found more in Matthew 6 than any other chapter in the bible therefore it has a lot to teach us about God as our father, and what it means to be his child.

It’s really important to God that we have a revelation of what it means to have Him as our father. How we live and what we live for is determined by our understanding of the fatherhood of God and the security it produces in our lives.

Father may my spiritual disciplines grow out of me knowing you as my Father.

Before we look at the chapter let us say a few things about God as our father.

In the Old Testament, the Jewish people had some kind of concept of God being a loving Father; however, this understanding of God was not often used. They saw God more as the Father of the nation, but not the individual.

When Jesus prayed he used the Aramaic word Abba for father. This is a word that was only used in the context of the home; it carried the idea on intimacy and respect. The Jews of Jesus’ time would have conversed in Aramaic or used Greek in everyday life, but they were trained to pray in classical Hebrew. It was similar to some Catholics who used to only pray in Latin. 1

They would recite words but not necessarily understand what they meant.

To this day a Jewish boy coming to Bar mitzvah learns the correct responses off by heart in Hebrew, even if he has no idea what he is saying. The Jewish people at the time of Christ would have had a concept of God as a loving and protective father. It was not a completely new or alien concept to them but they rarely addressed God as “Father” in prayer, which Jesus almost always did.

What happens if you were brought up in a family where the father figure was not very good, or may not have even been there? In Matthews Gospel fathers are portrayed in a primarily negative light, often being the ones that must be left behind by the sons who were chosen to follow the commands of the kingdom of heaven. For example, in 4:21–22 it is stated twice that the fishermen disciples leave their father in the midst of their joint work to follow Jesus, literally leaving their father holding the un-mended nets. See 10:21, 34-37. Matthew wants to draw a contrast between failing earthly fathers and a perfect heavenly father.

In biblical times a persons’ identity was always tied up with their father, e.g. when Jesus first met Simon He said, ‘You are Simon son of John you shall be called Peter’. John 1.42. The designation ‘son of’ was like our surnames, it helped distinguish people who had the same first name.

"You sum up the whole of New Testament teaching in a single phrase, if you speak of it as a revelation of the Fatherhood of the holy Creator. In the same way, you sum up the whole of New Testament religion if you describe it as the knowledge of God as one's Holy Father. If you want to judge how well a person understands Christianity, find out how much he makes of the thought of being God's child, and

having God as his Father. If this is not the thought that prompts and controls his worship and prayers and his whole outlook on life, it means that he does not understand Christianity very well at all." Citation: J. I. Packer, Knowing God, p. 182.

Father help me to totally embrace the identity 0f being your child,

Bible in a year: 2 Kings 8:16-10:24
title: knowing God as Father. part 1
study_refs: Matthew 6 begins with two very important words, which are “Be careful,’ It would be tempting to just read over these two words and miss what they are saying. “Be Careful is one word in the Greek, PROSECHO. It means to “be continually guarding against.” It has the idea of continually watching yourself. It was used to describe the skill of a sea captain who was able to bring his vessel into harbour without beaching it on the hidden shallow rocks.

html:
1. The spiritual disciplines we practice must be done in the context of enjoying God as father.

It is so easy to reduce our relationship with God into a religious box-ticking exercise where reputation becomes more important than intimacy. These people became religious, doing the right things in the wrong way, and gradually they became trapped in a need to get their affirmation and approval from others because they had not grasped that God is their father. When people loose their way spiritually it is not because they are bad people, but their waywardness can be traced back to the fact that they have ceased to believe that God is a loving father.

2. As God is our Father then we need to be real and honest before him.

When we are told that we should do our acts of righteousness in secret, it would be very easy to put a literal translation on this and think you should only pray in a private place, but that misses the point. Someone could do something in secret and still have a heart of a hypocrite. The secret refers to an attitude that is the antithesis to that of the hypocrite.

Sometimes we act before God in the same way the hypocrites comes before men. They acted in a certain way to get the approval and praise of men. They acted out of unreality in order to impress others; they were not being real or honest.

Sometimes that is how we come before God, we think we need to impress him, we need to win his approval, we are not honest about ourselves, and we have the same heart attitudes as the hypocrite who engages in a public performance. Our father is looking for authenticity not performance.

I should also mention that we all have a love inspired need from time to time to shut the door to the world and everything else and be alone with God because we love him and long to give ourselves to him.

3. As our Father, God wants to enrich our lives.

There is a very interesting play on words that we don’t pick up in our English translations. The word that is used for the reward that the hypocrite receives from other people, and the word for reward that is used to describe the father’s response to authentic spirituality are different. The reward of the hypocrite is misthos which was used to describe a persons wage or salary, it is the same word used to describe a hired hand. Misthos describes the heart of the taker. These people thought in terms of deserving something, they had a ‘You owe me’ mindset. They treat God like an employer who owes them something for their good behaviour.

The other word apodidomi reflects the heart of the giver. When the father rewards his children it is his deep expression of his pleasure and delight. The father finds great joy and satisfaction. The rewards that the father gives his children are to teach us about his heart. They are a deep expression of God’s satisfaction and pleasure. The reward is the Joy of God’s heart flowing over into ours. Knowing God as Father will change our understanding of prayer.

Bible in a year: 2 kings 10:25-14:10
study_refs: What can we learn about God being our Father from this chapter?

html:
As Christians, many of us want a faith that is simple and straightforward with no uncertainty, no confusion, no doubt, and few questions. We are the ‘sat- nav’ generation who want to be told how to reach our destination with the least amount of trouble or hardship. And we have adopted the same kind of ’sat nav’ attitude when it comes to our faith and our relationship with Jesus. We want the quickest and easiest way to spiritual maturity. We want God to tell us every turn we should make, we want our relationship with Jesus to be free from complications, conflict and confusion. Sometimes we want God to micro manage or lives, and levitate from the responsibility of having to make decisions. We want a faith that is neat and sorted, we want a life free from mystery and lost-ness. But, as we are going to see, sometimes our relationship with Jesus is all about uncertainty.

In Matthew 16 we read the back story of the Transfiguration of Jesus which is recorded in chapter 17:1-13. A number of things happen that help us understand the Transfiguration.

1. Peter confessed that Jesus was the Messiah the Son of the living God. This was one of the high points in the Gospel, Peter was beginning to understand who Jesus was. God the Father was teaching Peter. We will soon see that although Peter had received a revelation from God the Father about his Son Jesus, Peter’s understanding of Jesus was still incomplete.

2. Jesus began to teach the disciples about his suffering and death. Now here was the problem, in the mind of Peter and the other disciples there was no room for a suffering Messiah. Reading Matthew 16:22 you get the impression that Peter was angry with Jesus, The NLT reads ‘Peter took him aside and corrected him. ‘Heaven forbid, Lord. This will never happen to you.’ The word the NLT translates correct is epitimaō, it has a technical meaning: it is used in Greek religion of gaining control over a spirit or a demon. Robert Guelich (Word Biblical Commentary: Mark.)

3. Jesus had to rebuke Peter by referring to him as a stumbling block, who was under the influence of Satan. This must had been a real shock to Peter; although Peter may have meant well, Jesus could see the work of Satan behind what Peter had said.

4. Jesus begins not only to talk about his cross and his suffering, but he speaks also about their suffering and their cross. We are so familiar with these verses that they do not shock us the way they would have shocked these first disciples. These disciples had seen the Roman crosses on the side of the roads, they had seen the cruel death many had suffered. And now Jesus their Messiah wanted them to carry their cross, a symbol of defeat and shame? One of the songs we sing is ‘This is amazing grace.’ One of the lines is about Jesus bearing our cross, I understand the sentiment behind the words, but Jesus bore our sin so we could bear our cross. We have been designed to live cross shaped lives, it would be a cruel injustice for God to take our ‘cross’ from us.

5. Jesus promised that some of his disciples would see him come in glory in Matthew 16:27-28. There has been a lot of debate about these verses but I think they are referring to Jesus’ Transfiguration. They are also Jesus expressing a pastoral concern, this is how Jesus wanted to deal with the challenges that his disciples were facing regarding their relationship with him.

So as we go with Peter, James and John up to the mount of Transfiguration what can we learn?

Father help me accept the fact that your will for my life can or may produce some uncertainty Bible in a year reading plan 2 Kings 14:11-17:18
title: the transfiguration part 1
study_refs: While he was still speaking, a bright cloud covered them, and a voice from the cloud said,“This is my Son, whom I love; with him I am well pleased. Listen to him! When the disciples heard this, they fell face down to the ground, terrified. But Jesus came and touched them. “Get up, ”he said. “Don’t be afraid.” When they looked up, they saw no one except Jesus. As they were coming down the mountain, Jesus instructed them, “Don’t tell anyone what you have seen, until the Son of Man has been raised from the dead. ”The disciples asked him, “Why then do the teachers of the law say that Elijah must come first?” Jesus replied, “To be sure, Elijah comes and will restore all things. But I tell you, Elijah has already come and they did not recognize him, but have done to him everything they wished. In the same way the Son of Man is going to suffer at their hands.” Then the disciples understood that he was talking to them about John the Baptist.

html:
One of the problems we have is that we do not really have a category were Jesus neatly fits. We are always trying to domesticate Jesus, trying to deconstruct him, so he will fit better into our lives. Sometimes we want what I would call a ‘squeezed theology’, we want to make Him fit into the compartments we have constructed in our minds, keep Him contained and controlled. Then we see His glory, and our paper thin theology is shredded, and we discover that the Jesus we think we know is very different to the Jesus we need to know. And the Jesus we need to know is very different to the Jesus we want to know.

Matthew tells us that Jesus took and led Peter, James and John up a high mountain. The word he uses for took "paralambanō" means; to receive near, i.e. to associate with oneself in any familiar or intimate act. I think this tells us a lot about what is going on in the heart of Jesus; He knew that the best way to correct the misunderstanding of these disciples was through intimacy and a revelation of His glory. Intimacy with Jesus heals our theology

B. These men needed to develop a theology of suffering.

One of the most dangerous things about the church in our culture is that we have gone a long way to eradicate a theology of suffering. We have bought into the health, wealth and prosperity gospel in a very subliminal ways. We can often live with an undercurrent sense of entitlement, or deserving. We think that whole hearted commitment to Jesus means that God owes us, and our lives should be free from suffering. We would never verbalise this kind of thinking but perhaps in our hearts we hold onto verses 1Samuel 2:30 believing that if we live right then God owes us.

We need a theology of suffering that give us the freedom to take up our cross.

I have been thinking, is it possible to follow Jesus without a theology and expectation of suffering? I wonder if our lack of appreciation of the glory of Jesus is the reason why we find it difficult to accept or cope with suffering. We need to be people who grapple to grasp the glory of Jesus so we wont be defined by our suffering and pain. When our hearts are ripped open and broken, and our lives are in bits, the hardest thing to see, but the most necessary thing to see is the glory of Jesus.

C. We need to realise that suffering and glory are often the same thing. In our world view we often compartmentalise life, we have everything boxed up in neat compartments, especially when it comes to suffering and glory. Luke tells us that Moses and Elijah were speaking to Jesus about his death Luke 9:30. They were not talking about his victory, or his splendour, or his majesty, but his death. There are a number of verses in John 13 that clearly show the relationship between glory and suffering.

30. ‘As soon as Judas had taken the bread, he went out. And it was night. 31 When he was gone, Jesus said, “Now the Son of Man is glorified and God is glorified in him. 32 If God is glorified in him, God will glorify the Son in himself, and will glorify him at once.’

Jesus was able to discern the hand and purpose of his father in his suffering. Jesus understood that his suffering was not a random series of undetermined events that were unrelated to the purposes and plans of God. He knew that his suffering had a built-in capacity to bring his father glory as he went through it.

D. We need to leave the past behind by learning from it. Moses and Elijah appeared and began to talk to Jesus. Moses and Elijah were pinnacles of the Jewish faith and spirituality. Moses and Elijah were representatives of the law and the prophets. Moses and Elijah, who were taught to every good Jew, teaching them how to live and please God. But now it was time to listen to a new voice. Moses and Elijah appear on the mountain before the glory of Jesus to affirm that His voice, His suffering, His Glory is the way. Moses and Elijah had fulfilled their purposes, now it was time to listen to Jesus.

Father forgive me if my heart is set on ease and comfort, and I carry a subliminal sense of entitlement. Bible in a year reading plan 2 Kings 17:19-19:24

Day 112

the transfiguration part 3

In Jewish liturgy there was a daily prayer called the ‘Shema.’ It is the Hebrew word that begins the most important prayer in Judaism. It is found in Deuteronomy 6:4, which begins with the command to “Hear.” The whole Shema prayer, which includes verses 4-9, is spoken daily in the Jewish tradition: The word Shema means to listen. look at what Matthew says.

Peter said to Jesus, “Lord, it is good for us to be here. If you wish, I will put up three shelters—one for you, one for Moses and one for Elijah.” While he was still speaking, a bright cloud covered them, and a voice from the cloud said, “This is my Son, whom I love; with him I am well pleased. Listen to him!

A voice from heaven, the voice of God speaking directly to the three disciples telling them to listen to his Son. Sometimes we are unable to hear what Jesus is saying to us in the present because we are so accustomed to listening to the voices of the past. We suffer from nostalgic hearing. Although the voices of the past may have been good and important, it is time for a new listen to a new Shema. A new attentiveness to Jesus.

I find it remarkable that as the disciples came down the mountain with Jesus they got into a theological discussion about Elijah. God had just spoken to them from heaven, this is only the second time this had happened in hundreds of years. In the minds of these disciples, Jesus had to be at least equal to Moses an Elijah, but they had not really grasped his full identity. So the Father says ‘This is my Son whom I love, with him I am well pleased, listen to him.’ Here was God the father revealing his heart, talking about what was most important to him, sharing the pleasure he found in Jesus.

As Christians there can be times of uncertainty in our relationship with Jesus. Sometimes we have expectations that are not met, dreams that are dashed and hopes that feel shattered. The Jesus we thought we knew can be different to the Jesus we are experiencing. It is a times like this we need to experience a new intimacy, a new appreciation of his glory, a new realisation that the Jesus we love and worship is greater and bigger than we will ever know or understand.

Father I wish the voice of Jesus was the dominate voice in my life. Bible in a year reading plan 1Kingss 19:25-23:9

html:
All of us at one time or another will build walls in our hearts and minds that protect us from certain people. We develop a ‘them and us’ mindset that that keeps some people at arm’s length. The reasons for this may be to protect ourselves from the hurt that these people have caused us but a lot of the time it is because we have a prejudice against them for no real reason except that they are different from us. However, as we think about our ‘internal walls,’ there are a few things we need to be aware of.

Not all walls are wrong, some of them are essential. If you know from experience that someone is out to hurt you, to do you harm, or wants to destroy you, then you need to protect yourself; you need to contain that relationship with well-defined boundaries. You do not put yourself in a position where you know that a person is going to misuse, control or manipulate you.

However, not all walls are right.

On the other hand, we can build barriers that prevent us from becoming the people God longs for us to be. We create barriers in our minds against people who are different to us. Because we don’t understand them we think we need to protect ourselves from them. They are not like us and so we keep our distance and don’t get too close in-case... So, the person of a different sexual orientation, or the person who is of a different religion, or different ethnicity, or different ‘social class’ or the physically/mentally disabled, or those who are of a different political persuasion, ‘our Samaritan’, are all boxed up, put in a place outside our comfort zones, at a safe distance beyond our reach and all our walls are intact standing strong.

When Jesus told the Parable of the Good Samaritan he was giving us a very clear picture of what it means to love God whole heartily, he wanted to paint for us a picture as to what it means to live a justified life. To minister to people outside or boundaries and comfort zones.

Father help me to discern between the right and wrong walls in my life

study_refs: The story we call the Good Samaritan is one of the best-known stories in the bible, and therein lies a problem, it is well known but not very well understood. This is a story that explains what it means to really love God, and to love your neighbour as yourself. It is a story about crossing boundaries, about taking down walls, and going across borders to meet the needs of others. It is not simply about being kind or altruistic, which of course is a good thing, but it is far more radical than that, it is about being kind way beyond your comfort zone. It is about showing mercy to those we would consider at best our enemy, it is about bringing the love of God to those we would consider un-loveable.

html:
The teacher of the Law stands up and asks a question in order to test Jesus. ‘What must I do to inherit eternal life?’ This teacher of the law was a theologian who was extremely well read in the Old Testament scriptures, he was probably a Levite for at this time most of the teachers of the law were practising Levites that assisted the priests in the temple in Jerusalem. This teacher was not coming to Jesus out of good motives, he wanted to ‘test’ him, the same word that is used of Satan when he was trying to tempt Jesus in the wilderness.

The question he asked Jesus is very interesting for two reasons. He was asking what one thing could he do to inherit eternal life. He had no concept of grace, he did not understand unconditional love. He had a mindset that caused him to relate to God and to others on the basis of merit. Secondly to speak of doing in order to inherit is a paradox. An inheritance by nature is a gift.

In response to the man’s question Jesus asks him a question ‘How do you read it?’ I think this may have been a moment of pride for the teacher of the law. Here he is, a well-educated teacher going to teach Jesus the ‘uneducated’ rabbi from Galilee something.

In reply to Jesus the teacher of the law answers ‘Love the Lord your God with all your heart and with all your soul and all your strength and with all your mind, and your neighbour as yourself.’ What the teacher of the law says here is a combination of two verses from the Torah or the book of the law. Deut 6:5 and Lev 19:18.

In a second response to what the man said Jesus said ‘You have answered correctly, do this and you will live.’ This response of Jesus must have shocked the teacher of the law, it was as if Jesus was affirming him, not him affirming Jesus, he had suddenly become the pupil not the teacher,

Still not satisfied the Teacher of the law wanted to justify himself so he asks ‘who is my neighbour?” In asking this question the teacher of the law is trying to show that the restricted group of people he loved were the people God classified as neighbours. So, all good faithful Jews were the people who he loved. He just wanted Jesus to agree with him.

Thomas D Long wrote, ‘The lawyer is now in the dock; the lawyer is now the one on trial. No longer the solicitor prosecuting the case, the lawyer is now the accused defending his righteousness. So, the lawyer, now suddenly the defendant, seeks to do what every accused person desires. As Luke puts it, he wanted to “justify himself.” And so, he asks the one question he believes will do just that: “Who is my neighbour?” source unknown

He was not asking this particular question in order to understand more clearly who were his neighbours, but rather to ascertain the identity of those men and women he could eliminate from his love. Who could he safely put into the category of ‘non-neighbour’? Who could he cross off his list of ‘neighbours’? Where could he draw the line? He hoped that Jesus’ second answer to his question would confirm his own conviction that he was safe in this little circle of love, and bound for glory.’

So, in response to this second question Jesus tells this famous parable. But his answer does not put ‘neighbour,’ into a nice neat category, Jesus pulls down the internal wall of prejudice and inappropriate self-protection. Jesus redefines what it means to love God and love your neighbour.

Father use every circumstance of my life to grow my love for you and for others

Bible in a year: 1 Chronicles 1:17-3:9
title: The Good Samaritan part 2
study_refs: The context of the parable.

html:
The place in the Parable.

The story that Jesus told, took place on the road between Jerusalem and Jericho. It was a very dangerous road to walk along and was notorious in its day as one of those roads that you wouldn’t travel along on your own as you could easily have been hijacked or killed. Its nickname was the ‘Way of Blood!’

The people in the parable In the parable there are four main characters.

[a] The man who was robbed and attacked.

It would be very easy to be like the priest and Levite and walk passed this man. (There were two ways of identifying someone in those days, by the clothes they wore and by how they spoke. Clothing in the ancient world symbolized a person’s wealth, class or religion.) This man lay naked and silent, Jesus tells us he was ‘half dead,’ He had lost the marks of identity, because of the cruelty of others he was reduced to being a nobody.

[b] The Priest and the Levite.

Some people think that the reason that the Priest and the Levite didn't go and see the man is because they thought he was a corpse and they didn't want to come into contact with him because they would become defiled. This is unlikely for a few reasons. They were coming away from the Temple. If they were going up to the Temple to worship that might be a concern, because if you touch the corpse and became defiled, you wouldn't be able to enter the Temple. The text doesn't say they were concerned about purity.

If you look in the Bible, it shows us very clearly, for example in Deuteronomy 21, that even criminals, even people who had been executed, had to be buried. Ancient Jews had a very serious concern about the burial of the dead. Josephus tells us in one of his writings, that Jews were known for the fact that they did not leave the dead unburied. The rabbis taught that the burial of the dead was considered a very solemn commandment. Any Jew who came across a corpse that was unburied had an obligation to bury that person. In fact, the Mishnah, tells us that even if a high priest had encountered an unburied corpse, they would have an obligation to bury it, regardless of being defiled by the corpse. There was a widely-held view that Jews should help Jews.

Rabbi Ben Sirach in Sirach 12:1, 4-5a 6-7 wrote.
‘If you do a good turn, know for whom you are doing it…Give to a devout man, but do not go to the help of a sinner. Do good to a humble man, but give nothing to a godless one. Refuse him bread, do not give him any, or he might become stronger than you… For the Most High Himself detests sinners and will repay the wicked with vengeance. Give to a good man but do not go to the help of a sinner.’

The word passed by is used only here (Lk 10:31, 32) in the Bible and means to pass by on the opposite side, emphasizing that the priest and the Levite went out of their way! They made a deliberate choice to cross over on the other side of the road.

[c] The Samaritan.

Samaritans, were the descendants of pagan peoples who had come into the northern part of Israel at the time of the Assyrian exile. And although they worshipped the God of Israel, they were always regarded by Jews as kind of half pagan - half Israelite. Even worse, they had their own Temple up in the north at Mount Gerizim, they had their own priesthood, their own sacrifices, they were, in a sense, rivals with the Temple of Jerusalem and the Jews in the South. So, they were arch-enemies, and there was no love lost between them. They were regarded by many Jews as basically worse than pagans.

Father thank you that you teach us through this story the holding on to our religious traditions at the expense of not showing love to those in need is wrong..

Bible in a year: 1 Chronicles 3:10-6:30
title: The Good Samaritan part 3

html:
Lessons from the parable

Having a heart of compassion helps us to reach beyond our walls. When the Samaritan saw the man in the ditch he took pity on him. The word used for pity is the same word for compassion, splanghnizomi which means to be so disturbed and emotionally upset that you must act. Let’s us think again about our internal walls, the ones we use to protect our comfort zones from people who are different than us. The walls of prejudice, sectarianism, and pride. Compassion breaks down these barriers.

Compassion for others should redefine who we are. The title Good Samaritan was a paradox. As far as the Jewish people of Jesus’ day, to be good, and to be a Samaritan was impossible. But this Samaritan did not allow what others thought about him to define who he was or what he became.

Sometimes it is very difficult to break free from the negative things people believe and say about us, [and to us.] Sometimes we are brought up to believe the worse about ourselves. ‘I’m only a Samaritan what difference can I make?’ This man allowed compassion for others to shape who he was, he could have had a chip on his shoulder, he could have felt sorry for himself. He had lots of reasons not to get involved, but he couldn’t walk past. Maybe compassion for others is part of our healing process.

Compassion changed how he saw others. This Samaritan saw the same things the Priest and the Levite saw. But how he saw him was very different. He saw the man lying in the road as an opportunity for him to show mercy. One commentator pointed out that the word mercy in English is the translation of the Greek word eleos. This word has the same ultimate root as the old Greek word for oil, more precisely, olive oil; a substance which was used extensively as a soothing agent for bruises and minor wounds. The oil was poured onto the wound and gently massaged in, thus soothing, comforting and making whole the injured part. To show mercy entails being a soothing presence. Imagine having a life that is soothing to others.

Compassion needs to be practical and relevant, look at what the Samaritan did: -

a. He went to him

b. and bandaged his wounds,

c. pouring on oil and wine.

D. Then he put the man on his own donkey,

e. brought him to an inn

f. and took care of him. The next day he took out two denarii and gave them to the innkeeper.

g. Look after him,’ he said,

h. ‘and when I return, I will reimburse you for any extra expense you may have.

Compassion will cause you to have the heart of a servant. The elite and powerful sat on donkeys, the power-less servants lead them from the front. Through the simple act of placing the power-less man on the donkey, and then leading the donkey and the man to the inn, the Samaritan turned deeply-held expectations of power upside down.

Compassion is the evidence of loving your enemy, the Hebrew word for neighbour in Leviticus 19:18 is ren, the two letters that make up that word when you take the vowels out, are the same two letters for the Hebrew word for enemy. So, in other words, Hebrew, which is written with consonants and not any vowels, the two letters used for enemy and neighbour are the same two letters. So when the man asks the question, and Jesus says to him, what do you read in the law, there might be a deeper meaning, a more subtle meaning. Namely, Jesus is asking him, do you see in the law love your neighbour as yourself, or do you also see not just love your neighbour but love your enemy as yourself? In other words, there is a kind of a double meaning in the statement. Whether or not that's the case we don’t know, it's certainly clear that in Luke, Jesus is using the parable of the Good Samaritan, to teach, not just about love of neighbour and love of one's own friends and family, but love of strangers and even love of enemies. That's what mercy is all about.

Jesus concludes by asking. ‘Which of these three do you think was a neighbour to the man who fell into the hands of robbers?” Jesus is asking which of the three, Loves the Lord their God with all their heart and with all your soul and al their strength and with all their mind, and their neighbour as themselves?’ Which of the three displayed, evidence of eternal life? The Samaritan.

We live in a broken world, where a lot of humanity are living in a ditch where they are hurting and broken. The world needs to experience the radical nature of present day Samaritans who are overflowing with compassion and generosity. This will only be possible when we Love the Lord our God with all our heart and with all our soul and all our strength and with all our mind, and our neighbour as ourselves.’

Father may I be defined by compassion.

Bible in a year: 1 Chronicles 6:31-8:28
title: The Good Samaritan part 4

html:
A MASS DESERTION.

John 6 begins with many people following Jesus, in fact they are described as a great crowd, the Greek word polys [crowd] is used four times in this chapter to refer to the people, 6:2,5,60,66. We know that there were more than 5000 people as Jesus had fed them with two small fish and three barley loaves. Now there was a change in mood, a change in atmosphere, the crowds that thronged to Jesus and wanted to make him King, were now leaving in their droves. As people begin to leave, Jesus turns to the twelve with a very searching question. “You do not want to leave too, do you?” or 'Why don't you leave me and go with them too?' (This is a more accurate translation from the original text in Greek.) This is one of those questions that is too big for a yes or no answer. Jesus asked the question for their benefit in order that they would have an awareness of where they were in a spiritual sense. This is a defining question, a question that is usually asked through the crisis and pain of life.

Mostly this question comes to us in a non-verbal way. Life happens, disappointment comes, prayers remain unanswered, and expectations are unmet. Faithfulness feels unrewarded, and you think, is it worth it? You endeavour to live for God, without seeing much blessing or encouragement. So you think, ‘Can I keep going? Do I even want to keep going?’ The bread you hoped for never materialised, and like the crowds that deserted Jesus, you feel angry, confused and unsure. And you think it would be easier to walk than to stay.

So in the context of our life, with all its unsettling doubt, its messy uncertainty and fearful apprehension Jesus comes to us and asks “You don’t want to leave too do you? How we answer this question portrays how we see our future, our priorities, the direction of our lives, what we will be living for and how we are intending to live.

So how are we going to give a positive answer to this question? How is our faith going to survive the onslaught of pain, confusion and fear that are an inevitable part of this life? How can we determine to become people of long-term, life-long faithfulness? What can we do to prevent ourselves from becoming people who sacrifice integrity and commitment to Jesus so we can follow the crowds?

We need to relate to Jesus on the basis of appetite and hunger. We need to develop an attitude that constantly desires more of Him.

The crowds that deserted Jesus were called disciples, but they did not have the heart attitude of a disciple. The essence of authentic discipleship is desire or hunger. Listen to what Jesus had said:-

Jesus said to them, John 6:53-59 “I tell you the truth, unless you eat the flesh of the Son of Man and drink his blood, you have no life in you. Whoever eats my flesh and drinks my blood has eternal life, and I will raise them up at the last day. For my flesh is real food and my blood is real drink. Whoever eats my flesh and drinks my blood remains in me, and I in them. Just as the living Father sent me and I live because of the Father, so the one who feeds on me will live because of me. 5This is the bread that came down from heaven. Your forefathers ate manna and died, but whoever feeds on this bread will live forever.” He said this while teaching in the synagogue in Capernaum.

When those who were following Jesus at this time heard these words they were offended. John tells us that they found this a ‘hard’ teaching. The word "hard" in this context does not mean hard to understand but rather objectionable, offensive, or impossible to accept. What Jesus said to them was hard for them to swallow.

Father may I have a perpetual hunger for Jesus so I can follow him all my life.

Bible in a year: 1 Chronicles 8:29-11:12
title: ‘ you do not want to leave me too do you’ part 1
study_refs: The passage we are going to look at could be described as a spiritual catalyst, it is a passage that confronts and challenges. It is a passage that will cause us to draw a line in the sand; it will hopefully cause us to make some important decisions that will affect how we will choose to live the rest of our lives. It is a passage that won’t allow us to ignore it, or skim over it; it is like a filter that separates true discipleship from false discipleship.

html:
They had a too literal understanding of what Jesus was saying, which in turn made it more difficult for them to hunger after Him. They didn’t understand that what Jesus was talking about was that He was to be their only source of life in the spiritual sense. They needed to hunger for Him in an intimate way and their literal understanding of the passage wouldn’t allow them to do that.

Lack of hunger for Jesus will prevent genuine faithfulness. We come alive and animated as we learn how to hunger for the bread of life.

It is interesting how we encourage discipleship and evaluate faithfulness. We encourage people to read their bible, and pray every day, which are good things to do, but they are not real indicators of faithful living. They can become like a ‘box ticking’ exercise. The essence and motivation for faithful living is appetite and desire.

Appetite is an indication of what we love, it tells us what is really important to us. No one is void of appetite; we have all dedicated our hearts to hunger after something. Being nourished and satisfied by the reality of Jesus is to experience eternal life.

We need to understand that following Jesus is more about the quality of our lives not about what we do.

Those who are wanting to follow Jesus, wanting to be authentic disciples, desiring to love Jesus with all of their hearts for all of their lives, need to understand that the quality of their lives is dependent upon the work of the Holy Spirit within them. Achievement, success, ministry, reputation, occupation and social status are all good things, but none of them can give life or affect the value of someone’s life. So when Jesus says to these ‘run away,’ disciples. ‘The Spirit gives life; the flesh counts for nothing. The words I have spoken to you—they are full of the Spirit and life,’ Jesus was confronting their materialistic motivation that caused them to seek Jesus out after he had fed the multitudes on the previous day. These were disciples who wanted a conditional relationship with Jesus. They had a,, ‘Lord if you meet my needs I will follow you’ mindset.

Sometimes people base their relationship with Jesus on the hope that He will deal with their pain or problems. Life is messy, the bank account may be empty, a family member may be dying, or a marriage may be falling apart, so we see Jesus as the problem solver. We think that life equals my problems being solved, my bank account being full, my business being successful, my children being Christians, my health being good, and we could go on and on. All these things are good, but they cannot be, or were never meant to be a source of life

‘The Spirit gives life,’ are some of the most important words you are ever going to hear. We have all thought that if we could achieve certain objectives, or possess certain objects then we would feel fulfilled, complete, whole, and satisfied as people. We need a huge paradigm shift in our thinking. We need to be convinced that the life that we need to live, and the life that we want to live is only possible with the ongoing work of God’s Spirit within us.

Our commitment and faithfulness to Jesus is related to how we respond and co-operate with the Holy Spirit. Faithfulness is the result of character, and our character and its development is where the Holy Spirit does His greatest and most essential work.

We need to grow in our knowledge of Jesus.

Let us look at how Peter responded to Jesus’ question on behalf of the other disciples. ‘Simon Peter answered him, “Lord, to whom we shall go? You have the words of eternal life.  We have come to believe and to know that you are the Holy One of God.”

I want to say something that may surprise some.

If we are going to remain faithful to Jesus, we are going to live by faith; we are going to have to trust Jesus with our lives and circumstances. However in one sense faith is not enough, we will need something else. Before you jump to conclusion and think I am a heretic, let us look carefully at how Peter replied. We have come to believe and to know that you are the Holy One of God.” We need to have faith and knowledge, to believe and know.

The first purpose of following Jesus is not to get to heaven, or to have your life sorted, but it is to be transformed and freed from the power and guilt of sin so that you will have a new capacity to know Him. The point of salvation is to know God. When the bible speaks of eternal life it is not thinking about the longevity of life, rather it is referring to knowing God and being intimate with him. The ultimate purpose of salvation is to know God.(John 17 v 3) If these crowds of people really knew who Jesus was there is no way they would have walked. Knowledge of God is the bedrock of commitment. Often we can be lead astray because of our ignorance of God. We need to experience a knowing that is beyond cerebral facts and theological data. We need to have hearts that have been broken and healed by the reality of God.

We need to appreciate the glory of been chosen by Jesus so we can enter into the process of transformation. The chapter ends with two verses that seem a bit unconnected. Then Jesus replied, “Have I not chosen you, the Twelve? Yet one of you is a devil!” (He meant Judas, the son of Simon Iscariot, who, though one of the Twelve, was later to betray him.)

Many people apply this verse to the topic of election and predestination, I am sure that these verses certainly allude to that, but there may be a more pastoral and practical application.
Jesus wants these disciples know that he had ‘eklegomai’ chosen them. The word carries the idea of being chosen from among many so you can be with someone. Let the glory and wonder of that into your heart; let that truth stretch your mind. Jesus decided to choose you so you could be with him. Think of the emotional and psychological benefits of grasping the truth that you have not been ignored, or passed over, or forgotten, you are not a mistake or an afterthought, but chosen. ‘’For he chose us in him before the creation of the world to be holy…’ Ephesians 1:4 Wow! I think that in utterly amazing

Jesus said “Have I not chosen you, the Twelve? Yet one of you is a devil!” The sad thing is that Judas remained a devil, he stayed the same, he kept on being the person he had always been, and he did not allow the glory of Jesus’ loving choice of him to transform him. And in staying the same he betrayed Jesus.

Sometimes we need to stand back and reflect on how Jesus has chosen us, and be overwhelmed with awe and appreciation. As we begin to realise and appreciate the wondrous glory and eternal joy that there is in the heart of God of his choice of us, we will begin to be transformed and change from glory to glory. If you are anything like me, then you will listen to the negative lies that often play in our heads, we find it difficult to see ourselves as God sees us. We sometimes think God chooses the same way the computer geek is chosen for the sports team, he is the last one to be picked because someone has to take him. That is not how God chooses us. God chooses us with a deep sense of exciting joy, because in his heart he has a passionate longing for intimacy with us. Gods choice of us is similar to how a man would choose his bride, the main difference would be that Gods love for us will always surpass the love a man could have for his bride.

Father I pray that I will never be like Judas who remained unchanged by your grace Bible in a year reading plan 1 Chronicles 11:13-15:29
title: ‘ you do not want to leave me too do you’ part 2
study_refs: But why did they find this teaching so objectionable? Why were they offended by it? These disciples taught Jesus was being hard. The word for hard [offended] in some translations is skleros which means, hard, stiff, dried up, dry, severe. When referring to voices or sounds it means hoarse or harsh ( Jn 6:60 ). When referring to things it means hard or tough. When referring to people, it conveys an inhuman character.

html:
I don’t know if you have ever seen the film ‘The King’s Speech?’ It tells the story of King George VI who was king from 1936-1952. It was during this time the Monarchy began to broadcast live to the nation. This was very ironic because George VI had a very bad stutter. He was unable to use his voice as he had hoped. One of the reasons why he had stutter was because of his relationship with his father King George V who once said:-

‘My father was frightened of his mother; I was frightened of my father, and I am damned well going to see to it that my children are frightened of me.’

Imagine being brought up in atmosphere of fear, it is going to have devastating and dramatic effects on you and your future. Many people have be brought up in homes where their has been a dysfunctional father. Many of us carry wounds, scars and debilitating baggage because of an unhealthy or unloving relationship with our fathers. So when we are told that God wants us to know him as father, we can feel a bit uncomfortable, or uneasy.

I wonder what you think of this quote by J I Packer “You sum up the whole of New Testament religion if you describe it as the knowledge of God as one’s holy Father. If you want to judge how well a person understands Christianity, find out how much he makes of the thought of being God’s child, and having God as his Father. If this is not the thought that prompts and controls his worship and prayers and his whole outlook on life, it means that he does not understand Christianity very well at all.
J.I. Packer, Knowing God, pp. 186
For everything that Christ taught, everything that makes the New Testament new, and better than the Old, everything that is distinctively Christian as opposed to merely Jewish, is summed up in the knowledge of the Fatherhood of God. ‘Father’ is the Christian name for God. Our understanding of Christianity cannot be better than our grasp of adoption.”

Many of us are happy to relate to God as Lord, or Saviour, or King, but not father. Irrespective of what we think of our fathers, we do a great injustice to God, and grave harm to ourselves if we consciously or unconsciously project our experience and understanding of our earthly father upon him. Yet knowing God as father is the key to knowing God; If we were to understand the ‘Lord’s prayer,’ as an expression of our needs, it interesting that it begins with the words, ‘Our Father,’ Maybe knowing God as ‘father,’ is our greatest need, and the source of security that will produce fruitful living.

Father help me to choose to know you as father Bible in a year reading plan 1 Chronicles 16:1-19:9
title: The Fathers love for His Son. Part 1
study_refs: Jesus replied, “Let it be so now; it is proper for us to do this to fulfil all righteousness.” Then John consented. As soon as Jesus was baptized, he went up out of the water. At that moment heaven was opened, and he saw the Spirit of God descending like a dove and alighting on him. And a voice from heaven said, “This is my Son, whom I love; with him I am well pleased.”

html:
God as Father in the Bible.

In the Old Testament there are about 1200 references to father. 15 of these are referring to God, and 13 of the 15 references used 0f God as father are talking of God being the father of the nation of Israel not of an individual. The other two references are used in the context of prayer in Jeremiah 3:4,19, again they speaking about a corporate response to God.

In the New Testament Father was the word Jesus used most often when speaking about or to God, about 170 times. In every prayer accept one Jesus spoke to God as Father. If you read the gospel of John, it could be understood as an exposition of Jesus’ relationship with his Father, in the gospel there are 109 references to the father.

I just want to mention the word Abba that Jesus used in Mark 14:36 which reads. Abba, Father,” he said, “everything is possible for you. Take this cup from me. Yet not what I will, but what you will.” This is the only time we have on record of Jesus using the title Abba. This is in some ways the most difficult time in Jesus’ life, so it is very significant on this occasion. It has been widely taught in Christian circles that the word Abba was used by a young child to communicate with their father, and many see it as a ‘daddy word. This is an incomplete understanding of the word. The word was also used by adult children as an expression of great honour and respect. Sometimes the Rabbis were called Abba.

There is something in all of us that longs for intimacy, intimacy [with people and with God,] is a God given need, that is why we need to know God as Abba. The important thing is this, having a right respect for God, and living a life that honours him, is the consequence of intimacy with Him.

What kind of relationship did God the father have with Jesus? This is a very big question, and we could go to lots of places in the bible to try and answer that. So I thought we should take a look at the Baptism of Jesus, and consider what the Father said there, in these words we discover some indication as to how the father related to his Son.

As we consider the Fathers love for Jesus, we need to realise that the love the Father has for his Son Jesus is the same love he has for you and me. God the father does not love Jesus any more that he loves you, nor do he love you any less than he loves Jesus.(John 17 v 23) The relationship the father has with his Son is a prototype, or an example of the kind of relationship he wants to have with us.

We also need to recognise that because many of us have had poor experiences of fatherhood, and we all have had a wrong or incomplete understanding of God, we may find it difficult to accept and embrace the fatherhood of God.

Lets have a look at the text.

Jesus went to John to be baptized, This is very strange because John was baptizing people because they were turning from their sin and turning to God. See Matthew 3:1-12, We know that Jesus had lived a life free from sin, he lived a life in continual fellowship with his father, so why did he want John to baptize him? He choose to be baptized so he could humbly identify with us. His baptism was an expression of profound humility and radical identification.

Father help me to humbly identify with others. Bible in a year reading plan 1 Chronicles 19:10-23:11
title: The Fathers love for His Son. Part 2
study_refs: Jesus replied, “Let it be so now; it is proper for us to do this to fulfil all righteousness.” Then John consented. As soon as Jesus was baptized, he went up out of the water. At that moment heaven was opened, and he saw the Spirit of God descending like a dove and alighting on him. And a voice from heaven said, “This is my Son, whom I love; with him I am well pleased.”

html:
When the heavens tore open, it was as if God the Father was so determined to show his love to his Son. It was as if nothing would get in the way of God pouring his love upon his Jesus. The love the Father had for his son was always intentional.

Authentic love at its essence is always proactive, it will always choose to express its self. When Mark tells us the heavens were torn open, he was alluding to a passage in the Old Testament, Isaiah 64:1-4

Oh, that you would rend the heavens and come down, that the mountains would tremble before you! 2 As when fire sets twigs ablaze and causes water to boil,

come down to make your name known to your enemies and cause the nations to quake before you! 3 or when you did awesome things that we did not expect,
you came down, and the mountains trembled before you. 4 Since ancient times no one has heard, no ear has perceived, no eye has seen any God besides you,
who acts on behalf of those who wait for him.

Isaiah 64:1-4 is part of a longer prayer of lament recorded in Isaiah 63:7-64:12. A lament is a prayer that cries out to God from the midst of desperate grief, pain, or any circumstance that seems out of control. It vocalizes the hurt to God with the conviction, and the faith, that God can, and will bring relief. A lament is not just the venting of frustration, but is a profound statement of faith in God from the midst of utter human hopelessness. The significance of a lament is that the worshipper prays in the midst of his pain. He believes that God cares about His condition and he has enough faith in God to trust Him with the outcome. When the heavens were torn open at the baptism of Jesus, it was God the father intervening into our history and pain.

2. The father expressed his love by affirming Jesus’ identity. Knowing who we are and accepting who we are can be a difficult process. Often how we view ourselves is very different as to how God sees us. The word that is used for love is agapetos, it describes one who is in a very special relationship with another and in secular Greek is used mostly of a child, especially an only child to whom all the love of his parents is given (e.g. used by the Father describing His only Son and Abraham describing his "only son" in Ge 22:2).

In the world in which we live, identity is usually tied to a persons abilities, achievements or successes. But biblically a persons identity has nothing to do with what we do, or what we achieve, but has everything to do with who we are. When Jesus was being baptized, he wasn't standing before his father with an impressive list of achievements that made him loveable. Jesus understood that he needed to receive his Father’s love if he was going to accomplish his father’s will.

For Jesus accepting his identity was about him being able to be the person his father saw him to be. How God sees us is the most important thing about us. If you were to hear God speaking from heaven, and say ‘you are my son, my daughter,’ how would you react? Most of the time when we find ourselves far from God it can usually be traced back to some kind of identity crisis about how God sees us, or how we think God sees us. It is difficult to live as a child of God if you do not believe you are a child of God.

It is very interesting that immediately after the Father declared Jesus to be his Son, Jesus was taken into the wilderness where he was tempted by Satan. The whole point of the temptation was to question and undermine Jesus’ identity. Three times he begins each temptation with the same question, ‘if you are the Son of God?’ He was trying to do the complete opposite to Jesus, to what his father was doing at his baptism. Temptation to sin is Satan’s attempt to rob us of our identity.

Father thank you that 0ur identity is not about our achievements, but your love for us.

Bible in a year: 1 Chronicles 23:12-26:19
title: The Fathers love for His Son. Part 3
study_refs: 1. The father expressed his love for Jesus in a very clear and bold way. In Mark’s account of the Baptism of Jesus we are told a very interesting thing., He says that the heavens were torn open. The word for torn is schizomenous, this is a violent word that means to tear or cleave and it requires determination and strength. The same word is used in Mark 15:38 talking about the curtain in the temple being torn in two. (Apparently the temple curtain was so heavy that it took 300 men to lift it.)

html:
It would be very easy to read this incident in the life of Jesus, and think, its a bit mushy or a bit sentimental. It does not sound very macho. But when we look a bit deeper and scratch beneath the surface we discover that when God the father spoke he was alluding to three old testament passages.

In Psalm 2 7-9 we read 7 I will proclaim the Lord’s decree: He said to me, “You are my son; today I have become your father. 8 Ask me,, and I will make the nations your inheritance, the ends of the earth your possession. 9 You will break them with a rod of iron, you will dash them to pieces like pottery.”. Psalm 2 is a messianic psalm which describes the privileges and responsibility of the Son.

The second passage that is alluded to his Genesis 22 look at what it says, Some time later God tested Abraham. He said to him, “Abraham!” “Here I am,” he replied. 2Then God said, “Take your son, your only son, whom you love—Isaac—and go to the region of Moriah. Sacrifice him there as a burnt offering on a mountain I will show you.”

The third passage is Isaiah 42:1 “Here is my servant, whom I uphold,
my chosen one in whom I delight. Isaiah 42:1-4 is the first reference of four that refer to a suffering messiah in Isaiah 40-55. [see 46:1-6, 50:4-9, 52:13-53:12.].

As Jesus listened to his father speak, he not only heard affirming words of encouragement, but he also heard words of challenge. He knew that the affirming word that came from the old testament were also words that predicted his suffering and death.

The affirming love that God the father pours into our lives is the same love that produces courage and perseverance. The love through which God shows his pleasure is the same love that strengthens us for the suffering and sacrifices of the life. The life of Jesus teaches us that God the Father loves us and when we receive that love we are able to live the life that God has called us to.

Father I acknowledge I cant do your will for my life without living the knowledge of your love

Bible in a year: 1
title: The Fathers love for His Son. Part 4
study_refs: 3. The father also expressed his pleasure with his Son. I find this amazing, God the Father did not think, ‘Jesus knows how I feel about him,’ He did not assume that his Son knew that he was loved. Matthew 1:18-25 This is how the birth of Jesus the Messiah came about. His mother Mary was pledged to be married to Joseph, but before they came together, she was found to be pregnant through the Holy Spirit. She will give birth to a son, and you are to give him the name Jesus, because he will save his people from their sins.” All this took place to fulfil what the Lord had said through the prophet: “The virgin will conceive and give birth to a son, and they will call him Immanuel” (which means “God with us”). When Joseph woke up, he did what the angel of the Lord had commanded him and took Mary home as his wife. But he did not consummate their marriage until she gave birth to a son. And he gave him the name Jesus.

Loving when family does not look as it should.

The greatest joy in life is often found in the context of family, where love and support is given, were people are nurtured, a place where people feel safe, where they can be themselves. I have been thinking How amazing it would be if we could cultivate a family life where God felt loved. Where our relationships, our words, our actions and everything else that goes to make up our lives as families, caused God to know that he is loved.

However, for some the family is far from a safe place, it is not a place of love and joy. Sometimes we open the door of our families to sinful behaviour, to wrong influences, to loveless activities,. Sometimes we sacrifice family harmony to selfishness, and before long we our homes become places where God feels rejected or abandoned, our homes cease to be a loving nourishing, safe places.

At other times God sends circumstances into our lives that bring chaos, confusion and fear. Sometimes there are people and families who are trying their best to live for God, then God begins to move in their lives in ways they could never expect, and life just get more messy, dreams die, family life becomes difficult, relationships are strained, the future looks bleak, and you you cant understand why God would let all this happen.

We are going to take a look at the Christmas story and try to learn how we can love God through our families. We are going to look at the life of Joseph, for he has a lot to teach us about loving God in the context of family.

If you think about it for a moment their was nothing special about the family Jesus was born into, Yes Joseph was from the line of David, but he was poor, and of very little influence. It seems like other families would have been better place to prepared Jesus for his ministry as the Son of God. It might have been better for the Messiah—like the prophet Samuel and John the Baptist—to grow up in a priestly household. He could have devoted days to prayer and the study of Scripture as well as had daily access to the temple precincts. Or, perhaps the Messiah could have been raised within a Pharisees household as was the Apostle Paul (Acts 23:6). This lay movement was highly devoted to God and zealous for the application of Old Testament Scriptures (Torah and tradition) to daily living. However, God wanted His Son to live in an ordinary family, like ours

Joseph is a very interesting person, when we think of the Christmas story Joseph is probably the person who gets the least attention. We talk a lot about Mary, we are fascinated by the wise men, the shepherds and the angles, but Joseph, we are incline to ignore him, we not incline to get too excited about him, we don’t here too many sermons about him. Yet Joseph teaches us a lot about how to love God, when family life is not what you had hoped. How to love God when you hopes and dreams come crashing down? How to love God when your plans fall apart? How to love God when your heart is full of fear?

It may be, that one of the reasons why we find it easy to ignore Joseph is because he is a quiet man. He is mentioned 12 times in the New Testament, but we have no record of him ever speaking, he is silent, yet when we take a close look at his life, he teaches us a lot.

Father may Jesus feel loved in our family
