Matthew 1:18-25 This is how the birth of Jesus the Messiah came about. His mother Mary was pledged to be married to Joseph, but before they came together, she was found to be pregnant through the Holy Spirit. Because Joseph her husband was faithful to the law, and yet did not want to expose her to public disgrace, he had in mind to divorce her quietly but after he had considered this, an angle of the Lord appeared to him in a dream and said, “Joseph son of David, do not be afraid to take Mary home as your wife, because what is conceived in her is from the Holy Spirit. She will give birth to a son, and you are to give him the name Jesus, because he will save his people from their sins.” All this took place to fulfil what the Lord had said through the prophet: “The virgin will conceive and give birth to a son, and they will call him Immanuel” (which means “God with us”). When Joseph woke up, he did what the angel of the Lord had commanded him and took Mary home as his wife. But he did not consummate their marriage until she gave birth to a son. And he gave him the name Jesus.

1. Joseph and Mary were betrothed. Understanding betrothal.

The first stage of the betrothal was finding a suitable spouse for the bride or bridegroom. In the ancient Near Eastern culture, this was most often initiated by the families of the bride and groom. Though a young man could make his preference for a wife known to his family, his parents may or may not have agreed to pursue his wishes. For the most part, it was the responsibility of the parents to choose a suitable spouse for their children. Young men and women were pledged to each other at ages as young as twelve or thirteen.

The second stage was the betrothal ceremony. I remember when I was growing up I was often told that when the bible talked about being betrothed it was like our engagement. It’s not. The betrothal was entered into, it was absolutely binding. It lasted for one year. During that year the couple were known as man and wife, although they had not the rights of man and wife. It could not be terminated in any other way than by divorce or death. In the Jewish law we frequently find what is to us a curious phrase. A girl whose fiancée had died during the year of betrothal is called "a virgin who is a widow". During the betrothal ceremony the Man gave his bride to be a glass of wine, which only drank if she was prepared to absolutely faithful and totally committed to him.

So it was during this time that Mary conceived, and that is a problem, during the betrothal period sexual relationships were not permitted, even though Mary and Joseph were known as husband and wife. What was Joseph going to do? How should he respond to this?

2. Joseph need to find the balance between justice and mercy. Joseph was a righteous man, he was what was known in Judaism a tsaddiyq The NIV text says that Joseph was ‘faithful to the law.’ and he was, but the term righteous means a lot more

‘Biblical righteousness is inevitably social, because it is about relationships. When most modern people see the word “righteousness” in the Bible, they tend to think of it in terms of private morality, such as sexual chastity or diligence in prayer and Bible study. But in the Bible tzadeqah refers to day-to-day living in which a person conducts all relationships in family and society with fairness, generosity, and equity.’ Tim Keller https://generositymonk.com/2016/09/14/tim-keller-biblical-righteousness-exhibits-generosity/ accessed 29/03/2025

John Ortberg speaking about tsaddiyq says ‘Joseph did not eat unclean food. He didn't mix with the wrong kinds of people. He didn't keep his carpentry shop open on the Sabbath to make a few extra drachmas. He was a tsaddîyq; that was his identity. Everybody knew this about him. Nobody invited Joseph over to have ham sandwiches with tax collectors and prostitutes. https://www.preachingtoday.com/sermons/sermons/2010/july/recognizingdivineinterruptions.html#:~:text=He%20didn't%20keep%20his,with%20tax%20collectors%20and%20prostitutes. Accessed 311/03/2025

Before we unpack the dilemma Joseph let me give you two questions to think about. Are you known, or would you like to be known as a righteous person? Do you love righteousness? Do you have a strong emotional attachment to it? I think any lack of love off righteousness will make it more difficult for it to become the defining attribute of our lives.

Joseph dilemma is this, he wants to be righteous and do what the law requires, but if he does that, then he will be putting Mary in a position where she will be publicly shame. Matthew tells us ‘that he did not want to expose her to public disgrace.’ Joseph believing that Mary had been unfaithful to him, wanted to protect Mary, he wanted to shield her from public reticule. The word used for disgrace means to make someone a public example, our make them a sorry spectacle.

What should he do? He sees his wife pregnant, and he knows that he is not the father, what is he feeling? Is he feeling angry? Humiliated? Confused? Betrayed? Did he feel all his hopes and dreams were gone? Probable, but he was also feeling love, and he does not want Mary to be publicly humiliated, so he is not going to drag her in front of a public court to get his pound of flesh. Why not? Because he wants to protect her, he wants to shield her. His love for Mary was greater than his dreams, hopes and expectations. Therefore, he decided to take a course of action that would cause the least shame to Mary. So he chaoses to divorce her quietly. How was that done? The two parties could get together before two or three witnesses and write out a private bill of which did not state the reason for the divorce such as is indicated in Deuteronomy 24.

I think this is amazing, Joseph wants to do what is right, he wants to be truthful, but not at the expense of love. If we stand for truth without expressing love then we are not really standing for truth. In every family things arise that can cause this tension between doing what is right and showing love.

Father thank you that love and righteousness are always compatible

John Ortberg says,

Is it possible there's a ministry of disequilibrium God is allowing to take place in Joseph's life so he'll come to a new era of growth? Is it possible in your life, maybe right now? If you're confused or disoriented or uncertain about something, maybe it's not because you've done something wrong. Maybe you're about to grow. Maybe what you need to do is wait on God and trust God's going to do something in your life you don't even know about yet! I love that https://www.preachingtoday.com/sermons/sermons/2010/july/recognizingdivineinterruptions.html

When Joseph woke up, he did what the angel of the Lord had commanded him and took Mary home as his wife. But he did not consummate their marriage until she gave birth to a son. And he gave him the name Jesus.

Joseph anger

In Matthew 1:20 we read these words ‘But after he considered this, an angel of the Lord appeared to him in a dream.’ One interesting idea that is presented is that translation of the Greek word “enthymeomai” as “considered” may not be accurate in Matthew 1:20. While not an incorrect translation of the word, enthymeomai has an alternate meaning of “becoming angry”. This translation brings an entirely different perspective to this part of the story. Joseph was not some flat character in a story, but was a real person with understandable emotions. He was not some kind of emotional-less person with robotic obedience, but he had to work through his feelings. He needed to think through his anger in order to move forward in a positive way.

If you are anything like me, it is very easy to allow your emotions to become a motivator for action, especially anger. Joseph was right to be angry, but he did not allow his anger to make him impulsive, he know that all these circumstances were not solely about him, so he took a step back, and began to process what was going on inside him. He was able to make a gracious decision to divorce Mary quietly because he did not just accept the fact he was angry, but he thought it through.

Sometimes justified anger can lead to wrong decisions, even sinful decisions. In refusing to allow his anger to become a catalyst for action Joseph was able to make the grace filled choice to divorce Mary quietly. It impossible for anger and grace to be in our hearts at the same time.

If we want to protect the life of Jesus in our families then their can be no place for uncontrolled or defining anger. To be known as an angry person is one of the saddest indictments anyone can ever receive. It is hard living with an angry person, someone who uses their anger to control and manipulate. Members of their families have to walk on egg shells in case the angry person blows. The angry person in the home is like the screaming toddler who needs to be the centre of attention. So the question we need to ask, is anger a continual factor in our lives as families? Joseph thought his way through his anger and in doing so was able to embrace God’s purposes for his life.

Father, if I am angry about your will for my life, help me to work through it thoughtfully.

She will give birth to a son, and you are to give him the name Jesus, because he will save his people from their sins.” All this took place to fulfil what the Lord had said through the prophet: “The virgin will conceive and give birth to a son, and they will call him Immanuel” (which means “God with us”). When Joseph woke up, he did what the angel of the Lord had commanded him and took Mary home as his wife. But he did not consummate their marriage until she gave birth to a son. And he gave him the name Jesus.

Joseph’s revelation. Let us look again at verses

19-20 Because Joseph her husband was faithful to the law, and yet did not want to expose her to public disgrace, he had in mind to divorce her quietly. 20 But after he had considered this, an angel of the Lord appeared to him in a dream and said, “Joseph son of David, do not be afraid to take Mary home as your wife, because what is conceived in her is from the Holy Spirit.

Do you notice anything strange about these two verses? They seem to be the wrong way round. It would have been easier if the angel of the Lord had come to Joseph before Mary had conceived, if the angel had come and told Joseph what was going to happen, it would have made a life a lot easier. That is what the angel Gabriel did with Mary. Mary this is what is going to happen. But with Joseph it is the other way round

One writer wrote this.

‘The circumstances in which this mystery is revealed to him, precisely when he is reflecting on these things is not without significance. God could have clearly spared him suffering by acquainting with the divine plan at the same time, for example, as he revealed it to the virgin Mary. [In Luke’s Gospel.] She too would have been spared the anguish of seeing Joseph suffer and of herself having to keep a secrete that otherwise would have immediately resolved the problem. God does not pay attention to the way men sees things… For some time he permits Joseph to debate in anguished confusion, understanding nothing and seeing no clear way out, not knowing exactly what he ought to do in a situation as unforeseeable as it was delicate and painful. It was only when arrived at an honourable solution consonant with his imperfect knowledge of reality that God intervened by the means of an angel.. only then, and not earlier did God let him know what was necessary for him in order to rectify his erroneous decision.’ Douglas Wirth. Source unknown

Joseph was full of fear, he knew that he could never marry Mary now, for to do so would mean at least his reputation would have been ruined, and possibly his own family disown him, which would mean he would be disinherited. The interesting thing is this, God did nothing to change the circumstances that cause Joseph to fear. In fact, God tells him to do the very thing he is afraid of. The angel went on to say that his son would be called Immanuel which means God with us.

Joseph I want you to do the very thing you are afraid to do, but I want you to know that I am Immanuel. Sometimes we would rather have changed circumstances that know the reality of God with us.

J C Ryle writes that Immanuel promises to be "with us daily to pardon and forgive; with us daily to sanctify and strengthen; with us daily to defend and keep; with us daily to lead and to guide; with us in sorrow, and with us in joy; with us in sickness, and with us in health; with us in life, and with us in death; with us in time, and with us in eternity."

The name Immanuel sums up God’s heart, and all his purposes for his Son Jesus, It encapsulates God’s longing for us, it expresses our greatest need and depicts the best source of courage and devotion.

Maybe you can identify with Joseph, you have all these conflicting emotions raging in you heart, you feel disappointed and confused. The neat black and white boxes you have used to contain your life have all been destroyed. Maybe, God is wrestling with you as he did with Joseph so you can build a home where Jesus will feel loved. At this time God confirmed and challenged at the same time what Joseph believed and how he thought so he could embrace the mystery of the incarnation.

For Joseph this was a spiritual rite of passage, it was Gods way of bringing him to maturity, so he could provide a home where God feels loved.

Father thank you that the life of Joseph teaches us that your presence in our lives is more important than a change in our circumstance. Thank you that sometimes you don’t want us to live in a ‘black and white’ world. Bible in a year reading plan 2 Chronicles 2o:14-24:14

His mother Mary was pledged to be married to Joseph, but before they came together, she was found to be pregnant through the Holy Spirit. Because Joseph her husband was faithful to the law, and yet did not want to expose her to public disgrace, he had in mind to divorce her quietly but after he had considered this, an angle of the Lord appeared to him in a dream and said, “Joseph son of David, do not be afraid to take Mary home as your wife, because what is conceived in her is from the Holy Spirit. She will give birth to a son, and you are to give him the name Jesus, because he will save his people from their sins.” All this took place to fulfil what the Lord had said through the prophet: “The virgin will conceive and give birth to a son, and they will call him Immanuel” (which means “God with us”). When Joseph woke up, he did what the angel of the Lord had commanded him and took Mary home as his wife. But he did not consummate their marriage until she gave birth to a son. And he gave him the name Jesus.

I wonder if you have ever been deeply challenged or disturbed by the ‘Christmas.’ story. It is a story we all know, and that a problem, because we know it so well it has become ‘Disney-tised.’ we have sanitised it to make it more palatable. But if we were to take a closer look we will discover that the Christmas story is about difficult relationships, frustrated plans, divine interruptions, unfavourable circumstances, hard choices, insecure authorities, cruel atrocities, unexpected visitors. And yet despite all this, the story of Christmas teaches us how to live with God’s perspective on life it teaches a lot about building a family where God feels loved.

Joseph and Mary did not live in some kind of utopia where it was easy to love God. Life was difficult, demanding, uncomfortable and sometimes uncertain, but because of what was In their hearts their home and marriage became somewhere where God felt love. we started to look at Joseph and how God dealt with him so he could be a father to Jesus. We want to consider him and see how his commitment to God worked itself out in his family. I think this is the most important thing about our Christian life, how is it worked out in the context of our family life.

1. Joseph needed to see Mary the way God saw her. When the angel of the Lord appeared to Joseph in a dream, Joseph was able to have a different and new perspective about Mary. Joseph listened to what God had to say and this had a dramatic positive effect on his relationship with Mary. We read ‘Joseph son of David, do not be afraid to take Mary home as your wife, because what is conceived in her is from the Holy Spirit.’

Joseph needed to get pass all his cultural upbringing and his rigid understanding of the law if he was going to see Mary as God saw her. If he was going to really love Mary, then he needed to continually see her from God perspective

How we see people is the number one test of our spirituality. How we see other and how we relate to them, especially in the family context is the most accurate indicator of our spirituality.

​Let us think through the consequences of this. What difference would it make if we saw our spouse has God saw them. To see your spouse as God sees them is to recognise their value, it is the celebrate their worth, it is to be filled with gratitude for them, it is seeing that are to be loved unconditionally.

We live in a culture where people think it is funny or cleaver to belittle or demean their spouses. This not only happens in non-Christians homes, but sadly in Christian home also. In some ‘Christian’ homes there are wives who hide behind a false comfort, they say to themselves, something like, ’but he doesn’t hit me.’ and they choose to live in a dark secrete world of emotional abuse where they feel robbed of dignity, respect and self worth, and because emotional abuse does not leave physical scars it can almost become acceptable, it is tolerated. This can also happen to men, who are emotionally and verbally abused.

Emotional abuse is not someone losing their temper in an argument or having a heated disagreement with you on occasion. It is when your normal becomes a regular pattern of disrespectful, hurtful, demeaning, manipulative behaviour.

Emotional abuse often uses verbal abuse, which could include angry outbursts, screaming, swearing, ridicule, name calling, blaming, accusation, criticism, threats, orders, mockery, manipulation, coercion, put-downs, shaming, word twisting, rewriting history, and attacking personal character.

Jesus categorizes verbal abuse as a serious offence with eternal consequences: “You have heard that it was said to the people long ago, ‘You shall not murder, and anyone who murders will be subject to judgment.’ But I tell you that anyone who is angry with a brother or sister will be subject to judgment. Again, anyone who says to a brother or sister, ‘Raca,’ [an Aramaic term of contempt meaning “worthless, empty”] is answerable to the court. And anyone who says, ‘You fool!’ will be in danger of the fire of hell. Matthew 5:22.

God’s desire is that we “encourage one another and build each other up” (1 Thessalonians 5:11) and that we “do not let any unwholesome talk come out of [our] mouths, but only what is helpful for building others up according to their needs” (Ephesians 4:29). God intends that our words and our relationships be healthy and life giving. Encouragement must be intentional, it is something we consciously choose to do. Some people say, ‘encouragement is not my gift,’ that is like saying ‘love is not my responsibility.’

Father help us to always view our spouse as you do

html:
Matthew 1:18-25 This is how the birth of Jesus the Messiah came about. His mother Mary was pledged to be married to Joseph, but before they came together, she was found to be pregnant through the Holy Spirit. Because Joseph her husband was faithful to the law, and yet did not want to expose her to public disgrace, he had in mind to divorce her quietly but after he had considered this, an angle of the Lord appeared to him in a dream and said, “Joseph son of David, do not be afraid to take Mary home as your wife, because what is conceived in her is from the Holy Spirit. She will give birth to a son, and you are to give him the name Jesus, because he will save his people from their sins.” All this took place to fulfil what the Lord had said through the prophet: “The virgin will conceive and give birth to a son, and they will call him Immanuel” (which means “God with us”). When Joseph woke up, he did what the angel of the Lord had commanded him and took Mary home as his wife. But he did not consummate their marriage until she gave birth to a son. And he gave him the name Jesus.

Joseph needed to create space so God could work in Mary’s life.

God was asking Joseph to make choices that would enhance and encourage what God had already began to do in Mary… Matthew 1:25 says But he did not consummate their marriage until she gave birth to a son. At surface level this verse is telling us that Joseph and Mary were not physically intimate until after Jesus was born. However, in this verse there is a very important principle that is an essential for every Christian marriage. ‘Their will be times when we will have to sacrifices our desires, wants, ‘needs’ so that God can complete a work he is doing in the life of your spouse.’ This principle could apply to many areas of life.

Marriage should never be tit-for-tat. Do we hold our spouse accountable for moral, upright behaviour? Yes! Do we withhold our love when we feel we are not being loved? No! Christ’s invitation to love is without limits, without strings attached. We are called to love freely and sacrifice for our spouse sincerely.

Are we prepared to make substantial and continuous sacrifice so God can produce the life of Jesus in your spouse. I wonder what kind of concern or care do we have for the spiritual lives of those we are married to. I totally realise that we will never be held responsible for an other persons spirituality, but we have a God given responsibility to encourage and help others to grow and mature spiritually, especially those we love most.

For Joseph and Mary the very centre of their marriage was the activity of God and the life of Jesus, and as Christians we should endeavour to have the same in our homes and marriages. But how can we do that.

Here are a few suggestions.

a. Pray about each others spiritual life and their relationship with God, remember your spouses relationship with God is the most important thing in their lives.

b. Pray together, not as some kind of formal activity, but spontaneously, for example, if you discussing something, or making plans, make prayer a part of the discussion.

c. Be intentional in wanting to encourage your spouse spiritually, make it a deliberate choice.

d. explore the word of God together, talk about what you hear in church, ask questions of each other, share verses,

e. offer assistance. Just ask is their anything I can do to help you. Take on practical task to free the other person up so they can go and pray, or read, or do some kind of ministry.

f. Plan spiritual activities together, It could a morning praying together, or going on a retreat with friends, our it just might something like promising to pray for each other during a difficult day when you are apart

g. Be prepared to make sacrifices and go out of your way to encourage others spiritually.

Joseph displayed a heart like Jesus. When you look at the life of Joseph you get the impression that he was the kind of man who did not care much for the limelight, he didn’t write any books, preach any sermons, do any miraculous. We are never told if he was especially gifted, or if he had accomplished great things. All we know is that he was a godly quiet man who live the obscurity of Nazareth. Bringing up the Son of God in Nazareth was like the queen being brought up in an unknown and undesirable place. Nazareth was a small unimpressive place with a bad reputation. Joseph choose to live there, see Matthew 2:23

Joseph, like Jesus did not live out of an ego. He knew that he could make a difference by living a godly life. We are told about Jesus that ‘although he was rich, yet for our sakes he became poor.’ 2 Corinthians 8:9. Joseph embodied this same kind of attitude. Being a father to the Son of God could have caused him to look for notoriety, or popularity, but instead he embraced the obscurity of Nazareth. I think there is something very beautiful about humility in the home. Humility in the home makes the home a better place.

Humility is found in many forms such as modesty, meekness, humbleness, lowliness of mind, and submission. These are all things that go against our natural desire to excel and be seen in this world. We are often driven by a need to be right, to be in charge and to come first, and time and again, we deceive ourselves into thinking that settling for anything less is a sign of weakness. Writing about pride C,S, Lewis wrote ‘According to Christian teachers, the essential vice, the utmost evil, is Pride. Unchastity, anger, greed, drunkenness, and all that, are mere flea bites in comparison: it was through Pride that the devil became the devil: Pride leads to every other vice: it is the complete anti-God state of mind…… it is Pride which has been the chief cause of misery in every nation and every family since the world began.’ Source unown

I think the most important lesson we can learn from Joseph is that life is essentially about character, not ability, or achievement, or position or even opportunity, but about who we are and what we are becoming. Every thing Joseph was, we can be. We have all the opportunity to build families were God feels loved. We don’t need to be rich or cleaver, or strong, or loud, we don’t need to be specially gifted, or be well connected. But, you do need to have a humble love for righteousness and a heart that is prepared to make any sacrifice necessary so God can complete his work in the life of your spouse. We should aim to become families where God feels loved.

Father may our homes be places were we display encouraging humble love. Bible in a year reading plan. 2 Chronicles 24:15-28:17
title: Study topic nativity part 7

html:
Luke 1:26-38

In the sixth month of Elizabeth’s pregnancy, God sent the angel Gabriel to Nazareth, a village in Galilee, to a virgin named Mary. She was engaged to be married to a man named Joseph, a descendant of King David Gabriel appeared to her and said, “Greetings, favoured woman! The Lord is with you! Confused and disturbed, Mary tried to think what the angel could mean. “Don’t be afraid, Mary,” the angel told her, “for you have found favour with God. You will conceive and give birth to a son, and you will name him Jesus. He will be very great and will be called the Son of the Most High. The Lord God will give him the throne of his ancestor David. And he will reign over Israel forever; his Kingdom will never end!” Mary asked the angel, “But how can this happen? I am a virgin.” he angel replied, “The Holy Spirit will come upon you, and the power of the Most High will overshadow you. So the baby to be born will be holy, and he will be called the Son of God. What’s more, your relative Elizabeth has become pregnant in her old age! People used to say she was barren, but she has conceived a son and is now in her sixth month. For the word of God will never fail.” Mary responded, “I am the Lord’s servant. May everything you have said about me come true.” And then the angel left her.

Sometimes in life we can get some really good news, and we get excited and feel really encouraged. However, sometimes good news can challenge and confront us, it can threaten our status-quo. For example if you were to hear that you were to be getting a new job with a large pay increase, you would be thrilled, but you may also feel a bit daunted because you will have new and probably more responsibilities.

The Good news is, that Jesus was to be born of Mary. Jesus, the creator of the universe became a tiny egg in a womb of a virgin. As God stepped down, Mary began to carry His greatest expression of love for the world in her womb. ‘It is by far the most amazing miracle in the whole Bible – far more amazing than the resurrection and more amazing than the creation of the universe. The fact that the infinite, omnipotent, eternal Son of God could become man and join Himself to a human nature forever, so that infinite God became one person with finite man, will remain for eternity the most profound miracle and the most profound mystery in all the universe.’ Wayne Grudem

The Word became flesh! God became human! The invisible became visible! The untouchable became touchable! Eternal life experienced temporal death! The transcendent one, descended and drew near! The unlimited became limited! The infinite became finite! The immutable became mutable! The unbreakable became fragile! Spirit became matter! Eternity entered time! The independent became dependent! The almighty became weak! The loved became hated! The exalted was humbled! Glory was subjected to shame! Fame turned into obscurity! From inexpressible joy to tears of unimaginable grief! From a throne to a cross! From ruler to being ruled! From power to weakness! Sam Storms. Pleasures Evermore 2000, p. 153-154

We should be people who rejoice and glory in the incarnation of Jesus, we have a God who understands us, a God who identifies with us, a God who cares for us, a God who is with us, this is very good news.

However, the good news of Jesus’ birth is also challenging and confronting. It will confront and challenge our understanding of life and how we live it. We need to grasp the fact that the nativity story needs to become part of our story. I understand that the nativity story as recorded in the bible is unique and can never be repeated. However, the spiritual principles and biblical truths that shaped Mary life, need to shape our lives. The birth narratives in the gospels are more than historical records, they are also templates God uses to continually reveal Jesus. We must learn from Mary’s relationship with God, having the expected hope that Jesus will be formed in us. We all need our own personalised ‘nativity’ story. Our lives need to become an echo of the nativity, where Jesus is formed in us and revealed through us. Let’s be honest we would rather watch the nativity as a sanitised children’s play than be part of it. The bold allegiance that the original characters of the nativity gave to God, needs to become ours. So let us look at our passage and try and become a people in whom the life of Jesus can be produced in us.

Father may my life echo the nativity story, may Jesus be formed in me

Luke 1:26-38

In the sixth month of Elizabeth’s pregnancy, God sent the angel Gabriel to Nazareth, a village in Galilee, to a virgin named Mary. She was engaged to be married to a man named Joseph, a descendant of King David Gabriel appeared to her and said, “Greetings, favoured woman! The Lord is with you! Confused and disturbed, Mary tried to think what the angel could mean. “Don’t be afraid, Mary,” the angel told her, “for you have found favour with God. You will conceive and give birth to a son, and you will name him Jesus. He will be very great and will be called the Son of the Most High. The Lord God will give him the throne of his ancestor David. And he will reign over Israel forever; his Kingdom will never end!” Mary asked the angel, “But how can this happen? I am a virgin.” he angel replied, “The Holy Spirit will come upon you, and the power of the Most High will overshadow you. So the baby to be born will be holy, and he will be called the Son of God. What’s more, your relative Elizabeth has become pregnant in her old age! People used to say she was barren, but she has conceived a son and is now in her sixth month. For the word of God will never fail.” Mary responded, “I am the Lord’s servant. May everything you have said about me come true.” And then the angel left her.

Location does not determine influence.

The passage begins with these words. ‘In the sixth month of Elizabeth’s pregnancy, God sent the angel Gabriel to Nazareth, a village in Galilee. This is the second time Gabriel is mentioned in this chapter. The first time we meet him in the Temple in Jerusalem where he met Zechariah. There could not be more of a contrast. The Temple, the most important building in the nation, the heart of Jerusalem around which the life of the city revolved, compared with Nazareth. Nazareth is not mentioned in the Old Testament nor is it among the sixty-three villages of Galilee mentioned in the Hebrew Talmud, or the forty-five mentioned by first-century Jewish historian Josephus, who knew the area well. This was an insignificant little town. Its population is estimated to have been between one hundred and four hundred people, though its lack of mention in the Talmud and by Josephus might suggest that it was far smaller. It was not very accessible and was bypassed by the main trade routes. Nathaniel, one of the disciples asked the question, ‘Can anything good come out of Nazareth?’ I read one source that claimed that Nazareth was a location where there was a ravine where the carcases of dead animals were dumped, causing toxins to fill the air, causing illness and disabilities among the population.

The Nativity story teaches us, that in our obscurity and isolation we need an encounter with God. We need to meet God where we are at.

Sometimes we can feel so isolated, so cut of from others we can be tempted to think that our lives are of little if any consequence to God. Maybe you feel that you are in ‘Nazareth,’ it may not be a geographical Nazareth, but it may be a socially or emotional, it may be behind your front door. We need to ask God to meet us in bleakness of our obscurity and realise that prestige, position and power are never necessary for the purposes of God to be accomplished in our lives.

In a small cottage by the roadside in the village of Barvas lived two elderly women, Peggy and Christine Smith. They were eighty-four and eighty-two years old. Peggy was blind and her sister almost bent double with arthritis. Unable to attend public worship, their humble cottage became a sanctuary where they met with God. To them came the promise: “I will pour water upon him that is thirsty and floods upon the dry ground,” they pleaded this day and night in prayer.

One night Peggy had a revelation, revival was coming and the church of her fathers would be crowded again with young people! She sent for the minister, the Rev. James Murray MacKay, and told him what God had shown her, asking him to call his elders and deacons together for special times of waiting upon God. In the same district a group of men praying in a barn experienced a foretaste of coming blessing.

Look at these words regarding the revival:-

‘There was a fear to count the converted, as ministers didn’t want to fall into David’s sin of pride (1 Chron. 21:2). Though that was the general attitude towards counting converts, we did find one record that stated there were 20,000 converts during the first five weeks.’
Duncan Campbell indicated that 75% of those saved during the Hebrides Revival were saved before they came to church.

Plans are expendable.

Mary was a young girl between the age of 12-15 who was betrothed to a man called Joseph. Betrothal was a legally binding covenant that could only be dissolved by divorce. During this time the man and his bride lived apart. He stayed at his father’s home, where he would extend his father’s home in preparation for bringing his bride home. Add to the pressure, conception during the betrothal period which was considered an act of adultery and could be punishable by death. You could say that Gabriel's announcement trashed Mary’s hopes, dreams and plans. In obeying God, Mary would have been misjudged and wrongly perceived as shameful. The bible gives us no indication as to how Mary may have viewed the dramatic change and interruption to her plans, but we can be sure that she would have felt unprepared for such a dramatic turn of events. She did not ask for or seek this role in God’s plans; God has simply stepped into her life and brought her into his service.

There are two important things I want to say about this.

At their essence most of the plans we make, especially life changing plans, like getting married, getting a job, changing direction in life are emotionally based decisions. They are more than cold facts written on a white board, and for the most part they come from an emotional place, and are full of emotional expectations. So when God’s will begins to threaten our hopes and plans we really struggle. We struggle because we are not unemotional robots, we struggle because our hopes for the future have caused us to become excited about our plans. This is what you could call ‘ the nativity struggle.’

Have you ever thought that Mary could have said no, just as much as we have the freedom to say no?

There will be times in our lives when we will have to engage in ‘the nativity struggle.’ when we will have to decide, do I want to do life my way, or Gods way? When we have to decide if God’s eternal purposes are more important than our temporary agenda.

Also we need to come to a heart conviction that it is better to live a difficult, complex life within the will of God, than to life in the safe monotony of my own existence. There were lots of reasons why Mary could have said no, could have played it safe, but she had the courage to see beyond the boundaries of her emotional safe plans and her obscurity, and choose the difficult path because it was the best. ‘The Nativity struggle’ is having the courage not play it safe. ‘The Nativity struggle’ is to let encounters with God determine the course of your life so His Son can be formed in you.

Father I pray that the obscurity of my life will not become a comfort zone where I hide

And he will reign over Israel forever; his Kingdom will never end!” Mary asked the angel, “But how can this happen? I am a virgin.” he angel replied, “The Holy Spirit will come upon you, and the power of the Most High will overshadow you. So the baby to be born will be holy, and he will be called the Son of God. What’s more, your relative Elizabeth has become pregnant in her old age! People used to say she was barren, but she has conceived a son and is now in her sixth month. For the word of God will never fail.” Mary responded, “I am the Lord’s servant. May everything you have said about me come true.” And then the angel left her.

You are totally accepted.

What I find fascinating about Mary is the thing that caused her to be confused and disturbed. Look at what the text says, ‘Gabriel appeared to her and said, “Greetings, favoured woman! The Lord is with you!. Confused and disturbed, Mary tried to think what the angel could mean. The appearance of the angel Gabriel did not disturb her, but what he said about her. What is going on here? The English words “highly favoured” in the verse above are a translation of the Greek word charitoo. This word occurs only twice in the New Testament: Ephesians 1:6 and Luke 1:28. This word Charitoo is a verb, which in essence means to “bestow favour.” It indicates an action that God performed on those who have found favour in His sight. For Mary the thought that she was highly favoured by God was something she would have found difficult to accept, just like many of us.

We know in our heads that God loves and accepts us, but we live and think as if he doesn’t. That is why our insecurities have such a massive influence upon our lives, for we think God could not love us, or we need to do better or be better so God will love us. This ingrained belief, that we are not totally or really accepted by God, will rob us of the courage and resilience to do the will of God.

‘Mary, God the father has a wonderful plan for your life, but before you know that plan you need to know that you are completely loved and accepted by God.’ Listen to this. God’s love is so great for you that he wants to form Jesus in you. See Galatians 4:19

Father help me to accept your love so I can do your will

And he will reign over Israel forever; his Kingdom will never end!” Mary asked the angel, “But how can this happen? I am a virgin.” he angel replied, “The Holy Spirit will come upon you, and the power of the Most High will overshadow you. So the baby to be born will be holy, and he will be called the Son of God. What’s more, your relative Elizabeth has become pregnant in her old age! People used to say she was barren, but she has conceived a son and is now in her sixth month. For the word of God will never fail.” Mary responded, “I am the Lord’s servant. May everything you have said about me come true.” And then the angel left her.#

The Holy Spirit makes the impossible possible.

Mary asks a very important question. “But how can this happen? I am a virgin.” This question was followed by a remark of self-awareness that indicated that Mary knew that she did not have the resources or ability to accomplish what God was asking of her. ‘I am a virgin.’ She did not realise that lack of resources and ability were the very things that qualified her for the task she was being called to.

I love the angel’s reply. The angel replied, “The Holy Spirit will come upon you, and the power of the Most High will overshadow you. So the baby to be born will be holy, and he will be called the Son of God.’

For Mary to fulfil God’s purposes for her life, and for Jesus, it would require a deep work of the Holy Spirit in Mary’s life. For Mary, the purposes of God for her, was tied to the work of the Spirit within her.

This is so important, Like Mary we will not be able to accomplish God’s good intentions and purposed for us, unless we are prepared to allow the Holy Spirit to produce new life within us.

When the angel talks about being overshadowed by the Most High, it is carrying the idea of being overshadowed in a harsh desert, and providing protection from the blazing sun. The same word is used twice in the Greek version of the Psalms to describe to protection of God. Psalm 91:4 ‘He will cover you with his feathers, and under his wings you will find refuge; his faithfulness will be your shield and rampart.’ Psalm 140:7 ‘Sovereign LORD, my strong deliverer, you shield my head in the day of battle.’

Mary although you may not feel it or think it, the safest place in the world is in the will of God.

As individuals we need to recognise our great need of the transforming, Christ forming work in our lives, for without it, we will never be able to accomplish what God may ask of us.

This encounter with the angel ended with these words:-

‘I am the Lord’s servant. May everything you have said about me come true.’ Like Mary’s nativity story, ours must lead to radical submission. ‘I am your Servant, A doule, a female slave. Needless to say, the role of a slave is not one that equates with pride, arrogance, haughtiness, or ego. It doesn’t equate with self-will or independence, either. To the contrary, it speaks of submission and brokenness."Mary placed herself completely at God's disposal, even though she knew the outcome would bring shame and disgrace on her in the eyes of her neighbours." Ralph Earle. Source unknown

Her body became a living sacrifice and a temple of the Holy Spirit.

If we are going to see Jesus transform our world, then we will need to echo the original nativity with our nativity story.

Father, may the Holy Spirit form Jesus in me

html:
In those days Caesar Augustus issued a decree that a census should be taken of the entire Roman world. (This was the first census that took place while Quirinius was governor of Syria.) And everyone went to their own town to register. So Joseph also went up from the town of Nazareth in Galilee to Judea, to Bethlehem the town of David, because he belonged to the house and line of David. He went there to register with Mary, who was pledged to be married to him and was expecting a child. While they were there, the time came for the baby to be born, and she gave birth to her firstborn, a son. She wrapped him in cloths and placed him in a manger, because there was no guest room available for them.

Some version translate verse 7 as ‘No room in the Inn.

We want to look at Luke’s record of the birth of Jesus. As we look at this story there are three hurdles we need to get over if we are going to grasp its importance.

1. This is a ‘well known’ story, most of us have been brought up on the Christmas story, and so we are familiar with it. We know that Mary and Joseph came from Nazareth to Bethlehem. We know how there was no room in the Inn so Jesus was born in a stable. Being over familiar, we are inclined to think that our understanding must be right.

2. When you read Luke’s account of the birth of Jesus, he does not say much about it. Someone has called Luke's record ‘A little duel of economical story telling.’

There are 1151 verses in the book of Luke, 7 of these verse deal with the circumstances surrounding Jesus’ birth. Only one verse deals with His actual birth itself. (Luke gives us a lot more details about the Shepherds.) His account feels very ordinary, there was nothing miraculous about Jesus’ birth. His conception was miraculous, the announcement to the Shepherds was miraculous, but the birth itself happened in a very ordinary, down to earth way, there were no miracles, no angels, just a teenage girl giving birth.

3. The fact that the bible gives us so few details regarding Jesus’ birth has led to lot of speculation, assumptions and misinformation. One of the reasons why we misunderstand the Christmas story, is because of a novel about the birth of Jesus known as The Protevangelium of James, which was published 200 years after the life of Jesus.

‘In the novel, as they approach Bethlehem, Mary says to Joseph, “Joseph, take me down from the ass, for the child within me presses me, to come forth.”7 Responding to this request, Joseph leaves Mary in a cave and rushes off to Bethlehem to find a midwife. After seeing fanciful visions on the way, Joseph returns with the midwife (the baby has already been born) to be faced with a dark cloud and then a bright light overshadowing the cave.’ Kenneth Bailey.

So we want to try and separate what may have happened and what definitely did not happen, and in doing so we will be more able to identify with the story.

1. The life of Jesus is revealed through the ordinary of everyday life. I think most of us like the Christmas story as we have always known it, it has a bit of a tabloid feel about it. A pregnant teenager giving birth in a cave/stable. Maybe the fact that we think Jesus was born in a stable means we can keep him at a safe distance, from ourselves, and we have no way of applying a stable birth scenario to our every day lives. But if we were to remove all the speculations, assumptions and misunderstandings we will not only discover a story about Jesus’ wonderful birth, but we will also discover some life forming applications for our own lives.

Father thank you that your grace can sanctify the ordinariness of life

html:
The birth of Jesus Luke 2:1-7

In those days Caesar Augustus issued a decree that a census should be taken of the entire Roman world. (This was the first census that took place while Quirinius was governor of Syria.) And everyone went to their own town to register. So Joseph also went up from the town of Nazareth in Galilee to Judea, to Bethlehem the town of David, because he belonged to the house and line of David. He went there to register with Mary, who was pledged to be married to him and was expecting a child. While they were there, the time came for the baby to be born, and she gave birth to her firstborn, a son. She wrapped him in cloths and placed him in a manger, because there was no guest room available for them.

Some version translate verse 7 as ‘No room in the Inn.

Let us consider what may have happened.

a. In the culture of Jesus’ day there was a strong culture of hospitality, and it would have been a shameful thing for a community not to offer hospitality, even more so to a young, pregnant girl. Hospitality was seen as a virtue. In the Old Testament, it was specifically commanded by God: “When an alien lives with you in your land, do not mistreat him. The alien living with you must be treated as one of your native-born. Love him as yourself, for you were aliens in Egypt” (Leviticus 19:33-34.

The Talmud even says that welcoming guests is “greater than welcoming the Divine Presence [Shekhinah].” the Mishnah says "Let your home be wide open and the needy be members of your household. In the bible hospitality was an expression of ‘hased,’ which carries a sense of love and loyalty that inspires merciful and compassionate behaviour toward another person.

b Joseph was returning to the village of his origin.

‘In the Middle East, historical memories are long, and the extended family, with its connection to its village of origin, is important. In such a world, a man like Joseph could have appeared in Bethlehem, and told people, “I am Joseph, son of Heli, son of Matthat, the son of Levi” and most homes in town would be open to him. It is more likely that Mary and Joseph were probably staying with relatives in Bethlehem, rather than trying to find the nearest travel inn. This actually makes more sense of the story, because for Joseph to return to Bethlehem for a census meant that he had to have strong links there, and if he had relatives there, it would make sense that he and Mary would have stayed with them.’ Kenneth Bailey

c. Jesus was probably not born immediately after Mary and Joseph arrived in Bethlehem.

Kenneth Bailey says. ‘Joseph had time to make adequate arrangements. Luke 2:4 says that Joseph and Mary “went up from Galilee to Judea,” and verse 6 states, “while they were there, the days were accomplished that she should be delivered” (KJV, italics added). The average Christian thinks that Jesus was born the same night the holy family arrived—hence Joseph’s haste and willingness to accept any shelter, even the shelter of a stable.’

https://oslermennonitechurch.org/wp-content/uploads/2023-12-31-Christ-Born-into-Community-Patty-Friesen.docx.pdf accessed 2/04/2025

d. The fact that Mary was pregnant would have increased the communities responsibility to care for her. Not to do so would require them to disregard their Jewish identity and their beliefs.

Luke tells us, ‘She wrapped him in cloths and placed him in a manger, because there was no room for them in the inn. When we read this verse there are two significant cultural things we need to keep in mind.

a. In this culture, poor families kept their animals inside at night. Most houses consisted of two rooms. One large room which was divided in two, a lower part and a higher part. The family lived and slept in the higher bit of the room and the animals were kept in the lower part of the room, they were kept indoors at night for safety, and to provide some more heat for the family. The upper part of the room often had a built-in manger which was assessable to the animals for feeding.

B, Many homes had a second room called the ’Katalyma,’ and this is the word Luke uses for Inn. The word Katalyma was used to describe the guest room. This is the same word used in Luke 22:11 and Mark 14:14 to describe the upper room where Jesus eat the passover with his disciples. The best translation of the word is ‘a place to stay.’ In the parable of the Good Samaritan Luke uses the word pandocheion, which refers specifically to an inn for travellers (cf. 10:34).

So, we never read of an Inn-keeper, nor is there any biblical evidence of Joseph or Mary being turned away from anywhere or being refused accommodation. So is is more likely that Jesus was born in the large family room that was adjoined to where the animals were kept at night.

Father thank that Jesus has come to be part of our families.

title: Study topic nativity part 13

html:
The birth of Jesus Luke 2:1-7

In those days Caesar Augustus issued a decree that a census should be taken of the entire Roman world. (This was the first census that took place while Quirinius was governor of Syria.) And everyone went to their own town to register. So Joseph also went up from the town of Nazareth in Galilee to Judea, to Bethlehem the town of David, because he belonged to the house and line of David. He went there to register with Mary, who was pledged to be married to him and was expecting a child. While they were there, the time came for the baby to be born, and she gave birth to her firstborn, a son. She wrapped him in cloths and placed him in a manger, because there was no guest room available for them.

Some version translate verse 7 as ‘No room in the Inn.

So we need to ask, ‘How should all this affect my life?’

1. The incarnation should radically affect our family life.

Think about it this way, The Jesus that is born in the stable is an excluded Jesus, he’s ‘out there,’he is not invading our space. And let us be honest, that is the kind of Jesus many people want. But the Jesus that is born in the ‘Katalyma.’ guest room, well he becomes a guest. We are so glad that he comes and stays for a while, we make a sporadic effort to accommodate him, we have time when we go out of our way to fit our lives around him. However, treating him as a guest means that at its essence the majority of our lives is not really about him. Being a guest in someone’s home is lovely but it is never the same as being part of the family, a guest will never have the same freedom as a member of the family.

I think it is so easy for anyone of us to put Jesus into the stable or the guest room in order to protect and control our own space. One of the first lessons we learn from the incarnation of Jesus is that he wants to sanctify the ordinariness of family life. The last place he wants to be is in a stable or a guest room, rather he wants to be, [and we need him to be] at the very heart of family life.

Let us take a step back and think about the implications of what this means.

a. Is our family life centred around Jesus? This is not an easy question to hear or to answer. Having a Christ centred family will only happen if it is intentional, it will never happen by default? How do we know if we have Christ centred family? One of the ways to answer that question is to ask ourselves if our lives as a family would be very different if we had no knowledge of Jesus or his presence. In other words, would/could our family life survive with little or no acknowledgement of Jesus? Has the reality of Jesus at the heart of our home become an absolute essential for our families and marriages.

b. Are our families a place where there is space for the life of Jesus to grow? Jesus was born in the heart if the family, not in the stable or the guest room, and it was in the context of the family that Jesus grew. As parents, Mary and Joseph were continually learning and discovering new things about Jesus. I like that. As families we need a corporate experience of discovering Jesus. I think at times we have over individualised our relationship with Jesus.

We have heard of married couples who are happy to do their own thing. He does his thing with his mates, and she does her thing with her friends, and occasionally they do something together. The reason I mentioned this, is because for the most part when it comes to our spiritual lives, there can be an over independence. We are like the above mentioned couple. We do our own ‘spiritual’ thing during the week. Then we go to church together on a Sunday. To be a Christian family which is Christ centred is about having a shared experience of Jesus in the context of our homes. Just let me say that being a church going family is very different than being a Christian family.

c. Are our families a place that is dominated by love. Could you say that love is the main thing that continually characterises you family life?

There is something fascinating about this passage that is very easily missed. Look how Luke describes Mary, ‘He went there to register with Mary, who was pledged to be married to him.’ He does not call Mary his wife, they were not married at this time. We know from Matthew 1:25. ‘But he did not consummate their marriage until she gave birth to a son. This is important because consummation was part of the wedding celebration, and Joseph did not want to be identified as Jesus’ biological father, so they probably got married after Jesus birth.

So think how radical Joseph’s love for Mary must had been. To completely accept her, never ashamed to be seen with her. His acceptance of Mary was deeply embedded in the reality of the life of Jesus. An authentic Christian home is where people are accepted because of the life of Jesus. Sadly in many homes that claim to be Christian, there is control, not acceptance, manipulation, not acceptance, a desire to change others not acceptance, resentment not acceptance. There are homes were the experience of love is the unusual rather than normal, where being served is more important than serving. And we have excluded Jesus to either the stable or the guest room. When our lives as families is defined by Jesus and his love, then we will be better resourced to deal with the inevitability of tension, stress and pain.

A Christian author, Kaylene Yoder wrote, ‘The condition of our hearts will shape the culture of our home.’

4.If the authentic life of Jesus is the essence of our homes it will affect those outside our home.

As we have said their was nothing miraculous about Jesus’ birth. It was a very ordinary birth. Mary had to go through all the usual labour pains in order to bring Jesus into the world. But what was miraculous was what happened in the fields of Bethlehem. Angles appeared to despised shepherds and they were drawn to Jesus

Their is a story in Mark 7 where Jesus wanted some time to himself verse 24 says.
He got up and departed from there to the region of Tyre. He entered a house and did not want anyone to know it, but he could not escape notice. Christian Standard Bible.

I love that. It was Jesus ‘In the house that could not escape notice,’ When the life of Jesus fills our homes the angles have something to sing about and the world becomes a better place. Their is something very powerful and relevant about a home that pulsates with the life of Jesus.

Jesus once said, “Anyone who loves me will obey my teaching. My Father will love them, and we will come to them and make our home with them.’ John 14:23. Jesus is not looking for a stable or a guest room, but a home. I want you to think about the culture of your family, is it Christ centred and Christ orientated? Are their strong tangible evidences that the life of Jesus is transforming the dynamics within our family life. It is interesting that the Incarnation of Jesus was first displayed through a family.

let us take Jesus out of the stable so he can be at home with us

Father forgive me for wanting to put Jesus in a stable

html:
Mary’s Song Luke 1:46-56

And Mary said: “My soul glorifies the Lord and my spirit rejoices in God my Saviour, for he has been mindful of the humble state of his servant. From now on all generations will call me blessed, for the Mighty One has done great things for me—holy is his name. His mercy extends to those who fear him, from generation to generation. He has performed mighty deeds with his arm; he has scattered those who are proud in their inmost thoughts. He has brought down rulers from their thrones but has lifted up the humble. He has filled the hungry with good things but has sent the rich away empty. He has helped his servant Israel, remembering to be merciful to Abraham and his descendants forever, just as he promised our ancestors.”Mary stayed with Elizabeth for about three months and then returned home.

We want to look at a passage of scripture that is known as the Magnificat, or Mary’s song. It can be divided into two sections. In the first section Mary talks about God’s dealings with herself (Luke 1:46-49) and in the second she speaks about God’s concern for justice for the world. (Luke1:50-55) I want to look at the first part of the song, and to do that I want to ask a question.

How can we prepare ourselves for the future? Or to put it another way, What preparation or changes do you need to make in your thinking so you can cope with the future?

Let me share a story with you.

During the British Antarctic Expedition of 1910-13, – Captain Robert Scott and four others tried to be the first to reach the South Pole, however, Roald Amundsen beat them by just over a month. While Amundsen and his men came back safely, Scott's party all died on the return from their expedition. - What led to the death of Scott's party?

There were a number of reasons why Scott failed.

Scott’s cumbersome and complex transport plans were an underlying cause of the disaster. They involved a team of dogs, 19 Manchurian ponies, and 3 experimental (and expensive) motor sledges. Ponies are unsuited to Antarctica. They suffered in the cold weather, delaying the start of Scott’s journey. Worse still, many of the animals purchased were old and worn out. 2 never reached Antarctica and 6 died on a preparatory journey. The motor sledges were even less successful.

Another major problem was the fact that Scott’s team’s rations were deficient in various nutrients, such as vitamin C, which caused them to suffer from scurvy. Scott made decisions that caused further problems. He had originally planned to travel to the pole with three other men. At the last minute, he took an extra person – Bowers. This made the tent cramped and increased the time it took to cook meals. It also caused logistical complications, as all the food supplies had been packed for groups of four. Almost all water on the continent is frozen. To get a drink, Scott and his companions had to melt ice and snow on their paraffin-burning stove. Fuel supplies were thus vital to keeping explorers hydrated. To reduce weight, the explorers left much of their fuel in cans in depots on their way to the pole, planning to pick these up on the way back. The problem was, that the cans leaked due to faulty seals. On the way back from the pole, Scott found that many contained much less fuel than expected. Without enough water, the explorers became increasingly dehydrated, hampering their physical and mental performance. To add to all this, there was a particularly harsh winter that the explorers were not prepared for.

Let’s think of the challenge that Mary faced. A much greater challenge than going to the South Pole, she had to raise The Son of God!!!

Unlike Scott and his team Mary made the right preparations. We are going to look at Mary’s song which gives us some insight as to how she saw herself, and how she built her life on a theological foundation so she could embrace the future that God had called her to.

It is so easy for any of us to go into life ill prepared. I understand we cannot plan for the unexpected, life happens, trouble comes and sometimes we can feel overwhelmed. However, there is a lot we can do, and one of the things we should do, is build our lives on a solid theological foundation so we will have the spiritual resources to cope with the future.

Often our spiritual lives are the last thing we think of when it comes to us making preparations for the future. We make plans around our families, our finances, our occupations, our leisure time, we prepare as much as we can for these things, and it is right that we do so. However, we rarely think that we need to be prepared spiritually for the future God is calling us to. It is so easy for any of us to go into the future not having prepared ourselves spiritually, and when life happens, pain comes, and God’s will seems too demanding, we don’t have the resilience or resources to cope.

Father help me to prepare spiritually for the future.

html:
Mary’s Song Luke 1:46-56

And Mary said: “My soul glorifies the Lord and my spirit rejoices in God my Saviour, for he has been mindful of the humble state of his servant.
From now on all generations will call me blessed, for the Mighty One has done great things for me—holy is his name. His mercy extends to those who fear him,
from generation to generation. He has performed mighty deeds with his arm; he has scattered those who are proud in their inmost thoughts. He has brought down rulers from their thrones but has lifted up the humble. He has filled the hungry with good things but has sent the rich away empty. He has helped his servant Israel, remembering to be merciful to Abraham and his descendants forever, just as he promised our ancestors.”Mary stayed with Elizabeth for about three months and then returned home.

1. She was spiritually minded.

As you read through this song you will notice that there are at least 15 references to God. Mary talks about God in two distinct ways. Who he is, and what he does. He is,

a. The Lord.

b. God.

c. Saviour

d. The Mighty One.

e. Holy.

And what he does.

a. He has done great things for me.

b. His mercy extends to those who fear Him.

c. He has performed mighty deeds with His arm.

d. He has scattered those who are proud.

e. He has brought rulers from their thrones.

f. He has lifted up the humble.

g. He fills the hungry with good things.

h. He sent the rich away empty.

i. He has helped his servant Israel.

j. He has remembered to be merciful.

For a 12-15 year old girl, Mary had a comprehensive view of God. How did one so young have such a high view of God. When you hear the words of Mary’s song, it is filled with Scripture, you will get allusions to Psalm 103, Psalm 22, Psalm 147, Psalm 98, I Samuel 1 (you’ll hear Hannah’s song in this), but you’ll also hear passages like Job 12. Mary knew her Bible.

J.C. Ryle says about her:

“She gives expression with her lips to what has been treasured in her heart; and what has been treasured in her heart is God’s word, the Holy Scripture.”  Quoted by Duncan, Ligon, https://fpcjackson.org/resource-library/sermons/mary-on-the-christian-life/

Here is the important thing, her spiritual mind, her knowledge of God and the scriptures, determined how she saw the world and her future in it. Her spiritual mindedness allowed her to submit to God.

If we are going to become spiritually minded then we will need to make saturating ourselves in the scriptures as a life long project. It is so easy in our busy lives to develop a minimalist approach to reading the bible. We just do enough that will make us feel okay about ourselves. We don’t create the space to think or meditate on the things we have read.

I would recommend that at times you create space for a ‘long read’ of scripture. As people we often struggle with taking in what they read, so the thought of sitting and doing a long read sounds very daunting. Let me give you a new perspective. Imagine you are eating a beautiful meal, and as you take the first few mouthfuls you are very conscious of the succulent taste, and the texture of the food, and you know that this food is good for you. However, as the meal progresses your awareness of the taste and texture of the food decrease.. The food hasn’t change, nor has it’s nutritional value, it is just that you have become used to the food, and maybe you are engaged in conversation making you less aware of the taste, you keep eating because you recognise that your body requires it. This same principle can apply to how we approach our bible reading. We can all say there is a lot that we read that we don’t understand or even remember, but we recognise that this is spiritually nutritious for us.

Father may my mind be saturated by your word

html:
Mary’s Song Luke 1:46-56

And Mary said: “My soul glorifies the Lord and my spirit rejoices in God my Saviour, for he has been mindful of the humble state of his servant.
From now on all generations will call me blessed, for the Mighty One has done great things for me—holy is his name. His mercy extends to those who fear him,
from generation to generation. He has performed mighty deeds with his arm; he has scattered those who are proud in their inmost thoughts. He has brought down rulers from their thrones but has lifted up the humble. He has filled the hungry with good things but has sent the rich away empty. He has helped his servant Israel, remembering to be merciful to Abraham and his descendants forever, just as he promised our ancestors.”Mary stayed with Elizabeth for about three months and then returned home.

She was a worshipper.

Listen to what she says."Oh, how my soul praises the Lord.

This is amazing, Mary has just found out that her plans and reputation were going to be trashed. She been told that she was going to be responsible for mothering the Son of God. She did not know what Joseph her betrothed would do when he heard she was pregnant. Also, to claim that Yahweh, the God Israel caused her conception, would have been blasphemous as that is something the pagans believed their ‘god’s’ would have done. She knew that she was going to be misunderstood and judged, but instead of being overcome with worry and self-concern, she worshipped.

Sometimes we sing ‘Come, now is the time to worship, Come, now is the time to give your heart, Come, just as you are to worship, Come, just as you are before your God.’ It is easy to sing this in church, but when you are facing the reality of an uncomfortable future, this becomes much more difficult, but probably more necessary.

Why?

Because when we worship God, we are reminding ourselves who He is, we are recognising his greatness and glory. It is in times of crisis, change and uncertainty that we need a more focused understanding of who God is. This fresh appreciation of God, is part of us preparing ourselves for the future.

"Mary's song’’ is called the Magnificat because the first word of it in Latin is Magnificat. Mary’s intense desire to magnify God became a determining influence that enabled her to accomplish God’s will for her life. The Greek word for praises is megaluno. It has two basic meanings. 1. To speak very highly of, 2. To show kindness. Mary had this deep hearts desire to speak highly of her God, and in doing so she was showing great kindness to God. For Mary, her recognition and praise of God in the present, gave her a confidence in God for the future. Here is a question we need to ask ourselves, ‘Is the exalting of God a natural part of our everyday conversation? Has it become our default language?

Father may my heart be always be filled with praise and gratitude for you,

html:
Mary’s Song Luke 1:46-56

And Mary said: “My soul glorifies the Lord and my spirit rejoices in God my Saviour, for he has been mindful of the humble state of his servant.
From now on all generations will call me blessed, for the Mighty One has done great things for me—holy is his name. His mercy extends to those who fear him,
from generation to generation. He has performed mighty deeds with his arm; he has scattered those who are proud in their inmost thoughts. He has brought down rulers from their thrones but has lifted up the humble. He has filled the hungry with good things but has sent the rich away empty. He has helped his servant Israel, remembering to be merciful to Abraham and his descendants forever, just as he promised our ancestors.”Mary stayed with Elizabeth for about three months and then returned home.

Mary had a proper understanding of herself.

How we see the future and Gods purposes in it, has a lot to do about how we choose to see ourselves. Often there are two sinful extremes as to how we perceive ourselves. We can either be full of pride and independent, or we can be full of shame and believe that we are of no value and of no use. These two sinful postures are self-centred and the antithesis to how Mary viewed herself.

Look how she describes herself. ‘For he took notice of his lowly servant girl, or his bound slave. She saw herself as HIS servant. HIS servant is a good way to understand the kind of people we need to be if we are going to have a proper attitude towards our future in God. This is not the first time Mary understood herself to be a doule, see Luke 1::38. She had developed the mindset of a servant.

Ralph Earl says, ‘That the Greek doule bound servant signifies that "Mary placed herself completely at God's disposal, even though she knew the outcome would bring shame and disgrace on her in the eyes of her neighbours." (Word Meanings) This word conveys the idea of the slave's close, binding ties with the master, belonging to him, obligated (desirous) to do his will. Her will is ideally all together subsumed in the will of the master.

We are all in a continual struggle between entitlement and servant-hood. We can go into the future with a must have attitude, I deserve, I am entitled. Or we can be like Mary, recognise that life is not about us but about Him. We can have a servant attitude that says ‘Lord no matter what, I want to be radically submitted and committed to you.

David Livingstone was a pioneer missionary to Africa, who walked over 29,000 miles. His wife died early in their ministry and he faced stiff opposition from other Christians. He prayed, “Send me anywhere, only go with me. Lay any burden on me, only sustain me. Sever any ties but the tie that binds me to Your service and to Your heart.”

Mary understood that the only way she could embrace the future purposes of God, was to have an authentic heart of a servant.

She did not allow her place in society to determine God’s future for.

As we read the Magnificat we can see that Mary was aware of two things about her life. Her status and God’s grace.

When she speaks about God being mindful of her humble state, she was referring to her social and economic deprivation, The word Luke uses for ’humble estate.’ comes from the Greek word tapeino which was almost used exclusively in a derisive way, most commonly of a slave. Try and think, if Mary lived in your town or village, she would probably live in the most deprived part. If she had a job, it would had been very lowed paid. She would have had no power, position or status and would have been unnoticed for her unremarkable life. She would probably have need of the foodbank, and may have found it difficult to fit into the middle class church. Yet, this poor, pregnant teenager, faced the future with great hope and high expectations. How was she able to think beyond her circumstances? How was she able to see past the difficult reality of her present circumstances? She was conscious not only of her low status, but also that she was blessed. In fact all generations would call her blessed.

In our thinking we often equate being blessed with the improvement of our circumstances. So we get money to pay a bill, or we get the job we were hoping for, our we meet the love of our lives. These are all blessings and we should be thankful for them, however, for Mary, the blessing of God did not improve her circumstances, in fact they made them more difficult. Yet she felt blessed. The blessing she was referring to was more profound, more significant and more life changing than circumstantial change and dreams fulfilled.

At this time in Jewish history there was a strong theological belief that the rich were blessed and the poor were cursed. And here was Mary able to see outside the confines of common theology to recognise that being blessed by God was much bigger than having our needs and desires met.

The word Luke uses for blessed in verse 48 is only found twice in the New Testament, here and in James 5:11. The idea behind it is, to be considered blessed by God. It is like Mary was saying, ‘God has called me blessed and the reason I am blessed is because I have the honour of submitting to His will so he can accomplish His purposes through me.’ For Mary a ‘blessed life’ was more about God working in her and through her than having fulfilled dreams, financial security, or a good job. The essence of a truly blessed life, is having an increased capacity to carry the life of Jesus into our world.

God may bless you with a prosperous future, or he may not. He may bless you by giving you the desires of your heart, or he may not. But He will definitely bless you, if you go into the future with a spiritual mind, and a submissive heart, then you will know the richest of all blessings, that is carrying the life of Jesus into your world.

Let me give you one more piece of information about Captain Scott. He and his friends died about 11 miles from a depot where there was fresh supplies. He almost made it, but he didn’t.

God asked a ‘big ask’ of young Mary, God asked her to go on a dangerous journey that would cost her everything for the rest of her life. She made it, because she understood that the only way to prepare for this journey was to develop and maintain a spiritual focus and have a spiritual character.

Father help me understand that I need to have the attitude of a servant
