html:
stud text Luke 3:23-38. Now Jesus himself was about thirty years old when he began his ministry. He was the son, so it was thought, of Joseph,

the son of Heli, the son of Matthat, the son of Levi, the son of Melki, the son of Jannai, the son of Joseph, the son of Mattathias, the son of Amos, the son of Nahum, the son of Esli, the son of Naggai, the son of Maath, the son of Mattathias, the son of Semein, the son of Josek, the son of Joda, the son of Joanan, the son of Rhesa, the son of Zerubbabel, the son of Shealtiel, the son of Neri the son of Melki, the son of Addi, the son of Cosam, the son of Elmadam, the son of Er, the son of Joshua, the son of Eliezer, the son of Jorim, the son of Matthat, he son of Levi, the son of Simeon the son of Judah, the son of Joseph, the son of Jonam, the son of Eliakim, the son of Melea, the son of Menna, the son of Mattatha, the son of Nathan, the son of David, the son of Jesse, the son of Obed, the son of Boaz, the son of Salmon, the son of Nahshon, the son of Amminadab, the son of Ram the son of Hezron, the son of Perez, the son of Judah, the son of Jacob, the son of Isaac, the son of Abraham, the son of Terah, the son of Nahor, the son of Serug, the son of Reu, the son of Peleg, the son of Eber, the son of Shelah, the son of Cainan, the son of Arphaxad, the son of Shem, the son of Noah, the son of Lamech, the son of Methuselah, the son of Enoch, the son of Jared, the son of Mahalalel, the son of Kenan, the son of Enosh, the son of Seth, the son of Adam,the son of God.

Up to this point Luke has given us a long introduction, a kind of a backstory. From chapter 1:5-3:20, Luke has been setting the stage, creating a historical context so we can understand who Jesus is. But now his focus is about to change. He wants us to get to know who Jesus really is, so in chapters 3:21-4:13 Luke uses three things to reveal Jesus identity.

Jesus’ identity is revealed through the voice of his Father. Luke 3:21-22

Jesus’ identity is revealed through his genealogy. Luke 3:23-38.

Jesus’ identity is revealed through his defeat of Satan. Luke 3:1-13.

Up to now Luke has basically told us about a lot of people and their relationship to the story of Jesus. Herod, Zechariah, Elizabeth, Gabriel, Mary, John, Augustus, Quirinius, Joseph, The Shepherds, The Angels, Simeon, Anna, Tiberius, Pontius Pilate, Herod Antipas, Philip, Lysanias, Annas and Caiaphas, 19 different individuals or groups identified, all playing a part in Jesus’ story to a greater or lesser degree; but now it is time for Jesus to take the centre stage. So Luke uses the witness of God in heaven at his baptism. The witness of mankind on the earth through his genealogy, and the witness of the defeat of Satan in the wilderness.

We want to look at the second of these witnesses the genealogy of Jesus. Before we look at the passage let me say a few things about it.

1. According to the Anchor Bible dictionary there are about 25 genealogies in the Bible. That is quite a lot. They are difficult to read, like reading the old phone books we used to get, and they are even more difficult to understand. They feel irrelevant to our lives. But we must remember that they are part of the inspired word of God. 2 Timothy 3:16-17 says:-

‘All Scripture is God-breathed and is useful for teaching, rebuking, correcting and training in righteousness, 17 so that the servant of God may be thoroughly equipped for every good work.’

2. One reason family history was important to Israel is that it proved one’s identity as a Jew. It was a legal instrument used to safeguard a persons inheritance and property. So a person’s genealogy entitled them to remain on the land God had given to that family/clan and tribe through Joshua. The genealogy was a bit like our deeds to our homes or land.

3. The Bible's genealogies were also important in determining who could serve in certain roles. These included only Levites working in the tabernacle and temple, as well as descendants of Aaron who were to serve as high priests. In addition, many activities in the Mosaic Law were limited to those who could prove they were Jewish descendants. They were something like a CV which helped authenticate a persons credibility to serve God in the tabernacle/temple.

Father thank there is nothing random about our existence, we are all part of a bigger story

title: Finding your place in the story of Jesus. Part 1

html:
So what can we learn from a list of 77 names?

1. The significance of the unknown is an essential part of Jesus’ story. As you read through this genealogy you will discover 36 names we know nothing about, some are not even mentioned in the Old Testament. People with no profile, just ordinary people had an essential part in Jesus’ story.

The story of Jesus and His kingdom, is really a story about anonymous people who choose to live their lives for God as best as they could.

Let me illustrate:-

Tobias and Ollie Ham owned a farm in Allen County near Scottsville, Kentucky Tobias [1847-1935] was a part time farmer and pastor, living in poverty. You probably have never heard of him. He had a son called Mordecai who became an evangelist. Mordecai was a controversial but successful evangelist. Now there was a farmworker called Albert McMakin, who you have probably never heard of either, invited his employers’ 16 year old son to a mission held by Mordecai in Charlotte in 1934. The son was called Billy, Billy Graham.

The genealogy of Jesus teaches that for the most part, God fulfils his purposes in history through the lives of anonymous people whose lives appear to be unremarkable, but they are an essential part of Jesus’ story.

Feelings of anonymity can cause a person to feel unnoticed, unimportant, of no value with nothing to contribute.

Today, there is a craving for notoriety, people want their 15 minutes of fame. The celebrity pop culture dominates social media, everybody wants to be a somebody. There is something known as FOBI which is the fear of being insignificant, and yet if you were to look at Luke’s genealogy of Jesus there seems to be more unknown than known.

Eli. Nothing else is known of him.

Matthat. Nothing else is known of him.

Levi. Nothing else is known of him.

Jannai. Nothing else is known of him.

Joseph. Nothing else is known of this Joseph.

Mattathias Nothing else is known of him.

Amos. Nothing else is known of him.

Nahum. Nothing else is known of him.

Hesil. Nothing else is known of him.

Naggai. Nothing else is known of him.

There are ten other names in Luke’s genealogy that we know absolutely nothing about.

We need to try and grasp the fact that being a part of Jesus’ story is the most significant thing about us. We may not be part of his genealogy, but we are part of his story. We may not be well known, or greatly gifted, but we are part of his story. Our achievements may be modest, our ministry may be limited but we are part of his story.

Father thank you that being anonymous does not rob us of significance.

title: Finding your place in the story of Jesus. Part 2
study_refs: 4. It is very significant that Luke’s genealogy of Jesus is one of the most contested portions of scripture, causing many sceptics to raise questions about the authentic identity of Jesus. If you were compare Luke’s genealogy with Matthew’s they are very different. Luke includes many names that Matthew doesn’t. Between Jesus and David, Matthew records 28 generations, as Luke Records 43 because his genealogy is more comprehensive. Matthew left out a number of names because his purpose for recording the genealogy was very different to Luke’s. The problem is that between Jesus and David, Luke's list has very different names to Matthew’s. In Matthew, Joseph’s father is called Jacob, while in Luke he is called Heli. After David is mentioned, the list are the same, then Luke goes past Abraham to Adam.

There have been many attempts over the years to try and reconcile these two genealogies. Some of these theories are very complicated and convoluted. One that is popular amongst evangelical scholars is what is known as the Metoridlineal Theory, which suggests that Luke traces Jesus’ genealogy through his mother Mary and not Joseph his step father. On the surface this sound very plausible, however, there are a number of problems with it. This is a recently new theory, it was first suggested in 1490 by Annius of Viterbo who was an Italian Dominican friar, scholar, and historian. I personally don’t agree with this theory because, Luke was a historian and he was very careful about what he recorded, and he tells us that Heli is the father of Joseph.

One possible solution could be that Matthew traces his line through Joseph’s mother and Luke traces it through his father. So the Jacob of Matthew 1:16 may be Joseph’s grandfather on his mothers side. And the Heli of Luke 3:23 may be Joseph’s actual father. We don’t really know.

html:
2. The genealogy teaches us that God honours and celebrates our humanity. When Luke wrote his gospel, he was writing to people who had been saved out of Greek and Roman culture. Greeks and Romans had a pantheon of gods that were seen as superhuman, often were cruel and sexually perverse. They were seen as distant and very different to humans. Zeus was the most important god to the Greeks. He was worshipped in every Greek home, and was famous for his promiscuity. Zeus was said to live on top of Mount Olympus with the other major gods. From there, he could see everything that humans did. He sent thunder, lightning, rain, and winds down to Earth.

When we compare Jesus with the common understanding that the Greeks had about ‘gods,’ this genealogy must have blown their minds This was unheard of, where God would come to earth, using the normalities of everyday living. Human body, [Mary], families, history. The genealogy of Jesus, teaches us that he is one of us. These early Greek/gentile Christians may have had to rethink their understanding of God. A God who comes close, a God who understands, a God who shares our experiences.

Listen to this:-

‘Shattering records with their seemingly non-stop output of movies and t.v. shows, Marvel is the movie franchise that has steadily become the highest-grossing in the world. Among many other high-grossing film franchises in the U.S. and Canada (Harry Potter, James Bond, Lord of the Rings, etc.), Marvel takes first place with a staggering $10.2 billion lead ahead of Star Wars in second place. While this may surprise some, that number doesn’t even include the X-Men or Spider-Man franchises. Thanks to the endless amounts of usable material from generations of comic books, the end of the Marvel universe may never come.’ https://www.ign.com/articles/highest-grossing-marvel-movies.

The reason why I share this is because the Marvel movies, are based on the Greek and Roman mythological gods. It may be that their popularity and success is because these movies reflect the kind of god most people really want. A strong deliverer who is so different to us, so that we don’t need to have a relationship with him.

The genealogy of Jesus sanctifies the ordinary. It teaches us that God uses ordinary people to bring his redeeming purposes into the world. Yes there were a few notable names in Luke’s list, but as we have seen many were named but unknown.

Father thank you we are human enough to be part of the story of Jesus

He was the son, so it was thought, of Joseph, the son of Heli, the son of Matthat, the son of Levi, the son of Melki, the son of Jannai, the son of Joseph, the son of Mattathias, the son of Amos, the son of Nahum, the son of Esli, the son of Naggai, the son of Maath, the son of Mattathias, the son of Semein, the son of Josek, the son of Joda, the son of Joanan, the son of Rhesa, the son of Zerubbabel, the son of Shealtiel, the son of Neri the son of Melki, the son of Addi, the son of Cosam, the son of Elmadam, the son of Er, the son of Joshua, the son of Eliezer, the son of Jorim, the son of Matthat, he son of Levi, the son of Simeon the son of Judah, the son of Joseph, the son of Jonam, the son of Eliakim, the son of Melea, the son of Menna, the son of Mattatha, the son of Nathan, the son of David, the son of Jesse, the son of Obed, the son of Boaz, the son of Salmon, the son of Nahshon, the son of Amminadab, the son of Ram the son of Hezron, the son of Perez, the son of Judah, the son of Jacob, the son of Isaac, the son of Abraham, the son of Terah, the son of Nahor, the son of Serug, the son of Reu, the son of Peleg, the son of Eber, the son of Shelah, the son of Cainan, the son of Arphaxad, the son of Shem, the son of Noah, the son of Lamech, the son of Methuselah, the son of Enoch, the son of Jared, the son of Mahalalel, the son of Kenan, the son of Enosh, the son of Seth, the son of Adam,the son of God.

The genealogy of Jesus, teaches us that God uses the lives of individuals to accomplish his sovereign purposes in history. As we have said, the most significant thing about any of us, is the part we play in the story of Jesus. We may, or may not know what part we are playing. Many in the genealogy had no idea that they were playing a part in Jesus coming into the world. God was using their lives to ensure that the glory of his sovereign plans would be revealed. The genealogy of Jesus shouts ‘your life is about much more than you.’ Our lives are about God and his continual involvement in history. That does not mean that God just sees us as inanimate objects like pieces on a chess board that he moves at his whim. Rather we are his co-workers, his ‘instruments of righteousness’ that tell his story to this present generation.

The first name that Luke mentions in this chapter is Tiberius, who’s full name was Tiberius Caesar Augustus son of god. For him to have this title meant he had to be born into a royal family with pomp, power and prestige.

Jesus also came from a royal family, but at the time of his birth there was no pomp, power and prestige. Jesus the Son of God was born into the ordinary, making the ordinary extraordinary.

Father most of the time I am unaware of my part in Jesus’ story.

title: Finding your place in the story of Jesus. Part 4

html:
For you is life exhausting and full of great stress. Has the known and familiar, been replaced with uncertainty and insecurity. Has life become so difficult, have you lost loved ones, or have you lost jobs and financial security. Others who used to be fit and healthy are now no longer. Maybe your plans have been cancelled, hopes have been dashed and dreams shattered. And yet in the mist of all this exhaustion and pain of life we can have a wonderful, life enhancing hope.

A hope that we read about in the Christmas story. A hope that is realistic, down to earth, kind of hope, that enables us to cope with the harsh realities of the present. The hope of the Christmas story is a hope that is not some kind of wishful thinking, it is not a hope that allows us to bury our heads in the sand, so we can pretend that the chaos and pain of our lives is not real. The glorious hope we read about in the Christmas story, and in the rest of the Gospels could be summed in one word. Emmanuel. She will give birth to a son, and you are to give him the name Jesus, because he will save his people from their sins.”All this took place to fulfil what the Lord had said through the prophet: The virgin will conceive and give birth to a son, and they will call him Immanuel (which means “God with us”).
The name Immanuel describes the essence of the heart of God.

The name Immanuel is a profound revelation of the heart of God.
It expresses God’s dreams and hopes.

It reveals God’s deepest desires. ‘God with us.’

In that name the purpose of creation is explained, ‘God with us.’

In that name the goal of salvation is discovered. ‘God with us’

In that name the will of God for our lives is disclosed, God with us.

Often when we think of salvation we think in these terms. ‘God has saved me so
that when I die I will be able to go to heaven to be with Him.’ That is absolutely true, however there is an other truth that I think is even more important
for the here and now, and that is, ‘God has saved me so that he can be with me
on earth.’ Immanuel sums up how our lives need to be defined in the here and
now. If this is true then how can we relate to this God, and what difference will it make to the crazy, messy confusion of my life?

a. We can relate to God and know that he is with us because of Jesus. Before the angel told Joseph to call the baby Immanuel, he said ‘You shall call His name Jesus Because he will save his people from their sins.’

Let me give you a personal illustration that might help us. Having a disability means that not everyone can relate to me, sometimes they don’t understand me, {I can’t think why!} At other times people feel awkward or embarrassed, so they avoid meaningful contact. Sometimes people don’t have the right character our abilities they need to engage with me. This is the kind of problem we all have with God. Our sin inhibits and limits our ability to know, enjoy and engage with God We need to understand that the most serious consequence of our sin is that it prevents us from having intimacy with God.
Father thank you as Immanuel, Jesus is able to relate to me and understand me.

html:
Look carefully at what the angel said to Joseph, ‘You shall call His name Jesus Because he will save his people from their sins.’ This would have been mind blown for Joseph. Nothing had every been said like this before. Let me explain, Being a Jew, Joseph would had been taught the importance of going to the temple at least three times a year to make sacrifice for the forgiveness of sin, as well as for other things.

These sacrifices for forgiveness were extremely limited in two ways. One they were only a sign post to God’s ultimate sacrifice in Jesus. But, secondly although the animal sacrifice assured the person making them of forgives, they were unable to save them from their sin, that is the power of sin. When we read ‘You shall call His name Jesus Because he will save his people from their sins.’ we automatically assume that this is speaking forgiveness. This statement includes forgiveness, but it is a lot more. Jesus wants to break the power or control of sin in our lives so we can enjoy Immanuel. Paul wrote in Romans For sin shall no longer be your master, because you are not under the law, but under grace. 6:14

If God is with us, then how do you explain all the crazy stuff that is happening in our lives? That is a very good and important question. When you read that the angel told Joseph that the child would be called Immanuel Joseph was in the middle of a crisis. This was a time of emotional confusion, uncertainty and fear. Mary, his betrothed, was pregnant outside marriage, she claimed that God was the father, which which would have been perceived as blasphemy. This was far from being an ideal situation. And yet, it was here that Joseph learned about the glory of Immanuel.

The life of Joseph teaches us that our need for ‘Immanuel.’ God with us, will always be greater than our need for a change of our circumstances. When life is very difficult and painful sometimes God will come and change our circumstances, but very often he wont, because he understands that experiencing him with us in the crisis is what we really need.

‘To stand in the presence of God, that is what the gospel is. The Gospel is not primarily about forgiveness. It is not primarily about good feelings. It is not primarily about power. All these things are by products, sparks. It’s primarily about the presence of God.’ Timothy Keller.
https://quotefancy.com/quote/921425/Timothy-Keller-To-stand-in-the-presence-of-God-that-is-what-the-Gospel-is-The-Gospel-is accessed 2/04/2025


“Why do some persons 'find' God in a way that others do not? Why does God manifest His Presence to some and let multitudes of others struggle along in the half-light of imperfect Christian experience? Of course the will of God is the same for all. He has no favourites within His household. All He has ever done for any of His children He will do for all of His children. The difference lies not with God but with us.― A.W. Tozer, https://www.goodreads.com/quotes/1112562-why-do-some-persons-find-god-in-a-way-that accessed 2/04/2025

We have been created and designed for divine immanence, that is why Jesus is Immanuel. We need to teach ourselves that although the removal of difficult circumstances is rightfully desirable our greater need is the intimate presence of God.

At times the wounds of life are so deep and so acute that the only way we can fully recover is to have our hearts and mind marinated in the healing presence of God. . Immanuel comes to us in the normalcy of everyday life. When you think about the circumstances that brought Immanuel into the world were not very spectacular or impressive. They was no red carpet, no welcoming dignitaries, no formal civic reception, no grandiose event to receive Immanuel. Just a couple who were ordinary, a couple who had no power, position or prestige. A young girl who had conceived outside marriage giving birth in a strange place far from home. This is the way it had to be, because Immanuel wants to be God with us in the ordinariness of our everyday lives. Immanuel with us in our ordinariness is the real glory of life. In our homes, in our marriages, in our families, in all our relationships, at our work, in our lack of work, in our school, in our university course, in our health, in our sickness, in the good times, in the bad times and in every other situation and circumstance of our lives, is where Immanuel longs to be.

Father I need to know Immanuel in all of life

html:
How can we know our Immanuel, how can we move from assuming that God is with
us to experiencing God with us? experiencing the presence of God begins with a choice. We must choose to believe in and recognise His presence. Have you ever went into a room and you have tried to ignore someone, or for what every reason you have just not realised they were there. That is how we often we react or respond to the presence of God. We can either ignore him, or assume that he is not there.

Years ago when I lived and worked in Donegal a group of people from Hamilton Road Baptist Church came to see us. I went into the room where they were, and guess who was the first person I looked for? Caroline. Why, because I loved her and was excited that she was there. And that is something like how we should be thinking about Immanuel. Every room we walk into in life, the first thing we should do is look for Immanuel, the presence of the living God.

Often when life is very difficult we can pursue solutions, we want to fix things.
Our we look for answers or explanations, and we ask questions like, What is God
doing? Or, what is God saying? These are great questions to ask, however,
sometimes we need ‘presence’ before we need solutions or answers. Our hearts
need to engage with the one who loves us more than anyone else.

Experiencing the presence of God happens when we recognise that God wants to encounter us in all of life. When it comes to our understanding of ‘spirituality’ in our western thinking we usually have two main categories, spiritual and unspiritual. We compartmentalise our lives into ‘God categories,’ and ‘worldly categories,’ This is known as Platonic thinking where you have areas of our lives that are set apart for God and the other parts God has no interest in. Often we are not conscious of thinking this way. This subliminal thinking will create in us a default position that says something like ‘I don’t expect to encounter God at….’Biblical spirituality is the antithesis to platonic thinking, For it believes that all of life is about God and in every area of life he can be encountered and known. Are their areas of your life where you don’t really expect to experience Immanuel. For example, when you got to work, our school do you every think I might encounter God today. Or would we have no expectation or desire for such an encounter. You may be out for coffee, our working in the garden, our having and family time at home, our out on a date with you wife, or a million other scenarios, but they all contain the potential of having an encounter with Immanuel.
When Immanuel comes to us so we cam become the people we are meant to be. If you were to really think about it, there is nothing demeaning of diminishing about enjoying the presence of God. In fact the complete opposite happens, the experienced presence of God encourages and animates a person. We are never more alive than when our lives are touched by his presence. It is in His presence our true identities are discovered. It is in accepting presence we are free to be who we really are. God will manifest his presence in our lives through the work and ministry of the Holy Spirit, and it is through his presence God manifests the intensity of His love. Sometimes we need to create a ’sacred space’ were we prioritise drawing near to God so he can pour his love into our hearts. As we draw to God, he draws near to us, and it then we discover the glory of being who we were meant to be.


we must not understand Immanuel just as someone who helps us in our ‘crisis management,’or who ‘enables us for ministry,’ He does do that, but primarily we need to understand Immanuel, God with us, the core essential for life.

O God please be with us.

Father I acknowledge that I need to experience your presence in every area of

my life.

Jesus Reinstates Peter

When they had finished eating, Jesus said to Simon Peter. “Simon son of John, do you love me more than these?” “Yes, Lord,” he said, “you know that I love you.” Jesus said, “Feed my lambs.”Again Jesus said, “Simon son of John, do you love me?” He answered, “Yes, Lord, you know that I love you.”Jesus said, “Take care of my sheep.” The third time he said to him, “Simon son of John, do you love me?”Peter was hurt because Jesus asked him the third time, “Do you love me?” He said, “Lord, you know all things you know that I love you.”Jesus said, “Feed my sheep. Very truly I tell you, when you were younger you dressed yourself and went where you wanted; but when you are old you will stretch out your hands, and someone else will dress you and lead you where you do not want to go.” Jesus said this to indicate the kind of death by which Peter would glorify God. Then he said to him, “Follow me!” Peter turned and saw that the disciple whom Jesus loved was following them. (This was the one who had leaned back against Jesus at the supper and had said, “Lord, who is going to betray you?”)When Peter saw him, he asked, “Lord, what about him?” Jesus answered, “If I want him to remain alive until I return, what is that to you? You must follow me.”Because of this, the rumour spread among the believers that this disciple would not die. But Jesus did not say that he would not die; he only said, “If I want him to remain alive until I return, what is that to you?” This is the disciple who testifies to these things and who wrote them down. We know that his testimony is true. Jesus did many other things as well. if every one of them were written down, I suppose that even the whole world would not have room for the books that would be written.

John 21 is one of those chapters that is well known and it is a passage that
people like to speak on, yet in many ways it is a bit of an unusual chapter that
feels a bit out of place, like an after thought, like a post script. The reason
why I say that is because of what it says in the last two verses of chapter 20 we read.

The NIV reads:-
The Purpose of John’s Gospel.
‘’30 Jesus performed many other signs in the presence of his disciples, which are
not recorded in this book. But these are written that you may believe [This is bettter understood as ‘go on believing’,] that Jesus is the Messiah, the Son of God and that by believing you may have life in his
name.’’

This seems to be a good ending point for the book, a neat conclusion. Then we
read, ‘’Afterwords Jesus appeared again to his disciples, by the Sea of
Galilee...’ So why do we have this post script? this ‘apparent’ appendix? John 21 could be viewed as an ‘encapsulation’ of who Jesus is and what he came to do. Twice in the chapter John uses the word phaneroo ‘appeared, this term conveys the showing of one’s character, motivations or intentions, and it comes from the verb phainō, which means “to shine.”

So as we consider John 21 we need to keep in mind that Jesus’ actions and
words were intended to give His disciples a fuller and deeper revelation of who
he is. You could also say that this chapter not only gives a revelation of Jesus,
but it also gives us a micro synopsis of John’s gospel, and a fitting summation of
all the gospels. For in this chapter we have a demonstration of resurrection life
and power. This may seem a bit surprising, but when I think of living in resurrection power I am inclined to think terms of the spectacular, the impressive, the powerful. But as you read John 21 it feels very ordinary. Okay, there was the great catch of fish, but everything else feels very down to earth. Men out fishing, catching nothing, frustration, failure, disappointment, a barbecue on the beach, difficult conversations. No fireworks or awesome displays of power. But there was the gentle healing power of grace, which is what resurrection power is all about.

Father thank you for the gentle power of the resurrection.

To fish or not to fish? That is the question

The chapter begins with these words. ‘’Afterwards Jesus appeared again to his disciples, by the Sea of Galilee. It happened this way. Simon Peter, Thomas also known as Didymus, Nathaniel from Cana in Galilee, the sons of Zebedee, and two other disciples were together. “I’m going out to fish,” Simon Peter told them, and they said, “We’ll go with you.” So they went out and got into the boat, but that night they caught nothing.’
There has been a lot of debate about whether Peter was being obedient or
disobedient when he went fishing. There are a lot of arguments that can be
made either way. However, I think that the question about Peter’s obedience in
this context is the wrong question to ask. I am not saying that obedience is not
an important issue. However, there are times when we can over simplify things
and just have two categories were everything falls, obedience or disobedience. As we shall see Peters problem was much deeper and more profound than obedience or disobedience.

1. Peter was motivated by a sense of shame.

The bible does not tell us what Peter is thinking or feeling, but we can be certain that he was in a very vulnerable condition. He was in danger of being redefined by his failure. He had betrayed Jesus three times with oaths and curses. He had boasted that although everyone else would forsake Jesus he would never. How could he ever get back from this? He is now motivated by shame, he hast lost all his confidence, so he retreats to where he feels safe and in control, to a place he knows well, a comfort zone.

Peter fishes for answers.

What have I done? What were those three years about? Who was Jesus? Where is he? Who am I? What will I do now? Where will I go? What will happen to me? Peter is searching for meaning, a way forward, a place in life. He goes fishing hoping to ease his pain, trying to get beyond his guilt, possibly believing that all his hope and desires to follow Jesus were gone. He found it easier to go fishing than deal with the consequences and the emotional turmoil of his failure.

We all know what it is to fail, we all know what it feels like when we want to disappear, to become unseen. When we are struggling with personal failure, there is something comforting being out in the middle of the sea in the black of night where we are unnoticed. Our shame and guilt create in us a strong desire for isolation. We are often driven by intense sense of shame, and we wrongly conclude that we are worthless of acceptance and love. It is in this dark place we need to encounter the risen Lord, and yet, if we are honest, this is the last place we want to encounter him. I love the fact that Jesus came to Peter where he was. Peter was not in prayer meeting, or at a special retreat. No he was in the mess and confusion of his everyday life. Jesus met him in the last place you would not really expect Jesus to be. Our everyday lives need to be touched and influenced by Jesus and his resurrection grace. We need to be open to the process of restoration, so we will not be defined by our failure.

Peter experienced the mercy of an empty net.

We read in verse 5 ‘He called out to them, “Friends, haven’t you any fish?” “No,”They answered.’ A better reading of this verse would be, ‘He called out, you haven’t caught any fish have you?’ This is more of a statement than a question. It is as if it had been planned or ordained that Simon Peter and the other disciples would catch no fish. In the frustration and disappointment of an empty net Peter learned that he had not the ability to fix what was going on in his heart, and fish in a net was not going to change anything. Sometimes we think, ‘if only,….’ believing that if the ‘if only,’ blank was filled in, we would feel better about ourselves. We often try to medicate our pain with stuff when want we really need is renewal in our relationship with Jesus.

Peter needed to learn that his eagerness to please Jesus would not remove

the need to have a difficult conversation. As you read this passage you get the impression that Peter wanted to please Jesus in an attempt to replace the pain he had caused. Listen to these words. ‘Then the disciple whom Jesus loved said to Peter, “It is the Lord!” As soon as Simon Peter heard him say, “It is the Lord,” he wrapped his outer garment around him (for he had taken it off) and jumped into the water….. So Simon Peter climbed back into the boat and dragged the net ashore. It was full of large fish.’

Look at what Peter did.
As soon as he heard, he wrapped his outer garment around himself, he jumped into the water, He climb back into the boat He dragged the net ashore He made every effort to please the Lord. I am sure the Lord appreciated his eagerness, however, eagerness and the desire to please would not go far enough to deal with the real pain of his heart.

When we fail and feel compromised it is very easy to think ‘if I try harder, or if I do better then I won’t fall into the same trap, or make the same mistakes.’

Enthusiasm is important but it will not address the reasons why we failed in the first place. Peter’s enthusiasm was an honest expression of his desire to please Jesus, but there was a need to go beyond enthusiasm to healing and wholeness. And sometimes that can be a process.

Peter needed to learn that acceptance proceeds restoration.

Look at what verse 10 says. ‘’And then Jesus says to them, ‘Bring some of the
fish you have just caught.’ Jesus is asking His disciples for something. Can you
imagine what that must have communicated to these disciples? Perhaps the
disciples think that they have nothing Jesus needs; they have nothing to offer
Jesus whatsoever, he doesn’t need them. But Jesus says, ‘No, I want to eat
your fish. I value what you have caught. I value what you have to bring to me.

The second thing Jesus does to show how he accepted Peter and the rest of the
disciples was he said ‘Come and have breakfast.

Being invited to a meal at the time of Jesus signified deep friendship, intimacy and unity. So before Jesus chose to have a difficult conversation with Peter, Jesus did everything he could to help Peter feel accepted.

This is very interesting because we usually work the other way round. We think
in terms of ‘Sort yourself out then we will accept you,’ but we need to understand that people change because they are loved. It is only in the context of accepting love that significant life-changing confrontation and conversation can take place.

Jesus needed to have a difficult conversation with Peter.‘’When they had finished eating, Jesus said to Simon Peter, “Simon son of John, do you love me more than these?” “Yes, Lord,” he said, “you know that I love you.” Jesus said, “Feed my lambs.”1 Again Jesus said, “Simon son of John, do you love me?” He answered, “Yes, Lord, you know that I love you.” Jesus said, “Take care of my sheep. The third time he said to him, “Simon son of John, do you love me?” Peter was hurt because Jesus asked him the third time, “Do you love me?” He said, “Lord, you know all things; you know that I love you.” Jesus said, “Feed my sheep.”

This was a very difficult conversation for Peter, we are told that he was hurt. The word John uses carries the idea of heaviness or distress. Sometime Jesus needs to come to us and ask us uncomfortable questions, questions that are critically important and life defining.
Consider what Christ doesn’t do. He doesn’t try to make Peter feel guilty. He doesn’t humiliate him publicly. He doesn’t ask him, “Are you sorry for what you did?” He doesn’t make him promise to do better. He just asks one question:

Father thank you that you restore us, and for the way you restore us. Bible in a year reading plan Job 32:11-35:16

But Jesus did not say that he would not die; he only said, “If I want him to remain alive until I return, what is that to you?” This is the disciple who testifies to these things and who wrote them down. We know that his testimony is true. Jesus did many other things as well. if every one of them were written down, I suppose that even the whole world would not have room for the books that would be written.

“Do you love me?” Jesus knew that Peter needed to discover a life that would be defined by Jesus’ love for him, and his love for Jesus. Peter needed to make a public declaration of his love and commitment.

Let us take a step back and consider this. Jesus is standing in front of us asking us if we have a life defining love for him. What I find fascinating is that Jesus cares about how we love him. Talking to Peter after he had defeated Satan, sin and death, having all authority in heaven and earth. Yet his power and position did not take from Jesus his desire for our love. If you see yourself as a follower of Jesus, then you need to know that your love for Him is important to him. A good question to ask ourselves is not do I love Jesus, but what kind of love do I want to have for Jesus?’

When Jesus asks, ‘Do you love me’? He is wanting to uncover the very essence of
who we are. He is wanting to bring to the surface the motives and desires that
drive and compel us.

When Jesus asks, ‘Do you love me’? He is really asking ‘What are you living for?

When Jesus ask, ‘Do you love me’? He is teaching us about what it really means to be human. Having a life defining love for Jesus is the highest and best expression of our humanity.
We need to understand the ‘Do you love me’? Question first and foremost Jesus’ pursuit of intimacy with peter. Notice Jesus did not say ‘do you love ministry or do you love my plans but ‘Do you love me’?


Peter failed Jesus very badly, he denied his Lord and caused great pain and distress, and although his failure was both critical and serious, it did not define him. He went on to become a leader in the church, someone God used to make a difference. However, his leadership was not based on his strength, or his ability, or his power, but on Love, love for Jesus, and love for the people of God. ‘If you love me feed my sheep.’ Let me see your love for me in how you care for others. Don’t say you Love Jesus and you don’t care for others.

John 21 is a chapter that teaches us about the restoring power of the resurrection, it teaches us that we do not need to be defined by failure but we can live lives that are defined and shaped by love. Let me finish with a quote.

from Augustine

St. Augustine (354-430) “What does love look like? It has the hands to help others. It has the feet to hasten to the poor and needy. It has the eyes to see misery and want. It has ears to hear the sighs and sorrows of men and women.

That’s what love looks like.”

Father please please grow my capacity to love you. Bible in a year reading plan Job 36:1-39:12

study_refs: Afterward Jesus appeared again to his disciple by the Sea of Galilee. It happened this way: Simon Peter, Thomas (also known as Didymus), Nathanael from Cana in Galilee, the sons of Zebedee, and two other disciples were together “I’m going out to fish,” Simon Peter told them, and they said, “We’ll go with you.” So they went out and got into the boat, but that night they caught nothing. html:
Have you ever thought to yourself,

‘What would it be like to love God with all of my heart for all of my life?’ Have you ever dreamed of living a life that is ablaze with the reality of God? A life that is more about longing than apathy. A life that cannot settle for shallow mediocre spiritual existence that lacks the reality and revelation of God.

Listen to these quotes:-

Speaking about longing for God.
‘The soul must long for God in order to be set aflame by God’s love; but if the soul cannot yet feel the longing, then it must long for the longing. To long for the longing is also from God.’ Meister Eckhart. https://www.azquotes.com/author/4339-Meister_Eckhart/tag/soul. Accessed 10/07/25

‘I want to deliberately encourage this mighty longing after God. The lack of it has brought us to our present low estate. The stiff and wooden quality about our religious lives is a result of our lack of holy desire. Complacency is a deadly foe of all spiritual growth. Acute desire must be present or there will be no manifestation of Christ to His people. He waits to be wanted. Too bad that with many of us He waits so long, so very long, in vain–‘ A W Tozer.

https://www.goodreads.com/quotes/7452324-i-want-deliberately-to-encourage-this-mighty-longing-after-god

Longing for God is a basic trait of authentic Christianity and an essential requirement for faithfulness. Longing for God makes the difference between cold, dry, dead religion and a life of compassionate zeal and joy.

We want to look at the life of someone who loved God with all her heart for all her life. Her name is Anna, which is the Greek version of the Hebrew name Hanna. Both these names mean grace. She is mentioned once in the bible, and her life is covered in three verses, 84 words in the NIV, and yet her story is both encouraging and challenging. She demonstrates what it means to grow old faithfully.

Her Family.

Anna was from the Tribe of Asher. Anna’s father was called Phanuel, which means the face of God.

Asher’s name is said to mean “happy, contentment, richness, affirmation.” In the biblical account, Joshua assigned to Asher, western and coastal Galilee, a region with comparatively low temperature and much rainfall, making it some of the most fertile land in Canaan, with rich pasture, wooded hills, and orchards; as such Asher became particularly prosperous, and known for its olive oil. The daughters of the Tribe of Asher had a good reputation and were sought after as wives by the Priests and Kings of Israel..

There is a lot we do not know about Anna, but we can be sure that she was not living in her family inheritance. If what we are told about how beautiful and sought after the daughters of the tribe of Asher were, then in all probability as a young widow, Anna would have had ample opportunity to remarry.

Her Role.

Anna is introduced directly as a "prophetess!" Anna had the gift of prophecy and was apparently known to possess that gift since Luke calls her specifically "the prophetess Anna." She is certainly notable as a prophetess because there had not been any truly inspired spokesperson for God for 400 years, since the prophet Malachi! In the Bible there are six other named prophetess’. In the Old Testament: Miriam (Ex. 15:20), Deborah (Judges 4:4), Huldah (2 Kings 22:14), Isaiah’s wife (Isa. 8:3), and Noadiah (Neh. 6:14) The sixth one was Jezebel (Rev 2:20.) an evil prophetess

The title ‘Prophetess’ does not mean that she constantly foretold the future, or that she put herself forward publicly, but that she knew and interpreted the Word and the will of God, for the edification of others. A prophet/prophetess is “one who speaks for a God and interprets his will to man,” or, in a more general sense, an “interpreter.” Anna loved God with all her heart for all her life because she allowed the purposes and gift of God to define who she was. She was the only one who was willing to listen to God and speak for God at this time.

We are not all called to be prophets/prophetess’, but we are all called to have lives through which God speaks. The perpetual silence of God FROM our life is spiritually deafening to the world around us. Lives that don’t carry and explain the voice of God are plugs in the ears of the lost..

Father I want to love you with all my heart for all my life, Bible in a year reading plan Job 39:13-42:9
title: Anna part 1
study_refs: Anna, a prophet, was also there in the Temple. She was the daughter of Phanuel from the tribe of Asher, and she was very old. Her husband died when they had been married only seven years. Then she lived as a widow to the age of eighty-four. She never left the Temple but stayed there day and night, worshipping God with fasting and prayer. She came along just as Simeon was talking with Mary and Joseph, and she began praising God. She talked about the child to everyone who had been waiting expectantly for God to rescue Jerusalem.’

html:
Anna grew.

Luke tells us that she was advanced in years. Her age has been an issue of some debate. She evidently became a widow after only seven years of marriage. The next phrase means either that she lived to the age of 84 or that she had been a widow for 84 years. If the latter is true, having probably gotten married at the age of 14, she would now be 105. In either case, she’s old! The amazing thing about Anna, despite a lifetime of pain and loss, she demonstrated a robust and tangible love for God. She was widowed as a young women. In this culture widowhood was to guarantee poverty. This was why in the days of the early church, Paul urged YOUNG widows to remarry so the church was not overly burdened with their support. (1st Timothy 5:14.)

We need to make an important distinction, there is a vast difference between growing old and growing up. All who grow old do not grow up. Some people grow old and become cantankerous and selfish. They allow the pain of the past to become defining. Anna’s pain was real and profound but it did not make her bitter or angry.

In the natural sequence of events, growing old should be twinned with growing spiritually, the older we become, our need and desire for God should grow. I have been struck recently by Daniel, as an old man he prayed three times a day. Old age can be very difficult, our bodies slow down, we have a lot more limitations, we suffer aches and pains and we are unable to do what we once could. In the light of all that it can become a bit depressing. However, there may be a more positive way to view growing old. We need to become excited about the spiritual opportunities that old age can bring. In our later years we have more time and often less responsibility. Think about that, more time for spiritual disciplines, more time to pray, more time to read God’s word, more time to think about, and talk about spiritual things. More time to share your faith with others, more time to regain the spiritual ground we may have lost to our past. We should try see the free time that comes with old age as an opportunity to rescue our devotional lives from the minimalistic habits that may have shaped them in the past.

This may sound a bit idealistic, and it is, it may even sound unrealistic, and it is, if we have no strong desire for God. In the story of Anna, Luke needed to use spiritual verbs to describe and explain Anna’s life. ‘Serving, worshipping, fasting, praying.’ Imagine living a life that could be only explained by spiritual language. It seems that Anna had a life-long hunger for God. Would that not be amazing? Day after day hungering for God. Week after week hungering for God. Month after month hungering for God. Year after year, after year hungering for God. Decade after decade after decade after decade, hungering for God. Being possessed by a holy discontentment that would reshape our lives. This is something we should all pray for, and life-long hunger for God.

Anna did not allow those around her to determine her spirituality.

Did Anna live and sleep in the Temple? There were living quarters surrounding the Temple precincts, however, no one was permitted to sleep within the Temple itself, nor were women allowed to stay there at night. Luke’s point is simply that she was there at every available hour.

There is something we need to remember, at this time in the history of Israel the temple for the most part was descending into corruption. Herod had great influence in the life and running of the temple. He appointed the high priest, which was a political appointment. It became a place marked with greed and the abuse of power for example. Because Jewish law required a temple tax of a half-shekel (Exodus 30:11–16), Jews and visitors from other nations came to pay their taxes when they offered their sacrifices. However, foreign coins with the image of pagan emperors would not be accepted in God’s temple, so money changers exchanged those foreign coins for Jewish money, but they did so at an exorbitant profit. Rather than provide this service as a business in another part of town, they exploited the religious zeal of the visitors to Jerusalem and did their business on temple grounds. Because they determined their own exchange rate, money changers easily took advantage of the poor and the foreigners pouring into Jerusalem for Passover. When they brought their animals for the sacrifice it was deemed “unapproved” so this forced the worshipper to buy another animal—at an inflated price—from the temple vendors. Such goings-on, exploiting the poor and the foreigner, angered the Lord Jesus and was strictly forbidden in the Mosaic Law (Exodus 22:21; Leviticus 19:34).

Further more Anna was at a huge disadvantage because of her gender. While Jewish women enjoyed more respect in that day than women in other cultures, there still was a fair amount of discrimination against them. The rabbis did not approve of the same amount of instruction in the Torah being given to girls as to boys. They regarded women's minds as not adapted for such investigations (Alfred Edersheim, Sketches of Jewish Social Life [Eerdmans], pp. 132–133). The women were restricted to an area of the temple called “The Women’s Court.” They could not enter the inner court where the ceremonies were performed. The segregation of women into a separate place was never mentioned or found in the Old Testament

It was into this environment that Anna chose to live for God. She did not allow her circumstances or others to dumb down her spirituality. She would have received little if any encouragement from the religious authorities, but she decided to march to the beat of a different drum. She decided to walk the road less travelled. She decided not to go with the crowd or follow the herd. She knew the potential of living for God and recognised that the loneliness of authentic absloute faithfulness was a price worth paying.

Can I just say that Anna was a very courageous women. It would have been very easy for her to acquiesce to formulaic religion, where she could have ticked all the right boxes, she could have gone through the motions, but she would never have encountered Jesus. Her courage kept her from the spiritual mediocrity of her peers.

Anna had the ability to understand who Jesus was.

Luke tells us, ‘Coming up to them at that very moment, she gave thanks to God and spoke about the child to all who were looking forward to the redemption of Jerusalem.’

This is amazing, Anna did not have some great vision, or a visit from an angel like Zechariah. No, she was just going about her every day ordinary pursuit of God when she encountered the awesome vulnerability of God in a child.

One commentator writes

‘Anna possessed divine insight into things normally hidden from ordinary people, and hence was able to recognise who the child in the temple was and then to proclaim his significance to those who were interested’.’ (G. Friedrich, TDNT VI, 836).

Did other people see Jesus that day?

Yes and no. Most saw a poor young couple with a baby, making the required sacrifice for dedication. Two saw Jesus, the revelation of God, in the context of the familiarity of their every day lives.

Could it be that in the familiarity of our lives is the best and the most important place to encounter Jesus? I think on that day in the temple that day there were two very vulnerable people, God incarnate in the small weak body of baby Jesus, and an old widow called Anna. On that day they touched each other lives. On that day Anna knew that the choices and sacrifices she had made were all worth it. On that day Anna learned that the purpose and ultimate goal for this life was Jesus. Anna loved God with all her heart for all her life. Oh that we would be the same! Father may I be like Anna. title: Simon from Cyrene part 1
study_refs: Mark 15:21. A certain man from Cyrene, Simon, the father of Alexander and Rufus, was passing by on his way in from the country, and they forced him to carry the cross. The record for most extras in a film is in the 1982 classic Gandhi, which used over 300,000 extras for the funeral scene. About 200,000 were volunteers and 94,560 were paid a small fee (under contract). The sequence was filmed on 31st Jan 1981, the 33rd anniversary of Mohand as K. Gandhi's funeral. 11 crews shot over 20,000 feet of film, which was pared down to 125 seconds in the final release. In the massive drama of the passion of the cross it could be very easy to miss the role played by others who could be perceived as ‘extras,’ seen as those who have blended into the background, with very little significance to the plot line,

Simon of Cyrene could be viewed in this way. We know that he was the man who helped Jesus carry his cross. He is known and unknown. He is there but rarely seen. Why would three of the gospels mention him? Matthew 27:32, Mark 15:21 and Luke 23:26;. He was from Cyrene, modern day Libya, about 900 miles from Jerusalem. Cyrene had a large Jewish population, it may be that Simon had travelled to Jerusalem for the passover. Two other things to mention. He had two sons Alexander and Rufus who were known to the early church, see Romans 16:13. And Luke tells us that Simon was going into the city as Jesus was about to leave it, and it then he was forced to carry the cross of Jesus. Although Simon never says a word in scripture this incident in his life has a lot to say to us. Simon was someone who shared in the Suffering of Jesus, he was the only person who helped Jesus on this terrible day. To share in Christ’s sufferings was one of the Apostle Paul’s aspirations when he said ’I want to know Christ—yes, to know the power of his resurrection and participation in his sufferings, becoming like him in his death. ’To participate in the suffering of Jesus is ‘fellowship of the heart,’ it is the deepest kind of relationship anyone can have with Jesus, it is the sharing the feeling of sorrow that happens when we choose to share his cross. At the place of suffering there is also the simultaneous call to intimacy. So what does it mean to share in his suffering? We need to accept the unexpected burdens that are forced upon us. In those days a Roman solider had the right commandeer any civilian to carry a burden like their kit, or the patibulum the cross-bar of the cross that usually weighed between thirty or forty pounds and was usually strapped across the shoulders. No Roman soldier would disgrace himself by carrying a cross for a criminal, so they forced Simon to carry the cross. This was not something that Simon was expecting, or anticipated, he was a passing by when he was forced into the drama of the cross. Often in life unexpected burdens come our way, burden that draw us into dramas that we don’t fully understand. We find ourselves in circumstances that are beyond our control, our freedom is taken from us, our plans are lying in ruins. we could feel a bit like Simon, embracing something that feels cruel and reeking of death. Maybe this is the only way we have of sharing in the fellowship of Jesus’ suffering. We will never have to re-enact what Simon did on ‘good Friday, but at some points in our lives the burdens that are enforced upon us will cause us to decide if we are really prepared to endure the burden, and pay the price of following Jesus to the extent that we can have fellowship in his suffering. Like Simon we have no control or say what burden we may have to carry, however, we can choose to allow those burdens to direct us in the way of Jesus. The unexpected crisis, burdens and interruptions that disrupt our lives could be the things that make Jesus more real. They could be the means where by we can follow Jesus on a path we would never choose for ourselves.

html:
He would have been unable to fulfil his intended purpose for his visit to Jerusalem. Sometimes, when we begin to share in the sufferings of Jesus, our plans get thwarted, even good spiritual plans that we have earnestly made. I find this very challenging. Something in me would rather go to the temple with the masses, and have an easy ‘religion’ than carry a cross, I find it easier to hold onto my old religious ways than carry a defining cross behind Jesus and be viewed as an object of disdain and criminalised by my association with him. To carry the cross of Jesus would not had been seen as a badge honour but a symbol of profound shame. There was no visible glory in this act of sharing in Jesus’ suffering, but there was a profound identifying with him that is only possible in suffering.

One final thought. The way of the cross is not for ‘super-hero’s.’ Jesus’ body had been robbed of its strength because of a long night of interrogation and brutal torture. As God he could have adorned the ‘cape of divinity,’ As the God man he could had made the journey to Galgotha in his own strength. But instead he chose in humility, to embrace his humanity and all its weakness and pain. He allowed himself to need the help of another. This is still the way of the cross. We either can be a Simon or we need a Simon. To share in the sufferings of Jesus means that you become more than a passer-by. Have you ever thought about the character of a passer by. A passer by is someone who makes little if any difference, they are people who take no concern or responsibility for those they are passing. Sadly it is too easy for anyone of us to live our lives as those who simply pass by. We keep our distance, we don’t get involved, we are focused on our own journey. However, when we begin to share in the suffering of Jesus, we loose our status as those who simply pass by. We become those who will accept the cross so we can follow Jesus.

One of the greatest tragedies for any Christian is not having a cross to carry, or not knowing how to carry it, thus, becoming someone who just passes by. To share in the suffering means that we become a part of the greatest and most essential work in the history of the world. This is the opposite to just passing by. The will of God is accomplished through those who have their present interrupted by the cross, and the future defined by the cross. Those who humbly accept the shameful, humiliating position of accepting the cross are those who are able to carry out God’s purposes because their lives is no longer about them.

we have been given circumstances and burdens that we haven’t chosen for ourselves. Like Simon, our hopes and plans have been destroyed. However these days may give us a unique opportunity to follow Jesus in ways that we haven’t done before and to share in His suffering so that we can experience the depth of fellowship with Him we all long for. As God’s story unfolds in these days, let us not become like those who just pass by but let us become people who are used by God to show his story to the world.

Father I confess it is so easy to embrace the status of a ‘passer by’ who does not get involved.

title: Simon from Cyrene part 2
study_refs: There is a possibility that Simon may had been a Jewish pilgrim who had travelled from Cyrene to celebrate the passover. If this is the case, he was a man on a spiritual journey who desired to meet with God. He may have been looking forward to coming to the temple, possibly for the first time to make sacrifices in the temple. This may have been something he had looked forward to for a long time; but there was a problem. When he began to carry the cross of Jesus he would have been designated as being unclean, preventing him from going to the temple, from making sacrifices and excluded from the passover celebrations. As the cross was placed on his back he was no longer able to partake in his religious /customs and practices of the passover. He was separated from the ritualistic worship of his fore fathers through the cross of Jesus.

Look at the following list.

a. Be a positive influence on others. Matthew 5:13-16.

b. Don’t live angrily with others. Matthew 5:21-22.

c. Pursue to make peace with others. Matthew 5:23-26.

d. Don’t exploit others sexually. Matthew 5:287-30

e. Don’t make excuses for lack of commitment. Matthew 5:31-32. [The people of Jesus’ day made any excuse to wrongly divorce their wives.]

f. Keep your word to others. Matthew 5;33-37.

g Do not retaliate. Matthew 5:38-42.

h. Love your enemies. Matthew 5:43-48.

I. Give to the poor. Matthew 6:1-4.

j. Be Authentic. Matthew 6:5-7,

k. Develop a life of dependence on God. 6:7-18.

l. Relationships are more important than possessions. Matthew 6:19-34.

m. Don’t be judgmental Matthew 7:1-6.

n. Be kind Matthew 7:12.

o. Don’t hide behind ministry Matthew 7:15-23.

The way people relate to each other within the Kingdom of God should be very distinctive to how others relate. There should be a freshness, a depth, an attracting beauty. High definition relationships that display the glory of God.

Our relationship with others is the primary indicator of the kind of relationship we have with God. However, if we are going to build, sustain and grow healthy relationships that honestly reflect authentic submission and love for God then we will need to learn how to forgive. In the sermon on the mount Jesus addresses the issue of forgiveness.

We want to look at what Jesus said about forgiveness in this context, then try and apply what it means to our lives.

We need to acknowledge that forgiveness is a very emotive and difficult subject. Many of us have been greatly hurt, we carry wounds that may never heal, many have known the pain of rejection, the pain of betrayal, and the thought of expressing forgiveness to that person feels traumatic, if not impossible.

We need to get a clear understanding as to what forgiveness is and what it isn’t.

Often we have a very confused or distorted understanding when it comes to forgiving others, which makes the act of forgiving more difficult.

Forgiveness is not belittling the pain you have suffered. It does not mean that the pain of betrayal will disappear. It does not mean that the pain you have suffered does not matter. In fact the act of forgiving helps manage and control the hurt, preventing it from developing into bitterness.

Forgiveness is not condoning someone's evil behaviour towards you. Forgiving is not saying, the evil act you did to me does not matter, it does matter, and because it matters I need to engage in the process of forgiving.

Forgiveness is not absolving someone of the consequences of their bad behaviour. Forgiveness will not eradicate the consequences that are the result of your sin against someone.

Forgiveness is not forgetting. Many in the church teach the false practice of ‘forgive and forget.’ when in reality to ‘forgive and forget’ makes authentic forgiveness impossible because it is a refusal to deal with the real issues. God has made us in such a way that it is Psychologically impossible to totally eradicate all memory of hurt done to us in the past. People would often say that God forgets our sins, that is not true, God chooses not to remember them, see Jeremiah 31:34.

Not forgetting does not mean that we obsessively continually recall every detail, rather we acknowledge the hurt of the past in such a way that it can’t define who we are and who we are becoming.

Forgiveness does not mean that you should not maintain protective boundaries to prevent further hurt or abuse.

In our passage Jesus makes six direct references to forgiveness. It is as if Jesus wants us to understand how important forgiveness is for the maintaining of healthy relationships. Father do my relationships please you?

Bible in a year: Psalms 11:1-17:5
title: forgive part 1
study_refs: If we were to sit down and read through the Sermon on the Mount you would discover one main theme, one major note, which is relationship. The sermon is describing those who live under the authority and rule of the Kingdom of God. How that rule is manifested and seen in our lives, is through how we relate to others. It is as if Jesus is saying that the only authentic indication that you are living for me is through your relationships; not your ministry, not you work for God, but the quality of your relationships.

html:
These word are a footnote or an appendix to the Lord’s prayer. They are a commentary on verse 12 which reads, And forgive us our debts as we also have forgiven our debtors. So what is Jesus saying?

1. Those who are forgiven will forgive.

As we have already said, forgiving others can be very difficult, painful and demanding, especially if we have been severely hurt or traumatised by them. Forgiveness can feel like a step too far. Yet we are confronted by these words of Jesus.

We need to look at who Jesus is talking to here. He is not talking to those who are needing initial, first time forgiveness for entry into relationship with God. These people were already clearly believers in Jesus' mind. These are people that possess the kingdom of heaven (5:3, 10), who hunger and thirst after righteousness (6), who are called the sons of God (9), who are the salt of the earth (13) and the light of the world (14) and who have God as their personal Father in a relational way.

These are people who have experienced and enjoyed the enriching freeing power of the grace of God; they are people who have learned that they can be redefined by forgiveness. They are people who have had their shame removed. So for them not to show forgiveness is to belittle what God has done in their lives and deny who they have become in Jesus.

As Christians, God expects us to be the most forgiving people.

In the New Testament, the word forgiveness was used primarily to describe the release of someone from a financial obligation. Forgiveness gives up the right to hurt back. When you forgive someone, you are saying, “What that person did to me was wrong. He has hurt me deeply and deserves to pay for his offence. But today I am releasing him of the obligation he has toward me. I am not forgiving him because he has asked to be forgiven or deserves to be forgiven. I am forgiving him because of the tremendous forgiveness God has offered me. Asking for God’s forgiveness for one’s own sins, all the while withholding forgiveness from someone else, is not only bizarre but hypocritical.

We forgive because our relationships are important to our Father.

One of the things God will hold us accountable for is the nature and quality of our relationships. Imagine two children sitting in the back arguing, and mum and dad are in the front of the car, overjoyed, thrilled and delighted that the children are arguing and fighting. Of course, that would never happen. When I have an unforgiving heart towards others, I am internalising my conflict with them. We can weaponise our emotions, and begin to harbour feelings of resentment and bitterness. Sadly the church has created a consumer approach to relationships. I get involved with others if they meet my needs, and if they hurt me then I am free to walk away, my relationship with them is like a ‘soiled nappy,’ disposable. I don’t have to work through the issues and the struggles of forgiving.

We are never more like God than when we forgive.

The glories of the character of God is most clearly seen when we have a heart of forgiveness. The life of Jesus is best displayed through our love and forgiveness of others. When we forgive another person, we discover that we are participating in a supernatural event. God not only gives the command to forgive, but the power to forgive. Conversely, when we abstain from the difficult process of forgiving and choose not to forgive, then we are never less like God.

Father may the attitudes of my heart echo your heart.

title: forgive part 2
study_refs: What Jesus says. ‘For if you forgive others their trespasses your heavenly father will forgive you, but if you do not forgive others their trespasses, neither will your father forgive you.’

html:
One of the difficult issues regarding others is the question of their repentance, if they are not sorry, then how can we forgive?

We need to stand on the porch. What do I mean. We all know and love the story of the ‘prodigal son.’ while telling this story Jesus said these words, ‘“But while he was still a long way off, his father saw him and was filled with compassion for him; he ran to his son, threw his arms around him and kissed him.’ The son was ‘still a long way off, and his father saw him and filled with compassion he ran.’ The father had developed a heart that longed to forgive his son, he longed for the opportunity to show mercy. Maybe he sat on his porch, scanning the horizon, looking and longing, ready to run at the least glimmer of repentance?

In some ways the question of the offending persons repentance is irrelevant, for this reason, the repentance of the ‘offender, although essential, will not increase my ability to forgive. It may increase my opportunity to forgive, but not my ability to forgive. If I am not living with the hope and expectation of forgiving the person who has hurt me before they repent, I am unlikely to feel different if they repent.

We forgive because we refuse to define the person who has hurt us by the harm they have done to us.

There are two pitfalls we need to avoid that will hinder us in our desire and ability to forgive. We can cause the hurt caused to us to become defining. So we develop a victim mindset. Sometimes, the pain is so deep, and the circumstances in which we were hurt were so dark that it is a huge battle not to live as a victim.

On the other hand, if we have been deeply hurt by someone, it is very difficult to see past what they have done, and their offence against us becomes the only way we choose to identify them. When God forgives us he is choosing not to allow our sin to become means by which he identifies us. Does that mean he ignores or belittles our sin? Of course not. As sinful people we are more than just sinful people. And as forgiven people we have an opportunity to see people as more than those who have hurt us.

One final question:- What does it mean when Jesus said ‘But if you do not forgive others their trespasses, neither will your father forgive you.’ What is he saying? We know from other scriptures that nothing will separate us from the love of God, we also know that salvation is a gift from God, it is something you cannot earn or deserve.. so how are we to understand these words? I think what Jesus may be saying here is, ‘If we choose not to forgive, God will hand us over to the consequences and the fruit of our unforgiving attitude.’

An unforgiving attitude will produce a rotten, bitter harvest in our lives, not in the lives of others. It will diminish us into small graceless people who will use their energy to carry and maintain their resentment and bitterness.

When God hands us over to the consequences of being unforgiving, what happens?

Could I suggest the following?

1. Our fellowship with the Father is blocked.

2. The Holy Spirit is grieved.

3. Our prayers will not be answered.

4. God leaves us alone to face the problems of life in our own power.

5. The devil gains a foothold through our bitterness.

6. We waste time nursing a wounded spirit.

7. We become enslaved to the people we hate.

8. We become like the people we refuse to forgive.

9. We can develop physical and psychological problems.

.

Although the bible is insistent that we live as forgiving people, it never down plays how difficult and costly forgiving others can be. No one knows this truth more than God. The price and pain he paid to forgive us cannot be measured. When God the Father allowed his dear son to be murdered at the cross, one of the things we learn is that although the price of forgiveness is high, Love chooses to pay it.

Father may I have ‘a sitting on the porch’ attitude scanning for an opportunity to forgive. Bible in a year reading plan Psalms 18:37-21:13

html:
We know that what Jesus says here is in the setting of a passover meal. The passover meal had two main functions, one was to remember the great deliverance God accomplished when he rescued his people from Egypt. The second purpose of the passover was to remember the covenant God had made with his people Israel. The covenant God made at Sinai was seen in two distinct ways. It was seen as a king making at agreement with his subjects. But, it was also seen and understood as a marriage covenant.

In Exodus 6:6-7 we read these words

Therefore, say to the Israelites: ‘I am the Lord, and I will bring you out from under the yoke of the Egyptians. I will free you from being slaves to them, and I will redeem you with an outstretched arm and with mighty acts of judgment. I will take you as my own people, and I will be your God.

Here God promises to do 4 things/[1] I will bring you out, [2] I will free you, [3] I will redeem you, [4] I will take you.

Over time these promises became the words that were used in a Jewish marriage proposal. This is what a young man would say to the lady he wanted to marry. This proposal was also re-enacted during the passover. During the passover they would drink from the cup four times, each time would represent one of the four promises. The passover was a proposal meal.

Father thank you that Jesus as our groom wants an intimate relationship with us.

study_refs: The passage we are looking is a very well known passage, it is a passage that is often used as an evangelistic or an apologetic text that shows people that Jesus is the only way to the Father. Although it may be legitimate to use the text in the way, I don’t think that this was its intended purpose. Jesus is speaking to those who have made a commitment to follow him. He is speaking to people who’s world is about to fall apart. This is a pastoral passage, where Jesus wants to equip those who love him with the resources to cope with the inevitability of trouble, uncertainty, confusion and fear. Part of the problem with this passage, in my view is that it has been ‘over heaven-ised.’ by that I mean that most people assume that Jesus is referring to heaven in this passage and his purpose is to generate hope in the hearts of his disciples. I am sure there is an element of truth in this kind of application, but I don’t think this was Jesus’ intention. Nor do I think the disciples would have thought about heaven when they heard these words.

I think that the over emphasis to heaven has robbed these verses of some of their present day application. In John 16:1 Jesus said, ‘ All this I have told you so that you will not fall away.’ The idea behind the word for fall away is that of an animal caught in a snare or a trap, with the complete loss of freedom.

The words that Jesus spoke at this time were to help his disciples to remain faithful, to keep going. You could say than in John chapters 14-16 Jesus defines faithfulness. So how are we to understand John 14:1-14? Before we look at our passage let me give you some cultural background.

html:
Consisting of two ceremonies separated by a period of time.

The first ceremony was known as the Erusin, or betrothal. Here the man would make the four ‘I will’ statements. They both would sign the KETUBAH which was a legally binding agreement, then they would share a cup of wine. The father of the groom would pay the mohar, which was originally the purchase price of the bride, and it is therefore understandable why it was paid by the father of the groom to the father of the bride. In ancient days, marriage was not an agreement between two individuals, but between two families. This ceremony would end with the groom giving gifts to the bride that would help her cope with his absence.

After the ERUSIN the groom would return to his fathers home and build an extension onto his fathers house. This may have taken a long time, and the father of the groom would decide when the room was complete and appropriate for his sons new bride. It was then and only then was the son able to go back to his bride and bring her home for the NISUIN the second ceremony, which included celebration and consummation of the marriage.

It is with this cultural context that we need to interpret what Jesus is saying to his disciples. When Jesus says ‘I go to prepare a place for you he was speaking and thinking like a betrothed groom.

Father thank you are looking to see in us the faithfulness of a spouse.
