html:
When Jesus says to Thomas that he is ‘the way’ he is saying that intimacy and devotion are essential for faithfulness in this troubling world. Like us Thomas did not get what Jesus was saying. Thomas was thinking in terms of directions, he wanted a road map, a how to. But he needed to change his thinking, he needed to recalibrate his understanding. I do not think Jesus was thinking about or referring to heaven when he said these things. But he was trying to teach his disciples how to remain faithful in times of trouble.

During the period between the ERUSIN and the NISUIN the bride had to remain completely faithful and exclusive to the groom. They could not ‘disengage,’ The only way of breaking the covenant made at the ERUSIN was through divorce. So she needed to wait, not knowing when her groom would return for her.

To know Jesus as ‘the way’ is to view him in the same way a young Middle Eastern bride would see her groom. For her all her hopes, dreams, desires, expectations and longings are on her groom. He is the way to her future. He is more than an acquaintance, he is not some kind of add-on to her life, he is her life, He is her future.

Let us take a step back and ask ourselves some hard questions. Do we really want Jesus to be ‘the way’?

Do we have the emotional ability to so invest our lives in Jesus that we know that all my future hopes and dreams depend on an intimate relationship with him?

Some of us may need to rediscover the way. We feel lost and disconnected, we live more like jilted lovers than expectant brides. We have lost the joy of our first love, we have no intense desire or consuming passion for the one we used to love. We need to rediscover the way, for if we don’t our lives will be reduced a dry religious statement instead of a dynamic relationship.

Father thank you that placing all our hope in Jesus is the ‘way’.

html:
Knowing the Father is the essence of intimacy. John’s gospel is a gospel about the father. In chapters 13-17 there are 50 references to the father, and in verses 6-13 of our chapter there are 12 references; there is an intensity, a depth, a depiction of the kind of father God is and the kind of father he wants to enjoy.

John 14:10 says. ‘Don’t you believe that I am in the Father, and that the Father is in me? The words I say to you I do not speak on my own authority. html:
In our culture we often struggle with the idea of loving others as a command. Our understanding of love is usually seen as a feeling or an emotion, and although there are feelings and emotions involved, love is best understood as a deliberate choice of our wills to be submissive to the purposes and desires of God. You could say that living a life of submission to God is living a life that loves others. Love needs to be rooted in deliberate acts of obedience because if our love for others is motivated by our emotions then it will be fickle and inconsistent.

Jesus says “A new command I give you: Love one another. As I have loved you, so you must love one another.

In the new testament we are told 15 times to love one another, In the writings of John we are told 9 times to love one another, twice in his gospel and 7 times in his letters.

John summarises the Gospel with these words. And this is his command: to believe in the name of his Son, Jesus Christ, and to love one another as he commanded us. 1 John 3:23. We also know that in the Old Testament we are commanded to love one another Leviticus 19:18.

So how is this a new commandment?

The word new has idea of ‘fresh.’ Or a ‘new kind’ of something that is a contrast to what previously existed. If you think of it in this way. If you were to compare today's iphone with the first iphones, they are both iphones, but they are very different. When Jesus speaks about a new commandment, he is giving the old commandment a new depth, a new intensity, a new dimension. He is saying ‘love each other, but it must be in the same way that I have loved you.’

2. What does it mean to love people in the way Jesus loves us?

a. It is not complicated.

In chapter 13 of John, Jesus shows us what he is thinking about when he talks about

loving others the way he loves us. The interesting thing about this chapter is that there are no miracles, no awesome displays of power, nothing spectacular.

It was Jesus responding to an everyday circumstance. Or in the words of Richard Foster ‘Jesus took a basin and a towel and redefined greatness.’ https://oursinglepurpose.wordpress.com/2013/01/14/a-towel-and-a-basin-spiritual-discipline-of-service. Accessed 11/07/25

John tells us that ‘Having loved his own who were in the world, he loved them to the end.’ Some translations read ‘He showed them the full extent of his love,’ There was nothing half-hearted, or dispassionate about this love. The simple humble act of foot washing was the complete or full expression of Jesus’ love.

b. It requires security and humility.

Look at how John describes Jesus’ thinking at this time. John 13: ‘Jesus knew that the hour had come for him to leave this world and go to the Father. Having loved his own who were in the world...Jesus knew that the Father had put all things under his power, and that he had come from God and was returning to God.’

Jesus knew that this was the time of his death, John 13:3 ‘Jesus knew that the hour had come for him to leave the world.’ But he did not see himself as a victim of unfortunate cruel circumstances that were outside his control. He lived out of a security that allowed him to be humble. He had come from God and was returning to God.

At its root all pride is an expression of insecurity. Many people go through life never knowing the glorious joy of having their ‘feet washed,’ because of their insecurity and pride. There is a very interesting thing we miss in our English versions. When it says in verse 4 that Jesus ‘took off his outer clothes.’ the word used for ‘took of,’ is ‘tithemi. This word means to put something in it proper place, it is the word the New Testament uses for being ordained. Servant hood is essential if we are going to fulfil God’s ordained purposes for our lives.

c. Feet washing is symbolic.

To ‘wash someone’s feet,’ is a symbolic act of radical, humble, sacrificial, practical serving love that chooses to meet the needs of others despite their own personal circumstances, status or position. Any inability on our part to ‘wash feet,’ to show radical, humble, sacrificial, practical serving love that chooses to meet the needs of others despite our own personal circumstances, status or position robs us of our humanity.

Think about this question:-

‘My life would not be the same if I could not…?

What are some of the answers you would put in?

‘My life would not be the same if I could not see, or could not hear, or could not do my job, or be married!

But have you ever thought,

‘My life would not be the same if I could not wash other peoples feet!’ probable not.?

Are we prepared to ‘wash feet’ This may appear to be irrelevant and unimportant, but it’s not, because how we answer this question will go some way in determining what kind of person we are, or what kind of person we are going to become.

If we are not prepared to wash peoples feet,

a. We will never be like Jesus.

b. We will never be the people God wants us to be.

c. We are living in disobedience

d. We will never love people with the love they most need, Love them the way Jesus loves us. Unless we are prepared to be loving sacrificially in each others lives then we are not authentic followers of Jesus.

d. Jesus expects us to follow his example.

Look at these words.

Now that I, your Lord and Teacher, have washed your feet, you also should wash one another’s feet. I have set you an example that you should do as I have done for you.

Notice what Jesus did not say Now that I, your Lord and Teacher, have washed your feet, you also should wash my feet. It would be an honour to wash Jesus’ feet, but to wash the feet of a ‘Judas,’ an enemy, or a ‘Peter’ someone who is going to let us down!!!

Could it be that we are thinking ‘Jesus you are asking too much! I want to go to church, I want sit and be spoon fed, I don’t want to get my hands dirty, I don’t want to put my hand into my pocket, I don’t want to have to open my purse, or my home, or my heart; this is not what I have signed up for, this is not the Jesus I want to follow.’

If that is how you are thinking, or if that is how we are living, then we have got very serious problems. Is it possible to call ourselves followers of Jesus and not be motivated to display random acts of radical love.

Father it is only loving the way Jesus does that I discover my full potential. Bible in a year reading plan Psalms 35:22-37:26
title: loving others part 1

html:
How do we show love to others?

a. Take the initiative. All these men were lounging around the table, then one of the disciples asked Jesus, ‘would you mind washing our feet.’ No that is not what happened. Jesus acted because he saw a need and an opportunity to show love.

Sometimes we complicate or over think things. If you have a thought about showing kindness to someone then just do it. You don’t need to over think it, or even pray about it, just do it. Don’t assume someone else will do it, or think, that is not my responsibility. We are all good at killing initiative. We find it so easy to rationalise deeds of kindness away.

Recently we had an experience when someone came to us at a funeral and insisted that they give us a gift of money. At the time we did not realise that a few hours later we would run out of oil, this person’s kindness helped us get oil. There are a ‘million ways to wash feet.’ You can visit, text, send a letter, make a phone call, provide food, pray with someone, take them for coffee, baby sit, invite them for a meal, give them a lift, take time to listen to them. And lots lots more, there are a million ways to wash feet.

b. Be spontaneous.

Look what John says The evening meal was in progress, and the devil had already prompted Judas, the son of Simon Iscariot, to betray Jesus. so he[Jesus] got up from the meal, took off his outer clothing, and wrapped a towel around his waist. After that, he poured water into a basin and began to wash his disciples’ feet, drying them with the towel that was wrapped around him. There was no fan-fare, no big announcement, Jesus just stopped what he was doing, he stopped taking part in the meal so he could wash their feet.

When you feel that you should ‘wash someone feet,’ act as soon as you can, and sometimes that will require immediate action, where we will have to stop what we are doing. Sometimes our refusal to act immediately may rob us of an opportunity to show appropriate love.

c. Be sacrificial.

It was proper hospitality to offer your guests a basin of water for their feet. But guests were usually expected to wash their own feet. Washing the dirt off someone else’s feet was a task reserved for only the lowest ranking Gentile servants, and Jewish slaves were often exempted from this duty. In a household without slaves, everyone washed his or her own feet.

In washing the feet of his disciples Jesus was sacrificing his reputation. It is okay to loose your reputation for the sake of showing selfless love to others. Sadly many people loose their reputation because of selfish sinfulness and in the process they hurt others.

d. The expression of love is more important than the success of love. As you read through this passage you get the feeling that the disciples didn’t really get what Jesus did. In verse12 Jesus said, ‘Do you understand what I have done for you? We read about Peter’s difficulty in accepting what was happening and Judas walked away.

Loving others the way Jesus loves us is not a panacea, it is not a guarantee for success. That has to be okay.

There are two things we need to notice as we conclude.

1. Jesus has promised that ‘If we love one another as He has loved us, everyone will know we are His disciples.’

The radical ongoing expression of sacrificial foot washing love is the only way we have of getting the attention of the world outside. We don’t need more programmes, better advertisements, slicker services, but radical love for one another.

2. Jesus said in verse ‘Now that you know these things, you will be blessed if you do them.’ Knowing, doing, blessed. The word used for blessed is the Greek word ‘Makarios.’

Writing about this word Ray Pritchard writes that makarios "doesn’t even apply to human emotions. It’s a statement of how God views people who live a certain way. The root idea of blessed is “approved by God.” https://www.preceptaustin.org/matthew_53.

I love this picture, Jesus is showing radical love of ‘feet washing’ to his disciples, and his father is in heaven standing clapping with great approval and delight. Have you ever watched your child on the stage or on the sports field, and the pride and joy you feel as they perform. When we adopt a ‘foot washing’ attitude to life so we can love others the way Jesus loves us we will be sustained by the approving applause of heaven, we will be blessed.

Questions you may want to consider as we think about.

1. Can you identify any insecurities that may be preventing you from showing the radical love of Jesus to others?

2. What does the act of ‘foot washing’ look like in your everyday life?

Father Help me to initiate love for others.

Yet there are some of you who do not believe.” For Jesus had known from the beginning which of them did not believe and who would betray him. He went on to say, “This is why I told you that no one can come to me unless the Father has enabled them. ”From this time many of his disciples turned back and no longer followed him.

In John 6 we are introduced to a new understanding of who Jesus is and how he understands himself. In this Gospel Jesus uses seven ‘I am’ statements to teach us about who he is and who we are. They are, ’I am the bread of life (6:35, 51); the light of the world (8:12; 9:5); the gate (10:7, 9); the Good Shepherd (10:11, 14); the resurrection and the life (11:25); the way, the truth and the life (14:6); and the true vine (15:1,5).

When Jesus refers to himself as ‘I Am’ he was using the Old Testament name for God. (See Exodus 3:14.) However, these seven statements are more than a revelation of Jesus, they also describe our needs and how he alone can meet those needs.

As we dig into this passage, we are going to learn that as we encounter Jesus we cannot avoid encountering ourselves. And that is our problem, we would rather live with the Jesus we think we know, or the Jesus we want to know than the Jesus we need to know. We are continually deconstructing the Jesus of the bible so he will fit better into our lives. We have got this all wrong, we are the ones that need to change, not him. Being made in the image of God, means that our encounters with Jesus, will show us who we really need to be.

In John 6 we meet a lot of people who wanted Jesus, they wanted a relationship with him, but the problem was that they wanted a relationship with him on their terms. They wanted Jesus to become a ‘father Christmas,’ type god. The kind of god who would meet all their needs, a god who bought into their materialism, a god who was consumer friendly.

To help us grasp the life changing message we need to take a brief look at its context.

On the previous day Jesus had miraculously fed a crowd of over 5000 people. We are so familiar with this story that we miss its impact. Most of these people were poor, and lived on a subsistence diet. In Matthew’s account we are told ‘They all ate and were satisfied.’ Matthew 14:20. These people knew what it was like to be hungry. The word Matthew uses for satisfied was the same word used to describe a well-fed animal.

By Jesus’ time, most families in Israel had no land. Most of the land was controlled by a few powerful families and moneylenders. Tax collectors and soldiers would grab most of the crops that were grown and most money that was earned. The people were left with very little to live on. Most people were hungry most of the time. Many would have to find some work each day as a day laborer to buy their food for that day. That is why Jesus knew the people had followed him round the lake to listen to his teaching all day would be hungry. If they had not worked, they would have had no food, and would not have been able to buy any.

For these people, the Roman Empire was a terrible place to live. Land was concentrated in the hands of a few. Capital was no longer distributed evenly. The people did not have money to lend to others, because all surpluses were taken by the Romans and the temple system. Life was brutal and extreme poverty was normal. (No wonder people were looking for a Messiah who would break the shackles of Rome and free them from the burden of debt and tax.)

It is in this context that the crowd went looking for Jesus; as we go through this passage we are going to notice that Jesus confronts them at a very deep and challenging level.

Father help me understand that the context or the circumstances of my life will not excuse wrong attitudes about Jesus.

He went on to say, “This is why I told you that no one can come to me unless the Father has enabled them. ”From this time many of his disciples turned back and no longer followed him.

Jesus exposes their motives

‘When they found him on the other side of the lake, they asked him, “Rabbi, when did you get here?” Jesus answered, “Very truly I tell you, you are looking for me, not because you saw the signs I performed but because you ate the loaves and had your fill.’

The question the people asked Jesus “Rabbi, when did you get here?” may appear innocent enough, but we must read it in the context of what happened the previous day when they wanted to take Jesus by force and make him King. Jesus refused to be controlled or manipulated by them.

Jesus does not answer their question. He says something very strong and very confrontational, ‘Very truly I tell you.’ The words ‘very truly,’ or truly, truly, in the older versions, are used 25 times in John and was used when Jesus was going to say something very important. And then he says, ‘you are looking for me, not because you saw the signs I performed but because you ate the loaves and had your fill.’

The Message reads “You’ve come looking for me not because you saw God in my actions but because I fed you, filled your stomachs—and for free.”

These people were following Jesus with wrong selfish motives, and Jesus was not going to allow it. They wanted to be with Jesus because of what he could do for them, not because they wanted to know and love him. It is like getting married to someone not because you love them, but because they can do something for you. In the light of passage, we need to conclude that Jesus is interested in our motive for following him.

Why do you want to follow Jesus? Why do you want to live for God? Some may think that if you are doing the right thing, and following Jesus then surely motive is not important. Look at these words by A W Tozer.

‘The test by which all conduct must finally be judged is motive. As water cannot rise higher than its source, so the moral quality in an act can never be higher than the motive that inspires it. For this reason, no act that arises from an evil motive can be good, even though some good may appear to come out of it. Every deed done out of anger or spite, for instance, will be found at last to have been done for the enemy and against the Kingdom of God. Unfortunately, the nature of religious activity is such that much of it can be carried on for reasons that are not good, such as anger, jealousy, ambition, vanity and avarice. All such activity is essentially evil and will be counted as such at the judgment.’ tps://acts2024ministries.wordpress.com/tag/tozer/#:~:text=The%20test%20by%20which%20all,to%20come%20out%20of%20it.

Motives are important because they are all about our hearts, and following Jesus is all about the heart. Many people give up their Christian faith because their motivation has been about using Jesus not knowing and loving Him. When their expectations are not met, they get frustrated and angry and then they walk away.

Jesus redirects their focus.

“Do not work for food that perishes but for food that lasts for eternal life, which the Son of Man will give you, because God the Father has set his seal on him.”

In some ways these words redefine our humanity and go against our cultural and social norms. We live in a world where we are taught our significance, identity and security are all tied up in our work. Work is a good thing and a gift from God, but the focus of our lives must be primarily on our spiritual lives.

Do you remember when Jesus was hungry in the wilderness, Satan tempted him to turn stones into bread. Basically, he was saying ‘Jesus use your power to meet your own needs, it is not God’s will for you to be hungry.’ Jesus’ reply was amazing. He quoted Deuteronomy 8;3.’Man does not live on bread alone, but on every word, that comes from the mouth of God.’ This is what Jesus is saying to these people. ‘you need more than bread, you need more than having your material needs met, you need to grasp the fact that your humanity is created for intimacy with God and that is what you should be labouring at.

Our jobs have a measure of importance and we should do our best at them, however, if we take them too seriously, and they become essential for our identity and significance, then we will not have the heart or energy to labour for the bread that does not spoil. Remember Jesus is speaking to people who had very little, they were poor people, yet their poverty did not excuse them from having a materialistic attitude.

This principle needs to govern our lives. The quality of the lives we live is not dependent upon the possessions we possess, or the things we achieve, but upon us allowing the word of God to nourish and transform us.

Father expose in me any wrong motive for following you

He went on to say, “This is why I told you that no one can come to me unless the Father has enabled them. ”From this time many of his disciples turned back and no longer followed him.

Jesus looks for their faith.

In verse 28-29 we read “Then they asked him, “What must we do to do the works God requires?” Jesus answered, “The work of God is this: to believe in the one he has sent.”

What is Jesus saying here. Jesus is not saying that we are saved by doing work. But what he is saying is that these people must work at having faith.

When we think of believing we usually have a very narrow or precise understanding of what faith means. Let me explain, often we think as unbelief or doubt as the opposite of belief/faith. And they can be, especially when it comes to our understanding or reasoning. However, a better word to describe the opposite of the bible’s understanding belief/faith is independence. The Greek word John uses for belief pisteuō) means a lot more than mental assent. The word was used by the Greeks to mean “to believe in something” not just to believe facts about something. It meant to trust in; to have confidence in. It means to entrust oneself to an entity in complete confidence. To believe in with the implication of total commitment to the one who is trusted.

The interesting thing is this, Jesus describes the act or process of total dependence, i.e. believing as work. Why would he do that? I think most of us are uncomfortable with the thought of being dependent, we are happy with a ‘cerebral,’ faith, a faith that acknowledges, but we need a faith that depends.

To become people who are living dependent lives is never a default position, it is not something we would choose or want. We don’t like to look weak, or recognize we are people of need. We need to cultivate an attitude of dependence. We need to work hard to become people who live as those who continually feel their need of God. Very early in Greek history, the word for work was associated with specific occupations like farming or being a soldier. It draws a picture of someone actively engaged in production or achievement. We need to become people who are actively engaged in becoming people who have an ever-increasing need of God. Cultivating dependence upon God at its essence is one of the ways we express our love for him.

The work of complete and total surrender of dependence is the best work any person can do, the word that describes this work is faith.

Let me just give one simply illustration of how we resist dependence and fight to hold onto our independence. Do you ever find it difficult to ask for prayer? Sometimes it is the last thing we will do. We don’t want to become vulnerable, we want to protect our reputation of being able to cope. Prayer is a language of dependence.

The work of faith is not only developing dependence, but it is choosing to trust God irrespective of what circumstances we may be struggling with. It is trusting God in the face of uncertainty and confusion. Sometimes holding on to your faith can be very hard work.

There is a difference between depending on someone and using someone. These people were looking for Jesus to use him to meet their need for bread. However, when it comes to dependence upon Jesus, it has more to do with love and devotion. Dependence upon Jesus is to acknowledge Jesus himself is our greatest need.

Father help me to cultivate real dependence on you.

Jesus needs to change our hunger.

Jesus said to them, “Very truly I tell you, unless you eat the flesh of the Son of Man and drink his blood, you have no life in you. Whoever eats my flesh and drinks my blood has eternal life, and I will raise them up at the last day. For my flesh is real food and my blood is real drink. Whoever eats my flesh and drinks my blood remains in me, and I in them. Just as the living Father sent me and I live because of the Father, so the one who feeds on me will live because of me.”

These verses are hard to understand, and many people think that Jesus is talking about communion here. But this is very unlikely for several reasons.

Jesus is talking to people who are about to walk away, not sincere believers who want to remember the Lord’s death.

Jesus said, ‘Whoever eats my flesh and drinks my blood has eternal life, and I will raise them up at the last day.’ Does that mean that if we take communion we become Christians?

When Jesus instituted the Lord’s supper/communion he never uses the word flesh, always the word body. In John’s gospel the word ‘flesh’ has more to do with the incarnation.

To understand this passage as speaking about communion is to miss it point and rob it of its power. The combination of ‘flesh and blood,’ in Hebrew as in English can mean the whole person rather than designated two distinct parts. It may be that by using the phrases ‘eating flesh,’ and ‘drinking blood,’ Jesus is indicating that we need to receive all of Him.

In verse 54 there is something that our translations do not pick up. When Jesus says. Whoever eats my flesh and drinks my blood has eternal life, and I will raise them up at the last day.’ He changes the word for eat. Phago which is used eleven times to the word trogo. The difference in these words is important. Phago means to consume, to gulp down and is always in a tense that indicates a one time action. Trogo, however is more about eating slowly, taking your time, to chew, to continually feed upon. This is something we need to be doing all the time.

Why do we want to follow Jesus? Are we like these people in John 6, who followed Jesus not because they loved him, but because they wanted something from him. It is hardest to live for God and to follow Jesus when we have no hunger for him. When our hearts are more concerned about ‘bread that perishes,’ we will not have the attitude of heart that is needed to live for God fully. One of the saddest verses in the whole bible is found in this chapter.

“From that time on many of his disciples turned back and no longer followed him.”

Are we willing to follow Jesus no matter what? The Jesus who does not fit into my neat theological box? the Jesus who won’t do miracles on demand? the Jesus who will not be used or controlled? Jesus who insists on being lord of our lives?

Father may my heart be filled with the right hunger so I can follow you fully.

John 15:12-17 My command is this: Love each other as I have loved you. Greater love has no one than this: to lay down one’s life for one’s friends. You are my friends if you do what I command. I no longer call you servants, because a servant does not know his master’s business. Instead, I have called you friends, for everything that I learned from my Father I have made known to you. You did not choose me, but I chose you and appointed you so that you might go and bear fruit—fruit that will last—and so that whatever you ask in my name the Father will give you This is my command: Love each other.

We want to explore together what it means to ‘do life together.’ There is a verse in the bible that Christians love to quote. John 10:10, ‘I have come that you might have life, and have it to the full.’

This verse has caused some problems for some people, let us be honest, would you use the word ‘abundant’ or the phrase ‘life to the full,’ to describe your life? Or would you use words like, ‘exhausted, ‘surviving,’ ‘overwhelmed?’ Sometimes you may feel that you are hardly able to cope and abundant life seems like an illusion. Part of our problem is we have over ‘individualised’ understanding of what Jesus was saying here. ‘Abundant life,’ ‘Life to the full,’ is a corporate experience; it is something that happens within the context of community.

There is another way of looking at this that may help us grasp how important ‘doing life together’ is. In 1Corthians Paul describes the church as a body made up of different parts, he talks about how every part of the body is essential. As part of his argument he says, ‘The eye cannot say to hand ‘I don’t need you!’ And the head cannot say to the feet ‘I don’t need you!’ 1Corthians12:21. The word that Paul uses for need in this verse carries the idea of needing help.

Why do you think sometimes we all find it hard to ask for help? We find it difficult to recognise that our need of help should be our default position, or factory setting if you like, or creators intention. God has designed us in such a way that we need each other. Not only are we designed to need and receive help from others, but also the providences and circumstances that God brings into our lives highlight our need of others and their help, life is too big and too tough for us to make it by ourselves. Needing help from others is one of the glories of our humanity, for in recognising our need of help we realise that we were never created to be independent self-contained people. Refusal to ask for help is one of the ways sin dehumanises

I want to try and unpack this whole subject and try and give us some practical steps we can take to build a community that can embrace life to the full, and grasp the importance of doing life together.

We want to begin by looking at ‘doing life together,’ by considering the importance of being a friend and having a friend. Many people who attend church often feel out of place, disconnected, isolated. Many people who faithfully attend church, they faithfully serve God, but in their hearts there is an ache, a longing to be ‘known’ to be appreciated and loved. Every one of us has a God given need for intimacy and full acceptance. We are not made for shallow superficial relationships, but for quality friendships that transform and sustain us.

Some very spiritual people would say that all you need is God, that God is enough. But that kind of thinking is not biblical. When God saw Adam alone in the garden, he did not say to Adam, ‘Now Adam, you have me, I am all you need.’ No, he gave Adam another human being who he could relate to. God knew that Adam bore his image, and in bearing the image of God, Adam needed to have healthy, quality relationships so he could be the person he was meant to be.

Let me just say something about loneliness

‘Loneliness was the first thing that God's eye named as not good.’ - John Milton

The word lonely means ’dejected for want of company,’ I think loneliness could be understood as ‘echo’s of lost-ness,’

Listen to these words that help us understand loneliness. "Darkness is such that I really do not see—neither with my mind nor with my reason—the place of God in my soul is blank—There is no God in me—when the pain of longing is so great—I just long & long for God. … The torture and pain I can't explain."A letter of mother Teresa from 1961

Researchers rate loneliness as a higher risk to people than lifelong smoking. Researchers also link a lack of social interaction with the onset of degenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s. One study reported a doubled risk of Alzheimer’s disease in lonely people compared with those who were not lonely.

It has been shown that loneliness makes it harder to regulate behaviour, rendering people more likely to drink excessively, have unhealthier diets or take less exercise. There is also evidence that loneliness adversely affects the immune and cardio-vascular systems.

Loneliness is a taboo subject. It is not a subject we find easy to talk about, as people we find it hard to confess that we may be lonely, for in doing so we think we appear to be weak or lacking something.

In order for us to do life together we will need to understand and experience Jesus’ understanding of friendship. Jesus had a lot to say about friendship, and as we shall see Jesus’ teaching on friendship gives it a new significance and depth, Jesus elevates the concept of friendship to a new height of commitment and love. You could say that the way Jesus approaches friendship is so radical and counter cultural that it may feel alien to most of us. Father we live in a world that is suffer from a pandemic of lonelinessBible in a year reading plan Psalms 51:10-54:7

John 15:12-17 My command is this: Love each other as I have loved you. Greater love has no one than this: to lay down one’s life for one’s friends. You are my friends if you do what I command. I no longer call you servants, because a servant does not know his master’s business. Instead, I have called you friends, for everything that I learned from my Father I have made known to you. You did not choose me, but I chose you and appointed you so that you might go and bear fruit—fruit that will last—and so that whatever you ask in my name the Father will give you This is my command: Love each other.

Friendships are such an essential part of life, and loneliness can be a threat to life. Jesus had a lot of important things to say about friendship. The text we want to look at is John 15:12-17. It is part of Jesus’ final words to his disciples on the night before he died. We need to keep that in mind, for the context of these words give them a greater seriousness. Jesus is preparing his disciples for the future, He is giving them essential instructions so they can live the life he wants them to live. There are a number of lessons we can learn from what Jesus says in these verses.

Relationships are more important than programmes. If you look carefully at these verses they start and end the same way. ‘This is my command that you love each other.’ John 15:12, 17. When you think about it, this on the surface appears to be a strange thing to say. If you were leaving your work in the hands of someone else, you might give them a strategy, or a ‘to do list,’ or some kind of programme to follow. But Jesus does not do that. He simply commands that we love each other.

Sometimes in church life we find it easier to invest in programmes than in relationships. Programmes are always dispensable, relationships are never. The love that Christians should have for each other is the only foundation for authentic evangelism. In John 13:34-35 Jesus said ‘A new commandment I give you. Love one another. As I have loved you, so you must love one another. By this all men will know that that you are my disciples, if you love one another.’

Generally do you think churches pray more about programmes than they do about relationships? Are we inclined to operate as if programmes are more important than relationships?

Friendship is the natural, spontaneous outworking of the love of God in someone’s life. ‘Friend’ was the word Jesus used to describe the natural consequences of his love for his disciples what does it mean to Love one another as friends? The word the bible often uses for love is AGAPE. What is AGAPE love?

The source of agape love is not the character of the person who is being loved, or even their need, but rather it is about the character and nature of the person who is ‘doing the loving.’

The quality of agape love is unconditional, it is not based on merit, and it does not need to be deserved.

The goal of agape love is always the highest good of the other person, no matter the cost.

The evidence of agape love is action. It is not emotion centred but will centred. It is practical, it chooses to act.

The extent of agape love is sacrificial. The true nature of love will always lead to sacrifice.

To be a friend means that we need to receive God’s love for us. When we read the words ‘Love each other as I have loved you,’ it would very easy to feel overwhelmed with such a request, and in being overwhelmed we are inclined to draw back and think that Jesus is making an unreasonable demand. The key to loving others is God’s love for us. As we receive, embrace and enjoy God’s love for us, we will be secure enough to love others. Sometimes others are badly affected and suffer greatly when we refuse to receive God’s love for us.

Father forgive us when we live and act in a way that says programmes are more impotent than relationships.

title: Doing life together Part 2

html:
John 15:12-17 My command is this: Love each other as I have loved you. Greater love has no one than this: to lay down one’s life for one’s friends. You are my friends if you do what I command. I no longer call you servants, because a servant does not know his master’s business. Instead, I have called you friends, for everything that I learned from my Father I have made known to you. You did not choose me, but I chose you and appointed you so that you might go and bear fruit—fruit that will last—and so that whatever you ask in my name the Father will give you This is my command: Love each other.

Being a friend means that we understand the dynamics and the expectations of the friendship. Often when it comes to friendships we are reluctant to express any expectations or aspirations we may have. Jesus did not suffer from this kind of reluctance, he said, ‘You are my friends if you do what I command you.’ John 15:14. This is not to suggest that we are to command our friends to do certain things. But it is suggesting that we have appropriate and realistic expectations of the friendship.

When it comes to friendship there are two kinds of expectations that are equally wrong. There is a too high expectation which usually kills the friendship by making us demanding, controlling and selfish. The other is having too low or no expectations at all. These kinds of friendships are usually put onto ‘automatic pilot,’ and before you know it friendships are reduced to acquaintances. With no expectations’ comes no commitment.

Being a friend requires open vulnerability. Look at what Jesus said, ‘I no longer call you servants, because a servant does not know his master’s business. Instead, I have called you friends, for everything that I learned from my Father I have made known to you.’ John 15:15. This is with massive implications. For Jesus there was a connection between being open and learning from his Father, and being open with others. In the mind and experience of Jesus these two things are connected, they are linked, they are indissoluble. The heart attitudes that we require so we can open ourselves up to God in order to hear what he wants to say to us, are the same heart attitudes required to open ourselves up to others. Both these things require vulnerability.

The things that we learn from the Father will always encourage and enhance our friendships. As we listen to God our capacity to enter into meaningful, God pleasing friendships will increase.

Friendships need time to develop. Jesus says a very interesting thing to his disciples. ‘I no longer call you servants, because a servant does not know his master’s business. Instead, I have called you friends.’ Through time, Jesus’ relationship with His disciples changed, it grew, it matured, the dynamics of the friendship changed. This is not an automatic certainty; growth in friendship must be intentional. Growth in friendships will change how we view the other person. Our understanding and perception of the other person will gradually change.

Authentic friendship could be understood as a reflection of election. What do I mean? In verse 16 Jesus said, ‘You have not chosen me but I have chosen you,’ Bible teachers, rightly use this as one of the verses to teach about election.. According to one Greek scholar one of the meanings of the word for chosen, eklegomai in classical literature carries the idea of selecting something that is beautiful or praise worthy. It was also used to describe the appointment of soldiers and judges. This is very important. God will never choose us because we are beautiful or praise worthy people. He will never choose us because we are strong soldiers and wise judges. But, he does choose us for the potential he sees in us; he knows that his grace can transform us. Remember the first words Jesus spoke to Peter, ‘You are, you will be.’ John 1:42.

What has that all to do with friendship? Being made in the image of God, there is something built into all of us that is created to choose to befriend others, not because they are beautiful people, but because we see potential in them that no one else may see. We become strongly intentional in our friendships; we befriend those who are weak, those who are in need, because we understand the potential of the grace of God.

Father may my friendship with others help them discover their potential.

html:
John 15:12-17 My command is this: Love each other as I have loved you. Greater love has no one than this: to lay down one’s life for one’s friends. You are my friends if you do what I command. I no longer call you servants, because a servant does not know his master’s business. Instead, I have called you friends, for everything that I learned from my Father I have made known to you. You did not choose me, but I chose you and appointed you so that you might go and bear fruit—fruit that will last—and so that whatever you ask in my name the Father will give you This is my command: Love each other.

Friendships are essential for spiritual growth. When Jesus chose these men to be his friends he chose them with the intention that their lives would become more fruitful. ‘You did not choose me, but I chose you and appointed you to go and bear fruit, fruit that will last.’ Loving, sacrificial friendships are the ground where people grow most. It is in the context of feeling loved, secure and accepted. That is were a person’s life can mature and bear fruit. When we become dominated by our insecurities, growth and maturity is hindered if not prevented.

Our friendships with others will have an effect on our relationship with God. It is interesting to notice that Jesus began his teaching on friendships by talking about how God’s relationship with us effects our relationships; however near the end of the section He talks about the complete opposite. How our relationships with others affects our relationship with God.

There is a statement at the end of verse 16 that is often overlooked, ‘Then the father will give you whatever you ask in my name.’ Six times during this last night with his disciples Jesus talks about praying in his name. I find the implications of what Jesus is saying here staggering. He is tying together how we live and what we will pray for. If we become the kind of friends Jesus wants us to be, the natural consequence of that kind of living is we will pray in Jesus’ name, we will be asking the Father the same things Jesus would be asking for, because we are endeavouring to love each other the way he loves us. One of the things to pray in Jesus name is to ask for what he would ask for because we love others as Jesus would want us to. It is having our prayers shaped by the character of Jesus being formed in us.

In his book Quality Friendships Gary Inrig asks a number of searching questions about friendship.

a. What are the limits of my friendship? Do I use people or do I lay down my life for them? How much do I know of sacrificial love?

b. What is my impact on others? Am I a change agent for godliness in my friend’s life? Is he/she more of a disciple because of me? Am I giving myself in such a way that God-given needs are being met in his/her life?

c. Do I take the risk of openness, or is there a careful constructed wall around my life that no one can penetrate? Have I ever expressed verbally my love and appreciation for my friend and displayed that love by opening up my life to them?

d. Am I an initiator of love, or am I waiting for others to earn my approval or to reach out to me? Do I choose my friends because of my needs or because of their needs?

E, How am I helping my friend realise his/her full potential in any or every area of their life? Is he/she fruitful because of me? .

Father help to recognise and remember that their a link between my friendships and prayer life.

html:
WHAT IS THE CONTEXT OF MATTHEW 10?

THE CONTEXT IN RELATION TO JESUS OWN PERCEPTION ON MINISTRY.

What Jesus is teaching here is much more than blues print for ministry. It is not a how to manual. He is giving more than instructions for ministry. He is sharing how he perceives ministry. He is highlighting some of the attitudes and responses he has when thing get tough. He is opening His heart. He is saying, here is how and why I do ministry. He is teaching the principles by which he operates.

Matthew 9:35-38 Jesus went through all the towns and villages, teaching in their synagogues, preaching the good news of the kingdom and healing every disease and sickness. When he saw the crowds, he had compassion on them, because they were harassed and helpless, like sheep without a shepherd. Then he said to his disciples, "The harvest is plentiful but the workers are few. Ask the Lord of the harvest, therefore, to send out workers into his harvest field." These verses give us some idea what was going on in the mind and heart of Jesus before he called the twelve and gave them instructions for ministry.

THE PEOPLE JESUS SAW

When he saw the crowds, he had compassion on them, because they were harassed and helpless, like sheep without a shepherd. These people are described as

Harassed

Helpless

Sheep without a shepherd.

Harassed. Sometimes the word is translated distressed. At it's root the word has the meaning of flaying or skinning. It carries the idea of being battered, bruised, mangled, ripped apart, worn out or exhausted.

Helpless or downcast, has the basic meaning of being thrown down prostrate and utterly helpless as from drunkenness or a mortal wound

Sheep without a shepherd. They were neglected, vulnerable people that no one cared for.

Why where these people in such a state? Because of the legalistic system in which they were brought up. These people suffered because the religious system they were brought up in was anti-grace, and the opposite of love.

Three initial lessons we need to learn from Matthew 10.

THE MINISTRY JESUS HAS CALLED US TO IS MEANT TO SET PEOPLE FREE, NOT PUT MORE BURDENS ON THEM.

One bible commentator wrote ‘The real test of religion, (or ministry) is, does it make wings to lift a man up or a dead weight to drag him down? Is a man helped by his religion (or ministry) or is he haunted by it? Does it carry him, or does he carry it? The Pharisees believed that to do God's will was to observe their thousand of petty rules and regulations and nothing could be further from the Kingdom of God, his basic idea, his love.’

It is easy for any ministry to degenerate into a legalistic system; many ministries start of with good intentions, yet with the passing of times they begin to rob people of freedom instead of bringing them into freedom. Freely they receive freely they give. But soon they loose they own freedom, and unintentionally and often unconsciously they begin to take others out of freedom, and even drive some into bondage.

When a ministry degenerates into an abusive system, it was never the intention of those who become abusive, to do so. Their is seldom a theological reason why a ministry, church, person becomes abusive. But often through time, they find some theological perversion to justify they activity, which they are doing, which abuses others. Usually ministry degeneration is the result of personal degeneration and someone's refusal to deal with real issues in their own lives.

A person, church or an organisation can be involved in an abusive ministry and yet not realise it. One of the most common expressions off abuse is summed up in the phrase “keeping things ticking over” or “sustaining the status-Quo” How we may ask is “keeping things ticking over” or “sustaining the status-Quo” abusive?

When ore ministry has been reduced into a ministry of maintenance, then something is wrong in us, we have lost our vision and passion, that in turn will turn our focus to the external, and how things appear. People who are satisfied with the status Quo who have no vision, will be unable to lead others into abundant life. People who are happy to live with the status quo are dying on the inside.

Ministries that do nothing can be abusive, people will suffer through neglect.

INSECURITY THE ROOT OF ABUSE

The Pharisees appeared to be self-confident secure people, but in reality they lived lives that were full of fear and insecurity. That is why they needed the approval of others, that is why they insisted in killing Jesus.

Every time we putt burdens on people, we oppose the ministry of Jesus in their lives, and our ministry becomes illegitimate and worthless.

Matthew 10 is Jesus prescription for remaining in freedom and for bringing others into freedom. Jesus teaching in this chapter is to help us, to help others who are under bondage.

WHEN WE RESPOND TO LEGITIMATE FEARS IN ILLEGITIMATE WAYS WE WILL BRING OTHERS AND OURSELVES INTO BONDAGE.

Reading through the chapter we discover how often Jesus address the emotional life of the missionary and how he should respond to those emotions.

a. "Let your peace rest on it." "Let you peace return to you." 13

b. "Do not worry" 19.

"Stand firm to the end" 22.

"So do not be afraid" 26.

"So don't be afraid" 31.

Often our inability to handle or control our own emotional lives will cause us to miss handle others, and even try to control them. Often people who promote a legalistic system on others are very insecure, with deep emotional needs. Often their control others and sometimes their abuse of others is their way of trying to meet their own emotional needs.

Father critique my ministry am I being abusive and leading other out of freedom?

html:
In this passage Jesus spends a lot of time addressing the emotional needs of those he is sending out. It is worth noting that Jesus motivation for ministry was compassion. Maybe our lack of compassion augments our inability to manger our own emotional needs?

The background of the passage.

Understanding compassion.

Matthew 9:32-38 “While they were going out, a man who was demon-possessed and could not talk was brought to Jesus. And when the demon was driven out, the man who had been mute spoke. The crowd was amazed and said, "Nothing like this has ever been seen in Israel." But the Pharisees said, "It is by the prince of demons that he drives out demons."

Often we hear people teach from Matthew 9:35-38 about Jesus feeling compassion for the people and then asking his disciples to pray that the Lord of the harvest would send out workers into his harvest field. But if we are going to really understand the full impact of this passage and how it relates to us having a heart for people, then we will need to take a look at the proceeding passage.

This incident effected Jesus deeply, and he refers to in the next chapter Matthew 10:24-25 "A student is not above his teacher, nor a servant above his master. It is enough for the student to be like his teacher, and the servant like his master. If the head of the house has been called Beelzebub, how much more the members of his household?

We need to understand what these people were saying when they called Jesus Beelzebub, and how it deeply effected Jesus. The word Beelzebub is found seven times in the New Testament, and always in the context of the Pharisees misjudging Jesus. On a number of occasions they claim that Satan, the prince of demons inspired the work Jesus was doing. What does Beelzebub mean?

Some believe that it has an Old Testament origin. King Ahaziah, in an act of apostasy, sent to inquire of "Baal-zebub, the god of Ekron," in one of the Philistine cities (II Kings 1:2-16). The two parts of "Baal-zebub" means, "lord of the fly." Baal was the Canaanite god of fertility and fire, one of the chief deities of the area. Zebub means fly or poisonous insect (the same word is used of one of the plagues of Egypt, Exodus. 8:20-32). The Philistines may have actually worshiped the fly.

In Mark 3:22 (= Matt. 12:24; cf. 9:34; Luke 11:15) the Pharisees disparage Jesus and attempt to explain his power over demons as itself of demonic origin by saying, "He is Beelzebub, the prince of the demons." The precise meaning of Beelzebub is uncertain. Yet it certainly is related to the name of the pagan deity associated with the enduring enemy of Israel. It can also mean, Lord of the house, or higher abode. In the sense that often the pagan temples were often located on high ground.

In these verses Jesus shares some of the pain of his own heart. To be called Beelzebub causes Jesus some pain, it made an impact on Him. Why did Jesus think it was important to share this incident? There may be two possible reasons. Firstly, because they were suggesting that Jesus’ ministry had a demonic origin and not a divine one. It would be like someone in a public position declaring that you were demonized, therefore, who you are, and what you do is both wrong and dangerous. They were not only attacking His ministry, but they were attacking who He was so they could undermine His ministry.

Jesus was not immune to feeling pain, what people said effected him, he did not have some emotional body armor to protect Him, but as He shares His pain, He is teaching his disciples how he coped with these evil allegations.

Father thank you that Jesus understands the pain we feel when other criticize us

html:
With what we have considered over the last two days, We can now understand better what is happening in Matthew 9 verses 35-38

Jesus went through all the towns and villages, teaching in their synagogues, preaching the good news of the kingdom and healing every disease and sickness. When he saw the crowds, he had compassion on them, because they were harassed and helpless, like sheep without a shepherd. Then he said to his disciples, "The harvest is plentiful but the workers are few. Ask the Lord of the harvest, therefore, to send out workers into his harvest field."

What is compassion?

The word compassion is found 12 times in the New Testament. Eight times it refers to Jesus emotional condition. Of all the words used to describe his emotional life, this was the word used most often. Matthew 9:36; Matthew 14:14; Matthew 15:32; Matthew 20:34; Mark 1:41; Mark 6:34; Mark 8:2; Luke 7:13; There is a very important reason why the New Testament uses the word compassion most often to describe the emotional life of Jesus.

Often as Christians we put far too much emphasis on what we mistakenly refer to as 'a call'. We had some significant spiritual experience in the past, and we assume that this 'call' has empowered and equipped us for ministry. For Jesus, ongoing experience of compassion was one of the indications that His 'call' was from the Father.

On three occasions, Jesus refers to it in his teaching. In the Parable of the Unforgiving servant Matthew 18:27 The Parable of the Good Samaritan Luke 10:33, and the Parable of the Prodigal Son Luke 15:20.

It was also used as a cry of a father over his demonised son Mark 9:22.

Every time Jesus was moved with compassion, something significant happened in the lives of other people.

When Jesus was moved with compassion other people saw it. Compassion is not something you can hide.

What is Compassion?

Most of us have a sentimental understanding of what compassion is, but we need to take a step back and try and understand what compassion felt like for Jesus.

If we are going to understand Jesus, and if we are going to have an effective ministry, then we will need to have a proper understanding of compassion.

COMPASSION IS A NEGATIVE EMOTION.

The Greek word for COMPASSION is Splagchnizomai; this is a very strong word. Originally, the word was used to describe the inward parts, or the entrails of a sacrificial animal. They were removed, roasted and eaten as part of a sacrificial meal. Later the word came to mean sacrificial meal.

The word furthered developed to mean human entrails. The idea behind the word is to be moved in your guts. It carries the idea that you feel so distressed and upset about someone else's need, that you feel physically sick.

So when we read about Jesus being moved with compassion, we are reading about a man in pain, a man who is feeling the deep painful reality of authentic love for others.

How we handle the pain caused by others will determine our ability to feel compassion for them.

The mishandling of pain is often the biggest hindrance to how we minister onto others. I love the way Jesus dealt with what He was going through. He did not grit his teeth, clench His fists and be strong. He did not allow public demands prevent Him from grieving. He did not act Mr cool and give the impression He was able to cope. Often we read, “He withdrew by boat privately to a solitary place,” however that was not always to pray. Often He withdrew because He was in pain. He did not pretend.

Because He dealt honestly with His own pain, when He needed to feel compassion for others, He was able to. If we feel the need to be strong and prove ourselves, if we think we need to have all the answers, then we will never take time off, we will never withdraw, we will never give ourselves the time and space to deal with our own hurting emotions. Then we will never be able to show compassion

The worst thing we could ever do is not be honest about our pain. When we begin to pretend to be strong or to be in control when we are not, then we begin to relate to others on the basis of a lie.

Because others have hurt us, we can fear the pain of compassion. Compassion is not a comfortable emotion, in some ways it feels as painful as rejection or grief. However, the pain of compassion, although difficult to live with, will bring about a healthy motivation to help others. Often our motivation for being involved with people is wrong or misplaced.

The Pharisees said, "It is by the prince of demons that he drives out demons." Surely Jesus you need to build up some walls, you need to protect yourself, and you need to be strong and prove yourself. It is too risky to care for others, too painful. Compassion means that you choose to become emotionally involved with people, We choose to get emotionally involved, despite the hurt and misunderstanding of others.

Father May I never put you call on my life in the place of compassion,

html:
THE PEOPLE JESUS SAW

When He saw the crowds, He had compassion on them, because they were harassed and helpless, like sheep without a shepherd. These people are described as

a. Harassed

b. Helpless

c. Sheep without a shepherd.

As we have previously said

a. Harassed. Sometimes the word is translated distressed. At its root the word has the meaning of flaying or skinning. It carries the idea of being battered, bruised, mangled, ripped apart, worn out or exhausted.

b. Helpless or downcast, has the basic meaning of being thrown down prostrate and utterly helpless as from drunkenness or a mortal wound.

c. Sheep without a shepherd. They were neglected, vulnerable people that no one cared for.

Please note what the text does not say. "Jesus saw a pack of lost sinners who deserve to go to hell."

Have you ever wondered why Jesus only spoke about hell to his disciples or the Pharisees and never to the 'die hard sinners’, as we would call them?

Why where these people in such a state? Because of the legalistic system in which they were brought up. These people suffered because the religious system they were brought up in was anti-grace, and the opposite of love.

Legalism and love are incompatible, and cannot be in the same heart. If someone is legalistic in their outlook, if their focus in on the external, if they are motivated by the need of approval from others, then they will not be able to show love to those who are wounded and broken. They may long to show love, they may have strong desire to show love, but will be incapable. Why?

Legalism puts burdens on people.

Compassion lifts burdens off people.

Legalism focuses on the external.

Compassion deals with the internal.

Legalism focuses on what a person does.

Compassion focuses on who a person is

Legalism increases a person needs.

Compassion meets a person needs.

Legalism demands that we keep all the rules.

Compassion shows love grace and encouragement.

Legalism tries to control others.

Compassion leads others into freedom.

Legalism makes a person hard and unteachable.

Compassion makes a person sensitive, vulnerable and giving.

Legalism leads to death.

Compassion leads to life.

Legalism reflects the law.

Compassion reflects the cross.

Father may my life and ministry be marked and motivated with compassion

html:
WE NEED TO UNDERSTAND THE NATURE OF BIBLICAL AUTHORITY.

He called his twelve disciples to him and gave them authority to drive out evil spirits and to heal every disease and sickness. Matthew 10:1. The word Matthew uses for authority is EXOUSIA.

When we think of the word authority we usually think of terms of power and abuse, but this is not what the word authority means.

The word means to have the freedom of choice to use power and authority in a right way. It is very important that we understand what Jesus is saying here. Only those who have a sense of freedom are able to reach others in an effective way. If we are not free, we will feel a need to control others, and conform to the world around us, looking for approval.

Any ministry that is not a genuine expression of spiritual freedom is going to end up destroying others. Many people get involved in ministry because they are looking for freedom, not because they are free.

Only people who feel free with in them selves have the ability and the freedom to reach others. Those who are not free will not have the courage to confront difficult issues, because the Pharisees had authority but no freedom, and they ended up abusing people.

The reason why Jesus was able to give authority to these men was because he was free in himself. If he hadn’t been enjoying his freedom, then he would have never have given authority to his disciples.

One of the indications that a leader is not free is that he will feel the need to do every thing himself. Jesus could have thought, “this work is far too important to hand over to these men, this is a work of world proportions, ‘these men are too week, too inexperienced, too unreliable, too undependable to do this great work” But Jesus did not think that way, because he was free. His freedom had nothing to do with the success or failure of his ministry. But his ministry had everything to do with his freedom.

The whole purpose of the teaching of Jesus in this passage is to show us how to maintain our freedom. We can lose our freedom very easily, a wrong reaction to fear, worry, rejection our any other pressure that ministry can throw up, can rob us of our freedom. Once your freedom goes, so does authentic ministry.

We need to note what Jesus did here. He gave them authority to drive out evil spirits and to heal every disease and sickness. He did not give them authority over people. Only people who are not free need to have authority over people.

What is the basis of the freedom Jesus has given to us. Matthew tells us “He called his twelve disciples to him and gave them authority.” The word he uses for called is very interesting. PROSKALEO. It means to summon. Was use by a superior over someone under them. It is a very intense word, which meant to call someone to you in order to confront him or her face to face.

This is the basis of our freedom. When Jesus calls us primarily his call is to fellowship with him, called to him. Therefore it is in the context of that intimate fellowship, Jesus confronts us. There can be no authority without freedom. No freedom without confrontation. No confrontation without fellowship.

The freedom Jesus gives us should be one of the biggest motivations for spiritual warfare.

Father may my ministry be an expression of internal freedom, free from the dominate control of my insecurities. Bible in a year reading plan Psalms 73:21-76:7

Matthew 10 5-15 gives us Jesus first instructions to the world first Christian missionaries, what Jesus says here is helpful for all missionaries, at all times and in all places

They were under his instruction. “These twelve Jesus sent out with the following Instructions” Matthew 10:5a The Greek word for instructions is Parangello, used by all kinds of authorities. A military term used to describe an order giving by a commanding officer. It was an order that required unhesitating and unqualified obedience. It was a word used to describe an official court summons. It was used to describe a moral obligation. It was also used to describe a prescription from a doctor. So what Jesus is going to say here to these men is not merely some good ideas he has thought of, they are command, they are things he demands of us. They are instruction for Ministry.

THESE ARE INSTRUCTIONS FOR A SPIRITUAL MISSION NOT FOR A SUCCESSFUL MISSION

Often we are tempted into thinking that if we do everything Jesus commands us to do then our ministry is bound to be successful, But if you read this passage carefully they you will notice that Jesus spoke very little about success,

Look at the following phrases from the Passage

F. 21 “Brother will betray brother to death, and a

Father his child; children will rebel against there

Parents and have them put to death.”

G. 22 “All men will hate you because of me, but

He who stands firm to the end will be saved.”

H. 23 “When you are persecuted in one place,

Flee to another.

I. 25 ”If the head of the house has been called

Beelzebub, how much more the members

Of his household!”

J. 26 "So do not be afraid of them.”

K. 28 “Do not be afraid of those who kill the body

But cannot kill the soul.”

L. 34 "Do not suppose that I have come to bring

Peace to the earth. I did not come to bring peace,

but a sword.

M. 35 “For I have come to turn a man against his father,

A daughter against her mother, a daughter-in-law

Against her mother-in-law--”

N. 36. “A man's enemies will be the members of his own household.'

In this chapter Jesus give a realistic perception on ministry and the pressures of ministry. It is because of his realism that he gives these instructions, It because of his love for his apostles that he gives these commandments. Knowing how to handle the stress and strain of ministry is more important than knowing how to be successful in ministry

Father thank you that Jesus had more to say about how we cope with the stress of ministry than the success of ministry. Bible in a year reading plan Psalms 76:8-78:24

html:
PRINCIPLES WHICH SHOULD DIRECT OUR MINISTRY.

1. WE SHOULD HAVE A REALISTIC STRATEGY.

Strategy is a necessity not a luxury. Jesus begins by saying, "Do not go among the Gentiles or enter any town of the Samaritans. Go rather to the lost sheep of Israel.’ One of the mistakes of many missions and churches is that they either have no strategy or their strategy is too wide or too general. Jesus is saying that Ministry must be tied down to specifics. If it too broad, then nothing will get done, and if it is to narrow then it will become too inflexible. How did Jesus set the strategy of reaching the lost house of Israel at this time? There were five contributing facts that helped Jesus set this strategy.

A. He was emotionally effected by the situation on the ground. We are told by Matthew that has we have seen, “When Jesus saw the crowds he had compassion on the.” Strategy for mission must always begin in the heart not the mind. Strategy for ministry, which is devoid of emotional involvement, will become cold orthodoxy, and will be very hard to be implemented. When strategy and emotions combined there is more change of seeing the strategy implemented. If we do not make some emotional investment into the lives of those we are trying to reach, then when the pressure comes we will be more able to keep going because we have heart involvement

B. He prayed about what he saw and how he felt. “Ask the Lord of the harvest to send out workers into His harvest field.’ Having an adequate emotional respire is not enough, we must also have our hart responses checked by the wisdom of cooperate prayer. When we turn the passion of our hearts into effective prayer, then we will be more able to see the way forward. Prayer gives our enthusiasm direction.

We need to ask the Question. What can we learn from,

Jesus directions regarding praying for the harvest field?

When Jesus said “Ask the Lord of the harvest to send out workers into His harvest field” The word he uses for “Send out” is an extremely strong word, it literally means to drive out your enemies. In the LXX the word is used in the context where an enemy, frustrating or standing in the way of God’s fulfilling his purpose for his chosen people, is ‘cast out’ by God, so that God’s purposes may be fulfilled. See Exodus 23:30 Deuteronomy 33:27ff.

The word was mostly used in the New Testament in relation to casting out demons. It is the same word Jesus uses in verse 1 of chapter 10, where he says, “He gave them authority to drive out demons.” This is very helpful. Jesus wants the people God sends out to be a passionate expression of God’s Ekballo, Or God’s resistance to evil. The people God is sending out are Gods answer to Satan, and his kingdom. God wants his passion to been seen through our lives.

This is the same word Mark uses in 1:12 when it says, “At once the Spirit sent him into the desert.” We know that Jesus went into the desert to confront Satan.

The word is also found in Mark 11:15 On reaching Jerusalem, Jesus entered the temple area and began driving out those who were buying and selling there. He overturned the tables of the moneychangers and the benches of those selling dove.

Luke 13:28 “There will be weeping there, and gnashing of teeth, when you see Abraham, Isaac and Jacob and all the prophets in the Kingdom of God, but yourself thrown out.”

So the intent behind the word is one of God opposing evil that is been done to others.

There is another principle expressed through Jesus’ use of Ekballo, As we have said, it is a very passionate word. God desires to express his passion through us. If our lives do not express God’s passion, then they will not express his love. God’s love and God’s passion are inseparable. God’s love for us is a passionate love. Can a heart with no passion express God’s love???

It is interesting to observe from the life of Jesus that he never had apathy in his heart, he often felt tired, or weary, or even discouraged. But he never allowed apathy in his heart. Our English word apathy comes from the Greek word APEITHEO that is used to describe disobedience or unbelief in the New Testament.

Jesus tells his disciples to, said “Ask the Lord of the harvest to send out workers into His harvest field” what kind of people did he have in mind. What was he thinking about when he spoke about workers?

What we have in our hearts will determine what kind of workers we will be. If we are experiencing the Ekballo in our hearts then we are going to be the kind of workers Jesus wants us to be. When Jesus calls for workers to be sent into the harvest he is referring to a hired hand, a slave, someone who is paid a low wage. Someone who has no high ambition for them selves. Someone who is not afraid of hard work.

The humble commitment required by a worker in God’s harvest field is only possible when God works in someone’s heart. We must be energized by what God is doing in us, often we lack the emotional and spiritual resources to labour for God because inside we are not experiencing the passion of God.

Father I would love to have a heat full of your strategic passion. Bible in a year reading plan Psalms 78:25-72

html:
Jesus did not try to do everything at once. “Go to the lost sheep of Israel” Jesus loved all mankind, he had a hart for the whole world, but he knew he had limitation, the limitations of a physical body, so he made a choice to reach those were nearest him at that time.

People often make the mistake of being frustrated by their limitations, instead of seeing their limitations as a God given opportunity to specialize.

Jesus accepted the emotional and cultural hang UPS of his disciples for that time. In the future Jesus would have to challenge the prejudice and cultural restrictions of his apostles. But at this present time Jesus was sensitive to their cultural limitations, so he said to them. “Do not go among the Gentiles, or enter any town of the Samaritans.” This restriction was for the good of the apostles, and also for the good of the Gentiles and Samaritans that would be reached in the future. Maybe if they had visited the gentiles and Samaritans without dealing with the prejudice in their hearts then they may have caused more problems making it more difficult to reach them in the future.

He spoke of those who he wanted to reach in a compassionate way. Jesus spoke of them as the “Lost sheep of Israel.” He did not speak about them as sinners who needed saved, or evil people who needed to repent, He could of called them these things and been totally honest. But he described them as “sheep that were lost.” How we initially see people will determine how we will try and achieve our God given strategy. If we see people who need to change, repent and turn from sin, then we will approach them with hardness and aggression, instead of feeling compassion and love.

The Strategy of Jesus was Emotional, Spiritual, Limited, Protective, short term, and relevant.

WE SHOULD NOT CONFUSE STRATEGY WITH ABILITY.

Jesus continues by saying to his Apostles. “As you go, preach this message: 'The kingdom of heaven is near.' Heal the sick, raise the dead, cleanse those who have leprosy,.....” when we look at these verses we are confronted with a list of impossibilities. Heal the sick, raise the dead, and cleanse those who have leprosy. No strategy will empower a person to do these things. These things can only be done when the power of God is working in their lives.

The only explanation for our ministry should be the life of Jesus in us. Our lives should be full of things that can only be explained by God. What Jesus was asking these men to do was a continuation of what he was doing in Matthew 8-9. In theses chapters Jesus Healed the sick, raised the dead, cleansed those who have leprosy,.....” So our ministry should be a continuation of Jesus’ ministry. These things can only happen through the manifestation of the power of God.

God may not reveal His power through us in the same way as he revealed his power here, But their must be evidence of the power of God in our lives if we are going to reach people in relevant and significance ways. There can be no relevance without the power of God. All authentic ministry requires a supernatural source.

There is a problem in how some people read this verse. Look again at what Jesus said.

“As you go, preach this message: 'The kingdom of heaven is near.' Heal the sick, raise the dead, cleanse those who have leprosy,.....” People are inclined to read this verse like this. “As you go, preach this message: 'The kingdom of heaven is near.’ No problem, we can do that, we can go to people and share the Gospel with them and tell them about The kingdom of God.

'Heal the sick, raise the dead, cleanse those who have leprosy,.....” I could never do that, I could never see God’s power like that being revealed through my life.

But what Jesus is saying here, is to preach the message: that the kingdom of heaven is near.' depends no more on your ability as does 'healing the sick, raising the dead, cleansing those who have leprosy depends on your ability. In other words we need the same power to preach the good news of the kingdom as we do to heal the sick, raise the dead, cleanse those who have leprosy

The Greek Word for preach is the word KERYSSO which described the activity of someone the Greeks called a KERYS or HERALD “The KERYS was always under the authority of someone else, the person who he was a Spokesman for. ..... He conveyed the message and intention of his master. He had therefore... no liberty of his own to negotiate. His office had in every case an official character, even when he appeared in the market place as a public middleman or announcer. He was therefore the announcer of judicial verdicts. What he announced became valid by act of proclamation.” So Jesus is saying to these men, You can only proclaim and demonstrate my authority when you bow to my authority

Father we need you power just as much to share the message of the kingdom as we do for the miraculous. Bible in a year reading plan Psalms 79-82
