html:
THE GOAL OF MINISTRY IS NOT TO PLEASE EVERYONE.

"I did not come to bring peace but a sword. I have come to turn a man against his Father.’ One of the evidences that a person is insecure and is not ministering from a posture of dependence upon God is that they will feel that their role is to keep everyone happy. So they use their resources and energy making sure that they keep everyone one side, Yet Jesus is saying that this is wrong. Sometimes people need to experience the sword, Sometimes speaking the truth, dealing with issues, has a piercing effect on people. This requires courage

HOW SHOULD WE RESPOND TO THE HOSTILITY KINGDOM LIFE WILL BRING. Listen to what Jesus says for ‘I have come to turn " 'a man against his father, a daughter against her mother, a daughter-in-law against her mother-in-law--a man's enemies will be the members of his own household.' "Anyone who loves his father or mother more than me is not worthy of me; anyone who loves his son or daughter more than me is not worthy of me.’ Here Jesus is speaking of heavy-duty hostility. When Jesus speaks of turning family members against he other, he uses the word DICHAZO which mean to cut into two parts or cleave asunder. The word means to be at variance with someone. So we need to ask, how should someone handle such painful and traumatic relationships.

We need to stand back and remember that Jesus own family were at variance with him, they thought he was mad, they did not believe him to be who he said he was. Jesus knew about the pain and stress caused by degenerating relationships within a family context. So how did Jesus cope with such pressure.

". Anyone who does not take his cross and follow me is not worthy of me.’ We need to remember that Jesus objective in life to was to bring glory to his father by taking up his cross. All through his life Jesus had a heart posture that meant his life was heading to a death on a cross. The heart attitudes Jesus required to go to the cross, did not just appear during his last week on earth, no, those heart attitudes were always their. All through his life Jesus had taken up his cross in his heart.

Think of some of the required heart attitudes Jesus would need if he was going to fulfil his father's will and go to the cross.

He was able to take up his cross because his heart was full of love.

He did not allow the injustice of his cruel death, to rob him of the freedom to forgive. He knew that the pain of forgiving was consistent with the character of God, and how his Father had designed life. He knew that to love your enemy invariably brings God Glory. He knew to exact vengeance by coming down from his cross would never meet the deep needs of his own loving heart, or the demands of justice. He knew that only sacrificial expressions of radical love are the only way to reach the world with transforming grace.

If Jesus had cross attitudes in his heart, all through his life, what a difference that made in handling family hostility. Jesus was able to handle the hostility of his own family because he knew he was going to the cross.

The same principle applies to our lives, If we are taking up our cross, not as a rule, but because of love in our hearts, we will respond appropriately to kingdom conflict.

Then Jesus says ‘whoever finds his life will lose it, and whoever loses his life for my sake will find it." Finding and loosing life is tied up with our ability to take up our cross. In the midst of great turmoil and hostility, a person can find life, when they have the heart attitudes of a cross carrier and they take up the cross. The heart attitudes that led Jesus to the cross are in their essence life finding attitudes.

Jesus' concept of finding life is both alternative and confrontational to how most people perceive the finding of life to mean. For Jesus the finding of life included things like pain, suffering, and forgiveness, sacrifice even sorrow. For most of us, we equate the finding of life with such things as peace, joy, comfort and a pain free existence where all our needs are met. Most of us have fallen for the lie, that we honestly believe that life is found in having a comfortable care free life with no emotional stresses.

When God made us he made us in his own image. He made us with the need to have a cross-shaped life. He made us with a build in need to share the same attitudes of the heart of Jesus, the attitudes that enabled and empowered Jesus to go to the cross are the same heart attitudes that bring life to the full to every individual.

For Jesus the most painful time of his life was also the time when he brought his Father much glory. The shame of the cross did not rob Jesus of his dignity or value. The cross did not belittle him or rob him of life, rather the cross enabled Jesus to find and express life in all it's fullness, because he was expressing the heart of God in all it's glory. For Jesus, the cross was the ultimate expression of life finding. Finding life, and taking up the cross are inseparable. Life can't be found till the cross is carried, for in caring our crosses we should be expressing the loving heart of God. In expressing the loving heart of God, we are living to the full.

SHARING MORE THAN A MESSAGE. MATTHEW 10:40-42 Jesus concludes his teaching on ministry with these words, "He who receives you receives me, and he who receives me receives the one who sent me. Before we consider what these words mean, we need to remind ourselves of the context of the chapter and the intention of Jesus in all this teaching.

THE PURPOSE OF HIS TEACHING. The whole purpose of Jesus teaching in this chapter is to give his disciples instructions and encouragement to prevent them from having a ministry that is both legalistic and binding on people. When he saw the crowds, he had compassion on them, because they were harassed and helpless, like sheep without a shepherd. The heart of Jesus wanted to set his people free. He wanted more than anything to have is ministry of bringing freedom, to continue and progress through his disciples.

WHO HE IS TALKING TO.

The second things we need to remind ourselves, is whom Jesus is addressing in these verses. Most people fall into the temptation of reading this verse. "He who receives you receives me, and he who receives me receives the one who sent me." Divorced from its context and apply it to all Christian, in all places, and at all times. So we read "He who receives you receives me, and he who receives me receives the one who sent me." And we assume that this is always the case, that when someone receives us, they also receive Jesus. But if we were honest, we have all have people who have shown us a measure of acceptance, but they seem to have no spiritual interest or indication that they have received Jesus also.

This verse is furthered complicated by the fact that Jesus as been teaching all through the chapter that many people would reject both them and the message they were bringing. So what does theses verses mean?

"He who receives you receives me, and he who receives me receives the one who sent me. ‘

Those who have understood the teaching of Jesus up to this point will bring more than the message of the gospel, they will bring the Jesus of the gospel.

We have worked through this chapter, we have learned many lessons, lessons that will hopefully shape our characters as well as our ministry. If we begin to have lives that have been so shaped by the instructions of Jesus in this chapter. Remember the Greek word for instructions is Parangello, used by all kinds of authorities. A military term used to describe an order giving by a commanding officer. It was an order that required unhesitating and unqualified obedience. It was a word used to describe an official court summons. It was used to describe a moral obligation. It was also used to describe a prescription from a doctor. So what Jesus is going to say here to these men is not merely some good ideas he has thought of, they are command, they are things he demands of us. If the lessons of this chapter become real, then the YOU that people receive will be much more that a person with a message, they will be someone who is full of the life of Jesus. "He who receives you receives me, and he who receives me receives the one who sent me.’

The implication of this verse is quite staggering. People need to receive more than the message of the Gospel, they need to receive Jesus also, our they need to hear more than words that we might say, they also need to see Jesus, the source of our lives in us. There is an indissoluble link between our lives and the lives of Jesus. The world has no other way of seeing the reality of the life of Jesus except through us. So the YOU that Jesus is addressing in this verse is not the professional career missionary who is totally committed to the work of mission, The YOU of this verse, are those who have found Jesus to be their only source of life, and only reason for living.

We must not misunderstand what Jesus is saying here, He is not giving a guarantee that people will receive the YOU of this verse. Most of the chapter has be telling us that reject is more probable than being received. But when people do receive us, they are also receiving Jesus.

‘Anyone who receives a prophet because he is a prophet will receive a prophet's reward, and anyone who receives a righteous man because he is a righteous man will receive a righteous man's reward.

In this passage Jesus uses two different words for receive, In verse 40 the word dechomai is used this word carries the idea of off accepting or receiving letters or presents. It also means to hear with understanding or to show hospitality. It is a passive word, indicating that something is offered not forced. The second word for in verse 41 is a much stronger word. Lambano, this word means to seize, to take hold of something, for example we speak of someone being seized with fear So what is Jesus saying. We have two choices when it comes to reaching other people. We can either go to others with the life of Jesus so "He who receives you receives me, or we go to people on the basis of our ministry and integrity. ‘Anyone who receives a prophet because he is a prophet will receive a prophet's reward, and anyone who receives a righteous man because he is a righteous man will receive a righteous man's reward.

When we go to others, because we have a ministry, or because we believe it is the right thing to do, then our hold approach will be different. We will have to use our strength and power to get people to receive something. Because we are going on the strength of our ministry and integrity we could assume that this is a good basis for people to receive our ministry. However, going on this basis will require that we will have to Lambano the person and not dechomai the person.

Ministry, gifts and integrity are very important, but they are not enough, Jesus says that if we go on the basis of our ministry, a prophet, or if we go on the basis of or integrity, a righteous man, people will be blessed, people will receive a reward, but the YOU of verse 40 will not only bring a reward to people, they will bring Jesus to people.

It is so easy to base or ministry on the gifts God has kindly given us, and it is so easy to assume that because we are perceived as people of integrity, then we must be bringing the life of Jesus to people. So in order to prevent us from relying on the gift we have received and developed. Instead of relying on our reputations and others perceptions of us as righteous we need to become the YOU of verse 40, how?

Jesus concludes this teaching in a most wonderful and profound way. He says Matthew 10:42 ’And if anyone gives even a cup of cold water to one of these little ones because he is my disciple, I tell you the truth, he will certainly not lose his reward.’ We need to go to people not in the strength of our prophetic ministry, or any other gifting. We need to go to people not in the strength of our integrity, although that is very important. Rather we need to go to people in the weakness of one of the ‘little ones. ‘

Being a vulnerable ‘little one,’ has more influence than any prophetic gift, our any strong integrity. As weak vulnerable dependant ‘little one,’ we find our life in Jesus alone. The little ones of this verse is not the young convert, our the immature Christian, The ‘little ones’ who is Jesus’ disciple of this verse are those who God will use to bring the kingdom. God will bless people through the usage of our gifts, and people of integrity are indispensable. But it is through the little ones, the YOU of verse 40 that the kingdom comes with the reality of the life of Christ.

html:
We want to look at a well-known story about two sisters, and the different ways they responded to Jesus. In reading this story it is very easy to go down the lines of identifying with one of the sisters. Some feel that they can identify more with Martha than with Mary, these people would see themselves as being practical, they are the kind of people who are not afraid to get their hands dirty, like the Samaritan in the previous parable they are eager to respond to the practical needs of others. However there are others like Mary, who is more devotional than practical, they are deep thinkers; people who like to sit at Jesus’ feet, they like to read and hold theological discussions. However, to approach the text in this way is to miss the point. Luke is not trying to set up one kind of service against another. The issue that Luke is addressing is much deeper than the type of service we offer; rather he is addressing the heart behind the service.

The initial welcome

‘As Jesus and his disciples went on their way, he came to a certain village where a woman named Martha opened her house to him.’ As we begin to look at this incident we need to remember that in bible times, hospitality was very important. In the ancient world the practice of hospitality meant to graciously receive a stranger into one's land, home, or community and provide directly for that person's needs. In the ancient world hospitality was nothing like today’s image of good hospitality. Because people travelled by foot, journeys took a long time therefore travellers depended on the hospitality of others to help them on their way. Middle Eastern hospitality would have included the offering of a meal consisting of a number of different dishes from which guests could select. To share food with someone was to share life. So this was a very important time for the two sisters.

Luke tells us Martha opened her house to him. Martha wanted to show Jesus complete acceptance. Everything in her wanted to be a perfect host. (It is interesting that the name Martha means lady or mistress, she was the mistress or lady of the house ;) she had a reputation to live up to, and cultural expectations to fulfil.

Often when we have a desire to do something for the Lord, everything with in us wants to do it right, we want to please him, but often we become like Martha, and we end up treating Jesus in the same way a bad host would mistreat an honoured guest. The things that were going on in Martha’s heart robbed Jesus of the hospitality He should have received. In serving God, the condition of our hearts is much more important than what we may be doing or any success we may have.

Martha’s mistakes

Martha is the predominate character in this incident, it is written so we can learn from her. Luke records not so much as one word spoken by Mary. She is like the silent observer.

Luke tells us more about what was going on inside Martha than what she was doing. ‘Martha was distracted.’ The word translated "distracted" is Greek perispao, from which we get our English word perspective, the word means ‘to be pulled in many directions or dragging a burden.' Martha’s mind and emotions were all over the place. The word was also used for a woman with a sad expression on her face. She was too preoccupied with being a good host and this was leading to an attitude that was entirely unhelpful. At this point Martha’s was loosing perspective. The things that she was doing had begun to take control of her. Her duties had begun to dictate her feelings, affections and thoughts toward herself and others.

Before we leave this point we should mention that sometimes people use their service for Jesus as a form of avoidance mechanism, they don’t want to deal with the issues of their own hearts, so they mistakenly think that if they are busy serving Jesus they must be okay. What we do for Jesus will mean very little to him, if anything, if we are refusing to face up to and deal with the issues that are going on inside us.

Father thank you that both Mary’s and Martha’s service was important to you

html:
She accused Mary of being the problem because she refused to recognise the problem in herself. ‘Lord don’t you care that my sister has left me?’ Martha does not see any problem with herself, but she blames those who are innocent of wrongdoing. The word for left, kataleipo, is a very strong word it means to be forsaken. The word was used to describe the leaving a loved one at death, it carries the idea of feeling bereaved. Martha was having a massive emotional over reaction to Mary, she was feeling like a victim, at this point she was out of control. Her emotions were clouding her judgment.

She tried to use Jesus as a means of fulfilling her agenda. ‘Tell her to help me.’ Luke uses a very unusual word to describe the help Martha asked for. The meaning of the word can best be illustrated when we think of carrying a huge log, Have you ever tried to carry one by yourself? One end falls down, then the other end falls down and the whole thing swings this way and that. To carry a log is much easier if there are two people, one on each end. Martha was asking for a partner. The only other time the word is used is in Romans 8:26 speaking about the Help we receive from the Holy Spirit. What Martha really needed was for God to become her partner in work, however, her failure to recognise this meant she placed impossible demands on other people and only increased the frustration and tension in the household. Martha’s mistake was not that she was working in the kitchen. Her mistake was rushing out and demanding Mary show her love in the same way.

Charles Hummell, wrote in Freedom from the Tyranny of the Urgent:

‘Tension and frustration mount when we are performing the wrong tasks or trying to cram too many of the right activities into a given period. A critical spirit develops and we begin to judge and condemn others for what they do or don’t do. Anytime you feel a wave of criticism gaining momentum in your spirit remember it’s completely out of line as far as God is concerned.’ [Charles Hummel. Priorities: Tyranny of the Urgent. Christian Basic Bible Studies. (InterVarsity Press, 1994)].

Martha’s biggest problem was that she lacked self-control. We may not be totally responsible for how the circumstances around us make us feel, but we are totally responsible for how we manage and control our responses and emotions. The Greek word for self-control egkrateia literally means a holding oneself in or the ability to take a grip of oneself. Plato uses egkrateia to refer to self-mastery. It is the spirit which has mastered its desires and its love of pleasure. Secular Greek uses egkrateia of the virtue of an Emperor who never lets his private interests influence the government of his people. Self-control is part of the fruit of the Spirit.

Self-control means mastering one’s emotions rather than being controlled by them.

Father sometimes we lose perspective because we have lost control of our emotions.

study_refs: Martha ‘She came to him…’ a more literal meaning of the phrase ephistemai in v. 40 can simply mean "to stand near or by," and even "to oppose.” It conveys the ideas of urgency, as of a soldier ready to go into battle on a moment’s notice or a guard who stands continually on alert for threat of enemy infiltration or attack. It is as if Martha feels a need to stand up for herself, so she bursts into the room totally exasperated with Jesus and Mary, she is frustrated and angry, and says, ‘Lord don’t you care?’She begins to think wrongly about Jesus. ‘Lord don’t you care?’ At this time she is viewing Jesus as someone who is unconcerned about her and what she is feeling. When we stop believing that Jesus cares, we start to lash out at others. When Martha says, “Lord, don’t you care?” she really means to say, “Lord, you don’t care at all because if you did, you would have told Mary to go to the kitchen and help me.” Martha is feeling neglected and abandoned by Jesus however, although she was feeling this way, her feelings were not communicating the truth.

html:
Doctors sometimes talk about the “presenting problem,” which refers to the problem the patient brings to the examining room. The patient may complain of a sore throat, a runny nose, and an achy back, but it is the doctor’s job to look beneath those symptoms to discover the real cause. Martha’s “presenting problem” is very clear, so to Martha’s surprise Jesus turns around and begins to talk to her, not Mary. This was not what Martha was expecting, she had hoped, in fact she was so sure that she was right and that Jesus would take her side.

Jesus did not respond to Martha’s anger in anger. How easy it would have been for Jesus to have a scorching, or at least a sarcastic response to Martha, but no trace of anger can be seen.

Jesus dealt with Martha’s attitude, not her action. Martha’s service in the kitchen was not inferior to Mary’s devotion, the difference was their attitude. Jesus did not condemn Martha; rather he helped her identify what was going on in her heart.

So what did Jesus do?

Jesus answers by repeating her name twice. It is used for emphasis, often when the Lord is trying to get the attention of someone He will repeat their name. Jesus is trying to cut through the fog of Martha’s enslavement to her work. In repeating her name he assures her of his love. He knows how she feels and he understands her frustration. Even in his words of reproof, there is warmth and compassion in his voice.

He explained her emotional condition. ‘‘You are worried and upset about many things.’

Worried

The biblical word for worry merimnao is a compound of two Greek words, merizo ("to divide") and nous ("the mind"). Anxiety splits our energy between today's priorities and tomorrow's problems.

Upset thorubazo = "be troubled, distressed, emotionally upset" v. 41 this is the only occurrence in the NT of this particular word, but related terms refer to a "riot" or "(loud) commotion". Generally the word refers to the noise that a crowd makes, either as appreciation: "cheers," "applause;" or the opposite: "groan," "murmur," "uproar". So the word strongly hints at noise besides just the inner turmoil. Don't we all know people who make sure that everyone else knows about their inner anxieties? Or, as I suggested above, it could refer to all the demands within Martha, pulling her in all sorts of directions.

Jesus addresses the issue of priorities “But only one thing is needed.’ Each day can be taken up with things that we must do, things that we should do, things that we could do, and general stuff. If we do not wish to waste time then we need to identify and respond to the "must do" category. It is amazing that uncertainty about priorities can cause so much internal distress. Mary understood what was essential. We can only relate to Jesus and others as we should when we understand and accept what our priorities should be.

Mary was not at Jesus’ feet by chance, rather this was a deliberate choice made after some careful thought and consideration. The word for chosen is the same word used to describe God’s choice of us. The word means to select one thing from many possibilities. Both Martha and Mary had a choice of what to do with their time.

Father sometimes I need help to identify what should be my priorities.

title: Martha and Mary part 3
study_refs: Jesus’ response to Martha.

html:
She had real courage. We read this story and think nothing of it, but in the culture of that day what Mary did, required real courage.

Some rabbis said that women could not study the Torah and debated the existence of their female soul. Rabbi Eliazer said, "If a man gives his daughter knowledge of the law, it as though he taught her lechery," and "Better to burn the Torah than to teach it to women" (Emswiller 1977:22). The first century world of Judaism apparently classed women with “slaves,” “heathen,” and “brutish men,”

So with that in mind, Mary takes the traditional male role of 'sitting at the feet' or studying with the rabbi. Jesus approves of her interest in intellectual and spiritual matters, for she is told that she has chosen the better part" (McHaffie 1986:15).

She was teachable.

“Mary sat at the Lord’s feet.’ ‘Figuratively, at his feet’ seems to have been the phrase describing a disciple or learner.

She was prepared to listen.

Listening is hard work especially in a context of tension. It’s not easy to sit in a church and listen carefully for 20 or 30 or 40 minutes. Sooner or later, the mind tends to drift off. The disciple must learn from the Master. Otherwise, the disciple's busyness may create more problems than it solves. Mary has correctly discerned that listening to Jesus and learning his ways is more important than anything else she can choose. Mary has chosen what is better, and it will not be taken away from her.” No one can take this precious spiritual food away from her. The word translated "taken away" means to be robbed, deprived of something. When we loose our ability to listen to what Jesus wants to say to us, we will be robbed in other areas of our lives

Martha loved Jesus as much as Mary did. Martha’s practical service was not any less important than Mary’s devotion at Jesus’ feet. The problem was the heart attitude behind Martha’s service, not the service itself. Those of us who love Jesus have a desire to serve Him, however if we serve him with wrong attitudes and unresolved issues we will cause Him to feel like an uncomfortable guest in our lives.

Father may I serve you with a right heart attitude

title: Martha and Mary part 4
study_refs: What was there in Mary that caused her to make this choice?

html:
As Christians we are called to love, know and follow Jesus. Loving, knowing and following Jesus needs to become an intentional, life-long transformational experience. As Christians we need to be continually choosing to completely orientate the whole of our lives around the reality of the person and presence of Jesus. We need to be continually curious about him. We need to be continually teachable, always learning new things about him. need to continually long for a deeper and better relationship with him. We need to develop a core belief that Jesus is an absolute necessary part of us if we are going to function properly as a human beings in our everyday lives. So to help us love, know and follow Jesus, we want to look at Jesus’ relationship with the Holy Spirit, and how this relationship affected his every day life, and what Jesus taught about the Spirit. But let us start with three important foundation principles:-

1. Jesus’ relationship with the Holy Spirit helps us understand who Jesus is.

As a man, Jesus lived a life that needed the work of the Holy Spirit. He did what he did, not because he was God incarnate, but because he was submitted and filled with the Holy Spirit. The person Jesus became, the work Jesus did and the example Jesus is, was because of his relationship with the Holy Spirit.

Peter said ‘You know… how God anointed Jesus of Nazareth with the Holy Spirit and power, and how he went around doing good and healing all who were under the power of the devil, because God was with him.’ (Acts 10:37-38)

It would be very easy for us to think that Jesus did all his great works because he was fully God, and was working out if his Devine nature. In Philippians 2, Paul says that “though he was in the form of God, [he] did not count equality with God a thing to be grasped, but made himself nothing, taking the form of a servant, being born in the likeness of men. And being found in human form, he humbled himself by becoming obedient to the point of death, even death on a cross” (v 6-8).

Paul is not saying that the eternal Son of God gave up or surrendered any attributes of deity. Jesus “made himself nothing” or “emptied” himself by becoming a man, not by ceasing to be God. Thus, in becoming a human being, “the Son of God willed to renounce the exercise of his divine powers, attributes, prerogatives, so that he might live fully within those limitations which inhere in being truly human.” (Gerald Hawthorne, The Presence & the Power, 208). He willingly chose not to use his Devine power. In Jesus, we see a human being doing super-human things and ask “How?”

The answer is: Not from the power of his own divine nature, but through the power of the Holy Spirit. For Jesus, his miraculous demonstration of his power was because he was anointed with the Spirit.

In fact, Jesus himself said that his ministry was because he was anointed with the Holy Spirit.

Luke 4:16-19 ‘When he came to the village of Nazareth, his boyhood home, he went as usual to the synagogue on the Sabbath and stood up to read the Scriptures. The scroll of Isaiah the prophet was handed to him. He unrolled the scroll and found the place where this was written: “The Spirit of the Lord is upon me, for he has anointed me to bring Good News to poor. He has sent me to proclaim that captives will be released, that the blind will see, that the oppressed will be set free, and that the time of the Lord’s favour has come.’

Jesus lived normally within the confines of his human limitations, relying predominantly on the divine resources of the Father and the Holy Spirit, while using his own divine power infrequently, if at all. As a man, Jesus lived the life he lived, not because he had a divine nature but because he was predominantly dependant on the Holy Spirit. As a man, he chose to live a life that required the empowering of the Holy Spirit. On occasions, Jesus did display aspects of his divine nature, for example when he was transfigured, or when he forgave sin, for only God can forgive sin; but for the most part, Jesus lived as an ordinary man who had a life that was empowered by the Holy Spirit.

“The Holy Spirit was the divine power by which Jesus overcame his human limitations [such as being limited in knowledge and bound by physical space and human strength], rose above his human weakness, and won out over his human mortality.” Gerald Hawthorne.

If Jesus was to use his Devine power and authority as a man, he would have ceased to be truly human, that is why he choose a life of dependence on the Holy Spirit.

You could say that Jesus’ humanity was defined by his continually dependence upon the Holy Spirit.

The Spirit was active in Jesus’ birth.

“The Holy Spirit will come upon you, and the power of the Most High will overshadow you. So the holy one to be born will be called the Son of God.” (Luke 1:35)

Father thank you that to be truly human we need the continual growing work off the Holy Spirit in our lives.

title: study topic JESUS AND THE SPIRIT. Part 1

html:
The Holy Spirit at the birth of Jesus/

Luke 1:35 The angel answered, “The Holy Spirit will come on you, and the power of the Most High will overshadow you. So the holy one to be born will be called the Son of God.

The Holy Spirit was active in Jesus’ baptism.

Luke 3:22 – ‘And the Holy Spirit descended on him in bodily form, like a dove; and a voice came from heaven, “You are my beloved Son; with you I am well pleased.”

The Holy Spirit initiated his conflict with Satan.

Mark 1:12-13 ‘The Spirit then compelled Jesus to go into the wilderness. Where he was tempted by Satan.’

The Holy Spirit was active in Jesus’ ministry.

Luke 4:14 ‘And Jesus returned in the power of the Spirit to Galilee, and a report about him went out through all the surrounding country.’

Acts 10:37-38 – ‘You know what has happened throughout Judea, beginning in Galilee after the baptism that John preached — how God anointed Jesus of Nazareth with the Holy Spirit and power, and how he went around doing good and healing all who were under the power of the devil, because God was with him.’

The Holy Spirit was active in Jesus’ death.

Hebrews 9:14 – ‘How much more will the blood of Christ, who through the eternal Spirit, offered himself without blemish to God, purify our conscience from dead works to serve the living God.’

The Spirit was active at Jesus’ resurrection.

Romans 8:11 – ‘If the Spirit of him who raised Jesus from the dead dwells in you, he who raised Christ Jesus from the dead will also give life to your mortal bodies through his Spirit who dwells in you.’

Father in every area of my life I need the ministry of the Spirit.

html:
Jesus’ life teaches us that dependence upon the Holy Spirit is more necessary than having a position or power. Dependence is an acknowledgement of our weakness and limitations. Dependence comes out of being self aware, having a correct understanding and acceptance of who we are and that the purposes and plans God has for your life, will always be bigger than your abilities, strength, gifts or talents. In 2 Corinthians 13:4, Paul talks about the weakness of Christ. ’We, too, are weak, just as Christ was,..’ NLT

We do not expect to think of Jesus in terms of weakness. When Paul says ‘We, too are weak just as Christ was,’ he is speaking about Jesus’ death on the cross, however Jesus continually demonstrated a weakness that was consistent with his humanity. The fascinating thing about what Paul said is that he did not speak about the weakness of Jesus, but the weakness of Christ. The word Christ is not a name, but a title, a title which simply means ‘anointed one’. The weakness of the ‘anointed one.’ In some ways Jesus’ anointing did not eradicate his weakness, but enhanced it. The anointing of the Spirit did not make Jesus into some super human who used his power to demonstrate his greatness, rather the anointing of the Spirit led Jesus down a bloody path of ultimate powerlessness and shame and the brutal weakness of death by crucifixion.

Listen to these words.

‘[God] is weak and powerless in the world, and that is the way, the only way, in which he can be with us and help us... Man’s religiosity makes him look in his distress to the

power of God in the world; he uses God as a Deus ex machina. The Bible however directs him to the powerlessness and suffering of God; only a suffering God can help.’ (Bonhoeffer,Letters and Papers, 360–361)

[deus ex machina, (Latin: “god from the machine] It is a literary term that is used to describe something suddenly and impossible happening in order to save a main character in the plot.

We live in an age of the ‘Marvel movie.’ were we are presented with superhumans who are devoid of any kind of weakness. We could be tempted to think that the work of the Spirit in our lives will eradicate our weaknesses. However, it is our weaknesses, our limitations, our lack of ability that help us recognise and accept our need of the Spirit. Without our weaknesses we would become independent and too strong for God to use. Father thank you that our weakness o part of your design for our lives Bible in a year reading plan Psalms 138:4-140:13
title: The Spirit in the. life of Jesus part 3

html:
Jesus’ relationship with the Holy Spirit, helps us understand who the Spirit is.

The life and teaching of Jesus give us a clear understanding of the character and role of the Holy Spirit. The life of Jesus crystallises who the Holy Spirit is and what he is about. As a Spirit filled man, Jesus demonstrated God’s intended lifestyle for every Spirit filled man/woman.

On this point, Mark Jones in the book Knowing God said, “Any Christians wanting to know Jesus, will inevitably find themselves faced with the fact that Jesus from the time of his conception, had an inseparable companion: the eternal Holy Spirit. To know Jesus is to know the Holy Spirit and vice-versa.”

If we are going to understand what the Holy Spirit wants to do in our lives we need to look at the life of Jesus. We are told in John 3:34 that Jesus had the Spirit in his life without limit, and Jesus’ experience of the Spirit was greater than ours, but that does not mean that Jesus ceases to be our example or prototype of what it means to live as Spirit filled people. Jesus after his resurrection appeared unto his disciples and said. ‘Peace be with you. As the father as sent me so I am sending you. Then he breathed on them and said ‘Receive the Holy Spirit.’ listen to these words:-

“Not only is Jesus their Saviour because of who he was and because of his own complete obedience to the Father’s will, (cf. Heb. 10:5-7) but he is the supreme example for them of what is possible in a human life because of his own total dependence upon the Spirit of God. Jesus is living proof of how those who are his followers may exceed the limitations of their humanness in order that they, like him, might carry to completion against all odds their God-given mission in life-by the Holy Spirit. Jesus demonstrated clearly that God’s intended way for human beings to live, the ideal way to live, the supremely successful way to live, is in conjunction with God, in harmony with God, in touch with the power of God, and not apart from God, not independent of God, not without God. The Spirit was the presence and power of God in Jesus, and fully so.” (234) Gerald Hawthorne

As we look at Jesus’ relationship with the Holy Spirit we are going to discover that life in the Spirit is not some kind of mystical, ethereal, subjective experience that produces a spiritual high. But we will see that for Jesus, life in the Spirit led to robust, practical living that caused him to be involved in the messy needs of others.

Jesus’ relationship with the Holy Spirit helps us understand who we are.

As a perfect man, living in dependence on the Holy Spirit and in the power of the Holy Spirit, Jesus redefines what it means to be human. If Jesus was a perfect human, then we need to conclude that authentic, real, God-intended humanity is an expression of a Spirit filled life. Or you could put it another way by saying, that nobody can be who they are really meant to be, without the continual work of the Spirit in their lives. Living life in the Spirit gives us an opportunity to be ourselves, to embrace and enjoy our humanity as God intended.

We need to develop a theological and biblical anthropology, anthropology being the study of what makes us human. I believe, that only when we come to the realisation that we have been made by God and made for God, will we be able to understand our humanness. Our lives and body's have been bespokely designed to accommodate the person and work of the Spirit. Maybe seeing our humanity as something that needs to be an expression of a Spirit filled life, would/could/should change our understanding of the fruit and gifts of the Spirit.

The fruit of the Spirit is far more than replacements for the works of the flesh. They are expressions of God’s high intentions for man before sin.

Joy is LOVE rejoicing,

Peace is LOVE at rest,

Patience is LOVE waiting,

Kindness is LOVE interacting,

Goodness is LOVE initiating,

Faithfulness is LOVE keeping it’s word,

Gentleness is LOVE empathising,

Self-Control is LOVE resisting temptation.

Father thank you for the truth that authentic humanity needs to be Spirit filled humanity

Bible in a year: psalm 141:1-145:7
title: The Spirit in the .life of Jesus part 4

html:
The gifts of the Spirit are far more than demonstration of God’s power, they are expressions of his tender heart of love toward mankind, they are gifts that are given by God to his children so they can enter into life enhancing relationships. See 1 Corinthians 12:7, 14:4,5,12,26.

A proper use of the gifts of the Spirit would increase our ability to give and receive love. In 1Corinthians 12 and 14, Paul gives us a lot of teaching about the

gifts if the Spirit. It is important that we see chapters 12,13 and 14 as dealing with one subject, the use of the gifts in the context of the body of Christ.

Chapter 13, Paul’s famous passage on love describes God’s intended effect of spiritual gifts. Maybe that is one of the reasons why the gifts of the Spirit have been a theological contentious issue. Their misuse or their not being used at all has diminished love within the church and prevented spiritual enriching relationships.

Many people often ask the question, ‘What is my spiritual gift?’ This is not a bad question to ask. However I think a better way to get the answer is to ask. ‘God how do you want to empower and equip me so that my life would be a continual source of encouragement and spiritual support to other?’

I think you could honestly say that the work of Spirit in us, makes us more human because we are becoming more like Jesus.

Living a Spirit dependant life is one of the ways, maybe the most essential way, we show love and faithfulness to Jesus.

If we were to think of a Spirit filled life as a means of identifying our love for God and our commitment to him I think we would have a very different approach to life and to what is means to be faithful to God. I hope our understanding of who the Spirit is will be transformed, and our relationship with the Holy Spirit revolutionised, so we will be able to embrace and enjoy our humanity.

Father may the spiritual gifts in my life encourage and strengthen others.

Bible in a year: psalm 145:8-148:6
title: The Spirit in the life of Jesus part 5

html:
The Spirit at the conception of Jesus.

We all know and love the Christmas story, we are familiar with the main characters, Mary, Joseph, angels, wise men, shepherds, and Herod. However there is one character in the nativity we either completely ignore or give very little thought to, and that is the person of the Holy Spirit. The nativity story is recorded both in Matthew and Luke, and if you were to compare them you will notice that they are very different. The reason for this is because each writer is telling the same story but from a different perspective. Matthew is telling the Story from Joseph’s perspective, while Luke is telling it from Mary’s perspective. However despite the difference in perspective and content they are both in agreement about the role of Holy Spirit in the conception. They both record that an angelic being told Mary that she would conceive by the power of the Holy Spirit.

Luke tells us that Gabriel spoke to Mary. ‘Mary asked the angel, “But how can this happen? I am a virgin.”The angel replied, “The Holy Spirit will come upon you, and the power of the Most High will overshadow you. So the baby to be born will be holy, and he will be called the Son of God.’ 1:34-35.

Matthew tells us that the angel of the Lord spoke to Joseph. ‘As he considered this, an angel of the Lord appeared to him in a dream. “Joseph, son of David,” the angel said, “do not be afraid to take Mary as your wife. For the child within her was conceived by the Holy Spirit.’ Matthew 1:20

I think we need to consider the significance of this. The same message about the role of the Holy Spirit is delivered twice by an angelic being to two different people at two different times.

There may be a number of reasons why we are not too inclined to consider the role of the Holy Spirit in the birth narrative of Jesus.

1. We find it easier to relate to the human characters of the story.

We are familiar with Mary and Joseph, we know their backstory, we know that she is probably a young teenager who scandalously conceived outside the legitimate confines of marriage. We know that because Joseph was a righteous man he was unsure as to what he should do. Should he divorce her? Divorce being the only way of nullifying the betrothal covenant.
This is a drama, a story that catches our imagination and pulls on our emotions. We are slow to recognise that the Holy Spirit is there working in the background, making things happen, we might consider him playing a vital role, but we would not see him as one of the main characters.

Maybe the uniqueness of this event causes us to overlook the role of the Spirit in this situation.

We all know that there will never be an other miraculous conception. What the Holy Spirit did in the life of Mary was an abnormal one off event. However, although the work of the Spirit in Mary was unique and unrepeated, the character of the Holy Spirit, the principles by which he works and goal or objective he has [to produce in us the reality of Jesus,] are the same. Our lives need to become an echo of the nativity, where Jesus is formed in us and revealed through us. Let’s be honest we would rather watch the nativity as a sanitised children’s play than be part of it, however, we all need our own personalised ‘nativity’ story.. Our lives need to become an echo of the original nativity.

A third possible reason why we may ignore the role of the Holy Spirit in the nativity is we may assume that Mary’s and Joseph's understanding of who the Holy Spirit is the same or similar to our understanding of the Spirit. So when we read ‘The Holy Spirit will come upon you, and the power of the Most High will overshadow you,’ we must not assume that Mary understood it as we do.

We need to keep in mind that Mary and Joseph lived at a time when Rabbinic teaching was prevalent.

‘For centuries according to many of the rabbis, those teachers who most influenced the thinking of the first century Palestinian Judaism, the Spirit had been silent, his work was over and his activity was a past phenomenon. The Spirit had indeed given Israel the Torah, lots prophets and the whole of its scriptures, but having done that, his work has ceased.’ Gerald Hawthorne.

It was a common belief that the Holy Spirit had departed from Israel and no-one had the Spirit. So when the angel declared that Mary would conceive by the power of the Holy Spirit, he was telling Mary that her experience of God would be outside her understanding. Sometimes God will do things in our lives that may appear to be outside the normal or the usual. Sadly this fact can lead to people doing things that are either ridiculous, selfish, dangerous our immoral. The Holy Spirit is called the Holy Spirit, and he will never ask anyone to act outside the moral will of God. He will never resort to sin, deceit or abusive manipulation to accomplish the will of the father in your life or the lives of others There was absolutely no immorality in Mary’s conception outside marriage.

Father Thank you that the work of the Spirit may be unusual but will never be immoral or egotistical.

Bible in a year: Psalm 148:7-150:6 proverbs 11-2:9
title: The Spirit in the .life of Jesus part 6

html:
Mary was to understand that God’s will for her life could only be accomplished by her allowing the Holy Spirit to work in her life.

As we have said what God did through Mary was very unique and will never be repeated. Nevertheless, this principle applies to our lives. We will not be able to do the will of God for our lives without the ongoing creative work of the Spirit within us.

The fascinating thing about the birth announcement of Jesus is that it is not very practical or specific. You would think for the most important birth in human history there would be a bit more detail. The when and where, some details about the outworking of it all. No there are no details, no road map, just the information that this can only happen through the work of the Spirit within her.

Often when it comes to accomplishing God’s will, for us, knowing details is often the priority. While knowing details may be important, a greater priority is experiencing the Spirit. By default we are inclined to think that if I know the details of God’s will I will be able to accomplish it. But God’s will can only be accomplished by God’s Spirit in God’s people. Knowing what God wants you to do will never empower you to do what he wants you to do.

The will of God for our lives should make us more open to the work of the Holy Spirit and become more dependant on him.

I am coming to believe that God’s will for every individual is one of the things he uses to mature our relationship with the Holy Spirit. He takes us out of our comfort zones, he put us in places where we are our of our depth. He may ask of us things that could cause us to feel inadequate and overwhelmed, so we will cultivate a dependence on the Spirit.

Let me point a number of lessons from the work of the Spirit in the life of Mary.

1. There will be glory and pain of the work of the Spirit in our lives. The nativity story teaches us that the work of the Spirit in our lives is glorious and painful at the same time. What could be more glorious for Mary to have the life of Jesus formed in her.

Listen to these words:-

‘The Word became flesh! God became human! The invisible became visible! The untouchable became touchable! Eternal life experienced temporal death! The transcendent one, descended and drew near! The unlimited became limited! The infinite became finite! The immutable became mutable! The unbreakable became fragile! Spirit became matter! Eternity entered time! The independent became dependent! The almighty became weak! The loved became hated! The exalted was humbled! Glory was subjected to shame! Fame turned into obscurity! From inexpressible joy to tears of unimaginable grief! From a throne to a cross! From ruler to being ruled! From power to weakness!’ Sam Storms

Think about how amazing, how wonderful, how fantastic, how glorious, how marvellous, how spectacular, how awesome, how astonishing and how sensational the Holy Spirit wants to produce in us the life of Jesus. The incarnation of Jesus is continued through his body, the church. The incarnate Jesus continues to express himself through the transforming power of the Holy Spirit in us.

The glorious work of the Spirit in a persons life will never make them immune to pain, suffering or paying a high price to follow Jesus. Sometimes in the modern church, living in the Spirit can be presented as a panacea to all of life’s woes. We are inclined to think that if we are submitted fully to God, life might be easier or better. The life of Jesus teaches us, as does the life of Mary that although living a Spirit life is wonderful, it is also challenging, complex, and at times very isolating.

Mary was a young girl between the age of 12-15 who was betrothed to a man called Joseph. Betrothal was a legally binding covenant that could only be dissolved by divorce. During this time the man and his bride lived apart. He stayed at his father’s home, where he would extend his father’s home in preparation for bringing his bride home. Add to the pressure, conception during the betrothal period which was considered an act of adultery and could be punishable by death. You could say that Gabriel's announcement trashed Mary’s hopes, dreams and plans. In obeying God, Mary would have been misjudged and wrongly perceived as shameful. The bible gives us no indication as to how Mary may have viewed the dramatic change and interruption to her plans, but we can be sure that she would have felt unprepared for such a dramatic turn of events. She did not ask for or seek this role in God’s plans; God has simply stepped into her life and brought her into his service.

There are two important things I want to say about this.

At their essence most of the plans we make, especially life changing plans, like getting married, getting a job, changing direction in life are emotionally based decisions. They are more than cold facts written on a white board, and for the most part they come from an emotional place, and are full of emotional expectations. So when God’s will begins to threaten our hopes and plans we really struggle. We struggle because we are not unemotional robots, we struggle because our hopes for the future have caused us to become excited about our plans. This is what you could call ‘ the nativity struggle.’

Have you ever thought that Mary could have said no, just as much as we have the freedom to say yes? There will be times in our lives when we will have to engage in ‘the nativity struggle.’ when we will have to decide, do I want to do life my way, or God’s way? When we have to decide if God’s eternal purposes are more important than our temporary agenda.

Also we need to come to a heart conviction that it is better to live a difficult, complex life within the will of God, than to life in the safe monotony of my own existence. There were lots of reasons why Mary could have said no, she could have played it safe, but she had the courage to see beyond the boundaries of her emotional safe plans and her obscurity, and choose the difficult path because it was the best. ‘The Nativity struggle’ is having the courage not play it safe. ‘The Nativity struggle’ is to let encounters with God determine the course of your life so His Son can be formed in you.

But not only is Mary going to know the pain of the life of the Spirit but she is also going to know the glory of the Spirits work in her life. When she asked the angel ‘How can this happen, the angel replied, ’The Holy Spirit will come upon you and the power of the Most High will overshadow you.’ The word for overshadow is episkiazo which is used four times in the Greek translation of the Old Testament. When God overshadowed the tabernacle with his presence see Exodus 40:35. In Psalm 91:4 the same word is used to describe how God [protectively covers his people. The other two uses Psalm 140:7 and Proverbs 18:11. both these verses use the word to describe a means of protection..

For Mary the work of the Holy Spirit in her life did not protect her from the painful realities of living a life for God, rather it protected her in the painful realities of living for God.

Father thank you that the Holy Spirit protects us in the in the painful realities of living for God not from those painful realities.

Bible in a year: proverbs 2:10-5:14
title: The Spirit in the .life of Jesus part 7

html:
The work of the Holy Spirit in the life of Mary teaches us that submission is more important than opportunity.

If you were to really think about it, Mary is probably the least likely person who you would have thought to make a difference in the world, she was a pheasant teenage girl, who probably could not read, and yet Luke tells us.

‘In the sixth month of Elizabeth’s pregnancy, God sent the angel Gabriel to Nazareth, a village in Galilee.’

This is the second time Gabriel is mentioned in this chapter. The first time we meet him in the Temple in Jerusalem where he met Zechariah. There could not be more of a contrast. The Temple, the most important building in the nation, the heart of Jerusalem around which the life of the city revolved, and then Nazareth. Nazareth is not mentioned in the Old Testament nor is it among the sixty-three villages of Galilee

mentioned in the Hebrew Talmud, or the forty-five mentioned by first-century Jewish historian Josephus, who knew the area well. This was an insignificant little town. Its population is estimated to have been between one hundred and four hundred people, though its lack of mention in the Talmud and by Josephus might suggest that it was far

smaller. It was not very accessible and was bypassed by the main trade routes. Nathaniel, one of the disciples asked the question, ‘Can anything good come out of Nazareth?’

I read one source that explained that Nazareth evolved into the major refuge site for Galilee, Judah and Samaria. Around Nazareth there were many abandoned quarries that were ideal for landfill. Into these quarries the carcasses of dead animals and other refuse was placed. Because of the high level of lead contamination and bacteria putrefaction caused by the garbage dumps, Nazareth became synonymous with physical and mental illness. Nazareth became a derogatory slang word for anything that was despicable, dirty or diseased.

The Nativity story teaches us, that in our obscurity and isolation we need an encounter with God. We need to meet God where we are at.

Sometimes we can feel so isolated, so cut of from others we can be tempted to think that our lives are of little if any consequence to God. Maybe you feel that you are in ‘Nazareth,’ it may not be a geographical Nazareth, but it may be a socially or emotionally, it may be behind your front door. We need to ask God to meet us in bleakness of our obscurity and realise that prestige, position and power are never necessary for the purposes of God to be accomplished in our lives. Our social, economic, environmental or geographical status does not determine the purposes of God for our lives. The critical factor for anyone who wants to see God’s will accomplished in them, is their relationship with the Holy Spirit. Submission is more important than opportunity. D L Moody said, “The world has yet to see what God can do with a man fully consecrated to him. By God’s help, I aim to be that man.”

Mary was seemingly a nobody from a despised placed, but because of her submission to God and His Spirit, the world was transformed.

The work of the Holy Spirit in our lives needs to sanctify the ordinary.

After the angel Gabriel came to Mary, everything in her world changed. The future would be very different than she could have ever imagined, however, on the other hand nothing changed. Mary remained where she was, her daily life was not radically changed. Yes she went to see her relative Elisabeth, but for the most part the mundane routine of her life remained the same. We don’t read of any more angelic visits, or special revelations, except when John leaped for joy in his mother’s womb. Luke 1:41.

It was in the mundane ordinariness of the every day that God found the space to grow Mary and the life of Jesus within her. God could have set Mary in some luxurious palace where she could had been waited on and had all her needs met, but he didn’t. Mary, full of the life of Jesus through the power of the Spirit had to grow in the dim realities of her normal obscure life. Something in me thinks that God loves to turn the ordinariness of our lives into a holy space.

The work of the Holy Spirit in our lives will challenge how we think about ourselves so we can receive God’s love. What I find fascinating about Mary is the thing that caused her to be confused and disturbed. Look at what the text says, ‘Gabriel appeared to her and said, “Greetings, favoured woman! The Lord is with you!. Confused and disturbed, Mary tried to think what the angel could mean. The word Luke uses for disturbed “diatarasso” meant “agitate” perplexed,” “greatly troubled.” The appearance of the angel Gabriel did not disturb her, but what he said about her.

What is going on here? The English words “highly favoured” in the verse above are a translation of the Greek word charitoo. This word occurs only twice in the New Testament: Ephesians 1:6 and Luke 1:28. This word Charitoo is a verb, which in essence means to “bestow favour.” It indicates an action that God performed on those who have found favour in His sight. For Mary the thought that she was highly favoured by God was something she would have found difficult to accept, ‘Mary you are highly favoured.’ for Mary this did not add up. She would never have seen or described herself as being ‘highly favoured by God.’ I love the fact that the work of the Spirit in a persons life will always affirm them and assure them of God’s love for them.

Just like many of us, Mary struggled with the fact that she was favoured by God. Intellectually and emotionally this did not make sense. However, if she was going to be able to accomplish to purposes of God for her life, through the power of the Spirit then she would need to embrace the fact that she was totally loved by God.

We know in our heads that God loves and accepts us, but we live and think as if he doesn’t. That is why our insecurities have such a massive influence upon our lives, for we think God could not love us, or we need to do better or be better so God will love us. This ingrained belief, that we are not totally or really accepted by God, will rob us of the courage and resilience to do the will of God.

One of the crucial roles, if not the most crucial role of the Spirit is to affirm us in the reality of the love of God, we will unpack this more when we consider the role of the Holy Spirit at the baptism of Jesus.

Father may the Holy Spirit help me to receive your love and encouragement.

Bible in a year: proverbs 5:15-8:11
title: The Spirit in the life of Jesus part 8

html:
The Baptism Of Jesus. Matthew 3:13-16

Many people, both Christians and non Christians are living with an acute crisis of identity. Sadly too many Christians do not know who they are.

‘Most Christians do not know who they are in Christ, to one degree of another. We all wear false labels or identities which can lead to a lot of confusion, loneliness, anxiety, failure, insecurity, depression, and fear, with a ripple effect that goes into our families and all interpersonal areas of our lives. Add to that, once Satan can take the child of God down in the area of our image, he wins, as we become isolated, depressed, ineffectual in life, and ultimately hopeless that we'll never change, or our circumstances will never change.’ Penny Wiser White. Who Am I?

Knowing who we are before God is essential for a holy and effective life. Many of our insecurities and fears stem from our confusion and uncertainty about our identity. So we look for an identity in all the wrong places not realising that in doing this we are actually affirming and enabling our insecurities. People go into old age addicted to their insecurities because they have spent their whole life finding their identity in the wrong place. Their is someone I know who is in their seventies, and every time I meet him, he lets me know about what he is doing for God and the position of ‘authority’ he has within certain mission organisation. I believe that he is expressing deep insecurities when he tells me these things. However, if what we achieve or do for God becomes more important than our relationship with Him, we are not just creating a false identity, but we are also being evil. I realise that that sounds very strong, and it is. But let me remind you of the words of Jesus. ‘Many will say to me on that day, ‘Lord, Lord, did we not prophesy in your name and in your name drive out demons and in your name perform many miracles?’ ‘Then I will tell them plainly, ‘I never knew you. Away from me, you evildoers!’ Matthew 7;22-23

As we are going to see from the life of Jesus, the role of the Holy Spirit in our lives is to help us accept that we are children of God. Paul said it this way in Romans 8:15-16 ’So you have not received a spirit that makes you fearful slaves. Instead, you received God’s Spirit when he adopted you as his own children. Now we call him, “Abba, Father. For his Spirit joins with our spirit to affirm that we are God’s children.’

We need to get our minds around this. As it was for Jesus so it needs to be for us. The primary work of the Spirit is to help us find our identity in the Father’s love. I do not hear many people pray about this. We are happy to rightly ask the Spirit to help us in our ministry, or to work in the lives of others, but rarely do we seek the Spirit’s help when it comes to discovering and accepting who we are. And yet identity rooted in the love of the Father, through the work of the Spirit, needs to be the place from where our lives and ministry come from.

We know that Jesus did his ministry through the power of the Spirit see Acts 10:38. Luke 4:18. But this power of the Spirit for ministry was an expression of him knowing his Fathers love. He did what he did in ministry not only because he knew that his father loves us, but because he also knew that the father loved him.

There was no identity crisis in the life of Jesus Christ. He knew who He was. He knew where He had come from, and why he was here. And he knew where He was going. And when you are that liberated, then you can serve.’ Howard Hendricks.

The Holy Spirit at the Baptism of Jesus

1. Let’s consider the heart attitude as Jesus got baptised.

a. Humility.

Jesus went to John to be baptized. This is very strange because John was baptizing people because they were turning from their sin and turning to God. See Matthew 3:1-12. We know that Jesus had lived a life free from sin, he lived a life in continual fellowship with his Father, so why did he want John to baptize him? He chose to be baptized so he could humbly identify with us. His baptism was an expression of profound humility and radical identification. You could say that in some ways the humility and identification that Jesus expressed in his baptism was a shadow of the humility and identification he would show at the cross. Jesus would be unable to accomplish his father’s will without living a life of continual humility. His humility enabled him to meaningfully relate to every broken and needy person he met.

b. Prayer.

Luke tells us, ‘As he was praying the heavens opened.’ we do not know what Jesus prayed for, but there may be a clue in the text. In Mark’s account of the Baptism of Jesus we are told a very interesting thing. He says that the heavens were torn open. The word for torn is schizomenous, this is a violent word that means to tear or cleave and it requires determination and strength. The same word is used in Mark 15:38 talking about the curtain in the temple being torn in two. (Apparently the temple curtain was so heavy that it took 300 men to lift it.) When Mark tells us the heavens were torn open, he was alluding to a passage in the Old Testament, Isaiah 64:1-4

‘Oh, that you would rend the heavens and come down, that the mountains would tremble before you! 2 As when fire sets twigs ablaze and causes water to boil, come down to make your name known to your enemies and cause the nations to quake before you! 3 or when you did awesome things that we did not expect, you came down, and the mountains trembled before you. 4 Since ancient times no one has heard, no ear has perceived, no eye has seen any God besides you, who acts on behalf of those who wait for him.’

Isaiah 64:1-4 is part of a longer prayer of lament recorded in Isaiah 63:7-64:12. A lament is a prayer that cries out to God from the midst of desperate grief, pain, or any circumstance that seems out of control. It vocalizes the hurt to God with the conviction, the faith, that God can and will bring relief. A lament is not just the venting of frustration, but is a profound statement of faith in God from the midst of utter human hopelessness. The significance of a lament is that the worshipper prays in the midst of his pain. He believes that God cares about His condition and he has enough faith in God to trust Him with the outcome. It is interesting to note that the prayer recorded in Isaiah 64:1-4 is that God would rend the heavens, come down and make your name know to your enemies by great displays of power causing the mountains to tremble. However, when God tore open the heavens, his power and glory were not displayed in the way the prayer in Isaiah had hoped or expected. Their was no powerful display of God’s just wrath, but a display of the tender love of a father.

Father may the powerful affirming ministry of the Spirit continually touch my life.

Bible in a year: proverbs 8:12-11:11
title: The Spirit in the life of Jesus part 9

html:
The Holy Spirit in bodily form descended on him like a dove.

I don’t think this was Jesus’ first experience of the Spirit. Although we are not explicitly told, there is inference in the language that Luke uses to describe Jesus’ growth that he may have been aware of the work of the Spirit in his life. See Luke 2:40,52. However, at his baptism it seems that his experience of the Spirit deepened as he was about to embark on his mission to bring the Kingdom of God to a needy world.

There has been a lot of debate about the significance of the Spirit descending on him like a dove. According to Leon Morris ‘The symbolism is puzzling, as the dove was not an accepted symbol of the Holy Spirit (though a few late Jewish writings do use it). Rather the dove stood for Israel.’ Many suggest that because a dove is pure and gentle that is is a picture of the Holy Spirit. While that is true, I think the dove was a symbol of the countercultural nature of the kingdom of God.

Jesus lived his entire human life in a country that was under the aggressive authority of the Roman Empire. The insignia of the Roman Empire was the eagle which symbolised strength and power. If you saw the insignia of an eagle on a pole, that meant that the Romans had come to your land to stay. The kingdom of God comes more like a dove than an eagle. The work of the Spirit does not need power, position, force or strength. The coming of the Spirit upon Jesus teaches us that God does not require the brutal ‘eagle like,’ forces of an earthly empire to build his kingdom. Could it be that aggression, or a need to dominate others, is a way that churches and individual Christians try to compensate for the fact that they are not living in the Spirit?

The voice of the Father

I don’t know if you have ever seen the film ‘The King’s Speech?’ It tells the story of King George VI who was king from 1936-1952. It was during this time the Monarchy began to broadcast live to the nation. This was very ironic because George VI had a very bad stutter. He was unable to use his voice as he had hoped. One of the reasons why he had stutter was because of his relationship with his father King George V who once said:-

‘My father was frightened of his mother; I was frightened of my father, and I am damned well going to see to it that my children are frightened of me.’

Imagine [maybe you don’t have to imagine it.] being brought up in atmosphere of fear, it is going to have devastating and dramatic effects on you and your future. Many people have be brought up in homes where there has been a dysfunctional father. Many of us carry wounds, scars and debilitating baggage because of an unhealthy or unloving relationship with our fathers. So when we are told that God wants us to know him as father, we can feel a bit uncomfortable, or uneasy.

I wonder what you think of this quote by J I Packer.

“You sum up the whole of New Testament religion if you describe it as the knowledge of God as one’s holy Father. If you want to judge how well a person understands Christianity, find out how much he makes of the thought of being God’s child, and having God as his Father. If this is not the thought that prompts and controls his worship and prayers and his whole outlook on life, it means that he does not understand Christianity very well at all. For everything that Christ taught, everything that makes the New Testament new, and better than the Old, everything that is distinctively Christian as opposed to merely Jewish, is summed up in the knowledge of the Fatherhood of God. ‘Father’ is the Christian name for God. Our understanding of Christianity cannot be better than our grasp of adoption.”

https://www.goodreads.com/quotes/958523-you-sum-up-the-whole-of-new-testament-religion-if. Accessed 18/07/25

Many of us are happy to relate to God as Lord, or Savior, or King, but not father. Irrespective of what we think of our fathers, we do a great injustice to God, and grave harm to ourselves if we project our experience and understanding of our earthly father upon him. Yet knowing God as father is the key to knowing God; that is why the ‘Lord’s prayer,’ begins with the words, ‘Our Father,’ Maybe knowing God as ‘father,’ is our greatest need, and the source of security that will produce fruitful living.

In the New Testament, Father was the word Jesus used most often when speaking about or to God, about 170 times in all the word is used. In every prayer except one, Jesus spoke to God as Father. If you read the gospel of John, it could be understood as an exposition of Jesus’ relationship with his Father, in the gospel there are 109 references to the father.

The word Abba that Jesus used in Mark 14:36 which reads. Abba, Father,” he said, “everything is possible for you. Take this cup from me. Yet not what I will, but what you will.” This is the only time we have on record of Jesus using the title Abba. This is in some ways the most difficult time in Jesus’ life, so it is very significant on this occasion. It has been widely taught in Christian circles that the word Abba was used by a young child to communicate with their father, and many see it as a ‘daddy’ word.

This is an incomplete understanding of the word. The word was also used by adults as an expression of great honour and respect. Sometimes the Rabbis were called Abba.

Sometimes the voice of the Father is the most difficult voice to hear, we are more attuned to lesser voices, our own voices, the voice of others, the voice of the enemy.

Sometimes we allow the lies of the enemy to control our minds, and we cannot really accept the immutable fact that God loves being our father. Father thank you that you love and enjoy being my Father Bible in a year reading plan proverbs 11:12-13:25
title: The Spirit in the life of Jesus part 10

html:
Through the ministry of the Spirit the father expressed his love by affirming Jesus’ identity.

As we have been saying, knowing who we are and accepting who we are can be a difficult process. Often how we view ourselves is very different as to how God sees us. The word that is used for love in Matthew 3:17 is agapetos, it describes one who is in a very special relationship with another and in secular Greek is used mostly of a child, especially an only child to whom all the love of his parents is given (e.g. used by the Father describing His only Son and Abraham describing his "only son" in).Gen 22:2

Biblically a persons identity has nothing to do with what we do, or what we achieve, but has everything to do with who we are. When Jesus was being baptized, he wasn't standing before his Father with an impressive list of achievements that made him loveable. Jesus understood that he needed to receive his Father’s love if he was going to accomplish his Father’s will.

For Jesus accepting his identity was about him being able to be the person his Father saw him to be. How God sees us is the most important thing about us. If you were to hear God speaking from heaven, and say ‘you are my son, my daughter,’ how would you react? Most of the time when we find ourselves far from God, it can usually be traced back to some kind of identity crisis about how God sees us, or how we think God should sees us. It is difficult to live as a child of God, if you do not believe you are a child of God.

The father also expressed his pleasure with his Son.

I find this amazing, God the Father did not think, ‘Jesus knows how I feel about him,’ He did not assume that his Son knew that he was loved. Authentic love and pleasure we find in others needs to be expressed. Expressing love is both a divine and human necessity. The word for pleased eudokeo. In classic Greek it means to be well pleased or content, to be favoured.

It would be very easy to read this incident in the life of Jesus, and think, its a bit mushy or a bit sentimental. It does not sound very macho. But when we look a bit deeper and scratch beneath the surface we discover that when God the Father spoke, he was alluding to three old testament passages.

In Psalm 2 7-9 we read 7 ‘I will proclaim the Lord’s decree: He said to me, “You are my son; today I have become your father. 8 Ask me, and I will make the nations your inheritance, the ends of the earth your possession. 9 You will break them with a rod of iron, you will dash them to pieces like pottery.”. Psalm 2 is a messianic psalm which describes the privileges and responsibility of the Son.

The second passage that is alluded to is Genesis 22 look at what it says, Some time later God tested Abraham. He said to him, “Abraham!” “Here I am,” he replied. 2 Then God said, “Take your son, your only son, whom you love—Isaac—and go to the region of Moriah. Sacrifice him there as a burnt offering on a mountain I will show you.”

The third passage is Isaiah 42:1 “Here is my servant, whom I uphold,
my chosen one in whom I delight. Isaiah 42:1-4 is the first reference of four that refer to a suffering messiah in Isaiah 40-55. [see 46:1-6, 50:4-9, 52:13-53:12.].

As Jesus listened to his father speak, he not only heard affirming words of encouragement, but he also heard words of challenge. He knew that the affirming word that came from the Old Testament were also words that predicted his suffering and death.

‘There was no identity crisis in the life of Jesus Christ. He knew who He was. He knew where He had come from, and why he was here. And he knew where He was going. And when you are that liberated, then you can serve.’

Howard G. Hendricks https://quotefancy.com/quote/1591744/Howard-G-Hendricks-There-was-no-identity-crisis-in-the-life-of-Jesus-Christ-He-knew-who. Accessed 3/04/20255

Father thank you we find the courage to do your will when we discover and live out of our identity in you.

Bible in a year: proverbs, 14-16
title: The Spirit in the life of Jesus part 11

html:
Spirits involvement in Jesus’ temptation in the wilderness.

It is very surprising what happened to Jesus after he experienced the Holy Spirit at his baptism. Mark tells us that ‘The Spirit then compelled Jesus to go into the wilderness.’ Mark 1:12. It is as if Jesus as a man, needed to experience the life and work of the Spirit in his private and personal life before he could demonstrate the power of the Spirit through his ministry. This was a time of testing ordained by his Father, so Jesus could discover what it really meant to live in submission as a human son.

Or to put it an other way, the work of the Spirit in Jesus’ personal life was a means of continually affirming his identity. At his baptism, Jesus was declared as God’s son, in the wilderness, Jesus chose to act as God’s son and live out of his true identity.

Jesus was submitted to the Spirit.

As we have seen before. The word translated compelled is ekballo in Mark 1:12 is a very weak translation. The word he uses for “Sent” is an extremely strong word, it literally means to drive out your enemies. In the LXX [The Greek translation of the New Testament.] the word is used to describe how God cast Adam out of the garden of Eden see Genesis 3:34. it was also used in the context where an enemy, frustrating or standing in the way of God fulfilling his purpose for his chosen people, so they are ‘cast out’ by God, so that God’s purposes may be fulfilled. See Exodus 23:30 Deuteronomy 33:27ff.

We are not told how the Spirit did this. But as a man, Jesus made a conscious choice to submit his life to leading and control of the Spirit even though is was contrary to everything that felt right or comfortable.

The word for wilderness (eremos) means lonesome, solitary, uninhabited, uncultivated region. MacArthur adds that "the wilderness of Judea, where Jesus was most likely tempted, was the most barren, desolate region in all of Israel. Scarred by precipitous cliffs, deep ravines, and tumbled boulders, it was a region so barren that animals could not be pastured in it.
