In this remote, largely uninhabited area, Jesus might be more alone than anywhere else in Israel. This particular desert was known as ‘Jeshimmon’ or "The Desolation." This stretch of land covers a 35×15 miles scarred plot of limestone waste between Jerusalem and the Dead Sea. It remains inhospitable and barren, incapable of sustaining human life.

I love the fact that Luke speaks about Jesus being loved by the Father before being led by the Spirit. Jesus knew that he was completely loved by his Father, and this gave him the security to be lead by the Spirit. Often as Christians we struggle with being Spirit led. Sometimes God may put something in our minds or hearts and we think, ‘I could never do that,’ or ‘is this really God?’ And we allow fear and insecurity to stop us. Be assured, if you feel you should pray with someone, or show some kindness to someone, make a sacrifice so you just bless someone, or just feel you should show them love and bring God’s grace to them, these feelings or desires are never of Satan.

We must not overthink and allow or insecurities to prevent us from acting. Knowing that God loves you, will give you the courage to follow the Spirit’s leading.

I think I have falling into the trap of thinking that the work of the Spirit in my life is more about ‘Eden,’ than the wilderness. I want God to place me in a garden, where I feel comfortable, safe, and secure, not in a howling wilderness where I feel exposed, vulnerable and out of control. Yet it’s in the solitude of the wilderness we discover that God our Father is enough. We need to get our head around the fact that sometimes when we are not in the wilderness we maybe outside the will of God! Sometimes people can think and talk about a ‘wilderness experience’ as if it were something that is bad, evil or even a consequence of sin. Now sometimes that can/may be the case. However, a ‘wilderness experience’ also can or may be the result of complete faithfulness and devotion to God.

It is amazing that if you read through Luke’s gospel you will notice that Jesus often withdrew to the ethmos, wilderness Luke 4:42, 5:16, 9:10 and sometimes to other places, 6:12, 9:18, 11:1 and 22:39. Although Jesus’ initial experience in the desert was extremely difficult, he developed a love for it because it was there were he could have a deeper relationship with his Father away from distracting noises and pressing responsibilities.

Father help me to accept the fact that sometimes the wilderness is completely in your will. Bible in a year reading plan proverbs 17-20
title: The Spirit in the life of Jesus part 12

html:
There is something else we need to consider about the wilderness/ethmos. It was considered to be the home of Satan, the lodging place of demons and the arena of evil forces of the powers of darkness. At the time of Jesus, the association of demons and the wilderness would have been very familiar to most Jews. Demonic encounters in the Gospels are often set in the desert (e.g.,Matt 12:43–45; Luke 8:29;11:24–26 )

Back to our word ekballo in Mark 1:12. As we have mentioned before. It was mostly used in the New Testament in relation to casting out demons. The word expresses passion of God’s Ekballo, or God’s resistance to evil. God was sending his son into the wilderness with a strong passion so he could confront and unmask the evil one. This is very important. Most people understand the temptation of Jesus as a response of Satan to the baptism of Jesus. But I think it is more likely that God, by the power and leading of the Holy Spirit was taking the battle to Satan through his Son. Jesus’ anointing and affirmation at his baptism made him ‘battle ready.’ He went into the enemies’ territory not just to learn how to be a faithful son who was confined to the limitations of a human body, but he also exposed the subtle ways of Satan through his absolute faithfulness.

It is interesting that Mark 1:12 uses the word ekballo for Jesus being led/driven into the wilderness, because Mark had a positive understanding of spiritual warfare. There are four major exorcism stories in Mark, Mark 1:21-28, 5:1-20, 7:24-30, 9;14-29. Three of these stories have a common denominator, in 1:21-28, 5:1-20 and 9:14-29 Jesus went to where the demon was, he invaded their territory, He took the initiative. What he learned in the wilderness he continued to practice. According to Matthew 12:28 Jesus cast demons out by the Spirit of God.

When we compare what Luke tells us about Jesus being led by the Spirit into the wilderness at this time, with what Mark says, there is a slight but important difference in emphasis. Mark’s emphasis is ‘The Spirit led Jesus into the wilderness,’ while Luke’s emphasis is ‘The Spirit led Jesus in[not into, but in,] the wilderness.’ The word Luke uses to describe the Spirit leading Jesus in the wilderness ‘ago’, almost means the complete opposite to Ekballo, it has the idea to carry, to bring, to guide. and to keep leading. So as Jesus was fasting and was being tempted for forty days he continued to be led by the Spirit. This leading of the Spirit in the wilderness sustained Jesus in this hostile environment. If we sat back and think about this it would have a life giving effect upon our lives. There could have been a lot of things God the Father could have done to help his Son. He could have changed Jesus’ circumstance, he could have miraculously provided sustenance but he didn’t. Instead, Jesus expressed continual submission in a time of great testing so he could remain faithful in his humanity because off the leading of the Spirit. Father thank you, like you did with Jesus, sometimes you want to lead us in our wilderness’ Bible in a year reading plan Proverbs 21-23
title: The Spirit in the life of Jesus part 13

html:
It may be good to ask the question, ‘what did it look like for Jesus to be led by the Spirit while in the wilderness?’ The gospel writers do not explicitly tell us but they do give us some clues.

1.He was biblically minded.

If you listen to what Jesus said at this time in the wilderness all the words we have recorded come from Jesus referring the scriptures, Deuteronomy in particularly. As he was being led by the Spirit in the wilderness his mind was saturated with the word of God.

2. He was self controlled.

This was a physically challenging time for Jesus, he was hungry and tired, living with unmet needs, but through the leading of the Spirit he chose not to take things into his own hands. Through the leading and power of the Spirit he was able to keep his human desires in check, refusing to use his divine power to provide comfort or ease.

3. He trusted his Father.

As we have said, Jesus had divine power, and with a word he could have turned this wilderness into Eden. But he did not use his divine power, he did not play his ‘God card.’ He valued submission above power or ability, because he understood that being submitted to the will of God, was more important than having genuine needs met.

This is both amazing and extremely relevant. Here was Jesus, the creator of the universe. The one who created all things by the power of his word. But in his humanity he chose to set aside his divine power and ability, and instead he chose to submit himself to the leading of the Spirit. It is incredible to think that Jesus defeated Satan from the posture of submission not one of power or strength. It was through submission that he had the emotional and mental resolve to contend with the powers of darkness.

Like Jesus we need to learn what it means to be led by the Spirit, especially at times of isolation and temptation. Maybe it is at these times, when we feel extremely vulnerable or weak that our need to be led by the Spirit is even grater. Maybe it is in

the grit of our personal wildernesses that we learn what it means to be led by the Spirit. Could it be that the wilderness is Gods training ground? Where we learn the ways of the Spirit? Could it be that God-initiated spiritual warfare, is one of the things God chooses to use, to help us discover our true identity in him and our need of the Holy Spirit? Because the Father loved his Son Jesus, the Spirit led him to and through the wilderness so Jesus could teach us the essence of what it means to be a child led by the Spirit.

Let me conclude with a quote used by David Johnson in Gasping for breath

In his book, Backpacking with the saints, Belden Lane asks. ‘What happens when a ‘gifted child’ find himself in a wilderness where he’s stripped of any way of proving his worth? What does he do when there’s nothing he can do, when there’s no audience to applaud his performance, when he faces a cold, silent indifference, if not hostility? His world falls to pieces. The soul hungry for approval starves in a desert like that.’ pp 53

This is why it is so important to submit to the leading of the Spirit no matter where He leads. If He leads you into the wilderness, He will lead you through it.

Father thank you their is something holy about the vulnerability of the wilderness .

Bible in a year: Proverbs 24:1-27:10
title: The Spirit in the .life of Jesus part 14

html:
The role of the Holy Spirit in the Ministry of Jesus.

I wonder how you understand ministry? How would you define Christian ministry? What is Christian Ministry? How we answer this question is very important. Let me share a true story.

On June 13th 1995 The Chicago Tribune ran a story about a man named
Russell Edward Herman died at the age of 67 and in his will he left trillions of dollars to thousands of people he’d never met. Here is a summary of some of what he bequeathed:-

• $1.5 Billion for “projects” in southeastern Illinois
• $6 Trillion to the Federal Reserve Board to pay off the National Debt.
• $6 Trillion to the U. S. Treasury to get the country back on track.
• $2.41 Billion for national forests
• $2.41 Billion to the Ohio River Town of Cave-In Rock
• $189 Trillion for the “rehabilitation of states’ rights”
• $1 Million in American Gold Dollars to each person who has lived in Gallatin County for at least 10 years.

What was the catch? Russell Edward Herman didn’t have trillions of dollars. He was just a simple, poor carpenter. While the will of the late Russell Herman never paid off for his “beneficiaries,” it certainly enlivened conversations. Russell Edward Herman had great intentions, but he lacked the resources needed to make them a reality. His will, as a legal document, had the right title, was filed correctly, but it did not perform as expected. It was ineffective!

Although we can see the funny side of this, something like this can often happen when it comes to Christian ministry. In ministry, it is possible for people to have great hopes, wonderful vision, deep longing to see people lives transformed, but not have the power or resources to accomplish what they had hoped. It is easy for any ministry to slide into a maintenance mode where their goal is to keep things ticking over, where the status quo is sustained.

I don’t believe for one moment that people who see their ministry decline into solely a maintenance role, are bad people. Nor am I dismissing the importance, of maintenance as I’m aware that it requires love, support and a great deal of effort. I will never forget a missionary in France telling me he was happy ‘to flog a dead horse.’ Sadly many who are involved in ministry have succumb to the same attitude. Listen to this quote:-  

“I guess it comes down to a simply choice Billy, Get busy living or get busy dying.’

Sadly some ministries have got busy dying. They have lots of activities, lots of programmes, they are well organised and have good support but they may be in the process of busy dying. So that is why this passage in Luke 4:14-21 is an essential requirement if we are going to have a biblical understanding of ministry.

Father forgive my if I am involved in a ministry that is busy dying. Bible in a year reading plan Proverbs 27:11-3o:33
title: The Spirit in the life of Jesus part 15

html:
All ministry requires a distinctiveness that can only be explained by the power and presence of the Holy Spirit.

It is good to ask the question,

‘If a ministry is not empowered and sustained by the power and presence of the Holy Spirit, has it become an activity more than a ministry?’

With this is mind let us look at our passage, Luke 4:14-21.

The context of the passage.

This is Jesus’ first sermon in his home town of Nazareth. Luke includes this sermon at this point for a number of reasons.

1. Luke is not writing chronologically, he is not recording events in the life of Jesus in the sequence as they happened. Between verses 15 and 16 of Luke 4, there has probably been a year in the ministry of Jesus. Jesus already had a successful ministry in Capernaum (4:23). Jesus said to them, “Surely you will quote this proverb to me: ‘Physician, heal yourself!’ And you will tell me, ‘Do here in your home town what we have heard that you did in Capernaum.’” Jesus’ ministry up to this point gave the words that he was going to say here in the synagogue of Nazareth, credence and authenticity. Any one could say ‘The Spirit of the Lord is upon me,’ but unless there is tangible, clear evidence of the Spirits presence and power in our lives then our claim is bogus.

2. In verse 14 Luke tells us ‘Then Jesus returned to Galilee in the power of the Spirit.’ Remember that in the wilderness Satan had offered glory, kingdoms and authority, see 4:6-7. What a contrast, glory, kingdoms and authority, or the Power of the Spirit. A position of influence or the power of the Spirit. It may be that Jesus was open to the power of the Spirit because he had turned his back on all worldly understandings of power and authority. He understood that the world needs a Spirit filled servant more than a worldly king.

3. Luke wants to introduce us to the ministry of Jesus and how Jesus understood his ministry and what he had been called to do. It is interesting to notice that Jesus’ power to do his ministry, and his understanding of his ministry both were related to ‘Spirit of the Lord’ being upon him. There seems to be no uncertainty or confusion in Jesus’ mind as to what he had been sent to do. As you read the words ‘The Spirit of the Lord is upon me, for he has anointed me to bring good news to the poor. He has sent me to proclaim that captives will be released, that the blind will see, that the oppressed will be set free, and that the time of the Lord’s favour has come,’ you get the sense that these words are both very general and specific. They give us in broad strokes what Jesus was going to do without tying down specifics.

4. Jesus chose to preach this sermon to those who thought they knew him best. Why would he do that? He was teaching us that through the presence and power of the Spirit, God can use a life even though others may think very little of it.

‘Isn’t this Joseph’s son?’

If we were to think about this, this must have taken a lot of courage on Jesus’ part. Those who knew him the longest refused to take him seriously. Joseph’s kid, nothing special about him! They reacted in amazement to His words in the synagogue, and then they began to remind themselves of their personal history with him: they were saying, “Jesus is the son of the local carpenter; He’s common, like us. Where does He get the idea that He’s something special? The Messiah will not be a tradesman!” the Rabbi's taught

This was a very significant moment in the life of Jesus. In the face being rejected, disregarded and not been taking seriously by his community, he allowed himself to be

influenced more by the work of the Spirit in his life, than the wrong opinions, lack of understanding and the insults of others. The courage that he needed to do what His Father asked of him, came from his life in the Spirit.

If we continually live out of our insecurities, and have a constant need for the approval and praise of others to give us significance and worth, then we have a spiritual problem, and we will find it more difficult to find the courage we need to accomplish God’s will.

Father may the influence of the Spirit be the biggest influence upon my life.

Bible in a year: Proverbs
title: The Spirit in the life of Jesus part 16

html:
What does a Spirit filled ministry look like? What can we learn from Jesus understanding of his ministry?

1. A Spirit filled ministry gives people a right understanding about God by revealing the heart of God.

Before Jesus came, people had been wondering what God is really like... There had been 400 years of silence in terms of no recognised prophet declaring the will of God. You can imagine what the people thought. Does He hate us? Is He sick of us? Will He come to judge? Does He care about what we are going through down here on earth? And then God became a man and we could see what He was like. He came for the poor... the afflicted... the broken-hearted... the captive, the sinners. He came to set them free. Jesus’ ministry, corrected and changed peoples understanding of God. Ministry should always be about bringing the heart of God to a broken world. This is so radical, for Jesus living a Spirit filled life was about engaging in people lives. The term for poor (ptochos) refers to those who are abjectly poor or utterly destitute. The most common term for poor in the Hebrew Bible (‘ani) carries with it the notion of economically poor, but it also suggests the idea of oppression, exploitation and suffering.

The bible has many verses that say we should be continually caring for the poor for example:-

Deuteronomy 15:7
“But if there are any poor Israelites in your towns when you arrive in the land the Lord your God is giving you, do not be hard-hearted or tight-fisted toward them.”

Deuteronomy 15:10
“Give generously to the poor, not grudgingly, for the Lord your God will bless you in everything you do.”

Deuteronomy 15:11
“There will always be some in the land who are poor. That is why I am commanding you to share freely with the poor and with other Israelites in need.”

Deuteronomy 24:14
“Never take advantage of poor and destitute labourers, whether they are fellow Israelites or foreigners living in your towns.”

Deuteronomy 27:19
“Cursed is the man who withholds justice from the alien, the fatherless or the widow.”

Proverbs 14:31
“He who oppresses the poor shows contempt for their Maker, but whoever is kind to the needy honours God.”

Ezekiel 18:5-9

“Suppose there is a righteous man who does what is just and right. He does not eat at the mountain shrines or look to the idols of Israel. He does not defile his neighbour’s wife or have sexual relations with a woman during her period. He does not oppress anyone, but returns what he took in pledge for a loan. He does not commit robbery but gives his food to the hungry and provides clothing for the naked. He does not lend to them at interest or take a profit from them. He withholds his hand from doing wrong and judges fairly between two parties.

The implications of these verses are, if we do not care for the poor we are guilty of theft.

The power of the Spirit in our lives will always cause a connection with those who are destitute and poor.

2. A spirit filled ministry enhances our humanity by compensating for our limitations.

Let me read you a quote.

‘Jesus was indeed a human being, a genuine human person, owning all the limitations that pertain to humanity, and Jesus depended upon the Holy Spirit throughout his entire life to enable him to burst the boundaries of his human limitations. The Holy Spirit who descended upon him at his baptism, entered into him, and filled him, was the Spirit of God who infused him with the power to overcome temptations, teach with authority, challenge established religious structures in the name of God, see people not in the mass but as individuals, sense the inner joy of each person or their pain and hurt, reach out and touch people, lift them up, help them, heal them, find them, redeem them, save them, restore them to wholeness, and turn them back to God. In a word, to effectually carry to completion the mission his Father had given him to do and which only He could do in this fallen broken world.’ Gerald Hawthorne.

We have got limitations, sometimes we complain and moan about them. We often think ‘if only,’ ‘if only I could do this, or if only I had that gift or ability God could really use me.’ We fall into the comparison game. We are slow to recognise that our limitations are what teach and remind us that we need a continual and growing of the power and presence of the Spirit in our lives. Matthew 6:1-2, teach that giving to the poor is an act of righteousness, and any lack of generosity on our part is an expression of unrighteousness. Father may the Work of the Holy Spirit in me produce a continuous generosity Bible in a year reading plan Ecclesiastes 3:9-8:17
title: The Spirit in the ife of Jesus part 17

html:
3. A Spirit filled ministry redefines our understanding of the gospel.

The problem with Luke 4:18-19, is that many people have over spiritualised it. So they understand the poor as those who are spiritually poor, the captives, as those who are captive to sin, the blind are those who are spiritually blind and the oppressed are those who are oppressed by Satan. This is a legitimate but incomplete understanding, caused by a wrong understanding of the gospel.

When it comes to sharing the gospel there are two indispensable parts, there is the message of the gospel and the mercy of the gospel. For the most part the western church has focused on the message of the gospel, making evangelism lopsided. We have turned the presentation of the gospel into a cerebral event, with reasoning, apologetics, questions, debate, preaching and conversation. All these are good, however, in and of themselves they are insufficient without the mercy of the gospel.

When we reduce the ministry of the Spirit down to the words that we say, then we have not really grasped the heart of God. You could say that evangelism is essentially a call to get your hands dirty in the messy lives of the lost.

For Jesus, the gospel was a radical expression of relevance, it was wholistic, it was as much about life before dying as it was about life after dying. The Spirit upon Jesus not only drove him into the wilderness, but it also compelled him to be involved in the lives of the poor, the captive, the blind and the oppressed. A Spirit filled life is the antithesis to selfishness, it is an empowered life that will continually make sacrifices in order to engage with the needy and marginalised.

In 2008 David Knepprath and Josh Guisinger moved into the rough-and-tumble down Barberry Village complex in America. Roughly a dozen young Christian men and women have made Barberry Village their home. Their goal: To create a sense of community in a chaotic neighbourhood overrun with drugs, prostitution and gangs. Their work mirrors, in some ways, the "new monasticism" movement, in which Christians move into urban or rural areas to work with the poor. It's not an easy way to live. Some neighbours have been suspicious. Safety is an ongoing concern. And some of these urban missionaries have burned out on a project that can be a 24-hour-a-day burden. Yet they've been so successful that other complex owners asked them to replicate their efforts. Congregations have volunteered their services. A woman from Virginia is moving to the Portland area so she can do similar work in another neighbourhood. Now, at least once a month, churches cook meals for the residents at Barberry Village. In early August, children were invited to a three-day Bible camp. Guisinger and Knepprath and their friends have also helped people move. They've thrown birthday parties for neighbours. And they cleaned up one woman's flooded apartment. Police officers are still dispatched to Barberry Village on a regular basis, sometimes more than once a day. But many neighbours say the complex is safer, friendlier and better for children. A former manager called the young men and women a "godsend.""I hope they continue to do this," said Eugenia Swartout, who lives at the complex with her family. "It gives us some safety and security knowing there are kind people out here and not just bad guys."In the beginning, it was just a group of guys.

Life in the Spirit is explicitly incarnational and practical. It give us the ability to relate to people and their real needs.

4. Life in the Spirit need to be consistent with biblical truth.

Jesus described his experience of the Spirit with biblical language. He quotes Isaiah 61:1-2 and part of Isaiah 58:6. For Jesus his experience of the Spirit was not some kind of mystical experience that made him feel good about himself, rather, his was an experience that allowed him to be secure enough to accomplish the will of the Father for his life by laying his life down for others.

I think that there is a possibility that we have a too subjective understanding of what life in the Spirit is, it has become another means of seeking an emotional high, or self fulfilment. Of course there is real deep joy in living a Spirit filled life, but that joy should move us out of self-centred living to a life of sacrificial service and radical love for others.

5 Life in the Spirit requires great courage.

When Jesus read from Isaiah he chose not complete verse 2, which speaks about the ‘day of God’s anger against their enemies.’ NLT

The omission of the next phrase in Isaiah 61:2—‘day of God’s anger against their enemies.’”NLT—is also significant. Jesus’ audience would suppose that the day of their own salvation would be the day of judgment on their pagan enemies. But the delay of judgment means that this time of the Lord’s favour benefits the Gentiles also. Jesus affirms (vv. 24–27) that Gentiles are also recipients of God’s grace, even when Jews were not so blessed.’Walter L. Liefeld, “Luke,” in The Expositor’s Bible Commentary: Matthew, Mark, Luke, ed. Frank E. Gaebelein, vol. 8 (Grand Rapids, MI: Zondervan Publishing House, 1984), 867.

When the people of Jesus’ home town were listening to him, they began by liking what they were hearing, however when the began to hear Jesus not speaking about God’s vengeance on their enemies, and speak about God’s love and care for the Gentiles they were furious. The word for furious Thumos describes a tumultuous welling up of the whole spirit; a mighty emotion which seizes and moves the whole inner man. They were full of murderous intent. They could not accept the message of grace. They reduced the gospel to fit into their agenda and expectations. The thought that God would love a pagan widow from Zeraphath and a pagan general from Syrian revolted them. So in the middle of synagogue worship, ‘they jumped up and forced Jesus to the edge of the of the hill on which the town was built. ‘They intended to push him over the cliff.’ In that culture when someone was going to be stoned to death they were usually thrown of a cliff first. This was absolutely horrendous, this was a satanic inspired reaction to the grace of God and the work of the Spirit.

To live a Spirit filled life that will produce an effective ministry will mean that we will need great courage. If we lack courage we will take the easy road, we will choose to make our life and ministry about us. We will decide who does and who doesn't deserve the grace of God. We will place people into categories of who we will or we won’t share the love of God with.

This sermon of Jesus at Nazareth is a description and expectation of authentic ministry. Authentic ministry is having the capacity beyond any natural ability to show love, grace, compassion and mercy to anyone irrespective of their character or circumstance, through the power of the Spirit

Martin Niemöller (1892–1984) was a prominent Lutheran pastor in Germany. In the 1920s and early 1930s. He was imprisoned in concentrations camps from 1938 to 1945. He narrowly escaped execution. After his imprisonment, he expressed his deep regret about not having done enough to help victims of the Nazis. His regret was expressed in the following poem

First they came for the Communists
And I did not speak out
Because I was not a Communist
Then they came for the Socialists
And I did not speak out
Because I was not a Socialist
Then they came for the trade unionists
And I did not speak out
Because I was not a trade unionist
Then they came for the Jews
And I did not speak out
Because I was not a Jew
Then they came for me
And there was no one left to peak out for me.

https://hmd.org.uk/resource/first-they-came-by-pastor-martin-niemoller/

Jesus said, ‘“The Spirit of the Lord is upon me, for he has anointed me to bring Good News to the poor. He has sent me to proclaim that captives will be released, that the blind will see, that the oppressed will be set free, and that the time of the Lord’s favour has come.’

May it be the same for us.

Father thank you that a Spirit’s life will cause us to be practical in our care for others. Bible in a year reading plan Ecclesiastes 9-2 Song Of Solomon 1-2
title: The Spirit in the life of Jesus part 18

html:
We have been learning how all of Jesus’ life was determined by his relationship with the Holy Spirit. He was conceived by the power of the Spirit, at his baptism he was anointed by the Spirit. He was led into and through the wilderness by the Spirit. And he understood his ministry to be empowered by the Spirit. All his life was defined by the power of the Spirit. If that is the case, then we need to try and discover if the Holy Spirit played any role in his death and resurrection. There is no mention in the gospels about the role of the Spirit during the death or resurrection of Jesus, however outside the gospels we find some indications of the role and help of the Spirit in Jesus’ life at this time.

The holy Spirit at the death of Jesus.

In Hebrews 9:14 we read “the blood of Christ, who through the eternal Spirit offered himself without blemish to God.” This is not an easy phrase to understand. What is the writer to the Hebrews referring to when he speaks of the ‘eternal Spirit?’ Some people think, that because of this unique title, ‘eternal Spirit,’ which is only found here in the bible, that it must not be the Holy Spirit, but the divine spirit of Jesus.

This is not the only unique title that the writer to the Hebrews has for the Holy Spirit. In Hebrews 10:29 most bibles translate the name of the Spirit as the Spirit of grace, which is another unique title.

Some commentators think that the eternal spirit in this verse is referring to Jesus’ divine nature as an eternal Son. But this could not be the case because Jesus needed to die as a sinless man, not a divine being with extra internal resources that would be eliminated or usurped his humanity.

Writing about this Gerald F Hawthorne says:-

‘Did he not begin his epistle with a most exalted view of Jesus, describing him as Son, Divine, God even (Heb 1:2-12)? Yes, to be sure. And yet paradoxically his emphasis throughout this document is upon the genuineness of Jesus’ humanity. He certainly affirmed the preexistence of Jesus, but he equally affirms the realness of Jesus as a human being. But it is fundamental to his entire argument that Jesus faced life and death as a person of flesh and blood (Heb 2:14), not a person who by virtue of his divine nature had a distinct and unparalleled advantage over all other persons. The writer to the Hebrews believed that Jesus “had to be made like [other people] in every way” (2:7 NEB), that he was ‘’tempted in every way, just as we are – yet without sin” (4:15 NIV), and that “he himself suffered when he was tempted” (2:18 NIV). He believed that Jesus, in facing his own death, was in desperate straits and that as a consequence he prayed with loud cries and tears to God who could save him from death (5:7). The writer believed, perhaps, that in Gethsemane, Jesus faced his greatest of all temptations – the intense temptation to live, the temptation to flee death, to draw back from the cross, to say “NO” to the Father’s will for whatever reasons might have been coursing through his mind. But just as Jesus had overcome all previous temptations, even temptations to go his own way and do his own will, aided in these victories by the Holy Spirit, so now as well...Just as Jesus was strengthened throughout his life by the Holy Spirit upon whom he had depended to help him make the right moral choices, so now at this ultimately crucial moment he was strengthened by the Spirit so he was able to choose for God and against himself and say, ”Not my will but yours! Here I am! I have come to do your will, O God” (Heb. 10:7 Mark 14:34-36).

John MacArthur puts it this way "Jesus did everything He did on earth in obedience to the Father through the Spirit. Even in His supreme sacrifice, He through the eternal Spirit, offered Himself without blemish to God. In doing so, He provided the cleansing of our consciences from dead works to serve the living God.’. https://www.barabbas.com/macarthurs-view-of-hebrews-911-14/ accessed 4/04/2025

This is the only time in the New Testament that speaks of the role of the Holy Spirits involvement at the death of Jesus. To read that Jesus offered himself to God by the power of the eternal Spirit is revolutionary and should transform our understanding of the work of the Spirit in our lives.

In the face of the terrifying cruelty of the cross, the Power of the Holy Spirit heightened Jesus’ resolve, deepened his commitment and gave him the courage to offer himself to the Father through death. It is significant that it is the writer to the Hebrews that tells us that it was through the eternal Spirit that Jesus offered himself to God. The believers who received the letter to the Hebrews were in a very precarious situation, and their commitment to Jesus was being threatened.

‘This magnificent letter to the Hebrews was written to a group of first-century Christians who were in danger of giving up. It is clear from even a casual reading of the letter that the times were hard for Jewish Christians especially. Many of them had been exposed to fierce persecution. They had been physically assaulted, their homes had been plundered; some had been cast into prison on account of their faith, others had been ridiculed in public because of their resolute trust in Jesus (10:32–34). Many of these Jewish Christians had accepted all this adversity joyfully. But others had ‘shrunk back’ from their earlier allegiance to Christ and became apostates. Without going that far, others were in danger of compromise. Raymond Brown, The Message of Hebrews: Christ above All. Page 13

At times in all our lives we will find ourselves in a situation where God may be asking something of us that we may feel or think is too much or too difficult, so we allow our fears and anxieties to determine our response to God, fear becomes our master, the thing that controls us. The anxiety and fear that Jesus experienced before his death on the cross was very real, but it was through the power of the Spirit that he was able to work his way through them.

In a lesser, but in a very real way, the recipients of the letter to the Hebrews were facing a similar issue. They needed to know the power of the Spirit if they were going to remain faithful and find the courage that authentic commitment requires.

Father may the Holy Spirit give me the courage I need to completely offer myself to you

title: The Spirit in the life of Jesus part 19

html:
I think we need to be biblical and realistic and accept the fact that there will be times when the will of God for our lives will be painful, demanding and will require the power of the Holy Spirit in our lives to see it fulfilled.

But there is a problem, because many Christians believe that God will never ask of you, or give you more than you are able to cope with. This commonly held belief is based off 1 Corinthians 10:13. ‘’No temptation has overtaken you that is not common to man. God is faithful, and He will not let you be tempted beyond your ability, but with the temptation He will provide the way of escape, that you may be able to endure it.”

Many people teaching that “God won’t give you more than you can handle” explain that the word “temptation,” or peirasmos in Greek, can refer to temptation to a sin, a trial, or any type of suffering. They are right. In fact, the Greek word used here for “temptation” can be used to speak of both suffering and sin..

However, when we look to the context of the passage to determine which meaning Paul intended, we find that he is addressing sin, not suffering. Verse 6 addresses those who “desire evil.” In verse 7 Paul addresses “idolaters,” showing the context of this passage is sin. Verse 8 identifies this idolatry specifically as “sexual immorality.” The following verses continue to address sin as we read of “put(ting) Christ to the test” in verse 9 and grumbling in verse 10. And verse 12 gives the exhortation “therefore, let anyone who thinks that he stands take heed lest he fall,” which continues the focus of the passage on addressing sin. Verse 13 continues to address sin within the context of these verses. The plain reading of this text should lead us to conclude that Paul chose to use the word “temptation” to address temptation to sin, not trials and suffering, in this passage.

This verse is ensuring us that God will provide an escape from the temptation of potential sin. However it is not saying that we will be kept from suffering nor is it saying that God’s will for our lives is tailored to our physical, emotional or psychological abilities or strengths. The will of God can be beyond our capacities to cope and way outside our comfort zones, making the empowering of the Spirit more necessary. For Jesus in his humanity, the ability to offer himself to God was aided by the power of the eternal Spirit.

There is one other thing we need to mention. The word ‘offered’ in this verse is very suggestive. I think it says a lot about the heart of Jesus, he did not see himself as a victim caught in the cruel claws of horrific circumstances which could appear outside the control of God. Rather, through the power of the Spirit he viewed the circumstances of his death as a means whereby he could offer his life to God in death. This offering attitude made acceptance of the cross possible.

Wouldn’t it be amazing if the power of the Spirit in our lives were to transform our thinking about ourselves so that we would begin to understand and live as if our lives were an offering onto God, and that through the Spirit’s power we could accept the challenges, demands, sacrifices and losses his will for our lives will entail.

Father thank you that you always provide a way to escape from sinning

Bible in a year: Isaiah 1:10-5:17
title: The Spirit in the life of Jesus part 20

html:
The Holy Spirit at Jesus’ resurrection.

When we think about the resurrection we are not inclined to think much about the role of the Holy Spirit in this event. The predominate emphasis of scripture is not that Jesus ‘rose’ from the dead, but that he was ‘raised’ from the dead. Jesus’ resurrection primarily was something that happened to him, not something he did. Seventeen times in the Acts and the epistles it is stated that God raised Jesus from the dead. See Acts 3:15, 4:10, 5:30, 10:40, 13:30, 37, Rom 4:24, 8:11.34 10:9, 1 Cor. 6:14, 15:15. 2 Cor. 4:14, Gal. 1:1, Eph. 1:20, Col. 2:12. 1 Thess. 1:10.

The question is how did God do this?

He did through the power of His Spirit

1 Peter 3:18 says 18 ‘’Christ suffered for our sins once for all time. He never sinned, but he died for sinners to bring you safely home to God. He suffered physical death, but he was raised to life in the Spirit.’’

Romans 8:11 says ‘’The Spirit of God, who raised Jesus from the dead, lives in you. And just as God raised Christ Jesus from the dead, he will give life to your mortal bodies by this same Spirit living within you.’’

So according to Paul, The Spirit of God who raised Jesus lives in us. But what does that mean for us in the present? The power of the Spirit that raised Jesus, wants to strengthen, empower, sustain and redefine the purpose of our mortal bodies for the same reasons why he raised Jesus from the dead. Or to put it another way, through our mortal physical bodies the Holy Spirit wants to accomplish the same thing that he accomplished through the resurrection of Jesus.

The resurrection of Jesus may well be the greatest expression of the Spirits power. And through this power, Jesus was vindicated, exalted and His victory over Satan, sin and death was clearly demonstrated.

Because the Spirit who raised Jesus from the dead lives in us, the story of our lives is much bigger than us, the story of our lives must be, Jesus is vindicated, Jesus is exalted, Jesus has won. This is what it means to live a Spirit filled life. Paul once said, ‘I want to know Christ—yes, to know the power of his resurrection.’

The power of the resurrection that brings Jesus great glory The Spirit filled life is a life that has been empowered to demonstrate the glory, exaltation, vindication and victory of the risen Christ., Father may the story of our lives reflect the glorious victory of Jesus Bible in a year reading plan Isaiah 5:18-9::12
title: The Spirit in the life of Jesus part 21

html:
We want to finish off by looking at the Holy Spirit and the ascension of Jesus. As we look at this, there are two truths we need to keep in mind. The church as a collection of individuals make up the body of Christ, and as Jesus’ new body on earth we need a collective experience of the Spirit. Secondly we need to view Jesus’ ascension as his enthronement and Pentecost is an expression of his royal power.

The background to Pentecost.

Originally Pentecost was a Jewish feast or celebration which comes in the early summer (mid May-mid June). It’s the only Levitical Feast Day between the 3 spring feasts (Passover, Unleavened Bread, and First Fruits) and the 3 in the autumn festivals (Rosh Hashanna, Yom Kippur, and Tabernacles). The Hebrew name for this Day is Shavuot, which means weeks, so in Israel it’s often called the Feast of Weeks.

We know from the Old Testament that this feast was originally ordained by God so that His people could celebrate the early harvest. In Palestine there were two harvests each year. The early harvest came during the months of May and June; the final harvest came in the autumn. Pentecost was the celebration of the beginning of the early wheat harvest. The word Pentecost means fifty, so 7 weeks and 1 day after the celebration of the Passover, Jerusalem would have been filled with people celebrating the feast.

For Christians, Pentecost should be a very important day, although sadly the protestant tradition has played it down and hasn’t really grasped its importance. It should be a day of celebration just like Christmas day and Easter Sunday. For on the Day of Pentecost, God the Holy Spirit came to live in mankind, and the world became a new place. The day of Pentecost is slightly different to our Christmas and Easter celebration in this regard. At Christmas and Easter we celebrate what Jesus did for us through his birth, death and resurrection. But at Pentecost we share in and experience what Jesus did for us through his birth, death and resurrection and accension.

What can we learn from the day of Pentecost? What can it teach us?

1. Pentecost is God’s victory cry.

The coming of the Holy Spirit is tangible evidence that Jesus is Lord. It is one of the ways Jesus demonstrated his victory over Satan, sin and death. In the gospel of John, on the last and greatest day of the festival, Jesus stood and said in a loud voice, “Let anyone who is thirsty come to me and drink. Whoever believes in me, as Scripture has said, rivers of living water will flow from within them.” By this, he meant the Spirit, whom those who believed in him were later to receive. Up to that time Spirit had not been given, since Jesus had not been glorified.’ John 7:37-39. At Pentecost Jesus was now glorified and seated at the right hand of God. The father wanted the world to know that He had accepted the sacrifice that Jesus had made for our sin, so the Spirit acted in such a way that could not be missed or ignored.

Father thank you that the day of Pentecost is a deceleration f Jesus’ great victory.

Bible in a year: Isaiah 9:13-13:16
title: The Holy Spirit and the ascension of Jesus. Acts 1 and 2

html:
When we compare the coming of the Holy Spirit at Pentecost, with the coming of the Holy Spirit at the baptism of Jesus we see a vast contrast. At the baptism of Jesus the Holy Spirit came like a dove, but here at Pentecost he comes with great power.

Luke says, in Acts 2:2 ‘And suddenly from heaven there came a sound like the rush of a violent wind, and it filled the entire house where they were sitting.’

The activity of the Spirit within the church will always demonstrate the victory and glorification of Jesus; He will always point to the fact that Jesus is Lord. The coming of the Spirit tells the world that things are now going to be different, they will never be the same, that mankind no longer needs to live in bondage to Satan and sin, that now we can really know God and live in relationship with Him.

Someone has said. ‘The Ascension activates Christ’s victory in history.’ And at Pentecost God made an irrefutable statement that things were going to be different because Jesus the Sovereign King was doing something that had never happened before. He was going to pour his Spirit upon all types of people. Male, female, young, old, Jew, Gentile, free and slave. This is totally amazing, totally breathtaking, almost unbelievable, that the victory of Jesus is manifested through the Spirit-filled lives of His people.

2.Through the coming Spirit, God began to fill the world with a new knowledge of Himself.

Before the day of Pentecost the Holy Spirit was active on the earth. In the Old Testament the Holy Spirit came upon individuals with a specific purpose in mind for a short period of time. Now the Holy Spirit has come upon people of all nations. God was not a localised deity, or the exclusive God of the Jewish nation, but the God of the entire world. Pentecost is about God demonstrating His Lordship over all the earth. Habakkuk 2:14. ‘For the earth will be filled with the knowledge of the glory of the LORD as the waters cover the sea.’ At Pentecost God began to show the glory of His grace through broken people who were deeply touched by His Spirit. The work of the Holy Spirit in our lives is the affirmation of Jesus’ supremacy and glorification.

3. The day of Pentecost is the beginning inauguration of God’s new creation.

The events that are recorded for us in Acts 2 not only have its roots in the Shavuot, but it has roots that go back to the creation story.

‘In the beginning God created the heavens and the earth. 2 Now the earth was formless and empty, darkness was over the surface of the deep, and the Spirit of God was hovering over the waters.’

Look at the descriptive words that are used in this verse, formless, empty and darkness. Then the Spirit of God begins hovering over the waters, this hovering was the prelude to order and beauty, it was the start of creation. So in Acts 2, God transforms the emptiness and darkness of mankind by bringing order to our chaos and confusion. This is what the Holy Spirit does; He rebuilds our lives, He makes the beauty of transformation a reality.

4. If we are going to understand the church and God’s intention and plan for His church, then we will need to understand the character and work of the Holy Spirit.

The character and work of the church should be an expression and an extension of the character and work of the Holy Spirit. To separate the life and work of the church from the life and work of the Spirit is to reduce the church to a legalistic religious club whose primary concern is to make sure all the boxes are ticked. To try and understand God’s intention for his church without a practical understanding of the Holy Spirit is like trying to understand mathematics without using numbers, it is not possible.

‘If the Holy Spirit was withdrawn from the church today, 95 percent of what we do would go on and not too many would know the difference. If the Holy Spirit had been withdrawn from the New Testament church, 95 percent of what they did would stop, and everybody would know the difference.” A. W. Tozer.https://www.thejesusgathering.org/aw-tozer.html accessed 4/04/2025

Father thank you the world is a better place because of Pentecost.

title: The Spirit in the life of Jesus part 23

html:
The Holy Spirit empowers people to be authentic witnesses. See Acts 1:8.

Think about how this power transformed the first-century believers. Prior to Pentecost, Simon Peter couldn't stand up for his faith when strangers asked him if he was a follower of Jesus. After the power of the Holy Spirit was poured out on Pentecost, Peter stood up and boldly preached the gospel, resulting in 3,000 people being saved.

We need to try and understand what the bible means when it is speaking about us ‘being witnesses.’ The Greek word Luke uses for witness ‘martys’ developed to mean martyr. Originally the word was used to describe a witness in a court, and was not used to describe someone who had died for their faith. Sometimes the same word was used to describe God, see Romans 1:9, John 15v26-27 or a false witness. Matthew 26:59. However it became to be used to describe the act of laying down your life for Jesus. (See Acts 22:20)

This development of the word is described in the Encyclopaedia Britannica.

‘The original meaning of the Greek word martys was ‘witness’; in this sense it is often used in the New Testament. Since the most striking witness which Christians could bear to their faith was to die rather than deny it, the word soon began to be used in reference to one who was not only a witness, but specifically a martyr.’ (Encyclopaedia Britannica, 200th Anniversary Edition, 1969, “Martyr”, Volume 14.)

When the Holy Spirit really touches a person’s life, that person develops the attitude of a martyr. They become courageous not because they are bold and strong, but because they have died to what used to be important and essential to them. Persecution does not make martyrs but reveals them. (And maybe our lack of courage is rooted in the fear of losing things we have not died to?) Maybe absolute surrender and dying to our own plans, dreams and desires is the root of real boldness and courage.

The Holy Spirit makes the church relevant.

On the day of Pentecost the disciples began to speak in other languages, languages that others understood. There has been so much debate about these verses, and the gift of tongues, that I think has been a diversion and misses the point. When the Holy Spirit moved in the church in the book of Acts, the church engaged in relevant ways with the community around them. The Holy Spirit needs to work in the Church so He can work in the world. When a church becomes insular and inward looking, you know that is not a church that is filled with the Holy Spirit. The more relevant the church is, the more the world will see the Glory of Jesus.

These disciples were able to relate to and communicate with people who were beyond their experience and understanding. The Holy Spirit is a missionary Spirit, and he can only reach the world by having his way in the church.

Just before we go on let me mention that if you read the gospels you will notice that when Jesus spoke about evangelism and reaching the world, he was always positive. He spoke about the field being white, ready for harvest in John 4. And how the harvest was plentiful but the workers were few in Matthew 9.

Was Jesus being naive? no, not at all, because He knew that the Holy Spirit that energises the church, is the same missionary Spirit that reaches the lost.

The work of the Holy Spirit in the church will cause the world to ask questions.

I think sometimes we believe that being relevant means that we make people feel comfortable, and that is true. But it also can mean to bring a challenge. In this passage we are told that the crowd were bewildered, utterly amazed and perplexed. (See Acts 2 verses 6, 7, and 12.) The Greek terms describing their reactions could be appropriately rendered as confused, in an uproar, beside themselves, blown away.

The power of the Spirit is for all who love Jesus.

If we are used to thinking that God only wants to use a certain type of person, or a certain gender, or a certain age for conveying his plans and purposes, then we are wrong. God’s Spirit tells us otherwise. All people, boys and girls, young and old, free and slaves, whether they be women or men. See Acts 2:17-18.

At Pentecost all the institutional norms were abolished. There was no more spiritual elite. There was no more gender exclusion. There was no more ageism when it came to being used by God. Pentecost inaugurated a new way to serve God. Because Jesus is glorified, and the Holy Spirit has come, then no-one on the basis of ability, status, gender or age can be nor should be excluded from being someone through whom God can speak to His world.

On the Day of Pentecost all the disciples were gathered together in one place, somewhere in Jerusalem. Think about that, the very place where Jesus was killed, the very place where the Roman authorities and religious leaders conspired together. This was the very place where Satan and his evil demons were allowed to carry out the most wicked deed ever done on planet earth. It was into this place of great spiritual darkness and injustice that the Holy Spirit came and brought new life and hope. Where we are may not be as dark and difficult as Jerusalem was in those days, however, we need to experience our localised Pentecost. We need the Spirit of God to come upon us so we can reach the people around us. What God may do in this location through the working of His Spirit may be very different to what happened in Jerusalem; we may not experience a violent rushing wind, or have tongues of fire rest upon us, but we must allow God to manifest the power of His Spirit in ways that he deems appropriate for us and the situation He has placed us in. Father please give your church a new experience of your Spirit. Bible in a year reading plan Isaiah 19:11-24:6
title: The Spirit in the life of Jesus part 24

html:
“An emotionally healthy disciple slows down to be with Jesus, goes beneath the surface of their life to be deeply transformed by Jesus, and offers their life as a gift to the world for Jesus.”

we have imbibed a version of Christianity that is more about going to heaven than it is about profound transformation. Jesus does not want to clean us up and make us ‘nice.’ he wants to make us different, as new, radical disciples that unsettle the world where he has placed us. In truth we do not want a radical Jesus to come and mess up our lives. We are content with a ‘tidy up,’ a ‘spring clean,’ when what we really need is a life reforming make over, we are happy with superficial, shallow obedience and fellowship with God that is neither costly or changing. If our experience of Jesus does not make a tangible, lasting transforming difference to our lives then we may not be following the Jesus of the bible

The story we are going to consider is a very well known story, and because it is so well known it has been sanitised, dumbed down to fit into our neat boxes. It is a story about a prostitute and a Pharisee. It is a story that should disturbed and make us uncomfortable because the point of this story is, we need to become like this prostitute and not like this Pharisee.

The Context of the story

Luke tells us in 7:36 ‘One of the Pharisees asked Jesus to have dinner with him, we know from verse 40 that this Pharisee was called Simon. In Luke gospel we read of Jesus being a 7 meals, Three of these meals were at the homes of Pharisees, Luke 7:36, 11:37, 14:1, these three meals were all contentious. We are not specifically told why Simon invited Jesus. But Luke gives us some clues.

1. Up to this point Luke has mentioned the Pharisees six time, 5:17,21,30, 33. 6:2,7 each time they are antagonistic against Jesus.

2.The way 7:36 is written in the Greek it reads One of the Pharisees kept on asking. It gives the impression that Jesus may have known that this was a set up, and he did not just accept right away.

3. We are told that they were reclining at the table this would indicate that this was a formal or ceremonious occasion. and yet we are told in verses 43-46 that Simon did not offer Jesus the customary expressions of welcome or acceptance. While not mandatory, it would have been a kind gesture for Simon as the host to have had his servants wash the feet of his guest. A kiss was a common form of greeting, although not necessarily, it was an expected act of courtesy. It was also a kind gesture to anoint the head of one’s guest with olive oil.

It appears that Simon’s intention was to judge and critique, with the hope of finding fault.

Simon was discourteous and showed no affection to Jesus. He wanted a relationship with Jesus devoid of depth and meaning. This was a religious man who was unable to relate or connect meaningfully with Jesus. He did not want Jesus to make any demands upon him, He did not want to bring change and transformation into his life, he did not want Jesus to challenge his beliefs or lifestyle. Einstein once said, ‘school has ruined my education.’ many Christians could say, ‘religion has ruined my relationship with Jesus.’ I think it should be the other way round. ‘Jesus has ruined my religion.’

Father may I experience your radical transformation in my life. Bible in a year reading plan Isaiah 24:7-28:22
study_refs: I want to start by asking this question, ‘How radical is our experience of Jesus?’ This is a very important question. Has Jesus totally transformed your life or has he merely cleaned it up? In the book Emotional Healthy Disciples, Peter Scazzero writes,

html:
We need to look a bit at the culture of the day to understand how this women could have been at this meal. We know that Simon would not have invited he, because in his mind he despised and look down on her. According to William Barclay.

‘The houses of well-to-do people were built round an open courtyard in the form of a hollow square. Often in the courtyard there would be a garden and a fountain; and there in the warm weather meals were eaten. It was the custom that when a Rabbi was at a meal in such a house, all kinds of people came in-they were quite free to do so-to listen to the pearls of wisdom which fell from his lips. That explains the presence of the woman.‘ https://churchplantinginternational.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/08/Power_of_Forgiveness_CPI_article.pdf. Accessed 28/07/25

we read. ‘When the Pharisee who had invited Him saw this, he said to himself If this man were a prophet, he would know what kind of women is touching him, she is a sinner. Luke 7:39

Prostitutes at that time were called “sinners” in polite company, just as they were called “fallen women” by the Victorians. Interestingly, the Gospels never record Jesus using a euphemism for the word prostitute, so when he condemned the Pharisees he said: “Tax collectors and prostitutes will get to the Kingdom of heaven before you” See Matthew 21:32-33.

Before the Roman army took over Judea in AD 6 there would have been few, if any, prostitutes in the very religious society of Palestine, but afterwards the presence of Roman soldiers created a demand for them. Paradoxically, this was because the soldiers were so disciplined – unlike other armies, they weren’t allowed to rape or even to get married, so they were forced to pay for sex.

How is all this relevant to our lives? We began by talking about our need to really know the radical Jesus, the Jesus who brings absolute transformation into our lives. So I want to look at this lady in our story and learn from her.

Forgiveness should be a catalyst for healing.

When Jesus says in verse 47 ‘I tell you her sins -and they are many, have been forgiven. this sentence is written in the past tense. So before this encounter with Jesus she had experience forgiveness. Now this is very important. Because her forgiveness led to what I would call a ‘klaio’ moment.’ what is that? The word ‘klaio’ is used in verse 38 for weeping. It is a word that indicates loud sobs, howling. The picture is of one lamenting with sobs or wailing aloud and was used to describe the wailing that took place when someone died. In secular Greek. klaio the word was used to describe physical or mental pain which is outwardly visible .

This may seem strange to us. Why is this women so distressed? Maybe because she has been forgiven she now has the freedom to mourn the pain her past has caused her. Being forgiven is a prelude to healing. When God forgives us he wipes our slate clean. We can stand before him completely accepted. However, forgiveness cannot eradicate consequence of the sin we have done to others or the sin others have done to us. Forgiveness removes the punishment for sin not the effects of sin. Forgiveness is instantaneous, dealing with the damaging consequences of sin, be it ours or others is a process. Forgiveness will not allow us to bury our heads in the sand and ignore what is going inside us. We bury our stuff because of shame and guilt.

As this women sobbed maybe she felt safe enough in the presence of Jesus to mourn her past, to grieve her wounds. We are incline to hide all our stuff under neglect and busyness, choosing not to recognise the affects it has on our lives. Forgiveness removes the suffocating impact of guilt and shame, allowing us to have the energy to deal with the pain sin has caused us.

Let us be honest with ourselves, most of us don’t really want to go where this women went. We don’t want to face the pain of dealing with all the pain caused by and to us, our shame causes us to bury the scars of our sin. The problem is, this is not a benign experience. For we end up distancing ourself from Jesus and we end up like Simon, having Jesus in our ‘home’ – life. But don’t really have a relationship with him, there is no depth, no intimacy, just a religion.

Father thank you that being forgiven frees us to grieve the wounds of the past.

Bible in a year: Isaiah 28:32-32:20.
study_refs: Luke wants to draw a stark contrast between Simon and the ‘sinful women.’ Simon represented everything that prevents someone from really knowing Jesus, but the messy untidy life of the woman represented the brokenness that gives people the capacity to know and be transformed by Jesus.

html:
Pouring this perfume on Jesus may have been a way for her to make a definitive statement about her new life. Part of the healing from the sin of the past may require us to ‘redefine’ something's that may had been used in wrong and sinful ways to meet our needs. She knew that pouring this perfume on Jesus would probable never be replaced. In letting go of the past her resources, could be used in the noble act of loving Jesus in significant and radical ways.

Jesus evaluation of this women’s actions.

On the surface this looked like an inappropriate noisy interruption that had total disregard for social norms. To Simon and his fellow Pharisees this was a messy disruption that did not sit well with their religious sensibilities. How did Jesus see, or understand what this women done. Listen to these words.

‘She has shown me much love.’ Let those sink into your heart. ‘She has shown me much love.’ I don’t think these words are ever spoken of anybody else in scripture. ‘She has shown me much love.’ What did she do. She didn’t say a word. She didn’t do some great deed, or preach a sermon, our witness to the other guest. No she impacted this gathering, and every generation sense by showing Jesus much love.

Imagine showing Jesus much love. Imagine having the courage to be honest, real, authentic. Imagine loving Jesus enough to disregard what other thought so you could authentically and radical expressed much love to Jesus.

1. Maybe the only way we can avoid becoming like Simon is show Jesus much love. Safe, sanctimonious religiosity of Simon will keep us from really loving Jesus.

2. Expressing love to Jesus in radical uncomfortable way is an essential if we are going to love Jesus as we should.

3, I think this moment when this lady anointed Jesus, may have been one of the greatest moments of his life and ministry. For in that moment he saw the awesome, ultimate power of HIS GRACE. He saw in the flesh and blood of this woman the reason why he had come to earth, the reason why his father sent him. What he had come to do, to rescue, to transform, to turn ‘sinners’ [ euphemism for prostitute] into saints who know how to show him much love.

Father may my life be a continual expression of much love for Jesus.

Luke tells us that she had an alabaster jar full of expensive perfume. This alabaster jar of perfume would had been used as part of her work as a prostitute, Writing about the life of a prostitute the writer of proverbs said this My bed is spread with beautiful blankets, with coloured sheets of Egyptian linen. I’ve perfumed my bed with myrrh, aloes, and cinnamon. Proverbs 7:16-17. This perfume was also very expensive about a years wages and could had been sold to provide her security in the future. This was incredible, she brought to Jesus that was a symbol of her murky past and gave to him as a love sacrifice. That what once used for ill gotten gain as become a holy offering that brought great joy to Jesus. This was a holy moment when sorrow and love mixed. An astonishing sacrifice was made, breaking ties with the sinful lifestyle of the past, and placing hope in God for the future.

html:
Reading and understanding the beatitudes can be a daunting experience, they are anti cultural, they challenge how most people think, they redefine priorities and they revolutionise lives. They are like verbalised missiles that destroy tightly held belief systems. They redefine our understanding of our humanity, and show us how to really experience God.

A W Tozer Said “What comes into our minds when we think about God is the most important thing about us.”

Many of us are content to live with a dysfunctional view of God, we often try to reconstruct God into something we want him to be, we can use our circumstances to interpret God for us, and often we end up with a wrong and unbiblical view of Him.

Often our ‘seeing’ of God can be distorted and intermittent. Sometimes we are very sure what God is doing in our lives, but more often than not, we are less sure, we can feel confused and unsure how to make sense of our situations. Maybe you have earnestly brought a circumstance or a situation to God, hoping God would intervene, and he hasn’t. Maybe you have had a genuine need that God doesn’t seem to meet, and you don’t understand why? And you can’t see God, or if you do see him, you do not like what you see.

It is so easy for any one of us to live with a dysfunctional view of God. And not see God for whom he really is, and see him for whom we think he is. To have a proper view of God requires deep, radical transformation within us so we have a capacity to comprehend God in some measure. When Jesus speaks about seeing God, he is not talking about our theological understanding, but how we most frequently relate to God.

Often we do not really express how we perceive God; often our relationship with God is tied up with some hidden agenda or alternative motive, causing us to have a blurred lined theology, [i.e. a confused and unhealthy understanding of God.] How we really perceive God is ingrained within us, and often there is a distorted view of God ingrained deep within our hearts

For example, sometimes we relate to God the same way people relate to the ‘banker’ in television programe ‘deal or no deal’ we have at set of conditions in our mind that has become the basis of our Relationship with God. We think if I do all the right things, then God will come through for me, I deserve God’s blessings, I have earned enough brownie points for God to answer my prayers. We would never verbalise this kind of thinking, but deep within us, that is how we often view God. Our seeing of God is distorted.

Not seeing God can be a scary distressing experience, it can make a person feel vulnerable, confused and very alone. There are dark periods in our lives when it seems impossible to discern or detect God, we are groping for some kind of understanding, grasping for some kind of sense of what we are experiencing. It is at times like this, this beatitude come to our aid. ‘Blessed are the pure in heart for they shall see God.’

If we are going to recognise God as God then we need to experience a pure heart. So what I want to do is help us grasp what Jesus means when he speaks about a pure heart, and look at the external evidences of a pure heart.

Father thank you that you will never make a deal with us. Bible in a year reading plan Isaiah 37:30-40:32
study_refs: Pure in heart part 1

html:
Being pure in heart means that we commit ourselves to the process of sanctification and change. The word that Jesus uses for pure in this verse means to clean or de-clutter. It is the Greek word katharos, from where we get our word catharsis. As a society we are often encouraged to suppress what is really going on inside us. We all go to great lengths to keep things hidden within our hearts. For some, a public persona is more important than the condition of our hearts.

Catharsis is a release of emotional tension after an overwhelming experience, that restores or refreshes the spirit.

The things that we keep buried, and refuse to deal with, are usually the things that defile and destroy us. We all need to experience the catharsis of confession.

One of the weaknesses of protestant theology is that it is slow to encourage confession. It is through confessing that we engage in the process in coming to terms with the realities of our hearts. The word the bible uses for confess is homologeo, and it literally means to agree with and consent to. When I am talking about confession I am not only referring to the confession of our sin, but the confession of our hearts, our pain, our frustrations, our disappointments. So when we confess, we are saying, ‘I agree with God about my sin.’ When we confess our pain and disappointment we are being real and honest about ourselves.

Most of us long for a ‘homologeo experience.’ We would love to be able to sit down with one person or a couple of people where we could tell them how we really are. We all need a homologeo experience’ one that shortens the gap between perception others have of us, and reality. We all need a ‘homologeo’ experience, were we are free to be ourselves with all our mess and insecurities. We all need a ‘homologeo’ experience,’ that gives vent to buried frustrations and concealed tears. The first ‘homologeo’ experience recorded in the bible is found in Genesis 3:8ff

“Then the man and his wife heard the sound of the Lord God as he was walking in the garden in the cool of the day, and they hid from the Lord God among the trees of the garden. But the Lord God called to the man, “Where are you? He answered, “I heard you in the garden, and I was afraid because I was naked; so I hid.”And he said, “Who told you that you were naked? Have you eaten from the tree that I commanded you not to eat from?” The man said, “The woman you put here with me—she gave me some fruit from the tree, and I ate it.”

Do we really want to be pure hearted? Do we really want to embark on the painful process of dealing with the stuff we have buried and concealed for years? Are we prepared to ‘katharos’ our hearts? To come from behind the tree were we are hiding? To embark on the process of really dealing with the stuff we are so used to burying, the stuff that defiles and destroys us?

Father thank you that confession is a lot more than saying sorry.

Bible in a year: Isaiah 41-44
study_refs: Pure in heart part 2

Being pure in heart does not mean that we are sinless. We know from other scriptures that “If we say we have no sin, we deceive ourselves and the truth is not in us, 1 John 1:8, so we all struggle with sin, we will never be perfect. However being pure in heart has a lot to do with our attitude towards our own personal sin. Being pure in heart begins with a realistic bout of self-knowledge. It starts with the acknowledgement that we cannot stay the way we are and we need to experience the ongoing transformation of the gospel. Salvation is more about what God is doing in our hearts in the present rather than what he did in the past.

html:
The Greeks used the word pure ‘katharos’ to describe one "clear from shame", "clear of guilt." When shame and guilt dominate, they also defile, we have all tasted their souring effects upon or lives. They have the ability to corrupt our thinking and distort our perception of God. For many feelings of guilt and shame have become their default setting, it has become their habitual way of feeling and thinking

Can you imagine living a life that has been purified from shame and guilt? Shame and guilt are the dominant emotions that control the lives of many Christians. There is nothing cleansing or liberating about shame or guilt. They are the complete antithesis to all that Jesus came to do in our lives. They desecrate authentic Christianity by making holy living impossible. That is why having a pure heart includes complete liberation from motivating guilt and demeaning shame

Being pure in heart means that we will be single minded. Purity of heart is to will one thing.”– Søren Kierkegaard. Kierkegaard is describing a passion for God that overrides everything else. Often we suffer from divided loyalties; we want to do the will of God as long as it is encompassed within our wills. But to be pure in heart is to have an eclipsing desire for God that will overshadow all other desires.

We can become fragmented people, pulled in a thousand different directions, living hectic lives with confused priorities. We don’t really know how to desire God, we don’t understand what it means to cultivate an overriding longing for God that will dominate and control us.

To ‘will one thing,’ is to develop an attitude of surrender and continual submission. It is a strong longing to bow our lives before God in surrender. It is the love of relinquishing our wills, and transforming our desires so we can discover the privilege of really loving God, and seeing Him for who he really is.

We want to conclude by asking the question. What are the practical implications of being pure in heart?

Jesus may have been thinking about Psalm 24 when he spoke this beatitude. The first four verses read, 1 The earth is the LORD'`S, and everything in it, the world, and all who live in it; 2 for he founded it upon the seas and established it upon the waters. 3 Who may ascend the hill of the LORD? Who may stand in his holy place? 4 He who has clean hands and a pure heart, who does not lift up his soul to an idol or swear by what is false.

Having a pure heart will enrich and mature you relationship both with God and people. Look at what the Psalmist says. He does not lift up his soul to an idol, or swear by what is false. Pure heart is having idolatry filtered out of my worship of God and dishonesty filtered out of my relationship with people.

Integrity in worship is one of the most radical experiences anyone can experience, for when our idols are destroyed, something deep and precious is removed from our

lives, and we are never the same. An idol is anything apart from God that we believe to be an essential requirement to make us feel complete or secure. Often our relationship with our idols is so emotionally and psychologically connected that killing our idol can feel like killing part of ourselves. The destruction of our idols, is usually a heart breaking experience, for we lose the thing we have made our source of life and comfort.

“Every human being must live for something. Something must capture our imaginations, our heart’s most fundamental allegiance and hope. But the Bible tells us, without the intervention of the Holy Spirit, that object will never be God Himself.” Counterfeit Gods. Timothy Keller

B) We will have Integrity with others. The last part of Psalm 24:4 ‘Or swear by what is false. Sometimes in the Septuagint, (Greek translation of the Old Testament) the word ‘Katharos’ is translated integrity.’ We need to be honest, open, upfront, and transparent with others.

Tom Long says the pure in heart are “those whose faith is genuine, people of integrity whose words are backed up by their convictions, whose outward deeds match their inner commitments”

If idols are hard to kill, then masks are hard to take off. So much that is dishonest about us, comes from the act of trying to protect a ‘perceived identity.’ I find this challenging and disturbing, God is not one bit concerned about our reputations; He is very concerned with our characters and identity’s. Who I really am, is more important than who others think I am.

As a community of Gods people, as families, as couples, as single people, let us all commit ourselves to this wonderful process of being pure in heart. May we refuse to be defined by our baggage in the past or our pain in the present but rather let us become a people who are continually seeing God; seeing the divine in the ordinary and the eternal in the temporary. Let us become people of real vision.

Father may I experience the joy of a pure heart. Bible in a year reading plan Isaiah 45-49
