html:
As a young Christian I often received negative teaching about doubt. I was told that you should never doubt, doubt is a sinful attitude, it is a sign of spiritual weakness, it is something that causes God great displeasure and disappointment. When we have doubts we never talk about them, we never tell others how we are feeling in case they think less of us. So we try to bury them, or ignore them. We often have feelings of guilt and shame, and we think to ourselves ‘If I really loved God I would not have these doubts.’ This negative teaching is both wrong and unhelpful; it actually makes our doubt worse because it does not encourage honesty or reality. We were never taught what Doubt is, nor how we should manage or respond to it when we experience it.

What is Doubt?

“To be in doubt is to be in two minds, to be caught between two worlds, to be suspended between a desire to affirm and a desire to negate.” Os Guinness.

“Doubt is a state of mind in suspension between faith and unbelief so that it is neither them wholly and is each one partly.” Os Guinness.

Doubt is when your expectations of God and your experiences in life clash, causing fear and confusion.

It is important that we recognise that doubt for the Christian is very different than the doubts of the Non-Christian, in some ways the doubt of a Christian are the opposite of those who are not Christians.


The doubts of the non-Christian are generally painless. When a person who is not a Christian has doubts about God and his love, usually that is a painless experience, because their doubts are not in the context of a relationship. So they have a lethargic attitude towards their doubts, they don’t loose sleep, or get overly anxious about them, it’s not a matter of life and death.

On the other hand the doubts of the Christian are painful because they do have a relationship with God. The Christian has come to love and trust God, they put their hope and life in his, then suddenly a tragedy hits them and their life falls apart. Where is God, this sovereign God who appears to be sitting on his hands and doing nothing? Often the fact that we have faith in God makes our problem seem worse.

The doubts of the non-Christian can harden his heart and make him more rebellious; He allows his doubts to make him sinister and bitter, pushing him further from God.

On the other hand the doubts of the Christian is often the consequence of a wounded faith. Hard-heartedness or a closed mind does not cause this doubt.

Furthermore the doubts of the Christian are an integral part of his or her growth and if they are handled properly can lead to a deeper experience of God and spiritual maturity. Real spirituality is not possible without honest healthy doubt handled properly. Part of discipleship is to help people manage their doubts, or to teach them how to doubt properly. In many circles doubt is frowned upon and condemned. There is a false belief that equates all doubt with sin, but this is not the case.

Father thank you that doubt is part off the normal spiritual process.

Bible in a year: Isaiah 50-54
title: Learning How to Doubt. Part 1
study_refs: One of the most difficult things a person will ever have to do is to unlearn things. Learning new things is easier than unlearning old things. As Christians we are often put into situations that will demand the we rethink and revaluate what we believe and why we believe it. Often the things that we were taught in the past now don’t seem right or feel right in the light of our lives and experience. As Christians we will experience two eventualities; we will meet people who were once strong in their faith, but are now full of doubt and uncertainty, and we ourselves will from time to time struggle with doubt

html:
“Our real idea of God may lie buried under the rubbish of conventional religious notions and may require an intelligent and vigorous search before it is finally unearthed and exposed for what it is. Only after the ordeal of painful self-probing are we likely to discover what we actually believe about God.” A.W.Tozer. https://faithgateway.com/blogs/christian-books/a-w-tozer-what-is-god-like#:~:text=That%20our%20idea%20of%20God,exposed%20for%20what%20it%20is. Accessed 28/07/25

Doubt is one of the things that God uses to strip of us of our wrong perceptions about him, and the wrong theology we may have build our lives upon. The striping away of our false theology is a very painful, leaving us totally vulnerable. The pain of honest doubt develops our ability to communicate with God. Often as Christians we communicate with God as if He were some advanced answering machine with pre-programmed phrases and clichés, devoid of passion or enthusiasm. But when we are struggling with the pain of honest doubt, we pray differently, there is desperation in our praying, and a frank honesty. This is what God is looking for.

We are going to look at the incident where John the Baptist expressed his doubt and how Jesus responded to this.

The Historical context of John’s doubt.

Why was John in prison in the first place?

Herod Antipas, who ruled Galilee at this time, had previously paid a visit to his brother in Rome, and during that visit he seduced his brother's wife. When Herod returned home, he divorced his own wife and married the sister-in-law, Herodias, whom he lured away from her husband, his brother. Publicly and sternly John the Baptist rebuked Herod and called his sin to account before God. But when Herod learned of John's condemnation, he arrested John and threw him into prison in the dungeons of the fortress of Machaerus in the mountains near the Dead Sea.

Consider how John must have felt. He had been "filled with the Spirit" from his mother's womb. He took the strictest vow any Jewish man could take, the vow of the Nazarite. He had lived in the wilderness, preaching to the people. He had faithfully declared an unpopular message. He had done all as had God asked, but now he was imprisoned in the dungeon of an old fortress near the Dead Sea. In prison, John must have doubted the justice of God. He must’ve wondered if He had made a mistake. His circumstances clouded his perspective.

Reasons for doubt.

As we look at this incident from the life of John the Baptist there are a number of reasons why John may have doubted at this time.

At a superficial level Johns doubt was related to his circumstances. John, the very man who had attracted a flurry of attention in recent years because of his ‘no-holds-barred’ announcements of a New World order that was just around the corner. This fiery preacher who shook up everything and everyone with his blazing rhetoric about kingdom come. Here he is in prison where he has nothing but time to think and so John's has come up with a question. But the person to whom he wants to pose that question isn't there and hasn't visited him lately. John’s circumstances exacerbated his doubt.

After the death of his wife Joy, C.S.Lewis wrote

“Not that I am (I think) in much danger of ceasing to believe in God. The real danger is of coming to believe such dreadful things about him. The conclusion is not. ‘So there is no God after all.’ But, ‘So this is what he is really like, deceive yourself no longer.” https://www.goodreads.com/quotes/261264-not-that-i-am-i-think-in-much-danger-of#:~:text=Quote%20by%20C.S.,C.S.%20Lewis%2C%20A%20Grief%20Observed. Accessed 28?07/25

Difficult circumstances can expose our doubts, and wrong thinking.

Although John’s circumstances made his doubts worse they were not the root causes of his doubt.

Root 1. Incomplete information from John’s disciples.

Mathew 11:2,5 “When John heard in prison what Christ was doing, he sent his disciples..” Now look how Jesus begins and ends his reply, by addressing the importance of what he says “Go back and report to John all that you hear and see.” and “. The good news is preached to the poor.” In other words the disciples of Jesus communicated the deeds of Jesus without communicating the teaching of Jesus. John was told in prison what Jesus was doing, however, he did not told what Jesus was Saying.

Patte (The Gospel According to Matthew)

Why would people, including dedicated people such as John, doubt and be scandalised by Jesus? This section makes the point that it is because they consider Jesus' deeds without taking into account his words, his teaching and preaching. They take into account only one component of what constitutes the ministry of Jesus… In brief, one has doubts, is scandalised, and ultimately rejects Jesus and his ministry when one interprets Jesus' deeds in and of themselves, rather than in terms of Jesus' preaching and teaching.

Seeing God move in great power will never heal a person’s doubt. It is only as those deeds are understood in a theological context, that they will encourage faith.

Root 2. Wrong expectations of Jesus.

John was in doubt because he understood the coming Messiah to be someone that would bring judgement and fire. "'The axe is already at the root of the trees, and every tree that does not produce good fruit will be cut down and thrown into the fire. I baptise you with water, ...but He will baptise you with the Holy Spirit and with fire. His winnowing fork is in His hand, and He will clear His threshing floor, gathering His wheat into the barn and burning up the chaff with unquenchable fire'" (Mt. 3:10-12).

That was the kind of person John expected; that was the kind of Messiah he was looking for. And here is Jesus, out in the backwaters of Galilee healing the sick, insignificant people here and there, but He was not doing anything to really change the basic structural problems in Israel's life. Rome was still in control, the Pharisees still commanded the religious life of the nation, the Sadducees still were in charge of the temple, and the whole "system" seemed not to be threatened by the good Jesus was doing. What John taught about Jesus was partly true. Jesus would come in judgement, but not yet. Sometimes we are like John, we have some truth, and we put our expectations on half of the truth.

For John his doubt was an expression of disappointment with Jesus, many people do not love Jesus enough to be disappointed with him. John must have been disappointed with Jesus at this time for a number of reasons.

He had taught what he believed to be the truth, under the inspiration of the Holy Spirit, up to this point none of John’s predictions about Jesus had come true.

John was shut up in prison, and we have no record of Jesus coming to visit him, or make some efforts to get him released.

Sometime disappointment is the most genuine expression of love, there is no shame or disgrace in expressing disappointment to God, if it is an expression of broken faith and painful doubt. Sometimes it is the only way we can express our love for God.

Father thank you that sometimes doubt is the only way we have to express our love for you. Bible in a year reading plan Isaiah 55:1-60:9
title: Learning how to deal with doubt, part 2
study_refs: The painful honest doubt of the Christian is one of the things God uses to help us open our hearts up to him. Doubt makes us ask questions about God we would never ask normally.

html:
Doubt is one of the ways our hearts expresses it’s need to have a deeper and more intimate relationship with God. If we just accumulate facts about Jesus, and have no deep or personal intimacy with him, they we are going to be more open to doubt.

Root 4.The ministry of Jesus was too different to his thus causing John a measure of insecurity.

If you were to compare the life and ministry of Jesus with the life and ministry of John they were so different, and it would appear that they had nothing in common.

John spent most his time in the wilderness

Jesus spent most of his time in the villages and cities

John had a very secluded life where people had to come to him.

Jesus spent very little time in seclusion, he spent most of his time amongst people

John had a very restrictive diet and often fasted.

Jesus like to party, and spent a lot of time eating and drinking with people. Jesus drank wine and ate food that John would not touch.

John and Jesus, had very different emphasis in their ministry, John’s emphasis was on sin, judgement, and condemnation, while Jesus’ emphasis was on healing and salvation. Both emphases were biblical and important, but they were very different in tone and in their outworking.

John was the established prophet who had his tried and proven ways of doing life and ministry, along came Jesus, who John thought was the Messiah. The way Jesus lived his life and did his ministry was almost diametrical opposite to what John knew and taught.

Often when God acts differently to what we had hoped or expected, then we can begin to feel insecure, and this in turn can lead to doubt.

Father thank you that Jesus understands our doubt. Bible in a year reading plan Isaiah 60:10-65:25
title: Learning how to deal with doubt, part 3
study_refs: Lack of intimacy with Jesus may have been a factor in John’s doubt.

John began to live a secluded life in the wilderness, where he did most of his ministry. When did he recognise Jesus as the Messiah? It was only when the Spirit’s descended upon Him (John 1:29-34). Jesus avoided contact with John and his disciples to minimise competition and friction between them (John 4:1-3), and It was not until John’s arrest that Jesus’ public ministry officially commenced (Matt. 4:12, 17). The point here is that John did not have a close relationship with Jesus.

html:
There are a number of lessons we can learn from how John went about expressing his doubt.

He was vulnerable enough to share his doubt with others.

It is very temping for people who are in a position of leadership to feel that they need to be strong, they are to protect those they are responsible for from knowing their weaknesses or insecurities, so they always have the right answers, always feel in control. But John was not like that. He did not feel a need to protect his reputation, he was prepared to share his fears and doubts.

He needed help to share his doubts with Jesus.

John was restricted, shut up in prison, he need help. Doubt may be one on the things God uses to deepen our communication with Him, but this does not mean that we will not need the help of others. These disciples of John listen to what he had to say, and then went to Jesus on his behalf. When a person shares their doubts with us, we need to do all we can to help them through their doubt. Being faithfully committed to a doubting person is very important.

How did Jesus respond to John’s doubt?

Three things Jesus did not do

He did not condemn John but commended him. It was in the context of John expressing his doubt that Jesus said “I tell you the truth: Among those born of women their as not risen anyone greater than John the Baptist.” There is a lot of discussion about this verse, but I think that it’s significant that Jesus says these words in this context. When we are totally honest with Jesus, then our hearts are more open to receive his encouragement and comfort. Jesus will always defend those who have honest doubts. The interesting thing about these words in this context is that Jesus was anxious to defend John’s reputation.

He did not change Johns circumstances. John was in prison, John stayed in prison, John was murdered in prison. If anything, his circumstances got worse. As we have been saying, the roots of doubt are never external, of course when a persons goes through great suffering, it can inflame their doubt, and if life had been made a little bit easier for John it may have help medicate the pain of his doubt. But what Jesus wanted to do was much bigger than change John’s circumstances, he wanted to transform his heart.

He did not change anything he was doing in order to accommodate John’s doubts. When a person is full of insecurity, with feelings of vulnerability and confusion because of painful doubt, it is very easy for them to lash out at others, blaming them and demanding that they changed. Jesus understood that he did not need to change, what he was doing was consistent with His Father’s will. Doubting people can become angry and demanding. When John asked his question, he was challenging Jesus, attempting to force his hand, to press Jesus to announce that He was the Messiah, and to cause Him to begin to bring judgement to the earth. John had warned men that Messiah would come with fire, and John thought it was high time for Jesus to get on with it.

Father may I be like John and have the humility, wisdom and courage to express my doubts Bible in a year reading plan Isaiah 66 Jeremiah 1:1-2:25

html:
The context of the passage.

This blind man was healed during the feast of Tabernacles.

John intends us to connect this healing with the previous chapter, as the references to Jesus as the light of the world indicate (8:12; 9:5). The connection between the healing of the blind man and the Feast of Tabernacles is seen in two ways.

During the festival, large candelabra were lit in the temple courts. Because of the temple's elevated location, the light was visible throughout the city. "The light symbolized the revelation and truth of the Jewish faith" (Gower, 358-359). At the Feast of Tabernacles, Jesus declared himself to be the light of the world (8:12), a claim that he reiterates in 9:5.

At the festival, priests poured water from the Pool of Siloam onto the temple steps "so that it would flow down and out through the Temple to the world outside, and so indicate the way that the Jewish faith would satisfy the world" (Gower, 358). The Pool of Siloam is the place where Jesus will tell the blind man to wash the mud from his eyes. Just as a miraculous feeding of thousands with bread and fish illustrates that Jesus is the bread of life (6:1-14, 35-65); so now he illustrates that he is the light of the world by giving sight to a man in darkness. Father I confess that sometimes we want to hold onto and protect our blindness.

title: The man born blind. part 1
study_refs: This is a passage in the word of God that is both demanding and challenging. It is demanding and challenging because it makes us asks more questions than it answers, Questions like, Is some suffering the result of sin, while other suffering isn’t? How can we tell if suffering is the result of sin? Do we need to know if suffering is the consequence of sin? Would such knowledge make us judgmental of others? If suffering is not the direct consequence of a person’s sin does that mean that the suffering has been given to display the work of God in his life? These are some of the questions we need to grapple with as we approach this passage.

html:
Rabbi, who has sinned this man or his parents that he was born blind?’ How different is the perspective of the disciples to that of Jesus. If you read what John says carefully you will notice that it was Jesus who saw the blind man ‘As he went along, he saw a blind man.’ It was Jesus’ noticing the blind man that drew his disciple’s attention to him. They see the blind beggar as a case study, a topic for theological discussion and debate.

Often when we are faced with situations where we don’t know what to do, we begin to hide our impotence with words and discussions, often meaningless! The question they asked was none of their business. They didn’t discuss how they could help the man, or what practical support they could give him. There is a clue in their question that explains their inability to offer any practical help. They defined this man in terms of his supposed sin. They looked upon him as a sinner, justifying their inability to offer him practical help.

What can we learn from their question?

The theological problem in Judaism was to explain the cause of birth defects. The question of whether a handicapped child suffered the handicap from the sins of their parents or his/her own pre-natal sin was actively debated in Judaism. There is actually a rabbinic pronouncement from near the time of Jesus, "When a pregnant woman worships in a heathen temple the fetus also commits idolatry." Therefore, when a baby was born who was anything less than perfect, blame could be placed on the child if no sin were evident in the parents.

In the first century the popular folk-theology of the Jews saw a direct underlying connection between illness and sins. They lived in a cause and effect world. Bad things happen to bad people. Good things happen to good people. In a cause and effect world, everything is orderly, predictable, and understandable. In a "cause and effect" world, those who study the hardest excel; those who work the longest prosper. There are a number of thing we need to notice about this faulty theology.

It is worth noting that there can be a connection between sin and suffering. That was not true in the case of this blind man, but it is often true. Not all suffering is caused by sin, but sin does cause suffering. Jesus shows us that sin and suffering are not always related, but not that they are never related. There are texts in Scripture that clearly indicate that people are hurting and suffering and physically depraved and deprived because of their own evil ways. See 1 Corinthians 11:30.

We are not in a position to decide or judge if a person is suffering because of sin, that is for God to know, not us; that kind of knowledge would be too dangerous for us to have. John Wimber, founder of the Vineyard Movement in his book, Power Healing, said, "There are many reasons that people are not healed. Most of the reasons involve some form of sin and unbelief. Some do not have faith in God for healing; (and some have) personal, unconfessed sin (which) creates a barrier to God’s grace.’ p. 152 The cause of suffering should not determine our response to it.

Do children suffer because of their parent’s sin? The Old Testament teaches ‘You shall not make for yourself an idol in the form of anything in heaven above or on the earth beneath or in the waters below. You shall not bow down to them or worship them; for I, the lord your God, am a jealous God, punishing the children for the sins of their fathers to the third and forth generations of those who hate me.’ Exodus 20:4-5. These verses are speaking in a general sense, not specific. He is not saying when daddy sins junior gets it. He is saying when the fathers, plural, sin the generations, plural, pay. What do you mean? When Israel goes into idolatry and God punishes Israel by oppression, by scattering them, it's not only that generation that gets punished but it's the rest of the generations that follow. He is talking about national punishment. It’s not talking about particular sin of the father and the son gets punished. God doesn't operate like that but Israel thought He did.

The Old Testament says ‘The soul who sins is the one who will die. The son will not share the guilt of the father, nor will the father share the guilt of son. The righteousness of the righteous man will be credited to him, and the wickedness of the wicked will be charged against him.’ Ezekiel 18:20.

The question that the disciples asked was somewhat redundant. Would an answer to the question help them minister to the blind man, would they have been better equipped to meet the man’s needs if they had known if he or his parents had been the cause of his suffering? There is something within all of us that wants to understand and explain suffering. We think that if we had some answers we would cope better, we fear the mystery that suffering brings.

In the prefaced of his book The Problem of Pain, C.S. Lewis wrote:

‘For the far higher task of teaching fortitude and patience I was never fool enough to suppose myself qualified, nor have I anything to offer my readers except my conviction that when pain is to be borne, a little courage helps more than much knowledge, a little human sympathy more the much courage, and the least tincture of the love of God more than all.”

Father sometimes erudite theological debates rob us of the ability to show practical care for others. Bible in a year reading plan Jeremiah 5:20-8:22
title: The man born blind. Part 2
study_refs: The question the disciples asked.

html:
Before we look at what Jesus said to his disciples it is important to note that the answer he gave was not intended to feed their curiosity, increase their knowledge or to make them more theological sound. But the answer was to challenge their prejudice, change their attitudes and motivate them to practical care.

Jesus challenged their understanding of suffering.

For the Jew suffering was always related to sin, now here Jesus relates it to the revelation of God. This was something these disciples had never heard before. How could God be glorified through suffering? The interesting thing is that Jesus viewed his own suffering as a means of bringing glory to God.

‘All sufferings are opportunities for God to be glorified, irrespective of the cause. If our suffering is indeed a punishment for sin, then it becomes an occasion for repentance and thus the manifestation of God's grace as we are restored to fellowship with God. If our suffering is not a direct punishment for sin, then it is something God allows to happen in our lives, usually for reasons beyond our knowing, which nevertheless can help us die to self and find our true life in God. God does not allow anything to enter our lives that is not able to glorify him by drawing us into deeper intimacy with him and revealing his glory.’ IVP commentary.

Jesus challenged their lack of practical concern for the man.

‘We must work the works of him who sent me while it is day; night is coming when no one can work.’ He did not say, “I must work the works of him who sent me,” but ‘we must work’. What is the work Jesus is referring to? The work is the gracious, kind, compassionate, non-judgmental accepting attitude that Jesus showed towards the blind man, the work of accepting the outcast. The heart attitude that is expressed in the work Jesus spoke of is the opposite of the heart attitude that was expressed in the disciple’s question. Sometimes we over spiritualise the ‘work’ of God. We see it as some secret, mysterious thing that comes to us through some special revelation, when, all it is, is simply showing love and compassion to those we meet every day. An unhealthy and unhelpful interest in theology will prevent a person from showing compassion; a proper understanding of theology will motivate a person to do deeds of practical compassion.

The Greek word for work is ‘ergazomai" which has these possible meanings (from Lexicon of New Testament Greek):

To work, labour, do work.

To trade, to make gains by trading, "do business".

To do, work out, exercise, perform, commit, to cause to exist, produce.

To work for, earn by working, to acquire.

The work of showing a gracious, kind, compassionate, non-judgmental accepting attitude is demanding and will cost you emotionally, as well your time and your energy. The kind of work that God has called us to can only be done when we are in fellowship with Jesus. Fellowship with Jesus produces compassion and generosity within a person.

Jesus warns them of the danger of loosing an opportunity to share in his work.

‘Night is coming when no one can work.’ Every one of us will have ‘a night when we cannot work.’ There will be times when we will need to receive the ministry this beggar received, not give it. There will be times in the will of God that our lives will be shrouded in the darkness of night, and we wont have the resources to “work the works of him who sent’ We are those that have been sent to continue the works of Jesus. So when we can we must reach out in love. Any lost opportunity to show gracious, kind, compassionate, non-judgmental accepting attitude to others when we can, is a loss of life itself.

We must remember that this was a Sabbath day, 9:14 for the Jews of Jesus’ day, especially for those who lived in Jerusalem, the Sabbath was a very restricted day, where all kinds of work was forbidden because of the traditions of the elders. Sometimes we are tempted to play it safe, we don’t want to rock the boat in case we might offend others. We allow the traditions and expectations of others to restrict how and when we show compassion, and the needy suffer because we are afraid to take the opportunities that God has given us. I once read of a church in Australia who provided the local brothel with a weekly gift of buns and cakes. Causing the sex workers to ask questions a feel valued. Wow

Jesus reiterates his mission, ‘While I am in the world I am the light of the world.’ Jesus said this to establish a clear connection between the healing of this blind man and His claim to be the ‘Light of the world’ (John 18:12; cf. John 1:4; 12:46). What Jesus previously claimed He now demonstrated by this miracle. Jesus the light of the world is seen through the deeds of compassion and grace that the church does in appropriate times and appropriate way

Father help me see every opportunity to show compassion as an opportunity to share in the work of Jesus Bible in a year reading plan Jeremiah 9-12
title: The man born blind. Part 3
study_refs: Jesus response to the disciple’s question

html:
A few initial observations.

The New Testament records more accounts of Jesus restoring sight than any other miracle (Mk. 18:22-26; 10:46-52; Mt. 9:27-31; 12:22-23; 21:14; Mk. 8:22-26; Jn. 9:1-41). This predicted Messianic activity (Isa. 29:18; 35:5; 42:7) it became somewhat of a hallmark of His ministry.

Jesus never healed two blind people in the same way, he treated people as individuals. It is so easy when ministering unto others to try and establish some kind of formula, or a ‘one size fits all’ approach, but in doing this we cease to treat people as people and more like objects.

It is quite striking that the only reference to healing of blindness in the Bible other than in Jesus' ministry, is the case of Paul it was Jesus who both blinded and restored him. So Jesus' healing of the blind stands out as a major sign of his identity and the significance of his coming.

Look at what Jesus did here.

Firstly Jesus took the initiative. This blind man did not ask Jesus to heal him; Jesus saw his need and responded. Secondly, the method used by Jesus in the healing of the blind man might sound a little unusual to us, but would have been commonly practice in ancient times. The application of herbs and poultices to infected areas of the body was widely accepted as the proper application of their limited medical science. Certainly, the poultice had no intrinsic healing power. John emphasizes the use of the mud mentioning it in 9:6, 11, 14, 15. There has been much debate about why Jesus did this. Some commentators believe that there is allusion to the biblical picture of God as a potter and human beings as clay (for example, Job 10:9; Is 45:9; 64:8; Jer 18:6; Rom 9:2,) but this is unlikely because the picture of the potter in the bible is primarily a picture of someone who is in the process of judging or disciplining his people while they are still on the earth. Jesus did not need to put the mud on this blind man in order to heal him, but he chose to do so.

I wonder could I make a suggestion as to a ‘possible’ reason why Jesus chose to use this method at this time. To teach his disciples a very important lesson. Jesus knew that as he spat on the ground and made the mud, he was breaking the oral traditions on the elders and the expectations of the religious leaders.

Rabbinic teaching perverted Old Testament into a straight-jacket catalogue of rules. In healing this man on the Sabbath, Jesus violated four of their rules: ploughing (spittle rolling on the dirt), kneading (making the clay), anointing (putting clay on the man's eyes), and of course healing (illegal unless a life-threatening emergency). Jesus hated the way religion elevated ritual observance over human need, and never hesitated to break its rules. Jesus was saying, if you are frightened of men, and feel that you must conform to their rules and traditions, and then you will not show love and compassion to those who need it.

Thirdly sent to Siloam, a parable of his life of faith.

The healing was not effected until the man obeyed Jesus' command: Go . . . wash in the Pool of Siloam (9:7). Why didn't Jesus just heal him on the spot, as he did others? Why send a blind man, in particular, on such a journey? There must be something involved here that contributes to the revealing of God's work.

The pool of Siloam was built by Hezekiah during the reign of the Assyrian king, Sennacherib, about 600 years before this event. When the Assyrians threatened to lay siege to Jerusalem, Hezekiah built a tunnel from the Spring of Gihon, under the city walls, to the point within the walls where the pool was formed. This tunnel was approximately 1/3 mile long, running several feet below the surface of the ground. Rather than following a straight line, the tunnel snakes its way from source to mouth through hand-hewn limestone. In order to speed construction, two groups each started at opposite ends and worked towards each other.

What Jesus did was to demand an act of faith by the man being healed. The man could have simply said, "This is ridiculous," wiped the dirt from his eyes, and gone home blind. Instead, he had to walk a distance through one of the busiest and most crowded streets of the city to the pool. He would then have to wash his eyes at the pool while others watched. For a blind man, this would be very difficult. He would have to ask for directions and for help, and he might easily fall into some of the crevices alongside the road on the way down. It was difficult, but necessary. For the man needed to know that to become a man of vision didn’t mean that all his problems were solved. In going to the pool of Siloam, the blind man learned that Jesus could be trusted and obeyed.

John tells us that that the word Siloam means sent. Throughout this gospel Jesus is referred to as the one whom God has sent 51 times. To follow the sent one will restore our vision, but it will not remove the pain and stress of life. For this man to put his faith in Jesus, he would face opposition and obstacle, as we shall see in the rest of the chapter.

The spiritual significance of the miracle

‘Like all of the miracles in John, this miracle not only helped a real person by meeting his real physical need (blindness). It was also a "sign" (sumeion). As the word "sign" suggests, it was an "attesting miracle," meaning that its ultimate significance is not in the miracle itself, but in what it reveals symbolically about Jesus' unique ability to meet humanity's spiritual needs. In other words, Jesus' unique ability to restore physical sight to a man born blind is a miracle that validates his claim to be the only One who can provide spiritual revelation and understanding to a spiritually blind humanity.’ {Forget the source.}

Father thank you that Jesus treated ever blind man he healed differently

html:
The Broader context

This is the first recorded encounter Jesus had with a Pharisee. At this time the Pharisees who numbered about 6000. They were unsure what to think about Jesus. "Pharisee" is from a Greek word (pharisaios) taken from the Heb/Aramaic "Perisha" meaning "Separated one." In the time of Jesus, the Pharisees were one of the three chief Jewish sects, the others were the Sadducees and the Essenes. Of the three, the Pharisees were the most separated from the ways of the foreign influences that were invading Judaism, and from the ways of the common Jewish people in the land. They were strict legalists. They stood for the rigid observance of the letter and forms of the Law, and also for the traditions. There were some good men among them, no doubt, but for the most part they were known for their covetousness, self-righteousness and hypocrisy. Nicodemus came to Jesus as a representative of the Pharisees.

When Jesus cleansed the temple, as recorded John 2:13-22 this may have pleased the Pharisees, because they disapproved of how the Priests and the Sadducees were using the worship in the temple to rob and abuse people. For years there had been immoral activity going on in the temple and no one had ever stood up against it, until now, Jesus the carpenter from Galilee was prepared to take on the High Priest and the Sadducees, and confront their evil behaviour.

Nicodemus came to see Jesus as a representative of the religious authorities of the day. Nicodemus is thought to be the second most important person in Judaism next to the High Priest. Jesus knew of him, because he calls him ‘Israel teacher.’ He was the top academic and most important teacher of his day. Notice he says to Jesus, ’We know you are a teacher sent from God.’ He was not coming to Jesus as a personal seeker.

Immediate context John 2:23–25 reads, ‘Now while he was in Jerusalem at the Passover Festival, many people saw the signs he was performing and believed in his name. But Jesus would not entrust himself to them, for he knew all people. He did not need any testimony about mankind, for he knew what was in each person.’ These verses described Jesus’ refusal to accept shallow, sign-based faith, since in His omniscience, He understood the people’s hearts. This verse could be translated “Many believed in Jesus, but Jesus didn’t believe in them.” The story of Nicodemus is a case in point, since Nicodemus himself was one of those superficial believers whose heart Jesus read like an open book. Instead of affirming his profession, true the Lord refused to accept Nicodemus’s profession of faith, which was solely based on the signs he had witnessed (v. 2). Jesus pointed him to the life-transforming nature of saving faith. There is such a thing as superficial faith that does not result in salvation.

Father like Nicodemus we need Jesus to expose the nature of our faith.

Bible in a year: Jeremiah 16:10-20:18
title: Jesus and Nicodemus. Part 1
study_refs: The conversation Jesus had with Nicodemus is one of the most challenging conversations recorded in the word of God. The problem is that this passage is so well known in Christian circles that we have lost its challenge, it has ceased to be radical, we have lost the shock factor it would have had on those who originally read this story. In order to understand this powerful passage, we need to look at its context.

html:
As we have said, we are very familiar with Nicodemus’ conversation with Jesus, but there a lot in it we can miss. He came to Jesus at night and said. ‘Rabbi we know you are a teacher who has come from God. For no one could perform the miraculous signs you are doing if God were not with him.’ We need to try and understand what is happening here.

Jesus and Nicodemus came from two very different and opposite worlds. Nicodemus was the ultimate expression of what it meant to be part of the religious system of his day. He would have had the last word when it came to understanding the scriptures and how they related to everyday life. On the other hand, Jesus did not come from within the system. He had not been trained at the feet of men such as Gamaleil. He had no diplomas from the leading Jewish schools. Worse yet, he was a Galilean who were despised by Judaean Jews. So, for Nicodemus to come to Jesus and address him as Rabbi was astonishing.

In addressing Jesus as Rabbi, Nicodemus was basically saying, ‘You are like me, we are equal, we serve the same purpose.’ It is as if Nicodemus is trying to affirm Jesus, give Jesus his approval, Nicodemus had an insufficient understanding of Jesus. Nicodemus wanted to treat Jesus as a co-teacher, a fellow rabbi, not as the Messiah.

Jesus took charge of the conversation.

The two rabbis have met and exchanged their greetings. Eventually it was time for one or the other to establish the substantive topic of conversation. In most societies it is the privilege of the senior to move the conversation on, to offer topic. Now in the case of rabbinic Judaism we know that it was normal for the senior to speak before the junior. It is on the basis of an assumed superiority, therefore, that Nicodemus has offered topic for further conversation. In fact, as commonly happens, he offers several possible topics: the concept of ‘rabbi’, the implication of recognizing Jesus as a teacher, the significance and the provenance of signs. But Jesus accepts none of them. Had he done so he would have accepted also Nicodemus’ assumption of priority. Jesus takes up none of Nicodemus’ topics. This must had been a shock to Nicodemus, he was used to setting the agenda, he was used to being in control, now he was being undermined, he thought he had Jesus figured out.

The Jesus we think we know, and the Jesus we want to know is very different to the Jesus we need to know. Nicodemus is standing before Jesus and all his authority and prestige is about to be stripped away. Birth status was the single, all-important factor in determining a person's honor rating. Ascribed honor, the honor derived from one's status at birth, was simply a given. It usually stayed with a person for life. ... To be born over again, born for a second time (one meaning of another), however unthinkable that event might be, would alter one's ascribed honor status in a very fundamental way. A new ascribed honor status would derive from a new birth.

Father thank you that our status in this world will never impress Jesus.

html:
Gentile converting to Judaism

Being crowned king

Bar mitzvah (Jewish confirmation at age 13)

Being married

Being ordained a rabbi

Becoming the head of a rabbinic academy

Try and grasp what Nicodemus was hearing, Nicodemus, you are no better than a Gentile, you may be a successful Rabbi, who has conformed to the strict Jewish law but unless you become a totally new and different person you will never see or experience the kingdom of God.

Sometimes in church we are inclined to water down or redefine the gospel, we tell people things like, ‘ask Jesus into your heart,’ or ‘make a decision for Jesus.’ Or sometimes we preach a gospel of reformation, we encourage people to change. The problem is that often the gospel we present to others is not radical enough. Jesus is saying unless you become a completely different person the you will never know God.

This was humbling for Nicodemus. Here ’The teacher of Israel’ being told that everything he has achieved or become needs to become new. Jesus’ shocking statement was far more than Nicodemus had expected. Incredulous, Nicodemus said to Him, “How can a man be born when he is old? Can he enter a second time into his mother’s womb and be born?” Certainly, this highly educated Pharisee was not so obtuse as to have misinterpreted Jesus’ words in a simplistically literal sense. He knew our Lord was not talking about being physically reborn, but he replied in the context of the Lord’s analogy. How could he start all over, go back to the beginning? Jesus was telling him that entrance to God’s salvation was not a matter of adding something to all his efforts, not topping up his religious devotion, but rather cancelling everything and starting all over again.

Father help me to grasp how radical the gospel is.

Bible in a year: Jeremiah 25-27
title: Jesus and Nicodemus. Part 3
study_refs: The challenge

Jesus replied, “Very truly I tell you, no one can see the kingdom of God unless they are born again, or born from above.’ The phrase ‘Born again, has been over used, and has lost some of its original power. B orn again” actually had six meanings in Rabbinic Judaism:

html:
others will call themselves by the name of Jacob;
still others will write on their hand, ‘The Lord’s,’
and will take the name Israel.

Ezekiel 36:24-27 “‘For I will take you out of the nations; I will gather you from all the countries and bring you back into your own land. I will sprinkle clean water on you, and you will be clean; I will cleanse you from all your impurities and from all your idols. I will give you a new heart and put a new spirit in you; I will remove from you your heart of stone and give you a heart of flesh. And I will put my Spirit in you and move you to follow my decrees and be careful to keep my law.’

To be ‘Born again’ is to experience the work of the Holy Spirit producing new life. To be born of water and the Spirit is talking about one thing andit may well be referring to the cleansing and empowerment that comes through the new birth.

To help us understand the new birth, let us consider some of its consequences.

The new birth rescues our humanity. Before we become Christians, our sin has robbed us of the glory of our humanity. The new birth makes us more human, it increases our ability to fulfil our creator’s intention.

Being born again is to have a new identity, it is to have a new source of life, it is an understanding that nothing on earth can give you value or significance. It is so radical that you no longer depend on success, reputation or accomplishment to give you value. We will never become the people God wants us to be until we experience the new birth.

Being born again is to recognise that we are primarily spiritual creatures not physical. We have very real physical needs, we need food, clothes, shelter, heat water, etc. However, our physical needs may sustain life, they can never give live. We only come alive when we experience the regeneration of the Spirit.

Being born again means we can experience the Kingdom of God. Often when we read the phrase Kingdom of God we assume it is referring to heaven. But it’s not. Heaven may be a part of the Kingdom of God, but it is not the kingdom of God. The kingdom of God is where God rules, where God is king. Being born again is having a character that longs to completely submit to God. It is finding grea joy in absolute surrender. Something someone who is not a new creation would never want to do.

Being born again will help us understand and accept ourselves. Often the problem with self-acceptance is we don’t know who we are or who we should be. The new birth is where the journey of authenticity begins, for through it we begin to become the person God has designed us to be, and the person we have always wanted to be. Someone who knows they are accepted and loved

Being born again will change how you view the world. We live in a world where power, position, prestige and possessions are important, they become symbols of our significance and value. This was like the world Nicodemus lived in. Power, position, prestige and possessions are important when we are feeling insecure or unloved. However, being born again born into the family of God, should cause us to feel loved and secure because we have been born into a loving family with a loving father.

Being born again is the goal of the love of God. God gave his Son, to die a cruel death on the cross so we could become new people. It is as if God’s pursuing love finds it ultimate satisfaction in the new birth of those he has created. I don’t know if you have ever been at a birth, for most it is a wonderful, joyful experience, although it is not easy for the mother. The joy of such an experience is a pale shadow of how God feels about a person being born again.

Being born again means that we don’t ever need to live under condemnation. The new people we become through being born from above/again is designed to live completely free from condemnation. ‘God did not send his Son into the world to condemn it’ condemnation is the antithesis to the new birth, and will stop growth and maturity.

This meeting Nicodemus had with Jesus was very disturbing for him. Nicodemus had a set of fixed ideas of what a Messiah should be like. Jesus says something that totally destroys Nicodemus’ understanding and theology. Just as Moses lifted up the snake in the wilderness, so the Son of Man must be lifted up that everyone who believes may have eternal life in him.”For God so loved the world that he gave his one and only Son, that whoever believes in him shall not perish but have eternal life.’ When we read the words ‘For God so loved the world,’ we often mistakenly think that this verse is talking about the extent of God’s love, how much he loves the world. But that is not the writer’s intention. When we read ‘God so loved the world, the writer is referring back to verse 14. Jesus uses the story of Moses lifting up the snake in the wilderness from Numbers 21:4-9 to illustrate his death. This is a strange story and disturbing story, where Jesus compares his death on the cross with a bronze snake, I find this a bit uncomfortable. In this story snakes were used as a curse sent by God on his people for their ingratitude and rebellion. The snake equalled a curse, and on the cross Jesus became cursed for us. God loved the world so much that he gave His Son to bear the curse for us.

Here is the point, Nicodemus would have never conceived of a suffering Messiah, or a saviour who would die for others. Nicodemus wanted a Jesus who fitted neatly into his categories, his understanding, The Jesus he wanted, and the Jesus who is, were very different, it is only through the new birth are we able to accept Jesus for who he is, and not try and make him something we think he should be. Father thank you for the glories oh the new birth

title: Jesus and Nicodemus. Part 4
study_refs: Verses 5-8 have caused a lot of debate among theologians as to what Jesus meant when he spoke about being ‘born of the water and the Spirit.’. Jesus is dealing with Nicodemus and he is surprised by Nicodemus’ response to what Jesus has said. ‘You should not be surprised at my saying you must be born again.’ The word used for surprised is thaumazo, which means to be astonished, and it is where we get our English word traumatic from. Jesus is conscious that Nicodemus is really struggling. So Jesus presents the same truth but in different language. Knowing that Nicodemus was ‘Israel’s teacher and he was very well versed in the Old Testament Jesus uses the symbolism of the Old Testament to try and communicate the truth to Nicodemus. There are several Old Testament texts that use the symbolism of water and wind to refer to the new life the Spirit gives.

Isaiah 44:3-5 For I will pour water on the thirsty land, and streams on the dry ground; I will pour out my Spirit on your offspring, and my blessing on your descendants. They will spring up like grass in a meadow, like poplar trees by flowing streams. Some will say, ‘I belong to the Lord ’

html:
We want to look at a well known parable that Jesus told that may be able to help us move from a place where we feel spiritually stuck and distanced from God to a place where we have a better understanding of the Grace of God.

The story is the parable of the prodigal son, but we’re going to look at the elder brother and try and gain some help from his experience. But before we look at him let us mention a number of things.

We know from the context of the story that Jesus was confronting the ‘muttering’ of Pharisees and teachers of the law because they were complaining that Jesus was welcoming tax collectors and ‘sinners.’ see Luke 15:1-2. In the three parables Jesus is going to tell, Jesus wants to confront and refute the thinking and mindset of these Pharisees. For what these Pharisees thought and believed was the absolute antithesis to life in the Kingdom of God.

These Pharisees did not understand the importance of grace as an essential for authentic spiritual life.

We have been created to live lives that are full of grace and that are continually showing grace to others. This older Son was not an evil person, he was misguided, he lacked maturity and understanding; it was never his intention to be in a position where he was simply going through the motions. Like the Pharisees whom Jesus is addressing, this elder son had a mindset that prevented him from understanding grace. As far as grace was concerned this elder son had a blind spot. I am sure he could have verbalised some kind of theological definition of Grace, but he didn’t really get it.

The mistakes of the elder Son could be summed up in one word, attitude. Jesus has a lot to say about his heart attitude and his thinking. His inability to understand and live in grace was rooted in wrong thinking about himself, his father and his brother. He needed to unlearn a lot of things, things that had become the foundation of his life. He needed to unlearn deep seated beliefs.

Trying to live for Jesus without having a heart understanding of grace will cause us to become too religious and in being too religious our default potency will be to resist the way of the Kingdom of God, which is grace. Father help me to understand and accept my continual need of grace. Bible in a year reading plan Jeremiah 31:21-33:26
title: The missed glory of not living in grace. Part 1
study_refs: Have you ever sat down and taken stock of your relationship with God? Have you ever thought to yourself? This is not how it should be. There must be more to being a Christian than just going through the motions, dotting the ‘I’s’ and crossing the ‘T’s.’ Are you tired hiding behind a reputation? Do you feel duped or cheated as far as your relationship with God is concerned? Do you feel disappointed or just indifferent with your Christian experience?

html:
His thinking was not in a vacuum. The way this elder brother thought had developed over many years, Now in the first part of the Parable we have very little mention of the Elder son. All we know about him that he had a father and a younger brother. Now the people listening to Jesus would have picked up on the lack of activity of the elder son in the first part of the parable, for in that culture it was the responsibility of an elder son to mediate between his younger brother and his father. He had a cultural obligation to try a broker a peace between his brother and his father. He was the best placed person who had an opportunity to try and find a solution to the crisis the family was now experiencing.

This Elder brother however was pragmatic when it came to his responsibilities. It suited him better to stand back and say nothing. He was going to gain if his father carried out the request of his younger brother.

His silence indicated that his own personal gain was more important than the well being of his father and brother and their relationship. Sometimes we need to step up and take responsibility for situations, it is often too easy for us all to step back and say it would be easier and better for me not to get involved.

Sometimes people remain silent because they feel insecure, or they don’t like confrontation. However, this was not the case with the elder son, as we shall see he had no problem with confronting others. His silence was really an expression of selfishness. The inactivity of the elder brother turned him into someone who could not understand or display grace. Remaining silent when he knew he should have spoken began the process of him developing into a person who could not or would not understand grace.

He was an angry man. Jesus wants us to know what was going on in the heart of this older brother. He was angry. Jesus does not tell us who he is angry with or why. He may be angry because of the actions of his father, in throwing such a lavish party for his younger brother. (In giving the party the father had to use the elder brothers’ resources which of course he wouldn’t have been happy about.)

On a surface level we could probably sympathise with the elder brother. He had stayed at home and worked hard in order to protect the part inheritance he had received. And now here was his father using his inheritance to splash out on a big party for his irresponsible brother who just returned. However if we go a bit deeper and look beyond the surface, we will realise that for the elder brother his possessions was all he had. He was the kind of person who measured his value and success by the things he had. His distance from his father produced in him a materialistic mindset ‘what I possess is more important that my relationships, and if you touch my stuff I will get angry.’ Anger is not always wrong, but it was in this case because it was an expression of blatant selfishness. His anger prevented him from understanding, receiving or showing grace.

He had no respect for his Father. Listen to how he talks to his father. His first word is ‘Look,’ in using this word he refused to give his father the respect that he was due. You can almost feel his anger ‘Look!’

He thought of himself as a slave not a son! His father had pleaded with him to come in but he would not listen. So after he is rude to his father he begins to talk about himself. ‘All these years I have been slaving for you and never disobeyed your orders.’ What a tragiic statement. We need to understand that our ability to understand, enjoy and live in the reality of grace, depends on us choosing to live as sons and daughters of God.

Father thank you that youhave a deep desire that we have the mindset of a son of God

Bible in a year: Jeremiah 34--36
title: The missed glory of not living in grace. Part 2
study_refs: The thinking of the elder brother.

html:
Duty or a ‘must do’ attitude dries up a person’s relationship with the father. The idea behind the word duty is to owe something. If we base our relationship on the basis that we owe God something, and not on the basis of Grace then it will not be a healthy relationship. I could never give to God what I owe him, but that is ok. In fact it is better than ok; For God will only accept us on the basis of His grace alone. The elder sons’ relationship with the father was not based on Grace. He had an ‘I deserve,’ attitude, therefore, he was unable to understand grace, receive grace or be gracious.

Our father God wants our hearts not our duty, he wants our love more than he wants our service, he wants us to know and understand his heart.

He related to his father with a ‘deal mentality.’ Let me explain, listen to what he says to his father ‘All these years I’ve been slaving for you, (which was a lie as we shall see.) and never disobeyed your orders. Yet you never even gave me a young goat so I could celebrate with my friends.’ Do you see what he is saying here? He is saying ‘because I have been such an obedient son, you owe me. I have ticked all the boxes, and have done all my duties. I think I deserve something in return. He wasn’t really slaving for the Father, he was serving himself.

It is very easy for anyone of us to develop a ‘deal mentality’ when it comes to our relationship with God our Father. We may never verbalise these attitudes but we can think thoughts like. ‘I have been faithful, God has to bless me.’ Or, ‘If I am obedient then I deserve God to answer my prayers.’ We think, If I repent more, read the bible more, pray more, obey more, serve more and just try harder to be a good Christian, God will come through for me.’ This kind of thinking in Pharisaical therefore it is contrary to the Kingdom of God and anti-grace. God will only deal with us on the basis of Grace, nothing we can do or say will ever make us morew deserving of God’s love or blessing.

He was unable to celebrate.

This celebration is the very essence of the Father’s heart; it expressed the longing and desire of his heart. This was what the father had longed and hoped for, for years. However, because of what was going on in the heart of the older brother, he was unable to celebrate, understand or appreciate the heart of his Father. This celebration underscored what was really important. It highlighted that love, mercy, grace, forgiveness, acceptance and relationships are extremely important. This celebration could be defined as divine satisfaction. This was the happiest day in the life of the Father, but his older son was emotionally detached

As the father and younger son celebrated their relationship experienced healing, In the context of joyful acceptance, old barriers came down, bitterness and resentment melted away aentnd a new commitms to each other are forged as a shared future is anticipated.

As we have thought about this elder brother, we think he must be one of the saddest people we will meet in all of scriptures. As the Father and younger brother, along with their friends and neighbors enjoy the transforming and healing glory of celebrating grace, the elder son stands outside in the cold shadows nursing his anger. As the sound of music and dancing fills the air and the joyous noise of celebration surrounds him, he must feel so lost, so detached, so far from home. We are not told if he ever went in, or if he remained trapped in his Pharisaical mindset having a blind spot to the glory and wonder of grace of God.

At sometime in all our lives we have all stood in the shadows, we have all felt so far from home. We have all fallen for the lie that says ‘if I try harder, or do more or give more!’ and we have ended up disillusioned, confused, disappointed thinking there must be more to it than this.

Let’s end by pointing out one more thing from the parable. We are told that the Father went out and pleaded with him. The word that is used is parakaleō and it means to come along beside to encourage or comfort. This is wonderful. The father had every right to be angry, his eldest son had publicly shamed him by refusing to join the celebration, so his father goes out to him and shows him tender grace. But the son still didn’t get it, even when he was the recipient of grace.

If any of us are like the elder brother, our father is pleading with us; he is gently saying ‘it does not have to be this way.’ In great tenderness he is saying, ‘it’s time to come home, let us celebrate together.’ Father may I know the glory of celebrating with you. Once we stop believing that we are children of God then it won’t be long until there will be some distance between us and the Father.

When we read about the passion of Jesus we need to keep two things in mind.

Often God uses suffering to write the story of our lives.

later on in the same letter Peter says. Therefore, since Christ suffered in his body, arm yourselves also with the same attitude, because whoever suffers in the body is done with sin..1Peter 4:1 the attitudes Jesus showed are the attitudes we need to have in our lives. study_refs: Then the Jewish leaders took Jesus from Caiaphas to the palace of the Roman governor. By now it was early morning, and to avoid ceremonial uncleanness they did not enter the palace, because they wanted to be able to eat the Passover. So Pilate came out to them and asked, “What charges are you bringing against this man?” “If he were not a criminal,” they replied, “we would not have handed him over to you.” Pilate said, “Take him yourselves and judge him by your own law.” . “ But we have no right to execute anyone,” they objected. This took place to fulfil what Jesus had said about the kind of death he was going to die. Pilate then went back inside the palace, summoned Jesus and asked him, “Are you the king of the Jews?” “Is that your own idea, ”Jesus asked, “ or did others talk to you about me?” “Am I a Jew?” Pilate replied. “Your own people and chief priests handed you over to me. What is it you have done?” Jesus said, “My kingdom is not of this world. If it were, my servants would fight to prevent my arrest by the Jewish leaders. But now my kingdom is from another place.” “You are a king, then!” said Pilate. Jesus answered, “You say that I am a king. In fact, the reason I was born and came into the world is to testify to the truth. Everyone on the side of truth listens to me.” “What is truth?” retorted Pilate. With this he went out again to the Jews gathered there and said, “I find no basis for a charge against him. But it is your custom for me to release to you one prisoner at the time of the Passover. Do you want me to release ‘the king of the Jews’?” They shouted back, “No, not him! Give us Barabbas!” Now Barabbas had taken part in an uprising. Then Pilate took Jesus and had him flogged. The soldiers twisted together a crown of thorns and put it on his head. They clothed him in a purple robe and went up to him again and again, saying, “Hail, king of the Jews!” And they slapped him in the face. Once more Pilate came out and said to the Jews gathered there, “Look, I am bringing him out to you to let you know that I find no basis for a charge against him.”When Jesus came out wearing the crown of thorns and the purple robe, Pilate said to them, “Here is the man!” As soon as the chief priests and their officials saw him, they shouted, “Crucify! Crucify!” But Pilate answered, “You take him and crucify him. As for me, I find no basis for a charge against him.” The Jewish leaders insisted, “We have a law, and according to that law he must die, because he claimed to be the Son of God.” When Pilate heard this, he was even more afraid, and he went back inside the palace. “Where do you come from?” he asked Jesus, but Jesus gave him no answer. “Do you refuse to speak to me?” Pilate said. “Don’t you realize I have power either to free you or to crucify you?” Jesus answered, “You would have no power over me if it were not given to you from above. Therefore the one who handed me over to you is guilty of a greater sin.” From then on, Pilate tried to set Jesus free, but the Jewish leaders kept shouting, “If you let this man go, you are no friend of Caesar. Anyone who claims to be a king opposes Caesar.” When Pilate heard this, he brought Jesus out and sat down on the judge’s seat at a place known as the Stone Pavement (which in Aramaic is Gabbatha). It was the day of Preparation of the Passover; it was about noon. “ Here is your king,”Pilate said to the Jews. But they shouted, “Take him away! Take him away! Crucify him!” “ Shall I crucify your king?” Pilate asked. “ We have no king but Caesar,” the chief priests answered.Finally Pilate handed him over to them to be crucified

W e are going to look at Pilate and his encounter with Jesus. Let me give you a few facts about Pilate, in the other Gospels he is referred to Pountus Pilate, but only Pilate in John. He was the fifth governor of Judea from 25 to 36 Ad

There are 56 references to Pilate in the New Testament and if it were not for that he would not be so well known. Outside the New Testament there are a few references to him. B oth Philo and Josephus paint a very stark portrait of the Roman ruler. Pilate is characterized as oppressive, greedy, he is portrayed as being stubborn, and cruel. Philo specifically catalogues “his venality, his violence, his thefts, his assaults, his abusive behaviour, his frequent executions of untried prisoners, and his endless savage ferocity” ( Gaium 302), though some claim Philo exaggerated the matter. Nonetheless, Pilate did antagonize the Jews and they hated him (though they would later use him for the implementation of their own evil designs).

For example, he introduced into the city of Jerusalem certain ensigns that contained the image of Caesar, an act that infuriated the Hebrews because they considered the overture to be heathenish ( Antiquities 18.3.1; Wars 2.9.2-3). Further, three different coins minted by Pilate have been found by archaeologists. They depict pagan symbols, again reflecting his disdain for the Jewish conscience.’ Jackson, Wayne. html:
We want to look at Jesus’ trial before Pilate

John in his gospel concentrates on Jesus’ trial before Pilate. John wants us to see who Jesus is, he wants to see more than Jesus in his suffering. John also wants us to understand the world in which we live and how we should live in. Jesus trial before Pilate is a microcosm of a universal dynamic that effects all our lives, that is we either live from a position of truth or a position of power

John presents the trial of Jesus before Pilate in seven different sections.

1. Outside (18:28-32): Jews demand death of Jesus.

2. Inside (18:33-38a): Pilate and Jesus on kingship.

3. Outside (18:38b-40): Pilate finds no guilt; choice of Barrabbas.

4. Inside (19:1-3): Soldiers scourge Jesus.

5. Outside (19:4-8): Pilate finds no guilt; "Behold the Man."

6. Inside (19:9-11): Pilate and Jesus on power.

7. Outside (19:12-16a): Jews obtain death of Jesus.

Pilate and the abuse of power

In the middle of Pilates encounter with Jesus, Pilate says something that sums up how he thinks, how he sees the world, and how he see himself. ‘Don’t you realise I have power…’ John 19:10. What a revelation. For Pilate power was everything, power gave him significance, control, entitlement, authority. When he said ‘Don’t you realise I have power...’ he was basically saying. ‘Do you know who I am.’ But he was abusive and misused his power and position.

1. He did not take time to get to true facts. John says Then the Jewish leaders took Jesus from Caiaphas to the palace of the Roman governor. By now it was early morning, and to avoid ceremonial uncleanness they did not enter the palace, because they wanted to be able to eat the Passover

Just let me mention that the Jewish leaders were not prepared to go into Pilate’s Palace. The religious leaders were willing to condemn an innocent man to death, but they were unwilling to step foot in the Gentile’s residence. The Jewish leaders have cleansed their homes of leaven; they have prepared the passover lambs; they have performed the necessary rituals to insure ritual cleanness. The religious leaders would be required to kill their Passover lambs that very afternoon and keep the feast immediately after the sun went down. The religious leaders were not about to risk ceremonial defilement by entering the residence of a Gentile governor.

Sometimes people in positions of power within the church are more concerned about keeping unimportant religious rules that have nothing to do with spirituality than they are the things that really matter,

29 So Pilate came out to them and asked, “What charges are you bringing against this man?” 30 “If he were not a criminal,” they replied, “we would not have handed him over to you.”

This was an extremely cruel statement The word “criminal” from the Greek is kakopoios; evildoer, criminal; in the ancient world it meant a person currently actively involved in evil. Can you think of a worse name for Jesus?

Pilate asks, ‘What charges are you bringing against this man.’ and they refuse to answer his question. In fact they had already decided that Jesus should be executed, for when Pilate said ‘Take him yourselves and judge him by your own law, they replied, ‘But we have no right to execute anyone.

Pilate did not take the time or the effort to get the facts. In John’s account they could give no good reason why Jesus should suffer, and this did not worry Pilate. When people use their power and positions in ways that hurt and abuse others they usually are not interested in dealing with facts. The less facts the better as far as they are concerned.

Father may I always acknowledge that truth is always more important than power.

html:
Pilate did not care about truth. We all know the famous question Pilate asked, ‘what is truth?’ This was not a sincere question, for he didn’t wait for an answer. John tells us that ‘With this he went out again to the Jews.’


Pilate’s “What is truth” is a cynical retort, not a cry from the heart, as if to say, “when you have the full force of Rome behind you, truth is optional, truth gets thrown under the bus, truth is a victim to power. In the context of the abuse of power, truth becomes its first casualty. People like Pilate need to bury the truth for their abusive power structures to survive.

In Greek philosophy, one of the senses of aletheia, Greek word for truth. involved an accurate perspective on reality. Romans similarly spoke of veritas as a factual representation of events. At a very basic level Pilate was refusing to live in reality. He had created his own reality, and everything that he was doing was to protect his false reality by avoiding truth.

Miroslav Vow wrote,

‘trials are supposed to be about finding out what happened and meting out justice. In Jesus’ trial, neither the accusers nor the judge cared for the truth. . . . The judge scorns the very notion of truth: “What is truth?” he asks, and uninterested in any answer, he leaves the scene of dialogue . . . For both the accusers and the judge, the truth is irrelevant because it works at cross-purposes to their hold on power. The only truth they will recognize is “the truth of power.” It was the accused who raised the issue of truth by subtly reminding the judge of his highest obligation—find out the truth.’

Father help us never be afraid to do the hard work that may be required to bring out the truth.

html:
He refuses to take responsibility

In three ways Pilate tries to get of taking responsibility, [a] he tells the crowd to take Jesus and judge him John 18:31. Then he tells them to take Jesus and crucify. As for me I find no basis for a charge against him. 19:6. [b] Luke tells us that Pilate sent Jesus to Herod Luke 23:6 [c] He washes his hand in a basin saying ‘I am innocent of this man’s blood, it is your responsibility.’ Matthew27:24. Pontius Pilate, the governor, the most powerful man in the region, the only one with the judicial faculty to hand a man over to death, stands before a crowd and claims that he is not responsible for what he does. He claims that, in violating his own conscience and handing over an innocent man to torture, he is innocent.

‘it’s not my fault, he is to blame, I couldn’t help it. I didn’t mean to hurt them.’ and people have lots of different ways of avoiding taking responsibilities. Maybe their has been a ‘Pilate’ in you life, someone at home, at work, at church, at school, someone who has misused their position to hurt. Jesus knows how you feel, Jesus has stood where you stand and understands.

Looking at Pilate, we do not see a very nice person, he is a miserable human being with no redeeming qualities or moral courage who uses his power for self gain and gratification.

However when we look at Jesus we see someone who with internal beauty and strength was able to handle the cruel injustices.

1. He refused to use his power and position for his own benefit. Reading about Jesus before Pilate, you wonder why Jesus would not just call down fire from heaven and show these people his power and strength? But he didn’t, why.

[a] In the garden he had completely and without reservation submitted himself to his Fathers will, and he knew that this particular suffering was part of his fathers will. On occasions Jesus avoided suffering. Once the people of his own town tried to throw him of a cliff in order to kill him, and he walked away. Problem with you and me is we don’t always know if our suffer is part of God’s will for us, or are they just the consequences of living in a falling world. I don’t think it is too important to know, but what is important is that we live surrendered lives. Jesus could stand before Pilate because he had ‘kneeled’ in the garden.

[b] Jesus never used his power to serve his own needs, this something he learned in the wilderness when he was tempted by Satan. Satan wanted him to assert his power and turn stone into bread in order to feed his hunger, but he refused.

[c] I think another reason why Jesus may not have called fire down from heaven and use his divine power was because he knew that when we stand before ’our Pilate’ we could not do that. He wanted to teach us how to handle injustice.

[d] Above all Jesus wanted to fulfil his Fathers plan of salvation, and through suffer he gave himself a ransom for many.

Jesus remembered who he was and why he came look at verse 37.

‘You are a king, then!’ said Pilate. Jesus answered. ‘You are right in saying I am a king. In fact for this reason I was born, and for this I came into the world, to testify to truth. Everyone on the side of truth listens to me,’

I think this may be the only recorded time Jesus refers to his birth. When some one suffers the injustice of power abuse by an other person, they can feel worthless and insignificant. But like Jesus we have been born with significance, value and purpose.

Suffer injustice is an extremely lonely and painful experience, however injustice is not all powerful, even though it might feel that it is. It cannot rob a person of their value or their God give purpose. It can do a lot of terrible things but it cannot change the reason for your being. The pain of life cannot rob a person of purposes of God.

Just notice that the purposes of God are always consistent with the truth. If we go into error, or pretence, or denial or unreality, then you are not in the will of God. Pilate and Jesus were completely opposite. Jesus overcame power with truth.

One final thing Jesus did as he stood before Pilate, he redefined what a kingdom was. A kingdom is the authority which you live, and the kingdom determines how you live. Jesus said ‘my kingdom is not of this world.’ So how Jesus approached life was the antitheses to how Pilate did

Pilate kingdom was about power.

Jesus kingdom is about truth.

Pilate kingdom used force and violence.

Jesus kingdom is about love and grace.

Pilate kingdom was about taking the lives of others.

Jesus kingdom is about laying down you life for others.

Pilate kingdom was about saving yourself

Jesus kingdom is about saving others.

Let me end by quoting the verse we started with,

To this you were called, because Christ suffered for you, leaving you an example, that you should follow in his steps. 1Peter 2:21

Father thank you for the majestic beauty of Jesus and his kingdom. Bible in a year reading plan Jeremiah 51:11-52:34
