Pilate was a man who was motivated by fear John tells us that ‘he was even more afraid.’ John 19:8 This is very interesting. Pilate feared the Jewish leaders in case they reported him to Caesar. They said to Pilate. ‘If you let this man go you are no friend of Caesar. Friend of Caesar' was a coveted title of honour given by the Emperor for service. The title implied the recipient had a personal relationship with the Caesar, and so, had political clout. For Pilate, the title would have meant an appointment to a much more desirable post than Judea.

His motivation was fear and self-protection. He did not care what principles he had to break, or what morals he would have to ditch as long as he could hold unto his position of power. He feared loosing something that was not worth having.

html:
If we were to combine Matthew's account with Mark's we notice that Jesus does two things before He speaks.

Firstly, Jesus turned. Mark says, "When he turned" It was as if Jesus was being led away from the other disciples, and before He spoke he turned and faced them. Here we have Jesus facing the situation head on. When we are involved in spiritual warfare, we need to be real and face things as they really are. Often in church life we skirt around issues, burying things under the mat of activity, hoping that they will go away. The only way we can overcome the temptations of Satan is to face them. It is interesting to note that the word used for tum is the same word that is often used to describe man's conversion. It suggests a radical change of direction. The only way we can resist Satan is to constantly turn towards God and His purposes.

Secondly, Jesus looks at His disciples. Mark says 'But when Jesus turned and looked at his disciples,' Mark 8:33. He just didn't look at Peter, but at all the disciples. The Greek word for looked is ‘oida,’ which is a word that is derived from ‘eidoto’ see, or perceive by means of the senses. This knowledge, however, is not deep, it lies near the surface of things. It carries the idea of ascertaining what must be done about a certain situation. So before Jesus speaks, he assess the situation so he can take the appropriate action.

Then Jesus rebukes Peter. In Greek, the common word for rebuke is ‘epitimao,’ " to rebuke, reprove, censure, also, to wan in order to prevent an action or bring one to an end. Jesus uses the same word in rebuking the disciples in Luke 9:55. It is a word of authority. Jesus rebukes evil spirits (Luke 9:41-43; Mark 3:12; 9:25), diseases (Luke 4:39), and the elemental forces of nature (Mark 4:39). -It is also a word describing how Christian brothers are to relate to each other in a spirit of forgiveness: 'So watch yourselves. If your brother sins, rebuke (epitimao) him, and if he repents, forgive him.' (Luke 17:3).

The content of Jesus' rebuke.

Firstly Jesus identify Peter with Satan

Jesus doesn't call Pontius, Satan. He doesn't call Herod, Satan (a fox maybe but not Satan). Jesus doesn't call Caiaphas or Annias (the high priests), Satan. He calls one of his own Apostles, Satan. Why?

Peter’s rebuke was a repeat of the temptation that Satan offered Jesus in the wilderness. 'Again the Devil took him to a very high mountain and showed him all the kingdoms of the world and their splendour. All this I will give you, he said, if you bow down and worship me.' Matthew 4:8. In other words 'Jesus you don't have to suffer, you don't need to go to the cross. Or in Peter's words. 'This shall never happen to you.' Peter's insistence upon an alternatives to suffering is a satanic deception.

One of Satan's most effective weapons is not the sword but the velvet cushion. He comes to us and convinces us that we don't deserve suffering and pain, that we shouldn't have to suffer, especially for the needs of others. The belief that this life should be free from the humiliation of the cross is a satanic ploy designed to rob us of life. We need our crosses for the sake of others just as much as Jesus needed his cross for our sake

Father help me to recognise that the desire and plan of Satan is to keep me from carrying my cross

Bible in a year: lamentations 1:1-3:51
title: Jesus’ rebuke of Peter. Part 1
study_refs: We want to look at how Jesus responded to Peter's rebuke and then consider the teaching that Jesus gave to counteract Peter's thinking. When we first read Jesus' reaction to Peter, it may appear a bit strong to us, but as we will see Jesus' response was both appropriate and necessary.

html:
Jesus deals with the source of Peter's wrong thinking, Satan. The proper place for Satan is behind us, in the sense he mustn't be the object of or focus of our attention. This does not mean that we ignore him our pretend that he doesn't exist.

Rather, it means that we him put him and all that he has done to our lives behind us so we can really pursue God. Jesus then informs Peter; 'You are a stumbling block to me.' The word for stumbling block is skandalon from which we get our English word scandal. In Greek culture the word was used to describe the trigger in the trap on -which the bait placed which springs the trap when it is touched by the animal, causing the trap to close. It was also used to describe a stone on a pathway on which people would trip.

Skandalon always denotes the enticement or occasion leading to conduct which brings with it the ruin of the person in question. Skandala are things which lead others to turn away from God's salvation and thus to come to ruin. (Matt. 18:7. Luke 17:1). Imagine how terrible it would be being a stumbling block or a trap to the life of Jesus?

'Get behind me right now.' In front of me you're Satan, my stumbling block, behind me, you're Peter, my disciple. I can't build my church on you if you're standing in my way. Get behind me, where followers belong, where the church belongs.' Lastly Jesus tells us why Peter is acting in such a way. 'You do not have in mind the things of God, but the things of men.'What Jesus says here really exposes what if going on in Peter's heart. Matthew uses the word (phroneo) for mind.

The word Phroneo comes from the root word Phren that means the inner chambers of your heart. The word has an emphasis on the underlying disposition or attitude. Jesus' harsh critique of Peter involves more than just the few words he spoke on this occasion, but his inner attitude, the disposition of his heart, or we might even say, his very nature.

The word also has the sense of 'taking sides', 'supporting the cause of someone' e.g. when Josephus recounts the story of David's struggle to become king and the action of Abner, the commander of the opposing forces, seeking a political settlement with David. (2 Samuel 3) He says that the elders of Israel 'changed over to David's side' (Josephus. Antiquities 7.28). Mark uses this same idiom (8:33) to describe Peter's action. So Jesus is accusing Peter of shifting his loyalties and pursuing Satans agenda.

No matter how many Revelations a person may have received from God, from time to time they will need to experience the confrontation of Jesus.

We are all potential instruments in the hand of Satan, and sometimes the only way we can be delivered from his influence is through a harsh confrontation with Jesus.

The influence of Satan is often appealing, he does not want you to suffer, especially for the sake of others.

God loves us the way we are, but he loves us too much to let us stay that way.

Peter would have never had become the rock if Jesus hadn't confronted him. Not having a transformed mind can be the biggest threat to the Kingdom of God.

Father may your confrontation of me transform how I think and how I understand life. Bible in a year reading plan Lamentations 3:52-5:22 Ezekiel 1-2
title: Jesus’ rebuke of Peter. Part 2
study_refs: Jesus expressed his authority over Satan.

Then Jesus says to Peter 'Get behind me Satan.' Jesus' words are reminiscent of his response to Satan, 'Away with you, Satan.' Matthew (4:10), at the conclusion of the wilderness temptation. The difference is that Jesus commanded Satan to move away or depart (Greek: hupago), Aramaic idiom for 'get out of my sight,' while he commands Peter to move er (hupago again) to his proper position behind Jesus. That is the disciple's place behind the Master following Him. Before Jesus addresses the issues that caused Peter to become a stumbling block.

html:
The references in Matthew 16:24, Mark 8:34 and Luke 9:23 are all in the context of Peter's confession and rebuke of Jesus, although Luke does not mention that Peter rebuked Jesus. However this was a time of personal tension between the two. If we include Mark 10:21, that to was in the context of a strained relationship between the Rich Young Ruler and Jesus. When we think of Jesus taking up his own cross, that was to mend broken relationships between God and man, so as we try to understand what 'taking up your cross really means, we need to keep in mind the contexts in which Jesus spoke this command.

A second thing we need to keep in mind is that we must not tum the cross that Jesus was speaking of here into something it isn't. Many people think that a cross is any trial or hardship you are going through, such as, a health problem, a disability, bereavement, or being single. 'That's my cross,' we say, but this is not what Jesus meant. The problem with this understanding is that most of the pain we go through in life is not of our own choosing. I didn't wake up one morning and think Cerebral Palsy is the cross for me, so l chose my disability. No! When it comes to most of the trials and difficulties in life, we don't have a choice, but when it comes to taking up our cross we do have a choice.

When we read these verses about taking up your cross, we must remember that the context, in which Matthew 16 places this teaching, is intended to refute the influence and mindset of Satan. What Jesus is going to teach about taking up you cross is designed to protect us from Satanic influence.

So what is Jesus referring to when He speaks about our cross?

Crucifixion in the Ancient World. The cross in Jesus' day was an instrument of torture and execution, pure and simple. There wasn't a figurative use of 'cross' as a 'burden' or 'trial' in those days. Death on the cross was a shameful, excruciating, way to die. An ancient Greek poem describes it this way: Punished with limbs outstretched, they see the stake as their fate; They are fastened (and) nailed to it in the most bitter torment, evil food for birds of prey and grim pickings for dogs.'

Psuedo-Manetho, Apotelesmatica 4:198ff, cited by Martin Hengel, Crucifixion (Fortress Press, translated 1977), p. 9.

'At that time these words of Jesus might have been rendered thus: 'If anyone wishes to come after me, let him be prepared to be led out to public execution, following my example' (The Hard Sayings of Jesus, F. F. Bruce, p. 150).

There was no 'norm' for execution on the cross, though it often included flogging beforehand, the victim carrying the beam to the place of execution, being nailed to it with outstretched arms, raised up, and seated on a small wooden peg. But Seneca indicates there were many variations: 'I see crosses there, not just of one kind but made in many different ways: some have their victims with head down to the ground; some impale their private parts; others stretch out their arms on the gibbet. "[15] Seneca, Dialogue 6 (De consolatione ad Marciam) 20.3. Cited by Hengel, p. 25

Josephus, an eyewitness of Roman cruelty to the defenders at the fall of Jerusalem in 70 AD, gives us a gruesome picture:

‘They were first whipped, and then tormented with all sorts of tortures, before they died, and were then crucified before the wall of the city. This miserable procedure made Titus greatly to pity them, while they caught every day five hundred Jews; nay, some days they caught more.' The main reason why he did not forbid that cruelty was that he hoped the Jews might perhaps yield at that sight, out of fear lest they might themselves afterwards be liable to the same cruel treatment. So the soldiers, out of the wrath and hatred they bore the Jews, nailed those they caught, one after one way, and another after another, to the crosses, by way of jest, when their multitude was so great, that room was wanting for the crosses, and crosses wanting for the bodies.' Josephus, Wars of the Jews, 5, 11.

After a revolt following the death of Herod the Great, the Roman proconsul Varus crucified two thousand Jews. Crucifixion was a common practice in the Roman Empire.

When Jesus said, 'Take up your cross,' the disciples saw poor condemned souls marching along a road with the instrument of their own death strapped to their backs. Carrying one's cross meant walking to one's death.

is Jesus not being a bit extreme?

What is the point of being crucified? Surety God has come to give us life to the full! So why would we want to carry a cross? And what is our cross anyway?

The cross that Jesus is speaking about may not lead to physical death, in fact there may not be anything physical to it. What Jesus is referring to is the heart attitude of a cross bearer. Or to put it in the form of a question;

What kind of heart attitudes did Jesus display as he carried His cross? Jesus was expressing an attitude of love, forgiveness humility and submission as he bowed to, and suffered in the will of God. The attitudes and motives Jesus needed to die on the cross, are the same attitudes and motives we need for life.

Father I need to recognise that the cross I need to carry is an essential for my spiritual well-being. Bible in a year reading plan Ezekiel 3-8
title: Jesus’ rebuke of Peter. Part 3
study_refs: Before we look at what Jesus meant when he said 'Take up your cross and follow me,' we need to make a few observations that will help us in our understanding. Depending on what version of the bible you read, the phrase 'take up your cross' is either found five or six times. Many of the older translations include the phrase in Mark 10:21 as part of Jesus response to the Rich Young Ruler, while the more modern translations don't. If you look carefully at every context in which Jesus uses the phrase, it is also in the context of difficult relationships.

In Matthew 10:34-37 Jesus is speaking about difficult relationships, and how the demands of the Kingdom can put great strain on family relationships then He says in Matthew 10:38 'And anyone who does not take up his cross and follow me is not worthy of me.' This is similar to the context in Luke 14:27 'And whosoever does not carry his cross, and come after me, cannot be my disciple. ' The main difference being, that in Matthew 10 Jesus was speaking to the twelve, while in Luke 14 He is speaking to the crowds.

html:
We must deny ourselves

What does it men to deny yourself? Many people think that to deny yourself means that we must feel bad about ourselves, we must loathe ourselves, we suffer from a poor self image. However, those who think this way are unable to deny themselves. Denying yourself is an expression of security not insecurity, it is a volitional choice of our wills, not an emotional response to the world around us. When we fall into the trap of equating a low self-image with self-denial we are doing the complete opposite to what we think we are doing. People who suffer from chronic self-image problems can become self-obsessed and very selfish, this in turns prevents self-denial.

The Greek word for deny is arneomai means, disown, renounce, refuse, not to accept, to reject, to refuse something offered, it carries the idea of making a volitional choice. It is best illustrated in the words of Philippians 2:6-8 'Who being in very nature God, did not consider equality with God something to be grasped. But made himself nothing, taking the very nature of a servant, being made in human likeness. And being found in the appearance of a man he humbled himself, and became obedient to death even death on a cross.'

To deny yourself is to choose being a servant over having position of authority. To deny yourself is to choose humility over pride. To deny yourself is to choose to obey the will of God irrespective of the personal cost and pain.

What kind of person couldn't make choices like this, the person who is insecure because of a bad self image, the person who hasn't accepted themselves, so they desperately try to find life in other things and in other people rather than in God. To deny yourself is an expression of self acceptance and contentment.

What are the consequences of denying your self?

You will be able to take up your cross because your focus will not be on your self; you will have a spontaneous, automatic disposition to live a life of self-sacrifice so you can serve others.

You will discover real life. Jesus says four things about life, (Greek psyche) in these verses.

Whoever desires to save his life [psyche] will lose it.

Whoever loses his life [psyche] for Christ's sake will find it.

What profit is it to a man if he gains the whole world, and loses his own life [psyche?]

What will a man give in exchange for his life [psyche?]

It is quite amazing to me that some evangelical commentators understand the word saved in this context as referring to obtaining eternal salvation from hell

'There is no salvation apart from cross-bearing.' (Boice, Christ's Call To Discipleship, p 36).

‘'Thus in a sense we pay the ultimate price for salvation when our sinful self is nailed to a cross. It is total abandonment of self-will. It denotes implicit obedience, full surrender to the lordship of Christ" (MacArthur, The Gospel According to Jesus, p 140).

I think to interpret the word save in this context, as referring to salvation in this context is wrong for a number of reasons. Eternal salvation is not conditioned elsewhere in the Bible upon self denial and cross bearing. Eternal salvation is not something which we buy, it is a free gift.

Those being addressed here are believers, not unbelievers. Recompense according to one's deeds. Verse 27) is a not a salvation concept. Rather, it is a reward concept.

b. You will loose your life

So what does it mean to loose your life and save your life?

All believers have eternal life. However, only ‘self-denying’ believers will realise the full potential of eternal life (John 10:10). A 'saved life' is the glory of a life lived for God.

To loose one's life is to play it safe; it is to decide against the way of the cross and its conform with the status quo. It is to decide to play it safe, it is a deep concern for self-interest. "Survival at all costs," is a flawed philosophy by which to live. 'Be faithful to Christ no matter what the cost,' is the philosophy Jesus' disciples need to live by. We are made in such away, that when we live a self-obsessed life, something with in us dies. We have been made to live lives for the benefit of others, and that is only possible when we live a cross shaped life. "Jesus is not anti-our-life; he is anti-preoccupation-with-our-life" (Bruner, 593

'There are two attitudes toward life which are possible, and you can have only one or the other.'

One is to save your life now, i.e., hoard it, clutch it, cling to it, grasp it, try to get hold of it for yourself, take care of yourself, trust yourself, see that in every situation your first and major concern is, 'What's in it for me’ The other attitude is: lose it, i.e., fling it away, disregard what advantages there may be for you in a situation, and move out in dependence upon God, careless of what may happen to you.' Ray Steadman. https://cdn.pbc.org/Main_Service/1975/02/15/3315.pdf. Accessed 31/07/25

The word Jesus uses for loss 'apollumi,' has a wide range of meanings, it can mean to ruin, undo, lose utility; to totally remove something to eliminate its purpose or usefulness. According to Vine's Greek Dictionary, the meaning is not of extinction, but of loss of well being. This is the same word that is used in Luke 15, when Jesus tells the parables of the lost sheep, lost coin and the lost son.

Father help me to loose my life. Bible in a year reading plan Ezekiel 9-12
title: Jesus’ rebuke of Peter. Part 4
study_refs: So how do we become cross bearers?

html:
After speaking about loosing your life in order to find it Jesus goes on to say, 'What good will it be for a man if he gains the whole world, yet forfeits his soul.' Every time I have heard this verse spoken on, it has always been applied to people who are not Christians. As we have said, Jesus is primarily addressing his disciples. So how are we to understand what Jesus is saying here?

I think Jesus is using what I would call 'ironic hyperbole.' What do I mean? Jesus is saying something like this. 'If you were to gain the whole world, and everything that is in the world, and forfeit your life, your soul, and avoid your cross and the purposes of God for your life, then you will gain nothing.' In reality we all forfeit our life for a lot less. How you may ask? By not taking up our cross'

In Matthew 16:26 the word "Forfeit" Greek zemioo, which originally meant, 'to disadvantage.' Its meaning extends to "suffer damage or loss, forfeit, sustain injury. The word is found 339 other times in the New Testament, and never refers to eternal destruction. So when Jesus speaks about 'forfeiting our lives in this context. He is not speaking about eternal judgement, but rather the self-harm we inflict upon ourselves when we refuse the way of the cross, for an easier option.

Why is it essential that we find life by loosing it? If our mindset is the antithesis to the way of the cross, then we will never be ourselves. A book from years ago by John Powell, had the title: Why Am I Afraid to Tell You Who I Am? An answer given: 'I am afraid to tell you who l am, because, if I tell you who I am, you may not like who I am, and it's all that I have.' So, rather than risk being hurt, we don't tell others who we are. Trying to protect and save self from pain, we lose self. We pretend. We become hypocrites. We wear masks and build walls to protect ourselves. But if we have 'taken up our cross.' then we will not feel so easily threatened or intimidated. We will feel so secure, that we will be able to live out our lives in loving abandonment for the sake of others, which is the way of the cross.

Jesus concludes his teaching on taking up your cross with the words 'For the Son of Man is going to come in his Father's glory with his angels and then he will reward each person according to what he has done.’ If we were to compare this verse with Mark's you will notice that Mark refers to people being ashamed of Jesus. See Mark 8:38 ’If anyone is ashamed of me and my words in this adulterous and sinful generation, the Son of Man will be ashamed of them when he comes in his Father’s glory with the holy angels.’ This is both a warning and a promise. For those trying to save their own lives and to feather their own nests, it is a warning. For those willing to lose their lives for Jesus' sake, it is a promise. Matthew 25:31-46 expands the picture to let us know that we will be judged according to our deeds of mercy to the needy. We learn elsewhere that we are saved by grace through faith, but Jesus makes it clear in these two passages that our faith must manifest itself in good work.

The Greek word for ashamed epaischunomai is a vivid word in Greek, which literally mean to be appallingly embarrassed by a disfigurement. What Jesus is saying here is very powerful, when it comes to your discipleship, your deeds will either be motivated by the cross, or you will too ashamed to carry the cross. Sometimes we withhold from others and we don't stand up for justice and righteousness, in case people think less of us. Shame will prevent a person from carrying his cross. Shame will cause a person to be selfish. The shame that prevent us from carrying our cross is in reality shame about Jesus.

Father I acknowledge I can’t be the person I am meant to be without carrying my cross.

title: Jesus’ rebuke of Peter. Part 5
study_refs: You will have riqht priorities

html:
Of all the people in the bible Jesus knows the Holy Spirit better than anyone else. People can let on they know someone, sometimes people love to drop names and give the impression that they are bosom buddies with someone. But Jesus really knows and understands who the Holy Spirit is.

Jesus taught most about the Holy Spirit just before he died. During the upper room discourse before he died Jesus had some very important things to say to his disciples. The main topic of his conversation was the Holy Spirit. Jesus did not give them a strategy or a five-year plan, or a number of church building programs, but a lesson on the person and work of the Spirit. If you were to read chapters 14-16 there are about 24 direct and indirect references to the Holy Spirit.

In these last words of Jesus, he introduces us to two new names for the Holy Spirit, Advocate/comforter 14:16:26 15:26, 16:7 and the Spirit of truth John 14:17, 15:26, and 16;13. This is the first time in the bible that the Holy Spirit is given these names. Jesus knew that those who were going to live for him would continually need to experience these two characteristics of the Spirit. When you stand back and think about it, for Jesus to emphasize the Holy Spirit as being the comforter and the Spirit of truth at this time may seem a bit strange. Jesus was going to leave them, he was going to commit to them His vision and mission, so why not talk to them about the power of the Holy Spirit, or the sovereignty and control of the Spirit? Surely there must be a better way to empower people than using comfort and truth?

Let us try and see why Jesus may have introduced us to these two characteristics of the Spirit at this time.

The Spirit of truth encourages integrity. The word that Greeks use for truth was made up of two words aletheia, ‘a’ [no, not] and ‘lanthano’ meaning hidden or secret. So the word means ‘the state of not being hidden, factually or reality. So at a very basic level the work of the Holy Spirit in our lives generates reality. It will not allow us to pretend, to hide behind a mask but will lead us into authenticity.

Mask wearing is suffocating; it prevents the real you from breathing. Keeping things hidden is exhausting, you focus is on your reputation and how you are perceived by others, so how you are in church and how you are in the rest of your life is inconsistent. So when the Spirit of truth works in our lives he ‘un-hides,’ the hidden. He exposes the buried; he guides us into the ‘painful truth of reality.’

Father thank you that the Holy Spirit wants to rip of our masks.

Bible in a year: Ezekiel 16:44-20:17
title: Enjoying the Spirit of God. part 1
study_refs: As we grow in our faith it’s important that we become aware of the working of the Holy Spirit in our lives. It’s hard to be the people God’s wants us to be, or do the things God wants us to do without the ongoing changing work of the Holy Spirit in our lives. Or to say it another way, it’s more important that we depend on the Holy Spirit than it is to depend on the talents, abilities, vision strength and opportunities that God gives us. So we need to have some kind of understanding of the Spirit. So I thought it would be good to think about what Jesus said about the Holy Spirit. There are a number of good reasons for doing this.

html:
The truth is, Jesus is the ultimate ‘truth experience’ every man, woman and child needs to know, and this ‘truth experience’ is only realized when the Spirit guides us into all truth. So the Holy Spirit wants to make Jesus a permanent reality to us. I cannot think of anything more wonderful than knowledge of the reality of Jesus.

Integrity and intimacy are linked. Have you ever gone up to someone you wanted a better friendship/relationship with and say something like. ‘I would really love to get to know you better, so in order for that to happen why don’t we become more superficial, let’s pretend, and not be real and ensure that we keep our masks on;, avoid the truth and that will help us to know each other better.’ We would never say that, but that is often how we treat each other. But even more seriously is this, our lack of integrity with others affects our intimacy with Jesus.

Would you befriend someone who was unreal? Someone who was always putting on a performance? Would you share your heart and life with someone who you knew was always wearing a persona to hide his or her true thoughts and feelings from others, someone who has no interest in genuine relationships? Of course not. Do you think Jesus would like a relationship with that kind of person? Someone who is not real, someone who is always pretending?

Jesus loves broken sinful people, but he has very little time for people who are unreal and will not be honest about themselves. Jesus loves reality. The Spirit of truth comes to expose the hidden, and in doing so makes us more open to receive a true experience of Jesus. It is sad to think that the masks many Christians wear are the masks that blind them from really seeing Jesus.

The Holy Spirit will guide us into all truth. It would be very easy for us to miss the impact of this statement. The word guide is used only five times in the New Testament, twice in the writings of John, and only here in his gospel. I don’t think we really consider guidance into truth as being a priority. I think we would rather be guided into some kind of plan or purpose than be guided into truth; truth about ourselves and truth about God. Let me try and make this more practical. Can you think of a truth that God has helped you to understand? One that has led you to make changes in how you live and what you live for? The path God guides us on will include God’s plans and purposes, but his plans and purposes are not his priority. His priority is to lead us into truth so we can be transformed for intimacy with him.

Father thank you that to be guided into truth is more important than to be guided into your plans. Bible in a year reading plan Ezekiel 20:18-22:12
title: E njoying the Spirit of God. part 2
study_refs: The Spirit of truth encourages intimacy. Look at what Jesus said, ‘ He will glorify me because it is from me that he will receive what he will make known to you.’ In other words the Holy Spirit makes the truth about Jesus a reality. As the Holy Spirit works in our lives Jesus will become more real to us, and the things that are important to Jesus will become important to us.

html:
As Jesus spoke his last words to his disciples he knew that they would be feeling very frightened and insecure so he knew that they would need to know the ongoing help of the Spirit to encourage them to live in truth about themselves and about God. The way the Spirit helps us is that He draws close to us bringing assurance and hope and gives us courage to face the things we want to run from and hide.

Father thank you that the Spirit who confronts with the truth is the same Spirit who comforts us. Bible in a year reading plan Ezekiel 22:13-24:27
title: Enjoying the Spirit of God. part 3
study_refs: The second new name Jesus gives to the Holy Spirit is parakletos. There has been a lot of debate about why Jesus used this word to describe the Holy Spirit at this time? Paraklētos is variously translated as the "Comforter" (KJV), "Counsellor" (NIV, RSV), "Advocate" (NRSV), "Helper" (ESV). It can't be easly translated into English with one word that adequately covers its breadth of meaning. But there is a question that might help us understand this ministry of the Spirit.

When we have to face painful truths about ourselves, and demanding life- changing truths about God, what do we need? When we are wrestling with uncomfortable truth about ourselves we need comfort. When we are struggling with demanding truth that God has brought into our lives that will require sacrifice and change, we need help. When truth challenges our ‘status quo’ we need counsel. The parakletos is God personally assisting us through the ministry of the Holy Spirit to come to terms with the truth and live with its consequences

html:
One of the best known parts of the bible is what people call the ‘Sermon on the Mount’ which is recorded in Matthew 5-7. Much has been written and said about the Sermon on the Mount. I think the best way to understand it is to see it as Jesus giving us an extended, redefined understanding of righteousness. In the Sermon, Jesus describes for us what true righteousness is like.

When we hear the word ‘righteousness’ which is the word Matthew uses for holiness we don’t often get very excited. The word ‘righteousness’ is not famous for being a ‘buzz’ word, it not considered cool. We are not the kind of people to get thrilled or animated about living a righteous life. We have been brought up to think that living a righteous life, is a call to joyless boredom and serious demeanour, which is so far removed for the bibles understanding of righteousness.

The word for righteousness is from the Greek word dikaiosyne which in the broad sense describes a person who is as he ought to be, i.e. discovering his/her full potential. It also carries the idea of justice, integrity, virtue, purity of life, rightness, correctness of thinking feeling, and acting. We need to think of righteousness as something that is extremely positive and desirable. It could be described as a wholesome mature character. We are going to look at how Jesus redefined righteousness and painted it in bright attractive colours.

Jesus’ ‘new take’ on righteousness.

Righteousness requires an internal passion.

We must approach to issue of righteousness with passionate hearts. Look and how Jesus describes how we should engage with righteousness. “Blessed are those who hunger and thirst for righteousness.” Matt 5:6. “But seek first the kingdom of God and his righteousness.” Matt 6:33.

We need to develop an energetic and enthusiastic relationship with righteousness, we need to passionately love and enjoy it. We need motivating appetites for righteous living. We need to have a positive emotional relationship with righteousness. Negative emotions such as guilt or shame cannot lead to a righteous life.

Righteousness is satisfying

In hungering for righteousness we are making a very strong statement, we are refusing to accept or settle for the mediocre or the boring. We are acknowledging that we have the potential to live full and satisfying lives. We are expressing a legitimate need of our hearts. We have been made in such a way that righteous living is extremely satisfying and enhancing. Jesus said “Blessed are they that hunger and thirst for righteousness for they shall be filled.’’ The word filled ‘chortazo’ and it means to eat till one is full.

Righteous living will mean that we will guard our hearts and continually monitor their condition. If you read Matthew chapter five carefully you will notice that Jesus mentions, murder, adultery, divorce and oaths. The Pharisees of Jesus’ day prided themselves in keeping the law, now what they understood by keeping the law was that they never did the physical act. They had never physically murdered someone, or physically slept with another man’s wife. The point that Jesus makes in this passage is, if we have anger or lust in our hearts then we are as guilty as the actual murderer or adulterer. We are inclined to categorise sin, we think of wee sins, and big sins. That is like categorising cyanide. Is a little cyanide only a little harmful, or is it just as dangerous as a lot of cyanide. Jesus was very clear, he said “Unless your righteousness surpasses that of the Pharisees and the teachers of the law you will certainly not enter the kingdom of heaven.’’ The Pharisees kept the law exactly and meticulously, however, in their hearts they we full of anger, lust and greed.

Righteous living is not about appearance, or about ticking boxes, or about fulfilling the expectations of others, rather is about the conditions of our hearts and what we carry in them.

Father thank you we have been designed to love and enjoy righteousness.

Bible in a year: Ezekiel 25:1-28:10
title: Study topic Loving righteousness Part 1

html:
Righteousness is expressed in whole hearted commitment,

In Matthew 5:48 Jesus said “Be perfect therefore, as your heavenly Father is perfect. Many read these words and think Jesus is asking us to live sinless lives. However, the word Perfect (teleios) does not mean sinless perfection, but wholeheartedness and stands for total commitment. Righteous living will encourage whole hearted commitment to Jesus.

Righteous living means that we won’t have to perform in order to gain acceptance or approval. One of the things that Jesus does in the Sermon of the Mount is He contrasts authentic God pleasing righteousness with the phony, external righteousness of His day. The Pharisees craved for the acceptance and approval of others, and this became their motivation for doing ‘spiritual’ things like ‘giving to the poor, praying and fasting.’ They practice spiritual disciplines without having a heart for God. They were hypocrites. It is important we understand what the bible means when it talks about hypocrites.

‘‘A hypocrite is not a person who falls short of their high ideas or occasionally sins, because all Christians experience these failures. A hypocrite deliberately uses religion to cover up their sins and promote their own gains.” Warren W. Wiersbe. Source unknown

So to be a hypocrite is much more serious than living an inconsistent life, it is the deliberate use of religious activity to deceive others and hide your own sin and failure in order to promote a false image about yourself, in order to get the approval of others.

Righteousness will produce in us a sense of security and well being. Righteousness results in a person feeling secure and loved, it enhances us as people. It is so easy because of our feelings of insecurity to pervert our religious activity into religious showmanship. It is our insecurities that cause us to live for the approval of others.

“Ultimately our only reason for pleasing men around us is that we may please ourselves. Our real desire is not to please others as such; we want to please them because we know that, if we do, they will think better of us. In other words, we are pleasing ourselves and are merely concerned about self-gratification.” Lloyd Jones.

https://www.kingschurchlkld.com/sermon/righteousnessrewardandhypocrisy. Accessed 31/07/25

Doing spiritual “things” is not a guarantee or proof that we are spiritual people. Our desire for acceptance, approval and recognition from others can turn our spiritual activities and Christian service into expressions of selfishness and self-centredness devoid of any authentic righteousness. What we are in private, where no one sees us is who we really are.

So many Christians are too tired to live righteous lives. I have meet so many Christians who are completely exhausted, for years they have been trying to keep up a façade, trying to win the approval and acceptance of others, trying to fit in, trying to earn God’s love and blessing. This way of living has robbed them of passion and enthusiasm, their spark has gone, their colour has faded, and all they have is a reputation, a reputation for being ‘committed,’ a reputation that is not really worth having.

Righteous living is really just an appropriate response to the love of God or Father. Twelve times in Matthew six Jesus mentions the word Father. This is quite amazing. Jesus did not give us a list of rules, or ‘doe’s’ or ‘don't s’ rather he talks a lot about God as father. Look a Matthew 6:1, 4,6x2, 8, 9, 14, 15, 18x2, 26, and 32. Authentic righteousness is the result of being in a relationship with God as your father

For too long w have lived with the idea that to be holy or righteous is a drab and boring life. This is a distortion of the truth. Those who receive and enjoy God’s love and experience Him as Father will know the joy and freedom of living a life of righteousness.

Father may the joy of righteousness fill my life

html:
As we begin to look at spiritual formation, we need to start at the right place, we need to try and understand God’s original intention. Very often when it comes to understanding who we are, and the reason for our existence we start at the wrong place. Often we view mankind through the lens of sin. We have what I would call a ‘sin filter,’ So we view people primarily as ’sinners’ who need salvation. Now all that is absolutely true. However, if we make sin the starting designation point by which we are going to understand others or ourselves, then we are going to misunderstand what it means to be a person. And be unable to grasp the wholeness that spiritual formation can bring. The best way for us to honestly recognise sin in our lives is to realise that sin should not define us. Imagine you had a sickness or some kind of disability, would you like that to become the thing that defines you. Or would want to be seen as someone who was more that a ‘sickness,’ or a ‘disability?’

We need to start where the bible starts. We need to root our understanding of who we are in the creation story and use the definition it uses. When God created mankind on the sixth day of creation, he expressed his intention for His creation of mankind.

Genesis 1:26 reads, Then God said, “Let us make human beings in our image, to be like us. They will reign over the fish in the sea, the birds in the sky, the livestock, all the wild animals on the earth, and the small animals that scurry along the ground.” So God created human beings in his own image. In the image of God he created them; male and female he created them.

The phrase ‘image of God’ is the first description of man, it is the first defining statement of humanity. ‘Image of God’ expresses the essence, purpose and potential of our humanity. ‘image of God,’ encapsulates God’s good desire for you as a person and God’s will for your life. This initial defining designation by God over the creation of man is ultimate in nature, it cannot be improved or bettered. I think we find it difficult to grasp the weight of what it means to be made in the image of God. So how are we to understand what it means in the image of God? To help us understand what being made in the image means, we need to first ask the question, what did it mean to the original people who heard or read what Moses wrote in his record of creation?

Father thank you that you you have always seen us much more than people who are defined by sin

html:
Understanding Eden.

If you were to ask most Christians what they knew about the garden of Eden you would probable get an answer something like ‘Eden was a garden where Good placed Adam and Eve.’ That would be true, but incomplete. If I were to say to you that a television was a box that sits in the corner of the room. I would be telling the truth, but be saying nothing that would communicate what a television was. It’s the same with the garden of Eden. The garden of Eden needs to be understood as a sacred spaced, as holy ground.

Notice that the creation story is told in a period of seven days. This is significant! In the ancient Israelites’ world, temples were always dedicated with a seven-day ceremony. This was true not only of the Israelites’ temple built for their God), but also of neighbouring nations’ temples which they raised for their deities. This ritual was so deeply ingrained in ancient culture that the Israelites would have immediately understood a seven-day creation story to mean that creation itself was a temple for their God.

The Garden as the unique place of God’s presence. Eden was the place where God walked back and forth with man, paralleled this with later references to the Tabernacle (Gen. 3:8 with Lev. 26:12, Deut. 23:14; 2 Sam. 7:6–7).

Ezekiel’s view of the Garden of Eden as the first sanctuary. In Ezekiel 28:13–18 the prophet draws a number of parallels between Eden and Israel’s tabernacle/temple. Specifically, the prophet references Eden as a sanctuary and pictures Adam dressed as a priest (v. 13). And “Ezekiel 28:18 is probably, therefore, the most explicit place anywhere in canonical literature where the Garden of Eden is called a temple” Genesis 2:15 says God placed Adam in the Garden ‘to cultivate (i.e., work] it and to keep it.’ The two Hebrew words for ‘cultivate and keep’ are usually translated ‘serve and guard [or keep]’ elsewhere in the Old Testament. It is true that the Hebrew word usually translated ‘cultivate’ can refer to an agricultural task when used by itself… When, however, these two words…occur together in the Old Testament…, they refer either to Israelites ‘serving’ God and ‘guarding [keeping]’ God’s word…or to priests who ‘keep’ the ‘service’ (or ‘charge’) of the tabernacle (see Num. 3:7-8; 8:25-26; 18:5-6; 1 Chr. 23:32; Ezek. 44:14).

Before we move on let us think about this. God originally place mankind in a sacred space, a place were they were able to worship God and have fellowship with him. We have been designed for ’temple life.’ to find our life through worship.

“God’s purpose in creating Adam and Eve is summed up in what they could do for God that nothing else in the whole creation could do. They had an exclusive on God shared by no other of God’s creation.”
A.W. Tozer, https://www.goodreads.com/work/quotes/6270565-the-purpose-of-man-designed-to-worship. Accessed 22/05/2025

Listen to these words by C.S.Lewis

I think we delight to praise what we enjoy because the praise not merely expresses but completes the enjoyment; it is its appointed consummation. It is not out of compliment that lovers keep on telling one another how beautiful they are; the delight is incomplete till it is expressed… If it were possible for a created soul fully… to “appreciate”, that is to love and delight in, the worthiest object of all, and simultaneously at every moment to give this delight perfect expression, then that soul would be in supreme beatitude… The Scotch catechism says that man’s chief end is “to glorify God and enjoy Him forever”. But we shall then know that these are the same thing. Fully to enjoy is to glorify. In commanding us to glorify Him, God is inviting us to enjoy Him.’ https://www.goodreads.com/quotes/799916-i-think-we-delight-to-praise-what-we-enjoy-because. Accessed 22/05/2025

Have you ever thought what your life would be like if you had never, or couldn't worship God? We all worship something, and I am incline to think that everything else apart from God that we worship, in really an expression of self love.

The Ancient Near Eastern concept of temples in association with garden-like features. Gardens not untypically were part of temple complexes in the Ancient Near East” It was the custom to put an idol or image of their god in the temple as a representation of that god. The image of the god within the temple said that god was present. Image of God was also a title used for kings in ancient culture, the were understood as God’s representative on earth, this is why the kings of Egypt and Babylon were seen as being deified. Rulers could not be everywhere at once, and travel was slow. So, they would erect monuments or statues of themselves throughout their kingdoms. These “images” let everyone know that the king’s rule extended wherever his image was found. so in these cultures to be recognised as the image of God you had to be a very special and unique person.

Imagine the impact on the Hebrews slaves who had been rescued from Egypt when they heard what Moses wrote in Genesis 1, that they were made in the image of God. This was a title given to the Pharaoh. A Pharaoh who was strong, powerful, possessing authority. Yes, we can see why he would referred to as the image of God. But a broken, weak, despised slave, there is no way they could be considered as God’s image.

Father thank you no matter what others think about us, or what we think about ourselves we have been made in the Image of God.’

html:
How are we to understand the image of God?

Image of God is not something you have, it is something much more profound, it is something you are, something you have been made into, it is the very essence of who we are. Their has been a lot of debate as to what the term actually means, this debate has caused much confusion and I think has added to a lack of understanding about who we are.

Most Christians believe in what is known as the substantive view of the image of God, which means we are spiritually and physiologically similar to God. So God is rational, creative, he is moral knowing the difference between right and wrong. He has the ability to choose good or bad. unlike all other creatures human kind have these qualities to a greater degree. This sounds very reasonable. However, there are a number of problems with this understanding.

a. Some animals can be rational Cameron Buckner, assistant professor of philosophy at the University of Houston, argues in an article published in Philosophy and Phenomenological Research that a wide range of animal species exhibit so-called “executive control” when it comes to making decisions, consciously considering their goals and ways to satisfy those goals before acting. He acknowledges that language is required for some sophisticated forms of meta cognition, or thinking about thinking. But bolstered by a review of previously published research, Buckner concludes that a wide variety of animals – elephants, chimpanzees, ravens and lions, among others – engage in rational decision-making.

b. Can animals be moral? Eleanor, the matriarch of her family, is dying and unable to stand. Grace manages to lift her to her feet. She tries to get Eleanor to walk, pushing her gently along. But Eleanor falls again. Grace appears very distressed, and shrieks loudly. She persists in trying to get Eleanor to stand, unsuccessfully. Grace stays by the fallen figure of Eleanor for another hour, while night falls. If Grace were human, we might have little hesitation in attributing to her an emotion of a certain sort: compassion or sympathy. But neither Grace nor Eleanor is human. Eleanor is the matriarch of the First Ladies family of elephants. Grace is a younger member of another family of elephants.

Ian Douglas Hamilton, Bhalla, S., Wittemyer, G. & Vollrath, F., “Behavioural Reactions of Elephants Towards a Dying and Deceased Matriarch.” Applied Animal Behaviour Science 100, (2006), 67-102.

c. Satan, demons and angels, are creative, are moral, knowing the difference between right and wrong. And have the ability to choose good or bad. Does that mean they are created in the image of God?

d. What about people who are cognitively impaired. Those who have intellectual disabilities and restricted in the capacity to reason or do not have the necessary moral facilities to build relationships are they less than human. Are they not created in the image of God. That is what Hitler believed, so he had death camps build to exterminate non Aryan’s, not only Jews, but those with physical and mental disabilities.

Hitler set up a committee of physicians to prepare for the murder of mentally and physically disabled children. Known as the Reich Committee for the Scientific Treatment of Severe Hereditary and Congenital Diseases, the group was told to keep its mission secret. In August 1939, committee members asked doctors and midwives to fill out a questionnaire that would identify children born with various deformities or disabilities. Initially, the focus was on children under the age of three. The committee claimed it was using the information “to clarify certain scientific questions.” In fact, it was used to determine which children would be allowed to live. The committee relied entirely on the questionnaires in making its decisions. Members did not examine a single child, consult with other physicians, or speak to the families involved. Once a decision was made, the committee told the child’s parents only that their baby was being placed in a special hospital to “improve” treatment. There, death came quickly. After the war, a physician involved in the program told Robert Jay Lifton, an American psychiatrist, “According to the thinking of that time, in the case of children, killing seemed somehow justifiable whereas in the case of the adult mentally ill, that was definitely murder.” ‘Unworthy to live,’’ Holocaust and human behaviour. Chapter 8. Facinghistory.org

5. In the creation story and the rest of the Hebrew bible there are many similarities between mankind and the rest of the animal kingdom.

9:10,15.

Animals Genesis 41:2-19,

Exodus 21:28

These similarities means that it is important that we have a proper understanding of what it means to be made in God’s image, because the image of God is the thing that ultimately defines us from the rest of creation .

Father thank you that being made in your image is a lot more than having moral capacities Bible in a year reading plan Ezekiel 38:10-40:49

html:
So How are we to understand the image of God?

1. The image of God explains God’s purpose and our function. When we read the Genesis account of creation we are incline to think more about the ‘from’ of creation rather than the ‘for’ The Hebrew word ‘bara,’ create is more concerned about the ‘for,’ the purpose, the reason. God made us in his image so we can become like Jesus. In the New Testament Jesus is referred to as the Image of God.

Colossians 1:15
Verse
He is the image of the invisible God, the firstborn of all creation.

2 Corinthians 4:4
Verse
in whose case the god of this world has blinded the minds of the unbelieving so that they might not see the light of the gospel of the glory of Christ, who is the image of God.

Hebrews 1:3
Verse
And He is the radiance of His glory and the exact representation of His nature, and upholds all things by the word of His power. When He had made purification of sins, He sat down at the right hand of the Majesty on high,

‘Christ as the image of God is a reflection of God that demonstrates God’s intentions for all humanity. Christ illustrates God’s purposes and goals for humanity, Christ demonstrates who people can be. You could say that being created in the image of God give us the opportunity to reflect Jesus’ relationships with His father and with others. The image of God in you gives you the potential of having an intimate relationship with God. The image of God expresses God’s ultimate desire for our lives and our greatest need.

2. A proper understanding of the image of God will determine how we treat others. If God created humans in His image, and every life has value, then we cannot ignore those trapped in poverty, trafficking, or homelessness. We cannot ignore the widow or the orphan who bears the image of God. As image bearers of God—protector of strangers and helper of the fatherless and the widow (Ps. 146:9)

Has God not told us …

“Open your hand willingly to your poor and needy brother in your land” (Deut 15:11).

“Speak up for those who have no voice, for the justice of all who are dispossessed. Speak up, judge righteously, and defend the cause of the oppressed and needy” (Prov. 31:8-9).

“Pursue justice. Correct the oppressor. Defend the rights of the fatherless. Plead the widow’s cause” (Isa. 1:17).

Jesus taught that our response to the least of this world is in some measure an indication of the validity of the relationship with profess to have with Him. (See Matt. 25:35-45.

“I see Jesus in every human being. I say to myself, this is hungry Jesus, I must feed him. This is sick Jesus. This one has leprosy or gangrene; I must wash him and tend to him. I serve because I love Jesus.”―Mother Teresa

Seeing others as people created in the image of God will cause you to treat them with dignity and respect, when others see you as someone created in the image of God they will treat you with dignity and respect.

So often the church has abandoned this perspective. We allow people’s sin and failure to define them. The best way to understand an other person sinfulness and the effect it has on their lives is to firstly view them as people made in the image of God. It is important that we understand that no one’s sin has any ability to devalue them. For example if you were to get a coin with the kings head on it, if the image of the kings head was faded, our even difficult to make out. Would that mean that particulate coin had lost some of it’s value? No of course not. Sin may diminish or fade the image of God in someone, but it will never eradicate it, or make that person less valuable. When Jesus looked upon the crowds he had compassion on them and seen them as sheep without a shepherd. Matthew 9:36. Not as lost sinners who deserved to be condemned.

According to James 3:9 to curse a person who is made in the image of God is wrong. Cursing people is the same as cursing God. When we damage and dishonour people we are doing the same to God. Conversely, treating people well honours God. If dishonouring and mistreating people is an attack on God it is not surprising that Satan under the guise of the serpent attacked and deceived Adam and Eve.

If we were to take a step back, and think about people in our lives who have caused us pain. No matter how we feel about these people, their wrong treatment of you/me doest not make them any less the image of God.

Father thank you a persons sin cannot rob them of value Bible in a year reading plan Ezekiel 41-43

html:
Seeing ourselves being created in the image of God will determine how we accept and understand ourself. In our culture identity has never been more fluid or unstable. Increasingly people do not know who they are or what their lives are about. So for most people life is defined by the ‘idolatry of self.’ when we move away from the creators original intention, making our lives and our world into our image. We begin to harvest a crop of insecurities, anxieties and self loathing.

Awareness of being created to be an image bearer of God will prevent us from selfishly making our lives about us. It will enable us to live for someone and something bigger than ourselves. Living to reflect God to the world will enable us to live as someone not as something. We need to train ourselves to think differently about God’s will for our lives. The focus of our lives is to bear God’s image, reflect his glory. The biblical word for this is holiness. ‘Long ago even before he made the world, God loved us and choose in Christ to be holy and without fault in his eyes.’ Ephesians 1:4. This verse blows me away. Imagine God choose us before the creation of the world to be holy. What a mind blowing truth If we think the will of God for our lives is about searching for some special individual plan then we will miss it. God plan for all our lives is that we become defined by his image so we can authentically reflect him.

Father thank you that the call to live a holy is the very essence of your will for our lives

title: Study theme Spiritual formation [the process of becoming like Jesus] part 5

html:
One of the problems when it comes to our Christian experience is that we have created a filter through which we misunderstand or misinterpret terms that we use. For example if we were to ask you what you think and feel about holiness? Most people would think, ‘Well it is something we have to do, but we get don’t too excited about it.’ Yet four times in the Old Testament 1Chron 16:29, 2Chron 20:21, Psalm 29:2, 96:9, and in Hebrews 13:18, KJV we are told to ‘Worship the Lord in the beauty of holiness.’

The Hebrew word for beauty [hadara] was a word used to describe clothing that spoke of honour, majesty or glory.

You could say that holiness is the opposite of toxic shame. Holiness brings a sense of well-being and wholeness to a person.

We are however, continually tempted to live out of misunderstanding or our misrepresentation's of holiness to such an extent that we don’t know how to pursue it.

This means that we try other ways to cover our shame. For example, some people feel the need to continually talk about themselves. Or they have a desire to prove themselves, try desperately to medicate the deep sense of shame or self loathing they may feel. However, for the follower of Jesus, the only authentic cure for a life full of toxic shame is growth in holiness.

We are repeatedly told ‘Be holy for I am holy.’ see Leviticus 11:44, 11:45, 19:2, 20:26, 1 Peter 1:16. This reference is important for our understanding of holiness. 1 Peter is a letter from Peter to the believers who had been dispersed throughout the ancient world and who were under intense persecution. Peter wanted to comfort and encourage them. So one of the ways he does that is he tell them to be holy.

Try to put yourself in a situation where you are really struggling and life is not easy and a friend comes along and one of the things they say to you is ‘be holy.’ I reckon most of us would have a negative reaction to this. However, there are reasons why this was great advice from Peter.

To be holy means that you have been set apart for God.

We have all experienced what it is like not to be picked for something, to be left on the side lines. To be holy is the recognition that God has chosen you for himself. Listen to these mind blowing words. ‘Even before he made the world. God chose us in Christ to be holy and without blame in his eyes.’ Ephesians 1:4. I think this verse is amazing. Before God made the universe his big plan for our lives is that we be holy.

If we are under great pressure, how is the fact that we have been chosen by God going to make you feel?

To be holy means that you will have the moral resources to respond correctly to the pressure you will face.

Many Christians face unbearable heart breaking situations, and for some it is too much and sadly they feel they have no choice but to walk away from God and their faith. We must never judge or condemn these people, but we must ensure that we ourselves are growing in holiness, because we do not know what trials and temptations we may have to face in the future. It is by growing in holiness that we will be better equipped to cope with them. to be holy is how we protect our identity and lives as authentic human beings.

Very often when living under stressful circumstances we are inclined to make compromises. We cease to be the people God wants us to be, and we can develop a victim mindset, allowing the pain of life to define us. Being created in the image of God means that moral beauty of holiness needs to define us.

You could even say that the word holy sums up all of God’s intentions and plans for your life. Growing in holiness is how we discover the potential of being made in the image of God. And yet we don’t know how to be enthusiastic about it or enjoy holiness. When we do not associate holiness with joy, or beauty or abundant life, it will not become a priority.

But I think that there is an even more serious misunderstanding or misinterpretation when it comes to our Christian experience. If we were to ask what does it mean to become like Jesus, to really reflect the image of God, what would you say? Most people would answer that question by talking about the fruit of the Spirit, or talk about Jesus’ love, compassion and sacrifice.

Rick warren wrote ‘Becoming like Christ does not mean losing your personality or becoming a mindless clone. God created your uniqueness, so He certainly doesn’t want to destroy it. Christ likeness is all about transforming your character, not your personality. God wants you to develop the kind of character described in the beatitudes of Jesus (Matthew 5:1-12), the fruit of the Spirit (Galatians 5:22-23), Paul’s great chapter on love (1 Corinthians 13), and Peter’s list of the characteristics of an effective and productive life (2 Peter 1:5-8).’ The Purpose Driven Life (Zondervan, 2002) pp. 171-173.

Rick warren is absolutely correct, however, I think this is an incomplete or an insufficient understanding of what it means to be like Jesus. Sometimes we think that to become like Jesus is all about behaviour modification. When we become Christians there should be a radical change in how we behave. And yet, I know some people who would not claim to be a follower of Jesus, yet they are kind, loving and compassionate. Sometimes their behaviour and way of life is better than some Christians.

So to be like Jesus is much more than a transformation of our behaviour or lifestyle. Jesus behaved and lived the way he did because of his ‘attitude’ or the condition of his heart. The essence of Jesus’ life was cruciformity. Cruciformity is having a life that is continually being shaped by the attitudes that enabled Jesus to go to the cross. Or to put it an other way, authentic spiritual formation demands that our lives are shaped by the cross we are called to carry just as much as Jesus’ life was shaped by the cross he had to carry.

When Jesus tells us to take up our cross and follow him, he is asking us to think like him, he is inviting us to adopt his world-view. You can see why being like Jesus is much more that having a change in behaviour, even if that change is radical.

“Faith is an inauguration into a community and into a life of dying, or cruciformity.”Michael J. Gorman, Cruciformity

Father may the essence of my being be reshaped by holiness.

html:
So what is cruciformity? What does it mean to develop a cross-shaped life?

To answer that question let us look at Philippians 2:5-11.

This is is a wonderful passage of scripture, and before we look at it we need to say a few things.

1. This is a passage full of heavy, mind blowing theology, and it could be judged by us as great literature with no practical relevance to our lives. This could not be further from the truth.

As children of God, we need to know the mind of Christ just as much as He did. Having the same attitude as Jesus is not a luxury, but an essential requirement for the life God wants us to live. Having the same attitude as Jesus is equivalent to loving God with our minds.

2.The mindset that enabled Jesus to come to earth and die on a cross should shape and define us as people. We are made in such a way that we have a God-given need to experience the defining qualities of the mind of Jesus. Having the same mind as Jesus will enable us to carry our cross. If I am not thinking the way Jesus thinks then I will avoid carrying my cross.

3.To have the same attitude as Jesus does not require great intellect, theological knowledge or a capacity to understand everything, but it does require that our hearts embrace the same attitudes of Jesus.

The word attitude actually means a settled way of thinking; it is arrived at after careful thought. Originally the word attitude was a technical term in art for the posture of a figure in a statue or painting. So having the attitude of Jesus needs to become a fixed way of thinking.

4. The immediate context lets us know, that the specific attitude or mindset Paul is speaking about, is having a humble love for others.

Let us try and grasp the mindset that directed Jesus’ life and destiny, and discover what it means to love God with our minds.

This passage has caused a lot of discussion and there are a lot of technical things that I am not qualified to go into. However there are a number of principles that we can learn and apply to our lives.

a. Jesus was prepared to let go.

‘Who being in the very nature God did not consider equality with God something to be grasped.’

This simply means He did not think of his status as something to be clung to or grasped. The Greek word harpagmos, (grasped) which means "to snatch, or to clutch, to take hold of or to keep hold of. The word refers to something that a person has in their possession but chooses not to use to their own advantage. Jesus did not feel the need to hold on to his position, power, or prestige. He did not get his security from being in a place of prominence or authority, but from his relationship with his father. The implications of having this mindset are enormous.

Every time we feel a need to hold onto a position of power, or every time we feel a need to be seen to be in control in order to feel secure and fulfilled, we are opposing the attitudes that brought Jesus to earth and to the cross. Every time we demand our ‘rights’ and insist that our value as a person is related to some legitimate position we may have, we display a mindset that is the exact opposite to the mind of Christ.

We have all known or experienced people who can’t move on, who can’t step down. They may be involved in a church, or a ministry, or even in their job. And they are grasping to their position because it has become their source of identity and significance. They are unable and unwilling to let go.

As we have said the word harpagmos carries the idea of keeping hold of something, but, it has a second meaning that may deepen our understanding. The word was used to describe something seized through robbery. When a thief steals something, their focus is usually on themselves, with no or little regard for others. This is the same heart attitude of someone who is unable or unwilling to let go of a position of of prestige.

People in Christian ministry can live with an inflated sense of self-importance and an insatiable drive to be liked and to be at the centre of attention. Satan will capitalize on these traits and tempt them to compromise their morals and values. We need to celebrate that we are dispensable; we thank God that he will never need us, but he will always want us. There needs to be a ‘non grasping’ element in all our lives.

Father deliver me from any grasping or ‘I must have’ attitude

title: Study theme Spiritual formation [The process of becoming like Jesus] part 7

html:
Jesus was prepared to empty himself.

Paul goes on to say that Jesus made himself nothing. "Made himself nothing" (NIV), "made himself of no reputation" (KJV), and "emptied himself" (NRSV) is the Greek verb kenaō, literally, "to make empty, to empty," This phrase has caused much debate, as to what Jesus emptied himself of. I don’t think that is the right question to ask. I think the best way to understand the phrase is to see it as a summation of Jesus’ way of living.

The point Paul wants to make is that Jesus lived a poured out life. As a man, Jesus let go of all self interest; He refused to use his power or glory to gain a reputation. Often when Jesus healed someone, He would say something like “Don’t tell anyone.” He had no interest in making a name for himself.

To empty ourselves does not only mean that we pour out our lives for others in service, rather it means pouring out our life in service for others without some hidden selfish agenda. It is sacrificially giving ourselves solely for the good and benefit of others. As you read about the life of Jesus in the gospels, he was continually pouring out his life. You could say that Jesus was showing us that authentic humanity was expressed though emptying for the sake of others, not fulfilment for our own sakes

Author Leslie Ludy writes:-

‘God has not called us to build our lives around the pursuit of our own selfish desires, but to be poured-out sacrifices for His kingdom...We are proud, focused on self, consumed with our wealth and comforts, we live in an abundance of idleness and shallow pleasure, and we are indifferent to the plight of the needy around the world....our mentalities train us that this life is all about our dreams, our goals, and our ambitions. But that's not true Christianity.("Living A Poured Out Life")

Jesus understood that the only way to live was with the heart of a servant.

Paul chooses a very specific term doulos, to describe how much Jesus emptied himself; the word means “slave” or “bond-servant.”

In other words, Jesus became a particular kind of man, a slave, the lowest position a person could become in the Roman world. Being a doulos involved the losing of one’s own autonomy and the subordination of one’s will to another.

The Greeks felt only revulsion and contempt for the position of a slave. By law the slave was classed with immobile goods, had no rights at law and could not own property. Even his family did not belong to him; he was the property of the master. In Rabbinic literature the word slave constitutes one of the worst insults one man can hurl at another; it was not for nothing that a man might be excommunicated for calling his neighbour a slave”

Johh McAuthur says ‘They had no choice about anything. They owned nothing. They couldn’t be citizens and they couldn’t be a part of the army or the military. They were totally dependent on whoever owned them. It doesn’t mean that they didn’t have some benefits. They were provided for, cared for and protected. In many cases, treated kindly, compassionately, some even loved within families. But to the Greek and the Roman philosophically and socially, freedom was the pinnacle of life. So free men had only scorn for slaves and slaves longed to be free.’ The difference between a slave and a servant in Greek/Roman culture was very stark. Servants were hired workers who were paid. Slaves were not hired but owned. Servants could quit if they desired, a slave could only leave his master after 30 years, if he wanted to. Servants could have more than one job; a slave solely served the interest of his master. This is so counter cultural, having a mindset of a slave. Yet for Jesus it was a natural and honest expression of who he was. For Jesus living a life with the heart of a slave was primarily an expression of deep security. https://www.gty.org/sermons/80-321/slaves-for-christ.

Listen to these words.

’Jesus knew that the Father had put all things under his power, and that he had come from God and was returning to God; so he got up from the meal, took off his outer clothing, and wrapped a towel around his waist.’

In becoming a slave, Jesus was focusing his life; He was saying that as a son, he wanted to live exclusively for the will of his father, like a slave lived for his master. In having the nature of a slave he was permanently binding himself to the purposes of God and the needs of people.

Father thank you there is great freedom in being your slave

Bible in a year: . Daniel 4:28-7:12
title: Study theme Spiritual formation [the process of becoming like Jesus.] part 8

html:
Jesus humbled himself.

Humility is seeing ourselves as God has made us. Accepting who we are and acknowledging that the gifts and talents we have, come from God to be used in service for the good of others.

Often we are unable to live humble lives because we are driven by our insecurities. We want to look strong, to be successful, to have all the answers, to appear competent. However, if we are people who are secure then making humble choices won’t be a problem, you won’t need to be the best, or first, or top of the heap, you will be happy being a periphery person; someone who is secure in their relationship with God will be secure enough to embrace humility.

Humility enhances, dignifies and highlights the glories of being human. For Jesus, humility was not a reaction to pride, or even the opposite of pride, rather it was an authentic expression of his humanity.

When we think about our humanity, usually we make the mistake of starting at the wrong point. We are inclined to see man firstly as a fallen creature that has been shaped by sin. But to really understand our humanity we need to consider man before the fall, we need to think about God’s original intention. The attitudes that shaped the life of Jesus display authentic humanity; they describe what man would have been like before the fall.

Being human is too big a thing and too wonderful a thing to be ultimately defined by sin. To understand who we really are we need to see ourselves as God sees us before the fall, and that is what Jesus wants to show us in his humanity. Having the same attitude as Jesus and loving God with our minds, frees us to embrace our true humanity.

Jesus obeyed.

There is a lot in the word that Paul uses for obedient that we miss in our English translations. In English, the word "to obey" simply means to comply with an instruction, rule, law, etc. But in the Greek, hypkeoos (which is only found three times in the bible,) actually means to listen and respond. There is both a listening and a responding that is included, much like answering a doorbell or a phone. In other words, obedience for Jesus was rooted in and responding to his Fellowship with his father. For Jesus, obedience was only possible in the context of fellowship. (Maybe doing the right thing while out of fellowship with God is really a subtle form of disobedience.) Authentic obedience can only be expressed in the context of fellowship with God.

f. Jesus was obedient to death.

Jesus accepted that suffering was an unavoidable part of a life that was totally committed to God and his purposes. Jesus was obedient to death, even death on a cross! The Romans reserved the agonizing death of crucifixion for slaves and foreigners, and the Jews viewed death on a cross as a curse from God. We have become too familiar with the term ‘cross.’

"It is difficult after sixteen centuries and more, during which the cross has been a sacred symbol, to realize the unspeakable horror and loathing which the very mention or thought of the cross provoked in Paul's day. The word crux was unmentionable in polite Roman society (Cicero, ProRabirio 16); even when one was being condemned to death by crucifixion the sentence used an archaic formula which served as a sort of euphemism: arbori infelici suspendito, 'hang him on the unlucky tree' (Cicero, ibid. 13)."

How was Jesus able to endure such pain and shame? How was he able to become so humble, and pay such a high price?

He was able because we are told in verse 6 “He did not consider equality with God something to grasp.” He had let go of every desire for power, ambition and control, and in doing so he was able to die a cruel death on a shameful cross. Like Jesus we have a cross to carry, however that will only be possible when we have the same attitude that He had.

The image of God is most clearly demonstrated through a cruciform live

Father thank you that humility is always consistent with our humanity.
