title: Study theme Spiritual formation [The process of becoming like Jesus] part 9

html:
Apparently when Steve Jobs, the founder and director of Apple was giving any kind of presentation, he would talk about the company, its direction, its finances, it’s structure etc. Then just as he was about to walk off at the end of his presentation, he would say ‘One final thing.’ then he would produce Apple's latest invention. The ‘one final thing,’was the main purpose of the presentation. Something like this is happening in the story of creation as recorded in Genesis 1 and 2. In these chapters we have a record of God’s power and glory displayed through the wisdom of creation. Then we read in 2.25 ‘Adam and his wife were both naked and they felt no shame.’

We could be tempted to skip over this verse or not really notice it, but this is the ‘one final thing’ this verse expresses, the ultimate glory and purpose of God’s creation. This is a wonderful moment in the history of the universe. This is a ‘moment of intense beauty as creator and his created have an ‘all access,’ relationship that knows nothing of the distorting of shame.

What’s interesting is that the author could have finished with any description at the end of this chapter.

As Curt Thompson puts it:

‘He could have said the man and woman were naked and really happy (who wouldn’t be?), or they were naked and strong or confident, or they were naked and without fear or anger or sadness or disappointment or regret. And to be certain, all of these may have been true. With so many to choose from, why the emphasis on shame? It would seem that it is no accident.’ (The Soul of Shame)

Shame has a dehumanising power that prevents us from having any kind of meaningful relationship with God and others, as it reduces us to a shadow of our true selves.

Before we look at our text let me say a few general things about shame.

Shame is different than guilt.

The distinction between guilt and shame is important to understand.

Imagine I commit a crime, I am put on trial, the judge knows that I am totally guilty, but in his kindness and mercy he decides to forgive me. At that moment my guilt has been removed. I leave the court room and those who have been hurt by my crime see me. They see me not as someone who has been forgiven, but as someone who has caused them pain. They may use my crime to define me, i.e. a thief. I have been completely forgiven, but the feelings of shame remain.

a. There are two main sources of shame.

Shame is caused by the wrong things we have done. We have all done things that we are not proud of. And for some it is difficult to get beyond those past deeds, and receive forgiveness or forgive themselves, so they live in continual shame believing that they are unlovable and unacceptable.

Shame is also caused by what others do to us. Many people have been treated in very shameful ways, with words and deeds, causing them to develop a ‘shame shaped’ life; were they become entrapped in their negative feelings and destructive thinking about themselves.

Someone writing about the shame caused by others someone has said this.

‘It had been locked away for 23 years and had wreaked havoc on my life and the relationships I had in my life, not only with my friends, who really weren’t even my friends. I didn’t trust anybody…my wife didn’t know the darkest things about me. I had kind of conned her into marrying me almost. It’s a tough admission. I loved her dearly so I projected who I wanted to be, but I would never let her inside, because I always feared if someone knew the real me, they would run the other way. I tried to go forward with my life. Just feel shame, shame, shame…1 — P.J. Harvey.

https://www.dashhouse.com/beginning-shame-genesis-224-310-21/ 13/003/2025

Michael Lewis said “Shame can be defined simply as the feeling we have when we evaluate our actions, feelings or behaviour, and conclude that we have done wrong. It encompasses the whole of ourselves; it generates a wish to hide, to disappear, or even to die.”

Michael Lewis, Shame: The Exposed Self (New York: Te Free Press, 1992), 2.

Someone else has said:-

‘Shame is a conviction at the very core that one is defective and worthless. It is a deeply rooted emotion that one is bad, is wrong, and can’t do anything right. Shame is accompanied by self-loathing and feelings of deep inadequacy. It must be distinguished from guilt, which is the feeling that one has transgressed a boundary, hurt someone, or done something wrong.’

https://lindagraham-mft.net/im-hiding-please-see-me-unmasking-shame/ accessed 13/03/2025

When we read that Adam and his wife were naked and felt no shame, we must see this as more of an emotional and psychological description than a physical one. To be unashamed is to feel totally accepted. The Hebrew for shame is bawsh which has a root that means "to pale" (for example, when the blood drains from your face). It is referring to feeling of being uncomfortable, not at ease, feeling unworthy and unaccepted. The dictionary definition of shame goes something like this: Shame is the painful emotion caused by a consciousness of guilt or shortcoming or impropriety. It’s the condition of humiliating disgrace or disrepute.

We have been designed to live unashamed lives. You were made for a world without shame. You were meant to live as someone with nothing to hide, with no need to ever feel embarrassed or inadequate. We can’t even imagine this now. We were truly made to be unashamed. But unfortunately we live in a shame based culture were we are constantly being controlled and manipulated by shame. We are continually being told that we are never ‘enough.’ Never good enough, never strong enough, never clever enough. We are bombarded by messages of shame that rob us of any kind of healthy confidence which is required for righteous living.

You could say that shame is the antithesis to the image of God. Being made in the image of God means we were created to reflect his glory. However, when we are filled with feelings of shame, for the most part, we become terrified of displaying our failures, our weakness and our mistakes. Shame at it’s essence is inverted pride and covert narcissism. Shame, whether caused by my own failure/weakness, or by the mistreatment of others, places me at the centre of the universe.

When God made Adam and Eve they wore no clothes. They came into the world naked, but they did not know they were naked until the Fall. Why not? Because they had never looked at themselves – they were not obsessed with self-interest. They were self-less. Before the Fall they were concerned about the animals, they were concerned about the garden, and about the work that had been assigned to them. They were concerned with each other, one about the other. But now suddenly they saw themselves. This awareness of self-nakedness is a symbolic way of expressing the fact that this was the birth of being self-centred. They saw themselves and the immediate effect was to bring shame and embarrassment upon themselves.

Father thank you that it is not your will that I live under shame

html:
If we were to compare how Genesis records Adam and Eve after they disobeyed God and ate from the tree of the knowledge of good and evil we see how devastating shame is.

Shame changes how we see ourselves.

‘Then the eyes of both of them were opened, and they realized they were naked.’ This is interesting, they had always been naked, nothing in their physical bodies had changed, but how they saw and accepted themselves had changed.

‘Adam and Eve had never felt guilt before. The guilt they encountered was a fear-generated sense of shame, which creates the psychological obsession to hide and guard our marred and stained self from another’s gaze. In their complete astonishment at this avalanche of guilt into their souls, and their total inexperience with this feeling of shame, they respond like bewildered children. The inner need to hide expresses itself in an outward need to hide—even from each other.’ Garry Durham source unknown

In Genesis 2:25 we read that the man and his wife were naked and unashamed. By Genesis 3:7 there is shame – that sense of unease with yourself at the heart of your being. Not being able to be comfortable with yourself as you are, and therefore not being comfortable in the presence of another: that is shame. (Atkinson, The Message of Genesis 1–11 (Bible Speaks Today), 87)

The guilt they were feeling led to a deep sense of shame and self reproach because they did not handle their guilt correctly. What they should have done, was to seek God out and ask for mercy and forgiveness. Their shame led to a perverted self-perception that they wanted to hide from each other. It is interesting that the word used for naked in Genesis 3:7 is a different word that is used in 2:25. The word ‘erom’ in 3:7 is much more than physical nakedness. It could be understood as a loss of ‘glory’ This nakedness felt different to the former nakedness of Genesis 2. Their bodies had not changed, but internally there was a disconnect, a ‘something not right’ feeling. A feeling of being uncomfortable with themselves, a compulsion to hide.

Shame is something that often begins with illegitimate voices in our heads that repetitively use ‘tear down,’ language to humiliate us. They tell us things like ‘we are not enough, we are worthless and of no value.’ Eventually the voices may stop, but their message has been engraved upon our hearts, and now we are living with a continual sense of shame. We begin to use the language of shame to define ourselves. For many, shame has become their default, their modus operandi, their automatic way of seeing themselves and relating to the world around them.

Father may I experience freedom from engraved shame.

html:
Shame causes us to hide from God.

‘When the man and his wife heard the sound of the Lord God as he was walking in the garden in the cool of the day, they hid from the Lord God among the trees of the garden. But the Lord God called to the man, “Where are you?” he answered, “I heard you in the garden, and I was afraid because I was naked; so I hid.”

This is one of the most emotional moments in the whole bible. The created turn their backs on the creator, a God of love is spurned and rejected.

The words “hid themselves” in verse 8 here comes from the Hebrew word “châbâ” and it has to do with secrecy or to withdraw oneself in order to protect oneself’

What does it mean to hide from God? What does it look like?

a. Hiding from God is about us determining the terms of our relationship with him. When we are told that man and his wife hid from the Lord God, they were actually redefining their relationship with him. This ‘hiding’ is the antithesis to being ‘naked and unashamed.’ No more honesty, no more openness, no more reality, just shame, shame that breaks the heart of God, and will eventually lead to the brutal death of his lovely son.

This hiding from God was actually an expression of perverted thinking. They were hiding, not because they were sorry that they had offended a Holy God, but because of their sense of shame. They were hiding to avoid repentance and dealing with the problem.

One of the biggest threats to spiritual formation and authentic transformation is when we make a deliberate choice to hide from God. We have developed a host of subtle mechanisms we use to hide from ourselves and from God.

We live in denial, we avoid truth, we refuse to take responsibility, we blame others, we make excuses. And as we hide in an attempt to protect ourselves we are actually actively avoiding God.

b. They began to fear the voice they had heard so many times in the past; their perception of God had changed. They hide because they now had a distorted view of God. In the Complete Word Study Dictionary of the Old Testament the word afraid (yare) has two main meanings:

(1) the emotional and intellectual anticipation of harm, what one feels when things may go wrong and

(2) a very positive feeling of awe or reverence for God.

I think it is evident from the context – afraid in Genesis 3:10 is the first type. They saw God as a threat, reverence had been turned into dread and an intimate loving relationship with God ceases to be.

Hiding from God is about our inability to receive love. The convincing voice of shame says ‘you are unlovable, you are unaccepted,’ and we begin to believe the lie that God couldn’t really love us, so we hide. The vulnerability/nakedness we need in order to receive God’s love terrifies us, so we stay hidden.

The kind of relationship God wants with us, requires that we are free from the control of shame. Trying to relate to God and others in meaningful, enriching ways, while carrying shame is very difficult.

Father am I hiding anything from you?

title: Study theme Spiritual formation part 12 [The process of becoming like Jesus]

html:
Shame is something we cannot deal with on our own. It is important to remember that when they heard the voice of God they actually were not completely naked, so Adam’s response is a bit odd. Physically they were not naked for they were covered with fig leaves, but the shame that sin produced in them did not disappear when they covered their nakedness.

We can all identify with Adam and Eve, we have all tried to cover our shame and medicate it’s pain, but no matter what we do our shame still remains. We dress up, we get better jobs, we build relationships, we pursue our dreams. And yet we still feel an uneasiness about ourselves. We try harder, we jump through all the hoops, but because shame has become so ingrained in us, it is not long before we discover that no matter what we do we are unable to free ourselves from it.

As we read the rest of Genesis 3, we discover how God’s love of Adam and Eve helped them deal with their shame. I just want to look at one of the things God did. We read in verse 21, ‘The Lord God made garments of skin for Adam and his wife and clothed them.’

The word coverings in this verse describes something like a loin cloth which covers the lower part of the body. However the word garment in verse 21 covers the whole body but more importantly this same word is used in the rest of Genesis to describe the coat Jacob gave his son Joseph to show him how much he loved him as a son. In the book of Exodus the same word is used to describe the clothes the High Priest had to wear.

Can you see what God is doing here?

He allows them time to discover that they were unable to cover their own shame. He lets them sow fig leaves together and feel the futility of trying to remove their own shame. God does not remove the consequences of their disobediences, but he does cover their shame so they can cope with those consequences.

Through the death of an animal and the shedding of blood, God dresses Adam and Eve as sons and priests so they no longer have to live out of shame. God longs for intimacy with us, which is only possible when we are no longer clothed in shame but clothed as His sons and daughters.

Here is the important part. Forgiveness removes our guilt. Once you are forgiven by God you are totally, completely forgiven. However, it is spiritual formation or sanctification that removes our shame. Guilt is more about what we have done while shame is more about who we think we are. Shame will haunt us long after we have dealt with our guilt. Shame refuses to accept our new identity in Christ. It is through the process of spiritual formation that we move from our default of shame into the likeness of Jesus.

It is often difficult for someone to recognise their shame because it has become so engrained.

Please respond by circling the number that best corresponds to how you feel at this point in time for each item.

0 – very seldom or never

1 – sometimes

2 – often

1) Do you have difficulty accepting compliments from others? 0 1 2

2) Do you often apologize to others? Or feel that things are always your fault? 0 1 2

3) Do you have difficulty openly asserting your feelings, sharing your needs, and expressing your preferences? 0 1 2

4) Is it difficult to look at your naked body in a mirror? 0 1 2

5) Do you often berate yourself? For example call yourself “stupid” for making a mistake? 0 1 2

6. Are you excessively hard on yourself? Do your beat yourself up when it comes to spiritual disciplines? 0 1 2

6) Do you often feel as though you are not good enough? 0 1 2

7) Do you frequently compare yourself to others? 0 1 2

8) Do you often feel that you have to prove yourself to others to gain acceptance? 0 1 2

9) Do you dismiss or trivialize your accomplishments? 0 1 2

10) Do you often feel as though something is missing inside of you? 0 1 2

11) Do you often feel that you are not OK as you are? 0 1 2

12) Do you frequently wish that you were someone else? 0 1 2

13) Is it difficult to look people in the eyes when speaking to them? 0 1 2

14) I feel guilty when I am relaxing? 0 1 2

15) It is difficult to believe that anyone, even God, can love me as I am? 0 1 2

16) No matter what I do, it doesn’t feel good enough. 0 1 2

17) I often feel I should be punished. 0 1 2

18) I often feel that I should be doing more. If I did, God would love me more. 0 1 2

19) Do you have difficulty making decisions? Do you often second guess yourself? 0 1 2

20) Are you self-conscious in public? 0 1 2

Through his death on the cross Jesus removed our guilt and shame. The removal of our guilt is known as justification. The minute we became a Christian we were completely forgiven, there was no more condemnation. Justification is a judicial term, it describes how God sees us. Sanctification, on the other hand deals more with our experience of shame.

Shame is so rooted in our thinking that it requires the growth of transformed thinking and a maturing self-perspective caused by spiritual transformation to live free from its power. We all want a ‘’magic bullet’ a ‘super spiritual experience’ to remove our feelings of shame, because we are not aware that the removal of our feelings of shame is tied to our spiritual growth. The tragic thing is this, often the church has been guilty of turning shame into a motivating virtue. So it has been used to coerce, control and manipulate to get people to serve. In an essay on shame in the church at Dan Foster wrote:-

‘Shame is used in the church to make people conform to the norms of the group. Belief, in any system, is a social exercise. Nowhere is this more evident than in the evangelical church. If you want to fit in, there are a bunch of so-called, not-negotiable “truths” that you must ascribe to. Many of them are extra-Biblical and have more to do with tradition and dogma than the actual practice of following Christ.

Guilt-based religion and shame work well to keep the troops in line because shame certainly is a powerful motivator — but only in the short term. It does not result in real, lasting transformation. A system that uses shame to achieve its goals ultimately makes out God to be the same. Unwittingly, the church made God seem like an arm-folding, eye-rolling, head-shaking, fist-waving, disapproving megalomaniac, who is impossible to please and constantly unimpressed. Moreover, the church made it seem like God, with a heaving sigh, begrudgingly came and died for our sins, and we ought to feel constantly guilty about making him die in the first place.’ Now here is the big take away. If we are living out of shame, then our default will be to use shame in the lives of others in an attempt to accomplish God’s will for our lives, turning shame into a ‘virtue.’ This, for the most part will not be a conscious decision, but has more to do with immaturity and a lack of spiritual growth. As Christians we cannot become so accustomed to living with shame or even living out of shame. Shame is the antithesis to the image of God and in order that we become more like Jesus, we need the grace of God to deliver us from our shame and it’s power in our lives.’ Father deliver me pervasive effects of shame.’ https://goodmenproject.com/featured-content/the-church-needs-shame-to-function/.

html:
I wonder will we make it?

Author, former Desiring God contributor, former Philosophy professor at Moody Bible Institute. (2015—2017), and Trinity Evangelical Divinity PhD. grad Paul Maxwell announced on Instagram, that he is “not a Christian any more.”

I wonder will we make it?

Hillsong songwriter Marty Sampson wrote: “Time for some real talk… I’m genuinely losing my faith… Christians can be the most judgmental people on the planet – they can also be some of the most beautiful and loving people… but it’s not for me. I am not in any more.”

I wonder will we make it?

Dave Gass, the former pastor at Grace Family Fellowship, pastor at Covenant Church and Cedar Community Church, took to social media and announced: “After 40 years of being a devout follower, 20 of those being an evangelical pastor, I am walking away from the faith. Even though this has been a massive bomb dropped in my life, it has been decades in the making.”

I don’t know you but when I hear of people who were once used by God, leaving their faith and stopping following Jesus, I have two main emotions. I feel very sad. I have a friend who was a great bible teacher, and God used him all over the world, now he is very far from God.

The second emotion I feel is fear, fear of not ending the race well. I often wonder, will I be faithful to the end? Will I remain faithful by growing in faithfulness? Or will I end with a cold tired heart that has forgotten how to be passionate about Jesus? How we will cross the line is more important than when we started. We have no control as to when we will cross the finishing line, but we are absolutely responsible for how we cross it so let us look at some verses that will help us finish well.

In Galatians 6:6-10 Paul wrote these words ‘Nevertheless, the one who receives instruction in the word should share all good things with their instructor. 7 Do not be deceived: God cannot be mocked. A man reaps what he sows. 8 Whoever sows to please their flesh, from the flesh will reap destruction; whoever sows to please the Spirit, from the Spirit will reap eternal life. 9 Let us not become weary in doing good, for at the proper time we will reap a harvest if we do not give up. 10 Therefore, as we have opportunity, let us do good to all people, especially to those who belong to the family of believers.’

Paul gives us five areas of relationships where we need to be intentional, where we need to work hard at sowing that will produce a harvest of eternal life. Before we look at this we need to first consider the principle of sowing and reaping.

Madame Chiang Kai-shek once wrote: "If the past has taught us anything it is that every cause brings its effect, every action has a consequence. We Chinese have a saying: "If a man plants melons he will reap melons; if he sows beans, he will reap beans." And this is true of everyone's life; good begets good, and evil leads to evil. True enough, the sun shines on the saint and the sinner alike, and too often it seems that the wicked prosper. But we can say with certainty that, with the individual as with the nation, the flourishing of the wicked is an illusion, for, unceasingly, life keeps books on us all. In the end, we are all the sum total of our actions. Character cannot be counterfeited, nor can it put on and cast off as if it were a garment to meet the whim of the moment. Like the markings on wood which are ingrained in the very heart of the tree, character requires time and nurturing for growth and development. Thus also, day by day, we write our own destiny; for inexorably...we become what we do." https://www.ccel.org/contrib/exec_outlines/gal/ga6_7.htm. Accessed 04/08/25

Let me try and explain the implications of this principle.

[a] A harvest may be sown in secret but the harvest itself cannot be hidden.

This is so important. The seeds we sow in private will eventually become evident. In some ways the people we are and the things we do when nobody but God sees us, is when we sow prominent seeds that will have a massive influence on who we will become in the future.

[b] We alone are responsible for the seed we sow. Nobody else can sow our seed. Your seeds are your seeds, we cannot hold other people responsible for the people we become. Do others influence and effect us, yes. But no matter how I have been treated or mistreated by others, the harvest I will reap and the character I become is due to the seeds I am/have sowed.

[b] Time might pass before the harvest ripens but it will come.

The harvest will take time, be it a good harvest or a bad harvest it will come, That is both good news and bad news. I have been with people who have sown good seed and as they were dying their was a dignified composer about them. Conversely, others who have planted poor/bad seed all their lives have been bitter and agitated as they have faced death.

[c] The nature of the seed we sow will determine the harvest.

If we sow good seed like love, mercy, compassion, kindness and the like we can expect a good harvest. That is sowing to the Spirit. However, if we are sowing seed that is consistent with our sinful nature then we should expect to develop a character that is inconsistent with the image and purposes of God.

[d] The harvest will always be greater/more than the seed that you sow. The seeds we sow may seem to be small, like attitudes, thoughts, perceptions, prestiges. Seeds are almost inconsequential, they are so small, however, the size of the seed will not determine the size of the plant it will produce.

[e] You can do nothing about your past harvests but you can about future harvests. The harvest we reaped in the future does not have to be the same as the harvest we have reaped in the past. We can easily think, ‘if my circumstances are different in the future then I will be a better/happier person. The problem is, our circumstances do not determine the harvest we will reap in our characters. We can move homes, change our jobs, get married, but if we are sowing the seeds you have always sown, then nothing in you is going to change.

[g] The sowing and reaping principle applies to every area of our lives. When we sow seed we sow it in every single area of our lives, there is nothing in our lives immune from the sowing and reaping principle. ‘I wonder will we make it?’

Father help me be intentional in sowing good seed.

html:
Seeds of learning. We need to be people that longs to learn.

The first relationship that Paul talks about is the relationship between those who teach the word of God and those who are taught. Galatians 6:6. Nevertheless, the one who receives instruction in the word should share all good things with their instructor. As Christians we should always have a teachable attitude. If someone at school engages well with a teacher, they are probably going to enjoy the class more and perhaps learn more. This same principle applies to the church. The question is, are we teachable? What does it mean to be teachable? To help us grasp what Paul is saying there are two words that he uses that may help us.

[a] The first word for teach katēcheō, which was used in the sense of reporting something to another or to instruct someone, it was used to described an actor speaking down from a stage, and it is where our word echo is derived from. Paul uses it four times and uses it exclusively to refer to instructing someone in the Christian faith (1 Cor 14:19; Gal 6:6 [2x]; Rom 2:18). It is from this word that we get our word catechism. a summary of the principles of Christian religion in the form of questions and answers, used for religious instruction. So we need to be people who have continual eagerness to learn truth that will define our lives. Can I just say that being teachable is a choice, it is an intentional attitude, a deliberate mindset.

Let us take a step back and think about this. How do we listen to teaching from the word of God, what frame of mind do we have as we sit listening to sermons every week? We can either sit and be and not be engaged, thinking about lots of other things, or, we can sit with a teachable heart, longing to learn about God and ourselves.

[b] The second word Paul uses is koinoneo which means to share, not to impart but share, to have things in common, to hold in common, the word was used as business partners. Paul is saying that learning is a corporate experience, where we choose to invest in order to learn. The focus of this verse is the quality of the relationship between the teacher and those he is teaching. We need to be personally and proactively be investing some of our resources so we can have more opportunity to learn about God and know him better.

Ca I just say in passing that I have Learned that for some people being in bible collage can be a very dangerous place, because they are continually being taught, they are continually receiving information. Looking back a my own experience at bible college no one ever told me that the primary purpose, the ultimate goal, the most important and essential objective of being at bible college, was not to prepare for ministry. Was not to get to know the bible better. It wasn't even to help me discern God’s future purposes for my life. All these are important and good, but they are not, nor ever should they be the purpose of bible college. The ultimate objective of being at any bible college, is to get to know God.

For the Christian learning to know God for the most part will be a painful and difficult experience, because it will require all our false and wrong understandings about God [which often feel like truth,] to be demolished. It may require a deconstruction of some of our theology in order to build a more biblical theology that is more consistent with who God really is. How do you know if you are teachable?

You learn from anyone and everyone you can.

You listen to others carefully and patiently with a desire to learn from everyone you read widely especially outside your theological comfort zone.

You’re prepared to move out of your comfort zone, try something different, make mistakes, look stupid, answer wrongly, etc.

You don’t give up when you fail at something, but seek help, and try again and again until you get it right.

You are willing to change your views and practices when convincing evidence is presented to you, even if it means admitting you were wrong. Father thank you that life is being enrolled in a life long classroom. Bible in a year reading plan. Amos 5-9 Obadiah 1:1-9
title: Study theme Spiritual formation [process of becoming like Jesus.] part 15
study_refs: Let us look at this passage and try and discover the kind of seeds we should be sowing

html:
Paul gives three reasons why we should sow to the spirit

If we are not sowing to the Spirit then we are sowing to the flesh/sinful nature. John Stott said this: - ‘To "sow to the flesh" is to pander to it, to cosset, cuddle and stroke it, instead of crucifying it. The seeds we sow are largely thoughts and deeds. Every time we allow our mind to harbour a grudge, nurse a grievance, entertain an impure fantasy, or wallow in self-pity, we are sowing to the flesh. Every time we linger in bad company whose insidious influence we know we cannot resist, every time we lie in bed when we ought to be up and praying, every time we read pornographic literature, every time we take a risk that strains our self-control, we are sowing, sowing, sowing to the flesh.’ “The Message of Galatians” p. 170.

Gordon Fee gives this definition for the flesh.”The flesh is the condition of humanity “before and outside of Christ.” To walk in the flesh is to walk on our own, outside of Christ’s redemptive work, outside of the power of the Holy Spirit. https://www.fairlyspiritual.org/2011/02/21/live-according-to-the-spirit-not-according-to-the-flesh/https://www.fairlyspiritual.org/2011/02/21/live-according-to-the-spirit-not-according-to-the-flesh/ access 14/03/2025

Whether we do seemingly noble things or incredibly “wicked” things, if they are done outside of relationship with God, they are done in the flesh.

Robert Jewett defines "the flesh" in Galatians 5 and 6 as "Paul's term for everything aside from God in which one places his final trust.’ source unknown.

‘The flesh is the conviction that I am the most important thing in the universe. It is ultimately worship of myself— my pleasure, my exaltation, my success, my reputation. I will defend myself against, exalt myself over, prefer myself to any and every other person. There is an enormously self-centred core in me. Even self-destructive behaviour is an expression of personal power. If God says he loves me, I’ll destroy what he loves, to prove my superiority.’ Steve Zeisler. https://cdn.pbc.org/Main_Service/2000/10/08/4690.pdf

In Freudian terminology you could say that the flesh was like the ‘Id’

The id seeks instant gratification for our wants and needs. If these needs or wants are not met, a person can become tense, anxious, or angry. For example, Bart was stuck in traffic. He just wanted his vehicle to move! Enraged at the situation, Bart pulled his car onto the shoulder and sped forward, not caring that he was clipping people's side mirrors as he tried to get ahead of the cars in front of him.

At it’s essence our struggle with our flesh is always an identity issue. It is rooted in a wrong belief that what we have in Jesus is not enough so we develop a desire for independence from God, in order to quickly satisfy our present longings. The direction and trajectory of the flesh is always independence from God.

[b] When we are not sowing to the Spirit then we are deceiving ourselves and mocking God.

We can very easily deceive ourselves, sometimes we refuse to be honest with ourselves. We can go into performance mode in order to hide from ourselves. If everyone else thinks I am OK, then I must be!

To mock God, Greek word muckerizo, it carries the ides that we do not take what God is saying seriously. We think, it does not matter how I live, God cannot be serious, The verb he employs means literally “to turn up the nose” so as to treat with contempt. “In a culture where face and honour and shame was very important, to turn up one’s nose at someone was to shame them, it was to treat them as someone weak, as someone beneath one’s own dignity, and as unworthy of one’s respect” (Witherington, 431). The reference is not to verbal scoffing but to despising God by a whole way of life.

[c] Not to sow to the Spirit is to guarantee destruction. The word used for destruction is phthora, this is not a sudden destruction owing to external violence, but a dissolution brought about by internal decay. It describes decomposition which brings to mind the picture of loathsome decaying matter replete with maggots and other macabre microbes! Figuratively speaking the idea is that of the horrible thought of the "rotting" of one's morals which become more depraved with greater loss of integrity as a result of "slow internal decay".

On the other hand, to sow to the Spirit is to live a life that is surrendered to the Spirit. In chapter five Paul uses four verbs to describe our relationship with the Spirit. ‘Walk by the Spirit,’ ‘Led by the Spirit.’ ‘Live by the Spirit.’ and ‘keep in step with the Spirit.’ These words carry the idea of surrender, or submitting, holding lightly to our agendas, or plans, being open and flexible to go where the Spirit leads. It is important to recognise that when the bible talks about being led by the Spirit it is primarily talking about being led into transformation. The context of Paul’s teaching about being led by the Spirit is usually in the context of him talking about a Christian character and our transformation into the likeness of Jesus. To be led by the Spirit is to be led out of shame into grace, from guilt into freedom. from insecurity into the glorious love of God. To sow to the Spirit is to live a life that is continually in every circumstance displaying the fruit of the Spirit. no matter where or who we are with, or what we are doing, we recognise that the fruit of the Spirit is both appropriate and essential for that time. Father thank you there is no situation or circumstance in life where the fruit oft the Spirit is not essential.

title: Study theme Spiritual formation [The process of becoming like Jesus.] part 16
study_refs: Seeds of submission. Galatians 6:8 Whoever sows to please their flesh from the flesh will reap destruction; whoever sows to please the Spirit, from the Spirit will reap eternal life. We need to be a people that pleases the Spirit. When it comes to the principle of reaping and sowing we need to be people who sow to the Spirit. What does it mean to sow to the Spirit? To sow to the Spirit is to cultivate a life of dependant devotion.

html:
The word for good means beautiful, handsome, excellent, eminent, choice, surpassing, precious, useful, suitable, commendable, admirable. When we become weary, and feel like giving up, we should decide to choose to sow good seed, go and do something that is beautiful, excellent, etc.

Paul continues by saying for at the proper time we will reap a harvest if we do not give up. Often giving up is more a mental attitude and a negative emotion that can lead to physical exhaustion. We can lose our vision, our purpose, our enthusiasm and drive and before long we have ceased to sow the good seed that is consistent with living a godly life.

4. Seeds of love. We need to be people that does good to all.

Paul ends this section by giving two general principles for sowing good seed.

[a] Therefore, as we have opportunity, let us do good to all people. Three times in these verses Paul uses the word good. The word “all,” pas, means all, to each and every person. regardless of who or what they are; it doesn’t matter if they’re protestant, it doesn’t matter if they’re Catholic, it doesn’t matter if they’re Muslim, it doesn’t matter. You do good to all men, regardless of any prejudice, regardless of whether they’re believers or unbelievers. It doesn’t matter; you do good to all men. Maybe making the most out of life is about seeing it as a continual opportunity to do good to others. Imagine going into life with that attitude. The goodness that Paul is referring to is based upon a person’s character, it is a spontaneous expression of who they are.

5. Seeds of responsibility, especially to those who belong to the family of believers. Galatians 6:10, Therefore, as we have opportunity, let us do good to all people, especially to those who belong to the family of believers.


We have responsibility to the family of God. The word for family oikeios, refers to all the participants of a particular family. It carries the idea of belonging to a place of safety. If we are going to be an authentic expression of the life of God, then our lives must become a safe place for others. If we recognise others as part of our family, then we are going to be proactive in sowing seed that will produce life. We need to be people who demonstrate continual care for others.

‘Sowing to please the Spirit means "serving one another in love" (5:13), restoring one who has been caught in sin (6:1), carrying the burdens of others (6:2), giving generously to those who teach in the church (6:6) and doing good to all (6:9). Sometimes sowing to the Spirit has been defined in terms of private, personal holiness, as if it were something done in a closet by oneself. But sowing to the Spirit in the context of Paul's teaching here involves building love relationships with others. Sowing to the Spirit cannot be done in isolation or separation from others. Carrying the burdens of others requires in-depth participation in their pain and sorrow. As we see in verse 9, sowing to the Spirit means doing good to others. If sowing to the sinful nature means selfish indulgence, then sowing to the Spirit means selfless service. IVP Commentary

Every one of us are people of potential, there are lots of things we cannot do, control, or change, often circumstances are beyond our ability to do anything about, but the one thing we are all responsible for is the people we are becoming, the character we are developing into. In our passage, Paul promises that if we sow to the Spirit we will reap eternal life. We often make the mistake in thinking that when the bible speaks about eternal life it is talking about life in heaven, but it’s not. Eternal life is best understood as experiencing the very life of God in the present, it has more to do with the quality of our lives, than its longevity. The longevity of eternal life is only part of its quality, but it is not its essence. Eternal life is the reality life of God in the here and now. Eternal life is about becoming the people we are meant to be, the people God wants us to be.

I wonder will we make it?

Father may I be totally faithful till my last breath. Bible in a year reading plan. Micah 4-7 Nahum1-2.
title: Study theme Spiritual formation [The process of becoming like Jesus] part 17
study_refs: Seeds of perseverance. Galatians 6:9, Let us not become weary in doing good for at the proper time we will reap a harvest if we do not give up. We need not to become weary in doing good. Sometimes in life we get weary, tired, burned out. To be weary is to feel empty of a fighting spirit, to cease to fight for what is right, to become exhausted as a result of giving in to evil. - literally, “Let us not keep on giving in to evil while doing the good." Paul is telling us to keep on doing good, even if you feel that you are wasting your time, or if you feel that it is pointless. To sow good seed is to, keep on doing good in the face of evil and opposition, because good seed will produce a good harvest. Sometimes we become tired, we lose perspective, and we give into feelings of discouragement.

html:
Before we look at the passage we need to start by asking the question, ‘What does following Jesus look like in my life? Could people look at our lives and have to conclude that we are people who are zealously following Jesus? Jesus walked a lonely difficult path. He was out of step with the rest of society, and if we are going to follow him he will lead us along unconventional paths of righteous living. Following Jesus means that we wont be going with the crowds, we won’t be part of the herd. We will have a different agenda which will require a different path.

“The one who follows the crowd will usually go no further from the crowd. The one who walks alone is likely to find himself in places no one has ever been.” — Albert Einstein

Jesus put this way ‘You can enter God’s kingdom through the narrow gate. The highway to hell is broad and its gate is wide for the many who choose that way. But the gateway to life is very narrow and the road is difficult and only a few ever find it.’ Matthew 7:13-14. The pathway of authentic discipleship is narrow and sparsely populated.

Secondly, these three verses are a microcosm in discipleship. They give us a condensed understanding of what it really means to follow Jesus. They teach or show us in a compact way what discipleship is and how it should shape our lives. These verses in Luke 8:1-3 help us to go through the narrow gate and walk the road that is less travelled.

1 Following Jesus restores our dignity.

Luke tells that among the disciples following Jesus were a number of women, and he mentions three of them, Mary Magdalene, Joanna the wife of Chuza, Herod’s business manager, and Susanna, these and many other women followed Jesus. This was unheard of, for any rabbis to have female disciples was totally unacceptable.

Let me share some of the rabbinic writings about women.

“The female is irrelevant in creation, for she is not more than a parasitic thing taken from him for his utilization to become a special tool for his use as one of his special body parts to be used by him.”

Women were to be shunned in public social contact. Consider the following passage from the Mishna tractate Abot, 1, 5: “Engage not in too much conversation with women.’’ They said this with regard to one’s own wife. How much more does the rule apply to another man’s wife? As long as a man engages in too much conversation with women, he causes evil to himself, for he goes idle from the study of the Torah, so that his end will be that he will inherit gehenna.”

Women were not to be publicly taught the Torah. Consider, however, the following passage from the tractate Sota, 10a: “May the words of Torah be burned, than that they should be handed over to women.” In Sota 21b it is written, “Rabbi Eliezer says: ‘’Whoever teaches his daughter Torah teaches her obscenity.”

This attitude about women’s innate inability to learn the Torah was manifested by having special courts for women in the Second Temple and also in synagogues, where they were separated from men. This was never the practice in the Old Testament. The later practice continues to the present time among Orthodox Jews.

Yet contrary to all the common practices of his day, Jesus had female disciples. Why? Because he saw women as people of dignity. Dignity is the belief that all people hold a special value that's tied solely to their humanity. It has nothing to do with their class, race, gender, religion, abilities, or any other factor other than them being human.

Father as men we thank you for the ladies you have brought into our lives may we treat them as Jesus would, Bible in year reading plan. Nahum 3; Habakkuk 1-3; Zeph 1:1-13.
title: The road less travelled part 1
study_refs: In 1915 the poet Robert Frost published a poem called ‘The road not taken,’ and it may surprise you to know that Frost wrote the poem as a joke for a friend, another poet Edward Thomas . When they went walking together, Thomas was chronically indecisive about which road they ought to take and—in retrospect—often lamented that they should, in fact, have taken the other one. Soon after writing the poem in 1915, Frost griped to Thomas that he had read the poem to an audience of college students and that it had been “taken pretty seriously!’’ Despite the authors original intention, the poem has a serious message. The poem later became a catalyst for a famous book, ‘A road less travelled by M Scott Peck.
The reason I mentioned this is because we want to look at Luke 8:1-3 and as we dig into this passage we are going to discover that it is about a road less travelled, a road of radical discipleship.

html:
Luke 8:1-3 After this, Jesus travelled about from one town and village to another, proclaiming the good news of the kingdom of God. The Twelve were with him, and also some women who had been cured of evil spirits and diseases: Mary (called Magdalene from whom seven demons had come out; Joanna the wife of Chuza, the manager of Herod’s household; Susanna; and many others. These women were helping to support them out of their own means.

Following Jesus on the road of discipleship will always highlight a persons dignity, Jesus will never diminish or depreciate a person. And yet, so sadly at times this has been the way of the church. Skewed theology has been used by many to justify and defend the cruel mistreatment of women, and sometimes men. It is so easy to loose your dignity, and so difficult to get it back. Having been mistreated by others, we can so easily become addicted to a default mindset of self loathing and feelings of biting worthlessness.

Although to authentically follow Jesus is difficult and demanding, it is absolutely enhancing. Following Jesus helps us understand and accept our value.

To follow Jesus will be a demonstration of what he has done in our lives.

Luke makes it clear that these women were cured of evil spirits and diseases. The word Luke uses for ‘cure,’ therapeuo, originally was used to describe menial service, but then it also became to mean to be healed or cured. The service these women gave to Jesus came out of their healing. They served not because they felt guilty, not because they wanted some kind of payback, not because they were looking for approval or status, but because they were cured. For these women the choosing of the narrow road of discipleship was the consequences of the healing power of God in their lives.

This raises a question? Is there a link between healing and service? Often in the church there can be two types of people, those who are ‘over serving’ and those who are ‘not serving’. Now there can be a host of different reasons why some people are not serving, some of those may be legitimate, and some are not. However, in the context of what we are thinking about, we need to ask, ‘Is lack of service on my part the consequence of ‘a lack of healing in my life?’

For these women walking the narrow road to follow Jesus was the natural consequence of ‘therapeuo’ it was a healthy spontaneous response to the healing power of Jesus in their lives.

Father may I know your healing power in my life. Bible in year reading plan. Zeph. 1:14-3:20; Hag. 1-2; Zech. 1:1-11

ay 277

A road less travelled part 3

I have often thought that the problem with our humanity is that we are not human enough. As we are going to see the road of discipleship is one of the things God uses to make us more human. Our sin dehumanises us, and Jesus wants to reverse and eventually remove the dehumanising effects sin has had on us.

Luke tells us something that would be very easy to miss it’s impact. ‘and many others were contributing from their own resources to support Jesus and his disciples.’ Let these two words sink into your heart. ‘Support Jesus,’ I think most of us would feel slightly uncomfortable with the idea of supporting Jesus! The word Luke uses for support is diakoneo were our word deacon comes from. Mark Hepner states that ‘A survey of the uses of diakoneo in the NT indicates a basic meaning of “giving someone what is necessary to sustain their physical life.” https://www.sermonindex.net/modules/articles/index.php?view=article&aid=34459 accessed 16/03/20225

Consequently the word is frequently used in the gospels to mean “set food before someone” or “wait on someone.” This is very important because Jesus chose to become dependent on others. Why? Because he wanted to teach us how to be human, he wanted to show the glorious essence of our humanity. Let me explain. Jesus had a God given ability to do the miraculous, he was able to feed over 5000 people with 5 small loafs and 2 fish. But he never used his divine power to meet his own needs, he never turned stone into bread.

It was as if Jesus as a perfect man valued the relationships of dependence more than independence. He would rather receive from those who loved him than use his power to meet his own needs. The road of discipleship teaches us that to be as human as Jesus is to receive from others. Sometimes people can become so dehumanised by their pride they are unable to receive from others. You often hear people say something like ‘I am not a charity case.’ you know what, we are all charity cases. We all need the support, love and grace of others. As these women followed Jesus they got to know someone who was vulnerable enough to receive. Jesus’ vulnerability to receive allowed him to be really known by others. He was unafraid of reality or intimacy.

Think how it must have affected these women as they supported Jesus. I don’t believe for one moment that they supported Jesus with some kind of hidden agenda or that they gave so they would feel good about themselves. However, when Jesus received from them, it must have filled their hearts with great joy and gave them a deep sense of acceptance.

Father thank you for ever opportunity to minister onto Jesus. Bible in year reading plan. Zechariah 1:12-7:14 .
title: The road less travelled part 2
study_refs: To follow Jesus will help us to become as human as Him.

html:
We are told that these women contributed from their own resources. Most people who have written on this passage make the assumption that these must have been wealthy women. We are told that Joanna was the wife of Chuza, Herod’s business manger, so she may have been well off. But I do not think Luke is thinking about the wealth of these women. A better way to read this phrase would be, they used what they had at hand to support Jesus and his disciples.’ They used what they had, be it much or little.

We have all been designed in such a way that our lives need to be a continual expression of generosity. We have spoken about how difficult it can be to receive. But it can be also difficult to give. In the Hebrew mind and language there is no concept or word for charity. Instead they think in terms of ‘righteousness,’ so for them what we think of as ‘charity,’ they see it as an act of righteousness. This means as followers of Jesus, generosity needs to be a normal expression of who we are. We have a built-in need to be generous. Not only generous with or money, but with our time, our homes, ourselves. Just let me mention the way the end of verse 3 is written in the Greek, it needs to be understood as a continual action. These women continued to support Jesus.

To follow Jesus means that you intentionally engage in community life.

Joanna who lived a life of relative luxury and power, sharing life with Mary Magdalen whose life had been messed up by seven demons, and Susanna whom we know nothing about, and is only mentioned once in scripture. Joanna, Mary, Susanna, very different women from very different worlds, but they chose to live in community, despite the fact that their lives were so different. They were able to do this because Jesus was at the heart and was the heart of their lives together.

Very sadly we are living in a day where Christians seem to have an antipathy towards community. Consumerism has become the metric by which many people measures a church community, so unless a church meets all their bespoke specific needs they move. Their individualistic understanding of Christianity allows them to wash their hands of any care or responsibility for others.

If you are serious about following Jesus, this road less travelled will require a commitment to care and invest your life in Jesus, by caring and investing your life in others.

A verse of scripture I often think about says. ‘He died for everyone so that those who receive his new life will no longer live for themselves.’ 2 Corinthians 5:15. Jesus died ‘so that we no longer live for ourselves.’

As these women followed Jesus along this less travelled road, ‘every day became a school day.’ As they followed him and invested their lives in him they were continually discovering new things about him. The ordinary stuff of everyday life became holy as Jesus used them as illustrations to teach them about himself and his kingdom.

What an amazing privilege!

Father If I am not generous I have a spiritual problem.

title: A road less travelled part 4
study_refs: To follow Jesus will cause us to turn what we have into expressions of generosity.

html:
Have you ever felt lost in a crowd, maybe it has been at some sporting event, or a concert or even in a large city where there is hundreds or even thousands of people? There is lots of noise, activity, hustle and bustle. And you feel unnoticed, passed by, a total stranger among so many people, you blend in so much that you become invisible. Many people live their whole lives like that. Mr. and Mrs. anonymous, nameless faces in the sea of humanity, unseen by the vast majority. Many find the crowd the loneliest place on earth; others believe that in the whole scheme of things their life isn’t that important any way. They think ‘my life will make no difference,’ they believe that mediocrity is normal. So they accept the lie that says ‘stay lost in the crowd.’ They believe the lie that says ‘the life you are living is of very little if ant consequence. You don’t matter, you don’t count!’ So they spend their whole life lost in the crowd.

I want us to meet someone who stood out from the crowd. The interesting thing is that we virtually know nothing about him. We don’t know his name, we don’t know anything about his family, we know nothing about his education or if he had any special gifts. What we do know about him does not really help us.

He was a boy, The word John uses for you boy is paidarrion. The only other time this word is found in the New Testament is Matthew 11:16. This word is often used in critical literature to describe a child slave. We have no way of knowing if this young boy was a slave. If he was I think it brings a new dimension to this story

He was poor. {we know he was poor because only poor people ate barley bread.}

So if you were trying to describe him what we know about him doesn’t really help. Yet he stood out from the crowd, he made a difference, his life touched thousands, history would remember him. He is an example to millions. Then bible talks about him, it uses 12 words. Imagine having a 12 word biography.

“Here is a boy with five barley loaves and two small fish.” His biography was as small as his lunch. But he stood out from the crowd. Why? because he was generous.

This young boy has a lot to teach us about generosity.

Generosity means that we respond appropriately to the circumstances around us. There may have been up to 10,000 people there on that day. We are told there were 5000 men; there must have been women and children. The people had been with Jesus for three days and they were hungry, and had no food. So this young boy gives to Jesus all the food he has.

I don’t think this young boy had any idea what Jesus was going to do; I don’t think he said to himself ‘I am going to make sure that all these people get fed.’ Nor did he try and rationalize away his opportunity to respond to this humanitarian crisis. He did not say ‘All I have is five barley and two small fish, what difference will that make?’ The amazing thing is how Jesus receives these bread and fish.. John writes in 6:11 Jesus then took the loaves, gave thanks, and distributed to those who were seated as much as they wanted. He did the same with the fish. Jesus was thankful for the little this young boy had to give him. I can understand why we should be thankful to Jesus for what he gives to us. But, Jesus being thankful for the very little we give to him, that is amazzing.

Think of the circumstances of your life, the places where you live, the people that surround you, how do you think a generous person would respond in that situation?

Generosity will allow us to engage with the heart of Jesus. In giving his bread and fish this boy was sharing something of the heart of Jesus, he was looking at others in the same way Jesus was. The disciples saw the crowds as a problem. They said, ‘Send the crowds away so they can go to the villages and buy themselves food.’ In other words, ‘They’re not our problem!’ The young boy’s attitude was so different, ‘Lord I don’t have much, but the little I do have you can have it all.’ Generosity requires that we have ‘A Christ like,’ worldview.

What difference would it make if we saw the world in which we lived through the eyes of Jesus?

Father thank you I am in the right place to be generous and I have all I need to be generous

title: generosity part 1

html:
Generosity will help us discover our full potential and even more than our full potential. When we begin to live lives that are distinguished by generosity, that will bring the best out of us, it will make our lives more significant.

Generosity will affect how you view and manage your resources. Sometimes we try to justify or rationalise our lack of generosity. We think that we need to have more before we can be generous. But generosity has nothing to do with how much we have, or how little, it is about the condition of our hearts, affecting how we view our possessions and resources. You can have a lot and be mean and tight fisted. You can also be poor with little and be a very generous person. If we are not generous with the little we have, then we won’t be generous if we have a lot.

We all find it so easy to hold on to what we have got. Can you think of some generous act you would like to do for someone this week?

Generosity is something God loves to bless. There is a line in the story that is often overlooked. ‘Jesus then took the loaves, gave thanks and distributed to those who were seated as much as they wanted. He did the same with the fish.’ Why was Jesus so thankful for this meagre gift of food? There was nothing special about this bread and fish. However, this bread and fish gave Jesus an opportunity to share his heart of love and compassion for those who were around him, and that is why he is so thankful. Any opportunity Jesus has to use our expressions of generosity to bless others will cause him to be thankful.

Father, thank you that Jesus is thankful when we give him the little we have.

Bible in a year: Matthew 1-4
title: generosity part 2

html:
Understanding Generosity.

2 Corinthians 8:1-9 And now, brothers and sisters, we want you to know about the grace that God has given the Macedonian churches. In the midst of a very severe trial, their overflowing joy and their extreme poverty welled up in rich generosity. For I testify that they gave as much as they were able, and even beyond their ability. Entirely on their own, they urgently pleaded with us for the privilege of sharing in this service to the Lord’s people. And they exceeded our expectations: They gave themselves first of all to the Lord, and then by the will of God also to us. So we urged Titus, just as he had earlier made a beginning, to bring also to completion this act of grace on your part. But since you excel in everything—in faith, in speech, in knowledge, in complete earnestness and in the love we have kindled in you—see that you also excel in this grace of giving. I am not commanding you, but I want to test the sincerity of your love by comparing it with the earnestness of others. For you know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ,, that though he was rich, yet for your sake he became poor, so that you through his poverty might become rich.

Generosity is a familiar concept; hopefully there have been times in all our lives when others have come to us and shown us great kindness. Or there have been times when we have had the opportunity to be generous to others. However, our understanding of generosity it is usually defined by two things, ‘giving’ or ‘receiving’. Although ‘giving’ and ‘receiving’ are integral parts of generosity, we need to understand that as far as the bible is concerned generosity is so much more than this. You could even say that the giving and receiving components of generosity are more the consequences or the fruit of generosity.

Generosity is first and foremost a deep rooted characteristic that should be the distinguishing feature of people who are known as Christians. Generosity is the essence of community. A group of people cannot become a community of God if generosity is not a tangible growing reality. So we want to explore an example of generosity from the bible and try and grasp what it really is.

2 Corinthians 8-9 is probably the best exposition of generosity you are ever going to come across. Before we look at these verses we need to say a few things

Paul is using the Macedonian churches (Philippi and Thessalonica) as an example to encourage the church in Corinth to continue to collect money for the poor in Jerusalem. The Christians in Jerusalem had suffered greatly. They were ostracized by their communities which meant that they lost all opportunity to sell their goods or trade; they were also prohibited from buying everyday things like food, clothing, and other essentials. Their problem was made worse by a severe famine that had devastated the whole area of Judea.

Paul is not using the example of the Macedonian churches to make the Christians in Corinth feel guilty or ashamed. Rather he wanted them to see how the power of grace leads to authentic generosity. The Christians in Macedonia lived in extreme poverty, but they gave, and gave. Often in church circles guilt is the chief fund raiser. People use this passage, and they misuse story of the widow’s mite to wrongly motivate people. When Jesus saw this poor widow given all she had in Mark 12:41-43 he was so appalled and disgusted by such a religious system that abused the vulnerable he never went back to the temple after that.

When the translators translated 2 Corinthians 8-9 they used the word generous to translate two very different Greek words. The first word is Haplotēs which means arising out of purity of mind”. In other words, this ‘giving’ to those in need arose from pure intentions. See 2 Cor 8:1, 9:11 9:13. It could be understood as focused.

I don’t think God wants our generosity to be expressed in the same way we pay tax. There needs to be intentionality about generosity.

The second word eulogia means to bless, to praise or celebrate. These two words are two sides of the same ‘coin.’ The first word describes the character of the generous person, while the second word describes the effect on others a generous person has.

Remember the point of this passage is to encourage the Church in Corinth to care for the poor Christians in Jerusalem. It seems that in his word God encourages voluntary giving for his work, but compulsory giving to the poor. In the New Testament Christians are encouraged to give to the poor see Matthew 5:42 Acts 20:35, Romans 12:13, Galatians 2:9-10, Ephesians 4:28, Hebrews 13:16, James 1:27. They are also told that they should provide for those who teach Galatians 6:6, 1Timothy 5:17-18 1Corinthians 9:1-14. If you read this passage carefully it is interesting what is not said. Using the Church of Macedonia as an example of generosity Paul says nothing what so ever about how much they gave, it seems that the amount they gave was irrelevant.

Father may generosity be an indicator you are changing my heart.

title: generosity part 3

html:
Understanding Generosity.

2 Corinthians 8:1-9 And now, brothers and sisters, we want you to know about the grace that God has given the Macedonian churches. In the midst of a very severe trial, their overflowing joy and their extreme poverty welled up in rich generosity. For I testify that they gave as much as they were able, and even beyond their ability. Entirely on their own, they urgently pleaded with us for the privilege of sharing in this service to the Lord’s people. And they exceeded our expectations: They gave themselves first of all to the Lord, and then by the will of God also to us. So we urged Titus, just as he had earlier made a beginning, to bring also to completion this act of grace on your part. But since you excel in everything—in faith, in speech, in knowledge, in complete earnestness and in the love we have kindled in you—see that you also excel in this grace of giving. I am not commanding you, but I want to test the sincerity of your love by comparing it with the earnestness of others. For you know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ,, that though he was rich, yet for your sake he became poor, so that you through his poverty might become rich.

Paul had a lot to say about the heart behind their Giving. They gave because they had experienced the grace of God. ‘And now brothers we want you to know about the grace God has given the Macedonian churches.’

The grace of God in someone’s life will always have a radical effect. Generosity is the result of God’s grace transforming a person’s heart. When we allow the grace of God to transform our hearts our whole perspective about ourselves and our world view are completely changed. We discover a truth that we had never known be fore.

We discover that we are completely loved. No matter what we do, or don’t do God will always love us. This love produces in us a deep feeling of security.

We discover that the things we possess and the things we achieve can never add value to us as people. This is really important, because we hold on tight to things and positions because we believe that these things are an integral part of our value as people.

We discover that all people are worth loving because we are people made in the image of God

They gave despite their own pain. ‘Out of the most severe trial.’ The word “affliction” ‘severe trial’ (THLIPSIS) in the Greek literally refers to pressure as in crushing grapes. Figuratively, in light of this context it would describe the extreme pressure the Macedonians were under while engaging in their generous giving. Paul does not say what the trial is he is referring to but we do know from other scriptures that the churches in Macedonia were persecuted.

“For you, brethren, became imitators of the churches of God in Christ Jesus that are in Judea, for you also endured the same sufferings at the hands of your own countrymen, even as they did from the Jews, who both killed the Lord Jesus and the prophets, and drove us out.” So, what was the nature of the ordeal that was afflicting the churches of Macedonia? The Macedonian believers were being persecuted by their own countrymen in a similar manner as their Jewish brethren in Judea had been persecuted by their countrymen (1 Thessalonians 2:14-15.)

These believers were in the most severe trial despite being filled with the grace of God. The grace of God is not a panacea for all our problems. It will not take away all our trouble, but it will help us to respond to others in a healthy manner without becoming bitter, angry or selfish.

They gave out of overflowing joy. They gave out of hearts that were filled with joy. Joy is more than an emotion, it is proof of spiritual growth and maturity. It is not the consequence of circumstances; rather it is the result of the fruit of the Spirit growing in someone’s life. See Galatians 5:22. The best way to understand this kind of Joy is to realise that the opposite of this Joy is not sadness but hopelessness. I think it would be difficult to be mean spirited and have joy in your heart at the same time. Joy breaks down the walls that separate people, it empowers people to see beyond themselves and take the needs of others seriously.

It is interesting to note that Jesus spoke most about his own joy on the night before his cruel death on the cross than at any other time. The word Paul uses for joy comes from the word that means grace.

Father help me understand that generosity has nothing to do with circumstances or bank balance.

Bible in a year: Matthew 8:1-10:15
