html:
Understanding Generosity.

2 Corinthians 8:1-9 And now, brothers and sisters, we want you to know about the grace that God has given the Macedonian churches. In the midst of a very severe trial, their overflowing joy and their extreme poverty welled up in rich generosity. For I testify that they gave as much as they were able, and even beyond their ability. Entirely on their own, they urgently pleaded with us for the privilege of sharing in this service to the Lord’s people. And they exceeded our expectations: They gave themselves first of all to the Lord, and then by the will of God also to us. So we urged Titus, just as he had earlier made a beginning, to bring also to completion this act of grace on your part. But since you excel in everything—in faith, in speech, in knowledge, in complete earnestness and in the love we have kindled in you—see that you also excel in this grace of giving. I am not commanding you, but I want to test the sincerity of your love by comparing it with the earnestness of others. For you know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ,, that though he was rich, yet for your sake he became poor, so that you through his poverty might become rich.

The opportunity to be generous has nothing to do with the resources a person may or may not have. These Christians gave even though they were living in extreme poverty. The meaning behind these words is destitution. People often have a ‘if only’ attitude when it comes to generosity. They think ‘if only had I more I could do more, or give more.’ But this completely misses the point. If our hearts are full of grace and joy then even if we have little we will have enough to be generous. The important thing about this word used for poverty is that it is the same word that is used to describe the deliberate Intention of the Lord Jesus. ‘For you know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ that though he was rich, yet for your sakes he became poor, so that you through his poverty might become rich.’ 2 Corinthians 8:9

Their generosity was not caused by external pressure but internal desire. ‘For I testify that they gave as much as they were able, and even beyond their ability. Entirely on their own. They urgently pleaded with us for the privilege of sharing in this service to the saints.’ Often we see people begging for help, but these people were begging to give help. Why would they be so eager to give?

The life of God was so much at work in the hearts of these people that it could not be contained. The extravagant, uncontainable generosity of God erupted out of their lives; it was a spontaneous expression of the ongoing work of God in their hearts. This is so freeing, because guilt and shame could never reproduce this kind of generosity. Guilt motivated generosity is like trying to feed the hungry with stale bread. Guilt defiles or soils generosity, it robs it of its glory or beauty, making it into a subtle expression of selfishness.

Their generosity to others was consistent with giving themselves to the Lord. ‘They did not do as we expected, but they gave themselves first to the Lord and then to us in keeping with God’s will.’ Let me ask us this question, when did you last give yourself to the Lord? I am not talking about conversion, but the continual ongoing giving yourself to him.

Every one of us has opportunities and a need to live generous lives. We are never more alive or more God-like when we are displaying grace motivated generosity. There is only one thing that will prevent us from being generous that is the condition of our hearts. sometimes our lack of resources can be more of a help than a hindrance to generosity, for in having little to give we are more free to give ourselves. It is good to share practically and financially with others, but sometimes in doing that we don’t really give ourselves.

Our English word for generous `Comes from the Latin generosus which means ‘of noble birth.’ Noble can mean an exalted moral character or excellence. I like that. Through generosity we give birth to a life that is distinguished, a life that is attractive, and a life that makes others stop and say ‘I wish I was like that!’

Father may I have an excellent character

Bible in a year: Matthew 10:16-12:21.
title: study topic generosity part 5

html:
In Matthew 6 Jesus is exposing the false religion of the hypocrite.

“A hypocrite is not a person who falls short of their high ideas or occasionally sins, because all Christians experience these failures. A hypocrite deliberately uses religion to cover up their sins and promote their own gains.” Warren W. Wiersbe. Source unknown.

Then Jesus goes on to describe the materialist. Why? The hypocrite and the materialist work from the same premise, they reflect the same attitudes, they think in the same way.

They both put a lot of emphasis on the external.

They both look for life and approval outside of God.

They both are self-absorbed.

They both suffer from anxiety.

They both have an inability to deal with the real issues of the heart.

They both look for reward in this life, not in the life to come.

They both use false worship to hide what is really going on in their hearts.

Materialism is the natural consequence of faulty religious practices. In the first eighteen verses of Matthew 6 Jesus exposes the faulty and unfulfilling religious practices of those who never really had a relationship with God. To be involved in religiosity and not really know God will drive a person into materialism, in the hope that they will find life. It is no coincidence that many of the Pharisees of Jesus’ day were very wealthy. Their empty religion made money and possessions more important.

WHAT IS MATERIALISM?

Of all the modern addictions that are anaesthetising the 21st century, materialism is the one that the vast majority of the Christian church has got hooked on. Many Christians have fallen for the lie that what a person has gives a person value or contentment. Materialism is primarily a matter of reversed priorities. You cannot identify a materialist by an audit, but only by exposing his attitudes.

Father am I materialist at heart

Bible in a year: Matthew 12:22-14:12
title: materialism part 1
study_refs: The hypocrite and materialist are two expressions of the same kind of person.

html:
Materialism is the result of perverted values. Matthew 6:19-21

“Do not store up for yourself treasures on earth, where moth and rust destroy and where thieves break in and steal.” Matthew 6:19 Jesus is not banning possessions or condemning wealth; nor is he saying we should not save for a rainy day but he is saying that we should not put our identity, hope or security in earthly treasure.

In Jesus’ day, when the nation of Rome conquered a country, it took the contents of the national treasury. But they allowed individual persons to keep their freedom in their homelands and accumulate personal wealth on their own. As well of having a nation full of slaves, Rome allso had a nation full of individuals who were taxed on the additional treasure they could accumulate through their own ingenuity. People were encouraged to accumulate wealth because the more wealth they had, the more taxes Rome could get. The problem that arose was that people used their new personal wealth to define themselves. It defined: -

1. What you could do,2. Who you associated with,3. How well you ate,4. What kind of home you could live in,5. Your prestige in the community, 6. Your perception of yourself.

A person’s value and worth became related to how much wealth they had. Furthermore the problem was made even more complicated by the teachings of the Rabbi’s, who believed that the more wealth you had the more you were blessed of God. In the mind of Jesus this was perverted thinking. I think, that people, who struggle with accepting themselves, feeling crushed by a low self-image, will often pursue a materialistic lifestyle, believing it will add value to them as people.

Jesus exposes the folly of this thinking by giving three word pictures.

Moth eaten clothes.

Most of the garments that were prized in Jesus' day were made out of wool, which was expensive. If a person invested a large portion of their money and wealth in the accumulation of woollen garments or cloth, they ran a risk of it being destroyed. Many of the Israelites had one or two garments, which were constantly worn. But, the individual who had acquired many garments would discover after coming back to his collection after many weeks there were holes in them which rendered them useless.

Rusty goods

The Greek word for 'rust' (*brosis*) actually means 'eating'; it could refer to the corrosion caused by rust, but it also could apply to any devouring pest or vermin.

Stolen goods

In Jesus' day treasures were hidden in holes dug in the dirt floors of the home, or placed in compartments in the walls of a home. They were easy pickings for thieves with hammers and shovels who would dig through the wall, or dig into the ground in order to steal the treasure.

If we consider our material possessions as treasures then we are going to end up very disappointed and disillusioned people.

To have our heart set on treasure on earth is the result of outright deception, which will lead to frustration, disillusionment and a nagging anxiety.

Jesus says “But store up for yourself treasure in heaven.” What does this mean?

It means that the things that are important to God become life shaping and motivational for living.

It means that we will not look for life or fulfilment in the things we own, or in what we do.

It means that our emotional lives will be directed and controlled by a pursuit for righteousness.

It means that we will have a strong compulsion to invest our lives in the needs of others.

In the days of the terrible Decian persecution in Rome, the Roman authorities broke into a Christian church. They were out to loot the treasures they believed the church possessed. The Roman commander demanded from Laurentius, the deacon, "Show me your treasures at once!" Laurentius pointed at the widows and orphans who were being fed, and others who were being helped by the church, and he said, "These are the treasures of the church."

Jesus goes on to say, “For where your treasure is there you heart will be also.” One commentator wrote: -

“If a person’s real treasure, his ultimate aim in all his striving, is something pertaining to this earth the acquisition of money, fame, popularity, prestige, power-then his heart, the very centre of his life, will be completely absorbed in that mundane object. All of his activities, including even the so-called religious, will be subservient to this one goal.’ Mathen.

We may suppose that materialism is an undue desire for luxuries, but Jesus identifies it with an undue concern over necessities, such as food and clothing. As such we are all materialists..

Father free my heart from any undue concern over the material essentials of life.

Bible in a year: Matthew 1413-17:13
title: materialism part 2
study_refs: How does Jesus define materialism?

If most of us were asked to give a definition of materialism, I don’t think many of us would come up with the same definition or understanding as Jesus. Materialism in philosophy, is a widely held system of thought that explains the nature of the world as entirely dependent on matter, the final reality. (The Concise Columbia Encyclopaedia, Columbia University Press. Copyright © 1995 by Columbia University Press).
In verses 19-24 Jesus states three things that expose the true nature of materia lism.

html:
“The eye is the lamp of the body, if you eyes are good your whole body will be full of light. But if you eyes are bad your whole body will be full of darkness. If the light within you is darkness, how great is that darkness.”

The poet William Blake correctly points out that we do not see with the eye but through it. The eye is merely the instrument by which we focus and illumine the material presented to us. It is the person behind the eye who sees. The eye becomes a gate that determines what we will allow entrance into our lives. This ‘evil eye’ is known to have been representative of covetousness, envy and meanness in ancient times. It is similar to our expression “Green eyed monster”

In the Message these verses read.

“Your eyes are the window into your body. If you open your eyes wide in wonder and belief, your body fills with light. If you live squinty-eyed in greed and distrust, your body is a dark cellar. If you pull the blinds on your windows, what a dark life you have.”

The implications of these verses are staggering. If our perception of life is that of a materialist, the effect of that will be darkness in every other area of our lives. Having a materialists perception on life is not a benign thing. Materialism is a disease that effects the whole of life.

We become selfish.

We encourage greed.

People become dispensable like other commodities.

What we have becomes more important than relationships.

We evaluate others by what they have, not by who they are.

Priorities become confused.

Morals become corrupted.

The point of these verses is that materialism is not some minor flaw in one’s thinking. It is like a virus that has entered into our bloodstream. It detrimentally affects the whole person. As such, it must be taken seriously.

This is why Paul could say “The love of money if the ROOT of ALL evil.”

Father help me to recognise that to try and quench my thirst though materialism is drinking from a poisoned well

Bible in a year: Matthew 17:14-20:34
title: materialism part 3
study_refs: Materialism is the result of bad vision

html:
“No one can serve two masters. Either he will hate the one and love the other, or he will be devoted to the one and despise the other. You cannot serve both God and money.

We need to remember whom Jesus is speaking to here. He wasn’t speaking to men and women who had vast treasures stored away at home and who had holidays in the corners of the Roman Empire at their own expense! He was speaking to men and women like you and me actually, who were a lot poorer than most of us will probably ever be. These were peoplee who worked for a living and who would have often have struggled to make ends meet

It would be a mistake to think that Jesus is only addressing those who have a lot of material possessions. But Jesus is addressing is the person who does not put their trust and hope in God, but in material possessions and financial security.

To help us understand this, we need to look at the word used for Money in this verse. Some of the older translations use the word mamon.

“The word mamon had a most curious and a most revealing history. It comes from a root that means to entrust; and mamon was that which a man entrusted to a banker or to a safe deposit of some kind. Mamon was the wealth that a man entrusted to someone to keep safe for him. But as the years went on mamon came to mean, not that which is entrusted, but that in which a man puts his trust. The end of the process was that mamon came to be spelled with a capital M and came to be regarded as nothing less than a god.” William Barclay, The Gospel of Matthew (Edinburgh: The Saint Andrew Press, 1963), I, p. 252.

It is impossible to be a Christian who is fully committed to God and be a materialist at the same time. The hypocrite and the materialist are inseparable. One produces the other, they feed of each other

Father their nothing good about being a hypocrite or a materialist.

title: materialism part 4
study_refs: Materialism is a form of idolatry Matthew 6:24

html:
(The story of Bartimeus. Part 1

While on this journey Jesus did something that was amazing. He stopped. He put his journey on hold. He suspended the eternal purposes of God for a few seconds to respond to the holler in the dark. Jesus stopped to respond to the cries of a man called Blind Bartimeus.

Bartimeus was a very interesting and unique person. He is the only named person in the bible who Jesus healed. The reason why he is named is because his name tells us a lot about him. In the time of Jesus a person’s name was more than a title, it was more like a description of the person. Bartimeus means ‘son of Timaeus’ or ‘son of honour.’ We know nothing about his back ground, but with a name like Bartimeus it is safe to assume that he was not always a beggar that he had not always lived as an outcast. As a blind beggar he would have been filled with shame as he lived in his own dark world, a world that was so isolated, a world that the nameless, faceless crowd on their way to a religious feast in Jerusalem could not enter into or care about.

Try and imagine what life must had been like for Bartimeus, homeless and dark. Some one who was despised looked down upon. Then Jesus comes into his life, and he experiences the power of grace and Devine acceptance.

Father thank you for this amazing story about Jesus who stopped on his way to the cross for a blind beggar.

Bible in a year: Matthew 23:1-25:13
title: The Holler in the dark.
study_refs: Jesus is making his way to Jerusalem; He is going there to fulfil all the purposes of his father. This was the most important journey that was ever made by anyone in history. It was more important than Neil Armstrong’s journey to the moon, more important than Edmund Hillary’s journey to the top of Everest, more important than Columbus journey on the Santa Maria when he discovered America. It was even more important that the journey Princess Elizabeth made to Westminster Abbey to be crowned Queen. This journey was more important than any journey you or I will ever make. We have all made important Journeys, some wonderful, some dark and sad. But nothing like this journey, for at the end of this journey history would be redefined, and the world will never be the same. Jesus was journeying to Jerusalem where he would die on a cross in order to free mankind from the power of sin and Satan.

html:
(The story of Bartimeus. Part 2

So out of the darkness comes this heart wrenching cry. ‘Son of David have mercy on me.’ The religious crowd try to shut him up, try to silence him, they want to ignore his plight and take away his voice. They wanted to control him by using harsh words, [ “Be quiet!” many of the people yelled at him.] The Greek word for yelled is epitimao which carries the idea, to find fault with, to censure severely, to rebuke, to express strong disapproval of, or to denounce. Jesus’ reaction was completely different, he stopped. The heart of Jesus is touched by this man’s desperate cry, so he stops.

He stops and invites the man into his space, into his world. He calls Bartimeus from his darkness and his shame. Jesus stop’s in the middle of this epic journey to ask this lonely, shameful beggar ‘What can I do for you?’

He stops to listen, to listen to Bartimeus cry, his heart, his longing, his request. He creates time to listen. In the middle of noise, activity, mayhem and crowds, Jesus stops to engage, encourage and enrich the life of a humiliated beggar.

Mark tells us that Bartimaeus threw aside his coat, jumped up, and came to Jesus. Mark 10:50. This cloak was an item of clothing, that defined that he was a beggar. It was like his permission slip or a licence to be sitting there begging for money. If you were wearing a cloak like that it showed the people around you that you were a beggar. It was his identity. In biblical days, being blind was often seen as a curse. There was really no way to support yourself financially, so beggars were given cloaks, which gave them permission to beg. Beggars were defined as such by the cloak they wore. Usually, the cloak was the beggar’s one and only possession and their only source of income. Notice that Bartimeus throw away his cloak before he was healed. Often as Christians we say to God, ‘If you do this for me I will….’Sometimes we need to throw away the ‘symbols’ ‘cloaks’ of our past so we can really follow Jesus.

Jesus is never blinded to the needs of others by his pressing responsibilities or chaotic activity that may be going on around him, Jesus will always find time to stop.

Father thank you despite our circumstances Jesus is never blind to our needs or deaf to out cry.

Bible in a year: Matthew 25:14-26:68
title: The Holler in the dark.
study_refs: We also know that Bartimeus was not always blind. When Bartimeaus said to Jesus, ‘Rabbi I want to see’ the word used means to see again. We don’t know why he went blind, but we do know that in culture and at that time blindness was understood as a form of punishment for some kind of wrong behaviour.

html:
Peter’s experience of Jesus up to this point was wonderful, but it wasn’t sufficient to sustain a lifelong whole hearted devotion to Jesus. Peter’s thinking and perspective on life were completely reoriented by an experience of the holiness of Jesus. This was a ‘light bulb’ moment in Peter’s life. So as Peter began to haul in that huge catch of fish, a lot of lights went on, and Peter’s world was never the same. It was an experience that brought clarification and deep understanding. As Peter was struggling with this huge catch of fish, he was in the process of grasping truths that he up to now was unable to grasp. Sometimes the purpose of the blessings of God is to expose our sin.

Father thank you that sometimes you use miraculous provision to expose how terrible or hearts are.

Bible in a year: Matthew 26:69-28:20
title: Jesus catches Peter Part 1
study_refs: The Context of this story.

Some people read this story as Jesus calling Peter to follow Him: they see it as Peter’s initial call to leave all he has and to follow him, however I don’t think that is the case. At this time Peter had a relationship with Jesus, he knew and loved Jesus. If we were to look at the other gospels we know a number of things about Peter’s relationship with Jesus.
Peter was introduced to Jesus by his brother Andrew. John 1:41
Peter had been promised by Jesus that he would be changed and transformed by Jesus. John 1:42
Peter had some desire to follow Jesus. See Matthew 4:18-19. At this time Peter had an incomplete understanding of what it meant to follow Jesus fully.
Jesus spent time in Peter’s home, and while he was there Jesus healed Peter’s mother in law. Luke 4:38-39.

html:
Jesus invaded Peter’s space.

We are told by Luke that Jesus ‘saw two boats left there by the fishermen. He got into one of the boats, the one belonging to Simon. He asked Simon to put out a little from the shore. Then he sat down and taught the people from the boat.’ Five times in the story Luke refers to the boats, and his last reference he mentions that the boats were beginning to sink. Why so much emphasis on the boats?

The boat was a symbol of Peter’s identity, livelihood and significance. Jesus had been in Peter’s house, Luke 4:38. But now Jesus was going to invade Peter’s personal space. Peter’s boat was where he was in charge, where he was in control. It was where he could be himself, where he knew what to do and how to do it. His boat was his badge of competence, his sphere of proficiency, a representation of his expertise. Getting into Peter’s boat was Jesus’ way of getting to the very heart Peter.

The second thing that Jesus did was to teach Peter that his work in Peter’s life could not be confined or defined by Peter’s understanding or experience. Everything that Jesus asked Peter to do was contrary to all Peter’s training, understanding and experience as a professional fisherman. To go out onto the lake in the middle of the day with the hope of catching fish was a waste of time and energy.

Peter was going to learn that Jesus has the ability and the right to work outside the normal confines of the conventional. Neither Jesus nor his dealings with us can be boxed, neatly packaged or conveniently pigeon-holed, by the limitations of our understanding or experience.

As the tons of fish began to enter Peter’s nets, it dawned on Peter that Jesus had not only the power to heal people and exorcise demons, but he had control over the whole of creation, even the allusive fish that Peter and his friends were unable to net on the previous night. In verse 8 Peter refers to Jesus as Lord which means authoritative ownership. His evaluation and understanding of who Jesus was underwent a substantial change from master to Lord. In doing so he was giving him the supreme place in his life; he was pledging him implicit obedience and reverent worship..

Father may I know Jesus as my Lord

Bible in a year: Mark 1-3
title: Jesus catches Peter Part 2
study_refs: Before we look at how this revelation affected Peter, let us just mention how it came about. Without retelling the story I just want us to notice two ways in which Jesus prepared Peter’s heart for a deeper understanding of him.

html:
It is more necessary for us as Christians to experience the holiness of God than the power of God. There is something inside all of us that longs for a transforming experience of holiness. To be holy is to discover God’s original intention for our lives.

Peter got a new perspective on what was important in life. Luke tells us that Peter left everything and followed Jesus. He left his boat and nets, symbols of his security and identity. But he not only left his boats and nets, he left nets that were brimming with fish, he left a lucrative business, he left financial security. His leaving was a decisive break from all that was known, to pursue the unknown and the uncertain. The leaving everything meant that Peter’s whole value system changed, what was once important and essential for him became like discarded refuge on a beach.

The forth effect that this revelation had on Peter is probable the most noticeable if not the most radical, for it changed how Peter related to others, it increased Peter’s ability to relate to those who by culture and religious orientation where totally opposed to Peter and all that his religious heritage stood for.

If you read the rest in Luke 5 you will notice that Peter began to associate with people who he would never have associated with before. He met a paralysed man whom Jesus healed. In this culture he would have been viewed as the worst kind of sinner and his illness seen as punishment for sin. Next Peter met Levi who was a chief tax-collector and seen as a traitor and collaborator with the oppressive Romans. Because Peter experienced Grace he was able to move beyond his comfort zone and relate to people who at one time he would have hated and despised.

Father may I have an honest evaluation of myself so I can accept others

Bible in a year: Mark 4-5.
title: Jesus catches Peter Part 3
study_refs: At this time Peter got a revelation not only of Jesus, but also of himself.

He began to see himself as he had never seen himself before. He said to Jesus: “Go way from me Lord for I am a Sinful man.” It would be very easy to miss the full impact of what Peter is saying, he is redefining himself. He is seeing himself as he really is, i.e. with the blinkers removed, the blind spots revealed. This was a moment of clarity and honesty; this was an unveiling of Peter’s heart and an acknowledgement of Jesus’ holiness. In this confession he is saying, I am unworthy to be in your presence, he is confessing his need of mercy and grace. ‘He understands that sin produces distance between himself and God. Surely God wants nothing to do with a simple, sinful fisherman. It is best that Jesus go.

html:
We are all familiar with the story of how Peter denied Jesus three times, it is one of the few stories that is recorded in all the four gospels. The reasons why all four Gospel writers may have included this story is to warn us that we have all got the potential to be like Peter and deny Jesus. It one thing to start the Christian race, but it is quite another to finish it. Sadly none of us has any guarantee of finishing the race well. We all know people who started off on the Christian life, and now they live far from God. We want to look at Peter’s denial and hope we can learn some lessons from it.

Peter would have been the last person others would have expected to deny Jesus; he was the most prominent of all the disciples. Often he expressed his desire to follow Jesus, even lay down his life for Jesus. If we had not known that Jesus had said that Peter would deny him three times, we would have all been surprised or even shocked by his denial.

Peter’s denial of Jesus is a concentrated example of denial. When we read about how Peter denied that he knew Jesus, it is very stark, very blatant, and it gives the appearance of happening suddenly. I doubt few of us have denied Jesus in such a public and forceful way. There is a temptation to distance ourselves from Peter’s experience. However, the elements that went to make up Peter’s denial are found in every denial of Jesus, but they may not be as blatant.

Father I acknowledge like Peter I have the potential to deny Jesus, I pray that I never will.

Bible in a year: Mark 6-7
title: Peter’s denial of Jesus. Part 1
study_refs: In post-Depression American thousands of young servicemen and civilians streamed to arenas to see the programs, which included preaching, music, and various acts. One of the leaders in this movement was a young man from Canada, Charles Templeton, born in 1915. He was generally acknowledged to be the most versatile of the new young evangelists. Templeton soon rose to prominence, even surpassing another dynamic young preacher, Billy Graham. In 1946, he was listed among those best used of God by the National Association of Evangelicals. In 1996 i n his autobiography, Farewell to God , Charles Templeton lists his ‘reasons for rejecting the Christian faith.’

html:
What does denial look like?

The best way to answer that question is to get Jesus’ perspective on denial, to try and see it the way He does.

When Jesus predicts Peter’s denial the first thing Jesus tells Peter and the rest of the apostles that. “This very night you will all fall away on account of me.’ (Matthew 26:31.) When Jesus speaks of falling away he is thinking of these men being caught in a trap. The word used for ‘fall away, is skandalon from where we get our English word Scandal. Skandalon in Greek literally meant the wooden stick that would hold up one edge of a metal box-trap. Food would be put under the box. An animal would be tempted by the food to enter the trap. Then the hunter would stay a significant distance away, hidden from view. The hunter would then use a small string that was holding the skandalon stick. The hunter would pull on the string, causing the skandalon stick to collapse. The box-trap would fall, and the animal’s whole body would normally be trapped inside. The animal would be skandlised.

In other words, denial of Jesus is an expression of being trapped.

When we loose our freedom and become enslaved to something we are denying Jesus his rightful place.

The word also carries the idea of being offended or ashamed about someone else, as we shall see shortly, Peter may have been feeling ashamed, disappointed and confused about Jesus when he denied him.

In other words, denial of Jesus is an expression of being trapped. When we loose our freedom and become enslaved to something we are denying Jesus his rightful place.

Jesus uses a second word that gives us insight into how He perceives denial. Speaking to Peter Jesus said, “I tell you the truth this very night, before the rooster crows you will disown me three times. Matthew 26:34 The verb "aparneomai" (commonly translated "disowns") comes from the realm of legal and property transactions, and it means to renounce a relationship with someone or a claim upon property.

To deny Jesus is to treat him as a disregarded commodity, it is to treat Him as if he was something we had finished with, or we no longer wanted.

Father our denial of Jesus not only traps us but it also makes Jesus feel like a commodity.

Bible in a year: Mark 8:1-10:12
title: Peter’s denial of Jesus. Part 2
study_refs: What does it mean to deny Jesus?

html:
Reading the story of Peter’s denial, you could easily get the impression that it was a spontaneous event that just happened out of the blue, but that was not the case, and never is the case; all denial is rooted in the past.

On the night of Jesus’ betrayal and arrest Peter displayed a number of attitudes that contributed to his fall.

Peter was defensive rather than teachable. When Jesus said “This night before the rooster crows you will disown me three times.” Peter’s response was “Even if I have to die with you I will never disown you.” Peter was not prepared to listen; he was not prepared to evaluate his own heart. He could not cope with someone speaking into his life. He resented and rejected what Jesus was saying. I think we all have the capacity to fool ourselves; we all have significant blind spots that require the help and input of others to expose.

Peter was proud instead of being humble. John Stott once said “Pride is our greatest enemy while humility is our greatest friend.’” At its essence pride is an indication that our thinking about ourselves is wrong.

Peter was confused and uncertain about how to handle the pressures of this night. Peter loved Jesus, but in his confusion he made some choices that contributed to his denial. In Mark 14:50 we are told, “Every one forsook him and fled.” This included Peter. Then we read that “Peter followed him at a distance” 14:54. He initially fled, then he changed his mind, then he followed Jesus from a distance, his heart and his head were all over the place. He tried to find some middle ground between following and not following. He was looking for some kind of compromise. He loved Jesus but he could not allow his love for Jesus to dominate his life because of his pride and defensive nature.

Father help me to accept that I need to follow you whole heartily, there is no other way.

Bible in a year: Mark 10:13-12:12
title: Peter’s denial of Jesus. Part 3
study_refs: The roots of denial.

html:
His first challenge

The first challenge differs in form between the accounts, but the essence is the same; a young slave girl asks Peter whether he is one of Jesus’ disciples. This seems to have taken place relatively privately, and the challenge comes from someone who poses relatively little threat, a young girl with little power. The form of her question is hesitant, using a form of words that expects a negative answer, which makes it easier for Peter to deny than affirm. Peter takes the route the questioner steered him towards, and denies it, with each writer giving a different expression to his denial.

His second challenge

The second challenge, in a very similar form but in a more public context, comes from the same maid (Luke), another maid (Matt, Mark), or from the general company around the fire (John). One may imagine that these accounts represent a coherent story, with the girl who challenged him before, starting the challenge and the men around her then following it up. This was a more pressured situation than the first challenge. Peter denies Jesus again, Mark adding that the denial was with an oath.

Third challenge

A man in the courtyard makes the third challenge, and is far more immediately threatening to Peter’s personal safety. Note how the temptations have become ever more difficult to handle. Matthew Mark and Luke say the challenge is that Peter is a disciple, because he was a Galilean, on account of his accent. John however tells us that, the person making the challenge is a relative of the slave who had his ear cut off by Peter earlier, and he is saying that Peter had been in the garden and therefore had to be a disciple of Jesus. That was very threatening, for this man has a personal reason to hate him.

Many people reading the account of Peter’s denial conclude that the reason why he disowned Jesus at this time was because of fear. We think fear may have been a factor, but not the main factor. Peter is not portrayed as a fearful man. He was willing to stick his neck out when other disciples held back. It was Peter who walked on the water (maybe foolishly} while the rest watched from the safety of the boat. It was Peter who not only promised to stay with Jesus even unto death, but also was the first and only one to draw his sword and use it. In the Garden, Peter was willing to die for His Master. And think of the odds—one man, one sword against an entire crowd, heavily armed. That doesn’t look like fear to me.

Peter finds himself in the middle of the enemy camp, he is in a situation where he is out of his depth, and consequently very vulnerable. Here he was having a major paradigm shift. When Peter saw the object of his worship and loyalty, his God and Messiah humbly submitting to gross injustice; Peter’s understanding of Messiah’s predicted power and His coming kingdom fell apart. Everything Peter lived for, power over the Jews and Romans, the prestige of a high office, exaltation as a hand picked disciple of Jesus, bravery, valour, courage and victory over the enemies of Jesus – evaporated right before his eyes.

There are a number of consequences of denying Jesus that we should mention.

Denial breeds denial. It is rarely that any denial of Jesus is a one off isolated incident; it usually starts off small and like a rolling snowball gets bigger and bigger. Denying Jesus in small things usually proceeds to greater denial.

Denial of Jesus will usually mean we will have to lie about ourselves. Luke tells us that when Peter was asked. “You also are one of them,” Man I am not.” Peter replied. Luke 22:58. When any one of us begins to live a life that denies Jesus, we will cease to be honest with ourselves, and begin to deny who we really are.

Denying Jesus will bring out the worse in us. The word that Matthew uses in 26:74 for curse is katanathematizo. This is the only time this word is used in the bible; it literally means to curse vehemently. At this time Peter was very angry and out of control. Before he met Jesus he was a rough Galilean fisherman and in denying Jesus all his sinful habits began to come to the surface.

Denying Jesus will lead to bitter brokenness. Try and see this Galilean fisherman standing in the cold on a dark and terrible night, howling and weeping in absolute horror. Few of us like to see men crying, but Peter could not contain himself, for in the cold of that terrible night, Peter discovered who he really was. The pain of self-discovery became the catalyst for a life that was to depend on grace. The sobs and howls of this broken man would be the means by which he would go on to live by grace.

The steps to denial are usually small but significant. If we are going to remain faithful to Jesus, then let us encourage you with a number of statements.

“Examine yourself to see whether you are in the faith: test yourself. Do you realize that Christ Jesus is in you? Unless, of course you fail the test.” 2Corinthians 13:5

“So if you think you are standing firm, be careful that you don’t fall.” 1Corinthians 10:12.

Do you want to love Jesus with all of your heart for all of your life?

“Examine yourself to see whether you are in the faith: test yourself. Do you realize that Christ Jesus is in you? Unless, of course you fail the test.” 2Corinthians 13:5

“So if you think you are standing firm, be careful that you don’t fall.” 1Corinthians 10:12.

Do you want to love Jesus with all of your heart for all of your life?

Father may I never know the terrible consequences that denying Jesus brings into a persons life.

Luke 10:1-16

After this the Lord appointed seventy-two others and sent them two by two ahead of him to every town and place where he was about to go. He told them,“The harvest is plentiful, but the workers are few. Ask the Lord of the harvest, therefore, to send out workers into his harvest field. Go! I am sending you out like lambs among wolves. Do not take a purse or bag or sandals; and do not greet anyone on the road. When you enter a house, first say, ‘Peace to this house. If someone who promotes peace is there, your peace will rest on them; if not, it will return to you Stay there, eating and drinking whatever they give you, for the worker deserves his wages. Do not move around from house to house. “When you enter a town and are welcomed, eat what is offered to you. Heal the sick who are there and tell them, ‘The kingdom of God has come near to you.’ But when you enter a town and are not welcomed, go into its streets and say, ‘Even the dust of your town we wipe from our feet as a warning to you. Yet be sure of this: The kingdom of God has come near.’ I tell you, it will be more bearable on that day for Sodom than for that town. “Woe to you, Chorazin! Woe to you, Bethsaida! For if the miracles that were performed in you had been performed in Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long ago, sitting in sackcloth and ashes. But it will be more bearable for Tyre and Sidon at the judgment than for you. And you, Capernaum, will you be lifted to the heavens? No, you will go down to Hades. “Whoever listens to you listens to me; whoever rejects you rejects me; but whoever rejects me rejects him who sent me.”

For many of us evangelism is a difficult subject. It is something we would love to do, we feel guilty because we don’t do it, and most of us feel scared or uncomfortable about doing it, in case we get it wrong, or we may feel embarrassed or not confident enough to talk about our faith,

As I was looking at Luke 10 I came across a sermon on evangelism which began with this illustration

Near the end of World War II, a plane carrying 24 members of the U.S. military crashed into the dense New Guinea jungle. Only three survived and their condition deteriorated; they were soon suffering from gangrene and starvation. Here they were stranded deep in a jungle valley known for the cannibal tribes who lived there.

A daring rescue attempt was needed, and it did succeed.

The army tapped a special battalion of 66 men, trained as a parachute unit. Their battalion leader was told to recruit 10 volunteers from his unit, including two medics, to parachute into that dense jungle and guide the survivors out.

It was a dangerous assignment. When their lieutenant colonel stood before his men and told them what had happened, he informed them that he needed 10 volunteers to form a rescue squad. But then he gave them an honest portrayal of what they were going to encounter.

First, he said, the area they’d be jumping into was marked “unknown” on the map; it was uncharted territory. Secondly, he told them the jungle valley was so thick that it would be the worst possible drop zone; they might not get past the trees. Third, if they survived the jump, the tribes who lived in that valley could prove hostile and life-threatening.

When he finished, he paused and then asked for volunteers and all 66 men stepped forward.

I understand the sentiment behind this illustration and why it was used. However, this illustration feeds into the false subliminal belief that evangelism is only for the who are perceived to be ‘spiritual’ elite, the ‘SAS’ of the church or young. In calling the seventy two [some version read seventy] Jesus is teaching us that we all have a measure of responsibility when it comes to evangelism.

Father thank you that evangelism needs to be part of my life.

He told them,“The harvest is plentiful, but the workers are few. Ask the Lord of the harvest, therefore, to send out workers into his harvest field. Go! I am sending you out like lambs among wolves. If someone who promotes peace is there, your peace will rest on them; if not, it will return to you Stay there, eating and drinking whatever they give you, for the worker deserves his wages. Do not move around from house to house. “When you enter a town and are welcomed, eat what is offered to you. Heal the sick who are there and tell them, ‘The kingdom of God has come near to you.’ But when you enter a town and are not welcomed, go into its streets and say, ‘Even the dust of your town we wipe from our feet as a warning to you. Yet be sure of this: The kingdom of God has come near.’ I tell you, it will be more bearable on that day for Sodom than for that town. “Woe to you, Chorazin! Woe to you, Bethsaida! For if the miracles that were performed in you had been performed in Tyre and Sidon, they would have repented long ago, sitting in sackcloth and ashes. But it will be more bearable for Tyre and Sidon at the judgment than for you. And you, Capernaum, will you be lifted to the heavens? No, you will go down to Hades. “Whoever listens to you listens to me; whoever rejects you rejects me; but whoever rejects me rejects him who sent me.”

If I were to ask you, what is the primary objective of evangelism. You would Probably reply something like this, ’to see people converted and become Christians.’ I fully understand this reply, but in the light of our passage I am not too sure if the conversion of others is the primary objective of evangelism. Look at what Jesus did in verse 1 After this the Lord appointed seventy-two others. The word appointed is the Greek word anadeiknymi which means to proclaim any one as elected to office. to announce as appointed a king, general, etc. to lift up anything on high and exhibit it for all to behold.. Evangelism is a God appointed way of exalting Jesus.

I wonder what would happen if we were to redefine evangelism as a corporate, organised, opportunity to lift up Jesus by clearly demonstrating him to the World. Would this understanding make it easier to get involved in it?

Praying for evangelism.

I find it fascinating how Jesus tells his followers to pray about evangelism. “The harvest is plentiful, but the workers are few. Ask the Lord of the harvest, therefore, to send out workers into his harvest field. If that had been me talking to these followers of Jesus. I would have encouraged them to pray for the harvest not the workers. This is the second time Jesus asks his followers to ‘Ask the Lord of the harvest, therefore, to send out workers into his harvest field.’ See Matthew 9:38. If Jesus was intending to send the seventy/seventy two out why did he say Ask the Lord of the harvest, therefore, to send out workers into his harvest field.? Luke does say “The harvest is plentiful, but the workers are few. However, I think that we can have a ‘one size fits all’ approach to evangelism. I think every location requires it’s own unique style of evangelism, and when Jesus asks us to pray “Ask the Lord of the harvest to send out workers. We are asking God to send appropriate people into specific places, people who are tailored to reach specific people. The word that is use for ‘ask’ is the Greek word Deomai which describes an earnest, heartfelt plea rising from recognized need. It moves beyond routine petition to an impassioned cry.

Father teach me how to pray about evangelism.

We live in a ‘how do we’ generation. We love to have clear precise instructions as to how to do things. We have been to Ikea and have read the ‘how to’ instructions how to build your flat pact furniture, and if you are anything like me, [totally impractical] then the instructions are of no help. As we read Jesus’ instructions, on the surface they don’t seem very helpful or practical. Look at what he says to his followers. Go! I am sending you out like lambs among wolves. Do not take a purse or bag or sandals; and do not greet anyone on the road. I wonder what you think of these instructions? Are they even relevant to our lives?

Go! I am sending you out like lambs among wolves. Their needs to be a healthy vulnerability about our evangelism. The very vulnerability that puts us of evangelising is a God designed requirement for evangelising. Why? Because the way of Jesus is one of attractive vulnerability that attracts the weak and the broken. It is our vulnerability that makes us accessible to others. I have seen some evangelise like ‘lions among sparrows,’ very aggressive and threatening doing great harm.

Jesus continues by saying Do not take a purse or bag or sandals; Why would Jesus say this? What does he mean? When Jesus says Do not take a purse or bag or sandals; he is saying don’t be self-sufficient, but be dependent. This is revolutionary. Jesus is saying our ability to evangelise depends on us choosing to depend on God for our every day lives, not just for the power and ability to evangelise’ Why is this so? Because it is easier to talk about Jesus when you are depending on him. Sometimes we need to make decisions and choices that will increase our dependence upon God.

Father help me understand the link between my dependence upon you and my ability to evangelise.

html:
Remember the first disciples were fishermen, who would have been able to relate to what Jesus is saying here. So when we read “Be Careful,” Jesus is wanting to get our attention, he is saying that if we do not hear what he is going to say here, we are in danger of beaching our faith and shipwrecking our testimonies.

One of the ways we shipwreck our faith is sometimes we forget who we really are, we forget that we are children of the living God. Sometimes the storms of life cause us to hit the rocks and we feel that we have been ‘beached’ or stuck and we can’t move.

It is so easy to react to the storms of life by feeling that I must try harder, I must pray more, and I must read the bible more so I can get through this crisis. Spiritual disciplines are always a good thing. However in times of crisis we need more than spiritual disciplines and self effort, we need a fresh revelation of God.

Every commentary I have read on Matthew 6 believes that Jesus is teaching his disciples how to practice healthy wholesome Christian disciplines. So he talks about how they should give to the poor, how they should pray and how they should fast. Jesus is teaching how to cultivate a proper heart attitude so they can participate in the natural spiritual requirements of a follower of Jesus. The more I have looked at the chapter, the more I am inclined to think that the giving, praying and fasting, which are extremely important, are secondary issues as far as Matthew 6 is concerned. There is a much more important issue that is not often picked up.

If you read the whole Sermon on the Mount especially chapter 6 you will find one word that is repeated 17 times, 11 of which are in chapter 6. That word is Father. The word father is found more in Matthew 6 than any other chapter in the bible therefore it has a lot to teach us about God as our father, and what it means to be his child.

It’s really important to God that we have a revelation of what it means to have Him as our father. How we live and what we live for is determined by our understanding of the fatherhood of God and the security it produces in our lives.

Before we look at the chapter let us say a few things about God as our father.

In the Old Testament, the Jewish people had some kind of concept of God being a loving Father; however, this understanding of God was not often used. They saw God more as the Father of the nation, but not the individual.

When Jesus prayed he used the Aramaic word Abba for father. This is a word that was only used in the context of the home; it carried the idea on intimacy and respect. The Jews of Jesus’ time would have conversed in Aramaic or used Greek in everyday life, but they were trained to pray in classical Hebrew. It was similar to some Catholics who used to only pray in Latin.

They would recite words but not necessarily understand what they meant.

To this day a Jewish boy coming to Bar mitzvah learns the correct responses off by heart in Hebrew, even if he has no idea what he is saying. The Jewish people at the time of Christ would have had a concept of God as a loving and protective father. It was not a completely new or alien concept to them but they rarely addressed God as “Father” in prayer, which Jesus almost always did.

What happens if you were brought up in a family where the father figure was not very good, or may not have even been there? In Matthews Gospel fathers are portrayed in a primarily negative light, often being the ones that must be left behind by the sons who were chosen to follow the commands of the kingdom of heaven. For example, in 4:21–22 it is stated twice that the fishermen disciples leave their father in the midst of their joint work to follow Jesus, literally leaving their father holding the nets that were not mended. See 10:21, 34-37. Matthew wants to draw a contrast between failing earthly fathers and a perfect heavenly father.

In biblical times a persons’ identity was always tied up with their father, e.g. when Jesus first met Simon He said, ‘You are Simon son of John you shall be called Peter’. John 1.42. The designation ‘son of’ was like our surnames, it helped distinguish people who had the same first name.

"You sum up the whole of New Testament teaching in a single phrase, if you speak of it as a revelation of the Fatherhood of the holy Creator. In the same way, you sum up the whole of New Testament religion if you describe it as the knowledge of God as one's Holy Father. If you want to judge how well a person understands Christianity, find out how much he makes of the thought of being God's child, and having God as his Father. If this is not the thought that prompts and controls his worship and prayers and his whole outlook on life, it means that he does not understand Christianity very well at all." Citation: J. I. Packer, Knowing God, p. 182.

What can we learn about God being our Father from this chapter?

The spiritual disciplines we practice must be done in the context of enjoying God as father. It is so easy to reduce our relationship with God into a religious box-ticking exercise where reputation becomes more important than intimacy. These people became religious, doing the right things in the wrong way, and gradually they became trapped in a need to get their affirmation and approval from others because they had not grasped the fact that God is their father. When people loose their way spiritually it is not because they are bad people, but their waywardness can be traced back to the fact that they have ceased to believe that God is a loving father.

As God is our Father then we need to be real and honest before him. When we are told that we should do our acts of righteousness in secret, it would be very easy to put a literal translation on this and think you should only pray in a private place, but that misses the point.


Someone could do something in secret and still have a heart of a hypocrite. The secret refers to an attitude that is the antithesis to that of the hypocrite. Sometimes we act before God in the same way the hypocrites comes before men. They acted in a certain way to get the approval and praise of men. They acted out of unreality in order to impress others; they were not being real or honest.

Sometimes that is how we come before God, we think we need to impress him, we need to win his approval, we are not honest about ourselves, and we have the same heart attitudes as the hypocrite who engages in a public performance. Our father is looking for authenticity not performance.

I should also mention that we all have an inspired need from time to time to shut the door to the world and everything else and be alone with God because we love him and long to give ourselves to him.

Father thank you that no matter the circumstances I am facing you are always a loving father.
