study_refs: Matthew 6 begins with two very important words, which are “Be careful,’ [watch out NLT] It would be tempting to just read over these two words and miss what they are saying. “Be Careful is one word in the Greek, PROSECHO. It means to “be continually guarding against.” It has the idea of continually watching yourself. It was used to describe the skill of a sea captain who was able to bring his vessel into harbour without beaching it on the hidden shallow rocks.

html:
The other word apodidomi reflects the heart of the giver. Then your Father, who sees everything, will reward you. When the father rewards his children it is his deep expression of his pleasure and delight. The father finds great joy and satisfaction. The rewards that the father gives his children are to teach us about his heart. They are a deep expression of God’s satisfaction and pleasure. The reward is the Joy of God’s heart flowing over into ours.

Knowing God as Father will change our understanding of prayer. Prayer is one of the most difficult things in the Christian life. One of the reasons why we struggle so much with it is because of our perception or incorrect understanding of it. We have been deceived if we understand prayer as simply making requests to God. Bringing our needs and requests to God is an important element of prayer, but that is not the primary reason for praying.

Tim Keller says “One of the most basic things that the gospel does is change prayer from mere petition to fellowship and the praise of his glory.” https://www.cru.org/us/en/train-and-grow/spiritual-growth/prayer/the-gospel-and-prayer.

Understanding prayer as a means of fellowship with the father and a way of developing and maturing our relationship with him will transform how and why we pray. Authentic fellowship with our father will cause the reorientation of our desires, hopes and dreams. We will be anxious to honour his name, we will want his kingdom to come, and we will desire to commit our lives to his will, because we understand that he is our father.

Knowing God as your Father will help you establish healthy priorities and motivations for living. Reading through Matthew 6 can be very daunting. Think of the kind of things Jesus asks of us in this chapter.

We are to hallow Gods name

Pray that his kingdom will come

Ensure that his will be done

Forgive those who have hurt us

Live a life of dependence

Endeavour to avoid sin

Make sure that our treasure is in heaven not on earth

Avoid all worry,

Seek desperately for righteousness.

The important thing to understand is that guilt and condemnation cannot help or encourage us to do any of the above.

This kind of living is only possible as we discover that God really is our Father and He wants us to enjoy being his children.

Father may my love and devotion for you lead to a holy life.

Bible in a year: Luke 6:27-8:25.
title: Knowing God as Father. Part 2
study_refs: As our Father, God wants to enrich our lives. There is a very interesting play on words that we don’t pick up in our English translations. I tell you the truth, they have received all the reward they will ever get. The word that is used for the reward that the hypocrite receives from other people, and the word for reward that is used to describe the father’s response to authentic spirituality are different. The reward of the hypocrite is misthos which was used to describe a persons wage or salary, it is the same word used to describe a hired hand. Misthos describes the heart of the taker. These people thought in terms of deserving something, they had a ‘You owe me’ mindset. They treat God like an employer who owes them something for their good behaviour.

html:
The Parable of the sheep and the goats has caused a lot of controversy over the years; some people think that Jesus is teaching that if we do good works then we will be saved; but as we shall see, this understanding of the parable is impossible.

The necessity of judgment.

Before we look at this parable we need to consider the necessity of judgment. The bible teaches us that everyone will stand before God to be judged. Many people and even some Christians cannot reconcile a loving God with One, who judges, they ask ‘How can a loving God judge people, and condemn them to hell?’ Have you ever been a parent who gets angry with their child, does that make them an unloving parent? Of course not, being a God who can express anger in totally consistent with a loving God. Now I wonder if you have wondered what would happen if God refused to judge us. What would happen if God decided that we were not worth judging?

If God refused to judge us, that would be the worse judgement of all. Why? The refusal to judge us would deem us worthless and irrelevant. Because we are valuable people of worth and significance we are worth judging. So when God judges a person he is saying, ‘Your life does matter, what you do is important, you are not irrelevant or irresponsible but accountable for how you live.’ So that is why God’s judgment is consistent with and a reflection of His love.

Speaking about hell J.I.Packer writes: "Scripture sees hell as self-chosen . . . Hell appears as God's gesture of respect for human choice. All receive what they actually chose, either to be with God forever, worshipping him, or without God forever, worshipping themselves." (J.I.Packer, Concise Theology p.262-263.)

Jesus spoke about the reality of hell more than anybody else in the bible, the interesting thing about how Jesus spoke on this subject, was that he spoke more about hell to his disciples and followers than he did to the unconverted. For Jesus the fear of hell was never used to encourage repentance and salvation, rather it was used to encourage holy living for the benefit of others. It is so easy to confuse a fear of hell with a healthy fear of God. Fear of hell will motivate self preservation, while a Fear of God will encourage us to turn away from ourselves and seek change and renewal through repentance.

This parable asks us a very direct question, Are you a Christian? When we stand before God, the judgment that He will apply to our lives will reveal whether our not we are really Christians.

Father thank you that you see everyone valuable enough to judge.

Bible in a year: Luke 8:26-10:16
title: parable of the sheep and the goats part 1
study_refs: The Parables of Matthew 25 are parables about the Second Coming of the Lord Jesus. The reason why the New Testament has a lot to say about the Second Coming of Jesus is not to inform us about the details of his coming but rather, the doctrine of the Second Coming is primarily to challenge our thinking, redefine our priorities and change our hearts so we will live holy lives in this present generation. Jesus tells us these parables to help us to live for him. Did you ever go on a journey and stop at one of the signposts to your final destination to critique the signpost. Probably not. And yet that is what many Christians react to the sings of Jesus’ return. If our understanding of the signs of Jesus’ do not lead to a more holy life then we don’t really understand them or their purpose.

html:
The deeds that Jesus mentions here are the fruit of salvation not the root; these are the EVIDENCES of salvation, not the CAUSE of salvation.

All the deeds that Jesus mentions here are not hard to do; we don’t need a lot of money, or a lot of resources to show this kind of love, all we need is an open heart that cares.

‘Caring for the needy in the Hebrew Scriptures, for example, is the second most prominent theme. In the New Testament, we find that one of every sixteen verses is about poor people; in the gospels, one of every ten; in Luke, one of every seven. We find the poor everywhere in the Bible.’ Jim Wallis. Let Justice Roll.

Father help me make the most of every opportunity to care for others.

Bible in a year: Luke 10:17-12:12
title: parable of the sheep and the goats part 2
study_refs: Evidence of authentic Christianity.

‘ The arresting thing about this is that Jesus is clearly saying that the ultimate mark of an authentic Christian is not his creed, or his faith, or his Bible knowledge, but the concern which he shows to those who are in need. The practical demonstration of love is the final proof. And note also that Jesus does not ask anyone to present his case or argue his cause. He asks no questions nor requests any evidence. He simply extends to this one group the invitation, ‘Come, O blessed of my Father, inherit the kingdom.’ Then he explains the basis of his choice. He has simply noted that when they had opportunity to help someone in need, they did it. Nothing more is required.’ Ray Stedman https://www.raystedman.org/new-testament/matthew/the-unconscious-test accessed 12/04/2025

html:
‘For I was hungry and you gave me something to eat. I was thirsty and you gave me something to drink. I was a stranger and you invited me in, I needed clothes and you clothed me. I was sick and you looked after me. I was in prison and you visited me.’

Mother Teresa of Calcutta, whose nursing order of sisters had adopted precisely the teaching of this parable. Each day, she said, when she knelt to give medicine or apply a bandage to the sick from among the poorest of the poor, she reminded herself that she served the ‘hidden Christ’ in each person. ‘Lord Jesus, I do this not only for you but to you,’ was her prayer.

‘In Jesus’ vision of the last days we discover that when He does come into our heart, he brings all of needy humanity along with him!" Jensen [Preaching Matthew's Gospel, p. 222]

How are we treating Jesus?

There is a very interesting admission in this passage. Not once does Jesus refer to money. All the giving is of a practical kind. Can I suggest two reasons for that?

No matter how little or how much we have materially we are all responsible to reach out to others in need. The issue is not how much or how little we have, but the condition of our hearts.

We can only touch the heart of Jesus as we give ourselves to those in need. Reading the passage you sense that those who were authentic believers gave more than the person needed, in the process of meeting the needs of others, they gave themselves also.

As Christians we should be sacrificially investing ourselves in the lives of needy and broken people; to do so is to prove that our love for Jesus is authentic. It may be that our refusal to give ourselves to others has a dehumanising effect on us. We cease to be the people God intended us to be. Not to care for those in need is to deface the Image of God in ourselves, for God is a caring God.

Any indifference to the plight of the needy suggests that we almost approve of any suffering they may be going through. Furthermore through our indifference we are adding to their suffering.

For evil to advance, all is needed is for good men to do nothing.

What was the motive behind these people doing these deeds?

If we read the parable carefully you will notice that the righteous on Jesus’ right-hand side were surprised when they were commended for their good deeds. ‘Lord when did we see you hungry and feed you, or thirsty and give you something to drink?

When did we see you a stranger and invite you in, and needing clothes we clothe you? When did we see you sick or in prison and go and visit you?’

They were completely shocked by what Jesus had said.

Their shock indicates a number of things.

(a) They responded to the needs of others with no hidden agenda; they were not secretly hoping that their good deeds would buy them some brownie points!

(b) Responding to the needs of others is a natural and spontaneous expression of a righteous character. In Hebrew there is no word for charity. Rather the caring for those in need is called Tzedaka, a derivative of the Hebrew term for righteousness. So, evidence of true righteousness is caring for others not because you feel obliged, but because you are expressing authentic righteousness, it should be a default reaction.

Why would righteous living motivate someone to reach out to needy people?

Righteousness is very fulfilling and satisfying, creating within a person a deep sense of security so when a person is feeling secure they have the emotional confidence and the motivational impetus to reach out and care for others.

Remember Jesus said ‘Blessed are they that hunger and thirst after righteousness for they shall be filled.’

The condemnation of the goats on the left.

The ruling religious leaders of Jesus’ day formed a counsel, known as the Sanhedrin. During civil court cases, the Sanhedrin had a very definite way of identifying who was guilty and who was innocent. If you were acquitted of the crimes of which you were accused, you would be set on the right hand side of the judge. If you were condemned, you would be set on his left hand side. Thus, anyone looking on could immediately tell whether you had been found guilty or innocent. The left hand (in the Arab world) is the unclean hand. You would never offer it to someone, nor would you even be allowed to strike someone with it.

The goats of this parable didn’t see the needs around them, let alone recognise the presence of God in the suffering of the world. They were oblivious, and when called to account by the God of the universe they can only say, ‘We didn't know any of this mattered to you. We didn't know you were involved; we certainly didn't see you there.’

‘Let us remember that these are people who honestly think they are sheep! They can point with pride to a moment when they made a profession of belief, they are, perhaps dogmatic about a creed and are church members in good standing. However by their lack of response to the pleas for help that come to them from every side, they stand revealed as goats-false sheep-which never were sheep at all.’ Ray Stedman https://www.raystedman.org/new-testament/matthew/the-unconscious-test accessed 12/04/2025

“Jesus calls his followers to be a revolutionary, caring community, not comfortable conservationists protecting the status quo. This parable is designed to show how those who call Jesus Lord should live.” David Wenham. Source unknown

The parable of the sheep and the goats says that our attitudes to people in need are a good reflection of whether we are right with God or not. If we are Christians who have experienced God's grace in our lives, then we will show that grace in our treatment of others, especially those in need.

Father may I see all life as an opportunity to show Jesus love.

Bible in a year: Luke 12:13-14:11
title: parable of the sheep and the goats part 3
study_refs: How we treat people in need is an indication of what kind of relationship we have with Jesus. Listen to what Jesus said

html:
It is important that we understand why Jesus may have done this. The Signs that Jesus refers to are describing what God will be doing before the return of Jesus. The parables, however, tell us what we should be doing, or how we should be living with his return in mind. Therefore, can we suggest that is probably more important that we understand and grasp the message behind the parables, and worry less about the signs, which we have no control over?

Before we look at the parable of the ten virgins we need to say a word about how we should read these parables. Parables are stories Jesus used to make a spiritual point. However, some people have fallen into the trap of how they interpret the parable; they believe that everything in the story has a secondary meaning. So these people think that the five foolish bridesmaids, the five wise bridesmaids, the lamps, the oil and the bridegroom are all allegories of something else. This kind of interpretation can cause confusion, robbing us of the truth that Jesus wants to communicate.

The Background of the Parable

A wedding was the greatest event in a village or a town. It was the greatest single social celebration; where everybody got involved, friends, family, extended family, everyone. It was a time of great happiness; it was a time of festivity and celebration. And that's the scene we have here.

But it's essential for us to know that in a Jewish marriage, there were three elements. The first is engagement. Long before the scene we have here, there was an engagement. This was an official contract between the two fathers who were giving their daughter and their son to each other, as it were. So engagements weren't really made with the couple, they were made between the fathers.

A little while after that, there would be what was called the second phase of the wedding or the marriage which was the betrothal. Now the betrothal was the official ceremony. The couple would come together before friends and family and they would make vows and covenants and binding promises. They had an actual marriage ceremony and they made their commitments. Then letter they were then officially married. Any breaking of a betrothal period was only through a divorce. There had to be an actual divorce to dissolve the betrothal, this divorce was binding. Also if the husband happened to die during that period, the wife was considered a widow even though the marriage had not been physically consummated nor were they living together.

The third phase was the wedding feast, the wedding celebration itself where the groom would go to the bride’s house where she would be waiting with all of her bridesmaids. He arrives with all of the men that are with him and he collects his bride and her maids and they all go with torches, parading in the night through the village in a celebration of singing and joy that is unequalled in their social life. The day has finally come, everything is ready. He has prepared a home for her and is now going to get her and take her to that place. When they arrive at his home that night, the wedding party would go into the house and celebrate for as long as seven days. This starts at night time because they want to be able to go through the village with their lanterns so everyone would see them and enjoy the festival atmosphere.

Father thank you we can joyfully look forward to the return of Jesus.

Bible in a year: Luke 14:12-16:31
title: parable of the ten virgins part 1
study_refs: One of the things that cause much debate and confusion among Christians is the Second coming of Christ. People form theological allegiances with others based on what they believe about Jesus’ return. Churches have split because there was no commonality when it came to what people believed about Jesus’ second coming. The return of Jesus has for many become a divisive and contentious topic, but this was never meant to be.

In the book of Matthew we have five different sections of teaching given by Jesus. The last section of teaching that Matthew records for us is what is known as the Olivet Discourse. This is an extended teaching given by Christ about his second coming and the end of the world. This discourse is recorded in Matthew chapters 24 and 25. If you were to take the time to read through this discourse you would notice that in a general way Jesus uses two distinct methods to communicate the truth he wants to get over. In the first half of the discourse Jesus talks about signs Matthew 24:4-35. In the second half Jesus talks in Parables.

html:
As we have already said, it would be very easy for us to get bogged down in types and allegories and miss the message of the parable. So to help us learn something from the parable let us ask this question. The five foolish bridesmaids brought no oil. What does that say about them and what was going on in their hearts and minds?

The fact that the five foolish bridesmaids had no oil was an expression of their mindset, of their world view; it was a consequence of how they had always looked at life and the world around them. Coming to the feast without oil was an ongoing natural expression of how they had always lived. So in this parable Jesus is warning us, if you think like these foolish bridesmaids you may share their fate. If we have the same mindset as them then we will not be ready for Jesus’ return as they were not ready for the bridegroom. So what has this to teach us?

They refused to engage their minds and think things through. When Jesus refers to the five wise bridesmaids he does not use the usual word for wisdom which is Sophia, rather he uses the word ‘phronimos could be better translated as "thoughtful" or "considerate" (in the sense of someone who tries to consider all the facts in order to make a wise judgment.) Often in Christian circles we are discouraged from using our minds. We seldom take the time to sit down and think through what we believe, why we believe it and what the consequences of our beliefs are. We come to church, we sit in our pews and often we are disengaged from what is being said. Jesus would have never taught the way we teach today. In Jesus’ day, during the teaching, there was always some kind of interaction, between him and those he was teaching. A lot of our lethargy is rooted in our thinking. Our English word for lethargic come from the Greek word lethargos which means forgetfulness. So it is very important that we use our minds that we ask questions, that we wrestle with scriptures, and work hard to get a better understanding of what they are saying.

They were half hearted in how they lived. How do we know that? Well the text tells us that they brought their lamps but no oil; think about that, it doesn’t make sense; it’s like us buying a lamp and not buying a bulb to put in it. They approached their role as bridesmaids with a half hearted attitude.

Being half hearted about our relationship with Jesus will prevent us from finishing the race, we will give up. The nature of Christianity is such that it requires us to be passionate about it. A Christian without passion is like paint without colour, or music without sound. It doesn’t make any sense.

‘Our Lord finds our desires not too strong, but too weak. We are half-hearted creatures, fooling about with drink and sex and ambition, when infinite joy is offered to us, like an ignorant child who wants to go on making mud pies in the slum because he cannot imagine what is meant by the offer of a holiday at the sea. We are far too easily pleased.’ C.S.Lewis The Weight of Glory, and Other Addresses

For these Foolish Bridesmaids looking right was more important than being right. As you read this story you will notice that there was no mention of any external differences between the wise and foolish bridesmaids. They all looked as if they were honestly fulfilling their role, until the lack of oil of the foolish bridesmaids is mentioned. They looked the part to the onlooker, but in reality reputation was more important than authenticity. The life of a child of God in the kingdom should be one of authenticity, we should never appear to be one thing and in reality be something completely different.

Father am I a Christian without passion like paint without colour.

Bible in a year: Luke 17:1-19:27
title: parable of the ten virgins part 2
study_refs: Understanding the Parable.

html:
These foolish bridesmaids did not want to take responsibility for themselves. When these foolish bridesmaids realized that they had no oil they went to the wise bridesmaids. ‘Give us some of your oil. Our lamps are going out.’ There is nothing wrong with asking for help, however, sometimes people ask for help because they are not prepared to take responsibility for themselves. These people often blame others for their problems and develop a demanding attitude. They become angry, expecting others to fix their problems, and sort out their mess. There are certain things in our lives that God holds us completely responsible for. Things like our relationship with Jesus, and the conditions of our hearts. There are certain things in our lives that we alone can fix and sort out.

The foolish Bridesmaids discovered that residue from the past was unable to give them sufficient light in the presents. We are told two important things about these foolish bridesmaids. They had no oil, and then we are told that their lamps went out. Maybe they were able to light their lamps for a short time, because their was still some oil left over in their lamps from the past. This is a very important principle. For many Christians their spiritual lives is a thing of the past. They can look back when they really loved Jesus, they loved being a Christian, and they enjoyed God. But now it is oh so different, their passion has gone, they have lost their spark, and they are no longer animated by the things of God. Do you think your best days as a Christian are over? Has the glory of knowing and loving God become a distant memory rather than a present reality?

The saddest thing about these five foolish bridesmaids was that they were not known to the bridegroom. They were excluded from the wedding feast, not because they had no oil, nor because they came after the celebrations had started. No they we excluded because they were unknown to the bridegroom. ‘I tell you the truth, I don’t know you.’ Their foolish way of thinking robbed them of any opportunity of intimacy with the bridegroom.

Intimacy with Jesus is not a luxury for those who are perceived to be more spiritual, rather intimacy with Jesus is one of our greatest, and one of our most neglected needs. Imagine hearing those words from the Lord Jesus, ‘I don’t know you.’ ‘You have never given me your heart, you have never opened yourself up to me, and you have kept me at a distance.’

Remember that in these parables Jesus wants us to learn how to live a life of expectation; he wants us to joyfully anticipate his return. The only way we can do that is to live out of the heart. Whole hearted living for Jesus is the only way we will be ready for his return.

Father thank you that intimacy with Jesus is a necessity not a luxury

html:
In Matthew 16 we read the back story of the Transfiguration of Jesus which is recorded in chapter 17:1-13. A number of things happen that help us understand the Transfiguration.

1. Peter confessed that Jesus was the Messiah the Son of the living God. This was one of the high points in the Gospel, Peter was beginning to understand who Jesus was. God the Father was teaching Peter. We will soon see that although Peter had received a revelation from God the Father about his Son Jesus, Peter’s understanding of Jesus was still incomplete.

2. Jesus began to teach the disciples about his suffering and death. Now here was the problem, in the mind of Peter and the other disciples there was no room for a suffering Messiah. Reading Matthew 16:22 you get the impression that Peter was angry with Jesus, The NLT reads ‘Peter took him aside and corrected him. ‘Heaven forbid, Lord. This will never happen to you.’ The word the NLT translates correct is epitimaō, it has a technical meaning: it is used in Greek religion of gaining control over a spirit or a demon. Robert Guelich (Word Biblical Commentary: Mark.)

3. Jesus had to rebuke Peter by referring to him as a stumbling block, who was under the influence of Satan. This must had been a real shock to Peter; although Peter may have meant well, Jesus could see the work of Satan behind what Peter had said.

4. Jesus begins not only to talk about his cross and his suffering, but he speaks about their suffering and their cross. We are so familiar with these verses that they do not shock us the way they would have shocked these first disciples. These disciples had seen the Roman crosses on the side of the roads, they had seen the tough death many had suffered. And now Jesus their Messiah wanted them to carry their cross, a symbol of defeat and shame? One of the songs we sing is ‘This is amazing grace.’ One of the lines is about Jesus bearing our cross, I understand the sentiment behind the words, but Jesus bore our sin so we could bear our cross. We have been designed to live cross shaped lives, it would be a cruel injustice for God to take our ‘cross’ from us.

5. Jesus promised that some of his disciples would see him come in glory in Matthew 16:27-28. There has been a lot of debate about these verses but I think they are referring to Jesus’ Transfiguration. They are also Jesus expressing a pastoral concern, this is how Jesus wanted to deal with the challenges that his disciples were facing regarding their relationship with him.

Father thank you that there is pastoral healing in seeing the glory of Jesus.

Bible in a year: Luke 21:10-22:46
title: transfiguration part 1
study_refs: As Christians, many of us want a faith that is simple and straightforward with no uncertainty, no confusion, no doubt, and few questions. We are the ‘sat- nav’ generation who want to be told how to reach our destination with the least amount of trouble or hardship. And we have adopted the same kind of ’sat nav’ attitude when it comes to our faith and our relationship with Jesus. We want the quickest and easiest way to spiritual maturity. We want God to tell us every turn we should make, we want our relationship with Jesus to be free from complications, conflict and confusion. We want a faith that is neat and sorted, we want a life free from mystery and ‘lostness’. But, as we are going to see, sometimes our relationship with Jesus is all about uncertainty.

html:
A. These men needed to experience the glory of intimacy if they were going to have a proper understanding of Jesus.

One of the problems we have is that we do not really have a category were Jesus neatly fits. We are always trying to domesticate Jesus, trying to deconstruct him, so he will fit better into our lives. Sometimes we want what I would call a ‘squeezed theology’, we want to make Him fit into the compartments we have constructed in our minds, trying to keep Him contained and controlled. Then we see His glory, and our paper thin theology is shredded, and we discover that the Jesus we think we know is very different to the Jesus we need to know. The Jesus we need to know is very different to the Jesus we want to know.

Matthew tells us that Jesus took and led Peter, James and John up a high mountain. The word he uses for took "paralambanō" means; to receive near, i.e. to associate with oneself in any familiar or intimate act. I think this tells us a lot about what is going on in the heart of Jesus; He knew that the best way to correct the misunderstanding of these disciples was through intimacy and a revelation of His glory.

These men needed to develop a theology of suffering.

One of the most dangerous things about the church in our culture is that we have gone a long way to eradicate a theology of suffering. We have bought into the health, wealth and prosperity gospel in a very subliminal way. We can often live with an undercurrent sense of entitlement, or deserving. We think that whole hearted commitment to Jesus means that God owes us, and our lives should be free from suffering. We would never verbalise this kind of thinking but perhaps in our hearts we hold onto verses 1Samuel 2:30 believing that if we live right then God owes us.

We need a theology of suffering that give us the freedom to take up our cross.

I have been thinking, is it possible to follow Jesus without a theology and expectation of suffering? I wonder if our lack of appreciation of the glory of Jesus is the reason why we find it difficult to accept or cope with suffering. We need to be people who grapple to grasp the glory of Jesus so we wont be defined by our suffering and pain. When our hearts are ripped open and broken, and our lives are in bits, the hardest thing to see, but the most necessary thing to see is the glory of Jesus.

Father help me to love you in a way that accepts that suffering is a part of the life you have called me to.

Bible in a year: Luke 22:47-24:23.
title: transfiguration part 2
study_refs: So as we go with Peter, James and John up to the mount of Transfiguration what can we learn?

html:
30. ‘As soon as Judas had taken the bread, he went out. And it was night. 31 When he was gone, Jesus said, “Now the Son of Man is glorified and God is glorified in him. 32 If God is glorified in him, God will glorify the Son in himself, and will glorify him at once.’

Jesus was able to discern the hand and purpose of his father in his suffering. Jesus understood that his suffering was not a random series of undetermined events that were unrelated to the purposes and plans of God. He knew that his suffering had a built-in capacity to bring his father glory as he went through it.

We need to leave the past behind by learning from it. Moses and Elijah appeared and began to talk to Jesus. Moses and Elijah were pinnacles of the Jewish faith and spirituality. Moses and Elijah were representatives of the law and the prophets. Moses and Elijah, who were taught to every good Jew, teaching them how to live and please God. But now it was time to listen to a new voice. Moses and Elijah appear on the mountain before the glory of Jesus to affirm that His voice, His suffering, His Glory is the way. Moses and Elijah had fulfilled their purposes, now it was time to listen to Jesus.

In Jewish liturgy there was a daily prayer called the ‘Shema.’ It is the Hebrew word that begins the most important prayer in Judaism. It is found in Deuteronomy 6:4, which begins with the command to “Hear.” The word ‘Shema’ means to hear. The whole Shema prayer, which includes verses 4-9, of Deuteronomy 6 is spoken daily in the Jewish tradition: look at what Matthew says.

Peter said to Jesus, “Lord, it is good for us to be here. If you wish, I will put up three shelters—one for you, one for Moses and one for Elijah.” While he was still speaking, a bright cloud covered them, and a voice from the cloud said, “This is my Son, whom I love; with him I am well pleased. Listen to him!

A voice from heaven, the voice of God speaking directly to the three disciples telling them to listen to his Son. Sometimes we are unable to hear what Jesus is saying to us in the present because we are so accustomed to listening to the voices of the past. We suffer from nostalgic hearing. Although the voices of the past may have been good and important, it is time for a new listening, a new Shema. A new attentiveness to Jesus.

I find it remarkable that as the disciples came down the mountain with Jesus they got into a theological discussion about Elijah. God had just spoken to them from heaven, this is only the second time this had happened in hundreds of years. In the minds of these disciples, Jesus had to be at least equal to Moses an Elijah, but they had not really grasped his full identity. So the Father says ‘This is my Son whom I love, with him I am well pleased, listen to him.’ Here was God the father revealing his heart, talking about what was most important to him, sharing the pleasure he found in Jesus.

As Christians there can be times of uncertainty in our relationship with Jesus. Sometimes we have expectations that are not met, dreams that are dashed and hopes that feel shattered. The Jesus we thought we knew can be different to the Jesus we are experiencing. It is a times like this we need to experience a new intimacy, a new appreciation of his glory, a new realisation that the Jesus we love and worship is greater and bigger than we will ever know or understand.

Father help me listen to Jesus, more than the legitimate voices of the past.

Bible in a year: Luke 24:24-53 John 1:1-2:11
title: transfiguration part 3
study_refs: We need to realise that suffering and glory are often the same thing. In our world view we often compartmentalise life, we have everything boxed up in neat compartments, especially when it comes to suffering and glory. Luke tells us that Moses and Elijah were speaking to Jesus about his death Luke 9:30. They were not talking about his victory, or his splendour, or his majesty, but his death. There are a number of verses in John 13 that clearly show the relationship between glory and suffering.

html:
Every one of us will leave some kind of legacy, we will all cross the line and as we do we will leave behind a memorial to the race we have ran and how we ran it.

As we run the race of life it is very easy for anyone of us to fall into the trap of thinking, it’s my life, it’s my race, so how I run it is nobody else business. We can become small minded and selfish believing the lie that says “Your life is all about you.”

It is easy to forget that every one of us will pass something on to a future generation. It may be something that is wonderful or glorious, or it may be a disappointing legacy of sorrow and shame. The good news is we can choose what kind of legacy we want to leave. The legacy we leave is determined by the race we run, and how we run it.

What it says here in our passage will help us leave behind a Godly legacy.

Jesus says in John 15:12-17

12 This is my command: Love one another the way I loved you. You are my friends when you do things I command you. I’m no longer calling you servants because servants don’t understand what their Master is thinking and planning. No. I’ve named you friends because I’ve let you in on everything I have heard from the Father. You didn’t choose me remember, I chose you, and put you in the world to bear fruit, fruit that won’t spoil.

If you look carefully at these verses, there is a phrase that Jesus uses that is very helpful when it comes to thinking about leaving a legacy. ‘Remember, I chose you, and put you in the world to bear fruit, fruit that will last.’ Jesus wants our lives to be fruitful.

What does that mean?

The fruit that He is talking about is not what we find in our fruit bowls at home, but it is a changed character, that is, we are different to what we were before we met Jesus. The bible talks about the ‘fruit of the Spirit’ which are all expressions of the personality of Jesus. Love, Joy, Peace, Patience, Kindness, Goodness, Faithfulness Gentleness and Self-Control. When we start bearing fruit these will be evident in our lives. People will see that we are different to how we used to be.

How do we bear fruit that will last?

Being fruitful does not mean that you are perfect but it does mean that you are in a process, were you are gradually growing and maturing. For our lives to really count then we need to take our relationship with Jesus seriously. Like the athlete running the race we need to make conscious decisions about what is going get us the best results. As we get closer to Jesus He will help us to mature into people who really love God. As we grow and begin to produce a Godly character our lives take on a new significance and will make a greater difference for good.

There are lots of things we may not be able to do. I doubt any of us will ever become Olympic gold medalists, but we all have the potential for growth and maturity. If we choose to, we all have the potential to become more like Jesus.

Father may my life produce a harvest of righteous fruit.

Bible in a year: John 2:12-4:38
study_refs: My command is this: Love each other as I have loved you. Greater love has no one than this: to lay down one’s life for one’s friends. You are my friends if you do what I command. I no longer call you servants, because a servant does not know his master’s business. Instead, I have called you friends, for everything that I learned from my Father I have made known to you. You did not choose me, but I chose you and appointed you so that you might go and bear fruit—fruit that will last—and so that whatever you ask in my name the Father will give you. This is my command: Love each other.

html:
A Good legacy comes from being secure. Look at what Jesus says “You didn’t choose me, remember I chose you.’ People begin to grow fruitful lives when they feel loved and secure. Jesus tells us that he has chosen us.

We all know what it feels like to be overlooked or rejected. I’m sure we can all remember a time when we were kids and being picked (or not) for the team in school sports. That awful moment when you wished you weren’t (just this once!) the last to be picked.

Jesus doesn’t look at any of us and see rejects! In fact He has chosen us because He sees us as people of great potential. The word for choose means to pick or choose out for one’s self. We need to grasp that our lives are not some random mistake, or some inconsequential event, but we are people who are deeply loved and chosen by the God of the universe. We are chosen by Jesus for he knows that it is only in relationship with him that we will be able to make sense of our lives.

A good legacy comes from developing friendship with Jesus. ‘You are my friends when you do things I command you. I’m no longer calling you servants because servants don’t understand what their Master is thinking and planning. No. I’ve named you friends because I’ve let you in on everything I have heard from the Father.’ The Message.

These words express some of the deepest longings of Jesus’ heart. Maybe Jesus had waited for all eternity to say these words. Jesus wants us to be more than servants; he wants us to be real intimate friends.

Have you ever thought how we usually choose our friends? We usually choose people who we can relate to, people who we have something in common with, people who are on our wavelength, people who get us. And that is not wrong. However, Jesus’ criterion for choosing friends is completely different from ours. He wants us to be his friend, for he knows that is what we desperately need. Jesus does not need us but he wants us, he wants us to have intimacy in our relationship with him.

Friendship with Jesus is a call from bondage into freedom, from slavery into intimacy.

It is right and proper that we have a servant attitude when it comes to our relationship with God. However, the essence of our relationship must be friendship that cultivates a servant heart. In Jesus’ day most people lived as servants, and as servants they lived difficult lives.

A bond-servant was like a slave.

They did what they were told, whether they understood the purpose of the work or not.

They were very often considered as tools to achieve the aims of someone else.

They were not considered intelligent enough to appreciate what their master was planning.

They were not permitted to eat at the same table as their masters.

They usually had separate living quarters, and were never invited to participate in family discussions.

Those who are friends with Jesus will transform the world in which they live.

A good legacy is the result of loving people the way Jesus loves us. “My command is this: Love each other as I have loved you.” I think this is one of the most wonderful statements in the whole bible. Jesus wants us to model His love; he wants our lives to be an on-going expression of His love in the here-and-now. Relationships are the key to a good legacy. The legacy God wants us to leave is not valued by the money or assets we leave, or measured by the things we achieve, rather it is all about how we loved, and the quality of relationships we build. We should never underestimate the power of friendship.

I wouldn’t be the person I am today if it wasn’t for Godly people who befriended me and invested their lives in me.

I would strongly encourage us all to do two things,

1). Ask God to bring people into your lives that will be your friends and have a Godly influence in your life.

2) Go out of your way to befriend others for their sake’s and make sacrificial commitment to them.

In this race we are running, none of us know how long or how short our race will be. None of us can choose when we will cross the finishing line. But we can choose what kind of legacy we will leave behind, we can choose how we are going to run the race, we can choose what we want to pass on to future generations. Let me finish with a story about a man who made a deliberate choice to leave a better legacy.

Alfred Nobel, the man behind the prestigious Nobel Peace Prize had his death prematurely announced by a French newspaper. In his obituary which he read, it asserted that he was remembered for inventing dynamite responsible for the death of countless human beings. It stated, “Dr. Alfred Nobel, who became rich by finding ways to kill more people faster than ever before, died yesterday.” This error is said to have had an incredible effect on him that he decided to leave behind him a better legacy. Nobel set aside the bulk of his estate to establish the Nobel Prizes, to be awarded annually to people who help to bring peace into areas of conflict and war.

This is good news. No matter what we have done in our past, we can choose now to begin to produce fruit that will last so that when we cross the finishing line we will leave a legacy of love that will enrich future generations.

Father may my friendship with others help them grow spiritually.

html:
And yet as we read this story of the calming of the storm, the Jesus that is presented to us is a complete contrast to the disciples. The disciples panic stricken, fear-filled men who are unable to control the stormy circumstances of life. Jesus, on the other hand is fast asleep.

Reading this story superficially causes some unease within me and I can identify with the disciples. Why would Jesus choose to sleep at a time like this? It feels inappropriate or out of place. However, if we look at this incident a bit closer we will begin to understand that sometimes sleeping in the storm is an expression of true humanity that prepares for us the battles of the future.

As we consider this story it would be very tempting for us to reason that because Jesus was fully God, he knew all things, it was easy for him to rest at this time. He knew the unknown, the end from the beginning, therefore he could sleep. But that misses the point because we can assume that one of the reasons why Jesus slept was because he would have been physically tired. As a man, he knew what physical exhaustion felt like. Physical tiredness is something God cannot experience, see Psalm 121:4, it is a human experience. It is as if Jesus is teaching us that in some of the storms

of life the right human response is to rest.

Father teach me to rest in the middle of my storms.

Bible in a year: John 6:52-8:20.
title: Sleeping in the st0rm part 1
study_refs: Referring to someone recently, my wife said of them, ‘they are asleep in the boat.’

I like that, ‘sleeping in the boat’; when life is sun kissed, and calm is all around, that would be idyllic. But for some these are far from being ‘sun kissed days.’ The calm they knew yesterday seems so far away. In their lives, the storms of raging, illness, death and sorrow are like mighty merciless winds that appear to be destroying life as they once knew it. Others are living through broken-hearted turmoil as their loved ones are taken from them by the cruelty of life. Others have lost their jobs, their income, their financial security.. While others have had their plans put on hold, their hopes dashed and their lives turned upside down and there is a fear of sinking. For many life may feel like a drowning experience. We may feel like these first disciples of Jesus overwhelmed by life, terrified of drowning.

html:
If you read this story in its context in Mark 4 you will notice that before getting onto the boat Jesus had been teaching about the kingdom of God see Mark 4:26 and 30. His mind was focused on the fact that kingdom of God was a reality. He understood that God’s kingdom would come irrespective of what is going on around him. He felt secure as a man because his hope was in the indestructible kingdom of his Father. He knew that the storm could not diminish his Father’s power to reign.

I think that this incident must have had a big impact on Peter as he was able to do the same the night before his trial. Luke tells us in the book of Acts. ‘The night before Peter was to be put on trial, he was asleep, chained between two soldiers.’ Acts 12:8.

Is that not amazing? Chained between soldiers, facing possible death, and yet fast asleep!!

For most of us sleeping in the storm feels like an impossibility. Life is too difficult, our pain is too raw, our grief is overwhelming. That is okay, Jesus understands. How do I know that? Jesus was wakened from his sleep, not by the howling wind or the ferocious waves but by the shouting of his terrified disciples, disciples who were experienced fishermen, men who would had been accustomed to the danger of the sea of Galilee. Although they were familiar with the weather systems of Galilee, when this storm came they were out of their depth, so they shouted.

Gods Kingdom will come, His purposes will be done no matter what the storm. We need to allow this to settle our hearts and minds. In reality it is not easy not knowing what lies ahead, but please remember that we can trust the Father who is in control of it all.

Read about what Jesus did when he got out of the boat!

He set a demon-possessed man free. This man had a legion of demons which was the most severe case of demon possession in the word of God.

Perhaps we need Gods rest in the here and now to be able to overcome the evil one and his fiery darts in the future. Maybe you’re experiencing anxious thoughts that are not allowing you to rest in God. Listen to His word via songs or a recorded teaching. Keep in contact with people who will pray with you and for you. Be honest about how you're feeling. The disciples shouted for Jesus to help them. It’s not a shameful thing to ask for help. It’s important to let others know how you’re feeling.

Father may rest in the present prepare me for the future.

study_refs: So how was Jesus the man able to sleep in the back of the boat during this frighting storm? Yes he may had been very tired, but I don’t think being very tired would keep you asleep at a time like this.

html:
That simple act became the turning point for Mr. Nixon and led to a period of true forgiveness that allowed him to be regarded as one of the elder statesmen of the country until his death.

If we really understood how powerful and freeing grace was, we would pursue it with all our being. If we truly grasped the effects grace can have on hurting individuals and families, then we would eagerly want to show grace to all. People who are full of grace are the most God-like and are thus those who have real freedom, authority and influence.

Unfortunately we live in a world that is ungracious, a world where the strong dominate the weak, and the rich exploit the poor. We live in a world where mercy has become unfashionable, and grace has been reduced to a word more readily associated with ballet. As people we have two basic needs when it comes to grace. We need to receive it. We need to show it.

No matter who we are, be we an American President, or a homeless beggar, rich or poor, known or unknown, successful or not, we all are in a desperate need to receive grace. However, we all have just a similar need to show grace to others. Showing grace to others is not just some saintly virtue reserved for those who are perceived to be ‘super spiritual.’ Rather showing grace to others is the truest expression of our humanity, a humanity that has been made in the image of God.

In this story of Jesus’ encounter with the woman who had been caught in adultery. This story has a lot to teach us about the power of grace. It’s a story that says something about God’s response to sexual sin, but it’s only not about sexual sin. There’s a lesson here about how we respond to others who sin sexually and about the danger of self-righteousness which is, by its very nature, is at variance with grace.

In his book Mere Christianity, C. S. Lewis says,

If anyone thinks that Christians regard un-chastity (sexual sin) as the supreme vice, he is quite wrong. The sins of the flesh are bad, but they are the least bad of all sins. All the worst pleasures are purely spiritual. The pleasure of putting other people in the wrong, of bossing and patronizing and spoiling sport, and backbiting; the pleasures of power, of hatred. For there are two things inside me...they are the animal self and the diabolical self; and the diabolical self is the worst of the two. That is why a cold self-righteous prig who goes regularly to church may be far nearer to hell than a prostitute. But of course it is better to be neither! https://www.reddit.com/r/Catholicism/comments/1dqmzw9/whats_your_thoughts_on_c_s_lewis_take_on_sexual/#:~:text=Quote%3A,least%20bad%20of%20all%20 Accessed 12/04/2025

In the story recorded in John 7:53-8:10, Jesus confronts what C. S. Lewis would call a band of ‘cold, self-righteous prigs’ and a woman who was guilty of open sexual sin. He handles both with such wisdom and grace that the story has become a favourite of many.

Father help me understand that I have been created to receive and share grace

It was the memorial service for Hubert Humphrey, long-time senator from Minnesota, and one-time nominee as Democratic candidate for US President. The church was packed with dignitaries, but one man stood alone, shunned by most of the congregation. Only a few years before, Richard M. Nixon had resigned the Presidency, and although he’d been given a pardon by Gerald Ford he was still regarded by many as a ‘crook’. It was Nixon’s first visit to Washington since that shameful day when he departed the White House in a Marine helicopter and it seemed that nobody at the church that day wanted to engage with him. However, when President Jimmy Carter entered the building, greeting friends and colleagues, he noticed Nixon standing off in the distance. Walking over to him, Carter took Nixon’s hand and embraced him, saying for all to hear "Welcome Home, Mr. President."

html:
If you look carefully at how this text is introduced, you will notice that it says something like: ‘The most ancient Greek manuscripts do not include John 7:53-8:11.’ This may not seem too important, but there is a history behind the exclusion of this passage which helps us understand how the early church struggled with it.

‘Throughout the history of the church it has been held that, whoever wrote it, this little story is authentic. It rings true. It speaks to our condition. It is worth our while to study it, though not as an authentic part of John’s writing. The story is undoubtedly very ancient. Most authorities agree that it is referred to by Papias. It is mentioned also in the Apostolic Constitutions. But it is not mentioned very often in the early days. The reason probably is that in a day when the punishment for sexual sin was very severe among the Christians this story was thought to be too easily misinterpreted as countenancing un-chastity. When ecclesiastical discipline was somewhat relaxed the story was circulated more widely and with a greater measure of official sanction.’ Leon Morris Gospel of John pp 883

When it comes this passage, there seems to be a bit of a mystery. Many of the early manuscripts and papyri include it, the earliest church fathers quote it as scripture, and it is written in the same style as the rest of John’s gospel. Why then did some copyists not include it? What’s going on here?

It is likely that the early church struggled with this passage because they did not really or could not grasp the full nature of the message of grace. For example, the ‘Shepherd of Hermas’, writing in the early second century, held that Christians who committed serious sins could be forgiven once after public confession and penance. The amazing thing is that he was roundly criticized by his contemporaries…for being too lax! For example, Tertullian called him ‘the shepherd of adulterers.’ It's easy to see why legalistic people- especially men wouldn't like this passage.

The early church thought that what happened in this story would encourage sin, so they refused to teach it. This was based on a misunderstand of grace. They confused the showing of grace with condoning sin.. We will never be able to live a holy life if we do not understand and accept grace, grace will never condone or encourage sin: Look at what Titus 2:11-12 says.

‘For the grace of God that brings salvation has appeared to all men. It teaches us to say no to ungodliness and worldly passions and to live self-controlled, upright and godly lives in this present age.’

Basically these verses are saying that we cannot live self-controlled and holy lives unless we are being motivated by grace.

Father thank you that grace keep us from sinning

title: Grace to a broken women part2

html:
The members of the Sanhedrin have gone home, frustrated and angry that they can neither silence Jesus nor even manage to arrest Him. They are also deadlocked over how to deal with Him.

When the council members go to their own homes, Jesus and His disciples go to the Mount of Olives. Jesus also goes there in the latter days of His ministry to avoid being an easy target for assassination or arrest (see Luke 19:37; 22:39). Early in the morning, Jesus makes His way to the temple again. The people begin to gather around him, forming a crowd, and he begins to teach them.

Setting the scene.

'Caught in an act of adultery' says the writer. That was when the doors burst open. The covers jerked back. “This is not your husband” shout the fearsome looking men, as they bare down on the frightened woman. “Put on some clothes, we know how to deal with the likes of you.” And they do. So she is dragged from the moment of private passion in the bedroom to become a public spectacle in the streets. The woman clutches a thin robe to hide her nakedness, but nothing can hide her shame. From this moment on, her life will never be the same again. When she goes to the shops women will point and whisper. When she walks down the street heads will turn. When her name is mentioned people will remember this moment. And so she is paraded through the town until they reach the temple and there she is hurled before Jesus. In fear, shame and brokenness, she awaits her condemnation.

Think of the shame this lady must had been feeling.

The Oxford English Dictionary defines shame as a ‘painful emotion arising from the consciousness of something dishonouring, ridiculous or indecorous in one's own conduct or circumstances or of being in a situation which offends one's sense of modesty or decency.’

The Hebrew word for shame is buwsh. It carries something of each of the following’

Acute disappointment – of being let down by someone or something in which we have believed.

Being confounded. envisioning a situation in which a person is confounded or left speechless.

Exposure – which is perhaps the most important element in the biblical idea of shame. In particular, exposure of our sins and sinful natures in God's presence. This idea is found in the earliest pages of the bible in the story of the fall of Adam and Eve. We are told in Genesis 2:25, which describes the condition of our first parents before the fall, that "the man and his wife were both naked, and they felt no shame."

Disgrace. The final element in the biblical idea of shame is disgrace or extreme humiliation.

As this lady stood before Jesus she may well have been feeling all these things, she was probably an emotional wreck.

But there is more going on here than simply shaming and blaming a sinful woman. The men who threw her at Jesus’ feet had a hidden agenda. Things were not as they seemed. These religious leaders didn’t care about the woman nor on this occasion did they care about the law. They simply wanted to ‘test’ (peirazo-often translated as ‘tempt’) Jesus, so that they might have grounds for accusing him. In other words, their prior overt tactics had failed to silence Jesus, so now they resorted to a more crafty and subtle approach.

The attitude of the religious leaders.

It is important that we grasp the heart attitudes of these religious leaders as they drag this poor women into their conflict with Jesus.

They manipulated scripture to affirm their judgmental attitude.

They tried to cover their own sins by exposing the sin of others. We would never do that!

Father thank you that Jesus can rescue us from our shame.

title: Grace to a broken women part 3
