html:
The Old Testament listed adultery as a capital crime (Lev. 20:10). This is horrifying to the modern reader, where it merits no punishment in our society. Though we are no longer under Old Testament civil law, it is not difficult to understand why adultery could lead to such serious judgment. especially when compared to the other ancient Near Eastern law codes. The Mosaic law was very tough on crimes against people, relationships, and the family unit. The other law codes were very tough on property crimes – for example, cutting off hands for stealing. This difference highlights the contrasting value-systems of the people of God and those around them – of prioritising people versus things.

In some cases, according to the Jewish law book, the Mishnah, the adulterer is to be executed by strangulation. Even the shocking method of strangulation is set down in the Mishnah which is a very precise book and not to be read by the faint hearted…

The adulterer is to be placed in a manure pile up to his or her knees. A soft towel set within a rough towel is placed around the neck. The towels are drawn tighter and tighter until death occurs.

The religious leaders hoped to impale Jesus on the horns of a dilemma. If he agreed with the Old Testament law and called for her execution, they could accuse him of sedition before the Romans, because since 30 AD the Romans had taken away the Jews' right of capital punishment. However, if he said she shouldn't be stoned, they could accuse him of false teaching and discredit him with the people.

The Old Testament law mandated that to be prosecuted, adulterers needed to be caught in the act (Num. 5:13). Rabbi Samuel said, "In the case of adulterers, they (the witnesses) must have seen them in the posture of adulterers."Another scholar of Talmudic law says, "(It is not just an issue) of their having seen the couple in a `compromising situation,' for example, coming from a room in which they were alone, or even lying together on the same bed. The actual physical movements of the couple must have been capable of no other explanation, and the witnesses must have seen exactly the same acts at exactly the same time, in the presence of each other, so that their depositions would be identical in every respect."

As we read the account of this story in John, we see that the religious leaders tell Jesus that the woman had indeed been caught ‘in the very act of adultery’. It seems that they have been conscientious in their compliance with the detail of the Torah. However, their adherence to the law was selective and flawed.

The Torah also stated that both parties were to be produced and prosecuted (Deut. 22:22). If they caught the woman ‘in the very act,’ then where is the man? It is obvious that there is a conspiracy here! The whole story could have been fabricated, but the most plausible explanation is that these men have set the woman up to use her in their attempt to discredit Jesus.

They may have sent an ‘undercover agent’ to solicit the woman’s services (maybe even one of their own number), then on a pre-arranged signal, they burst in, let him go and dragged her to Jesus. This makes them accessories to the crime and therefore guilty of adultery themselves!

Father is their any condemnation in my heart towards others?

Bible in a year: John 17:14-19:42
title: Grace to a broken women part4
study_refs: The required judgment.

html:
The response of Jesus/

As the sun rises over the temple precincts, Jesus is faced with a theological and moral dilemma and everyone present waits to see how we responds. As we stand with the crowds, let us watch intently and listen carefully as Jesus demonstrate the transforming power of grace…

There are a few things worth noting here about Jesus’ response:

He didn’t speak. ‘But Jesus stooped down and wrote in the dust with his finger.’ This was totally unexpected. The Teachers of the Law and the Pharisees were probably expecting some kind of verbal response from Jesus, so his silence must have infuriated them. They are feeling ignored and we read that they ‘demanded an answer’. But Jesus slows everything down. He dictates the pace. He takes the situation out of the hands of the Pharisees and takes it into his own hands. Try and imagine the tension at this point. The Pharisees feel they have caught Jesus in a trap, and they are longing for him to incriminate himself, but he says nothing. Sometimes in tense situations we can say more without the use of words.

There has been much debate about what Jesus may have written, but John doesn’t tell us, so it mustn’t be important for us to know. However, Jesus writing on the ground must have taken the focus away from the woman.

When Jesus finally stands and speaks, he says ‘If any of you are without sin let him be the first to throw a stone at her.’

Notice Jesus doesn’t speak about the woman, but rather about the heart attitude of the self-righteous Pharisees. Jesus was exposing their sin; he was refusing to let them hide behind the sin of the woman. What he says, in effect, is, "You are no better off than she is. Your hearts are filled with murder and hatred."

Jesus allows them to leave without saying anything more to them. ‘At this those who heard began to go away one at a time, the oldest ones first, until only Jesus was left with the woman standing there.”’ With a simple word Jesus has diffused the tension and one by one, the stones are dropped and the Pharisees leave. It may be that the older ones realized that their trap for Jesus didn’t work, and according to Roman law they had no powers of execution. Or perhaps they had more sin in their hearts. Either way, the accusers gradually leave the scene, leaving Jesus to deal with the woman.

Jesus and the woman7

“until only Jesus was left with the woman standing there.” I think this is one of the most beautiful and holiest moments in the bible. All the accusers have gone, and probably the crowds with them, and a frail, fragile guilt-filled woman lies on the ground before the Lord Jesus. Her heart is pounding, her mouth is dry, her palms are sweaty…what will he say? He doesn’t question her; he doesn’t investigate to see if she might be innocent - they both know she is guilty. But in tender mercy he says.

‘Woman, where are they? Has no one condemned you.’ ‘No one Sir, she said. ‘Then neither do I condemn you,’ Jesus said, ‘Go and sin no more.’

Notice the order of what Jesus says: "Neither do I condemn you. Go and sin no more." First God assures us of his forgiveness; then he calls on us to cooperate with him as he liberates us from a life of sin. Why is this order so important? Because of the way God motivates us to live for him. RELIGION SAYS: "Change, or I will condemn you." The fear and threat of God's condemnation is always potentially hanging over our heads in order to "keep us in line."This does not promote deep and lasting change. People who live under by this principle tend to have a superficial and self-righteous kind of holiness. By contrast, GRACE SAYS: "I have forgiven and accepted you. Now respond to my love by allowing me to change your life. Loving gratitude is the most powerful motivator in the universe. We don't change in order to be accepted, but because we have been accepted. Real righteousness is practising love toward God and others. Nothing motivates this kind of lifestyle like forgiveness received. This is why grace, properly understood and appropriated, produces a superior righteousness in the lifestyle of its recipient.

That’s what’s so amazing about grace!

Grace isn’t fair…but it is right. Grace is always appropriate, no matter what the context.

You could read this story and simply think that Jesus is soft on sinners – a bit like an indulgent parent who continues to let their child ‘off the hook’ – as long as they promise to be a good girl or boy and not do it again.

How do we reconcile the grace of God with the widespread damage and hurt caused by adultery or other sin that destroys people and relationships. How can Jesus forgive so freely? Is he just like an indulgent parent who lets things go unchecked and doesn’t deal with the heart of the matter?

Maybe this is one of the reasons why we struggle so much with grace, it seems to undermine justice and fairness. To think that God loves the person who has caused you so much pain and distress, just as much as he loves you, can be a frightening and unsettling thought. Grace understands and accepts that no matter how guilty a person may be, their misdeeds, or mistreatment of us cannot reduce their value as people who are still loved by God, and people whom God wants us to love too, and that is very difficult.

You could say that this story of the lady caught in adultery contains one of the greatest ‘miracles’ of Jesus’ ministry. A lady, who life was shaped and marked with guilt and shame, was set free to go and sin no more. This is the power of grace.

Father thank you for the beauty of the grace that Jesus gives us.

Bible in a year: John 20-21 Acts 1:1-2:13
title: Grace to a broken women part 5
study_refs: But Jesus went to the Mount of Olives. At dawn he appeared again in the temple courts, where all the people gathered around him, and he sat down to teach them. The teachers of the law and the Pharisees brought in a woman caught in adultery. They made her stand before the group and said to Jesus, “Teacher, this woman was caught in the act of adultery. In the Law Moses commanded us to stone such women. Now what do you say?” They were using this question as a trap, in order to have a basis for accusing him. But Jesus bent down and started to write on the ground with his finger. When they kept on questioning him, he straightened up and said to them, “Let any one of you who is without sin be the first to throw a stone at her.” Again he stooped down and wrote on the ground. At this, those who heard began to go away one at a time, the older ones first, until only Jesus was left, with the woman still standing there. Jesus straightened up and asked her, “Woman, where are they? Has no one condemned you?” “No one, sir,” she said. “ Then neither do I condemn you,” Jesus declared. “Go now and leave your life of sin.”

html:
“I’m fine, how are you?”

“Fine thanks…”

And so goes the typical foyer conversation in churches up and down the land every Sunday morning. Questions asked without any expectation of an honest response. Answers given that don’t say anything at all. Empty exchanges and hollow conversations. We’ve all shared in this kind of experience.

Where did we learn this art of ‘shallow speak’? Talking, but not really saying anything. Hearing, without really listening. Maybe it’s something to do with our culture. Or maybe it’s more to do with our hearts. After all, in our hearts we know that this isn’t the way it’s meant to be.

You and I have been made for intimacy – to enjoy deep relationships both with God and others. That’s what we long for. To be intimate literally means to ‘make known.’ Intimacy is the act of opening yourself up to others so they can know the real you, it’s linked with feelings of closeness, safety, trust and transparency.

Unfortunately intimacy isn’t really in vogue. Instead, our society seems to be becoming more and more superficial. The Facebook Revolution may have helped us to be ‘connected’ to more people, but it seems as if we are less involved in the lives of others. ‘Friends’ have become an online category to tally-up, not a community of companions to experience and enjoy.

There’s a growing tendency for people to live individualistic and often lonely lives and as a result, community is in danger of becoming a topic of nostalgia, rather than a present reality. Sadly, many people go through life feeling like unknown entities, simply longing to be noticed, known and loved.

Superficiality threatens to become the shallow grave of the personality and a cold assassin of healthy, wholesome relationships.

To be superficial is to be affected by or concerned with ‘surface things’. Superficiality avoids depth, it does not penetrate emotionally or intellectually. And this is dangerous for human relationships. After all, people are like whales, we weren’t created to live in the shallows. We were made for the deep…we were made for intimacy.

The most important thing about our Christian experience is how well we know Jesus. The goal of authentic discipleship is not to learn and practice spiritual disciplines, although these are important, but rather to cultivate intimacy with Jesus.

Knowing Jesus intimately is not a luxury; it is the very heart and essence of our faith. Intimacy with Jesus will automatically open up our hearts to others and free us to nurture intimacy with them. Our relationship with God is intrinsically linked to our relationship with others. Intimacy is the only effective antidote to superficiality.

John 7:25-29 has much to teach us about the importance of knowing Jesus and the things that can threaten intimacy with him.

Father thank you that the goal 0f salvation is not to go to heaven, but to know you and your son Jesus.

Bible in a year: Acts 2:14-4:47
title: When people treat us superficially part 1
study_refs: “ How are you?”

html:
Jesus is at the Feast of Tabernacles in Jerusalem where the religious authorities have desires to kill him. There is a lot of tension and fear around the city. People are whispering and spreading rumours about Jesus. Halfway through the feast Jesus goes to the temple area in order to address the hostility of the religious authorities. As he is speaking, he is interrupted by the people of Jerusalem who have questions about his identity.

Jesus' identity was one of the most controversial issues of the day. As Jesus defines his identity here, we should not be surprised at the growing hostility of the Jewish authorities. Their knowledge of Jesus was superficial, they said Have the authorities really concluded that he is the Messiah? But we know where this man is from; when the Messiah comes, no one will know where he is from.” Their knowledge of Jesus was not based on any real, personl experience, but on hearsay and gossip.

The roots of superficiality

Often, superficiality stems from feelings of fear. When people feel threatened, or are not prepared to face their own problems, they can begin to question and belittle the identity of others. The people of Jerusalem were unable to accept what Jesus had been saying so they became hostile by being superficial about his identity. Their superficiality and hostility towards Jesus was rooted in the fact that they didn’t really know him:

They talked about him, not to him. ‘Isn’t this the man they are trying to kill?’ John 7:25. These remarks are neither a confession about Jesus' identity nor a testimony on his behalf. Rather they voice a question to each other.

Furthermore they stopped listening to what Jesus was saying. Remember, Jesus was still teaching at this point, and as he was speaking, they began to talk to each other. Their actions indicated that they didn’t think Jesus was worth listening to. They didn’t like what they were hearing so they switched off (like we often do), and turned their attention elsewhere.

John says 7:26 ‘At that point some of the people in Jerusalem began to ask..’ What ‘point’ is John referring to? In the previous verse, Jesus says ‘Stop judging by mere appearance, and make right judgements.’ That’s the point at which they stop listening. Jesus was confronting their whole value system and mindset.

The people of Jerusalem were greatly influenced by the Pharisees who always judged or evaluated a person by their external appearance and behaviour. It seems as though they didn’t like the implications of what Jesus was saying. So, as a sign of their disapproval they stopped listening, refusing to give Jesus their full attention, They began to discuss him, knowing that he was able to hear what they were saying. This is a classic example of superficiality, and disdain for a person. This was an expression of rude disregard that belittled Jesus and his teaching.

They refused to take any responsibility in wanting Jesus dead. We read that they were asking ‘Isn’t this the man they are trying to kill’. The people of Jerusalem were not prepared to help Jesus, or stand up for him, even though they are aware of the plots against him. They are for complicit in these murderous threats. Their lack of concern for Jesus made them as guilty as the religious leaders.

The negation of our responsibilities towards others will encourage superficiality. In superficial living their is always a ‘they,’ or a ‘him’ or a ‘he,’ or a ‘she,’ to blame, someone else is always responsible. There’s always someone else to ‘carry the can’, but it’s never us. Our superficiality prevents us from taking a good honest look at our own hearts, so we will automatically look for someone else to pin the blame on. Remember this was this same Jerusalem crowd that would eventually demand the blood and death of Jesus

They allowed others to influence their opinions about Jesus, refusing to come to their own conclusions. As the people discuss the rumoured plans to kill Jesus, they wonder whether the leaders had changed their mind, for John tells us that Jesus is ‘speaking publicly and they are not saying a word to him’ John 7:26a. So the people ask ‘Have the authorities really concluded that he is the Christ’ john 7:26b.

It appears that these people are not prepared to decide for themselves who Jesus was, but they prefer to be influenced by what their leaders might have been thinking.

There is a warning here for all who call themselves disciples of Jesus. We live at a time where Christians are not encouraged to think critically about their faith or consider why they believe what they believe. It’s too easy for us to sit in church, expecting to be spoon-fed, and then simply regurgitate what we’ve been told. We settle for second-hand faith, rather than first-hand experience of Jesus. And this is always fatal. After all, faith without relationship is little more than dry orthodoxy. It hardens the soul and kills the spirit within.

We need to be taught to think for ourselves and come to our own conclusions about Jesus and his truth. This does not mean that every person should arrive at their own private understanding of ‘the truth’. Biblical truth is best understood in the context of a seeking community, who are eager to learn and share together. However, this is not a licence for passive passengers who refuse to engage their own hearts and minds in the quest to know the real Jesus.

Father help me to engage my mind in spiritual thinking.

Bible in a year: Acts 5:1–7:29
title: When people treat us superficially part 2
study_refs: The context of the passage

html:
They did not base their expectations of the Messiah on the word of God, rather they made assumptions.

Despite what some in the crowd were saying about the perceived conclusions of the Pharisees, there were some who were convinced that Jesus was not the Messiah. John writes: ‘But we know where this man comes from; when the Christ comes, no one will know where he is from.’

During the Feast of the Tabernacles, Jerusalem would have been full of people from Galilee, where Jesus was already well known. As Matthew reminds us, many of those that listened to Jesus would have known that he was the carpenter's son and would also have know His mother, and his brothers (Mt. 13:55).

A common belief for Jews at this time was that Christ would appear suddenly with no known background. This may have been a piece of popular theology, probably based upon inferences from certain passages in the Apocrypha. It was a popular opinion, but it had no basis.

Since Jesus’ listeners knew his background, he could not be Messiah. Even if their opinions weren’t based on popular myth, they were probably unable to reconcile Jesus’ ordinariness with their expectations of the Promised Messiah

The problem was that they forgot what the Scriptures said:

"But you, Bethlehem Ephrathah, though you are little among the thousands of Judah, yet out of you shall come forth to Me the One to be Ruler in Israel, Whose goings forth are from of old, from everlasting" (Micah 5:2 NKJV).

God’s promised Messiah is fulfilled in the person of Jesus, from Nazareth.

A rigorous application of the word of God to our lives will prevent us from living superficially and developing superficial relationships. If we don’t take our bibles seriously, then we won’t take Jesus seriously. The whole purpose of reading and studying the bible is to get to know God. Bible knowledge is incomplete if it doesn’t lead to a strong desire for God and a deeper knowledge of God.

Many people read their bibles in the same way they would read an encyclopaedia: they amass information and facts. The bible is more like a personal journal than an encyclopaedia – God’s personal journal, where the Father shares his life and heart. The people standing around Jesus as he taught in the temple refused to take their Old Testament seriously, and choose to believe an urban myth, which had no scriptural authority.

Jesus response to superficiality

Superficial relationships with Jesus and with others are often acceptable to us. We have an unhealthy tolerance towards ‘shallow living,’ which expects little from our relationships. The great thing about this passage in John, is that it shows us that Jesus will never tolerate a superficial relationship with those he loves. He didn’t tolerate it then. He won’t tolerate it now. We matter too much to him.

How did Jesus respond to the superficiality of the people?

Jesus cried out. ‘Then Jesus, still teaching in the temple courts cried out.’ Including this occasion, the Gospel record says that on four occasions Jesus raised his voice to make a point. (John 12:44, Matthew 27:50; Mark 15:37; John 7:37). The Greek word for ‘cried out’ is krazo. Originally, this word described the unpleasant sound of a raven. It then came to refer to any screeching or screaming or crying out. The implication being that the sounds were not pleasant to hear. It is the fearful sound that the disciples in the boat make when they thought they were seeing a ghost walking on the water (14:26). It is the tone of voice that Peter uses when he begins to sink: "Lord, save me.”

This was a cry of pain and frustration. The people of Jerusalem had just used a legend or familiar folklore to completely dismiss Jesus and all that he stood for. Jesus felt the pain of misunderstanding, so he cried out, just as he did on the cross.

Jesus challenges their supposed knowledge of him. They had claimed to know Jesus, and where he was from, so as he continues to teach, we read that Jesus ‘cried out’: ‘Yes you know me and know where I am from.’

The phrase can be punctuated as a statement or as a question. Personally, I think he asked a question with irony: "So you know me and know where I am from? You think?” It was a confrontation of the people's arrogance. This seems like the best interpretation because immediately Jesus pointed out their ignorance John 7:28b-29.

Sometimes we need to challenge assumptions, expose ignorance, and confront misunderstandings. Jesus wanted them to know, that their understanding of him was so inadequate and incomplete that he could say, ‘they don’t know me at all.’ John 7:28 I find this statement very challenging. I wonder how Jesus would describe my knowledge of him.

Jesus goes on to tells them where he came from. They suspected that he came from Galilee or Bethlehem, but they were wrong, ‘I am not here on my own, but he who sent me is true. You do not know him, but I know him because I am from him and he sent me.’ Jesus found his identity and his security in his fellowship with his father, not in the opinions and reactions of men.

Superficiality is a disease that robs our hearts of whole life, and the only safeguard against superficial living and superficial relationships is to really know God. We realise that Jesus knew the Father in a way no one else could, but if we look at what Jesus says here, we discover something of what it means to know God.

Knowing God means that you have a sense of being sent by God. “But I know him because I am from him and he sent me. Jesus had a strong sense of purpose and direction. He didn’t wonder aimlessly through life, but he knew that he was sent by God. Knowing God gives a person purpose and direction.

The word John uses for ‘send’ in verse 29 is the Greek word apastello, which means ‘I send’. The word had the same meaning in both the Jewish and Greek worlds. It's used in Greek Classical Literature of the commissioning of a ship. The Jews used this term of men sent out by rabbis to teach in their name and with their authority.

Not knowing God will rob a person of their God given ‘apostolic nature’. I’m not suggesting that we are all going to be apostles – the Apostles were special individuals who God used at the genesis of the church. However, I do mean that as children of God, we each have a built-in necessity to respond to the commission of God and become ‘a sent one’, an apostle, bringing his message to the world. Knowing God will motivate us to respond to the God who loves to send people out.

Knowing God means that we will come from God. But I know him because I am from him. In a very special way, Jesus came from the Father; he was with his Father before the world was created. However, in a different sense we need to be continually ‘coming from the Father’. Knowing God is rooted in intimacy and fellowship with God and intimacy with God is the only authentic source for life and ministry. It would be wonderful if people could look at our lives and conclude that we have been ‘sent from God!’

Are we like the whale, frantically trying to live life in the shallow? Are our relationships verging on the meaninglessness because they lack vulnerability, honesty and depth?

Or do we really want to know God and experience intimacy with Him so that we can cultivate relationships that are deep, enriching and free from the blight of superficiality.

Father may I never cause Jesus to feel the pain of superficiality.

Bible in a year: Acts 7:30-9:22
title: When people treat us superficially part 3
study_refs: The crowds in Jerusalem wanted to base their thinking around the perspective of the religious authorities. They were not prepared to work out their own understanding, nor where they willing to engage with Jesus and ask him honest questions. Rather, they were carried along with a herd instinct, going with the crowd and swallowing the propaganda of their misguided leaders. Superficiality thrives on ignorance, it never thinks through issues, it never asks big questions, it is gullible, blindly accepting the status-quo.

html:
Thirst is a powerful thing.

We all know how it feels. We’re hot, dehydrated, with a dry mouth, a sore head and an inability to think about anything except…water, water…

It’s such an ordinary, tasteless, drink and yet it can be hard to want anything more, to desire anything as intensely as that ice-cold glass of pure, clear, water. Awww…

There’s nothing like having a thirst quenched. It’s so satisfying. It’s such a sense of relief. It refreshes and restores like nothing else.

It’s no surprise that we talk about ‘thirst’ in relation to lots of other things. It conveys a powerful sense of yearning, needing and searching for something to satisfy.

We all thirst for something. We can all identify with the experience of longing and hoping for something more, something that is real, something that will help us to feel valued and significant. But in reality, thirst is a very difficult thing to manage.

Thirst is an expression of our deepest need but often, we struggle to identify what we are really thirsty for. Even when we think we have recognised what we’re lacking, it’s really easy to turn to inappropriate ways or use inappropriate resources in an attempt to quench our thirst.

Over the next few days, in this next part of the Feast of Tabernacles, we are going to discover some of the wrong ways in which the religious leaders of the time tried to manage their thirst. We’ll see how their inappropriate reactions to Jesus was, in fact, an indicator that they were unable to control or satisfy the thirst that robbed them of real life.

In a desperate attempt to satisfy their thirst for control and their desire to silence Jesus, the insecurity and the hostility of the Pharisees rapidity increases. Ask yourself ‘What am I thirsty for?’ ‘What do the deepest longings of my heart say about me?’ Father may I be motivated by the right thirst’s, help me to honestly identify my thirst

Bible in a year: Acts 9:23-11:30
title: People who cannot manage their thirst. Part 1
study_refs: “ Driving up from Beersheba, a combined force of British, Australians and New Zealanders were pressing on the rear of the Turkish retreat over arid desert. The attack outdistanced its water carrying camel train. Water bottles were empty. The sun blazed pitilessly out of a sky where the vultures wheeled expectantly. “Our heads ached,” writes Gilbert, “and our eyes became bloodshot and dim in the blinding glare...Our tongues began to swell...Our lips turned a purplish black and burst. Those who dropped out of the column were never seen again, but the desperate force battled on to Sheria. There were wells at Sheria, and had they been unable to take the place by nightfall, thousands were doomed to die of thirst. “We fought that day,” writes Gilbert, “as men fight for their lives... We entered Sheria station on the heels of the retreating Turks. The first objects which met our view were the great stone cisterns full of cold, clear, drinking water. In the still night air the sound of water running into the tanks could be distinctly heard, maddening in its nearness; yet not a man murmured when orders were given for the battalions to fall in, two deep, facing the cisterns” He then describes the stern priorities: the wounded, those on guard duty, then company by company. It took four hours before the last man had his drink of water, and in all that time they had been standing twenty feet from a low stone wall on the other side of which were thousands of gallons of water. From an account of the British liberation of Palestine by Major V. Gilbert in The Last Crusade, quoted in Christ’s Call To Discipleship, J. M. Boice, Moody, 1986, p143.

html:
As the Pharisees mingle with the crowd, they become aware of the widespread discussions taking place concerning Jesus. John informs us that ‘Many in the crowd put their trust in him.’

This causes the religious leaders to panic, so they take the initiative in acting against Jesus, persuading the priestly authorities, who were in charge of the temple, to have Jesus arrested. In some ways this is a crucial moment for the Pharisees. They had hoped that fear and intimidation would have silenced Jesus and would have dissuaded the crowds from listening to him. But that had not happened. So in a doomed attempt to regain control, they decide to have Jesus arrested.

Sometimes when people feel threatened they can become aggressive. Their aggression is really an expression of perverted thirst for power, prestige and control.

I have often seen people act this way when someone else is calling the shots or takes the limelight away from them. Their sense of powerlessness leads them to become aggressive, tense, defensive and even angry, wanting to silence the other person.

We all develop subtle ways of trying to silence those who threaten our identity and make us feel vulnerable. Sometimes we question or ‘correct’ every statement they make or try to finish their sentences – as if to say “I think what she really means to say is…” At other times we ‘talk over them’, literally forcing our words to ride roughshod over theirs. Or we simple use a disparaging tone or sarcasm to belittle or embarrass them.

As the religious leaders listen to Jesus and see the effect he is having on the crowds they make a desperate attempt to try and silence him in order to protect their perverted thirst for power and control. So they send the temple guards to arrest him.

The Greek word for guards is huperetes, which means “servants.” It literally means an ‘under-rower’. In ancient days, it referred to those slaves who rowed the sailing ships below deck. These guards were at the disposal of the Sanhedrin, having various duties, “half cultic officials and half police” [Bultmann, p306]. They were considered as the lowest of the low, and the Pharisees sent them to arrest Jesus. At this time, because of the response of some of the people, these religious leaders were too afraid to come to Jesus themselves. So instead, they sent others who they think are dispensable to do their dirty work for them. If the crowds began to riot, they wouldn’t be caught in the middle.

This again is a sinful ploy that we are all guilty of using. Our vulnerability can often prevent us from dealing with an issue ourselves; we don’t want to lose face, so we use others to do our dirty work for us

A long time ago a friend once told me about a difficult conversation they had had with their pastor. The pastor informed them that a number of people were upset because they (my friend) had been wearing jeans to a prayer meeting. (Wow, ‘jeans’…at a prayer meeting! How heaven must have wept that night!)

My friend asked who these people were so they could deal with the issue appropriately, but the pastor refused to identify these ‘denim police’. It seemed pretty clear that the pastor was being deceptive. He was the one who was offended by my friend’s choice of clothing, but was hiding behind others in an effort to save his own reputation and avoid honesty and real communication.

The temple guards had come to arrest Jesus, but instead he arrests them. As they listened to Jesus, they sensed something in the air, something majestic, something powerful, something different. So rather than following through with their assignment, they linger with the crowd and listen in. Instead of taking Jesus captive, these men find themselves being captivated by his life-giving words. Later on in the chapter John writes ‘Finally the temple guards went back to the chief priests and Pharisees who asked them. Why didn’t you bring him in?’ ‘No one ever spoke the way this man does, the guards declared.’ (vv45-46)

It appears that to some degree these soldiers had understood Jesus’ teaching and were able to withstand the pressure to arrest an innocent man who spoke authoritative truth. So what did these guards hear that prevented them from arresting Jesus?

They heard someone speak with a sense of hope despite being in very difficult circumstances.

Look at what Jesus says. ‘I am with you for only a short time, and then I go to the one who sent me.’ John 7:33. Jesus seem to have an acute awareness that what he suffered and experienced in this life would not last for ever, because one day he would return to his Father. Despite his many trials and his profound suffering, Jesus had a sense of hope about the future.

Let me share the following story online:

Bible.org/illustrations/laboratory-experiment.

A number of years ago researchers performed an experiment to see the effect hope has on those undergoing hardship. Two sets of laboratory rats were placed in separate tubs of water. The researchers left one set in the water and found that within an hour they had all drowned. The other rats were periodically lifted out of the water and then returned. When that happened, the second set of rats swam for over 24 hours. Why? Not because they were given a rest, but because they suddenly had hope! Those animals somehow hoped that if they could stay afloat just a little longer, someone would reach down and rescue them. If hope holds such power for unthinking rodents, how much greater should is effect be on our lives. Today in the Word, May, 1990, MBI, p. 34

Hope is essential if we are going to cope with the pressures and demands of life. Hope is something that others find irresistible, it gives a person the ability to live and speak with authority and confidence. Hope is much more than a concept or a theory – it’s something that needs to live in our hearts, given us a healthy perspective on our present reality. Hope has to be experienced not explained.

On the other hand, hopelessness is the belief that this world gives us all we need for life and this is as good as it gets. Hopelessness can be an evidence of unsatisfied thirst, robbing a person of confidence and courage. Emil Bruner said "What oxygen is to the lungs, such is hope to the meaning of life."

They heard someone 'speak with boldness.
Jesus knew that his time had not yet come; he had a certainty that no one could touch him or stop him until the Father allowed it to happen. This gives him the freedom to be courageous. He had nothing to hide, so he lets people know what is going to happen: "I am going to be with you just a little while longer and then I will go away to him who sent me. You will seek for me but you will not find me." John 7:33-34. Jesus didn’t allow himself to be threatened by the evil plots of men. He wasn’t fearful, He was in control.

Napoleon Bonaparte is reported as saying “Courage is like love; it must have hope for nourishment." What I find interesting is that the virtues courage of Jesus was a complete contrast to the immoral cowardliness of the religious authorities who were not prepared to face Jesus themselves. The Old English word for coward was earg which also meant slothful, being cowardly is evidence of being sluggish or apathetic

Lack of boldness and confidence often result from a lack of spirituality. We need to have a strong sense of destiny that is rooted in the belief that our lives belong to a sovereign God who is in absolute control, and who will not allow anything to happen to us outside His will. Grasping the truth of God’s sovereign control will empower us, giving us both authority and confidence.

After telling us that the religious leaders dispatched the temple guards to arrest Jesus, John brings us back to Jesus’ engagement with the crowd. And his words at this point, seem to be causing debate and confusion. "What is he talking about?" they say. "Where does this man intend to go that we can’t find him? Will he go where our people live scattered among the Greeks, and teach the Greeks? What did he mean when he said ‘You will look for me, but you will not find me; and where I am you cannot come’?” John 7:35-36.

Father may I be nourished and comforted by the truth that you are the sovereign God. bible in a year reading plan Acts 12-13
title: People who cannot manage their thirst. Part 2
study_refs: Trying to arrest Jesus.

html:
These guards heard someone speak with love.

‘On the last and greatest day of the feast Jesus stood and said in a loud voice, ‘if anyone is thirsty let him come to me and drink.’

John 7:37.Before we look in detail at what Jesus says here we need to mention a few things

The vulnerability of Jesus’ invitation.

When we consider the events of this day, it’s important to remember that Jesus, far from turning himself away from the multitudes, many of whom had rejected him , extended his gracious invitation: ‘If anyone thirsts, let him come to me and drink.’

This invitation was to the very same people who had been hostile, disbelieving and dismissive of him.

As the guards sent to arrest heard Jesus speak, they not only heard his words, but they also felt his love. The lack of love in our hearts, even for our enemies, will render our words as superficial and useless. Despite the hatred of the people around him, Jesus knew that there were some who had a genuine thirst for God, and Jesus was prepared to open up his life to them.

The timing of the invitation.

It was on the last day of the feast, the day when people were leaving after a week of religious activity. Surly this was the worst time to make such an invitation, or maybe not. People had just experienced the effects that legalistic religion had done to the Jewish religion. It would have been difficult to be spiritually refreshed in Jerusalem at this time because of the hatred and bitterness of the religious authorities. So to prevent people from going away thirsty, Jesus gives this invitation.

c. The immediate context

Their were two important ceremonies that were part of The Feast of Tabernacles' celebration during Jesus' time that are especially important in the context of John 7 and 8. The first involved water and the second involved light. Because The Feast of Tabernacles was an autumn agricultural festival, special prayers for rain were made during the celebration. If rain fell at the time of Tabernacles or shortly afterwards, it was seen as an indication of forthcoming ample rains that would prepare and restore the soil for a successful crop the following year. Zechariah 10:1 contains instructions to pray for rain. Zechariah 14:17 warns that rain will be withheld if the Tabernacles’ ceremony is not properly celebrated.

In the I.V.P New Testament commentary on John’s Gospel, Murray writes:

It is virtually certain that the passage assumes the rite of water-drawing that took place on each of the seven days of the festival proper. The pilgrims entered into the procedures with greatest delight; it is stated, “He who has not seen the joy of the water-drawing has not seen joy in his whole lifetime.” At the break of day priests processed from the temple to the pool of Siloam. There they filled a golden pitcher with water and bore it back to the temple. On approaching the Watergate on the south side of the inner court a trumpet was sounded three times—joyous blasts which were explicitly related to Isa 12:3, “With joy you will draw water from the wells of salvation.” The priests bearing the water then processed around the altar, watched by the pilgrims, while the temple choir sang the Hallel (i.e., Pss 113–18). When the opening words of Psalm 118 were reached, “Give thanks to the Lord,” every man and boy shook the lulab (a bunch of willow and myrtle tied with palm) with his right hand and held aloft citrus fruit in his left hand (a sign of the harvest gathered in), and the cry “Give thanks to the Lord” was repeated three times.’

‘This invitation to come and drink is the climax of a series of references to water in this Gospel: the water turned to wine (chap. 2), the water of the new birth (chap. 3), the living water (chap. 4), the cleansing water of Bethesda (chap. 5) and the calming of the waters (chap. 6). All of these have revealed Jesus as the agent of God who brings God's gracious offer of life.’

Father thank you for the very kind invitation of Jesus.

title: People who cannot manage their thirst Part 3
study_refs: The Jews in Jerusalem thought that Jesus was going to the Diaspora, that is the Jews who were dispersed among the Greek world. ‘ “Where does this man intend to go that we cannot find him? Will he go where our people live scattered among the Greeks, and teach the Greeks.’ John 7:35. To them it seemed that since Jesus couldn’t crack the strictest of Jews living in the heart of Israel, he was going to give up on them and try to influence the less informed and the less committed Jews in the Greek speaking world. They misunderstood what he was saying; they saw this as a defeat for Jesus. They saw this as a way for Jesus to continue His ministry without the threat of the Jewish leaders who lived in Jerusalem.

This incident gives us some insight into misunderstanding and how it works. These people did a number of things that compounded their misunderstanding. (1) They assumed that they understood what Jesus meant when he said "I am going to be with you just a little while longer and then I will go away to him who sent me. You will seek for me but you will not find me, and where I am you cannot come" (2) They didn’t listen properly to what Jesus said. When they quoted Jesus they said ‘what does he mean when he said, you will look for me, but you will not find me, and where I am you cannot come.’ They left out "I am going to be with you just a little while longer and then I will go away to him who sent me.” If they had listened to all that Jesus said, and thought about it they would have been unable to come to the conclusions they did, because Jesus said, ‘then I will go away to him who sent me.’ Not to the Jews in the diaspora. Listening to others means that we choose to hear all they have got to say, and not jump to our own conclusions. (3) John says, ‘The Jews said to one another.’ They didn’t bring their questions to Jesus, but discussed amongst themselves. When people begin to discuss misunderstandings instead of going to the right source where they can be addressed, then people become more inclined to believe fiction over fact. At this juncture Jesus did not correct their misunderstanding,

html:
As people, our lives are producing some kind of ‘water’ i.e. ‘life’ – we are characterized either by ‘living water’ or ‘dead water’. "Living water" is a phrase used for flowing or fresh water, e.g., "running water" in English. Flowing water is usually drinkable water

something very important

The people who were opposing Jesus in this context represented those in need of living water, people who were unable to manage their thirst. The things that came out of their hearts like hatred and murder indicated that they that they were full of ‘dead water’ and in need of new life, of living water.’

The quality of our lives depends upon the work of the Holy Spirit in us. John informs us ‘By this he meant the Spirit whom those who believe in him would later receive.’ (v39). The way Jesus describes the work of the Holy Spirit in the life of a believer is wonderful. We are all in need of the ongoing refreshing work of the Spirit in or lives. The work of the Spirit within us is to continually refresh us so we can endure the pressures of life in a sinful world. We tend to think of the Holy Spirit as a doctrine to be studied, but for the first believers, the Spirit was understood as someone who empowered and refreshed their lives.

Our ability to receive and be matured by the Holy Spirit depends on what kind of relationship we have with Jesus. As we open up our lives to the Lord Jesus, we are more able to receive and experience the ministry of the Holy Spirit. We need to relate to Jesus as thirsty people. It is people who recognise their thirst for real life that are most able to relate to Jesus.

The main focus of the work of the Spirit in our lives is internally, dealing with our characters and emotions. What flows out of our lives is a reflection of the content of our hearts. Real and lasting change cannot take place in our hearts unless the river from within becomes the thing that distinguishes us. When our hearts are full off emotions and attitudes that are contrary to the fruit of the Spirit, then we cannot experience the satisfaction we long for.

There is a sense that what we have received from God is not meant to stay within us, but is to flow out of us. "Water" that stays still becomes stagnant. Could the same thing happen to our faith if it is not shared with others?

Verse 39 says ‘Up to this time the spirit had not been given, since Jesus had not been glorified.’ The oldest and best manuscripts do not contain the word "given." They literally say, "The [Holy] Spirit was not yet, because Jesus had not been glorified" NRSV: reads "For as yet there was no Spirit, because Jesus was not yet glorified". For John the meaning of Jesus being glorified is the crucifixion. John does not mean that the Holy Spirit did not exist until the Cross. After all John's gospel speaks in chapter 1 of the Holy Spirit descending and remaining on Jesus. What he means is that the Holy Spirit fully experienced by people and realised in their lives until after the crucifixion. It can be summed up by saying that Pentecost was not really possible until the events of Calvary had taken place. Thirsty people need to come to the cross – the thirst we all carry can only be quench by a meaningful encounter with God and his love for us through the death of his Son.

More confusion about Jesus’ identity.

Although the crowds heard Jesus speak with the same hope, boldness and love as the temple guards, it did not diminish any confusion they had. The Jews expected a fresh outpouring of the Holy Spirit when the Messiah came. They were keenly aware that the Holy Spirit had been the source of prophecy in the Old Testament and no prophets had arisen since Malachi about 400 B.C. They yearned for a fresh outpouring of the Spirit that would be demonstrated by the renewal of prophecy. When Jesus proclaimed the Spirit as living water coming again in abundance from himself, one logical conclusion would be that Jesus was declaring himself to be the Messiah.

On the other hand some in the crowd could not accept that Jesus was the Messiah because they assumed he was from Galilee, not from Bethlehem. This was the second time they used this argument during the week of the feast. They held onto old conclusions, refusing to make enquires or learn new things.

Speaking clearly and with authority does not guarantee that all people will hear and accept what we have to say. Doing things right, and with right motives will not ensure success, but it will mean that we can stand before God with a clear conscience.

The response of the Jewish leaders

The temple guards return empty-handed not because they had been rendered powerless by Jesus (compare with their later experience in John 18:3-6), nor because they feared the crowds, for some among the crowds also wanted to seize him (contrast later, Mt 26:5 par. Mk 14:2 par. Lk 22:2, 6). Rather, they are struck by the uniqueness of Jesus' message (7:46). This probably accounts for the fact that they were gone for four days (cf. 7:14, 32, 37) instead of an hour or so, as the authorities might have expected! It is right that they should be struck by Jesus' teaching. Here, the eternal Word was speaking about himself, about God and about the salvation he had brought in fulfilment of the promises made through the prophets. Jesus' very way of speaking was unique, as befit his unique message: I.V.P

Notice how the leaders react to the returning guards. They don’t ask the guards what makes Jesus so compelling. Nor do they debate the merits of his claims and they certainly don’t suggest that they would like to hear him for themselves. Instead they do a number of things:

A They ridicule the guards (v.47) "You mean He has deceived you too?" The message is clear, they were asking how the guards could be so stupid and gullible. It's a common form of argument, attack your opponent, then perhaps you won't have to deal with the issue.

B They try to coerce through peer pressure. (v. 48) "Have any of the rulers or of the Pharisees believed in Him?" The message again is clear. If the leaders don't believe in Jesus, then anyone who has any sense won't believe in him either.

C. They belittle and judge the opposition. (v. 49) "No, but this mob that knows nothing of the law, there is a curse on them." Here they insult all who believe in Jesus, referring to them as a gang, an unruly mob, the radicals of their day. The implication is clear - "If you don't want to be known as a rebel…renounce Him."

D. They would not listen to wise advice. We read that ‘Nicodemus who had gone to Jesus earlier and who was one of their number asked, “Does our law condemn anyone without hearing him to find out the facts?”’ John 7:50and yet they rejected what he had to say.

E. They told outright lies. When they responded to Nicodemus by saying that a prophet does not come out of Galilee John 7:52, that was not true, for many believed Jonah was from there.

Often we are like these religious leaders, we have come to some conclusions, and we are determined to avoid facts and truth at all costs, so we do mental gymnastics, twist words, ignore realities, in our desperation to avoid Jesus, and in doing so we remain in our thirst, expressing it in perverted and harmful ways.

As we consider the courage of Jesus in this passage and hear his gracious invitation to all who are thirsty, let us not make the same mistakes as the Pharisees. Let the thirst for life drive us to him, who is the only true source of living water and life everlasting.

Father may living water flow from my life.

html:
Twenty years ago, the term ‘road rage’ was never used, but it has now become part of everyday life. In top-level football matches, no game is complete without extreme expressions of anger and hostility, normally directed at the referee, even when their decisions are proven to be correct. Or take a typical round of ‘Prime Minister’s Questions’ in the House of Commons in London, where the Government and Opposition trade hostilities and insults rather than actually debating the issues of the day.

On the roads, on the football pitch, in the workplace…sometimes at home; we live in a hostile world. And many of us know this to be true from personal experience. If you’ve ever had the misfortune of being hated by someone, or being on the receiving end of their hostility, you’ll know that there is probably nothing more lonely or terrifying.

Our English word ‘hostile’ is from the Middle French word (same spelling) which means ‘of or belonging to an enemy’. It is a potent combination of cynicism, anger and aggression. In psychological terms, hostility has been described as the wilful refusal to accept evidence that one's perceptions of the world are wrong. It gives rise to the hostile person attempting to force or coerce others to come into line with their view, regardless how unlikely the outcome, regardless of the collateral damage.

Of course, ‘hostility’ isn’t just a 21st Century trait. It has marked humanity since the beginning of time. It was certainly around in Jesus’ day. It touched his life and made his relationship with others more difficult. Nowhere is this more evident than in chapter 7 of John’s account of Jesus life.

As we have already seen, Jesus is conscious of the fact that he is hated: “The world cannot hate you, but it hates me because because I testify that what it does is evil.” John 7:7. So, he is fully aware of what lies in wait for him in Jerusalem.

The question for us is how best to respond when someone has a hostile attitude towards us or if someone is aggressive and angry with us for no good reason? As we tag along with Jesus and join him in Jerusalem, we may discover some appropriate ways to manage hostile situations.

Setting the scene

Reading the early verses of John 7, we notice that the writer’s focus shifts from Jesus’ private life to the public domain, from familiarity to the unknown. Jesus’ journey takes him, and us, from a place of misunderstand to an environment of animosity.

At Feast time it was normal for families to go together up to Jerusalem; usually whole villages would travel together. This ensured safety and added to the sense of celebration. However, John informs us that ‘After his brothers left for the festival, Jesus also went, though secretly, staying out of public view.’

The Greek word for ‘secret’ is kruptos meaning ‘hidden’ – it’s the word from which we get our English word ‘cryptic’.

I think this must have been a very lonely moment for Jesus. As his community, family and friends travel to Jerusalem with a sense of anticipation and joy, Jesus travels as a lone and solitary figure. He doesn’t want to draw attention to himself or put others at risk. Nor does he feel the need to prove himself or to rush into Jerusalem with blazing authority. He just quietly approaches the place of conflict, because he feels secure in his Father. But soon the secrecy of this arrival will be shattered.

To add to the tension, John informs us that at the Feast, ‘…the Jewish leaders were watching for Jesus and asking, “Where is he?” (NIV1984)

Even before he arrives into the city, Jesus has already been singled out for surveillance. The religious leaders are watching and waiting for the chance to pursue their murderous intent.

During the Feast of Tabernacles, Jerusalem would normally have been buzzing – with a sense of carnival and joy. But on this occasion, something felt different, something wasn’t right.

John tells us that:

Among the crowds there was widespread whispering about him. Some said “He is a good man.” Others replied, “No, he deceives the people.” But no- one would say anything publicly about him for fear of the Jews. (v12)

This is very descriptive of the atmosphere in the city. Jesus is a marked man and both he and the crowds know it.

The Greek word for whispering is goggusmos. It means ‘sullen discontent, murmuring, criticism.’ It describes the low, threatening and discontented muttering of a mob that distrusts its leaders and is on the verge of an uprising. It is always associated with rebellion.

The Jewish leaders were expert at creating an atmosphere of fear, and the people of Jerusalem are being very careful about what they say concerning Jesus. It must have been a strange and difficult situation for Jesus to be in. The atmosphere is heavy with hostility and fear; people are glancing at Jesus as they whisper to each other.

Father thank you that Jesus understands when we are faced with tense and hostile situations

Bible in a year: Acts 19-20
title: When people are hostile towards us. Part 1
study_refs: Do you ever notice how much hostil ity and anger is around these days?

html:
It would be very easy to miss the enormity of that statement.

For those of us who lived through ‘the troubles’ in Northern Ireland, there will be at least some awareness of the impact fear can have on whole communities. That’s what ‘terrorism’ seeks to create – a sense of widespread fear. It’s what the Nazis used as a means of control. It’s what Nicolae Ceausescu and his Securitate used to suppress and silence Christians in Romania. On a more personal level, it’s what some employers use to control their employees or some husbands use to manipulate and oppress their wives. And sadly, fear can occasionally be used in churches to make sure people conform to and comply with the desires and wishes of those in charge. Rather than being places of freedom and honesty, such churches can become places where people are scared to speak out and express their questions and doubts.

From a national to an individual level, fear has been used as a controlling pressure by insecure people who misuse their positions of authority.

The nature of the hostility directed at Jesus

Usually the hostility of a person says more about them than the person they are being hostile towards. Our hostility towards others unmasks us and shows others what we are really like. Our hostility is a bold declaration of our loveless hearts; hostility is my inappropriateness and immaturity, preventing me from dealing with the differences in others that threaten me.

Hostility starts in the heart and is usually revealed by the words that we say; often the words spoken in the context of hostility reveal a loss of perspective and confusion.

Some said he is a good man. Others replied “No, he deceives the people”.

The climate of fear added much confusion about the identity of Jesus. ‘Some said he is a good man.’ The term ‘good’ here is the Greek word agathos. The Greeks had many words for good, but the word agathos tends to be used with a specific meaning. It does not just mean ‘good’ as we might use it, but it implies a goodness that is automatically inside or part of you because of who you are. Intrinsic goodness.

Others said Jesus was a deceiver. The word for ‘deceives’ is the Greek word planao, from which we get our English word 'planet'. The stars have fixed points in the sky but the planets are so-called ‘wandering stars’. Literally, this word means ‘to cause to stray, or to lead astray.’ They were accusing Jesus of diverting people from the orbit of truth.

John is indicating that there is no consensus about Jesus; peoples’ strongly held opinions about him are fuelling the tension. The interesting thing here is that these people are talking about Jesus, not talking to him. They don’t come to him with genuine questions; they make no attempt to seek clarification or understanding. Their minds are firmly closed and the gossip mongers are having a field day, arousing suspicion, spreading inaccuracy and inciting fear.

In telling us of the divided opinion about Jesus, John is preparing us here for the later debate about the identity of Jesus in verses 25-36. He is also keeping before the reader’s mind the question, “Who is he?”

Father may I live a life that is free from thee destructive power of fear.

Bible in a year: Acts 21:1-23:25.
title: When people are hostile towards us. Part 2
study_refs: Hostility will always produce fear, and often that fear can paralyse people. As John tells us , ‘…no-one would say anything publicly about him for fear of the Jews.’

html:
Lucius Annaeus Seneca, Roman philosopher, statesman, orator, and tragedian, who was Rome's leading intellectual figure of his time, said ‘He who dreads hostility too much is unfit to rule.’ http://www.britannica.com/eb/article-9083818

It is important that Jesus faces and confronts this hostility, if he is to reveal himself as the true Messiah.

As we look at Jesus’ response to the hostility he is facing here, we need to keep in mind that Jesus isn’t interested in self-promotion, he isn’t on some ego-trip. Rather, the complete opposite is the case. He understands that humility empowers a person to respond to the hostility of others in such a way as to disarm the protagonist.

So what does Jesus do?

Jesus shows courage


John says: ‘Not until halfway through the feast did Jesus go up to the temple courts and begin to teach.’

Jesus knows the Jews are seeking to kill him. For the past six months, he has kept away from Judea to avoid arrest or worse and now, suddenly, Jesus appears in Jerusalem, boldly teaching in the temple. This is incredible!

Often the fear of people can hinder us from facing situations or circumstances that are hostile. Being courageous is more to do with a person’s moral strength than their personality type. The English word for courage is from the French for ‘heart’ (coeur) – to be courageous is to live out of the heart. Revelation 20:8 helps us understand the importance of courage and its moral significance. We are given a list of people who will not enter heaven but are bound for the lake of fire.

“But the cowardly, the unbelieving, the vile, the murderers, the sexually immoral, those who practice magic, the idolaters and all liars—their place will be in the fiery lake of burning sulphur. This is the second death.” [NIV 1984]


The interesting thing about this list is that it begins with the cowardly, those who have no courage – those who refuse to live out of the heart. Perhaps the list begins with the cowardly because often a lack of courage in the face of hostility causes us to be drawn into other sin. The vulnerability caused by the hostility of others can stop us from living out of the heart, and so we begin to compromise our integrity and put up a front in order to placate our aggressor.

Jesus shows wisdom

John says ‘Not until halfway through the feast did Jesus go up to the temple courts.’ He doesn’t go up to the temple straight away, but he waits a few days, assesses the situation and gets a feel for what is going on.

When we are faced with hostile situations, it is very easy to react, to act without thinking. There is something within us that wants the problem to be fixed at once. Because of the vulnerability created within us, we look for the quick fix, the immediate solution. But more often than not, we would do well to pause, allow ourselves time to process the situation and respond accordingly.

Jesus shows discernment

When the people heard Jesus teach, John says ‘The Jews were amazed and asked, “How did this man get such learning without having studied?”’

This statement could be understood in two different and opposite ways. They could be saying, “Wow, what a teacher, he is worth listening too.” But given the context, it is more probable that these people aren’t so much admiring Jesus as finding ways to avoid the impact of his message. “Why should we listen to him, he hasn’t been educated?” They are calling into question his status as a valid teacher. However, Jesus is able to see behind their words.

When we are involved in hostile situations, we need God’s help to hear more than the words people are saying; we need to see the heart behind the words. However, this is not a license to make assumptions or to jump to conclusions.

The reason the people know that Jesus didn’t study at a rabbinical school was that he teaches differently from the other rabbis. When the other rabbis taught, they would always cite other authorities (i.e. widely respected rabbis): “According to Rabbi Hillel...” “Ah, but Rabbi Shammai says...” But Jesus never quotes other rabbis. Read the Sermon on the Mount. “You have heard it said unto you…but I tell you…” Jesus speaks from his own authority.

Jesus is dependent on God.

John 7:16, ‘My teaching is not my own, it comes from Him who sent me.’

What Jesus teaches is the direct consequence of his relationship with his Father, from whom he is continually learning new things. Jesus has a ‘teachable’ attitude, his learning is an expression of his dependence on his Abba.

When dealing with hostility, it is important that we face it from a stance of dependence upon God. We depend on God not because of the hostility, but because this is how we should be living our lives – in intimate relationship with our Father. Hostility cannot make us truly dependent on God, but it can reveal and increase the extent of our ongoing dependence and the depth of our relationship. One of the reasons why people find it hard to handle hostility is because they often feel that their source of life is being threatened. However, if we are dependent upon God and He is our source of life, then we have nothing to fear, for no hostility can threaten Him.

Jesus is transparent

He who speaks on his own does so to get honour for himself, but he who works for the honour of him who sent him is a man of truth, there is nothing false about him.

In the face of hostility, integrity and honesty are essential. We need to be real people who live out the truth. The desire for self-glory will rob a person of integrity and reality. In the face of opposition, we often feel the need to protect our reputation and preserve our ego, but in doing so, we can sacrifice our authenticity and forget who we really are. It is so tempting when we are trying to deal with hostility to resort to subtle, underhand tactics in order to protect us from further pain. But authentic living is costly – it involves vulnerability and can feel isolating. That’s how it was for Jesus, that’s how it should be for us.

Father may I have the spiritual maturity to face hostility like Jesus. bible in a year reading plan Acts 23:26-27:8.
title: When people are hostile towards us. Part 3
study_refs: Jesus’ response to hostility

html:
In verses 19-23 Jesus changes tack. Instead of continuing his defence of himself, he points out four things about his opponents. The reason why he does this is because he wants them to be real about themselves.

1. They disregard the Law of Moses.

John 7:19a, ‘Has not Moses given you the law? Yet not one of you keeps the law.’

We need to keep in mind that the context of what Jesus is saying here is his previous visit to Jerusalem when he healed the man at the pool of Bethesda on the Sabbath. The Jewish leaders were accusing Jesus of being a lawbreaker because of that episode. But in reality they were the real lawbreakers. Often in hostile situations people can accuse innocent people of the very sin of which they are guilty.

2. They have murder in their hearts

John 7:19b “Why are you trying to kill me?”

The fact that they have murderous intentions shows us that they are guilty of not keeping the law. Any unjustified hostility towards another person is evidence of a murderous heart.

3. They are inconsistent.

John 7:21-22 “I did one miracle, and you are all amazed. Yet, because Moses gave you circumcision (though actually it did not come from Moses, but from the patriarchs), you circumcise a boy on the Sabbath Now if a boy can be circumcised on the Sabbath so that the law of Moses may not be broken, why are you angry with me for healing a man’s whole body on the Sabbath?

These same people accused Jesus of defiling the Sabbath because he healed a man. Yet they practised circumcision on the Sabbath. They honestly thought that it was acceptable for them to break the Sabbath by doing the work of circumcision, but it was not all right for Jesus to heal on that same day. Unjust hostility reflects inconsistency and double standards.

4. They make superficial judgements.

John 7:2e “Stop judging by mere appearance, and make the right judgment.”


Unjust hostility is usually based on wrong conclusions, superficial judgments and ignorance of the facts. When we judge situations, circumstances or people on appearance, we will make a wrong assumption and draw incorrect conclusions. Judging by appearance is an expression of unrighteousness, judging by appearance is refusing to look at the heart of a matter; it is making a superficial response, which in turn encourages hostility.

So what are we to do with hostility?

On that day in Jerusalem, as Jesus spoke in the temple, trying to be heard by those who did not know him, love him or understand him, he must have felt emotionally drained. It’s easy to overlook such realities, but we must keep in mind that although Jesus was God he was also fully human. As such he taught us how to handle the pain and confusion of hostility.

Many people read passages like John 7 through a theological lens, but primarily it is a practical passage to help us know Jesus better, and to help us to become better people in the face of our own hostility. How we handle hostility is a real reflection of our spirituality and our relationship with God. It is so easy to feel insecure and threatened when we are being treated badly and misunderstood.

Like Jesus, we need to constantly find our security in God, so when hostility comes we will not fall apart, but will be secure in Him.

Father help me understand those who may be hostile towards me.

html:
If we are really going to grasp what Jesus is saying here, then we need to firstly see these verses as a warning. Jesus is warning against something. The first two words are “Be careful,’ As we have mentioned before. It would be temping to just read over these two words and miss what they are saying. ‘Be Careful’ is one word in the Greek, PROSECHO. It means to “be continually guarding against.” It has the idea of continually watching yourself. It was used to describe the skill of a sea captain who was able to bring his vessel into harbour without beaching it on the hidden shallow rocks. Remember the first disciples were fisher men, who would have been able to relate to what Jesus is saying here.

So when we read “Be Careful,” Jesus is wanting to get our attention, he is saying that if we do not hear what he is going to say, we are in danger of beaching our faith and shipwrecking our testimonies. What he goes on to say may seem strange to us. Jesus gives this very strong warning about doing your righteous acts before men and not before Gpd.

You who are parents what kind of things do you feel you need to warn you children about, Usually things that will endanger their live, or destroy their characters, so like a good parent Jesus is warning us about the danger of turning our Christian profession into a performance motivated by a desire to get the approval of others.

The heart attitudes that lie behind anyone turning their relationship with God into religious exhibitionism is the same heart attitudes that sabotage genuine faith and authentic spirituality. If our Christian faith is all about appearance and the need of the approval of other then we are in great danger. If how we look is more Important than how we are, then we can be sure that we are in the process of walking away from God.

Father help me be more concerned about the condition of my heart more than how I appear to others.

Bible in a year: Romans 1:16-5:11
title: Save me from my religion. Part 1
study_refs: The warning.

html:
When our focus is on how we look, and when the approval of others is essential for life, then we are driven by our insecurities. The Pharisees of Jesus’ day done their righteous acts before men, because they were basically very insecure. They wanted to be liked, they wanted to be thought highly off, they wanted to be looked upon with a sense of respect, they wanted to be considered to be spiritual and they wanted the seal of approval from others. So their whole life was about how others saw them. Why were they driven by insecurities? let me say, as we have mentioned before that the Fatherhood of God is mentioned more in this chapter than any other chapter in the bible.

When our focus is on how we look, and when the approval of others is essential for life, then we will never be able to be honest or real. So often how we look is so disconnected from how we are. We want to give the impression that we are strong, that we have got it all sorted, that we doing okay, but in reality we are feel far from God, we are plagued with doubts and confusion, and we would love someone to come along and put their arm round us and just accepts us in our mess. Being a follower of Jesus is a call to honesty and reality, not hypocrisy

“Hypocrisy,” Barclay explains is “the sin of using religion to cover up sin. A hypocrite is not a person who falls short of his high ideals, or who occasionally sins, because all of us experience these failures. A hypocrite deliberately uses religion to cover up his sins and promote his own gains.” https://thepreachersword.com/2023/04/20/negative-effects-of-religious-hypocrisy/#:~:text=%E2%80%9CHypocrisy%2C%E2%80%9D%20Barclay%20explains%20is,and%20promote%20his%20own%20gains.%E2%80%9D

So to be a hypocrite is much more serious than an inconsistent life, it is the deliberate use of religious activity to deceive others and hide your own sin and failure and need in order to promote a false image about yourself, in order to get the approval of others.

When our focus is on how we look, and when the approval of others is essential for life, then we are judging spirituality wrongly. I find it very interesting how we conclude if a person is spiritual or not. The Pharisees believed that if a person kept all external rules, i.e. if they were seen to attends the place of worship, and practices spiritual disciplines then they must be spiritual people. In our day we have fallen into the same trap, we think if a person goes to church, reads their bible, has a quiet time, wares the right cloths, and reads a certain version of the bible then they must be okay spiritually. But that is like trying to use a speedometer to measure the weight of something. God evaluates our spiritual life’s not by what we do, but by who we are. By the condition of our hearts and what we carry in them. I have seen this so often, and I have be guilty of it to, where people use religious activity to hide what is really go on in our hearts.

When our focus is on how we look, and when the approval of others is essential for life, we end up with spiritual fatigue. Wearing a mask, pretending to be someone we are not is extremely hard work and very sapping. Hiding behind a mask and refusing to be honest and real will never encourage or enrich a life. Rather it will drain a man of life and hope, and he wont experiencing the love and acceptance he craves for. Sometimes Christians keep themselves so busy either trying to be noticed, or trying to ease the ache of emptiness they carry in their hearts.

Father I confess that hiding and pretending are exhausting.

Bible in a year: Romans 5:12-8:25.
title: Save me from my religion. Part 2
study_refs: So why is focusing on the external, and seeking the approval of men such a threat to authentic spirituality?

html:
Pagan believed that the more time they spent praying, the more earnest they were, and then their god had to respond. The equated length of prayers with deserving an answer. In their thinking they thought that they could earn God blessings, they thought that God owed them, they thought that they could control God by being deserving of a response from him. In their paganism they never thought in terms of grace or favour. Does this sound familiar. Sometimes we are guilty of subliminal paganism, we think we can placate or appease God by our righteous act and long prayers. Every time we make ourselves the centre of our Christian experience we are guilty of practising clandestine paganism. At its essence paganism is raw selfishness.

So we need to ask how can we protect ourselves from falling into religious activity were we are more concerned about pleasing people or ourselves rather than God?

How can we become people of genuine spirituality?

As we have said before, in this chapter God is spoken of as ‘Father’ more than any other chapter in the bible. Twelve times in this chapter Jesus mentions the word Father. This is quite amazing. Jesus did not give us a list of rules, or ‘dos’ or ‘don't s’ rather he talks a lot about God as father. Look a Matthew 6:1, 4,6x2, 8, 9,14, 15, 18x2, 26, and 32 Many Christians are motivated by guilt and shame, and it is impossible for guilt or shame to produce spiritual life, in fact guilt and shame will encourage you to live before people not before God. Living a Godly life is not about conforming to external pressure, it is not about ticking boxes or keeping rules. Rather it is about enjoying the reality of God’s love and living in the reality of it. If we are not responsive to God’s love, if knowledge of God’s love is not at the essence of our being, then it will be impossible to live a holy life. God’s love is the greatest sanctifying influence we will ever know.

Father it is so easy for me to think and act like a pagan.
