title: Save me from my religion. Part 3
study_refs: When our focus is on how we look, and when the approval of others is essential for life, we in danger of cultivating the mindset of a pagan. I don’t know about you, but I find Jesus words here quite shocking, what we think as being spiritual, Jesus equates it with paganism. When the Pharisees prayed long elaborate prayers in public Jesus says that they were praying like pagan, Matthew 6:7 And when you pray, do not keep on babbling like pagans, for they think they will be heard because of their many words. Do not be like them, We need to critique what Jesus is saying here.

html:
If you were to ask people what we celebrate at Christmas, many would rightly say that we celebrate the birth of Jesus? However, if you were to ask, ‘what are the implications of Jesus’ birth? Or how should it, or how has it affected or changed their lives?, we would probably get a lot of questioning looks!!!

A lot of people are inclined to think about Christmas in the same way as they would view a Hans Christian Anderson story. It has a kind of ‘fairy tale’ feel about it. However, when you tear away all they myths and misunderstandings that surrounds the Christmas story, we discover a story that will perhaps disturb, challenge and expose the priorities by which we have chosen to live.

When we turn to the New Testament and try to grasp what really happened, we will discover that the story of Jesus’ birth exposes what kind of relationship we have with him. Christmas is an opportunity for us to ask ourselves ‘How am I treating Jesus?’ Perhaps we have turned the Christmas story into a fairytale which doesn’t make any demands of us, nor does it challenge our thinking?

So as we unpack this part of the Christmas story, we are going to examine how we are relating to Jesus in the here and now​? As we go through our passage we need to ask ourselves, ‘what kind of relationship do I have with Jesus’? Everyone of us relates to Jesus in some way. Everyone of us responds to, and treats Jesus in some way. No matter who we are we all have an opinion about Jesus, and we have all decided what kind of relationship we want with him. Hopefully as we look at the people in this part of the Christmas story and how they related to Jesus, we will be able to see who we best identify with, and see what we can change so we can discover the great honour of loving Jesus more.

1. Herod.

He was threatened by Jesus.

Matthew places the birth of Jesus in a political context, Matthew wants his readers to see that Jesus as King. So in chapter 2 he introduces Jesus as king of the Jews. When Herod heard this he was deeply disturbed. The word Matthew uses to ddescribe Herod's emotions means to be 'deeply disturbed' Greek word tarassō, this was a very emotional word, which carries the idea of acute mental distress, disquiet, to make restless, it literally means to shake back and forth. So what is going on here?

Let me tell you a few things about Herod. He was named king of the Jews by the Roman Senate in 40 B. C. By 37 B. C. he had crushed, with the help of Roman forces, all opposition to his rule. He was wealthy, politically gifted, intensely loyal, an excellent administrator, and clever enough to remain in the good graces of successive Roman emperors. His famine relief was superb and his building projects (including the temple, begun 20 B.C.) were admired even by his foes.

But he loved power, he inflicted incredibly heavy taxes on the people, and resented the fact that many Jews considered him a usurper. In his last years, suffering an illness that compounded his paranoia, he turned to cruelty and in fits of rage and jealousy killed close associates, his wife Mariamne and at least two of his sons. Caesar once said it was better to be Herod’s pig than his son.

Here is the point, Herod understood if Jesus was born King of the Jews, then he could not be King of the Jews, so his control, power and position was threatened. He was terrified of not being in control. For him power and position were essential, so he would go to any length to protect his throne and kingdom.

We might not like to admit it, but there is something of Herod in all of us. We may not be cruel like him but we want to be in control, we want to be king of our lives.

However, the message of Christmas is, ‘You cannot be king/queen, you cannot be in control.’ The message of Christmas is that Jesus is King, not me, not you.

Like Herod we develop subtle and almost in-perceptible ways of holding onto our thrones. Father thank you that Jesus is a threat to my selfish way of life. Bible in a year reading plan Romans 11:25-15:33
title: wise men part 1
study_refs: Christmas can be like Marmite, most people love it, but there are some who really hate it. But whether you love it or hate it, (or perhaps you hate what it has become), we can say with some degree of certainty that it is not properly understood.

html:
a. He was motivated by his emotions.

Herod allowed his emotions to control his thinking and determine his actions. He was paranoid and irrational. As we have seen he was in acute mental distress. There is in verse 4 something that we don’t pick up in our English translations. When we are told that he asked the teacher of the law, where the Messiah was to be born, it would be better understood that he kept on asking and asking and asking. There was a sense of panic and paranoia. Paranoia is very debilitating, and will always keep a person from truly worshipping Jesus, because it produces within a person a fear that ensures that they become the centre of their universe. There will always be a need to protect whatever is under threat, in this case it was Herod's throne.

b. He made plans in secret.

Look at verse 7. ‘Herod called for a private meeting.’ There was a duplicity, a hidden agenda about Herod, but even worse, he wanted to involved others in his duplicity. Herod must had been very convincing because God had to warn the men of Herods evil plan. There is always something intrinsically deceitful in the act of trying to keep control, or when we strive to hold onto a position of power or prestige.

c. He needed to lie in order to secure his objective.

‘When you find him come back and tell me so I can worship him.’ This was the use of spiritual language to express a bare face lie. He was hiding behind a claim that he wanted to worship Jesus.

d. He lashed out at others.]

Read verses Matthew 2:16-18. He was furious and innocent baby boys lost their lives. Sometimes the fear of not being in control can cause us to lash out at others causing them to suffer. We may not be cruel and barbaric like Herod. But sometimes when we are feeling threatened and not in control of our circumstances, we can lash out at others. When our ‘thrones’ are threatened we can go into fight mode to protect our lordship over our own lives.

Father in subtle ways we can be Herod and fight to keep control.

Bible in a year: Romans 16 1 Corinthians 1:1-4:13
title: wise men part 2
study_refs: There are four things that Herod did in his attempt to eradicate the threat he was feeling.

html:
The “Magi” are not easily identified with precision. They were thought to be a class of royal court officials who were consulted when the king needed divine guidance. They were known as a priestly caste of Medes who enjoyed special power to interpret dreams. Daniel 1:20; 2:2; 4:7; 5:7 refers to magoi in the Babylonian Empire. In later centuries down to NT times, the term loosely covered a wide variety of men interested in dreams, astrology, magic, books thought to contain mysterious references to the future, and the like.

They played both political and religious roles and were figures of some prominence in their land. Some Magi honestly inquired after truth; many were rogues and charlatans.

The important thing about the Magi in Matthew’s story is that they had a consuming desire to worship Jesus. Could it be that Matthew records this story first to teach us what is really means to appropriately respond to Jesus? This is the first time we read about worship in the New Testament. The word ‘proskyneo’ worship means to express in attitude or gesture, one’s complete dependence on, or submission to a high authority figure. (fall down and) worship, be obedient to, to prostrate oneself before, to welcome respectfully. These wise men knew that if they were every going to have a life changing encounter with Jesus they would need a heart that longed to worship Jesus. Lets notice a few things about their worship.

1. Their heart for worship meant that they live lives that were completely opposite to Herod and all that he stood for. As we have seen Herod lived a life that was motivated by the selfishness of his paranoia. These wise men on the other hand were very eager to meet with Jesus.

2. The heart of worship was intentional.

‘We have come to worship Him.’ Do you realise that we worship Jesus as much or as little as we want to? If we reduce worship to coming to church and singing then we will never worship properly, not even if we come to church and sing songs. Worship can only be a heart attitude that will lead to a life of total surrender. Jesus deserves and expects nothing less. This is the message of Christmas. Imagine having the words ‘we have come to worship him,’ written over our lives.

Father may my life discover the glory of worshiping you

Bible in a year: 1 Corinthians 4:14-7:40
title: wise men part 3
study_refs: Who were the ‘Magi’ or wise men?

html:
Their worship meant that they had to leave the darkness of the past. In all probability these men were involved in the dark crafts of the occult, so the journey they made to see Jesus was as much spiritual as it was geographical. There is one thing we can be certain about, if they had stayed where they where, they would have never worshiped Jesus. This was not an easy journey, geographically it was between 800-1000 miles. Spiritually, it was light years away.

4.Their worship meant they had the faith to humble themselves. As they came into the house they saw Jesus. who was probably a toddler at the time, and they prostrated themselves before him. This was a holy moment, this was the greatest moment in the lives of these wise men, as they lay with their faces in the ground before the King of the universe embodied in the physical frame of a toddler.

5. Their worship was costly, or was it? We know that they gave Jesus treasures of gold, frankincense and myrrh. We know that these are very costly, however, this kind of worship does not measure its giving in terms of cost, even if it is costly. This kind of worship thinks in terms of privilege not cost. Worship says, ‘Lord it is a totally undeserved honour and wonderful privilege of life for me to bow in worship before you and give you all that I am and have.’

Thirdly. Let me draw your attention to one more group of people. The leading priests and the teachers of the religious law. I am incline to think that these were the worst characters in our story. They were religious people who knew their scriptures, they knew God’s plans and God’s promises, and yet they had no heart for Jesus. As we know Jesus was born in Bethlehem about five miles from Jerusalem. However, we have no record of them going to find him or bowing down in worship before him.

I live in a country where lots of people are brought up in Christian homes, they are taught the scriptures, they go to church. They may profess to be Christian. But if we could see inside their hearts we might discover that they are more like the religious leaders than like the wise men. They have no real desire for God, they really don’t grasp the wonder of worship, and maybe at times they are like Herod, feeling a bit threatened by Jesus. I hope this advent we find ourselves challenged by the Christmas story.

Father I pray that my religious practices will not keep me from authentic worship of you

title: wise men part 4
study_refs: After they had heard the king, they went on their way, and the star they had seen when it rose went ahead of them until it stopped over the place where the child was .When they saw the star, they were overjoyed. html:
Luke 2:8-20. And there were shepherds living out in the fields nearby, keeping watch over their flocks at night.. An angel of the Lord appeared to them, and the glory of the Lord shone around them, and they were terrified. But the angel said to them, “Do not be afraid. I bring you good news that will cause great joy for all the people. Today in the town of David a Saviour has been born to you; he is the Messiah, the Lord. This will be a sign to you: You will find a baby wrapped in cloths and lying in a manger.” Suddenly a great company of the heavenly host appeared with the angel, praising God and saying, “Glory to God in the highest heaven, and on earth peace to those on whom his favour rests.”When the angels had left them and gone into heaven, the shepherds said to one another, “Let’s go to Bethlehem and see this thing that has happened, which the Lord has told us about.” So they hurried off and found Mary and Joseph, and the baby, who was lying in the manger. When they had seen him, they spread the word concerning what had been told them about this child, and all who heard it were amazed at what the shepherds said to them. But Mary treasured up all these things and pondered them in her heart. The shepherds returned, glorifying and praising God for all the things they had heard and seen, which were just as they had been told.

One of the things I love to study is the Christmas story. In some ways this story has become the Christianised version of’ ‘Chinese whispers’; so many myths and legends have become attached to the birth of Jesus that have developed a false relevance or an incomplete relevance to our lives.

The story of Jesus’ birth has been buried under fabricated traditions that it has become so sentimentalised that we are no longer shocked or disturbed by it.

For example it has often been assumed and taught that the shepherds were ‘down and outs’, I myself have wrongly believed this to be the case!!

“The rabbis considered them to be religious outcasts and their testimony was not admissible in court.” The conclusion that shepherds were societal outcasts has been reached by many scholars, and they have repeated this concept over and over again. For example, Farrar said in 1893, “Shepherds at this time were a despised class.” The problem with this understanding is that, it removes the challenge of the nativity story from the context of our lives. There are a number of reasons why people believed and taught this.

The two main sources used for understanding shepherds in first-century Israel are the Mishnah and the Babylonian Talmud. The Mishnah is a collection of rabbinic sayings. Rabbis would debate issues pertaining to the Old Testament and Mosaic Law. This collection of rabbinic traditions was from the time period before Christ started his public ministry up until around the year AD 200. It was written between AD 200 and 250. The Talmud is not helpful for interpreting the New Testament.

Many of the quotations are simply too late to be reliably useful because the rabbis are so far removed from the first-century context. https://research.lifeway.com/2015/12/17/christmas-urban-legends-shepherds-as-outcasts/ accessed 16/042025

There is better evidence for the idea that shepherds were not viewed as societal outcasts: the overarching biblical portrayal of shepherds. The description of shepherds in the Old and New Testaments would be formative for the minds of first-century Jews and Christians.

Beginning in the Old Testament, Exodus 3:1 says Moses was a shepherd: “Meanwhile, Moses was shepherding the flock of his father-in-law Jethro.” David was a shepherd (according to 1 Samuel 17) who took care of his father’s flocks.

These men are pillars of the Old Testament. Moses, and David were all connected to shepherding, and they were greatly esteemed in Jewish society.

So what can we learn from this passage of Scripture?

Father help me t0 work hard so I can understand your word and think through what I am being taught.

title: Shepherds encounter with the angels part 1

html:
Luke 2:8-20. And there were shepherds living out in the fields nearby, keeping watch over their flocks at night.. An angel of the Lord appeared to them, and the glory of the Lord shone around them, and they were terrified. But the angel said to them, “Do not be afraid. I bring you good news that will cause great joy for all the people. Today in the town of David a Saviour has been born to you; he is the Messiah, the Lord. This will be a sign to you: You will find a baby wrapped in cloths and lying in a manger.” Suddenly a great company of the heavenly host appeared with the angel, praising God and saying, “Glory to God in the highest heaven, and on earth peace to those on whom his favour rests.”When the angels had left them and gone into heaven, the shepherds said to one another, “Let’s go to Bethlehem and see this thing that has happened, which the Lord has told us about.” So they hurried off and found Mary and Joseph, and the baby, who was lying in the manger. When they had seen him, they spread the word concerning what had been told them about this child, and all who heard it were amazed at what the shepherds said to them. But Mary treasured up all these things and pondered them in her heart. The shepherds returned, glorifying and praising God for all the things they had heard and seen, which were just as they had been told.,

I think the best way to understand these shepherds is to see them as prototypes. They show what kind of affect the birth of Jesus should have on our lives.

1.The everyday spaces of life can be touched by the excitement of God-

’Suddenly a great company of the heavenly host appeared with the angel, praising God and saying, “Glory to God in the highest heaven, and on earth peace to those on whom his favour rests.”

These shepherds were living out in the fields when suddenly and unexpectedly a great company of heavenly host appeared. There was nothing special about this field. It was just an ordinary field touched with the presence and glory of God.

2. The nativity sanctifies the ordinary.

We are too platonic in our thinking. What does that men? We are inclined to see our worlds in two distinct categories. Sacred and secular.

As you read through the Old Testament you will notice that the glory of God was revealed on very specific occasions in very sacred locations like the dedications of the tabernacle, (see Exodus 40:34ff) Solomon’s temple, (see 2 Chronicles 7:1ff), and at the giving of the law. (Exodus 19-20.) The coming of Jesus has changed all that. The ordinary places of our lives is where we most need to meet God a be disturbed by his glory.

What is the glory of God?

When we think of the glory of God, we are inclined to think in terms of splendour or brightness, and yes, the idea of glory does contain these elements. However, the Hebrew word “kavod” is translated as “glory”, and this word contains the essence of something of value, of great appreciation, wealth, honour and weight.

So to be aware of God’s glory, is to allow the weight of God’s presence to influence your thinking and behaviour.

Imagine standing on a platform with a medium-sized aquarium full of water below you. Then imagine lifting a concrete block, aiming it just right, and dropping it into the aquarium, causing damage, and a bit of a splash.

When we encounter the glory of God, our agendas, priorities, and lives often get blown out of the water. Do you remember in Isaiah 6 the temple shook because of the weight of God’s glory

Encountering the glory of God means that you will be curtailed or contained because you are conscious of the presence of God. It is to allow the conscious presence of God to reset your desires, hopes and expectations.

‘Our Lord finds our desires, not too strong, but too weak. We are half hearted creatures, fooling about with drink and sex and ambition when infinite joy is offered us, like an ignorant child who wants to go on making mud pies in a slum because he cannot imagine what is meant by the offer of a holiday at the sea. We are far too easily pleased.’ C S Lewis

https://www.goodreads.com/quotes/702-it-would-seem-that-our-lord-finds-our-desires-not

Father may my normality be touched by your glory.

title: Shepherds encounter with the angels part 2

html:
Luke 2:8-20. And there were shepherds living out in the fields nearby, keeping watch over their flocks at night.. An angel of the Lord appeared to them, and the glory of the Lord shone around them, and they were terrified. But the angel said to them, “Do not be afraid. I bring you good news that will cause great joy for all the people. Today in the town of David a Saviour has been born to you; he is the Messiah, the Lord. This will be a sign to you: You will find a baby wrapped in cloths and lying in a manger.” Suddenly a great company of the heavenly host appeared with the angel, praising God and saying, “Glory to God in the highest heaven, and on earth peace to those on whom his favour rests.”When the angels had left them and gone into heaven, the shepherds said to one another, “Let’s go to Bethlehem and see this thing that has happened, which the Lord has told us about.” So they hurried off and found Mary and Joseph, and the baby, who was lying in the manger. When they had seen him, they spread the word concerning what had been told them about this child, and all who heard it were amazed at what the shepherds said to them. But Mary treasured up all these things and pondered them in her heart. The shepherds returned, glorifying and praising God for all the things they had heard and seen, which were just as they had been told.

The incarnation teaches us that the ordinary spaces of our lives, need to become places were we are influenced by the weight of Gods presence.

God’s glory carries the idea of great significance or impact. Every time we pray for God’s glory we are asking that the weight of God reshape our thinking and lives.

Let us not look for a lightweight God.

Let's not make God into a lightweight God who has little influence in our lives. Let’s not try to fit God neatly in our lives.

Let’s quit acting like his glory will only lead to minor ripples. These shepherds experienced a ‘holy disturbance,’ they were terrified or greatly afraid. Although, at this moment they were never more alive. They had an encounter with God that unsettled them.

We all need a God who will cause us to fear Him and will take away our fear at the same time.

3. We need to recognise the essential requirement of choosing vulnerability.

Look at what the angel said to the shepherds. Luke 2:12 ‘This will be a sign to you: You will find a baby wrapped in cloths and lying in a manger. A baby wrapped in cloths and lying in a manger.’

Luke is using this verse as a contrast to verses 1-2 which read, ‘In those days Caesar Augustus issued a decree that a census should be taken of the entire Roman world.

Caesar Augustus and a baby in a manger. What a contrast. God chose vulnerability, the very thing we try to avoid at all costs. There is so much we can learn from this.

Is it possible to enter into God’s will without vulnerability?

There is something God-like in choosing to be vulnerable, weak and helpless. We have bought into the lie that says we must be strong, be in control. have answers and solutions for every problem. We dare not appear weak or needy.

a. Could it be that our resistance to vulnerability is a subliminal way of resisting sanctification and the way of holiness?

Often in attempting to manage our vulnerability we resort to sinful deeds and habits in the hope we gain a measure of control.

b. Because a decision or a circumstance exposes our vulnerabilities it does not mean they are wrong or bad.

Sometimes we can allow fear or a perceived lack of ability prevent us from making a decision. Some people wrongly believe that there will always be an inner peace about the will of God, if that was so we would never leave our comfort zones.

4.The nativity means that we need to develop a Jesus-seeking lifestyle.

The shepherds demonstrated the importance of looking for Jesus.

Luke writes. ‘When the angels had left them and gone into heaven, the shepherds said to one another, “Let’s go to Bethlehem and see this thing that has happened, which the Lord has told us about.” So they hurried off and found Mary and Joseph, and the baby, who was lying in the manger.’

The shepherds were more than eager to find Jesus. They were zealous in their determination.

Some times as Christians we stop looking for Jesus. It is easy for any of us to think, ‘I’ve been a Christian for many years, I know Jesus!’ Ask yourself do you have an eager determination in your heart. Are we prepared to drop everything like these shepherds did, to have a new revelation of God?

The Nativity not only teaches us that Jesus came to Earth to be our Saviour, he also came to transform our lives and how we live. The every day spaces of our lives need to become holy ground were the glory and excitement of God are celebrated. And by the grace of God we will spend the rest of our lives pursuing Jesus.

Father may Jesus make a difference in every area of my life

html:
The etiquette of unwanted Christmas gifts

I wonder did you get any presents at Christmas you didn’t really want. So what did you do with unwanted presents and how do you avoid hurting the feelings of those who took the time and trouble to buy, wrap and give you a gift they thought you would like – or even love! Apparently there is a set etiquette for dealing with unwanted gifts.

Here are our top six tips to help you navigate the etiquette pitfalls.

Keep your plans under wrap

It’s best not to discuss unwanted presents in case you inadvertently tell the person who bought you that onesie what you thought of it. If you do tell people what you do with unloved presents be thoughtful, or you could end up looking a bit insensitive.

Regifting works, but be careful

Straightforward passing on of a gift to another person – regifting – can be a great solution. Check everything is in good order and fits or is suitable for the person you are regifting it to.

The ‘swap’ shop Holding a Christmas present ‘swapping’ party sounds like a great idea but you run the very real risk of seeing your friends’ faces fall as you all realise you’ve all brought each others’ carefully planned and exquisitely wrapped presents along to swap. (One to avoid).

Take the presents back

If you know where a gift came from you’ll probably be able to take it back and swap it or get a credit voucher in its place. If you don’t, you could ask the person who bought it for the receipt if they still have it. This is likely to go down a lot better if it’s an item of clothing bought in the wrong size but if it’s simply a case of not liking it, feelings could be trampled and relationships bruised.

Sell unwanted presents on eBay

As the Marie Claire November issue highlighted, demand and prices for Apple goods, Samsung, and Lego are high on EBay but look through the listings and there’s a market for nearly everything.

Give gifts to charity

Whatever your reasons for not wanting to keep Christmas presents, you can put them to good use and make a real difference to other people’s lives. Take them to your local charity shop and they’ll raise money for a good cause – and free up storage space in your home.

However, what happens when the unwanted gift is the grace of God? This may be a difficult concept to get our heads around, but there are some people who find it difficult if not impossible to receive grace. Paul spoke of those who ‘set aside’ the grace of God. Galatians 2:21. Even more surprisingly there are many people who want to follow Jesus find it hard to receive grace. No one would ever say, ‘I don’t want the grace of God,’ it is not something we would ever verbalise or even recognise. But we can develop an attitude that causes us to resist and refuse God’s grace. It is possible for any one of us to develop a mindset, or have a world view that will cause us to develop a default position of resisting grace. Our understanding of God and our relationship with him is viewed in such a way, that our natural response will be to try and live without grace. Their will never be a circumstance or a day in our lives where we will not n need the grace of God.

Father help me to honestly recognise my continual need of your grace.

title: shunning the grace of God part 1
study_refs: I do not set aside the grace of God, for if righteousness could be gained through the law, Christ died for nothing. Meanwhile, the older son was in the field. When he came near the house, he heard music and dancing. So he called one of the servants and asked him what was going on. ‘Your brother has come,’ he replied, ‘and your father has killed the fattened calf because he has him back safe and sound.’ “The older brother became angry and refused to go in. So his father went out and pleaded with him. But he answered his father, ‘Look! All these years I’ve been slaving for you and never disobeyed your orders. Yet you never gave me even a young goat so I could celebrate with my friends. But when this son of yours who has squandered your property with prostitutes comes home, you kill the fattened calf for him!’ “‘My son,’ the father said, ‘you are always with me, and everything I have is yours. But we had to celebrate and be glad, because this brother of yours was dead and is alive again; he was lost and is found.’”

html:
This is one of the best known parables of Jesus, but although it is well known, I don’t think it is very well understood. When you read the parables of Jesus you should always look for the ‘sting in the tale,’ the ending is never quite what you expect or hope for. So when you read the story of the prodigal son you are surprised to realise that the real prodigal is not the younger son who squandered his resources, but the elder brother who squandered his life, because he refused to understand grace, or receive it.

Before we look at this story, I think it is important to mention the cultural context of the story. One commentator Kenneth Bailey points out, that it is hard for us to imagine how insulting the older son's behaviour was to his father. He suggests that we imagine a wealthy man having a black tie, candle lit dinner for prestigious guests, only to have his son show up at the door unshaven, without shirt and shoes, and begin to verbally attack the father. According to Bailey, this analogy is too mild to convey the revolting nature of the older son's behaviour. He suggests that the behaviour of this son is actually more cutting than the behaviour of the youngest son at the beginning of the story. At least that disrespect was done in private.

We are going look at his attitudes that made it impossible for him to receive the grace of his father, and how the lack of grace affected him.

The elder son ran from the father into the activity of service. The first thing we are told about the elder son is, ‘Meanwhile, the elder son was in field.’ This is not a throw away statement but a succinct description of how the elder son lived, and what he lived for. The field was a symbol that summed up his life. He was the kind of person who tried to medicate his pain by doing, and found his value and significance in what he achieved. He buried himself in doing to compensate for his poor relationship with his father. In Christian circles people often fall into the trap of becoming too busy that they cannot really grasp what is important to the father.

Hard work is a good thing, but when our work becomes a place where we hide from dealing with the reality of our own hearts, then it is wrong, and this was the sin of the elder brother. Sometimes we use Christian service as a smoke screen to hide the real us.

When we fall into the mindset that puts too high a value on service we become incapable of receiving or enjoying the grace of God because our lives will be all about us trying to meet our own needs and medicate our own pain. Serving God is a wonderful thing if it is not being used to replace intimacy with the father. We will only experience healing and fullness in the embrace of the father. Sometimes our emptiness or baroness can drive us into service. If we were in the world we might turn to drugs, alcohol, materialism or some other vice to medicate our pain. Often Christian service can become ‘vice like,’ for it is used as means of anaesthetising ourselves from the pain of reality..

Father may I never use Christian service to anaesthetise my pain but let me be healed by your grace.

I do not set aside the grace of God, for if righteousness could be gained through the law, Christ died for nothing. Meanwhile, the older son was in the field. When he came near the house, he heard music and dancing. So he called one of the servants and asked him what was going on. ‘Your brother has come,’ he replied, ‘and your father has killed the fattened calf because he has him back safe and sound.’ “The older brother became angry and refused to go in. So his father went out and pleaded with him. But he answered his father, ‘Look! All these years I’ve been slaving for you and never disobeyed your orders. Yet you never gave me even a young goat so I could celebrate with my friends. But when this son of yours who has squandered your property with prostitutes comes home, you kill the fattened calf for him!’ “‘My son,’ the father said, ‘you are always with me, and everything I have is yours. But we had to celebrate and be glad, because this brother of yours was dead and is alive again; he was lost and is found.’”

The danger of a deal mentality.

The elder son had a transactional understanding of his relationship with his Father. ‘Look all these years I’ve been slaving for you and never disobeyed your orders. Yet you never even gave me a young goat so I could celebrate with my friends.’ He had a ‘deal mentality,’ a ‘you owe me’ attitude. On the surface, the elder brothers reasoning seemed to be completely justified. He had worked hard for his father, surely he deserved? But, this is not how God works; for God to give us what we deserved would break His heart and ours. The elder son had a deal mentality. ‘I do, therefore I deserve, therefore you owe.’

When we begin to relate to God in the context of a deal our devotion will be contaminated and polluted. We will be devoted to God not because we love him for who He is, but because we want Him to do what we want and give us what we want. Our devotion is sustained with the hope that God will keep his side of the bargain. Our love for God has strings attached, and we begin to develop a ‘satanic’ mindset, for it was Satan who said to God, “Does Job fear God for nothing?” Job 1:9. In other words “God has to buy mankind’s affection, he cannot be loved for himself.

Elisabeth Elliot tells an apocryphal story that illustrates the deal mentality that can prevent any of us from receiving the Grace of God.

One day Jesus said to his disciples: ‘I’d like you to carry a stone for me.’

He didn’t give any explanation. So the disciples looked around for a stone to carry, and Peter, being the practical sort, sought out the smallest stone he could possibly find. After all, Jesus didn’t give any regulation for weight and size! So he put it in his pocket. Jesus then said: “Follow Me.” He led them on a journey. About noon, Jesus had everyone sit down. He waved his hands and all the stones turned to bread. He said, “Now it’s time for lunch.” In a few seconds, Peter’s lunch was over. When lunch was done Jesus told them to stand up. He said again, “I’d like you to carry a stone for me.”

This time Peter said, “Aha! Now I get it!” So he looked around and saw a small boulder. He hoisted it on his back and it was painful, it made him stagger but he said, “I can’t wait for supper.” Jesus then said: “Follow Me.” He led them on a journey, with Peter barely being able to keep up. Around supper time Jesus led them to the side of a river. He said, “Now everyone, throw your stones into the water.” They did. Then he said, “Follow Me,” and began to walk. Peter and the others looked at him dumbfounded. Jesus sighed and said, “Don’t you remember what I asked you to do? Who were you carrying the stone for? https://delmelinscott.blogspot.com/2022/03/who-are-we-carrying-stone-for. Accessed 12/08/25

Father help me to love you only for you.

study_refs: I do not set aside the grace of God, for if righteousness could be gained through the law, Christ died for nothing. Meanwhile, the older son was in the field. When he came near the house, he heard music and dancing. So he called one of the servants and asked him what was going on. ‘Your brother has come,’ he replied, ‘and your father has killed the fattened calf because he has him back safe and sound.’ “The older brother became angry and refused to go in. So his father went out and pleaded with him. But he answered his father, ‘Look! All these years I’ve been slaving for you and never disobeyed your orders. Yet you never gave me even a young goat so I could celebrate with my friends. But when this son of yours who has squandered your property with prostitutes comes home, you kill the fattened calf for him!’ “‘My son,’ the father said, ‘you are always with me, and everything I have is yours. But we had to celebrate and be glad, because this brother of yours was dead and is alive again; he was lost and is found.’”
We want to look at two questions, 1. Why would people refuse grace? 2. What are the consequences of refusing grace?

Writing to the Christians in Galatia Paul said ‘I do not set aside the grace of God, for if righteousness could be gained through the law, Christ died for nothing.’ Galatians 2:21. The word translated ‘set aside,’ is atheteō which means to reject, it was used to describe the annulling of a will, or to treat something as having no value. In the Greek translation of the Old Testament, Septuagint, the word is often translated unfaithful or betray, to rebel and scorn. The Christians in Galatia had developed a resistant posture towards God’s grace; they were beginning to treat the grace of God as an unwanted gift. want to is try and examine the attitudes and mindset that prevents a person from receiving the grace of God. We want to look at the story of the elder brother in the parable of the Prodigal Son.

html:
Let us consider some of the consequences of refusing the grace of God.

The older brother allowed anger to reign in his heart. The older brother was so angry. (The Greek word for angry is orgizo which means "passionate rage." It comes from the root word orgao which referred to plants and fruits swelling with juice to the point of bursting.) The older brother in the parable was so filled with rage that he was ready to burst! He was "so mad he could have exploded!" The word also implies an abiding habit of the mind. Look at what he says about his younger brother. ‘But when this son of yours who has squandered your property with prostitutes comes home, you kill the fattened calf for him.’

Anger and grace are incompatible. Now we all know that Jesus got angry, but his anger was always against injustice and the suffering of others. It was never an expression of wounded pride, or selfish thinking, or self pity. Often our anger is about having our toes stood on, or our feelings hurt and it can be an expression of selfishness. Grace heals a persons heart, anger is an indication the healing is needed. Angry people are usually those who have a host of issues they have not dealt with. Their anger may be the result of mishandling their pain. Sometimes, anger is the thing people resort to when they are feeling vulnerable or insecure, they use their anger to try and control the situation. The gentle grace of God can calm the anger that rages in a person’s heart.

He lived like a slave, not as son. He forgot who he really was; he suffered from an identity crisis. He said to his father ‘Look! All these years I’ve been slaving for you! He did not see himself in terms of being a son involved in a joint enterprise with his father, but as a begrudging slave trapped in resentment and animosity. If only he could accept who his father was, and who he was. If he could but realise as a son of this father, he was going to be the recipient of grace. When we forget who we are, refusing to realise that we are completely accepted and loved by God, we will begin to struggle with receiving grace, developing a slavish adherence to a set of rules and expectations with no ability to cultivate the intimacy of a healthy relationship with our Father. One of Satans greatest and most effective weapons is to rob us of the joy of being the children of God. When Jesus was in the wilderness He came under the same attack when his identity was challenged. ‘If you are the Son of God...’ This elder brother had stopped thinking and acting like a son. This change in his thinking was gradual. As he began to get value and significance from what he was doing, the less he was able to enjoy it.

He lacked honesty about himself and honesty with his father. Reading the elder brothers assessment of himself, it appears that he had little if any self-awareness. He was blind to his own faults; he refused to recognise his own short comings and sin. He uses exaggerated language to cover his is sin. ‘I have never disobeyed your orders!’

At times we all suffer from blind spots, we all can become ignorant to the stuff that is going on inside our own hearts, it is important that see our sin for what it is, and although this is painful, it is freeing and opens us up to receive grace. There are other people who constantly see their sin, they are constantly feeling guilty and belittling themselves, this too is wrong, and can prevent a person from receiving grace, because they believe their sin is greater than the grace of God. God wants us to be honest about ourselves but not crush ourselves under self condemnation.

He was full of resentment and bitterness towards his brother. ‘This son of yours has wasted your wealth with prostitutes!’ This was much more than a cruel slander, after an accusation like that, if he can make it stick, no one is ever going to marry the guy, no family is ever going to give their daughter to this man.

We have been made to receive and share grace; it is a basic inbuilt default position. However, if we are refusing to receive grace, then we will not have the essential ability we will need to cope with the difficulties that are part of everyday normal relationships and we will end up becoming bitter lonely people with an incapacity for celebration and joy.

The saddest thing about this elder son was that he was unable to understand or grasp his father’s heart. He didn’t really get his father. What was important to his father was not important to him. He could not grasp why his father would be so kind and loving towards his brother. Grace isn’t fair and never will be. If we all got what we deserved we would be on a road to hell! So there’s no point in trying to understand it from any other position other than, it’s what God wants for us!

When God pours his grace into our lives, it is one of the ways he teaches us about who he is. It is a means of revelation; it is how he shares his heart with us. The younger son received the father grace and could enter into his father’s joy, the elder son couldn’t.

Three principals that help us live in grace.

Recognise the difference between having a relationship with the father and having fellowship with the father in that we may call ourselves Christians but not have intimacy with Him.

Being real is more important than how we appear.

Being a child is more important than service.

Father it is so easy to have angry heart like the older brother and not share your heart.

When Isaac was old and his eyes were so weak that he could no longer see  he called for Esau his older son and said to him, “My son.” “Here I am,” he answered. Isaac said, “I am now an old man and don’t know the day of my death. Now then, get your equipment—your quiver and bow—and go out to the open country to hunt some wild game for me Prepare me the kind of tasty food I like and bring it to me to eat, so that I may give you my blessing before I die.” Now Rebecca was listening as Isaac spoke to his son Esau. When Esau left for the open country to hunt game and bring it back, Rebecca said to her son Jacob,“Look, I overheard your father say to your brother Esau, ‘Bring me some game and prepare me some tasty food to eat, so that I may give you my blessing in the presence of the Lord before I die. Now, my son, listen carefully and do what I tell you: Go out to the flock and bring me two choice young goats, so I can prepare some tasty food for your father, just the way he likes it. Then take it to your father to eat, so that he may give you his blessing before he dies.” Jacob said to Rebecca his mother, “But my brother Esau is a hairy man while I have smooth skin. What if my father touches me? I would appear to be tricking him and would bring down a curse on myself rather than a blessing.” His mother said to him, “My son, let the curse fall on me. Just do what I say; go and get them for me.” So he went and got them and brought them to his mother, and she prepared some tasty food, just the way his father liked it. Then Rebecca took the best clothe of Esau her older son, which she had in the house, and put them on her younger son Jacob. She also covered his hands and the smooth part of his neck with the goatskins. Then she handed to her son Jacob the tasty food and the bread she had made. He went to his father and said, “My father.”“Yes, my son,” he answered. “Who is it?” Jacob said to his father, “I am Esau your firstborn. I have done as you told me. Please sit up and eat some of my game, so that you may give me your blessing.” Isaac asked his son, “How did you find it so quickly, my son?” “The Lord your God gave me success,” he replied. Then Isaac said to Jacob, “Come near so I can touch you, my son, to know whether you really are my son Esau or not.” Jacob went close to his father Isaac, who touched him and said, “The voice is the voice of Jacob, but the hands are the hands of Esau.” He did not recognize him, for his hands were hairy like those of his brother Esau; so he proceeded to bless him. Are you really my son Esau?” he asked.“I am,” he replied. Then he said, “My son, bring me some of your game to eat, so that I may give you my blessing.” Jacob brought it to him and he ate; and he brought some wine and he drank. Then his father Isaac said to him, “Come here, my son, and kiss me.” So he went to him and kissed him. When Isaac caught the smell of his clothes, he blessed him and said, “Ah, the smell of my son is like the smell of a field that the Lord has blessed. May God give you heaven’s dew and earth’s richness—an abundance of grain and new wine. May nations serve you and peoples bow down to you. Be lord over your brothers, and may the sons of your mother bow down to you. May those who curse you be cursed and those who bless you be blessed.”After Isaac finished blessing him, and Jacob had scarcely left his father’s presence, his brother Esau came in from hunting.He too prepared some tasty food and brought it to his father. Then he said to him, “My father, please sit up and eat some of my game, so that you may give me your blessing.” His father Isaac asked him, “Who are you?” “I am your son,” he answered, “your firstborn, Esau.” Isaac trembled violently and said, “Who was it, then, that hunted game and brought it to me I ate it just before you came and I blessed him—and indeed he will be blessed!” When Esau heard his father’s words, he burst out with a loud and bitter cry and said to his father, “Bless me—me too, my father But he said, “Your brother came deceitfully and took your blessing.” Esau said, “Isn’t he rightly named Jacob? This is the second time he has taken advantage of me: He took my birthright, and now he’s taken my blessing!” Then he asked, “Haven’t you reserved any blessing for me?” Isaac answered Esau, “I have made him lord over you and have made all his relatives his servants, and I have sustained him with grain and new wine. So what can I possibly do for you, my son?”Esau said to his father, “Do you have only one blessing, my father? Bless me too, my father!” Then Esau wept aloud. His father Isaac answered him, “Your dwelling will be away from the earth’s richness, away from the dew of heaven above. You will live by the sword and you will serve your brother.
But when you grow restless, you will throw his yoke from off your neck.” Esau held a grudge against Jacob because of the blessing his father had given him. He said to himself, “The days of mourning for my father are near; then I will kill my brother Jacob.” When Rebecca was told what her older son Esau had said, she sent for her younger son Jacob and said to him, “Your brother Esau is planning to avenge himself by killing you. Now then, my son, do what I say: Flee at once to my brother Laban in Harran. Stay with him for a while until your brother’s fury subsides. When your brother is no longer angry with you and forgets what you did to him, I’ll send word for you to come back from there. Why should I lose both of you in one day?” Then Rebecca said to Isaac, “I’m disgusted with living because of these Hittite women. If Jacob takes a wife from among the women of this land from Hittite women like these, my life will not be worth living.” Genesis 27

Sometimes when read the bible it can be very difficult because the passage we are reading from is extremely practical, and because it is so practical, it confronts, challenges and disturbs us. Sometimes we would rather listen to teaching that is doctrinal or theological, teaching that feeds our minds. However, if we are being taught something that is very practical, then we are more tempted to disengage, to switch of. What we want to look at a passage that is very practical, and extremely relevant to everyone.

Before we look at this passage let me start by saying that the nature and quality of a persons relationship with God is primarily displayed in the context of the family. In other words, if we were able to watch your family dynamics we would have a clear picture of what kind of love you have for God. What is life like behind the closed door of your home?

Also, it is interesting that the most comprehensive teaching about spiritual warfare in the New Testament is found in the context of Paul teaching about healthy family relationships in Ephesians 5 and 6. Christian family is something that Satan hates, and so he will do all he can to turn family life into a ‘war zone,’ or a centre for ‘crisis management. In saying that, this fact in no way removes us from our responsibilities

As Christians who are followers of Jesus, it is important that we live as families that seek and honour God, however, for some Christians, family life has slowly become dysfunctional, their homes have ceased to be a sacred space, set apart for love and nourishment. I remember being shocked by a young girls story, of how her abusive father was an elder in a local evangelical church. Dysfunctionality within any family is never an objective or a goal, no family seta out to be dysfunctional. it is the evolving consequence of attitudes and actions we express and do through the course of our everyday lives.

So what can we learn from our story.

1. When love dies, so does joy.

Reading through our passage it is very obvious that Isaac and Rebekah were no longer in love with each other. The bible describes in detail their affection for each other when they first met. Look at these verses from Genesis 24:62-67.

‘Meanwhile, Isaac, whose home was in the Negev, had returned from Beer-lahai-roi One evening as he was walking and meditating in the fields, he looked up and saw the camels coming. When Rebekah looked up and saw Isaac, she quickly dismounted from her camel.“Who is that man walking through the fields to meet us?” she asked the servant. And he replied, “It is my master.” So Rebekah covered her face with her veil. Then the servant told Isaac everything he had done. And Isaac brought Rebekah into his mother Sarah’s tent, and she became his wife. He loved her deeply, and she was a special comfort to him after the death of his mother.

The mention of love in marriage is not always found in Hebrew story because most marriages were arranged by the families of the couple. But for Isaac and Rebekah there was a strong emotional commitment to each other. We are told that ‘he loved her deeply’ However, by the time we get to chapter 27, their love for each other had become something in the past. The pain and challenges of life caused them to stop loving each other. They were together and not together at the same time.

There can be situations and circumstances where no matter how much you try, or how much you choose to love, you will not be able to reach the other person. However, as Christians, we have a God given obligation to make a deliberate choice to continually love our spouse and verbally and practically express that love daily. As we read through this chapter we get a warning that the homes of people who have a relationship with God can imperceptibly erode into places of dysfunctionality where there is no joy.

Father thank you for the amazing honour of loving our spouses for the rest of our lives.

The NLT says in verse 1 that Isaac was turning blind, other translations say he was completely blind, either way, |Isaac was someone with a loss of vision. When you read Genesis 27:1 you could easily get the impression that Isaac was on his deathbed, but he wasn’t, in fact he lived for a further 43 years. It is as if he had given up on life, maybe he thought God had finished with him. So he died before his death.

Also notice that his lack of vision made him self centered, and caused him to live out of his feelings not by faith. Look at these words.

However, when we begin to loose our spiritual vision we will go through life dependent on what we can relate to through our senses. So we think is terms of ‘what feels right!’ When we live on the basis of our senses, looking for instant gratification of our desires or appetites, we become less discerning.

If you were to read chapters 27:1-28-5 you will notice that there are seven short conversations. 1. Isaac and Esau 27:1-4. 2. Rebecca and Jacob 27:5-17 3. Isaac and Jacob 27:18-29. 4. Isaac and Esau, 27:30-40. 5. Rebecca and Jacob. 27:41-45. 6. Rebecca and Jacob. 27:46. 7. Isaac and Jacob 28:1-5. There is no record of them talking as a family. The communication between Isaac and Rebecca was minimal and was at cross purposes.

I do not think it is possible to emphasise how essential communication is for a good marriage and a healthy family life.

Let me make a few provocative statements and suggestions.

a. Recognise that honest, truthful communication expressed in love is one of the ways we express our devotion and commitment to each other.

b. Lack of communication with in marriage means that we could end up sleeping with a stranger.

c. Communication in marriage between spouses and with the whole family should become our default position. In other wards the more you do it the more you will do it.

d. Use the natural events of everyday life as an opportunity to communicate. For example when you eat your meals, don’t have a television or any other device distracting you. Make meal time a device free zone.

e. When communication happens naturally or spontaneously then let it happen. For example, if you begin to have a good, stimulating or important conversation over a meal, don’t be thinking, ‘look at the time and the dishes are not done,’ if you don’t have to be somewhere else for a commitment or an appointment, you should boil the kettle and savour the joyous honour of family talk.

f. If we only use family communication as a tool for ‘crisis management’ it actually becomes less effective for dealing with crisis and it could be counter productive.

Father may we become expert in communicating

html:
When Isaac was old and his eyes were so weak that he could no longer see  he called for Esau his older son and said to him, “My son.” “Here I am,” he answered. Isaac said, “I am now an old man and don’t know the day of my death. Now then, get your equipment—your quiver and bow—and go out to the open country to hunt some wild game for me Prepare me the kind of tasty food I like and bring it to me to eat, so that I may give you my blessing before I die.” Now Rebecca was listening as Isaac spoke to his son Esau. When Esau left for the open country to hunt game and bring it back, Rebecca said to her son Jacob,“Look, I overheard your father say to your brother Esau, ‘Bring me some game and prepare me some tasty food to eat, so that I may give you my blessing in the presence of the Lord before I die. Now, my son, listen carefully and do what I tell you: Go out to the flock and bring me two choice young goats, so I can prepare some tasty food for your father, just the way he likes it. Then take it to your father to eat, so that he may give you his blessing before he dies.” Jacob said to Rebecca his mother, “But my brother Esau is a hairy man while I have smooth skin. What if my father touches me? I would appear to be tricking him and would bring down a curse on myself rather than a blessing.” His mother said to him, “My son, let the curse fall on me. Just do what I say; go and get them for me.” So he went and got them and brought them to his mother, and she prepared some tasty food, just the way his father liked it. Then Rebecca took the best clothe of Esau her older son, which she had in the house, and put them on her younger son Jacob. She also covered his hands and the smooth part of his neck with the goatskins. Then she handed to her son Jacob the tasty food and the bread she had made. He went to his father and said, “My father.”“Yes, my son,” he answered. “Who is it?” Jacob said to his father, “I am Esau your firstborn. I have done as you told me. Please sit up and eat some of my game, so that you may give me your blessing.” Isaac asked his son, “How did you find it so quickly, my son?” “The Lord your God gave me success,” he replied. Then Isaac said to Jacob, “Come near so I can touch you, my son, to know whether you really are my son Esau or not.” Jacob went close to his father Isaac, who touched him and said, “The voice is the voice of Jacob, but the hands are the hands of Esau.” He did not recognize him, for his hands were hairy like those of his brother Esau; so he proceeded to bless him. Are you really my son Esau?” he asked.“I am,” he replied. Then he said, “My son, bring me some of your game to eat, so that I may give you my blessing.” Jacob brought it to him and he ate; and he brought some wine and he drank. Then his father Isaac said to him, “Come here, my son, and kiss me.” So he went to him and kissed him. When Isaac caught the smell of his clothes, he blessed him and said, “Ah, the smell of my son is like the smell of a field that the Lord has blessed. May God give you heaven’s dew and earth’s richness—an abundance of grain and new wine. May nations serve you and peoples bow down to you. Be lord over your brothers, and may the sons of your mother bow down to you. May those who curse you be cursed and those who bless you be blessed.”After Isaac finished blessing him, and Jacob had scarcely left his father’s presence, his brother Esau came in from hunting.He too prepared some tasty food and brought it to his father. Then he said to him, “My father, please sit up and eat some of my game, so that you may give me your blessing.” His father Isaac asked him, “Who are you?” “I am your son,” he answered, “your firstborn, Esau.” Isaac trembled violently and said, “Who was it, then, that hunted game and brought it to me I ate it just before you came and I blessed him—and indeed he will be blessed!” When Esau heard his father’s words, he burst out with a loud and bitter cry and said to his father, “Bless me—me too, my father But he said, “Your brother came deceitfully and took your blessing.” Esau said, “Isn’t he rightly named Jacob? This is the second time he has taken advantage of me: He took my birthright, and now he’s taken my blessing!” Then he asked, “Haven’t you reserved any blessing for me?” Isaac answered Esau, “I have made him lord over you and have made all his relatives his servants, and I have sustained him with grain and new wine. So what can I possibly do for you, my son?”Esau said to his father, “Do you have only one blessing, my father? Bless me too, my father!” Then Esau wept aloud. His father Isaac answered him, “Your dwelling will be away from the earth’s richness, away from the dew of heaven above. You will live by the sword and you will serve your brother. But when you grow restless, you will throw his yoke from off your neck.” Esau held a grudge against Jacob because of the blessing his father had given him. He said to himself, “The days of mourning for my father are near; then I will kill my brother Jacob.” When Rebecca was told what her older son Esau had said, she sent for her younger son Jacob and said to him, “Your brother Esau is planning to avenge himself by killing you. Now then, my son, do what I say: Flee at once to my brother Laban in Harran. Stay with him for a while until your brother’s fury subsides. When your brother is no longer angry with you and forgets what you did to him, I’ll send word for you to come back from there. Why should I lose both of you in one day?” Then Rebecca said to Isaac, “I’m disgusted with living because of these Hittite women. If Jacob takes a wife from among the women of this land from Hittite women like these, my life will not be worth living.”

Jacob shows us that lies and deceit destroy family life.

a. He was not concerned about truth.

Three times he refers to himself as Esau. he says ‘It’s Esau your first son.’ verse 19. The Hebrew of this verse reads, ‘Esau I am truly.’ This is what happens when people want to make a lie more convincing. They can over emphasise certain words to sound more credible; Jacob amplifies the enormity of his deceit by referring to him self as firstborn.

He claimed to have done something he hadn’t.

‘I’ve done as you told me. Here is the wild game. Now sit up and eat it so you can give me your blessing.’ There are two parts to this lie. He did not do what he said he did and the meat he brought was goat not venison which Jacob had asked for.

He dressed in Esau's clothes to give the wrong impression. His appearance was to propagate his lie, who I am and who you think I am are very different!

He tried to spiritualise his deceit.

Listen to what he said.

Isaac asked, “How did you find it so quickly, my son?” “The Lord your God put it in my path!” Jacob replied. He used the name of God, {note not his God] to give credence to his deceit.

When family members sacrifice truth, resorting to lying to each other in order to promote and protect their own agenda, this is a family on the road of dysfunctionality. If we are unable to be honest and real with each other in a loving and gracious manner, then we are creating an unholy space where God cannot be honoured and people will not know the blessing of being nourished in an atmosphere of Godly love

Why not sit down as married couples and ask yourselves.’Are we still in love? do we have honest and loving communication? or have we become strangers?

Why not sit down as a family and critique your life as a family. What is good about you family life? what is not so good? What could you do to improve family life? What small changes could you take to deepen and grow your communication with each other?

What is going on behind your closed door?

Father may our families be places of truth

During the night Jacob got up and took his two wives, his two servant wives, and his eleven sons and crossed the Jabbok River with them. After taking them to the other side, he sent over all his possessions. This left Jacob all alone in the camp, and a man came and wrestled with him until the dawn began to break. When the man saw that he would not win the match, he touched Jacob’s hip and wrenched it out of its socket. Then the man said, “Let me go, for the dawn is breaking!” But Jacob said, “I will not let you go unless you bless me.” “What is your name?” the man asked. He replied, “Jacob.” “Your name will no longer be Jacob,” the man told him. “From now on you will be called Israel, because you have fought with God and with men and have won.” “Please tell me your name,” Jacob said. “Why do you want to know my name?” the man replied. Then he blessed Jacob there. Jacob named the place Peniel (which means “face of God”), for he said, “I have seen God face to face, yet my life has been spared.”The sun was rising as Jacob left Peniel, and he was limping because of the injury to his hip (Even today the people of Israel don’t eat the tendon near the hip socket because of what happened that night when the man strained the tendon of Jacob’s hip.)

Let share a paragraph from The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe.

“Is he a man?” asked Lucy.

“Aslan a man!” said Mr. Beaver sternly. Certainly not. I tell you he is King of the wood and the son of the great emperor-beyond-the-sea. Don’t you know who is the King of the Beasts? Aslan is a lion – the Lion, the great lion.”

“Ooh!” said Susan, “I’d thought he was a man. Is he – quite safe? I shall feel rather nervous about meeting a lion.”

“That you will, dearie, and no mistake,” said Mrs. Beaver; “if there’s anyone who can appear before Aslan without their knees knocking, they’re either braver than most or else just silly.”

“Then he isn’t safe?” said Lucy.

“Safe?” said Mr. Beaver; “don’t you hear what Mrs. Beaver tells you? Who said anything about safe? ‘Course he isn’t safe. But he’s good. He’s the King, I tell you.”

Is he safe?

Asalm and God are alike, good but sometimes not safe. As we look at our passage we are going to discover that God is too good to be safe all the time; we are going to learn about the pain of grace.

I don’t know if you have ever thought of God not being safe. Remember this was God who wrestled with Jacob and gave him a permanent disability, this is not the kind of God that we want, but it is the kind of God that we sometimes need. If we were to find ourselves in Jacobs situation, were we were frightened and distressed, [see verse 7,] we would want a cuddle, we would want some comfort, some encouragement and sympathy. Not a night long exhausting wrestling match, not a painful dislocated hip, not a permanent disability that would change how you would do life from here on.

It may be the reason we do not expect to experience God in this way is because our understanding of salvation has been distorted. When we commonly think about salvation we are used to understanding it in terms of being saved from hell and judgement, and going to spend eternity in heaven with Jesus, which of course is absolutely true. However, heaven is not God’s ultimate goal of salvation. Getting to heaven will be wonderful, but in some ways that is the easy part. Listen to these words written by Paul.

‘Long ago, even before he made the world, God loved us and chose in Christ to be holy and without fault in his eyes.’ Ephesians 1:4.This verse expresses God’s ultimate goal of salvation. To make us holy, to completely transform us, to make us like Jesus, and that is the hard part. Because sin is so ingrained in our hearts and minds, the only way we can be experience the freedom of sanctification is to have, at times, a dangerous encounter with God that will threaten the people we have become, and transform us into the people we need to be. You could say that the transforming grace of God, is God way of saving me from myself. Saving me from the ultimate threat my own heart is to authentic spiritual maturity. This means that their will be times we will need encounter painful grace when God decides to wrestle us. Let us learn from Jacob

Father thank that sometimes we need to know that you are not safe

title: God wrestling with Jacob. Genesis 32:22-32.

html:
During the night Jacob got up and took his two wives, his two servant wives, and his eleven sons and crossed the Jabbok River with them. After taking them to the other side, he sent over all his possessions. This left Jacob all alone in the camp, and a man came and wrestled with him until the dawn began to break. When the man saw that he would not win the match, he touched Jacob’s hip and wrenched it out of its socket. Then the man said, “Let me go, for the dawn is breaking!” But Jacob said, “I will not let you go unless you bless me.” “What is your name?” the man asked. He replied, “Jacob.” “Your name will no longer be Jacob,” the man told him. “From now on you will be called Israel, because you have fought with God and with men and have won.” “Please tell me your name,” Jacob said. “Why do you want to know my name?” the man replied. Then he blessed Jacob there. Jacob named the place Peniel (which means “face of God”), for he said, “I have seen God face to face, yet my life has been spared.”The sun was rising as Jacob left Peniel, and he was limping because of the injury to his hip (Even today the people of Israel don’t eat the tendon near the hip socket because of what happened that night when the man strained the tendon of Jacob’s hip.)

1. Jacob was alone.

There are times when we need to be alone so God can do his deepest work in us. When it says that Jacob was alone, the Hebrew means that he was completely alone.

This was a place of solitude and silence. I understand that we live frenetic busy lives with so many demands, responsibilities and expectations from others that we could never imagine ourselves going to a place of solitude.

In our thinking, it would be very easy to confuse solitude with isolation but they are very different.

Solitude is where you creating a sacred space where you present yourself to God in the hope of encounter and transformation.

Isolation is a place where we carry our wounds and pain to, in the hope we can protect ourselves from further hurt.

“[In solitude] There is the freedom to be alone, not in order to be away from people but in order to hear the divine Whisper better” (Richard Foster Celebration of discipline 232).

“Solitude is a chosen separation for refining your soul. Isolation is what you crave when you neglect the first.” — Wayne Cordeiro

The problem is, we do not know how to be alone. We live with an epidemic of distraction, our smart phones are so smart that they can control and manipulate our lives (and we allow them!!).

In an essay called, ‘I used to be human.’ Andrew Sullivan writing about his addiction to his phone and how he ‘lived in the web.’’

‘...this new epidemic of distraction is our civilisation’s specific weakness. And its threat is not so much to our minds, even as they shape-shift under the pressure. The threat is to our souls. At this rate, if the noise does not relent, we might even forget we have any..

*This article appears in the September 19, 2016, issue of New York magazine.

2. God wrestled with Jacob. 24B and a man came and wrestled with him until the dawn began to break.

Notice this was God’s initiative. The text says ‘and a man came and wrestled him till dawn.’ We know from verse 30 that this was God. This was very unexpected and strange. We know that Jacob is frightened and distressed, see verse 7. Surely he needs comfort, encouragement, strengthening not an exhausting long night of wrestling. Why would God want to wrestle someone? Maybe it is only through the wrestle that God can get as close to us as he needs to be?

It was through the discomfort of being in the grip of Gods arms that Jacob realised who and what he really was. As God wrestled Jacob, Jacob discovered how needy and helpless he really was. It was through the wrestling that Jacob came to an end of himself.

Sometimes in our relationship with God there needs to be a threatening intensity, there is so much in our lives that need to be threatened by God. Our desire for independence and control, our need to be in charge and our sense of feeling we need to fix every situation. Or we need to appear strong, able, competent. God needs to threaten the mindset that believes we can manipulate others and circumstances,[something Jacob had done all his life.] If God does not threaten our engraved selfish mindsets, we will choose to live lives that are all about us.

Our transformation and holiness is so important to God, which means there are times when He, in his great grace, will have to wrestle with us. This wrestling will threaten and remove the heart attitudes and our perverted thinking that prevents authentic, radical change.

Look at these words from Hosea

‘Even in the womb, Jacob struggled with his brother; when he became a man, he even fought with God. Yes, he wrestled with the angel and won. He wept and pleaded for a blessing from him. There at Bethel he met God face to face, and God spoke to him.’ Hosea 12:3-4.

These words describe Jacob’s reaction to the wrestling of God. He wept and pleaded for a blessing. Here is the thing, this is the first time in his life that Jacob felt a desperate need of God, it was a desperation that was expressed through dependence. As he encountered God wrestling with him, the realisation of his true nature began to dawn on him. He discovered his need of grace as he wept and pleaded for a blessing.

3. God gave Jacob a gift of weakness.

We are told that ‘The man struck Jacob’s hip and knocked it out of joint at the socket.’ It was through the wrestle that Jacob discovered the glories essential of weakness. For Jacob this was a new and life saving discovery. This was a very painful and debilitating experience for Jacob. For the first time in his life he was unable to run. God had no choice for He knew that if he had not dislocated Jacobs hip he would have ran again. The pain of not being able to run was a severe mercy. It is interesting that it was only after Jacob lost his ability to run that he was able to be honest and real about himself, as we shall see.

The gift of weakness teaches us that God is more concerned with spiritual character than he is with physical strength or ability. Sometimes in our hearts we are running away, we don’t really want to engage with God, we don’t want to embrace the sanctifying process, we don’t want to deal with the stuff going on in our hearts. So God ‘dislocates’ us… he sends circumstances into our lives that curtail and prohibit us from reaction and responding in the ways we have always done.

4. Jacob became real about himself. We read in the NLT. ‘But Jacob panted, ‘I will not let you go unless you bless me.’’ ‘What is your name?’ the man asked. He replied ‘Jacob.’

This was a penetrating question that goes way beyond a name tag. ‘I am Jacob, I am Jacob the liar, Jacob the cheat, Jacob the selfish controller, Jacob the manipulator. As God wrestled with him in the dark of night, he began to be self aware, he began to recognise and accept who he really was. Maybe for the first time he really saw and felt the seriousness of his own sin and his need of grace. He once stole by lying about his identity (Genesis 27:19). In this instant, Jacob can either continue to be a liar, and a deceiver, or he can be honest about who he really is. It will take a painful, arduous, struggle in God presence and a lot of courage before we can be honest with ourselves about ourselves. This honesty is a prerequisite for transformation.

You don’t often read about Jacob referring to himself by his own name, for he knew that to call himself Jacob was to be specific about his sin and character. Often we can view our sin in a generic way. We know that we have sin, but we don’t deal specifically with our sin. It is something like going to see a doctor and saying ‘I feel ill.’ the fact that you feel ill is true, but unless you are are a bit more specific, the doctor will be limited in the help he/she can give. This same principle applies when it comes to dealing with the power of sin in our lives. Part of Gods wrestle with us is to expose the Jacob within us, to bring us to the place of heart-breaking yet liberating honesty.

5. Wrestling with God led to Jacob receiving a new identity.

‘Your name shall no longer be Jacob,’ the man told him. ‘It is now Israel,’ because you have struggled with God and men and have won.’ There is a lot of debate about what the precise meaning of the name Israel is. Some think it means to contend with God, others think it could mean, ‘let God reign.’ or ‘God prevails.’

Although we cannot be certain of the precise meaning of Israel we can be certain of a number of things.

a. Jacob got a new identity through the wrestle.

I don’t think we can be or accept who we are until we begin to become the person God wants us to be. Maybe our lack of self-acceptance, our insecurities, our self loathing could be because we have no idea of the person God wants us to become. God wrestling with us causes the pain that helps us discover a new and better identity.

b. The purposes of God for our lives are intrinsically linked to our identity. Israel was more than a new name for Jacob, it would become the name of a great nation who would redefine the whole history of the world. Who we are in God, and what we do with and for God are inseparable.

c. I love the fact that there is a lot of debate about the meaning of the name Israel. When God wrestles with us in order to transform us, our lives become bigger than ’box size,’ The work of God in us cannot be categorised, our reduced to a simple definition. The work of God in us is not always easy to understand or simplify, that what it is like to become an ‘Israel.’

Conclusion.

We began with the words of Mr Beaver to Lucy about Aslam, how he was good but not safe. Let me share another quote about Aslam from ‘The horse and the boy.’

Though the claw marks on her back have healed, Aravis doesn’t much like the scars that remain. Aslan had a plan when He had wounded her; perhaps these scars play a part,’

God given scars, divinely appointed limps, the bruises of grace these are the things that help us to become the holy people God longs for us to be.

Father sometimes it is the God inflicted scars that really change us
