html:
For my own part, I didn’t always find family life easy. One of the many reasons for this was that I spent most of my childhood living away from home in a school that was dedicated to the needs of disabled children. This prevented me from getting to know my brothers and sisters properly as I was growing up and it’s only recently that I’ve recognised how this contributed to us not connecting as families should. Like me I’m sure you can think of times in your family life when it wasn’t what you’d hoped or needed it to be, when life behind the front door wasn’t easy.

Getting started

It wasn’t until the 17th Century that the term ‘family’ was used specifically for the group of persons consisting of parents and their children. It initially referred to the servants of a household – famulus being the Latin for 'the servant'. Perhaps, in our families, there is something here for us to embrace. The role of each member of a family is surely to serve, rather than control or ‘use’ one another. Serving each other can help us to avoid dysfunctional family relationships. As we will see, such a servant attitude would have been very helpful to the brothers of Jesus before the Feast of Tabernacles.

We want look at a difficult encounter Jesus had with his own family. In some ways this is were we need to start, because how we handle conflict and tension with those in our own household can often influence how we handle the conflicts and tensions we will face outside our front door.

Setting the Scene: The family of Jesus

After this, Jesus went around in Galilee, purposely staying away from Judea because the Jews there were waiting to take his life. But when the Jewish Feast of Tabernacles was near, Jesus’ brothers said to him, “You ought to leave here and go to Judea, so that your disciples may see the miracles you do. No one who wants to become a public figure acts in secret. Since you are doing these things, show yourself to the world.” For even his own brothers did not believe in him.

Therefore Jesus told them, “The right time for me has not yet come; for you any time is right. The world cannot hate you, but it hates me because I testify that what it does is evil. You go to the Feast. I am not yet going up to this Feast, because for me the right time has not yet come.” Having said this, he stayed in Galilee.

However, after his brothers had left for the Feast, he went also, not publicly, but in secret.

Jesus was a member of a large family, the eldest of at least seven children. In the Gospel accounts, four brothers are named and at least two sisters (because the plural is used). See Matthew 13:55 and Mark 6:3.

If you’ve ever thought that Jesus must have come from a perfect family, then think again! Like any other family, the family of Jesus wasn’t immune to stress and tension. The Gospel accounts give us a number of indications of such tension. For example, when Mark says Jesus’ family were ‘offended’ by him (6:3), the word can mean ‘to judge unfavourably or unjustly’. In Mark 3:21, we read that Jesus’ family thought he was ‘out of his mind’, John also records an episode of likely tension between Jesus and his family John 7:10. The Scriptures portray the family of Jesus as one where conflict and misunderstanding were a reality.

Jesus stays in Galilee

Before John tells us about Jesus’ time at the Feast of Tabernacles, he gives us some important information about Jesus, his brothers and the reason he delayed his journey to Jerusalem.

Jesus has been away from Jerusalem for about a year. The last time he was there is recorded for us in John Chapter 5. At that time he sparked great controversy by healing a paralysed man on the Sabbath. The religious authorities were outraged and sought to kill him – not because of this amazing work of power and grace, but because they believed he broke a Sabbath rule.

The events recorded in John Chapter 6 begin ‘some time after’ this visit to Jerusalem and the chapter goes on to recount some stories about Jesus in and around Galilee. He crosses to ‘the far shore’, where he feeds the stomachs and souls of vast crowds before returning to teach in Capernaum. Then, we read the opening verses of Chapter 7

After this Jesus went around Galilee purposely staying away from Judea because the Jews there wanted to kill him.

Father thank you that Jesus understands how difficult family life can be

Bible in a year: 1 Timothy 1-5
title: Jesus and his brothers. Part 1
study_refs: For some the experience of families has been generally happy and healthy, most of us, however, are only too familiar with the domestic realities of slammed doors, prolonged disputes and bitter rivalries. Of course for many, the experience of family life is, or has been, particularly painful.

html:
Jesus makes a conscious and deliberate choice to stay in Galilee and avoid Judea and Jerusalem. We must remember that for Jesus, Jerusalem was to be the place of his execution – it was a city where Jesus’ time on earth would reach its ultimate climax. Jesus knew that there were already those in the Jerusalem who wanted him dead. Any visit to the city would involve risk and danger – so had to be carefully considered and well timed.

People could have accused Jesus of lacking courage or a lacking trust in his Father. However, Jesus had the wisdom and the faith to say “No”. He knew it wasn’t yet his time to die. So, for a period of time, he remained in Galilee.

It’s worth noting that despite Jesus’ eagerness to do the Father’s will, he did not rush into things. He was prepared to wait. Sometimes we can run ahead of God, we can become impatient. However, there will be occasions in our lives when even though we know that we are to ‘go to Jerusalem’; we need to wait until the time is right.

Of course ‘waiting on God’ is never wasted time. It certainly wasn’t for Jesus. In the six-month period between the feeding of the 5000 at Passover time in John 6, and the events in John 7, he poured his life into his disciples, teaching and encouraging them. It is very easy for us to underestimate how important our time on earth is. God has a plan and a purpose for all of our time here, just as He did for Jesus.

Family Pressure

Jesus decision to remain in Galilee could not be permanent. He knew that Jerusalem was to be the centre stage of his life’s mission. As a devoted Jew, Jesus also knew that it was required that every male should attend the annual Feast of Tabernacles in Jerusalem. So as the time comes for the Feast, Jesus has some very courageous choices to make.

Try to imagine the kind of pressure Jesus must be under at this time. The Feast of Tabernacles was a very important event for the community. Everyone was involved. As the head of the family unit, Jesus would have been expected by all not only to go to Jerusalem, but to lead his family to the Feast.

But as the community prepare themselves for the journey, Jesus shows no sign of joining them.

In verses 3 and 4, we read that his brothers come to him, saying:

“You ought to leave here and go to Judea, so that your disciples may see the miracles you do. No one who wants to be a public figure acts in secret. Since you are doing these things show yourself to the world.”

There are two things worth noticing before we look more closely at these verses.

Firstly, if his brothers had really cared for Jesus they would not have made this suggestion. Even though the law required every male to attend the Feast, they know that the authorities in Jerusalem want to kill Jesus, yet they seem quite happy for him to go there.

Furthermore we must keep in mind that they are speaking out of unbelief. In the next verse (v5), John says, ‘For even his brothers did not believe in him’. In other words they have no confidence in him, they doubt him, and they do not trust him. So the suggestion for Jesus to ‘go public’ in Judea is more an expression of doubt than encouragement.

A lack of care and a lack of confidence what a deadly cocktail!

In effect, Jesus brothers seem to be saying: “We don’t really care what happens to you because we have no confidence in you, so we suggest that you go.”

From our own experience, we know that such thoughtless and insensitive undertones can make a person react. We hear from a spouse, a parent, a child or a sibling, “I don’t respect you, I don’t care for you, I don’t trust your judgment,” and everything within us wants to react. We want to show them, we want to prove ourselves. To put ourselves in this story, many of us would be tempted to take things out of God’s hands and go to Jerusalem to make a point. Surely it would be easier to face the murderous cruelty of loveless strangers than the misunderstanding or suspicion of a family whom we love? We know in our hearts that this is not the way families should be. Often our front doors and plastic smiles hide from others how things really are.

Father help me understand and discern my family relationships

Bible in a year: 1 Timothy 6 2 Timothy 1-4
title: Jesus and his brothers part 2
study_refs: Staying in Galilee

html:
As we considering what is said to Jesus by his brothers in verses 3 and 4, we need to keep in mind John’s comment in verse 5, where he says ‘For even his brothers did not believe in him’. John is suggesting that something in the brother’s response reflects this lack of confidence and trust in Jesus. As we look at their words carefully we will notice there are four parts to what they say:

“You ought to leave here and go to Jerusalem so your disciples may see the miracles you do.”

It is possible that the larger than life presence of Jesus in Galilee could had made his brothers feel small and insignificant. Jesus is the talk of the town they aren’t; so perhaps they think that if Jesus was to go Jerusalem, leave Galilee, move out, leave home, then they might be noticed. Maybe they believe that they would be happier if Jesus wasn’t around. Instead of trying to work at their relationship with Jesus, they choose the easy option of trying to create some distance between themselves and him. The word John uses for ‘leave’ does not suggest a visit, or a trip, but carries the idea of changing homes. This often happens when relationships become terse and difficult; we think that creating some geographical distance will be the solution to internal conflict.

This might appear to be a legitimate and innocent comment. “You ought to leave here and go to Jerusalem so your disciples may see the miracles you do.” After all, Jesus has been performing miracles in Galilee and many there are believing in him. Surely, the same thing could happen in Jerusalem. But in light of the brothers ‘unbelief’ and lack of confident, it seems unlikely that such thinking was informing their suggestion.

Why then do they make this comment? Are they being sarcastic? Perhaps they are suggesting that Jesus needs to prove himself. After the feeding of the 5000, many of Jesus’ followers deserted him. This may well have encouraged his brothers to doubt that he was, indeed, sent by God. In telling Jesus to go to Jerusalem and perform some miracles, they may be suggesting that he needs to keep impressing his few remaining disciples if he wants to keep them.

“No one who wants to become a public figure acts in secret.”

In some senses this second part of the brothers’ suggestion is the key that really helps us understand what is going on in their hearts. They perceive Jesus as someone who wants to be a ‘public figure.’ Yes, crowds flock to Jesus, but he is not someone who seeks the limelight. Often when Jesus healed people, he told them not to tell anyone. Jesus had the heart of a servant, he was born in obscurity and he lived amongst the poor. But his brothers seem to see him as one who was eager for public recognition; this could not have been farther from the truth. If they had really known Jesus they would not have thought of him in this way.

“Since you are doing these things, show yourself to the world.”

On the surface this may appear to be an innocent statement, but it isn’t. Jesus’ brothers seem to want him to operate on the same grounds as most people operate. They want him to seek a name for himself, they want him to promote himself, they want him to become ambitious and be noticed. They may have been suggesting that his gifts were being wasted, and that he deserved to be seen by more people. The advice which Jesus’ brothers give him contained echoes of Satan’s temptation of Jesus in the wilderness. “Jesus prove yourself, let people see what you can do, take control of the situation, use your power to bolster your reputation.” It is as though Satan himself wants Jesus to go to Jerusalem to experience premature death.

The desire for glory and prestige is one of Satan’s most effective weapons. Satan comes to us under the guise of ambition and tells us that we deserve the best, we deserve to be top cat, and we have earned the right to be in charge. He says to us: “Go show yourself to the world.” And because of the illegitimate pursuit of praise, position and prestige we become slaves to our desires and victims of Satan. The self-promoting attitude that Satan encourages prevents a person from taking up their cross, and hinders them in their ability to cope with the tension of difficult relationships.

Father please may I have the spiritual maturity to handle the misunderstanding of others.

Bible in a year: Titus1-3 Philemon 1 Hebrews 1:1-2:10
title: Jesus and his brothers part 3
study_refs: As we look more closely at the suggestion Jesus’ brothers make at this time, we can learn a lot about their relationship, or lack of, with Jesus.

html:
Jesus understood what his brothers were suggesting, so he makes a careful and appropriate response:

“The right time for me has not yet come...”

Jesus submits his life to the timing and will of God.

The Bible has two different words for our one English word ‘time’. They are kairos and chronos. Chronos time is quantitative time. It’s the term from which the English words ‘chronology’ and ‘chronological’ are formed – it’s to do with seconds, minutes and hours. Kairos refers more to ‘the occasion’ and conveys the idea of seizing the moment, the moment when things are brought into being.

When Jesus says “The right time for me has not yet come…”, he uses kairos. In effect, he says: “This is not the right time or opportunity for me to go public in the way you suggest. You're asking me to abandon the appointed path that God has chosen, to go up to the Feast of Tabernacles and make it known to everybody that I am the Messiah. But if I did that it would be at the wrong time: it would never work.”

As Christians it is important that we understand and accept God’s timing for our lives - often this is difficult. One of the ways Satan makes this even more difficult is that he appeals to our pride. Pride makes us impatient and discontent. Pride will cause us to take things into our own hands and act prematurely in order to enhance our own reputation. Pride is more about our timing and our agenda, not God’s.

Jesus is able to resist the temptation contained in the suggestion of his brothers because he is free from pride and accepts the timing of his Father. When we struggle to accept God’s timing for our lives, it can be more difficult to resist the temptations that Satan may throw at us through the wrong expectations of others, especially those of our own families.

The tension between the expectations of others and the timing of God is something every Christian has to live with and the only way we can live comfortably with that tension is to consciously accept that God’s timing is always right. It is an expression of His love and kindness towards us. Accepting this will prevent us from running away from unwanted situations and people that we need to have in our lives.

For Jesus, following his brothers’ suggestion would have been, in some senses, the easy option. He could have gone to Jerusalem and demonstrated his power and glory; he could have destroyed those who wanted to kill him. After all, he was God. But he chooses instead to stay in submission to his Father and suffer the misunderstanding and sarcastic scorn of his family.

Jesus has a realistic understanding of the situation. He realises that his brothers are not thinking in terms of God’s purpose or God’s timing.

Jesus says to them, “..for you any time is right.” He means that if his brothers go up to the feast they will only be fulfilling what everybody expects of them. They would be acting as normal religious Jews, fulfilling a religious duty, which would not irritate anybody, raise any questions or challenge any beliefs. Therefore, they could act without fear of arousing antagonism or opposition. However, Jesus doesn’t have that luxury. He would be closely watched by the religious authorities, who would monitor his every move, hoping he would make some mistake or say something out of turn, so they could incriminate him.

When we are put under pressure from the expectations, demands and misunderstandings of others, we need to ask God for the wisdom to see beyond what they are asking. We need His help to see the whole picture and the possible consequences of their illegitimate demands.

Jesus’ brothers don’t think in terms of God’s timing, they think in terms of being ‘free’ – free to do what they want, when they want. They don’t see the need for being submitted and committed to God and His timing. This was a collision of mindsets and perceptions and this made conflict inevitable.

Jesus understood the world in which he lived

Jesus continues by saying, “The world cannot hate you, but it hates me because I testify that what it does is evil.”

The word ‘hate’ here comes from the ancient Greek word miseo. If any synonym could substitute for this word, it would come from a word like ‘detest,’ ‘loath,’ or ‘despise.’ In effect, Jesus is saying, “You are telling me to go up to the feast in Jerusalem and make a name for myself, but why would I do that, for the people you want me to impress are the people who despise me.”

Jesus has no intention of going to Jerusalem to seek the glory and praise of men, he isn’t going to allow himself to be pressurised by the uncaring expectations of his brothers. He refuses to be controlled or manipulated by them and accepts submission rather than glory. He knows that anonymity in the timing of God is better than being a public figure and so he says to them, “You go to the Feast. I am not yet going up to this Feast, because for me the right time has not yet come.” Sometimes people live under great pressure from the expectations of family and friends that they face the danger of stepping outside the will of God and take things into their own hands.

And as we read, ‘Having said this, he stayed in Galilee John 7:9…but only for a short time.

Following the timing of his heavenly Father rather than his earthly family, we read that ‘…after his brothers had left for the Feast, he went also, not publicly but in secret.’ (v10).

Father may my pride not led me impatience.

html:
I wonder do you believe that we as Christians should have a completely different attitude to work than non Christians? Should how we as Christians, understand work and how we do our work be noticeable different to those that are not followers of Jesus? Dorothy Sayers writing about work wrote

‘I asked that it should be looked upon, not as a necessary drudgery to be undergone for the purpose of making money, but as a way of life in which the nature of man should find its proper exercise and delight and so fulfil itself to the glory of God.’ https://www1.villanova.edu/content/dam/villanova/mission/faith/Why%20Work%20by%20Dorothy%20Sayers Accessed 03/06/2025

If we are going to have a healthy and biblical understanding about work then we will need to deal with a number of myths that many believe about work.

1. Work is only what I get paid to do. So when we think of work we automatically think in terms of salary, wages, employment. We see it as means of generating enough income in order to pay the bills. If you are working, and you generate an income because of your work, that is great. But much of the work we do has nothing to do with receiving an income. For example the full time mum at home looking after children, she is working but not paid, the student at school or university, they are working but not paid. The volunteer in the church or community, working but not paid. When we think about the creation of man, we are told that ‘That the Lord God took man and put him in the garden of Eden to work it and take care of it,’ Genesis 2:15. You could say that work is fulfilling you God given responsibilities in the place where God has put you.’

2. We are inclined to think some job/responsibilities have more spiritual significance than others. Is being a plumber less important than being a pastor, 0r is a bin man’s job 0f less spiritual significance than a bible teacher. Is ‘secular,’ employment more valuable than ‘Christian,’ employment? I think at some kind of level we which that this was the case. If we see the pastors, missionaries, bible teacher, church workers as the really spiritual job, it takes the pressure of the plumber, the binman and any other occupation you care to mention, to be seen as a spiritual occupation. The problem is, as far as the bible in concern nothing is ‘secular,’ The spiritual secular divide were categories devised by Plato to help him understand his world. Their are many jobs that are wrong for a Christian because certain types of occupations depend upon living an amoral life, i.e., a drug dealer, a thief, a prostitute. But for the most part, God sees the work we do as having spiritual significance.

Father thank you for the spiritual significance of the work we have been given.

Bible in a year: Hebrews 7-10.
title: Study topic The sanctity of work part 1

html:
‘Work is sacred.’ It was ordained by God from the beginning, before the fall of man. After the Fall, it just got tougher, frustrating, exhausting, sometimes even boring. But work pursued with excellence and integrity is still pleasing to God, a way of honouring Him by serving in the unique ways He has equipped us. Our work often provides the opportunities to proclaim Him to a broken, unredeemed world through our example, as well as by our words. Robert Tamasy Source unknown

‘Some people think that work is a necessary evil. Many people feel trapped in their places of work, be that paid or unpaid. How often have you heard things like, ‘It’s only a job, or ‘I am only a …? and sometimes we develop an unhealthy mindset, or an unhelpful emotional relationship with our work. Lets be honest, there are times when we are tired, or when things can be challenging, and at times we wish were somewhere else doing something else. However sometimes people develop a default negativity towards work.’

Let me ask a strange question that might help us develop a more positive attitude towards ‘work’ ‘paid or unpaid.’ ‘Do you hate worship? I realise that this a shocking question, and may appear to be unrelated. But did you know the Hebrew word avodah jointly means work, worship, and service. The various usages of this Hebrew word found first in Genesis 2:15 tell us that God’s original design and desire is that our work and our worship would be a seamless way of living. Every time we work we are also worshipping. It may not feel like worship. Paul understood this concept when he said.

Colossians 3:22-24

‘Slaves, obey your earthly masters in everything; and do it, not only when their eye is on you and to curry their favour, but with sincerity of heart and reverence for the Lord. 23 Whatever you do, work at it with all your heart, as working for the Lord, not for human masters, 24 since you know that you will receive an inheritance from the Lord as a reward. It is the Lord Christ you are serving.’

So what can proverbs teach about our attitude towards work. In proverbs there are two words that captivate the teachers attitude towards work, one of the words is negative and the other is positive. The negative word is laziness, often translated sluggard, and the positive word is diligence.

1. We need to avoid laziness. The book of proverbs introduces us to what some versions of the bible refer to as the sluggard. The word for sluggard indicates someone who is slothful, indolent or slack. His laziness is betrayed in a number of significant ways.

He lacks initiative. Solomon compares the life of the sluggard and the aunt he says,

Go to the ant, you sluggard; consider its ways and be wise! 7 It has no commander, no overseer or ruler, yet it stores its provisions in summer.
and gathers its food at harvest. Proverbs 6:6-7

The sluggard lacks the ability to act. He has no vision, no motivation. Proverbs has nothing good to say about the sluggard.

The sluggard will always make an excuse for his inactivity. ‘ listen to his excuse. ‘There a lion on the road, a fierce lion roaming the streets Proverbs 26:13. This was a silly excuse, like the school pupil telling their teacher ‘the dog eat my homework,’ a complete nonsense. It is interesting to note that the Hebrew for sluggard also means to be shifty or not upright. We create imaginary lions by lying to ourselves and others, we allow fear to drain us of diligence and zeal.

‘As the door swings on it hinges so the sluggard turns on his bed’ Proverbs 26:14. For this sluggard the bed became an icon of his dysfunctional life, for him life was all about, rest, ease, comfort, safety, and warmth. Their will be times in all our lives when we need to feel the security of rest, but, if it becomes a lifestyle, a habit, a means of avoiding responsible then it is wrong. Our icon may not be a bed, it could be a hobby, a ministry even a job, where you go to flee the realities and responsibilities of life.

The sluggard refuses to take responsibility for himself. ‘He buries his hand in the dish; he is too lazy to bring it back to his mouth.’ Proverbs 26:15. He is too lazy to feed himself He starts something but does not finish it, his life is littered with the unfinished.

The sluggard are incline to be unteachable, ‘he is wiser in his own eyes than seven people who answer discretely.’ Proverbs 26:16

Father hep me be spiritually minded enough to do my job,

Bible in a year: Hebrews 11-13
title: Study topic The sanctity of work part 2

html:
The reason why the book of proverb is so hard on the sluggard is because laziness is fundamentally a spiritual problem that has the potential to destroy us..

‘Your danger and mine is not that we become criminals, but rather we become respectable, decent, commonplace, mediocre Christians. The temptations that really saps our spiritual power are the television, banana cream pie, the easy chair and the credit card. The Christian wins or loses in these seemingly innocent little moments of decision. Lord, make my life a miracle.’ R,C.Ortlund Source unknown

The Positive word diligence

The main Hebrew word for diligent means sharp or determined, it paints a picture of someone who is always ready for the task at hand, like a knife that is sharpened and ready to be used. It is not about over-committing or feeling you have to take on every responsibility. Instead it is doing your best at the work you have been given. Being diligent is a heart attitude that honours God.

Their are two other Hebrew word used in proverbs for diligent. One means to be quick, skilled prompt and ready. The NIV translates this word has skill.

The third word used carries the idea of knowing or understanding. Diligence is passionate intentional.

We are diligent because we want to align our lives with God and His ways. We are diligent because we don’t want to waste our lives and all the opportunities that God gives us. We are diligent because life is too short to fritter it away A diligent person is wholehearted in whatever s/he does. Instead of being tentative or passive or lukewarm, a diligent person has a sense of what s/he should be doing and therefore “goes for it.” Another way to talk about it is to say that the diligent person is “passionate” about life. If you’re diligent, you live like you mean it.

Father may my love for you make me passionate about my job.

Bible in a year: James 1:1-4:10
title: Study topic The sanctity of work part 3

html:
Diligence makes the most of God given opportunities

Proverbs 12:27 reads ‘The lazy do not roast any game, but the diligent feed on the riches of the hunt.’

The picture here is of two men out hunting for food. The first man catches some game, but does nothing with it. By contrast a diligent man would not only trap an animal; he would see that it actually made its way to the dinner table. Whereas a lazy man loses focus and lacks follow-through, a diligent man is decisive and intentional. He remembers why he has gone hunting (to put food on the table) and doesn’t quit until that purpose is accomplished.

Think of the important opportunities we are given, opportunities to love, opportunities to serve, opportunities to give, opportunities to help. We may laugh at the lazy man who could not be bothered roasting game, but I reckon we are all guilty of doing the same.

b. Diligence does not look for the quick fix or the easy solution

Proverbs 21:5 The plans of the diligent lead to profit as surely as haste leads to poverty

In Proverbs, if you’re “hasty” you aren’t content with the normal, ongoing processes of life; you want things to happen quickly and so you take short-cuts and bounce around from one thing to another. The diligent person makes plans, and patiently waits. He has the long term in view. He decides on a wise course of action and keeps to it.

The diligent person knows when to work and when not to

In Proverbs 10:4-5 we read ‘Lazy hands make for poverty, but diligent hands bring wealth. He who gathers crops in summer is a prudent son, but he who sleeps during harvest is a disgraceful son.’

This proverb is simply saying that the diligent person knows when he needs to take responsibility, he his able to judge his circumstances and take the appropriate action, he is no a spectator on life.

A diligent person will have a healthy confidence

Proverbs 22:29 says ‘Do you see someone skilled [same word for diligent.] in their work? They will serve before kings; they will not serve before officials of low rank.

In those days to come before a king could have been a very dangerous thing, you need to be confident, you needed to know what you were doing. Diligence is an expression of confidence. The diligence of the confident get them noticed.

It would be very easy to read the book of Proverbs like a self-help manual, as if it were something like seven steps to a successful life. I know many people who are not Christians who live diligent lives, people who believe that they can earn salvation. So what is the distinctive message of Proverbs, how is it different from plethora of self-help books on the market? The diligent life lived by the wise begins with the fear of the Lord, 20 times in the book of Proverbs we read about the ‘fear of the lord.’ To fear God, is to lovingly acknowledge that he is God and as God he desires and deserves a diligent life lived by me.

William D. Eisenhower puts it this way in his article 'Fearing God" in Christianity Today:

Unfortunately, many of us presume that the world is the ultimate threat and that God's function is to offset it. How different this is from the biblical position that God is far scarier than the world …. When we assume that the world is the ultimate threat, we give it unwarranted power, for in truth, the world's threats are temporary. When we expect God to balance the stress of the world, we reduce him to the world's equal …. As I walk with the Lord, I discover that God poses an ominous threat to my ego, but not to me. He rescues me from my delusions, so he may reveal the truth that sets me free. He casts me down, only to lift me up again. He sits in judgement of my sin, but forgives me nevertheless. Fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom, but love from the Lord is its completion.

The book of Proverbs teaches us that wisdom is not simply a matter of learning certain rules and applying them mechanically, but at its core is the relationship with God. God in his mercy has given us all work to do, and he wants us to do it with the diligence of wisdom.

Father may wisdom mark my life.

html:
​Isaiah 52:13-53:12

At the foot of the cross. Part 1

13 See, my servant will prosper; he will be highly exalted. 14 But many were amazed when they saw him. His face was so disfigured he seemed hardly human, and from his appearance, one would scarcely know he was a man. 15 And he will startle many nations. Kings will stand speechless in his presence. For they will see what they had not been told; they will understand what they had not heard about. 53:1 Who has believed our message? To whom has the Lord revealed his powerful arm? 2 My servant grew up in the Lord’s presence like a tender green shoot, like a root in dry ground. There was nothing beautiful or majestic about his appearance, nothing to attract us to him. 3He was despised and rejected—a man of sorrows, acquainted with deepest grief. We turned our backs on him and looked the other way. He was despised, and we did not care. 4 Yet it was our weaknesses he carried; it was our sorrows that weighed him down. And we thought his troubles were a punishment from God, a punishment for his own sins! 5 But he was pierced for our rebellion, crushed for our sins. He was beaten so we could be whole. He was whipped so we could be healed. 6 All of us, like sheep, have strayed away. We have left God’s paths to follow our own. Yet the Lord laid on him the sins of us all. 7 He was oppressed and treated harshly, yet he never said a word. He was led like a lamb to the slaughter. And as a sheep is silent before the shearers, he did not open his mouth. 8 Unjustly condemned, he was led away. No one cared that he died without descendants, that his life was cut short in midstream, But he was struck down for the rebellion of my people. 9 He had done no wrong and had never deceived anyone. But he was buried like a criminal; he was put in a rich man’s grave. 10 But it was the Lord’s good plan to crush him and cause him grief. Yet when his life is made an offering for sin, he will have many descendants. He will enjoy a long life, and the Lord’s good plan will prosper in his hands. 11 When he sees all that is accomplished by his anguish, he will be satisfied. And because of his experience, my righteous servant will make it possible for many to be counted righteous, for he will bear all their sins. He will give him the honour of a victorious soldier, because he exposed himself to death. He was counted among the rebels. He bore the sins of many and interceded for rebels.

One of the most loved chapters in the bible is Isaiah 53. This passage of scripture is holy ground, it is known as the fifth gospel, or the first gospel. One commentator said that it reads as if ‘it was written at the foot of the cross.’ No other passage in all of scripture allows us to come as close to the suffering of Jesus. No other passage makes the vulnerability and weakness of Jesus so vivid. This passage draws into the very heart of God. It reveals God’s thoughts, emotions, purposes, plans, judgement, justice, grace and love. This chapter revels the depth of relationship between the Father and the Son. This chapter helps us to know and understand God, it is a window into the very soul of God, it takes us to the very essence of God and the reason for our existence.

Let me give you some facts about the chapter.

1. Actually the chapter begins in chapter 52:13. it is known as the forth Servant song, the first three servant songs are found in (Is 42:1-7; 49:1-9;50:4-9) this forth song Isa 52:13-53:12 is the longest, and is made up of five stanzas of three verses each; Chapter 52:13-15, 53:1-3. 4-6. 7-9 and 10-12. It is important to notice that this song starts and ends with God speaking about the exaltation and victory of his servant, see 52:13-15, 53:11b-12. These two passages describe his servant as a victorious king who has defeated his enemies. They are talking about the end of the story, about what will be accomplished through his suffering.

2. Up until the 11th century, Jewish Rabbi’s taught that this passage was speaking about the coming Messiah. Then, a completely different view was popularized by Jewish commentator Rashi (Rabbi Shlomo Itzchaki), who lived one thousand years after Jesus. Rashi believed that the servant passages of Isaiah referred to the collective fate of the nation of Israel rather than a personal Messiah. To this day, many rabbis persist in citing Rashi as the definitive word on how to interpret Isaiah 53. Others do see the weakness of Rashi’s view and say the passage applies to an individual, perhaps Isaiah himself, King Cyrus, King Hezekiah, Josiah, Ezekiel, Jeremiah, Moses, Job, or even some anonymous contemporaries of Isaiah as the one spoken of by the prophet. Because this chapter has caused “arguments and great confusion” the rabbis decided that the simplest thing would be to stop reading it in synagogues. So it is now banned in a lot of synagogues and many Jews will not read it. Recently Isaiah 53 was read to some individual Jewish people in the streets in Israel, they were all asked, ‘who the passage was speaking about?’ They all replied, ‘Jesus.’

So what we want to do is to look at these five stanzas and in doing so we are brought to the foot of the cross.

Father Thank you for allowing me to come to the cross

At the foot of the cross. Part 2

His face was so disfigured he seemed hardly human, and from his appearance, one would scarcely know he was a man. 15 And he will startle many nations. Kings will stand speechless in his presence. For they will see what they had not been told; they will understand what they had not heard about. 53:1 Who has believed our message? And as a sheep is silent before the shearers, he did not open his mouth. 8 Unjustly condemned, he was led away. No one cared that he died without descendants, that his life was cut short in midstream, But he was struck down for the rebellion of my people. 9 He had done no wrong and had never deceived anyone. But he was buried like a criminal; he was put in a rich man’s grave. 10 But it was the Lord’s good plan to crush him and cause him grief. Yet when his life is made an offering for sin, he will have many descendants. He will enjoy a long life, and the Lord’s good plan will prosper in his hands. 11 When he sees all that is accomplished by his anguish, he will be satisfied. And because of his experience, my righteous servant will make it possible for many to be counted righteous, for he will bear all their sins. He will give him the honour of a victorious soldier, because he exposed himself to death. He was counted among the rebels. He bore the sins of many and interceded for rebels.

Stanza

1 Look at My servant Isaiah 52:13-15

The first Stanza starts with the words see or behold my servant. This is God speaking here, and he is saying something like this. ‘Stop everything, set everything down and take a long enquiring look at my servant, see the Jesus you have never known.’

(Sometimes we think we have Jesus sussed, we reduce or change him so he will fit neatly into our sterile theological categories. When was the last time we learned something new about Jesus? As disciples we have been called to a life long journey of discovering and rediscovering who Jesus really is.)

God says for us to look, see, behold my servant shall prosper.’ The word prosper is the Hebrew work ‘sakal’ This word can be translated prosper, or succeed or to act wisely; the word means primarily to act wisely, to show prudence, good sense, insight and understanding. The natural fruit expected from acting wisely is that this leads to prosperity or success. For this servant, wisdom was submitting himself to the will of God, irrespective of the cost or the suffering. You could say that Isaiah 53 is a description of the wisest person who has ever lived. It is a revelation of a life lived in wisdom.

Wisdom is the understanding and acceptance that suffering may or probably will be a necessity in order for me to accomplish God’s will for my life.

The verses go on to say:-

‘He shall be exalted and lifted up and shall be very high. Just as there were many who were astonished at him—so marred was his appearance, beyond human semblance, and his form beyond that of mortals—so he shall startle many nations; kings shall shut their mouths because of him, for that which had not been told them they shall see, and that which they had not heard they shall contemplate.’

There is a lot in these verses, but let me mention one thing, when it comes to understanding people, often we equate their status with their appearance. When we are told that many were astonished at him, the idea behind the word is horrified. The Greek translation of the Old Testament uses the word adoxeo for the word marred. Which literally means "without glory," and conveys the idea of being held in no esteem, of being of ill repute or even of being despicable! It can mean to hold one in contempt. It suggests that the Jewish crowd were appalled at Him and held Him in contempt, but as far as God is concerned he shall be exalted and lifted up and shall be very high.

To be like Jesus is to live in such away that your are more conscious as to how God the Father sees you, than how others see you. It is very interesting that Isaiah speaks about the servant of the Lord having his face/appearance marred. The face is the most specific indicator of a persons identity. I understand that we will never, or could ever suffer the way Jesus had to. But often the way others treat us can mar our identity, the unkind things they say to us or about us can rob us of accepting who we are.

It is a terrifying thought to recognise that Satan was thrown out of heaven because he found his value, significance and worth on his appearance. The bible says:-

‘Therefore I cast you as a profane thing
Out of the mountain of God;
And I destroyed you, O covering cherub,
From the midst of the fiery stones.
"Your heart was lifted up because of your beauty;
You corrupted your wisdom for the sake of your splendour;’ Ezekiel 28:17

Father thank you that to suffer in your will is wisdom.

html:
At the foot of the cross. Part 3

13 See, my servant will prosper; he will be highly exalted. 14 But many were amazed when they saw him. His face was so disfigured he seemed hardly human, and from his appearance, one would scarcely know he was a man. 15 And he will startle many nations. Kings will stand speechless in his presence. For they will see what they had not been told; they will understand what they had not heard about. 53:1 Who has believed our message? To whom has the Lord revealed his powerful arm? 2 My servant grew up in the Lord’s presence like a tender green shoot, like a root in dry ground. There was nothing beautiful or majestic about his appearance, nothing to attract us to him. 3He was despised and rejected—a man of sorrows, acquainted with deepest grief. We turned our backs on him and looked the other way. He was despised, and we did not care. 4 Yet it was our weaknesses he carried; it was our sorrows that weighed him down. And we thought his troubles were a punishment from God, a punishment for his own sins! 5 But he was pierced for our rebellion, crushed for our sins. He was beaten so we could be whole. He was whipped so we could be healed. 6 All of us, like sheep, have strayed away. We have left God’s paths to follow our own. Yet the Lord laid on him the sins of us all. 7 He was oppressed and treated harshly, yet he never said a word. He was led like a lamb to the slaughter. And as a sheep is silent before the shearers, he did not open his mouth. 8 Unjustly condemned, he was led away. No one cared that he died without descendants, that his life was cut short in midstream, But he was struck down for the rebellion of my people. 9 He had done no wrong and had never deceived anyone. But he was buried like a criminal; he was put in a rich man’s grave. 10 But it was the Lord’s good plan to crush him and cause him grief. Yet when his life is made an offering for sin, he will have many descendants. He will enjoy a long life, and the Lord’s good plan will prosper in his hands. 11 When he sees all that is accomplished by his anguish, he will be satisfied. And because of his experience, my righteous servant will make it possible for many to be counted righteous, for he will bear all their sins. He will give him the honour of a victorious soldier, because he exposed himself to death. He was counted among the rebels. He bore the sins of many and interceded for rebels.

Stanza 2 The rejection of my servant. Isaiah 53:1-3

Isaiah 53:1-3 are very painful and disturbing verses. Look at some of the language Isaiah uses. He had no beauty or majesty to attract us to him, nothing in his appearance that we should desire him. He was despised and rejected by mankind, a man of suffering, and familiar with pain. Like one from whom people hide their faces, he was despised, and we held him in low esteem.

The idea behind despised is from a root meaning to accord little worth to something means to disdain or to hold in contempt. The Hebrew word Bazah is used in a number of places to mean “despise” in the sense of treating someone or something as totally insignificant or worthless. It is an emotional response which ranges from strong dislike to loathing!

He was rejected. The idea here in Isa 53:3 is being abandoned by others. The word rejected, The Hebrew word hadel, carries with it the idea of ceasing or desisting from something or leaving something before it reaches its end or conclusion. What Isaiah is saying is that when Jesus Christ came into the world, there would be many who would seem to have somewhat of an interest in Him for a while, but their interest was transient (and for what they could get out of it for themselves, as in Jn 6:66) and they would all eventually leave Him and abandon Him before He completed His assignment.

Why was he despised and rejected? Because he did not comply with their expectations. He did not fit into their categories, he was not impressive, he was not ‘Superman’, or ‘Iron man,’ or some other character from a movie, he was a servant. They saw him as a sapling, that is what the Hebrew means for tender plant. They were looking for a Messiah that was more like an oak tree, strong and impressive.

Can you imagine the depth of sorrow and grief Jesus must have felt? The pain of rejection is one of the most difficult kinds of pain to cope with. Some scientific studies have shown that the emotional pain of rejection can be worse than physical pain and our memories find it easier to relive an emotional trauma, making it harder to deal with. Jesus refused to allow the need for approval and acceptance, to divert him from the purposes of His Father. He would rather live in the pain of the will of God than fall into to trap of needing to prove himself into an attempt to ease the pain of rejection. Back in John 6 the people said to Jesus, ’So they asked him, “What sign then will you give that we may see it and believe you? What will you do? ‘ John 6:66. In other words, prove yourself, impress us, earn our acceptance!

Father thank you that Jesus choose sorrow for us.

Stanza 3. The heart of the servants. Isaiah 53:4-6 4 Yet it was our weaknesses he carried; it was our sorrows that weighed him down. And we thought his troubles were a punishment from God, a punishment for his own sins! 5 But he was pierced for our rebellion, crushed for our sins. He was beaten so we could be whole. He was whipped so we could be healed. 6 All of us, like sheep, have strayed away. We have left God’s paths to follow our own.

This third Stanza is the very heart of the poem. This Stanza is talking about the purpose, the goal, the outworking of the heart of God for the world. These are heart breaking verses that should cause us to weep in awe.

Look at these words:-

1. Jesus bore our grief

2. He carried our sorrows

3. He was pierced for our transgressions

4. He was crushed for our iniquities

5. He received the chastisement that brought us peace

6. He healed us via his wounds

7. He received the iniquity of us all.

Listen to what J C Ryle said. ’He did not die because he could not help it; he did not suffer because he could not escape. All the soldiers of Pilate’s army could not have taken him, if he had not been willing to be taken. They could not have hurt a hair of his head, if he had not given them permission.’ https://www.gracegems.org/Ryle/j18.htm Accessed 17/04/2025

Jesus made a deliberate choice to suffer greatly so he could lavish extravagant love upon us, he did not count the cost, he did not way up the price. He did not avoid the sacrifice or refuse the pain for he understood that the heart of his father longed to reach us with redeeming love. Jesus made a deliberate choice to choose the difficult road of suffering and redeeming love. (I wonder if there are times we need to make an intentional choice to chose suffering in order to advance God’s kingdom?)

At the cross, the wounding of God took place, earth had never been touched by such a deep sorrow or such profound grief. At the cross, suffering was sanctified and the acute agony and purity of Devine love was seen. At the cross, the heart of God was laid bare as the value of every human being was pronounced through Jesus’ death.

We need to ask the question, ‘How was Jesus able to do this? Why was he prepared to pay such a price?’ He was a servant, an ebed.

Walt Kaiser said this, “The dominant idea of ebed is not primarily a reference to subordination, but to ownership. This idea of being a slave, which is much more that being subordinate or submitted. It is the complete surrender of his will so God can accomplish His will through him.’ Source unknown

In some ways we need to become as committed as Jesus was, we need to cultivate a mind of a slave so we will have the courage not to make our lives about us. We are living in a world that needs to experience the extravagant love of God through us. We have no power to rescue people from sin, we can’t pay the price for an others sin, we have no redeeming power, however, we do all have lives that have been designed to be ebed in character. We need to become people who will display the extravagant of love of God, we need to experience the pain of showing agape love. This kind of love authenticates our relationship with God and our commitment to his will.

I sometimes think that we want to be known as Christians, but we don’t really want to be like Jesus. We don’t really think that we should have to suffer for the benefit of others, and yet that is what it means to be God’s servant.

Father help me be committed as Jesus.

The object of the whole passage is to mark the meek and quiet subjection of our Redeemer in His prolonged suffering. Father help me to be courages like Jesus

Three times in these verses Isaiah mentions the fact that Jesus kept silent, and no deceit came out of his mouth. This silence was a revelation of Jesus’ heart.

But how did he do this?

1 Peter 2:21-23. For you have been called for this purpose, since Christ also suffered for you, leaving you an example for you to follow in His steps, 22 Who committed no sin, now was any deceit found in his mouth, and while being reviled, He did not revile in return; while suffering, He uttered no threats, but kept entrusting Himself to Him who judges righteously. The word entrusting literally means to commit into someone hands.

As Jesus was suffering the cruel abuse at the hands of those who hated him, he was continually giving himself into the hands of Him who judges righteously. Could it be that his silence was an expression of him concentrating on entrusting and obeying God? Could it be that in the midst of this messy, cruel experience, Jesus’ focus was to keep trusting? We don’t know. But we do know what was going on in his heart, he was continually trusting. Entrusting God requires strong-mindedness, a determined choice to relinquish control in order to authentically commit yourself into his hands.

Father help me to continually submit myself into your hands.

He was counted among the rebels. He bore the sins of many and interceded for rebels.

Stanza 5 Victory.

As the poem began with God speaking in Isaiah 52:13-15 it ends with God speaking in 53:11-12. We hear the words in verse 11 ‘My righteous servant,’ where He is talking about his perspective and understanding of what Jesus has accomplished. What God says in verses 11-12 is introduced by the prophet giving us an insight into how God felt about the plan of salvation. They read, 11 When he sees all that is accomplished by his anguish, he will be satisfied. And because of his experience, my righteous servant will make it possible for many to be counted righteous, for he will bear all their sins. 12 I will give him the honour of a victorious soldier, because he exposed himself to death. He was counted among the rebels. He bore the sins of many and interceded for rebels.

‘But it was the Lord’s good plan to crush him.’

Some older versions read, ‘It pleased the Lord to crush him. This does not mean that God got some kind of joyful pleasure in seeing his son suffering. But it does mean that when God saw the outcome and the results of Jesus’ suffering, it brought him great joy and pleasure. I love how the NLT says that Jesus will receive the honour of a victorious solider. He has won the battle, he has defeated the enemy and he will see many counted righteous and will be satisfied. Sometimes the pain to victory can be much greater than the pain of defeat.

What can we learn from this passage?

We need to be a people who are continually ‘BEHOLDING JESUS.’

We need to discover the holy wisdom of total surrender to the will of God.

We must not confuse our status with our appearance. How we are seen by God should define us, not how we are seen by others.

Rejection is an inevitable pain that will be part of everyone's life, but we must not allow the pain of rejection drive us into becoming those who live to please ourselves or others.

We must become people who are shaped and defined by the extravagance of agape love.

We need to be continually focusing on entrusting our lives to God.

The end of the story has been written and it is very, very good.

Father thank you for the great victory of Jesus over Satan, sin and death.

title: Isaiah 52:13-53:12

html:
The context of the story Jesus is speaking about is the destruction of the temple. Spiritual abuse was so ingrained into the life of the temple that it had become normalized and acceptable. That the only thing that could be done was the complete destruction of the temple. Jesus saw this poor widow as a victim of the religious system.

Sadly many churches and congregations echo the temple way of life. Their is an acceptance or even an encouragement of abusive practices. These may be more covert that overt. They may not be as blatant as the story of this widow, but they are just as wrong and evil.

Any church that survives of spiritual abuse or normalizes the practice of spiritual abuse needs to be destroyed. Jesus tells us that ‘she gave every thing she had to live on.’ The temple authorities should had been giving to this widow not taking from her.

Try and think about the thought process that made poor widow think that God wanted her last penny ‘the shirt of her back’ What kind of understanding did she have of God? Did she wrongly view God as a kind of cruel ‘money lender, she needed to pay back? God has no time for a prosperity gospel nor has he any time for an abusive gospel that robs the poor and the vulnerable. Their are two things worth noting what happen after this incident is recorded. 1. Jesus never went back to the temple. 2. He immediately goes on to speak about the destruction of the temple, I wounder why!

Sometimes we need to sit back and examine our church and congregational lives to see if any abusive ways have slipped in.

Father may I never be the cause of spiritual abuse.

study_refs: It is very disturbing how this story has been used over the years. The traditional understanding is that Jesus is using the story of this poor widow as an example and encouragement of sacrificial living. This misuse of this story has deflected people from Jesus’ original intent. It is true that Jesus is using this widow as an example, but not the kind of example we may think. This widow is an example of someone who was being spiritually abused by a religious system.
